(Flix) AMÉLIE (2001) Audrey Tautou, above, in her breakthrough role, plays a French sprite working as a waitress who lays out elaborate practical jokes as payback for those who offend her friends. When she falls in love with Nino (Mathieu Kassovitz), Amélie finds herself incapable of revealing her feelings and instead turns Paris, recreated through sets and computer-generated imagery, into a kind of treasure hunt as she leaves clues about her identity, and he trails after her. headline: Short-Selling of Banco Espírito Santo Briefly Banned
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Short Selling', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: An audit in May by the Bank of Portugal found that the lender’s parent company was in “serious financial condition” and had “irregularities” in its accounts, putting pressure on Banco Espírito Santo’s stock.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Securities regulators in Portugal and Britain have temporarily banned short-selling in Banco Espírito Santo after the Portuguese lender’s stock fell more than 16 percent on Monday on fears about its corporate parent.

headline: How Would Chuck Norris Vote?
abstract: These days, you simply never know which ridiculous celebrity testimonial is going to work.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve learned through football that strong leadership can be the difference between winning and losing,” Brett Favre said, leaning on the bed of a dirt-crusted utility vehicle in the middle of some lush green field. Favre, who now sports a Gandalf-style beard, could have been taping a Viagra commercial, or maybe one of his usual spots for Wrangler jeans. Instead, the retired N.F.L. gunslinger had been called into another arena. “When it comes to our state’s future, trust me,” said Favre, the pride of Kiln, Miss., in an ad paid for by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. “Mississippi can win and win big with Thad Cochran as our strong voice in Washington.”

headline: Falling for the Photo in Staten Island
abstract: In 1962, a daring and ambitious young photographer met his match between the towers of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
lead_paragraph: “O.K. You sure you want to do this? Can you use this? Let me give you some background. You follow?”

headline: French Ex-Leader Questioned in Graft Inquiry, Imperiling Comeback Hopes
abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former leader, has been under scrutiny for possible financial irregularities in his 2007 campaign and for other alleged offenses.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, was detained Tuesday for questioning by French anticorruption investigators, a serious new turn in a blossoming criminal inquiry that threatens his hopes of a political comeback.

headline: BNP Paribas Is Confident It Can Absorb the Blow of a Record Fine
abstract: After admitting sanctions violations, shares in BNP Paribas rose more than 4 percent on Tuesday after the bank said it would offer the same dividend as last year – 1.50 euros a share, or about $2.05.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A day after their bank was handed a record penalty by the United States authorities for violating sanctions laws, officials at BNP Paribas struck a confident note on Tuesday about the bank’s future, insisting it would be able to continue meeting the needs of most customers and had “ample” capital to absorb an $8.9 billion fine.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: U.S.A. and Belgium: A Long-Running Battle for Supremacy Continues
abstract: As the two countries meet on the field in the World Cup, here’s a good-natured look at other ways they have engaged in competition.
lead_paragraph: Belgium and the United States are preparing to face off Tuesday in Salvador, Brazil, in the World Cup, but few realize just how many battles for supremacy these two nations have already fought, in and out of the sports world. Despite a population gap of more than 290 million, Belgians and Americans have proved to be worthy adversaries.

headline: New York Today: Belgians Among Us
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: World Cup waffles, hot weather, and a new twist in a cannibalism case.
lead_paragraph: Happy Tuesday morning to you on this first of July.

headline: Modest Euro Zone Growth Fails to Dent Unemployment Rate
abstract: The jobless rate in the 18-nation bloc was 11.6 percent in May, unchanged from the revised rate for April, with 18.6 million out of work, data showed.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The unemployment rate in the euro zone remained close to a high in May, according to official data released on Tuesday, a reminder that despite modest growth, the recession has never ended for millions of Europeans.

headline: Putin Warns Again of Force as Ukraine Fighting Spreads
abstract: Fighting resumed in the east early Tuesday, including artillery shelling around the rebel-controlled city of Slovyansk, after President Petro O. Poroshenko ended a 10-day cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The simmering standoff in eastern Ukraine exploded into warfare early Tuesday, pushing the conflict to a dangerous new phase and prompting President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to warn again that he reserves the right to use force to defend Russian-speaking citizens.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on immigration reform, corporate convictions, Argentine debt and Facebook experiments.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times echoes President Obama in urging legislators to pass comprehensive immigration reform. But on Monday, he said the federal government needed “additional authority to exercise discretion.” The editorial board asks: Does the President intend “to change the law that requires such children be given an adequate chance to have their cases heard in immigration court”? The law, enacted by the Bush administration, “recognizes that many unaccompanied minors are likely to be refugees or victims of human trafficking who need legal and humanitarian help. It also protects them from summary deportation and requires that the Border Patrol turn them over to a refugee resettlement office and, where appropriate, to the care of parents or other relatives living in the United States.” The Times believes “weakening those protections in a misguided effort to discourage new migrants would be a terrible outcome.”

headline: Housing: Small Economic Sector With a Big Impact
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Residential investment is crucial to understanding the ups and downs of economic cycles, but too often it has been an afterthought for policy makers.
lead_paragraph: Housing is a pretty tiny part of the economy. But housing also plays an enormous role in creating economic booms and busts. This is one of the most important paradoxes of how the economy works that policy makers are only now starting to grapple with adequately.

headline: 1969: A Warning on Global Warming
abstract: In a year full of man-made conflagrations came the first use of a term with the potential to make those hot spots look like campfires in comparison — global warming.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: When Data Can Do More Harm Than Good
abstract: A business owner whose business is all about data says there are times when it’s better to ignore the data.
lead_paragraph: At RJMetrics, data is king. We’ve built our business around the belief that data-driven decisions are better decisions, and we’ve made it our mission to inspire and empower data driven people. But having such a deep love affair with data can be a dangerous game. The truth is that, even for companies like ours, using data is not always the best path. In fact, sometimes data can do more harm than good.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Tech Spending Projections
abstract: It’s something of a ritual: On Monday, an analyst firm lowered its projection for information technology spending. Gartner’s projection change isn’t about economic weakness, however, but the tech we’re using, and how we use it.
lead_paragraph: Summer is flying by – Gartner has already trimmed its annual projections for worldwide information technology spending.

headline: Obama and Iraq
abstract: Republicans do not agree with President Obama’s policies in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Republicans do not agree with President Obama’s policies in Iraq.

headline: 1939: Joliot Seeks Uranium Advance
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A Frenchman tries to unlock atomic power in 1939.
lead_paragraph: Frédéric Joliot, co-winner of the 1935 Nobel Prize in chemistry, is trying to find a way to make a $2 pound of uranium give up as much heat or power as is now obtained from burning $10,000 worth of coal. Joliot is working independently of his wife, Irene Joliot Curie, with whom he was given the 1935 Nobel award. She is the daughter of Pierre and Marie Curie, discoverers of radium. If scientists can find practicable means to set up uranium chain reactions, then it is estimated that it may be possible to obtain from one pound of uranium as much energy as is at present obtained from 1,250 tons of coal. — New York Herald Tribune, July 2, 1939.

headline: A Closer Look at Simplifying Financial Aid Applications
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Concerns that ignoring assets would result in families with low income but high wealth getting aid are valid, but it is the lesser of two evils.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, making something simple raises a lot of fears.

headline: Sparse Turnout at Pro-China Rally in Hong Kong
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Two people who turned out for a pro-Beijing rally in Hong Kong said they were paid to attend the event.
lead_paragraph: While tens of thousands of people converged on Hong Kong’s Victoria Park for an annual protest march, Ali Hassan, Usman Zahid and their colleagues quietly passed out plastic Chinese and Hong Kong flags at a pro-establishment rally across the harbor.

headline: A Trail of Clues Leading to Victims and Heartbreak
abstract: The first clues that led to the grisly discovery of the bodies of three missing Israeli teenagers came only hours after their abduction in the West Bank was reported.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — One suspect took 10 years to complete a college degree in Shariah law, according to relatives, because his studies kept being interrupted by stints in Israeli prison. The other quit school at 13, has been in poor health since a swimming accident put him in a coma in 2007, and has worked as a blacksmith, a porter, and a clothes salesman, several people who know him said.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Road to BNP’s Guilty Plea
abstract: BNP’s guilty plea is the culmination of a long investigation into some of the world’s top banks. | Walgreen is looking to move abroad in a so-called inversion. | Who won the Bitcoin auction? | A group of New York hedge funds have backed Argentina into a corner.
lead_paragraph: State and federal authorities announced a criminal case against BNP Paribas on Monday for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. BNP’s agreement to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty ends months of arm-twisting by French officials. It is also the culmination of a long investigation into some of the world’s top banks, which began with a bus bombing two decades ago and a grieving New Jersey father’s quest for justice, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess write in DealBook.

headline: Seamy World of the Tabloid, Bared
abstract: “Great Britain,” Richard Bean’s satire about the phone-hacking scandal that brought down a newspaper, opened on Monday night at the National Theater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Which one is she? Where is the woman we have gathered here to see pilloried? Where is, you know, Rebekah Brooks?

headline: What’s News in Washington: The Politics of Women
abstract: The Supreme Court’s Hobby Lobby ruling has already raised the possibility of new legislation from Democrats in Congress and more executive action from President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington.

headline: Sotheby’s to Auction Mellon’s Treasures
abstract: On Tuesday, Sotheby’s announced that it would auction contents from the estate of Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny, who died in March.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Rachel Lambert Mellon died in March at the age of 103, the art world has been wondering what would become of the vast treasures of art and objects that she and her husband, Paul Mellon, had collected and lived with.

headline: In Performance: Benjamin Scheuer of ‘The Lion’
abstract: The composer and musician sings a number from his coming-of-age solo musical about losing his father at 13.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the composer and musician Benjamin Scheuer singing the number “Cookie-tin Banjo” from “The Lion,” his coming-of-age solo show about his relationship with his father, who died when Benjamin was 13. In the song Mr. Scheuer remembers how his love of music was inspired by a “simple homemade toy” crafted for him by his father. Directed by Sean Daniels for Manhattan Theater Club, “The Lion” continues through July 13 at City Center’s Studio II.

headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Recap: Of White Girls and Privilege
abstract: Piper gets the red carpet treatment, at least by Litchfield standards.
lead_paragraph: Season 2, Episode 8 It’s all about privilege in this episode — who benefits and who doesn’t — and it should surprise none of us at this point in the story (or history?) that our white heroine from Connecticut is the chief recipient. Piper gets her furlough after Healy makes some calls. Harder to judge is whether we’re supposed to be annoyed by her going on about her grandmother. (As I was – am I alone?)

headline: When Spell-Check Can’t Help
abstract: A couple of sound-alike mix-ups that we’ve stumbled over before, and a reminder that striving for polish and precision means taking care of the small stuff.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few more sound-alike mix-ups, all of which we’ve stumbled over before. Put them on your watch list:

headline: Japan Announces a Military Shift to Thwart China
abstract: The Japanese prime minister announced that his government would reinterpret the antiwar Constitution to allow the armed forces to come to the aid of friendly nations.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s prime minister announced a reinterpretation of the country’s pacifist Constitution on Tuesday, freeing its military for the first time in over 60 years to play a more assertive role in the increasingly tense region.

headline: In Testimony, Agent Calls Pistorius Caring
abstract: The track star’s agent said that Oscar Pistorius and his girlfriend had a strong relationship and that he did not intend to kill her.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A close associate of Oscar Pistorius said at his murder trial on Tuesday that, even on the night before the athlete killed his girlfriend, he was arranging for them to fly together — in business class — to a track meet in England as part of a series of trips abroad to show her “his world.”

headline: Limping in Solidarity and Leaping for Joy
abstract: Tanztheater Wuppertal brings “Palermo Palermo” to the Théâtre de la Ville, and Alexei Ratmansky’s “Psyché” returns to the Palais Garnier.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — There’s never a busier time for dance in France than the end of June and early July, with the Paris Opera Ballet at the Palais Garnier, the Tanztheater Wuppertal (for the past 35 years) at the Théâtre de la Ville, the Montpellier Danse Festival in that city, and numerous other festivals on the horizon. But this year’s cornucopia has been marred by strikes and rumblings over government cuts in unemployment benefits for some performers and technicians working in the arts.

headline: Turkish Premier Runs for President, an Office He Plans to Strengthen
abstract: The post, until now largely ceremonial, could become much more important under Mr. Erdogan, who has held power for a decade.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced Tuesday that he would run for Turkey’s presidency in elections next month, a move that is likely to position him as the country’s dominant political figure for years to come.

headline: European Union Reduces Cellphone Roaming Charges
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The move is part of plans to transform the bloc’s telecommunications infrastructure from one based on national borders into a pan-regional network.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Union on Tuesday cut cellphone roaming charges across the region by as much as 50 percent in the latest move to revamp how people communicate across the 28-country bloc.

headline: The Biological Grandparent Trap
abstract: I’m thrilled that my parents are so excited about Tori and Kelly’s baby, but I’m the sperm donor, and not the person raising this baby. I’m working to manage their expectations.
lead_paragraph: As someone who has never planned on having children, I’ve always counted on my straight brothers to be the ones to provide my parents with grandchildren. Unfortunately, they’ve shown no greater enthusiasm at the prospect of having children than I have. But I figure at least one of them is bound to have a happy accident eventually, right?

headline: French Ban on Face Veils Upheld by European Rights Court
abstract: The Strasbourg-based tribunal said that the ban on wearing the head covering in public did not violate Muslims’ religious liberty.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a ban imposed by France on the wearing of face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms and bolstering opponents of strict Islamic dress in other parts of Europe.

headline: Longevity Insurance Joins the Menu of Retirement Plan Options
abstract: New tax rules will allow workers to spend a lump sum of their retirement savings in exchange for a guaranteed income in their later years.
lead_paragraph: New tax rules will make it possible for workers to buy a type of annuity often called longevity insurance inside their retirement plans. The annuity aims to protect people from exhausting their savings in their later years.

headline: An Art Review in the Subway
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young freelance illustrator got a lift when a stranger exiting the subway dropped an enthusiastic review in her lap.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Cameroon Investigates Match-Fixing Charges
abstract: Cameroon’s soccer federation said late Monday that it would pay particular attention to a heavy defeat to Croatia in the opening round.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The plight of African teams at the World Cup has not subsided even after they all have been eliminated. Cameroon’s soccer federation announced late Monday that it would investigate its team for possible match fixing, paying particular attention to a lopsided loss to Croatia in the opening round.

headline: By Design | Just North of Paris, A New Concept Store Where Everything Is White
abstract: Located amidst the Saint Ouen flea markets, Le White sells snowy-hued objects by emerging French designers and artists.
lead_paragraph: Just north of Paris, amidst the sprawling antiques bazaar of the Saint-Ouen flea markets, a burgeoning community of contemporary design and fashion outposts is drawing the attention of the weekend shopping crowd. Within the last two years, Rue des Rosiers, the area’s main thoroughfare, has seen the arrivals of Ma Cocotte (a Philippe Starck-designed restaurant), Habitat 1964 (a midcentury-focused spinoff of the Terence Conran-founded housewares chain) and L’Éclaireur (the multibrand men’s and women’s boutique). The latest addition to the street, located within a quiet courtyard in a space that once belonged to one of Jacques Cousteau’s sons, is a minimalist new concept store that looks the way its name suggests: Le White.

headline: Lazy, Hazy Days of Celebration
abstract: The Times Insider puzzles are sizzling this month.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — Welcome to the July 2014 Times Premier Puzzle Pack. It’s the height of summer, and not only are we enjoying the warm weather, but we also celebrate our Independence Day this month. Bring your colored pencils as we pay tribute to a special symbol.

headline: After Aereo
abstract: Companies are already selling devices that allow people to capture over-the-air TV signals for private use.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court ruled last week that Aereo violated copyright law by retransmitting over-the-air TV signals and selling the content to its customers, broadcast networks celebrated the decision as a major victory. Meanwhile executives at Aereo lamented the decision as a “massive setback”—not just for its business but also for the entire technology industry.

headline: Are Categories Like Immigrant Fiction and ‘New American’ Fiction Valid or Worthwhile?
abstract: Pankaj Mishra and Francine Prose discuss whether categories like immigrant fiction are useful or meaningful labels.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Pankaj Mishra and Francine Prose discuss whether categories like immigrant fiction are useful or meaningful labels.

headline: Chronicler Recalls a Bridge’s Rising, 50 Years Later
abstract: Before the current Tappan Zee project, there was the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, which opened in 1964; Gay Talese talked about covering that construction.
lead_paragraph: On windy days, ironworkers clambered up catwalks, linked the 60 garage-size steel segments that made up the bridge deck, and tiptoed atop the bridge’s 70-story towers at the risk of their lives. Three men were killed in falls during the construction. The workers or their bosses bore names like Hard-Nosed Murphy and Drag-Up Drilling. One crane operator in a steelyard was James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion from 1935 to 1937, when he lost the crown to Joe Louis.

headline: Scenes of Protest in Hong Kong
abstract: In what may be the biggest demonstration in a decade, hundreds of thousands of people marched in Hong Kong to demand greater democracy.
lead_paragraph: In what may be the biggest demonstration in a decade, hundreds of thousands of people marched in Hong Kong to demand greater democracy.

headline: An Even More Nuanced Breakdown of the Supreme Court
abstract: Analyzing, and representing visually, how often each justice disagreed with each other justice yields some surprising patterns.
lead_paragraph: Last week, my colleagues Adam Liptak and Hannah Fairfield wrote about the divisions among Supreme Court justices. In showing the justices on a spectrum from more to less liberal, they found “a series of clusters, a few loners and several telling gaps,” not a steady progression from left to right.

headline: Twitter Names Ex-Goldman Banker Anthony Noto as Chief Financial Officer
abstract: The social media giant has shuffled its top ranks once again, appointing a well-known technology banker from Goldman Sachs to its executive team.
lead_paragraph: Updated with details on compensation package.

headline: Amanda Knox Co-Defendant Changes Strategy
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Raffaele Sollecito is using an alleged confession by Amanda Knox to argue he is innocent of killing a student in Italy in 2007.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In the long-running courtroom drama of the Amanda Knox case, her co-defendant and former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, was relegated by the news media to a minor role, eclipsed by the attention focused on Ms. Knox, a pretty 21-year-old American who captured the public spotlight.

headline: Big Bowl With Spicy Brown Bean, Squash and Corn Succotash
abstract: This version of succotash is lima-bean-free, with a kick that is a lively contrast to the sweet corn.
lead_paragraph: If you have a problem liking succotash, it’s probably because of the lima beans, which have a mealy consistency that is not to everybody’s taste. What’s not to like, though, if you use another bean? Pintos or borlottis are great, and Good Mother Stallards from Rancho Gordo are luxurious. This succotash has some spice to it, a nice contrast to the sweet corn. Make sure to hold onto the bean broth. I like bulgur with this, but any grain will work.

headline: G.M. Sales Rise as Buyers Ignore Recalls
abstract: The automaker reported a rare bit of good news on Tuesday, with sales up 1 percent, and said its annual selling rate remained in line with its forecast.
lead_paragraph: It has been a mystery in the auto industry in recent months: How can General Motors, embroiled in a safety crisis that has led to the recall of about 29 million vehicles worldwide this year, continue to have such strong sales?

headline: Ruling in Cannibal Case Revives Debate Over When a Fantasy Crosses a Criminal Line
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Overturning the 2013 conviction of a former New York City police officer accused of conspiring to kidnap, kill and eat women, a judge said the case reflected “the Internet age in which we live.”
lead_paragraph: In his mind and online persona, Gilberto Valle left little doubt about the depths of his depravation: In communications over the Internet, he imagined subjecting women he knew to sex-related torture and, in some cases, murder and cannibalism.

headline: Online, the Lying Is Easy
abstract: Charles Seife’s “Virtual Unreality” covers Internet hazards from sock puppets to bimbots.
lead_paragraph: Charles Seife is a pop historian who writes about mathematics and science, but his abiding theme, the topic that makes his heart leap like one of Jules Feiffer’s dancers in the springtime, is human credulity.

headline: Learned Macroeconomic Helplessness
abstract: We had the tools and the knowledge, but refused to use them.
lead_paragraph: One of the oddest, most frustrating things about the six years plus since the Great Recession began is the incessant whining from pundits that it’s all very complicated, and nobody knows what to do. As Dean Baker says, the story of this slump is remarkably simple; I would give more role to household debt than he does, but basically yes, it’s a huge slump in housing. Here’s residential investment as a percentage of GDP:

headline: Two-Bean and Tuna Salad
abstract: This is the most amazing version of tuna and bean salad I’ve ever tasted, thanks to Good Mother Stallard beans.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always had a weakness for tuna and bean salad. This one, because I used luxurious Good Mother Stallard beans from Rancho Gordo, is quite the most amazing version of the salad I’ve ever tasted. If you want to use a more commonly available bean for it, use pintos or borlottis, but cook them yourself instead of using canned. Then you can use some of the broth in the dressing and the beans themselves will taste better because you’re in control of the seasonings. The nutritional values here are based on tuna canned in water, but you could always use tuna in olive oil for a richer version.

headline: 1964: Luebke Is Re-elected in Berlin
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Heinrich Luebke is re-elected in West Germany in 1964.
lead_paragraph: BONN — Heinrich Luebke, 69, was overwhelmingly elected today [July 1] to a second five-year term as president of West Germany. The outcome was never in doubt because the former cabinet minister had been endorsed by both major parties, the ruling Christian Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats. The election, held in West Berlin despite strong Soviet and East German objections, reaffirmed West Germany’s insistence that the divided city is the real capital of Germany and some day will serve as such for a reunited nation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 2, 1964.

headline: Tostadas With Smashed Black Beans or Vaqueros, Salsa Fresca and Avocado
abstract: Refried heirloom vaquero beans add a special touch to these tostadas, but black beans work, too.
lead_paragraph: I have always had a weakness for black bean tostadas. These are not unlike Oaxacan tlayudas, though this recipe doesn’t call for that dish’s signature extra-large corn tortillas. I used luxurious black and white vaqueros from Rancho Gordo for these, but black beans will also work well. Cook them yourself (don’t use canned), because you’ll need the delicious broth. I don’t refry them for as long as I normally would because I like them moist, and vaqueros are starchier than black beans.

headline: G.O.P. Power Broker in Albany Accused of Lying to F.B.I.
abstract: Thomas W. Libous, the State Senate’s second-highest-ranking Republican and an ally of the governor, was indicted along with his son, who was accused of filing false tax returns.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Thomas W. Libous is a natural in Albany’s clubby corridors, a world away from the family grocery store in Binghamton, N.Y., where he worked growing up.

headline: Argentina vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Lionel Messi has four goals. The Swiss gave up just six goals in 10 qualifying matches; they have given up six in just three games at the Cup. More Messi goals to come?
lead_paragraph: Lionel Messi is tied for the Golden Boot with four goals. The Swiss gave up just six goals in 10 qualifying matches; they have given up six in just three games at the Cup. More Messi goals to come?

headline: Teenager Topples Top-Ranked Nadal in Round of 16
abstract: Nick Kyrgios, a 19-year-old wild-card entrant from Australia, advanced to the quarterfinals, as did Roger Federer, who beat Tommy Robredo and will next play Stan Wawrinka.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Until the evening shadows fell on Centre Court on Tuesday, the last time a teenager beat a No. 1 player at a men’s Grand Slam event was at the 2005 French Open. The winner then was Rafael Nadal, over Roger Federer, days after Nadal’s 19th birthday.

headline: I Am the Real Nick Cave
abstract: He has been a punk rocker, a neo-Faulknerian novelist, a screenwriter and a balladeer. Next, Cave plays the semireluctant star of a staged documentary about his life.
lead_paragraph: “I went to Graceland once,” Nick Cave said. “The rest of the band went in, but I stayed out on the curb, smoking cigarettes and feeling sorry for myself. Those last Elvis performances — the ones for television, when he was already sick — I must have watched those clips a hundred times. They’re like crucifixions.” He paused for a moment. “I couldn’t bring myself to go inside.”

headline: In Store | A.P.C. Sets Up Shop at the Wythe Hotel
abstract: Beginning today, the French retailer fills the Williamsburg hot spot’s boutique with its signature denim, home items designed in collaboration with Jessica Ogden and a slew of travel-friendly wares.
lead_paragraph: The Wythe Hotel has established itself as more than a place to stay in Williamsburg. Last month, it set up a chapel on the roof, where gay couples were married over the weekend during New York’s Pride Week. And of course there’s the location’s shop, whose wares change every several months and are usually curated by a local designer or brand. Beginning today, however, the Brooklyn boutique will open the doors to an assortment curated by its first international retailer: the French brand A.P.C.

headline: Arugula and Corn Salad With Roasted Red Peppers and White Bean
abstract: Canned beans can also be used in this composed salad with a base of sweet corn and pungent arugula.
lead_paragraph: Since you don’t need a broth for this composed salad, canned beans will work, though I always prefer the flavor of beans I’ve cooked myself. I like to use a white bean, either a cannellini or a navy bean. I’ve always loved sweet corn with pungent arugula. I combine the two for a salad bed, which I top with the roasted peppers and beans. So the dish is really two salads, one on top of the other.

headline: New York Summer Stories: Getting Out of Town
abstract: The New York Times is sharing stories that tell the tales of city summers across the decades during the next week. Today’s theme: escaping the city heat.
lead_paragraph: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archive that tell tales of New York City summers past.

headline: Facebook Flunks Its Apology
abstract: A linguist who studies apologies analyzes Facebook’s mea culpa for experimenting on its users’ feelings, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: “Ok so,” begins Adam D.I. Kramer’s apology for Facebook’s recent experiment on its users’ feelings. Mr. Kramer, a data scientist at Facebook, went on to explain the experiment in greater detail (Facebook altered some users’ news feeds, then analyzed the emotional content of their later posts) and to say, “my coauthors and I are very sorry for the way the paper described the research and any anxiety it caused.”

headline: World Cup 2014: Penalty Kick Strategy
abstract: Midfielder Kyle Beckerman demonstrates his penalty kick strategy, which he says is all about trusting yourself. On the other side of the ball, goalkeeper Nick Rimando says he aims to react, not guess.

According to The Post, the N.S.A. can “intercept through U.S. companies not just the communications of its overseas targets but any communications about its targets as well.”

headline: Who’s a ‘Christian’? Avoiding Labels in the Hobby Lobby Coverage
abstract: Readers object to a shorthand description of religious beliefs in Supreme Court coverage.
lead_paragraph: I heard from several thoughtful readers who object to The Times’s description of the owners of two companies in the news because of a major Supreme Court decision on Monday. (The companies are Hobby Lobby and Conestoga Wood Specialties.) That decision said that requiring such family-owned corporations to pay for insurance covering birth control was a violation of federal law protecting religious freedom.

headline: Penalties for Companies, but Executives Often Emerge Unscathed
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: The notion of the rogue employee is a convenient one, allowing senior management to admit to corporate misconduct while avoiding personal responsibility for violations, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Before BNP Paribas pleaded guilty to violating United States economic sanctions laws, the bank’s chief executive, Jean-Laurent Bonnafé, said in a message to employees that “malfunctions have occurred and mistakes were made.” It was much more than that, costing to the bank nearly $9 billion. But even then, the misconduct leading to that kind of penalty did not result in criminal charges against any individuals.

headline: Flame Retardants Are Everywhere
abstract: Flame retardants, widely used in furniture, bedding and clothing, have been found in a multitude of places, from breast milk to Antarctic penguins. Some of these chemicals are suspected carcinogens, but experts are unsure how their ubiquity will affect human health..
lead_paragraph: Just over 10 years ago, Dr. Arnold Schecter, a public health researcher in Texas, started finding traces of chemical flame retardants in the breast milk of American women. It appeared that the compounds were carried into the milk from fat in the mothers’ bodies.

lead_paragraph: Imagine yourself in a bar where a pickpocket takes money out of your wallet and with it buys you a glass of chardonnay. Although you would have preferred a pinot noir, you decide not to look that gift horse in the mouth and thank the stranger profusely for the kindness, assuming he paid for it. You might feel differently, of course, if you knew that you actually had paid for it yourself.

headline: Orwell Birthplace in India to Become a Museum
abstract: The bungalo where George Orwell was born, in what is now Motihari, India, is being restored.
lead_paragraph: The ramshackle three-room bungalow in Motihari, India where George Orwell was born in 1903 is being restored and transformed into a museum that will celebrate the life and career of the essayist and author, The Times of India reported. The renovation, which has been under discussion since 2010, when the house was declared a protected site, is being underwritten by the government of Bihar state, which is hoping the museum will become a tourist attraction. Motihari is in northeastern India, near the border of Nepal. Orwell, who was born Eric Arthur Blair, was born there while his father, Richard Blair, was posted in Bihar as an employee of the Indian Civil Service, to supervise the production of opium for export to China.

headline: Bonus All-World-Cup Ethicist Column!

lead_paragraph: In his most recent Ethicist column, Chuck Klosterman weighed in on whether it’s wrong to mention the result of a World Cup match in front of a friend who you know has recorded the game to watch later. We realized that this was just one of many fascinating questions raised by all the flopping, biting and cheering that’s been going on since June 12. We asked what other ethical questions you had about the World Cup, and you submitted some great ones via Facebook, Twitter and email. Read Klosterman’s responses in this week’s bonus column.

It is the fifth installment of the postal service’s Music Icons series, which also includes Johnny Cash, the Tejana star Lydia Mendoza and Ray Charles, all issued in 2013, and Jimi Hendrix, whose stamp was issued in March.

headline: A Straw Purchaser Goes to Jail

He also wounded an off duty police officer who was driving by. In the hours that followed, shots were exchanged with police, seven houses burned down and Mr. Spengler shot and killed himself. In the burnt debris of his home, police later found the remains of his 67-year old sister, Cheryl, whom he also had shot and killed.

abstract: What middle-class Republicans and urban liberals have in common.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Civil Rights Act of 1964, which banned discrimination in public accommodations, employment and federally funded activities like education, would not have passed without the support of House and Senate Republicans who were competing for black votes. And Presidents Kennedy and Johnson would not have advocated for the bill without being pressured to do so by a multiracial grass-roots movement.

headline: The Ukrainian Crisis Reaches a New Level
abstract: In ending the cease-fire with separatists and resuming attacks, the nation’s president took the conflict to a dangerous but inevitable level.
lead_paragraph: President Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine took the fateful step late Monday of ending his unilateral cease-fire in the struggle with separatists in eastern Ukraine, declaring: “We will attack and liberate our land.” The attacks began shortly after, moving the Ukrainian crisis to a highly dangerous but unavoidable level. Dangerous because Ukrainian forces are woefully ill-equipped and ill-trained to fight what is essentially a civil war, in which Ukrainian civilians are bound to be casualties; unavoidable because neither the rebels nor Russia ever took seriously the negotiations with Kiev and Western mediators. In effect, the long-building showdown has begun, and it is essential for the West to shed any illusions about what is at stake.

headline: Give Scotusblog a Seat in Court

lead_paragraph: At a few minutes past 10 a.m. on Monday, as the Supreme Court began to issue the final rulings of the term, 60,000 people — including journalists at major news outlets around the country — were following the live feed of Scotusblog, a website devoted to covering every warp and woof of the court’s complex litigation. Since its inception in 2002, the site has become required reading for Supreme Court news and analysis, winning multiple awards.

lead_paragraph: KETCHUM, Idaho — In 2003, the year he turned 17, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl left his mark on the wet cement floor of the Strega Tea Bar Gallery and Cafe, a swirling design signed with a florid “B.” The drawing is a lasting statement that this liberal-tinctured ski resort town, where he took ballet and fencing lessons, met artists and debated philosophy, had become his second home.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Plan to Fight AIDS in New York
abstract: The ambitious measures aim to reduce new H.I.V. infections to about 750 a year by 2020 from the current 3,000, but more financing is needed.
lead_paragraph: New York City was ravaged by AIDS after the first cases were reported more than 30 years ago, and the plague soared to about 14,000 new cases in the state and nearly 8,000 deaths a year in the city in the early 1990s. Since then, medication and prevention programs have lowered new infections with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, to about 3,000 a year and far fewer deaths. Now Gov. Andrew Cuomo has announced that he wants New York to reduce new infections to 750 by 2020, about the same as the number of new tuberculosis cases each year.

If implemented properly, the plan could speed payments to victims and their families, some of whom have waited years for G.M. to even acknowledge the defect, without forcing them to sue the company.

headline: People of Influence
abstract: The future of Ukraine is now in the hands of its own people.

The Guardian reported on Sunday that Ukrainians have crowdfunded the first “people’s drone” to help their army stem infiltration by Russian-supported rebels in Ukraine’s eastern provinces that border Russia. “Last week, Ukraine’s crowdfunding site ‘The People’s Project’ said that it had received enough donations to fund a drone,” The Guardian reported. “The organizers had originally hoped to buy a state-of-the-art Israeli drone — for $165,000 — or a cheaper American one costing $120,000. In the end, however, they managed to build the drone for just $35,000. A designer and other volunteers built the airframe, with a Ukrainian military institute chipping in technical equipment.”

headline: France: European Rights Court Upholds French Ban on Veils
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a French ban on wearing face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms.
lead_paragraph: The European Court of Human Rights has upheld a French ban on wearing face-covering veils in public, rejecting arguments that the measure violates religious freedoms and bolstering opponents of strict Islamic dress in other parts of Europe. The ban, which took effect three years ago, set French authorities on a collision course with conservative Muslims who said the wearing of such veils by women was an obligation of their faith. Judges at the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, said Tuesday that the ban was a legitimate attempt to preserve the norms of France’s diverse society and that it did not infringe on Europe’s Convention on Human Rights. The court was ruling on a case brought by an unidentified Frenchwoman who said the law was discriminatory and violated her freedom of conscience. The 24-year-old woman, a college graduate, requested anonymity for fear of reprisals if her identity became known. France was the first country in Europe to enact such a ban, followed by Belgium.

headline: The Light and Luxurious Look for the Fourth of July
abstract: The explosion of fireworks in the night sky on Friday will provide just the right backdrop for these neutral pieces.
lead_paragraph: Dressing for the Fourth of July, it’s easy to get lost in the red-white-and-blue stars and stripes mindset, or wrapped up in the sea of colorful summery prints. But opting for a few simple, neutral pieces with subtle graphic touches will keep things light and luxurious, and make for more of a statement this weekend against the backdrop of star-spangled fireworks. A tame terry cloth cape from Lisa Marie Fernandez adds drama when layered over simple swimsuits, like this maillot from Eres. Calm separates and accessories — two-toned sandals, a basic tote — round out a minimalist look. And an oversize but understated piece of jewelry, like this cuff from Céline, is just enough to pull it all together.

headline: In the Hills of Mexico, Patrón Processes Agave the Old-School Way
abstract: The company, which just introduced a new line of tequilas this month, takes T on a tour of its fields and distillery.
lead_paragraph: Patrón Spirits International distills small batches of premium tequila and tequila-based liquors at its rambling hacienda in Atotonilco, a small town in Mexico’s hilly Jalisco region that’s crawling with Weber Blue agave, a key ingredient for the local tequila industry there. Since 1989, the company’s co-founders, Martin Crowly and John Paul DeJoria (of John Paul Mitchell Systems Hair Care Company), and its master distiller, Francisco Alcaraz, have crafted high-end tipples like the amber-tinted Patrón Añejo that today are distributed to 120 countries around the world. Recently, they opened the doors to the Hacienda de Patrón distillery, erected in 2002 and closed to the public ever since, for a behind-the-scenes look at how its small-batch products are made, including a new range of 100 percent agave tequilas being released this month.

headline: What’s on Wednesday

lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (FX Movie Channel) THE CURIOUS CASE OF BENJAMIN BUTTON (2008) Brad Pitt received an Oscar nomination for his portrayal of Benjamin Button, a man born in his 80s in 1918 New Orleans, who ages in reverse into the 21st century, in this adaptation of a short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald. Cate Blanchett, above with Mr. Pitt, is Daisy, the dancer who loves Benjamin at whatever stage he is in. And Taraji P. Henson, who was also nominated, is the nursing home caretaker who raises him when his father abandons him. From Fitzgerald’s “odd, somewhat unpromising kernel, the director David Fincher and the screenwriter Eric Roth have cultivated a lush, romantic hothouse bloom, a film that shares only a title and a basic premise with its literary source,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that the film “sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist’s condition in a spirit that owes more to Jorge Luis Borges than to Fitzgerald.”

headline: War’s Lingering Requiem in Vietnam

headline: Feeling For | A Home Scenter That Design Aesthetes Can Appreciate
abstract: A new one-of-a-kind trio of wooden sculptures by the natural perfumer Haley Alexander van Oosten were inspired by an architect’s home and come at an art-gallery price.
lead_paragraph: For those who consider fragrance an invisible form of art, the olfactive medium has suddenly become much more visible these days, with an influx of objets d’art dedicated to perfuming the air. Now on display at Commune Design in Los Angeles: a rather rare trio of wooden “scenters” designed by the natural perfumer Haley Alexander van Oosten, the nose behind L’Oeil Du Vert. Crafted from vintage Douglas fir and redwood sourced from furniture makers and local dealers, each piece is entirely unique (as noted by the organic knots and cracks in the grain) and fastened with bronze and copper hardware. Inside, a handblown glass tube holds a custom aromatic oil, composed of California flora, amber and smoky notes, that transforms into a cold vapor to scent your environs.

headline: Slain by a Samurai Who Covets a Wife

It is the third festival visit by Heisei Nakamura-za, a Kabuki company from Tokyo started by Kanzaburo Nakamura XVIII, who was known for his vibrant and often funny influence on this traditional performance style. Mr. Kanzaburo died in 2012, and his two sons now run the company.

headline: Casting Time as a Lead Character
abstract: Collaborating on “Boyhood,” shot over 12 years as its young star grew up, Richard Linklater and Ethan Hawke drew on a shared philosophy about creative risk.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Ethan Hawke, sporting a ratty red turtleneck and a scraggly goatee, first worked with Richard Linklater on the set of “Before Sunrise,” playing an impulsive romantic who makes a bold pass at a stranger on a train. Over the next two decades, as Hollywood seemed to retrench into critic-proof franchises, that reckless romanticism continued to animate the friends’ idiosyncratic careers. Altogether, the two men, both Texas born, have made eight unpredictable movies together. On Friday, they will release their most audacious gamble yet, “Boyhood,” a film so formally bold that it is without an exact precedent.

headline: Empowering Words
abstract: A political theorist scrutinizes the Declaration of Independence, and see it as a clarion call for equality.
lead_paragraph: “I have never had a feeling politically,” Abraham Lincoln declared in Philadelphia on his way to the White House, “that did not spring from the sentiments embodied in the Declaration of Independence.” This statement cut to the core of Lincoln’s deepest reflections on politics and philosophy. The question is, what precisely are the “sentiments” embedded in the Declaration? This is an issue with which some of our best historical minds — Carl Becker, Garry Wills, Pauline Maier — have grappled.

headline: 1964: Klan Recruiting Drive Starts
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: the Ku Klux Klan recruits in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Miss. — A drive to recruit new members of the Ku Klux Klan was under way here yesterday and appeared to be meeting with some success. Klan posters displayed at the courthouse attracted groups of interested readers. The drive was initiated by Robert Shelton of Tuscaloosa, Ala., Imperial Grand Wizard of the Klan. Posters were thrown in every yard and doorway in this city of 6,000. The posters make the usual Klan claim that ‘‘White America’’ is threatened by Communism and mongrelization. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 3, 1964.

headline: Rightward Bound
abstract: The judicial philosophy of originalism, pioneered by Antonin Scalia, has become a hallmark of the Roberts court.
lead_paragraph: In July 1977, a law professor and former official in the Nixon and Ford administrations, Antonin Scalia, joined the editorial board of a new magazine called Regulation. It was decidedly not pro-. Its first issue featured an article in which Scalia expressed his contempt for legislation aimed at the “platitudinous goals of pursuing ‘the public interest’ or preventing ‘sex discrimination.’ ” The use of quotation marks was revealing. Here was Nino Scalia, 41 years old and already fully formed: scathing, self-confident and profoundly at odds with the premises of late-20th-­century American law and life.

headline: By Design | An L.A. Gallery and Shop So Laid Back, It’s at the Curator’s House
abstract: Julia Leonard’s Either Way L.A. project showcases functional art objects by emerging talent in a space below her Echo Park home.
lead_paragraph: The unique geography of Los Angeles — both physical and social — tends to encourage the city’s burgeoning art and design communities, especially on the artist-friendly east side, to think outside the white gallery box. Case in point: a rotating monthly pop-up known as Either Way L.A., a 150-square-foot exhibition space nestled in the garden studio beneath the hillside home of Julia Leonard, an artist and curator, in the bohemian enclave (and emerging microscale design hub) of Echo Park. “I wanted to show people in L.A. some things they haven’t seen yet,” she explains, “in an environment that didn’t feel as precious as a four-wall gallery.” Since she began the project a year ago, Leonard has showcased functional objects by exciting young talents from L.A. and beyond, such as the ceramists Jessica Hans and Morgan Peck. Now up is a show by the artist Dane Johnson, “Paintings You Can Wear,” a collection of garments hand-painted with abstract geometric shapes. Leonard devises each show’s theme in collaboration with the artist or designer on view. “Art can be so hard and harsh and it doesn’t need to be,” Leonard says. “I like the idea of running the gallery as if it’s a group effort.”

headline: Walking the Walk
abstract: For Ron Capps, a witness to five wars as an Army veteran and Foreign Service officer, writing a memoir about his PTSD has helped him come to terms with his experiences, which included a suicide attempt. He hopes the book itself — and talking about it — will encourage others like him to seek help.
lead_paragraph: “In the Army there are those who walk the walk, and those who just talk the talk.” My drill sergeant at Fort Knox said this to me more than 30 years ago. What he was implying was that there are jobs for soldiers, and jobs for people who just joined the Army for the college plan or to get some skills training.

abstract: As more companies seek to relocate by mergers — so-called inversions — it is more likely the law will change, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Tax-arbitrage mergers and acquisitions require a deep discount. American companies seeking to relocate by mergers in a bid to slash how much they pay Uncle Sam were a big part of the $1.8 trillion first-half deal boom. headline: A New York Concert to Honor Mandela, and Stream Online

Martin, and the South African playwright, director and choreographer Welcome Msomi, have assembled “Footsteps of Mandela,” a style-crossing work for choir, percussionists and solo voices from the jazz and opera worlds. Mr. Martin and Mr. Msomi will present the work at Riverside Church, where Mandela spoke on several occasions. Mr. Martin said in a telephone interview that he also hoped the performance would be streamed live on the Internet, in high-definition video, but that he was still seeing to the details.
