headline: Breezy Looks to Spruce Up Your Summer Wardrobe
abstract: Here are a few ideas — a flirty new miniskirt, a nervy manicure — to brighten your summer turnout and your outlook.
lead_paragraph: It’s the Fourth of July, high time to embrace the breezy, lighthearted look of the season. (The young women below have it down.) Here are a few ideas — a flirty new miniskirt, a nervy manicure — to brighten your summer turnout and your outlook.

headline: Reactions to Death of Palestinian Youth
abstract: Palestinian and Israeli officials and a relative of the slain teenager, whose body was found in a Jerusalem forest early Wednesday, discussed the kidnapping and killing.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian and Israeli officials and a relative of the slain teenager, whose body was found in a Jerusalem forest early Wednesday, discussed the kidnapping and killing.

headline: Gin, London Style
abstract: The Gin & Tonics Garden in London, a pop-up bar on the grounds of the Kew Royal Botanic Gardens, is serving cocktails made with the signature spirit and juices and infusions from plants grown in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Gin is the quintessential summertime tipple in Britain, but the traditional Wimbledon gin punch Pimm’s No.1 Cup has some fresh competition: the Gin & Tonics Garden, a pop-up bar on a secluded lane within the extensive grounds of the Kew Royal Botanic Gardens in London.

headline: No One Expects the Caliphate
abstract: Political imagination at the end of history.
lead_paragraph: The latest issue of the New Republic includes an essay by Mark Lilla, cited in a pessimistic column by my colleague David Brooks, that’s one of the richer takes on our present political-cultural big picture that I’ve read in some time. I’ve been looking for a news peg on which to hang some comments on Lilla’s argument, and I think I’ve found one in the news that the ISIS terrorist organization, a.k.a. the de facto government of eastern Syria and western Iraq, has taken the high-risk step of actually declaring a reborn caliphate in its conquered territory. The connection here is that one of Lilla’s themes is the way our ongoing end-of-history era has constricted the Western political imagination, leaving us unable to reckon with the complexities of a wider world where liberal democracy isn’t obviously spreading anymore:

headline: Weaning Older Patients Off Sleeping Pills
abstract: Valium, Xanax and other drugs are widely used for insomnia and anxiety, but long-term use can be hazardous.
lead_paragraph: “Deprescribe.” It’s a word I hadn’t encountered before, but Dr. Cara Tannenbaum, who holds an endowed chair in geriatric pharmacy at the University of Montreal, told me that “it’s been popping up with exponential frequency” in medical journals and conversations among geriatricians.

headline: At Thom Browne, It’s Not the Plot, It’s the Wardrobe
abstract: Sometimes the dramatic storylines behind a fashion show overshadow the pieces in terms of showiness.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Under a gridded neon light fixture, perched on plinths in rows of five, 20 models in plastic face masks and gray tailored suiting sat silently. They waited, as did the guests facing them, for Thom Browne’s show to start.

headline: 9 Worldly Ways to Make a Burger
abstract: An American staple with cosmopolitan adaptations.
lead_paragraph: An American staple with cosmopolitan adaptations.

headline: African Leaders Grant Themselves Immunity in Proposed Court
keywords: ['Immunity from Prosecution', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: African leaders have voted to give themselves immunity from prosecution for crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide in an African human rights court that does not yet exist.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — African leaders have voted to give themselves immunity from prosecution for crimes against humanity, war crimes and genocide in an African human rights court that does not yet exist, angering rights groups and puzzling activists on the continent.

headline: Ed Sheeran Hits No. 1
abstract: The 23-year-old British singer-songwriter topped the album chart with his second album, “x.”
lead_paragraph: Ed Sheeran, a 23-year-old British singer-songwriter who has been championed by Taylor Swift, topped the latest Billboard album chart with his second full album, “x” (Atlantic), beating out Phish’s latest release as well as recent hits by Lana Del Rey and Sam Smith.

headline: SEMA Garage Takes Aftermarket Parts From Concept to Reality
abstract: Using a 3-D scanner and a team of technicians, the SEMA Garage can even make a custom Z-shape trim piece for the ZZ Top guitarist’s hot rod.
lead_paragraph: The Specialty Equipment Manufacturing Association, better known as SEMA, doesn’t hold its annual trade show until November each year. But the organization’s focus on aftermarket parts has found another, full-time outlet: the SEMA Garage.

headline: Early Nick Drake Recording to Be Auctioned
abstract: A previously unknown tape made by the English folksinger in 1968, before his first album, will be sold by a London auction house.
lead_paragraph: The English folksinger and songwriter Nick Drake made three extraordinary albums between 1969 and 1972, and for many years, that was all there was. The discs, “Five Leaves Left,” “Bryter Layter” and “Pink Moon,” barely sold; Drake’s label, Island, dropped him; and in 1974, at age 26, he died of an overdose of antidepressant medicine.

headline: All of Tim Howard’s 16 Saves Against Belgium
abstract: Howard made his first save 43 seconds into the game. He finished with 16 saves, the most by a goalkeeper in a World Cup game since 1966.
lead_paragraph: Howard made his first save 43 seconds into the game. He finished with 16 saves, the most by a goalkeeper in a World Cup game since 1966.

headline: Washington, Roosevelt, Lincoln ... Howard?
abstract: Tim Howard’s brilliance in the United States’ loss to Belgium at the World Cup was an inspiration to Americans, some of whom took their adulation to amusing lengths.
lead_paragraph: When United States goalkeeper Tim Howard knocked down shot after shot in Tuesday’s game against Belgium — recording 16 saves, the most in a World Cup match since at least 1966 — the viewing experience wasn’t at all like watching LeBron James score 60 points or Peyton Manning drill a pass through three defenders for a last-second touchdown.

headline: What’s Gained and Lost as The Times Ends Many Blogs
abstract: From a high point of about 60 blogs, half are already gone with more to go.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:35 p.m., Thursday

headline: He’s Alone on a Stage, With Tough Characters
abstract: In his one-man show “The Bullpen,” Joe Assadourian draws on his experiences in a holding cell for detainees.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know for sure what kind of man Joe Assadourian is. After all, he’s served 12 years in prison for attempted murder. But I can say that he’s one terrific actor, and a very good playwright as well. That much is clear throughout his solo show, “The Bullpen,” which takes an extremely funny look at a particularly dreadful situation.

headline: Judge Whittles Down Insider Trading Charges Against Rajaratnam’s Brother
abstract: Rengan Rajaratnam, the younger brother of the former billionaire convicted of insider trading in 2011, is winning the war of attrition in his own trial.
lead_paragraph: Rengan Rajaratnam, the younger brother of Raj Rajaratnam, the former billionaire hedge fund manager convicted of insider trading in 2011, is winning the war of attrition in his own insider trading trial.

headline: App Smart | Road Trips
abstract: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can make your summer road trip smoother and more memorable.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can make your summer road trip smoother and more memorable.

headline: The Delights and Challenges of French Guiana
abstract: Cutting a path through this small South American country involved sweat, strangers and serendipity. Did it all pay off?
lead_paragraph: The 15th-century Treaty of Tordesillas famously divided South America, leaving Portugal much of what would become Brazil, and leaving Spain the rest. Somehow, along the way, the French muscled their way in to grab a foothold. Make that a toehold: French Guiana today makes up just 0.5 percent of the continent and 0.06 percent of its population, yet accounts for, in my estimation, 99 percent of its baguette consumption.

headline: Apps to Plan Summer Road Trips, Down to the Pit Stops
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Road Trips', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Apps offer help finding lodging, attractions and the best deals on gas.
lead_paragraph: A SMARTPHONE screen might seem a terrible distraction on a road trip. With the right apps, though, your phone can make any road trip smoother and more memorable.

headline: Designing a Perfect Summer
abstract: Kiel James Patrick draws interest by selling a fantasy life of a smart young crowd at play.
lead_paragraph: In January 2013, Richard Ross stood outside a drab brick building in Pawtucket, R.I., a fashion pilgrim drawn to an unlikely mecca. Months earlier, Mr. Ross had learned of a designer there named Kiel James Patrick, or KJP for short, who promotes his line of nautical-inspired bracelets and other apparel robustly through social media.

headline: Hobby Lobby, or When Corporations Get Things Both Ways
abstract: Monday’s contraception case decision made a muddle of the longstanding concept of “corporate separateness.”
lead_paragraph: Among the galling aspects of Monday’s Supreme Court ruling in the Hobby Lobby contraception case is that it made a muddle of the longstanding concept of “corporate separateness.”

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Torn Between Soccer and Shakespeare
abstract: John Lithgow and a fellow actor find their attention divided between the World Cup and the stage business at hand.
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: Mood-Lifting Additions to the Nail Scene
abstract: Nail polishes that draw attention to your fingertips.
lead_paragraph: The popularity of look-at-me nails, with brazen tints and fanciful patterns, shows little sign of abating. Here are some mood-lifting additions to the nail scene.

headline: Janet L. Yellen on Monetary Policy
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In an event at the International Monetary Fund in Washington, the Federal Reserve chairwoman said that monetary policy faces limitations as a tool to promote financial stability.
lead_paragraph: In an event at the International Monetary Fund in Washington, the Federal Reserve chairwoman said that monetary policy faces limitations as a tool to promote financial stability.

headline: What to Call the Extremists in Iraq?
abstract: Among the fast-shifting events in Iraq in recent days, an added source of confusion has been the name of the Sunni extremist group at the center of the fighting.
lead_paragraph: Among the fast-shifting events in Iraq in recent days, an added source of confusion has been the name of the Sunni extremist group at the center of the fighting.

headline: Nets Quickly Hire Lionel Hollins as Their Coach
abstract: Hollins, a veteran coach who guided the Grizzlies to the Western Conference finals in 2013, was the Nets’ primary candidate after Jason Kidd left to join the Bucks.
lead_paragraph: The interviews came and went for Lionel Hollins. He met last year with the Los Angeles Clippers and the Denver Nuggets, who opted for other candidates. In recent weeks, more teams called, including the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Los Angeles Lakers. Hollins did what he could to prepare, and then was left to hope for the best.

headline: Man Accused of Killing Brooklyn Boy, 6, in Elevator Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: A lawyer for Daniel St. Hubert said he was considering a psychiatric defense in the stabbings last month that also left a 7-year-old girl injured.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of stabbing a 6-year-old boy to death and wounding a 7-year-old girl in an elevator last month told police officers shortly after they took him into custody, “Satan has powers and controls things.”

headline: Aid From Massachusetts in New Hampshire Race
abstract: Scott Brown, seeking a Senate seat in New Hampshire after losing in Massachusetts, turns to Mitt Romney, the former governor who has helped his career at many crucial times.
lead_paragraph: STRATHAM, N.H. — It was a bit of an odd tableau: a former Massachusetts governor endorsing a former Massachusetts senator to represent the people of New Hampshire in the United States Senate.

headline: For Bonobos, a Good Fit in Stores as Well as Online
abstract: Bonobos is opening stores to prop up its online business, and drawing investors.
lead_paragraph: Bonobos, the e-commerce business best known for its well-fitted men’s pants, was never supposed to have brick-and-mortar shops. Then, all of a sudden, they opened a few and money came pouring in.

headline: An Alternative World Cup
abstract: While many soccer fans’ eyes were riveted on Brazil, a group of would-be nation-states met in Sweden last month in the ConIFA World Cup, a tournament for teams not recognized by the sport’s governing body.
lead_paragraph: It was a World Cup full of goals, political intrigue and pressure of an expectant home crowd. Amid equal measures of excitement and agony, penalties decided most of the second round games. In the end, an unlikely champion was crowned.

headline: Lindsay Lohan Sues Over a Character in Grand Theft Auto V
abstract: In a lawsuit, the actress claims that the makers of the video game used her likeness without authorization.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever played Grand Theft Auto V and thought that the minor character Lacey Jonas – a young startlet whom players rescue from pursuing paparazzi – seemed oddly like Lindsay Lohan? Jonas is a slinky blonde, like Ms. Lohan, and some players have noted that she sounds like Ms. Lohan, has a line of clothing like Ms. Lohan’s and has a penchant for complaining about the difficulties of being a star. The game also shows the Chateau Marmont, the West Hollywood hotel where Ms. Lohan racked up a bill of $46,000.

headline: The Perfect Drink for Cookouts (or Dugouts)
abstract: Rosie Schaap finally made it to a New York Times Magazine softball game this week. But she hadn’t come to play ball. She was there to do what she does best: provide refreshment.
lead_paragraph: I finally made it to a New York Times Magazine softball game this week. The Central Park evening was like a happy collision between a Hudson River School painting and a Norman Rockwell. Big blue sky, grand old trees — and scrappy journalists, editors and designers in our team’s bright green T-shirts.

headline: Italian Leader Presses His Case for Budget Relief in Europe
abstract: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi means to use Italy’s six-month tenure in the European Union presidency to promote policies that focus on growth.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The presidency of the European Union is largely ceremonial, rotating every six months among the bloc’s 28 nations. But Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy means to use its new presidency as a platform from which to seek relief for his country’s debt-saddled economy.

headline: For Spirits That Can Only Be Tied Down by a Sash
abstract: Kimonos, newly popular cover-ups, put you in touch with your bohemian side.
lead_paragraph: GLAMOUR IS A SLIPPERY CONCEPT, defined one season by a neoprene minidress, and the next by a gown cut from stiffened brocade. But in one of those pendulum swings as regular as rent hikes, it is encapsulated this summer in the loose, and louche, kimono, the casual uniform of music festival pilgrims traipsing through Coachella, South by Southwest or Bonnaroo. A stand-in for the trusty jeans jacket or cardigan, the look is being embraced this year by self-styled free spirits of every persuasion.

headline: La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels Opens in NoLIta
abstract: La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels in NoLIta is an outpost of a Parisian wine bar.
lead_paragraph: A sliver of the Sixth Arrondissement has landed on the fringes of NoLIta. An offshoot of La Compagnie des Vins Surnaturels, a renowned wine bar in Paris, opened in New York this May with an extensive wine list that would make a Michelin-starred restaurant blush.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Israel, South Africa, Afghanistan and Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, South Africa, Afghanistan and Kenya.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Loudon Wainwright Offers Another Reason It’s Tough to Live in Kentucky
abstract: An exclusive premiere of the song “Harlan County,” from Wainwright’s album Haven’t Got the Blues (Yet).
lead_paragraph: In a recent It’s the Economy column, Annie Lowrey wrote about the toughest places to live in America, based on research by the Upshot that focuses on six factors: education, household income, jobless rate, disability rate, life expectancy and obesity rate. Harlan, Ky., like many parts of the Bluegrass State, doesn’t fare so well. The median income is about half that of the country over all, the unemployment rate is more than twice as high and the life expectancy is seven years lower — all factors that make it one of the 25 hardest places to live in the country, according to the Upshot’s analysis.

headline: Gin, Miami Beach Style
abstract: The bar at the new Metropolitan by Como hotel in Miami Beach offers 40 varieties of gin, many of them from small-batch producers.
lead_paragraph: Como Hotels and Resorts, the Singapore-based brand of 12 upscale properties, recently opened its first hotel in the United States, the Metropolitan by Como, Miami Beach, which claims to have the city’s first artisanal gin bar.

headline: Common Back and Leg Pain Treatment May Not Help Much, Study Says
keywords: ['Back (Human Body Part)', 'Steroids', 'Research', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Patients in a randomized trial who had a steroid/anesthetic injection for the condition had no less pain than patients given anesthetic alone.
lead_paragraph: A widely used method of treating a common cause of back and leg pain — steroid injections for spinal stenosis — may provide little benefit for many patients, according to a new study that experts said should make doctors and patients think twice about the treatment.

headline: The Deadly Politics of Revenge
abstract: The murder of three teenage settlers in the West Bank has given Israel a pretext for an offensive to undermine the Palestinian leadership.

headline: The Devil Went to Midtown to Serenade the Lord
abstract: The City Center Encores! Off-Center series presents “Randy Newman’s Faust,” with the composer playing the Devil.
lead_paragraph: If the Devil were as endearingly funny as Randy Newman at the piano, a season in hell might not be so painful. Mr. Newman, the singer-songwriter known for his wry, bluesy tunes with lyrics etched in acid, portrayed the Lord’s nemesis on Tuesday night, in a concert performance of his musical-theater adaptation of Goethe’s “Faust” at City Center.

headline: U.S.A.-Belgium World Cup Game Drew 22 Million Viewers in Ratings
abstract: Tuesday’s World Cup game was the second-most-viewed soccer game ever on American television, trailing only the tournament’s America-Portugal match.
lead_paragraph: With just under 16.5 million viewers on ESPN, and 5.1 million more watching on Univision, the World Cup game on Tuesday between the United States and Belgium was the second-most-viewed soccer game ever on American television, trailing only the United States-Portugal game earlier in this tournament.

headline: They Need to Get in the Game
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Tennis', 'Wimbledon Tennis Tournament', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Sneakers', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Wimbledon shows that designers lag in seeking out the star athletes of summer.
lead_paragraph: SOMETHING ABOUT THE current Wimbledon has me scratching my head — and it’s not both Williams sisters losing in the third round despite their power groundstrokes, or Li Na and Caroline Wozniacki falling to Barbora Zahlavova-Strycova, who is ranked 43rd. It’s not, in fact, anything to do with playing style at all. Rather, it has to do with players’ style.

headline: Bratton Putting Desk Officers on Streets to Fight New York’s Summer Crime
abstract: The temporary program announced by the police commissioner, William J. Bratton, will last 90 days and draw on as many as 400 uniformed officers and detectives in office jobs.
lead_paragraph: As many as 400 veteran New York City officers assigned to desk jobs in the Police Department will return to the streets this summer as part of a broad push by Commissioner William J. Bratton to head off a seasonal spike in crime.

headline: Mixed Predictions About Wearables Like Smartwatches and Google Glass
abstract: Several prominent research firms made predictions about where these devices were headed. Their projections were all over the map.
lead_paragraph: The wearable computing market will be huge. Actually, it’s a passing fad. (Remember the netbook?) Or it will be a modest hit.

headline: Sweating Out Their Differences
abstract: Some Republican and Democratic members of the House of Representatives have common ground: their exercise routine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new muscle-crushing, sweat-inducing workout has infiltrated the inner sanctum of Congress, the members-only gym of the House of Representatives. And it is called, simply, the “Markwayne Mullin.”

headline: Songs of Love and Heartache, Self-Assured and Bittersweet
abstract: A violinist of outstanding reputation within jazz, folk-rock and country, Jenny Scheinman has steadily grown more comfortable as a singer-songwriter.
lead_paragraph: “Here’s the true love song on the album,” Jenny Scheinman said at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday night, holding her fiddle across her midsection like a mandolin. The album in question was “The Littlest Prisoner” (Sony Masterworks), and the song was “Sacrifice,” a dirgelike drift of rhyming couplets with a single-phrase melody kneaded into shape through repetition. Ms. Scheinman sang its lyrics — addressed first to a husband and then to their small child — with a deliberative heaviness, as in certain kinds of prayer.

headline: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
abstract: Jacques Sonck has spent almost 40 years in Belgium making portraits of people — with odd or singular looks — who capture his attention on the street.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Sonck has spent almost 40 years in Belgium making portraits of people — with odd or singular looks — who capture his attention on the street.

headline: Edit Your Facebook and Twitter History
abstract: Molly Wood explains how to download and delete activity on Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood explains how to download and delete activity on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: The Apps – and Airplane Blankets – That Track Our Lives
abstract: A new app measures the behavior of patients with mental illness, and it may become part of a larger conversation about privacy and our devices, ANNA NORTH writes.
lead_paragraph: A new app could help people with mental illness get timely treatment, by logging their behavior and sending the data to their doctors. But it may also become part of a larger conversation around how much we want our devices keeping track of us.

headline: Swear Off Social Media, for Good or Just for Now
abstract: Those concerned about their online profiles have a range of options, from deactivating their accounts completely to limiting who sees past posts.
lead_paragraph: SOCIAL media can be a harmless and easy way to keep track of friends, family and news.

headline: Yankees Fall Under .500 as Offensive Struggles Continue
abstract: Brian McCann and Carlos Beltran had productive days at the plate against the Rays, but the Yankees fell to 1-32 this season when allowing five or more runs.
lead_paragraph: Joe Girardi conceded recently that there was not much he could do to rouse the Yankees’ often-lifeless offense. Girardi believes he must be patient and hope that his veteran hitters, who have a record of success, will soon start hitting because big changes to the lineup are unlikely to make much difference.

headline: How to Digitally Avoid Taking It to the Grave
abstract: Tips to plan ahead for handling your digital content after your death.
lead_paragraph: Planning for control of your personal information after you die used to be as simple as telling someone about the desk drawer or the fireproof box or the safe deposit box at the local bank.

headline: Weinstein Company Is Said to Consider Spinning Off TV Unit
abstract: The company is pondering seeking cash for a big expansion that could include new television channels, or selling the TV unit to a digitally minded company.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Just seven months after declaring an ambitious thrust into television, the Weinstein Company, best known for its Oscar-winning film operation, is exploring plans to spin off its TV division into a separate company that could be sold to a strategic partner or taken public.

headline: The Facts and Figures Behind Jeff Koons’s Massive, Awe-Inspiring Show at the Whitney
abstract: The heaviest piece on display in “Jeff Koons: A Retrospective,” the booziest series, the work that had to travel the furthest and much more.
lead_paragraph: Like Jeff Koons himself, “Jeff Koons: A Retrospective,” at the Whitney Museum of American Art, is larger than life. The biggest show the institution has ever devoted to a single artist, it sprawls across all four floors, occupying 27,000 square feet of exhibition space. Included among the 145 works on display is a pastel Koons created last year specifically for T. The show also serves as the farewell party for the Whitney’s iconic Marcel Breuer building before the museum relocates to its new Renzo Piano-designed space downtown next year. Here, a few more key figures about this one-of-a-kind, once-in-a-lifetime survey.

headline: Jay Nixon Vetoes a Terrible Abortion Bill
abstract: The measure would triple Missouri’s mandatory waiting period.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri vetoed an extreme measure on Wednesday that would have tripled his state’s existing mandatory waiting period for women seeking an abortion, to 72-hours.

headline: Janet Yellen Says Fed Will Emphasize Stronger Regulation
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Fed chairwoman said monetary policy should focus on stable prices and maximum employment, not an increase in interest rates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Wednesday that the central bank did not plan to raise interest rates or alter its stimulus campaign to address concerns about excesses in the financial system.

headline: Winner in the Amazon War
abstract: A budding writer’s first published novel got a big lift from mentions on “The Colbert Report.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nobody expected much from Edan Lepucki’s debut novel. Her publisher planned a tiny first printing of 12,000 copies. She was assigned to an editor with almost no experience. Was there a marketing budget? How cute of her to ask.

headline: Thinking Locally, So Fighting Globally
abstract: In Beth Macy’s “Factory Man,” the head of a Southern furniture company pushes back against Chinese competition and unfavorable trade policies.
lead_paragraph: Beth Macy, a longtime reporter for The Roanoke Times in Virginia, understood how lucky she was when she accidentally uncovered the great, gripping story told in “Factory Man.” This is Ms. Macy’s first book, but it’s in a class with other runaway debuts like Laura Hillenbrand’s “Seabiscuit” and Katherine Boo’s “Behind the Beautiful Forevers”: These nonfiction narratives are more stirring and dramatic than most novels. And Ms. Macy writes so vigorously that she hooks you instantly. You won’t be putting this book down.

headline: Playing in a Part of Something Bigger
abstract: Landlady joins a lineage of New York City art-rock bands like Talking Heads and Dirty Projectors, who transmute existential questions and primal fears into exultant songs.
lead_paragraph: The musicians spilled off the stage when Adam Schatz’s rock band Landlady performed on Tuesday night at Rough Trade NYC. By the end of the set, there were a dozen horn players and half a dozen drummers and percussionists along with Mr. Schatz and Landlady’s core musicians, blaring and pounding as Mr. Schatz pushed the audience to sing along. It was an album party through a show of community. “This is such a special way to feel like you’re a part of something bigger,” Mr. Schatz announced as the musicians assembled. Mr. Schatz, who is also a jazz concert promoter, works with many other bands as well as Landlady, playing rock, funk, jazz, Afrobeat and improvisation. Landlady’s more-or-less pop songs hold a little of them all.

headline: Dutch Women Win European Championship
abstract: The European Team Championships concluded in Opatija, Croatia, on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The European Team Championships concluded in Opatija, Croatia, on Tuesday. The results in the women’s and open events were unclear until the last boards were finished.

headline: Sales at Ralo, C. Wonder, Grace & Favor and Warp & Weft
abstract: Sales and discounts on glassware, accessories and carpets this month.
lead_paragraph: Ralo carpets will discount all hand-knotted Tibetan rugs and handmade pillows up to 60 percent from July 5 through July 13 (a 5-by-8-foot Lhasa rug, originally $5,290, will be $2,116); 29 Howard Street (Crosby Street); 212-966-7661, tibetcarpet.com.

headline: Ahoy, Birdie!
abstract: Kites inspired by Balinese designs can be flown in a park or suspended over a crib.
lead_paragraph: Haptic Lab, the interdisciplinary design studio of Emily Fischer, a Brooklyn architect, specializes in handmade furniture, quilts and fanciful kites that are produced in collaboration with Balinese artisans.

headline: Out of Indonesia, Vintage Teak Furniture
keywords: ['Teak (Wood)', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture']
abstract: A California company, Teak Me Home, makes dressers and tables from old, old wood.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Teak Me Home opened a 2,000-square-foot showroom in Emeryville, Calif., to sell dressers and tables made from old-growth teak salvaged from 100-year-old Indonesian houses. “The beauty of the aged wood is that there’s more grain in the pattern,” said Alexander Elsinga, the founder. He has just introduced four new dining pieces that, like all Teak Me Home products, are made by hand in its Bay Area workshop. Prices range from $1,699 for a 40-inch round table that grows to a 64-inch oblong to $2,299 for an elliptical table that expands from five to nine feet. Famously durable, teak needs little effort to maintain its patina; a monthly wiping with furniture oil or wood polish will keep the wood “looking brilliant,” Mr. Elsinga said. The company ships nationwide. Information: 510-725-7258 or teakmehome.com.

headline: Our Niches, Our Shelves
abstract: A Brooklyn building’s residents show off one of its coziest architectural features.
lead_paragraph: The prospectus for 44 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, a six-story brick apartment building finished in 1940, promised all sorts of modern amenities: Venetian blinds, concealed radiation, radio outlets in every room. But it neglected to herald one of the building’s niftiest architectural features. In one wall of most of the foyers is an arched bookshelf niche, a Moderne version of the china cabinet. Like china cabinets, the niches were intended to be a place for the display of more than just books — where folks could show off their best (and most carefully edited) selves, as an environmental psychologist might say.

headline: The Women of Men’s Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Increasingly, female models are showing up on the men’s wear runways in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly, female models are showing up on the men’s wear runways in Europe.

headline: Faith, Severely Tested, in a German Commune
abstract: In “Nothing Bad Can Happen,” a young German Christian joins a family that makes him suffer for his beliefs.
lead_paragraph: Don’t believe the title: “Nothing Bad Can Happen” is a veritable smorgasbord of bad, at least for Tore (Julius Feldmeier), the newest member of a punk-rock Christian commune in Hamburg, Germany.

headline: A House That Sips Energy

lead_paragraph: With a voluptuous skin of high-performance fabric, Techstyle Haus is one of 25 projects on display through July 14 at the Solar Decathlon Europe 2014 in Versailles, France. headline: Government of Ecuador Can Sue Fugitive Bankers in U.S.
abstract: Ecuador has the right to sue a pair of fugitive bankers in courts in the United States to recover millions of dollars that the men are accused of embezzling, a Florida appellate court has ruled.
lead_paragraph: The government of Ecuador has the right to sue a pair of fugitive bankers in courts in the United States to recover millions of dollars that the government accuses the men of having embezzled, a Florida appellate court ruled on Wednesday. The bankers, Roberto and William Isaias, brothers who live in Coral Gables, Fla., have been convicted of embezzling $600 million from Filanbanco, a bank they owned in their native Ecuador. The Ecuadorean government sued them in a Miami court to recover a portion of the $200 million the government claims it is still owed. Last year, a state judge in Miami ruled in favor of the brothers, saying that international law did not allow Ecuador to seize properties in Florida. The Third District Court of Appeal overturned that verdict, ruling that the government was trying to recover funds, not seize property.

headline: Zoo Animals and Their Discontents
keywords: ['Zoos', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Emotions', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'ANIMALS', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Do donkeys get depressed? Are some aoudads anxious? And what can a zoo’s shrink do to help ease their minds?
lead_paragraph: Dr. Vint Virga likes to arrive at a zoo several hours before it opens, when the sun is still in the trees and the lanes are quiet and the trash cans empty. Many of the animals haven’t yet slipped into their afternoon ma­laise, when they retreat, appearing to wait out the heat and the visitors and not do much of anything. Virga likes to creep to the edge of their enclosures and watch. He chooses a spot and tries not to vary it, he says, “to give the animals a sense of control.” Sometimes he watches an animal for hours, hardly moving. That’s because what to an average zoo visitor looks like frolicking or restlessness or even boredom looks to Virga like a lot more — looks, in fact, like a veritable Russian novel of truculence, joy, sociability, horniness, ire, protectiveness, deference, melancholy and even humor.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on Japanese pacifism, Middle East restraint, a one-day difference and the drone memo.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times editorial board is critical of the decision of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to reinterpret “his country’s pacifist postwar Constitution so that the military can play a more assertive role than it has since World War II.” The board believes the move will only exacerbate tensions in a region where they are already high. “Japan’s military would still face restrictions on what it could do, but it would be allowed for the first time, for example, to help defend an American ship under attack, destroy a North Korean missile heading toward the United States or play a larger role in United Nations peacekeeping operations.” Still, the Japanese people remain generally opposed to engagement in conflict of any kind, and The Times believes it is fair for citizens to demand its government assure them that Japan will not revert to its militaristic roots.

headline: Q. & A. | Maya Lin on Saving the Planet Through Art
abstract: The artist, whose site-specific exhibiton, “Platform: Maya Lin,” opens at the Parrish Museum in Water Mill, N.Y. tomorrow, discusses how her work addresses climate change.
lead_paragraph: In 1981, Maya Lin first caught the world’s attention with her design for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. Three decades later, she is working on what she calls her “last memorial”: What is Missing?, a nonprofit that blends art and science to raise awareness about the ongoing loss of biodiversity and natural habitats. Man’s precarious relationship to nature is also at the center of Lin’s studio practice, where she uses the tools of a scientist — sonar resonance scans, satellite mapping — to create strikingly minimalist works. Her environmentally-minded site-specific projects, including “Pin River — Sandy,” a ghostly wall-sized installation that maps Hurricane Sandy’s flood plain using straight pins, are the subject of the exhibition “Platform: Maya Lin,” which opens this Friday at the Herzog & De Meuron-designed Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill, N.Y. As she readied the show, the artist discussed climate change, art’s power to shift perceptions and the place where the land meets the sea.

headline: What Did My Mother the Chemist See in Betty Crocker?
abstract: It’s hard to reconcile the all-American cookbook with the pragmatic, accomplished woman I know.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I loved looking at the photos in my mother’s old Betty Crocker cookbook: the chocolate cakes, the cookie house, even the cheese balls and fondues. Then, as an adult, I actually read the text and discovered that woven into the recipes were tidbits of advice for the 1960s homemaker: The man you marry will know the way he likes his eggs. And chances are he’ll be fussy about them. So it behooves a good wife to know how to make an egg behave in six basic ways.

headline: The Rickshaw Drivers of Kolkata, India
abstract: Is a leftover of the imperialism age on its last legs?
lead_paragraph: The rickshaws of Kolkata, India, remnants of British imperialism, are among the last in the world, but phasing them out has been far from simple. In 2005, Chief Minister Buddhadeb Bhattacharjee called them an “inhuman practice” and pushed for their eradication. But the All Bengal Rickshaw Union protested the ban, claiming that without alternative employment, the drivers would lose their livelihood. The photographer Dougie Wallace, who has a book coming out on taxis in Mumbai, “Road Wallah,” shot the drivers on these pages, many of whom told him they’ve been working for more than 20 years for less than 500 rupees ($8) a day. Still, says Shireen Hyrapiet, an instructor at Oregon State University who has interviewed drivers extensively, many young immigrants see pulling a rickshaw “as a means of upward social mobility.” Marnie Hanel

At the time, Navy divers wore constricting rubber “dry suits” over long wool underwear. When they leaked, the wool got wet and lost its warmth.

headline: Clean Water for Members Only

abstract: Cooler heads; warmer offspring.
lead_paragraph: Back in May, the Portland Water Bureau issued a boil-water notice for the area because of a temporary bacteria scare. Many received word of the potential contamination while at work. The only clean water available at my workplace was from a water cooler, paid for by some — but not all — employees who contribute to an office “water club” each month. Shortly after the city issued the notice, a member of the club reminded others in the office that the water cooler was only for dues-paying members. Thirsty co-workers could buy bottled water from the lobby or a nearby store. My question: In such a situation, what is the ethical duty to share potable water when clean tap water is unavailable? C.B., PORTLAND, ORE.

headline: 1964: CIA Helped Fidel Castro’s Sister
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Fidel Castro’s sister had been talking to the C.I.A. before defecting in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cuban Prime Minister Fidel Castro’s sister Juanita, who has defected to Mexico, had been in contact with the United States’ Central Intelligence Agency for nearly four years, the Herald Tribune learned yesterday [July 2]. Mr. Castro’s brother Raul, his trusted No. 2 man, protected Miss Castro from the dictator’s wrath and paved the way for her flight while the prime minister was away from Havana, according to highly placed intelligence sources. Miss Castro informed U.S. officials in 1960 that she was breaking with her brother’s regime. The CIA made it easy for her to enter Mexico on June 20. ‘‘She came out quite openly,’’ said an intelligence source. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 4, 1964

headline: Jobs Numbers Raise Questions About Fall in G.D.P.
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Growing employment is not mathematically compatible with a contracting, productive economy. Something must be off.
lead_paragraph: Today’s strong jobs report forcefully suggests that employment growth is accelerating. Payrolls have expanded by an average 272,000 jobs per month in the last three months compared with 210,000 over the last year.

headline: A ‘Battered’ Mideast Envoy Steps Down, but Keeps a Bag Packed
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Martin S. Indyk, who resigned last week as special envoy for Israel-Palestinian negotiations, says skepticism is the reason peacemaking efforts have failed for decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Martin S. Indyk announced his departure from Middle East peacemaking last week with a post on Twitter that said he was “battered but unbowed.” When that prompted questions from people curious about why he felt that way, he replied that if they knew anything about the nine months of negotiations between the Israelis and Palestinians, “you wouldn’t have to ask why.”

headline: Back to New York, With Toddlers in Tow
abstract: A family searches for a three-bedroom that also has plenty of space for living.
lead_paragraph: Back before they had children, Denise and Jim Burnham spent three years living in New York. They rented a one-bedroom with a balcony for around $3,400 a month in a Midtown West high-rise.

headline: Immigration
abstract: New books by Peter Eichstaedt, Aviva Chomsky, and Lou Dobbs and James O. Born.
lead_paragraph: THE DANGEROUS DIVIDEPeril and Promise on the US-Mexico BorderBy Peter Eichstaedt  Lawrence Hill, $26.95.

headline: The State of the Union’s Books
abstract: Prominent political figures who have assumed the critic’s role for the Book Review include Henry Kissinger and Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: With patriotism and fireworks in the air this weekend, the Book Review turns its attention to American life and thought, looking at new books by or about Hillary Clinton, Franklin Delano Roose­velt and the Supreme Court, among other subjects.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SOUND OF THINGS FALLING,  by Juan Gabriel Vásquez. Translated by Anne McLean. (Riverhead, $16.) Vásquez’s closely observed novel is built on Colombia’s tragic history with the drug trade. In 1990s Bogotá, a young lawyer named Antonio witnesses the assassination of a reclusive friend just out of prison after 20 years. Antonio’s search for answers leads him back to the 1960s, before Bogotá was engulfed by violence “whose actors are collectives and written with capital letters: the State, the Cartel, the Army, the Front.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SILKWORM,  by Robert Galbraith. (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $28.) The publishing world is the setting for this endlessly entertaining second novel featuring the detective Cormoran Strike, by J. K. Rowling, writing pseudonymously.

headline: Louis Zamperini, Olympian and ‘Unbroken’ War Survivor, Dies at 97
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Books and Literature', 'Olympic Games']
abstract: Mr. Zamperini’s experiences as an airman who crashed into the Pacific and spent 47 days adrift before his capture by the Japanese were told in a best-selling biography.
lead_paragraph: Louis Zamperini, an Olympic runner who as an airman during World War II crashed into the Pacific, was listed as dead and then spent 47 days adrift in a life raft before being captured by the Japanese and enduring a harsh imprisonment, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: New York Summer Stories: Air-Conditioning’s Start in Brooklyn
abstract: This holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archives that tell tales of city summers past. Today’s installment is about the history of air-conditioning.
lead_paragraph: During this holiday week, City Room is digging up articles from The New York Times archives that tell tales of city summers past.

headline: Buddhist-Muslim Mayhem Hits Myanmar’s No. 2 City
abstract: The authorities in Mandalay imposed a curfew after a surge in religious violence, incited by reports that a Muslim man had raped a Buddhist woman.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The authorities in Myanmar on Thursday declared a nighttime curfew in Mandalay, the country’s second-largest city, after a resurgence of religious violence left two people dead and more than a dozen injured.

headline: V.I.P. Room
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: With no cap on campaign contributions, political organizations target elite donors seeking insider access.
lead_paragraph: “Throw a fit. You’ll get whatever you want.” That’s the advice given to major donors by a senior “fixer” working the high-end hotels reserved for guests of the Obama Victory Fund at the 2012 Democratic convention. The campaign’s prized financial supporters got everything from “S.E.I.U. for Obama” thundersticks to “exclusive” campaign briefings to V.I.P. party-suite passes. Those who complained about lack of access could always “write a check to get a higher package,” according to a manual for volunteers.

headline: Under the Influence
abstract: Don Carpenter’s posthumous novel follows four aspiring writers during the early, heady days of the Beat scene.
lead_paragraph: If Ken Kesey’s “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest” prefigured the Age of Aquarius, then Don Carpenter’s semi-­autobiographical “Fridays at Enrico’s” can be read as the swan song of the entire Love Generation. After Carpenter burst onto the West Coast literary scene in 1966, with his gritty first novel, “Hard Rain Falling” (reissued in 2009 by New York Review Books), he became an unofficial adviser to fellow Bay Area writers trying to ride Jack Kerouac’s coattails. Never a hippie celebrity like Richard Brautigan or a living legend like Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Carpenter was a straight man to the more illustrious neo-Beat and -Dada artists of the era. With his moon face, receding hairline, professional discipline and calm demeanor, he was a steadying antidote to the counterculture bedlam of the tumultuous 1960s and beyond.

headline: Independence Days
abstract: An overburdened social worker becomes involved with a nearly feral boy and his survivalist father in 1980 Montana.
lead_paragraph: Reviewing a debut novel titled “The Orchard Keeper,” in 1965, the New York Times critic Orville Prescott chastened its author for nearly submerging “his own talents beneath a flood of imitation.” That young author was Cormac McCarthy, and the influence whose weight Prescott saw him sagging beneath belonged to William Faulkner. Among the hand-me-down characteristics Prescott noted: “the wandering pronouns with no visible antecedents; the recondite vocabulary and coined words; the dense prose packed with elaborate figures of speech; the deliberate ambiguity, the hints and withheld information; the confusion in time and place; and the flashbacks that fail to shed much light into the intermittent gloom.” All of these factors, he concluded, made for an exasperating book. “But the wonder,” he pivoted, “is that in spite of them it is also an impressive book.”

headline: Life Into Art
abstract: A portrait of the complex, quarrelsome, distinctive artist James McNeill Whistler.
lead_paragraph: Of all the American artists of the 19th century, James Abbott McNeill Whistler was probably the talkiest. In the 1870s, when he painted his famous portrait of his mother, he was living in London, a high-strung expatriate who saw fit to issue mission statements on what seemed like an hourly basis. “Art should be independent of all claptrap,” he declared, believing he had stripped painting of sentimentality and moral uplift and the other trademarks of Victorian culture.

headline: Escape From L.A.
abstract: In an apocalyptic future, a couple seek a stable community as they prepare for the birth of their baby.
lead_paragraph: Some dystopian novels, like Cormac ­McCarthy’s “The Road,” explore human relationships in dark, existential post-collapse scenarios, uninterested in either causes or solutions. Others engage with global warming head-on and imagine the possibilities beyond catastrophe, as in Margaret Atwood’s ultimately optimistic Madd­Addam trilogy. But there’s a middle path too — one exemplified by Edan Lepucki’s first novel, “California,” in which characters traverse a cross-section of mid-collapse landscape, framed by the gradual decline of civilization. This approach may seem too optimistic given dire news about melting icecaps and acidic oceans, but it does allow for a reading of the novel as satire, skewering the elements of modern life that have brought us to this tipping point.

headline: Patriarch and Pariah
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)']
abstract: The life, and death by lynch mob, of Joseph Smith, the founder of Mormonism.
lead_paragraph: A religion whose followers believe that the Earth was created somewhere in the neighborhood of the planet Kolob, and that the Garden of Eden was created somewhere in the neighborhood of Kansas City, Mo., would seem to have so fortified itself against mockery that there’s no sport in scorning it. In this respect, Mormonism is an honest reflection of its founder, a man who offers such an easy target that providing even a partial list of his myriad and exotic transgressions feels too easy, like a distasteful piling on.

headline: Rural Noir
abstract: In Tom Bouman’s “Dry Bones in the Valley,” an elderly recluse finds a stranger dead on his property in northeastern Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Some stories are so sad, you want them to have the comfort of a gentle storytelling voice. Tom Bouman extends that kindness in DRY BONES IN THE VALLEY (Norton, $24.95), his beautifully written first novel set in the mountainous region of northeastern Pennsylvania that sits atop the Marcellus Shale, a vast geological treasure, prized and exploited for its natural gas resources. With neighbors feuding over whether to lease drilling rights to companies accused of poisoning the environment, it’s no wonder that a crazy old recluse like Aubrey Dunigan would be testy with anyone he finds hanging around his decrepit farm. But these hills are also overrun with meth cookers, dope dealers and Mexican drug cartels. So just because a stranger is found dead on his property doesn’t make poor old Aubrey a murderer.

headline: A People’s History
abstract: America’s true story lies with “its most overlooked and marginalized peoples,” this book argues.
lead_paragraph: “Where else in the world does one have the freedom to contradict oneself?” Ilan Stavans asks in “A Most Imperfect Union,” a witty alternative history of the United States from the arrival of European settlers to the shooting of Trayvon Martin and the Mars rover landing in 2012. It’s a prequel to “Latino USA” — his previous collaboration with the illustrator Lalo Alcaraz, a cartoon history of Latino culture in America — and even more ambitious. This time the focus is on “the dispossessed and minority groups of all stripes, as well as individuals known and unknown to most students of American history.” What the books have in common, Stavans writes, is “sarcasm.”

headline: Bombers’ Early Light
abstract: Gearing up for World War II at Ford.
lead_paragraph: “England’s battles, it used to be said, were won on the playing fields of Eton,” the American labor leader Walter ­Reuther declared in 1940, but “America’s can be won on the assembly lines of Detroit.” Joseph Stalin agreed. Toasting President Roosevelt in 1943, he stated that “the most important things in this war are machines” and that the United States was “the country of machines.”

headline: Americanos
abstract: A group of Latino immigrants faces the challenges of assimilation in Cristina Henríquez’s novel.
lead_paragraph: If it’s true that — in the long tradition of “Don Quixote” — all novels are about road trips, then perhaps no novels detail the challenges of the journey more than immigrants’ tales. The tradition is long and worldwide. The hearts of the downtrodden, the forgotten and neglected, swell with hope at the prospect of starting over somewhere. They collect their courage along with essential belongings and begin the trek to the unforeseen. No matter if the stories they’ve heard about the new country are exaggerated and acculturation is a frightening hurdle, it will — it must — be better than the present situation. In this spirit, the characters in ­Cristina Henríquez’s new novel, “The Book of Unknown Americans,” have come to the United States.

headline: Exploring the Wild Weather of Mount Washington
abstract: A new exhibit at the Mount Washington Observatory in New Hampshire explores the extreme winters on the mountain.
lead_paragraph: In a feat of careful coordination between bouts of epic snowfall and freezing fog, work on a new museum at the self-proclaimed “home of the world’s worst weather” is now complete.

headline: Beyoncé: Genius or Terrorist?
abstract: Beyoncé is No. 1 on both Forbes’s “Celebrity 100″ and Time’s “100 Most Influential People,” JAKE FLANAGIN writes. But is she worthy of the titles?
lead_paragraph: In her 2011 hit, “Run the World (Girls),” Beyoncé Knowles, the onetime Destiny’s Child frontwoman turned solo megastar, demands, “Who runs the world?” This month, Forbes proffered an answer: she does.

headline: No Fragile Flower in This Fight
abstract: The writer and director of “Sex With Strangers,” opening at the Second Stage Theater, have sought to excavate the inner strength in the wounded female character.
lead_paragraph: “I’m fighting hard to keep an equilibrium between the characters,” said the playwright Laura Eason, whose “Sex With Strangers” begins previews on Tuesday at Second Stage Theater .

headline: And Fade Out ... but Not Fade Away
abstract: The documentary “Life Itself” is a warts-and-all portrait of Roger Ebert, the most famous and affectionately regarded of American movie critics.
lead_paragraph: “Life Itself,” Steve James’s documentary on the life of Roger Ebert, is in many ways like a wake at which intimate acquaintances warmly recall their departed friend in all his aspects, foibles and quirks along with his talents and triumphs. Deep currents of love and sorrow flow under the succession of often funny recollections of a busy life. But it is a wake where the departed is still present.

lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: Quick Stock Sales Toy With Volcker Rule’s Spirit
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: At times, investment banks have blurred the line between capital-raising and banned proprietary trading, Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Investment banks are using quick stock sales to toy with the spirit of the Volcker Rule. Wall Street sold some $23 billion in large trading orders, or block trades, for public companies in the first half of the year, according to Thomson Reuters data. That’s almost as much as initial public offerings have raised. These deals are a handy tool for corporations. But at times, investment banks blur the line between capital-raising and banned proprietary trading.

headline: Keeping Track of Hurricane Arthur
abstract: If conditions align, Hurricane Arthur could break a 3,173-day stretch in which no major hurricane has made landfall on United States shores.
lead_paragraph: In the hectic and devastating hurricane seasons of the mid 2000s, a coast-grazing storm like Hurricane Arthur would have been unremarkable. Here’s the storm’s limited coastal surge potential (the maps are helpful but are still listed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration as experimental). But in the news flow ahead of the Fourth of July weekend, there’s continuing coverage on news channels.

headline: Former Players File Objection to Proposed N.F.L. Settlement

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jordan Ellenberg, whose “How Not to Be Wrong” is No. 15 on the hardcover nonfiction list, recently said about math: “We know nothing. Right now we are standing in a tiny circle of light around our feet.”
lead_paragraph: By the Numbers: Jordan Ellenberg’s math-based guide to life, “How Not to Be Wrong,” is at No. 15 in its second week on the hardcover nonfiction list. Ellenberg is a star mathematician at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where the local alternative weekly recently asked him about his specialty in number theory — “addition and subtraction and multiplication, all the things you can do with numbers,” as Ellenberg put it. “Haven’t we already figured all that stuff out?” the reporter wondered, and Ellenberg laughed. “We know nothing,” he said. “Right now we are standing in a tiny circle of light around our feet, and every 1,000 years, we push that circle out just a little bit. Every time someone sticks his toe out beyond that circle, it opens up whole worlds of inquiry.” Ellenberg is also a published novelist (I met him at a summer fiction workshop almost 20 years ago), but he told the Madison weekly that one of the things he’d learned in his creative writing classes was how much he liked math.

headline: All the Conventional Cohabitation, but No Nuptials
abstract: For happily unmarried couples, cohabitation can come with legal protection.
lead_paragraph: When Rebecca Eckler and her boyfriend decided to have a baby and move in together three years ago, she had one condition. It wasn’t the promise of marriage, which Ms. Eckler deemed “so 2003,” but of a legally binding document that would dictate what would happen to the couple’s assets if they ever broke up.

headline: Text, Vent, Repeat
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Text Messaging', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Parenting']
abstract: Philip Galanes gives advice on a friend who texts too much and a father bothered by his son’s poetry.
lead_paragraph: I have a close friend who is going through a tough divorce. She often sends me long text messages about her horrific situation. I have asked her, on many occasions, to call me or come over to my place to talk because I find it difficult to be empathetic in a text reply. But she ignores me and continues sending long and repetitive text messages. Sometimes I choose not to respond, and she becomes upset that I am not “there” for her. What should I do?

headline: One of American Apparel’s Biggest Shareholders Sells Most of Stake
abstract: FiveT Capital, an asset management firm based in Zurich that is company’s second-largest shareholder, was unnerved by the recent turmoil at the retailer.
lead_paragraph: Unnerved by the recent turmoil at American Apparel and anxious about the company’s uncertain future, American Apparel’s second-largest shareholder has sold a substantial portion of its stake in the company.

abstract: I had never doubted my fiancé or my love for him, or our three-year relationship. And yet here I was, preparing to say “I do” and terrified that I was about to make a big mistake.
lead_paragraph: On our honeymoon in Paris, my husband and I were served breakfast every morning by the same short-haired woman. The breakfast came free with our hotel room: croissants, a basket of bread with its little trough of butter, fresh-squeezed orange juice and café au laits.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Sugar-Free Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a middle-aged woman with periods of confusion and dangerously low blood sugar levels.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, we challenged Well readers to solve the case of a middle-aged woman who suddenly began to have episodes of confusion caused by low blood sugars. Her endocrinologist thought she might have an insulinoma, an insulin-producing tumor of the pancreas, but the testing he did seemed to rule out that diagnosis. Nearly 200 of you took on the challenge of trying to figure out what was causing her life-threatening drops in blood sugar level.

headline: All in This Together
abstract: After years of living abroad, Jennifer Conlin and her husband buy her parents’ home and move in with them.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a series of circumstances led my husband and me to move back to the town where I grew up, and then to buy my parents’ home of 25 years. The home came with a lot of stuff: my mother’s colorful porcelain egg collection, my father’s dusty musical cassettes, rooms full of frayed chintz and endless silver in need of polish. It also came with my mother and father.

headline: In Paris, the Ultimate Place to Watch a World Cup Match
abstract: Le Royal Monceau Raffles Paris hotel is offering luxurious cocktail and dining events and state-of-the-art screenings for the tournament’s remaining games.
lead_paragraph: As the World Cup moves into the quarterfinal, semifinal, and final rounds, one Paris establishment is offering the ultimate setting for watching a match: Le Royal Monceau Raffles Paris, the grand Philippe Starck-redesigned hotel situated in the Eighth Arondissement. The hotel’s private theater, with seating for 99, will screen the playoff matches in live broadcast, enhanced with a few choice amenities. There will be strawberry and basil caipirinhas (in deference to the host country) and a pop-up Veuve Clicquot Champagne terrace (it’s still France, after all). There will be caramelized popcorn, made by the pastry chef and macaron maestro Pierre Hermé, to snack on, and a three-course dinner option from the hotel’s Michelin-starred restaurant, La Cuisine. And there will be state-of-the-art televisions specially installed by Sony for the occasion. While the setting is opulent (and the dress code specifies “no board shorts or flip-flops”), the mood will be spirited, according to the hotel’s manager, Pierre-Alexandre Francin. “Guests love the fact that they’re allowed to let loose, scream and shout whenever someone scores a goal,” he says.

headline: Dell Expands a Program for Tech Start-Ups
abstract: The first class includes a company that delivers live television to mobile devices over local broadband networks and allows subscribers to record programs for viewing later.
lead_paragraph: Dell has expanded its offerings for entrepreneurs with the Founders Club 50, a two-year acceleration program for 50 start-ups in a variety of industries. Dell had already established its own Entrepreneur in Residence program in 2011, started the Center for Entrepreneurs and created The Dell Innovators Credit Fund, a $100 million financing program.

headline: From a Night at the Roxy to Capitol Hill
abstract: U.S. Representative Sean Patrick Maloney and Randy Florke were married on June 21 at a church near their home in Cold Spring, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Representative Sean Patrick Maloney and Randy Florke were married on June 21 at a church near their home in Cold Spring, N.Y.

headline: Lime Is of the Essence
abstract: The lime crisis is over. It’s time to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: The origins of the daiquiri are vague and subject to embellishment and apocrypha. This is the case with many classic cocktails. We know for sure that there was a mine in Cuba called Daiquiri, not far from a beach of the same name, but we don’t know with certainty that an engineer there concocted the first daiquiri. And while the drink is bound forever to Ernest Hemingway, its most illustrious consumer — from whom one variant takes its name — he was not its creator.

headline: An Unrevised View of the Declaration of Independence
abstract: The New York Public Library is displaying a copy of the Declaration written out by Thomas Jefferson, which includes text that was edited in the final version.
lead_paragraph: In the days leading up to the Fourth of July, the New York Public Library has drawn crowds with a temporary display of one of its prime treasures — a copy of the Declaration of Independence written out by Thomas Jefferson. By Thursday, more than 10,000 people had lined up to see it, taking selfies in front of the display case, and in some cases quietly reading passages out loud.

headline: A Refreshing Drink for a Complicated Emotional State
abstract: Dashed World Cup hopes and a patriotic holiday collide, but there's a remedy.
lead_paragraph: Two things happened this week that give cause for a drink: In the World Cup, which The Upshot has been following obsessively, the United States lost a valiant game to Belgium and is now out of the contest, and the July 4 holiday is upon us. Rarely has there been a better occasion for a summer cocktail that is at once sorrowful and celebratory.

headline: SunTrust Reaches U.S. Settlement Over Mortgage Modifications
keywords: ['Homeowner Affordability and Stability Plan', 'Mortgages', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The lender agreed to pay as much as $320 million to resolve a federal criminal complaint that it mishandled applications for mortgage modifications.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors and SunTrust Banks reached a settlement on Thursday in a criminal investigation into the bank’s tardiness in approving mortgage modifications. The bank will pay as much as $320 million for a combination of consumer relief and housing counseling services.

headline: Clicking Their Way to Outrage
keywords: ['Social Media', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: On social media, people proudly trumpet their ethical outrage toward anyone or anything that has rubbed them the wrong way.
lead_paragraph: You needn’t Google far for recent case studies of Internet outrage. Log in to a social network and you’ll find it directed at celebrities and civilians alike. (See: Woody Allen, Stephen Colbert and Justine Sacco, the former communications director for IAC who posted an insensitive Twitter message about AIDS in Africa.) Politicians are a perennial favorite: Chris Christie, Rob Ford, Anthony Weiner. Then there’s the bigger game: courts of law, social movements, news media outlets, corporations and governments that have rubbed people the wrong way.

headline: A Relationship Where Marriage is Freedom
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Vows (Times Column)']
abstract: Outside the Roxy nightclub in Chelsea 20 years ago, Randy Florke met Sean Patrick Maloney. Now, the two are married with children.
lead_paragraph: In the close-knit world of New York City’s gay scene, circa 1992, Randy Florke was a somebody: flaxen-haired model, up-and-coming designer, Studio 54 habitué and downtown bon vivant. But on the night he met the man who would become his husband two decades later, he was being treated like a nobody.

headline: No Moral, No Uplift, Just a Restless ‘Click’
abstract: The Garry Winogrand retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum offers a montage of midcentury America, from ebullient to sexy to cranky to nascently gluttonous.
lead_paragraph: Garry Winogrand, who has an ample retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was born on the eve of the belt-tightening Great Depression, came of age in the pumped-up postwar 1950s and was photographer laureate — one, anyway — to the long era of morbid cultural and economic obesity that followed, and continues.

headline: Under Cover: The G.O.P. in Boldface Letters
abstract: Sam Tanenhaus’s story about the Republican Party’s identity crisis was given a typographic treatment on the cover this week. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Sometimes language is the strongest way to convey an idea,’’ says Gail Bichler, the magazine’s art director. That’s her explanation for why Sam Tanenhaus’s article about the Republican Party’s identity crisis was given a typographic treatment on the cover this week.

headline: If You’re Lighting Fourth of July Fireworks, Who’s Holding the Match?
abstract: When fireworks are legal, it’s up to parents to set limits and decide who should be lighting the fuse.
lead_paragraph: We’re about to go buy fireworks.

headline: Privacy Group Complains to F.T.C. About Facebook Emotion Study
abstract: The Electronic Privacy Information Center said Facebook deceived its users and violated a consent decree with American regulators with a study that manipulated the emotional tone of the news feeds of 700,000 users without their explicit consent.
lead_paragraph: Update 6:20 p.m.: This post was updated with a comment from the academic journal that published Facebook’s research.

headline: Space Pod Alights at the Serpentine Gallery
abstract: A pavilion resembling a space module, designed by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, has opened on the lawn of the Serpentine Gallery in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the 15th year, the Serpentine Gallery has commissioned an architect to design a temporary structure on its front lawn in Kensington Gardens here. Generally, those who are chosen have not built anything in Britain before. Over the years, Frank Gehry, Zaha Hadid, Jean Nouvel, Sou Fujimoto and Rem Koolhaas have each planted a pavilion here, some more bizarre than others. This year’s creation, by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, is a kind of alien space pod resting on 62 tons of giant quarry stones. Fashioned from semi-translucent, glass-reinforced plastic, like the Fiberglas used to build yachts, it arrived in 66 pieces and took six weeks to install. Inside are a cafe and space for events that bring together art, poetry, literature and film by emerging creators.

headline: Initial Wimbledon Run Still Drives a Former Semifinalist
abstract: Alexandra Stevenson, who reached the Wimbledon semifinals in 1999 at age 18, still dreams of a return there, even though she is ranked No. 429.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Alexandra Stevenson is sure she had to wear three pairs of socks to fit into the men’s tennis shoes she borrowed from her coach during qualifying at Wimbledon in 1999, the year she reached the semifinals.

headline: Scores of Militants Reported Killed by Iraqi Army, but Group Seizes Syrian Oil Field
abstract: The toughest fighting was in the northern Iraqi city of Tikrit, where residents said an intense bombing campaign by the Iraqi Army was underway in an effort to retake the city center.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Almost 200 Sunni militants were killed in battles with the Iraqi Army on Thursday, the Iraqi government said, but the militants’ group gained potentially significant economic ground in their struggle for leverage in the region, taking control of Syria’s largest oil field.

headline: At 75, Still Stepping Out of Line
abstract: A show at the New-York Historical Society celebrating Ludwig Bemelmans’s classic book “Madeline” is as much a tribute to its schoolgirl heroine as it is to her creator.
lead_paragraph: Could anything be more steeped in the order and orders of the Old World than those 12 little girls leaving an old house covered with vines, in two straight lines, in rain or shine? It has been 75 years since they made their appearance in Ludwig Bemelmans’s classic “Madeline” with their hair bows and yellow hats: models of propriety being led through the grandeur of touristic Paris (the Opera, the Place Vendôme, Notre Dame, the Tuileries). Except, of course, for Madeline, who never quite stayed in place.

headline: Making ‘American Ideals’
abstract: Stephen Doyle shows how he created an American flag and turned it into an open box for the cover of this week’s Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Doyle shows how he created an American flag and turned it into an open box for the cover of this week’s Book Review.

headline: Lawsuit Claims Katy Perry’s ‘Dark Horse’ Borrows From Christian Rap Song
abstract: A suit filed in federal court says that Ms. Perry’s hit “Dark Horse” is derivative of the 2008 song “Joyful Noise” by Flame.
lead_paragraph: Katy Perry, who will perform at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, may be making an appearance at a courthouse in St. Louis sometime soon. The Christian rapper Flame, who was born Marcus Gray, and three of his associates — Chike Ojukwu, Emanuel Lamber and Lecrae Moore, the co-creators of Flame’s 2008 song “Joyful Noise,” — filed a lawsuit against Ms. Perry and her label, Capitol Records, and others in federal court in St. Louis on Tuesday, charging that Ms. Perry used “Joyful Noise” without permission in her 2013 recording, “Dark Horse,” Courthouse News Service reported.

headline: Reactions to Hurricane Approaching N.C.
abstract: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina warned people to not “put your stupid hat on” as Hurricane Arthur approached the state. Meanwhile, tourists and visitors prepared for the storm.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina warned people to not “put your stupid hat on” as Hurricane Arthur approached the state. Meanwhile, tourists and visitors prepared for the storm.

headline: A Mondrian for London

lead_paragraph: Amid London’s booming hotel scene, the Mondrian London, opening Sept. 30, is poised to make a splashy debut – on the Thames riverfront in the increasingly trendy South Bank district.

headline: A Few Stories Among Characters
abstract: Lee Grant discusses her new memoir, “I Said Yes to Everything.”
lead_paragraph: The appetizers hadn’t even arrived and Lee Grant was already discussing the juiciest portion of her new memoir, “I Said Yes to Everything.” Did she sleep with Warren Beatty?

lead_paragraph: Just when you expect Fourth of July white, women appear all in black. At 8:30 a.m., 18 women visiting from Australia gathered in front of Tiffany & Company dressed à la Hepburn, with black dresses, long gloves, pearls and exaggerated cigarette holders. Most every morning, you’ll see tourists brown-bagging that famous meal outside Tiffany. One biker accounted for the weather in a two-piece outfit — call it minimalist black.

headline: Three Generations, One Home, One Unavoidable Future
abstract: Does sharing a home with your parents or in-laws also mean spending more time thinking about death?
lead_paragraph: When the writer Jennifer Conlin, her husband and her children moved in with her parents, it was a new twist on “till death do us part.”

headline: Racing Canoes in the Hudson
abstract: New York Outrigger is a paddling club that races using traditional Pacific Island canoes. Each year, it hosts “The Liberty Challenge,” a 12-mile race in the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: New York Outrigger is a paddling club that races using traditional Pacific Island canoes. Each year, it hosts “The Liberty Challenge,” a 12-mile race in the Hudson River.

headline: Couples Taking On ‘I Believe’ After ‘I Do’
abstract: Friends prompt a Jewish husband and a Roman Catholic wife to debate in “The Religion Thing,” at the Cell Theater.
lead_paragraph: At the start of “The Religion Thing,” Mo and Brian, a married couple in their 30s living the high-velocity life of Washington lawyers and lobbyists, are having Mo’s best friend since college, Patti, and her latest man, Jeff, over for dinner. It’s been six, maybe eight, months since the women have talked, let alone seen each other, and Patti has a lot to tell.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Castoff Joins a Master’s Canon
abstract: Samuel Beckett’s “Echo’s Bones,” a short story, is being published eight decades after his editor rejected it.
lead_paragraph: When the British publisher Chatto & Windus agreed in 1933 to publish Samuel Beckett’s first book of fiction, a collection of 10 interrelated stories titled “More Pricks Than Kicks,” it asked him for one final story, a culminating wallop.

headline: Fighting Summer FOMO
abstract: If you can’t get outside in the summer — or if you just don’t feel like it — it’s easy to feel like you’re missing out, ANNA NORTH writes. Luckily, you’re not alone.
lead_paragraph: Summer, as Americans are amply informed by everyone from Us Weekly to The Wall Street Journal, is supposed to be when you go to the beach, feast on barbecue, watch fireworks, and generally frolic in the sunlight. And if you’re indoors — either because you have to be or because you just don’t like going outside that much — it’s easy to feel like you’re missing out.

headline: Weekend Gas Prices Drop, but Iraq Crisis Is a Threat

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices are drifting lower just in time for the Fourth of July weekend, although they remain at the highest levels for this time of year since 2008 mainly because of the crisis in Iraq.
