lead_paragraph: At Campowerment, a group of women enjoyed a long weekend of traditional camp athletics and bonding.

headline: German Parliament Advances a National Minimum Wage
abstract: The lower house overwhelmingly approved a minimum wage of 8.50 euros (about $11.60) an hour, and the upper house is expected to follow next week.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The lower house of the German Parliament voted to establish a national minimum wage for the first time on Thursday — 8.50 euros (about $11.60) an hour — to take effect next year. Some lawmakers hailed the step as historic.

headline: Varied Sides of One Girl
abstract: Carroll Simmons, a performance collective, created a parody about Lena Dunham in “Too Many Lenas 3: Let Them Eat Cake.”
lead_paragraph: The performance collective Carroll Simmons is obsessed with the “Girls” creator and star Lena Dunham, no doubt about it. But something more complicated than hate-watching fuels its puzzlingly diffuse parody “Too Many Lenas 3: Let Them Eat Cake,” directed by David Bernstein at the New Ohio Theater as part of the Ice Factory Festival.

headline: Giving Uzbekistan Some Beach Flair
abstract: Two takes on Uzbek food, in Rockaway and Sheepshead Bay.
lead_paragraph: The air smells of salt and sunscreen, cumin and lamb, the Silk Road and the boardwalk. Out front is a surf rack slapped with stickers for Futures Fins and Mucho Aloha beer; inside are hulking Central Asian meat pastries the recipes for which reach back to the time of the Khans.

headline: A Happy Hunter for a Must-Have Taste
abstract: Mark Rosati, culinary director of Shake Shack, goes on the prowl in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, looking for the next must-have taste.
lead_paragraph: At a certain point in life, you’re old enough to stop thinking that other people’s jobs sound like fun. But when I heard about Mark Rosati, who is the culinary director of Shake Shack — meaning all 27 branches in this country and 21 internationally, including ones in Istanbul, Moscow and Dubai — I thought his job might be an exception.

abstract: Tours, shows, benefits and awards fill the calendar.

headline: Unorthodox Bookends Leading the Germans
abstract: For the German team at the World Cup, Thomas Müller, once again its leading scorer, is an unusually versatile forward. Manuel Neuer is an unusually versatile goalkeeper.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — It has been a hot and cold World Cup for Germany: from its bold statement match in steamy Salvador against Portugal to its botched lines and opportunities in the chill and drizzle of Porto Alegre against Algeria.

lead_paragraph: It has been 55 years since bitter labor relations exploded into one of the longest and most debilitating strikes the United States has ever seen.

headline: A New Forum for Charles Rennie Mackintosh’s Architecture
abstract: Scholars are completing a comprehensive online database of buildings by this Scottish master.
lead_paragraph: Scholars are completing an online database of buildings by the Scottish architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh, just as restorers are puzzling over how to rebuild his 1909 wing at the Glasgow School of Art, now in charred ruins.

headline: Social Media’s Vampires: They Text by Night
abstract: Often defying parents’ rules, many teenagers spend the wee hours using social media with friends.
lead_paragraph: Owen Lanahan’s parents demand that his cellphone be stored in the kitchen by 10 p.m., but sometimes he sneaks it into his bedroom. That’s because he considers late-night hours his “me” time.

abstract: Companies like In-State Angels are trying to help students and parents avoid the high price of out-of-state tuition, but some colleges frown on it.
lead_paragraph: Figuring out how to pay in-state college tuition for a college student who grew up elsewhere is the ultimate money hack.

headline: A Seasonal Staple, Slightly Less Buttoned Down
abstract: A little “Fantasia,” some humor and Rachmaninoff were on offer Wednesday night by the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s Summertime Classics concerts, which began on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall, are an opportunity to see the orchestra “kicking back,” its president and executive director, Matthew VanBesien, writes in the Playbill. The musical selections are “eminently listenable,” an article a few pages later says.

headline: Shifting Contexts, Psychodrama and Meta-Works
abstract: “Amy Sillman: one lump or two” at Bard College is a midcareer survey showing Ms. Sillman’s work on paper, canvas, phones and table screens.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — Abstract painting is on the move in “Amy Sillman: one lump or two,” a spirited midcareer survey at Bard College’s Center for Curatorial Studies. It jumps around from paper to canvas to phone and tablet screens, as if to say, “Catch me if you can.”

headline: ‘Glass Puzzle’
abstract: This small group show, organized by the painter Mary Simpson, runs wild with the theme of multiplied and divided selves.
lead_paragraph: Anchored by a magical early work by Joan Jonas, this small group show, organized by the painter Mary Simpson, runs wild with the theme of multiplied and divided selves. It should be seen especially for Ms. Jonas’s “Glass Puzzle,” a video installation from the early 1970s that involves two female performers, two cameras and various ways of distancing the spectator from the action. (Ms. Jonas, who once called the piece a “puzzle in space,” fed a live performance to a television monitor and then aimed a camera at the monitor, so that we ultimately see a fuzzy view of the women that’s further marred by reflections on the screen.)

headline: Ed Paschke
abstract: Ed Paschke, the great American painter who died in 2004, was a formalist in wolf’s clothing, or the most abstract of Photo Realists.
lead_paragraph: Think of Ed Paschke, the great American painter who died in 2004, was a formalist in wolf’s clothing, or the most abstract of Photo Realists. His dystopic photo-based paintings depict the denizens of a lurid dark side, where crime, race, clubs and an eerie glamour mixed with intimations of violence.

headline: Words That Do More Than Signify
abstract: Language and its interplay with medium and audience are examined in “Sites of Reason,” an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: In 1974 Allen Ruppersberg copied by hand the entire text of Oscar Wilde’s novel “The Picture of Dorian Gray” onto 20 6-by-6-foot canvases. It’s a safe bet that no one has ever read Mr. Ruppersberg’s rendering of the book all the way through. Printed in a pale marker on beige fabric, the words aren’t easy to decipher. But see for yourself: The whole thing is included in “Sites of Reason: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions” at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Brice Dellsperger: ‘Body Double: Vous N’en Croirez Pas Vos Yeux’
abstract: The French artist Brice Dellsperger takes cinephilia to absurdist extremes.
lead_paragraph: The French artist Brice Dellsperger takes cinephilia to absurdist extremes. He makes ultra-low-budget films in which he and a few other actors — usually in drag — recreate scenes and full-length versions of well-known movies, retaining the original soundtracks. He particularly favors Brian De Palma, the director of “Body Double,” but he’s also created interpretations of movies by David Lynch, Stanley Kubrick, Alfred Hitchcock and numerous others.

headline: ‘Thin Skin’: ‘Six Artists from Beirut’
abstract: This show offers an instant education in new painting from, or about, Beirut, the cosmopolitan but perennially embattled capital of Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Since opening last year, Taymour Grahne Gallery has been a boon to New York, which has few other outlets for contemporary art from the Middle East. Its current show offers an instant education in new painting from, or about, Beirut, the cosmopolitan but perennially embattled capital of Lebanon.

abstract: Nobody keeps a closer eye on an artist than other artists.
lead_paragraph: Nobody keeps a closer eye on an artist than other artists. So when Karina Daskalov, a director at Marian Goodman Gallery, was planning the inevitable summer group show, she called on artists she knew best, those already on the Goodman roster, for fresh candidates. Nearly 20 responded, and “Some Artists’ Artists” brings some valuable introductions and re-encounters.

lead_paragraph: The Museum of Arts and Design is plunging into the deep end of the biennial pool with a big, messy splash. headline: Jobs Rebound, Prosperity Lags
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Editorials', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Part-Time Employment']
abstract: The economy has added more jobs and is hiring more people, but the pay is still lousy.
lead_paragraph: The spring rebound in employment has come to pass — just a little later than projected. The economy added 288,000 jobs in June, and tallies for April and May were revised upward, bringing job creation over the past year to 2.49 million, the highest level in five years. The unemployment rate also fell to 6.1 percent, the lowest level in nearly six years, and, even better, the decline was unambiguously good news. It resulted from people getting hired and not leaving the work force.

headline: Downloads in Decline as Streamed Music Soars
abstract: Americans used streaming platforms to listen to 70.3 billion songs in the first half of 2014, as CD sales and downloads declined.
lead_paragraph: For the music industry, the good news about this year’s sales is not quite enough to make up for all the bad news.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a decision that drew an unusually fierce dissent from the three female justices, the Supreme Court sided Thursday with religiously affiliated nonprofit groups in a clash between religious freedom and women’s rights.

headline: College Debt and Home Buying
abstract: While homeownership is down nationally since the housing market collapse, the drop-off among younger adults, 25 to 34, is particularly striking.
lead_paragraph: Swelling student loan debt is commonly cited as a primary factor in the declining homeownership rate among 25- to 34-year-olds. But are the two really related?

lead_paragraph: HOW many pounds of ice does it take to put on a New York Philharmonic concert in the park?

headline: 36 Hours in the Berkshires
abstract: Do you prefer nature or culture? Indulging in local food or burning it off? Choose your own combination during a weekend in western Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The Berkshires, I used to think, were nothing special. Only after I left my childhood home in western Massachusetts did I learn that not every American countryside is crisscrossed by so many lines of music and literature, by crumbling stone walls running like half-forgotten stories through farms and woodlands, by ellipses of deep green hills fading to blue. The Berkshires, of course, have been beloved for centuries. Long before their Gilded Age heyday as the “Inland Newport,” a guillotine-fleeing lady-in-waiting of Marie Antoinette remarked on the region’s fertility and “majestic forests.” A sense of that history is one reason that I keep returning to favorite Berkshire spots. But this summer new attractions and renovations are making their mark on the county’s cultural, natural and culinary landscapes, and the decisions you’ll face every Berkshire morning — old or new? art or the outdoors? — are getting harder than ever to make.

headline: Syria Aid Needed, Refugee Agency Says

lead_paragraph: The United Nations refugee agency said Thursday that 70 percent of its $3.74 billion emergency budget for helping Syrian war refugees remained unfunded, and it warned of “dramatic consequences” in the Middle East if donors failed to provide the needed aid. António Guterres, the high commissioner for refugees, also said the total number of Syrian refugees had swelled to nearly three million and was increasing at the rate of 100,000 a month. “The international community simply cannot afford to let this growing and increasingly protracted population of refugees fall through the cracks,” Mr. Guterres, above, said in a statement on the agency’s website. “Nor can we fail to support the countries who generously host them.” The biggest concentrations of Syrian refugees are in Lebanon, Turkey and Jordan, with smaller populations in Iraq and Egypt.

headline: U.N. Peacekeepers’ Pay Dispute Is Resolved
abstract: Diplomats have resolved an unusually bitter dispute over how much United Nations peacekeepers should be paid.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats on Thursday resolved an unusually bitter dispute over how much United Nations peacekeepers should be paid. The countries that send troops, mostly from South Asia and Africa, are currently paid an average of $1,210 per soldier per month, a rate that has not changed for about a decade. The payments will increase gradually over the next four years, according to an agreement that is expected to be approved by the United Nations General Assembly, to just over $1,400. The countries contributing troops had wanted a rate of more than $1,700, based on an estimate provided by the United Nations Secretariat. Countries that fund peacekeeping missions — the United States, Japan and France are the largest funders — called that demand unrealistic. The total peacekeeping budget has increased to $8.6 billion, a record, though as the United Nations points out, that is less than 1 percent of total military expenditures worldwide. Each country decides how much of the reimbursement rate goes to individual soldiers.

lead_paragraph: Protesters held rallies in several Egyptian cities on Thursday in opposition to the military’s ouster one year ago of Mohamed Morsi, the country’s first fairly elected president. The protests in the capital, Cairo, were scattered and in some neighborhoods, small and quickly dispersed by riot police officers. At least one protester was killed. Mr. Morsi’s supporters have held regular rallies since his ouster on July 3, 2013, but the protests have dwindled in the face of an increasingly harsh government crackdown against Islamists and other dissidents that has included mass killings by the security forces, the arrests of tens of thousands of people and a ban on demonstrations. Separately on Thursday, an explosion in a Cairo apartment killed two people who the authorities said were militants in the process of preparing a bomb.

Their latest husband-wife project, though, is an appealing recording: a program of diverse “Love Duets.” Ms. Pérez’s warm, penetrating voice matches well but also contrasts interestingly with Mr. Costello’s rich, virile sound. They excel in duets from Massenet’s “Manon,” Verdi’s “La Traviata,” Gounod’s “Faust” and, best of all, the tender “Cherry Duet” from Mascagni’s “L’amico Fritz.” “One Hand, One Heart” from Bernstein’s “West Side Story” is disappointing: too somber, slow and self-consciously operatic. But they are charming in “I’ll Know” from “Guys and Dolls.” (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: 1914: Mercedes Finishes First in Grand Prix
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: German Mercedes drivers win the automobile Grand Prix in France in 1914.
lead_paragraph: The greatest automobile race of the year, the Grand Prix, organized by the Automobile Club de France, ended yesterday on the Lyons circuit in a definite and conclusive German victory. Lautenschlager, driving a Mercedes machine, finished first; Wagner, also driving a Mercedes, was second, and Salzer, another German, in the same make of machine, was third. Never since 1895, when the Automobile Club de France organized its first big competition, the race from Paris to Bordeaux, has an automobile race attracted so huge a crowd. Even the Paris-Vienna and Paris-Madrid contests of 1902 and 1903 were eclipsed. Lyons was hardly recognizable. It was the magnet for hundreds of automobiles and thousands and thousands of spectators. On Friday many of the cafés remained open all night. The streets were lined with automobiles unable to obtain garage, and the pavements were black with a multitude of pedestrians moving, because they could not help it, at a snail’s pace. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 5, 1914

For over an hour I’d been walking up the mountain trail without seeing a soul, marching to the off-kilter orchestras of Swiss cowbells ringing their dull symphonies in nearby meadows, to which I added my own contrapuntal exhalations whenever I stopped to catch my breath. headline: 1939: Nazi Germany Unprepared for World War II
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany seems unprepared for war in 1939.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany is faced with seemingly insurmountable obstacles to real preparedness for war, according to the semi-annual economic review of the Reichskredit Gesellschaft, which was published here today. Just at a time when the entire world is studying the Reich’s economic position in an effort to determine its war potential, this mid- year report reveals there are still a number of monkey wrenches in the country’s war machinery. Germany apparently is still handicapped by a severe shortage of labor, food products and raw materials. The economic expert, who summarized the report, found that the labor shortage is one of the weakest spots in Germany’s militarized economy. Even with the present size of fine armed forces, there is a shortage of one million workers and the only apparent way to increase the number of industrial and building workers is to import more foreign labor and ‘‘comb out superfluous labor’’ in the retail trades. It is estimated that the country could get 450,000 laborers by the combing-out process. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 5, 1939.

headline: The Secret of Effective Motivation
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Encourage people to do something for its own sake, not for its benefits.
lead_paragraph: THERE are two kinds of motive for engaging in any activity: internal and instrumental. If a scientist conducts research because she wants to discover important facts about the world, that’s an internal motive, since discovering facts is inherently related to the activity of research. If she conducts research because she wants to achieve scholarly renown, that’s an instrumental motive, since the relation between fame and research is not so inherent. Often, people have both internal and instrumental motives for doing what they do.

abstract: Girasole Cucina Italiana in Bound Brook offers a little bit of everything. Since its opening in 1996, there has been an emphasis on an ever-changing specials menu without ignoring the importance of a good Bolognese sauce.
lead_paragraph: Most Italian restaurants in New Jersey either specialize in red sauce and meatballs or focus more on perfecting their veal Francese or pasta and shellfish dishes. Those that embrace fresh ingredients and experimentation are few and far between. Girasole Cucina Italiana in Bound Brook offers a little bit of everything. Since its opening in 1996, one of the owners, Rob Russo, 45, has emphasized an ever-changing specials menu without ignoring the importance of a good Bolognese sauce.

headline: Take a Seat, Dockside, for Asian Flavors
abstract: Harlow East is the quintessential Hamptons restaurant, with expansive water views and a blue and white décor delivered with nautical flair. It’s the Sag Harbor outpost of the Manhattan restaurant Harlow, on East 56th Street.
lead_paragraph: Wide, white and airy, with shiny wood floors and a blue and white décor delivered with nautical flair, Harlow East is the quintessential Hamptons restaurant, offering expansive views of the water both inside and out. The restaurant, which opened on Memorial Day weekend, is the Sag Harbor outpost of the Manhattan restaurant Harlow, on East 56th Street. Neither place has anything to do with the Depression-era actress Jean Harlow, but both are named after the 8-year-old daughter of Richie Notar, the owner. Harlow East is located on Long Wharf in the former home of another New York City success story: B. Smith. If you go, try to snag a table on the wide porch under the crisp, navy blue awning to take in the best bay views. After all, you’ll be paying for it.

The big menu created by the chef and primary owner, James Chen, combines three cuisines, Japanese, Chinese and Thai — with a few Korean add-ons — and mixes corner-take-out favorites with more ambitious offerings.

headline: How to Prevent Summer Blackouts
keywords: ['Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Energy and Power', 'Air Conditioning', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Summer (Season)', 'Weather']
abstract: We can install a tiny device, and have a little concern for what our neighbors think of us.
lead_paragraph: IT’S July, and it’s starting to get hot. This month last year — on Friday, July 19, 2013 — New York City broke its electricity usage record. The demand strained Con Ed’s grid until it broke. Within hours, 5,200 Bronx residents were without power. And as more heat rolled in, the blackouts did too, in Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston — no major metropolitan area on the East Coast was spared. Earlier that summer, California, Texas, Illinois and other states fought the same battle with heat-driven peak demand. Canada, Japan, India, Nepal and virtually the entire world face the same issue.

Messi’s fellow forwards, Gonzalo Higuaín and Sergio Agüero, have fumbled, and after Agüero was injured, his replacement, Ezequiel Lavezzi, played poorly enough that he was substituted.

abstract: President Obama needs to set a specific goal for signing the international treaty and destroying the stockpile.
lead_paragraph: Ridding the world of destructive weapons is a slow and often discouraging process. The international treaty outlawing land mines started out that way but has turned into a success story, with 161 countries joining the pact. Nevertheless, the treaty will not reach its full effect if the United States, the most significant holdout, does not also sign on. President Obama took a step in that direction last week, but it is still not enough.

lead_paragraph: A long-running legal dispute between Argentina and investors who own some of its bonds could force the country to default on its foreign debt by the end of the month. lead_paragraph: Taxpayers complaining about a do-nothing Congress should take note that free travel junkets by lawmakers and their staffs are on the rise. House members are doing something. headline: Poised to Gain in Iraq Crisis, Kurds Face New Barriers to Autonomy
abstract: Although exporting its vast oil supply would give the Kurdish government leverage in its push for sovereignty, opposition from other nations has left the region’s future uncertain.

Hundreds of thousands of civil servants have gone months without a paycheck after Baghdad cut payments to the regional government in retaliation for its exporting oil without permission.

headline: My American Family
abstract: A previous generation of immigrants now supports today’s immigrants.
lead_paragraph: On the Fourth of July 1951, my parents were married. Not long ago, I asked my mother, who, at 87, is still going strong, why they chose that date. I thought there might have been some symbolism. She quickly disabused me. It was because that was the only time “the market” would be closed, and my father’s family could attend the wedding.

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE BEST MAN HOLIDAY (2013) In this follow-up to his 1999 debut, “The Best Man,” the writer and director Malcolm D. Lee reassembles his earlier film’s college friends — and reignites old rivalries — during Christmas at the home of the football god Lance (Morris Chestnut, above far left, with, from left, Taye Diggs, Harold Perrineau and Terrence Howard) and his wife, Mia (Monica Calhoun). The author Harper (Mr. Diggs) is now battling writer’s block and financial woes as his pregnant wife (Sanaa Lathan) nears her due date; the educator Julian (Mr. Perrineau) has learned that his wife (Regina Hall) has a past, available for viewing online; the troublemaking Shelby (Melissa De Sousa) is a reality television diva; and the womanizing Quentin (Mr. Howard) is living large amid celebrities. “Mr. Lee’s film is more traditional than its sexually frank humor might indicate, with faith and charity ultimately given pride of place (right alongside human pettiness),” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “But even if some of the crudeness and the drama feel forced, it’s hard to hate.”

headline: Swedish Sadomonetarist Setback
abstract: And Svensson vindicated.
lead_paragraph: OK, this is fairly amazing. I’ve written often about sadomonetarism among central bankers — the evident urge to find some reason, any reason, to raise interest rates despite high unemployment and low inflation. The most influential hive of this kind of thinking is the Bank for International Settlements, which for some reason commands great respect even though it offers an ever-changing rationale — inflation! Any day now! Or maybe not! Financial stability! — for its never-changing advocacy of tight money. But the place where policy makers most dramatically gave in to this urge is Sweden, where the majority at the Riksbank decided to indulge its rate-hike vice while freezing out one of the world’s leading experts on deflation risks, my friend and former colleague Lars Svensson.

headline: Do I Have the Right to Be?
keywords: ['Philosophy', 'Time', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: We fail to appreciate how radically contingent our lives really are.
lead_paragraph: It’s a disturbing thought: All of us are alive today thanks at least partly to some mass atrocity that was committed in the past. This is because war crimes, crimes against humanity, genocide and ethnic cleansing invariably affect who is born after them. Who knows how many of us can claim, “Even if the Holocaust had not occurred, I would still have been born”? And if you can, perhaps because you were conceived before 1933 or shortly afterward without having been influenced in some way by the effects of Hitlerism, what about the Crusades or slavery in America? Anyone who reflects on the unjust death of others will be surprised at how much his or her own right to be is put in question, to the point where his or her place on this earth can appear as a usurpation. This might not be obvious at first so let’s slow down a bit.

headline: When “Justice” Isn’t Just
abstract: Readers comment on my column about an innocent man who spent 25 years in prison for murder
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the flaws in our criminal justice system through the remarkable story of Michael Morton, author of a new memoir. Morton was a middle class guy in Austin with no criminal record, and he came home from work one day to find his wife murdered–and himself a key suspect. He spent the next 25 years in prison for murdering her, partly because the authorities suppressed exculpatory evidence. It’s as harrowing a story as you can imagine, and it’s a good starting point for a discussion about what to do to improve the justice system. Three elements of an improvement would be, I think: 1.) an end to the disastrous mass incarceration experiment that began in the 1970’s; 2.) an improved network of mental health services, so that prisons and jails are no longer our default mental health system; 3.) improved treatment programs for addicts, so that a failed war on drugs no longer fills up prisons and jails. That’s all a bit glib, I realize, and there’s no silver bullet solution the problems of drugs, but it’s impossible to read Morton’s memoir without feeling that the present system is an appalling and expensive mess.

abstract: Memories of a short but ferocious conflict between Vietnam and China in 1979 permeate the current sour relations between the two Communist countries now at odds over contested waters in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: LANG SON, Vietnam — She was 14 when Chinese artillery fire echoed across the hills around her home in northern Vietnam, and hundreds of thousands of Chinese soldiers swarmed across the border. She remembers sprinting with her parents through the peach trees, her waist-length hair flying, as they fled the invaders. They ran straight into the enemy.

headline: Militant Leader in Rare Appearance in Iraq

abstract: The leader of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, took the all but unprecedented step of delivering a videotaped sermon at a mosque in Mosul.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Wearing a black turban and black robes, the leader of the self-proclaimed Islamic state that stretches across eastern Syria and much of northern and western Iraq made a startling public appearance, his first in many years, at a well-known mosque in the Iraqi city of Mosul, according to a video released on Saturday whose contents were confirmed by experts and witnesses.

headline: Q. and A.: Lyle Goldstein on China and the Vietnamese Military
abstract: With friction rising in the South China Sea, Professor Goldstein, of the China Maritime Studies Institute at the Naval War College in Rhode Island, discusses the current state of Vietnam’s military and Chinese perceptions of it.
lead_paragraph: As friction increases between China and Vietnam over the South China Sea, an important question is how Vietnam’s military, famed decades ago for its resilience and guerrilla warfare, measures up. For the last two months, Chinese and Vietnamese Coast Guard vessels have been jostling each other around a billion-dollar Chinese oil rig that Vietnam says was unilaterally placed in its waters by Beijing. (Beijing says the waters are Chinese.) Warships from both countries lurk in the distance, and from time to time, the Chinese send air force fighters into the rig’s vicinity to show they mean business.

headline: Young Hand, Just Out of High School, Guides a City
abstract: In May, an 18-year-old became the mayor of Archer City, an oil and cattle hamlet south of Wichita Falls, which has about 1,800 residents.

headline: Imbibing the Joys of a Lusty Poet
abstract: Before Allen Ginsberg and the Beats descended on San Francisco, there was James Broughton.
lead_paragraph: Before Allen Ginsberg and the Beats descended on San Francisco, there was James Broughton (1913-99), a poet, experimental filmmaker, pansexual free spirit and proto-hippie who, like Ginsberg, was a spiritual descendant of Walt Whitman. His exuberant life and times are recalled in “Big Joy: The Adventures of James Broughton,” now available on DVD and on demand. Directed by Stephen Silha, Eric Slade and Dawn Logsdon, the documentary captures the euphoric mood of bohemian San Francisco just after World War II and includes many excerpts from his exhortatory poetry. For much of his life, he followed the dictum of his motto, “Follow your weird.”

headline: A Week When Parks Go Pan-American
abstract: We’re not all polyglots yet, but the Latin Alternative Music Conference keeps on pushing.

headline: 1914: America Sends a Million Dollars of Gold to Mexico
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Mexican rebels sponsored by money from the United States in 1914.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO, Tex. — More than a million dollars of gold from big business sources in the eastern States alone have been poured into the Mexican rebel coffers during the last nine months. This is admitted by Constitutionalists of prominence. It is added that since the split between Generals Carranza and Villa much money has been withheld, and the rebel cause now faces serious embarrassment. The bitterness engendered by the clash of the two leaders has loosened tongues, and the facts are now known for the first time. The money has come here in single drafts for $50,000 at a time on two local banks transferring the funds. It is impossible to get documental proof, but it is believed that most of it has gone to the honest needs of warfare. So acute has become the need of more money that Senor Alberto Madero has hurried to New York to impress the capitalists alleged to be financing the revolution with the necessity of funds. General Villa is trying to raise money by concessions for the sale of dynamite and the exportation of cattle. The Pearson and Guggenheim lumbering and mining interests have been allowed to reopen. Unusual protection is being afforded the latter. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 7, 1914

headline: The Enduring Appeal of the Something-Free Diet
abstract: Whether it’s fat, sugar or gluten, cutting something out of our diet appeals to us like nothing else, ANNA NORTH writes. Why do narratives of getting rid of something have such staying power?
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s fat, sugar, gluten or something new, the idea of cutting one item out of our diets seems to maintain its hold on our culture — even if what we’re supposed to cut changes with time. What is it about getting rid of something that makes it so popular, almost independent of what that something is?

headline: Known for Rescues, a Firefighter Dies in a Brooklyn Blaze
abstract: Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, who became trapped during a search for residents during the fire Saturday, was the first New York City firefighter to die in the line of duty in more than two years, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: After the call came in — a fire licking the curtains in a 19th-floor bedroom window, smoke pouring into the night — the fire ladder truck from nearby Hooper Street was the first to arrive on Saturday at the Brooklyn high-rise. Out jumped Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, a 14-year veteran, leading a team of four firefighters into 75 Wilson Street in Williamsburg. It seemed a routine fire, nothing out of the ordinary. Yet minutes after Lieutenant Ambelas, 40, headed into apartment 19B with two other firefighters to look for people who might be trapped, he was carried out unconscious, badly burned and on the verge of death.

headline: London Theater Journal: Two Wars, With Song and Sentiment
abstract: Ben Brantley on the revival of “Miss Saigon,” Sean O’Casey’s seldom-seen “The Silver Tassie,” and Peter Brook’s latest offering, “The Valley of Astonishment.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If war is indeed hell – and I hear no one contradicting that assertion – then I spent the better part of a day here in the netherworld. The afternoon found me in Vietnam in the mid-1970s, courtesy of a gauzy new revival of the Alain Boublil and Claude-Michael Schonberg musical “Miss Saigon.” That night I joined a ragged regiment of Irish soldiers during the First World War, via the National Theater’s startling production of Sean O’Casey’s seldom-seen “The Silver Tassie.”

headline: 1964: Fans Scream for Beatles at Movie Premiere
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A crowd of fans greeted the Beatles at the premiere of their first film, in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twelve thousand screaming teen-agers packed Piccadilly Circus tonight [July 6] for a look at the Beatles as they attended the world première of their first film, ‘‘A Hard Day’s Night.’’ Also present for the charity première were Princess Margaret and her husband, Lord Snowdon, but they received a much smaller ovation from the crowd. The Beatles — Paul McCartney, George Harrison, John Lennon and Ringo Starr — were presented to the royal couple in the lobby of the theater. ‘‘What do you think of the film?’’ asked the princess. ‘‘I don’t think we are very good, ma’am,’’ Mr. McCartney said with a smile. ‘‘But the director is very good.’’ As soon as the royal party left, usherettes in dresses printed with the Beatles’ faces rushed up to the quartet and asked them to sign their dresses. Ambulance men carried off about 20 fainting girls including one who screamed from her stretcher: ‘‘Let me up! I want to see them!’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 7, 1964.

Now in its 26th season, the series attracts dancers of all stripes: young, old, amateur, professional. They tend to have one thing in common: a fussiness, or a passion, when it comes to shoes. In many cases, it’s a matter of comfort, personal style or the material of the dance floor.

headline: Director to Correct Films on Guatemala
abstract: The director of two documentaries about human rights abuses in Guatemala said that she planned to correct inaccuracies in those films, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: The director of two documentaries about human rights abuses in Guatemala said that she planned to correct inaccuracies in those films, including blaming the country’s military for a village massacre, The Associated Press reported. The director, Pamela Yates, said in a statement that the decision resulted from investigations into the circumstances surrounding the killing of 17 villagers recounted in her 1984 film, “When the Mountains Tremble.” The scene took place in Batzul, where a local woman told the filmmakers that the men responsible for the murders wore military uniforms. Later reports and a recent visit by Ms. Yates revealed that the men had been members of guerrilla forces dressed as army soldiers. Ms. Yates said that she intended “to make a correction that will clarify what happened in this scene” in both that film and her 2011 documentary, “Granito: How to Nail a Dictator.” “When the Mountains Tremble” won multiple honors upon its release, including the Special Jury Award at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: No More Anthony on ‘Opie & Anthony’
abstract: The radio shock jock Anthony Cumia has scratched off another of his nine lives.
lead_paragraph: The radio shock jock Anthony Cumia has scratched off another of his nine lives: He was fired last week from SiriusXM’s “Opie & Anthony” radio show. The decision came after Mr. Cumia, below, posted what the company described in a news release as “racially charged and hate-filled remarks” on his personal Twitter account over a run-in with a black woman in Times Square. The tweets, as well as expletive-laced reactions toward his firing, have been removed from his account but can be found online. In the news release, Patrick Reilly, a SiriusXM spokesman, called Mr. Cumia’s comments “abhorrent” and “wholly inconsistent” with the company’s values. Fans have taken to social media to express support of Mr. Cumia, some saying they’ve canceled their SiriusXM subscriptions. An online petition to reinstate him had reached nearly 7,000 signatures through early Sunday afternoon. The show’s other host, Greg Hughes, a.k.a. Opie, posted on Twitter that he was devastated and would meet with SiriusXM on Tuesday. The hosts have a history of trouble. In 1998, Mr. Cumia and Mr. Hughes were fired from a Boston radio station for an April Fools’ prank in which they extensively, and falsely, reported that the city’s mayor had died in a traffic accident. In 2002, their syndicated show in New York was canceled after they broadcast a live account of a couple supposedly having sex in St. Patrick’s Cathedral. And in 2007, their XM Radio show was suspended for 30 days because of a bit about violent sex and Condoleezza Rice.

abstract: My struggling students craved instruction far more than freedom.

abstract: His conviction on espionage charges in 1978 raised alarms about the federal government’s use of wiretaps without court orders and spurred passage of the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.
lead_paragraph: David Truong, a Vietnamese antiwar activist whose conviction on espionage charges in the United States in 1978 raised alarms about the federal government’s use of wiretaps without court orders and spurred passage of the 1978 Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act prohibiting such practices, died on June 26 in Penang, Malaysia. He was 68.

headline: Beliefs, Facts and Money
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: How Republicans ignore the evidence and cling to that old-time economic religion.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday The Times published an article by the political scientist Brendan Nyhan about a troubling aspect of the current American scene — the stark partisan divide over issues that should be simply factual, like whether the planet is warming or evolution happened. It’s common to attribute such divisions to ignorance, but as Mr. Nyhan points out, the divide is actually worse among those who are seemingly better informed about the issues.

headline: Two Approaches to Tidal Politics
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: North Carolina is in foolhardy denial about the severity of rising seas, while Virginia’s leaders are forthrightly talking about the problem.
lead_paragraph: The politics of climate change are veering in starkly different directions in the neighboring states of North Carolina and Virginia. Foolhardy denial about the severity of rising seas is underway in North Carolina, where the Republican Legislature, prodded by tourism-dependent coastal counties and alarmed homeowners, ordered a state commission of experts to soften its estimate that coastal waters could rise 39 inches by the end of the century. The commission was told to revise its outlook, take into account dissenting views of climate change and produce a forecast of no more than 30 years — in hopes of keeping the estimated sea-level rise to no more than eight inches.

headline: Reining In the Drones
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The grave problems raised by this lethal technology need to be addressed by the Obama administration, as a bipartisan panel has just made clear.
lead_paragraph: For all the slick technology, there are grave moral and legal questions going unanswered in the government’s use of armed drones to kill people considered terrorist threats. The problems involving these secretive executions are ably underlined by a bipartisan panel of military and intelligence veterans who warn in a new report that without adequate controls and public accountability, the United States could be on a “slippery slope” into a form of perpetual warfare that invites other nations to follow suit and never explain themselves.

headline: The Risks of Hospital Mergers

abstract: When two top names in health care formed an alliance in Massachusetts, it did not turn out well for consumers.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, it looks as if Massachusetts made a serious mistake in 1994 when it let its two most prestigious (and costly) hospitals — Massachusetts General Hospital and Brigham and Women’s Hospital, both affiliated with Harvard — merge into a single system known as Partners HealthCare. Investigations by the state attorney general’s office have documented that the merger gave the hospitals enormous market leverage to drive up health care costs in the Boston area by demanding high reimbursements from insurers that were unrelated to the quality or complexity of care delivered.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) DANGEROUS ACTS STARRING THE UNSTABLE ELEMENTS OF BELARUS (2014) Since 2005, the Belarus Free Theater, including Yana Rusakevich, above, has addressed social and political issues in performances in and around Minsk, the country’s capital and the troupe’s base, often infuriating the government of President Aleksandr Lukashenko but rallying international supporters like Tom Stoppard and Jude Law. This documentary, directed by Madeleine Sackler, presents some of those works, including “Being Harold Pinter,” in which actors struggle to break free of a plastic sheet, and “Minsk 2011,” which pantomimes a police crackdown on a peaceful protest. “The scenes of protest and police brutality include footage gleaned from hundreds of hours filmed in collaboration with a cinematographer in Belarus (whom Ms. Sackler directed over Skype) and then smuggled out of the country,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The Belarus Free Theater, whose members are as articulate as they are talented, continue to spread the message of determined resistance to oppression.”

headline: 1914: Welsh Beats Ritchie on Points
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Boxer “Freddie” Welsh is crowned world lightweight champion in 1914.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The world’s lightweight boxing championship changed hands last night at Olympia, with “Freddy” Welsh, the British champion, winning the premier title from the American holder, “Willie” Ritchie, on points. Approximately eight thousand spectators watched the contest in Olympia. There were many women to lend refinement and beauty to the proceedings, but not so many, I should say, as last week, when “Bombardier” Wells met Colin Bell. This, perhaps, is explained by the fact that the “Bombardier” is an unusually strong drawing card with the feminine boxing enthusiasts. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 8, 1914.

headline: Pope Asks Forgiveness From Victims of Sex Abuse
abstract: In his first meeting with people abused by members of the clergy, Francis led a private Mass and pledged not to tolerate harm done to minors.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis on Monday used his first meeting with victims of clerical sexual abuse to offer his strongest condemnation of a crisis that has shaken the Roman Catholic Church, comparing priests who abuse minors to “a sacrilegious cult,” while begging forgiveness from victims and pledging to crack down on bishops who fail to protect children.

headline: A Louis Vuitton Chronograph Timepiece Inspired by Motor Racing
abstract: The new Tambour Twin Chrono Grand Sport can time two competitors separately and reveal the time differential between the two, all on one easy-to-read dial.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, the men’s fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the photographer Rob Kulisek captures a timepiece from Louis Vuitton.

headline: Setting the Table for Migrating Monarch Butterflies
keywords: ['Butterflies and Moths', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Insects']
abstract: Property owners can help provide migrating and struggling monarch butterflies with a milkweed buffet and then map the insects’ arrival.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t heard of any adult monarch butterflies arriving in the lower Hudson River Valley yet, but at least at our home the table is set for these migrants, which have had a very tough time at both ends of their continent-spanning range in recent years, with suburban sprawl in the Northeast, intensified corn production in the Midwest, deforestation in Mexico.

headline: Iraqi Parliament Wobbles Over Forming Government
abstract: The Parliament first said it would be at least five weeks before members would even try to elect a speaker, then said that members would try to meet Sunday — only five days later than originally planned.
lead_paragraph: Iraq’s political process appeared near collapse for several hours on Monday after the Parliament said it would be at least five weeks before members would even try to elect a speaker, the first step in the process of forming a government.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': A King’s Gotta Eat
abstract: John Lithgow, preparing for “King Lear,” takes his fellow actors out to lunch.
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: European Union Juggles Its Problem Children
abstract: The immediate task facing the European Union could be described as keeping the British in, the Russians out and the Germans down.
lead_paragraph: ROME — NATO’S first secretary general, Gen. Hastings Ismay, once said that the Western defense alliance was created “to keep the Americans in, the Russians out and the Germans down.”

headline: China Denies Entry to an American Scholar Who Spoke Up for a Uighur Colleague
abstract: The American professor said he believed he was being punished for his vocal backing of Ilham Tohti, an ethnic Uighur economics professor.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Elliot Sperling, an American professor, landed here in Beijing after a 12-hour flight from the New York area last weekend, he found himself dragged by border officers into a back room in the airport for an interrogation. They then marched him back to the same United Airlines jet that he had flown in on, despite the fact he had arrived with a valid one-year tourist visa.

headline: Egypt’s President Expresses Disappointment Over Conviction of Three Journalists
abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt appeared to raise the possibility of a presidential pardon for three journalists working for Al Jazeera’s English news channel.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt expressed disappointment in remarks published Monday at the conviction of three journalists from Al Jazeera’s English-language service, saying that their sentences had “negative consequences” and that he preferred that the journalists be deported rather than put on trial.

headline: Analytics: Boomerang Kids Talk Back
abstract: Boomerang kids were among the 1,650 readers who commented on our cover story about young people in their 20s and early 30s who have moved back in with their parents.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the July 6 issue of the magazine.

headline: Not Knut
abstract: Wicksellian? I don’t buy it.
lead_paragraph: Gavyn Davies takes on the de facto debate between the hard-money men at the BIS and the monetary doves, and frames it as a conflict between Keynes and Wicksell. But I don’t think that’s right. The BIS position is in fact just as inconsistent with Wicksell as it is with Keynes. That doesn’t mean that the BIS is wrong (although I believe that it is); it does mean that its view is much stranger and harder to defend than Davies suggests.

headline: Tele2 of Sweden to Sell TeliaSonera Its Norwegian Business
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: Tele2’s sale of its Norwegian business could be a test for European regulators because the deal would leave Norway with only two primary mobile providers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Swedish telecommunications company Tele2 said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Norwegian business to its larger rival TeliaSonera in a deal that values the business at about $744 million.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Insider Trading Case
abstract: A loss in Rengan Rajaratnam’s case would not signal a big reversal in the Justice Department’s insider trading crackdown but could make it more difficult to successfully prosecute some cases, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s long run of insider trading convictions may be near an end as the trial of Rengan Rajaratnam comes to a close this week. Prosecutors have had a series of setbacks that whittled down a case that started out with seven charges and now consists of a single count of conspiracy. And that count only covers losing trades.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Factory Man’
abstract: How to get people to reply to your emails. The value of cyber insurance. And seven things you do not want to hear about small-business tax deductions.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: The Battle Over Reconstruction
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Slavery', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why Lincoln used the controversial pocket veto to kill the Wade-Davis bill.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of July 4, 1864, as Congress was preparing to adjourn for the summer, Abraham Lincoln was busy in an office at the Capitol signing bills. Senator Charles Sumner hovered nearby “in a state of intense anxiety.” George Boutwell, a representative from Massachusetts, paced nervously. Senator Zachariah Chandler of Michigan kept asking anyone who would listen if one particular bill had been signed. Told no, he spoke with Lincoln who, according to the president’s secretary John Hay, said, “this bill was placed before me a few minutes before Congress adjourns. It is a matter of too much importance to be swallowed in that way.”

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A guessing game is centered on the voice behind the “Chicken Fat” song remake in an Apple commercial.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The American Advertising Federation and the Institute for Public Relations announced the winners of several awards.
lead_paragraph: American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven executives as the 2014 inductees into the Advertising Hall of Achievement, for ad professionals who are age 40 or under. The honorees, to be inducted on Nov. 18, are Lauren Connolly, executive vice president and executive creative director at BBDO New York, part of the BBDO North America division of BBDO Worldwide, which is owned by the Omnicom Group; Sarah Hofstetter, chief executive of 360i, part of Dentsu; Ross Martin, executive vice president of Scratch, part of the Viacom Media Networks unit of Viacom; Erika Nardini, chief marketing officer at AOL; Elias Plishner, executive vice president for worldwide digital marketing at Sony Pictures Entertainment, a division of Sony; Bozoma Saint John, global head of marketing at Beats Music, which was recently acquired by Apple; and Jennifer S. Warren, senior vice president and chief marketing officer at RadioShack. Mr. Plishner will also receive the Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award, presented to an inductee for public service.

headline: New Scarlett Work Among Highlights of Ballet Theater Season
abstract: An unnamed new work by the choreographer Liam Scarlett will make its world premiere during the American Ballet Theater season.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater will celebrate its 75th anniversary season with programs that include newly commissioned works and new productions alongside works by choreographers who have been significant in the company’s history – among them Michel Fokine, Frederick Ashton, Agnes de Mille, Jerome Robbins and Antony Tudor. The season will open with a 12-day residency at the David H. Koch Theater, on Oct. 22, 2014, and will run through December 2015.

headline: 1964: Sinatra Shielded From Press
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Frank Sinatra throws firecrackers at paparazzi in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Frank Sinatra, who more often rasps than croons to the press, arrived here yesterday for what he described as a few days’ “amusement.” Casualties from the running ruckus were reported to be two photographers slightly injured in brawls with the bodyguards, known as “gorillas” in French journals. “Get the so-and-so out of my way,” Sinatra shouted at the photographers. He then reportedly pulled a couple of small firecrackers from his pocket, lit and tossed them into the milling throng. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 8, 1964

headline: Grilled Vanilla-Ginger Pineapple
abstract: A sweet and pungent mix of vanilla and ginger syrup adds new dimension to a grilled pineapple.
lead_paragraph: Sherry Yard has a wonderful recipe in her first cookbook, “The Secrets of Baking,” called Roasted Voodoo Vanilla Pineapple. She roasts her pineapple with the dried vanilla pods that you save after you’ve scraped out the seeds, and fresh ginger. She inserts the pods into the flesh of the pineapple, a great idea if you’re roasting the pineapple for a long time.

headline: Grilled Watermelon and Feta Salad
abstract: A winning combination: sweet, juicy watermelon paired with salty cheese and pungent onions.
lead_paragraph: I love watermelon and feta salad, whether the watermelon is grilled or not. The sweet, juicy watermelon against the salty, creamy feta and pungent onions is a winning combination. This version introduces heat and char. Throw the watermelon slices, with the rind, onto the grill after or before you’ve grilled your meat or fish or vegetables. Grill them on both sides until just charred, then cut away the rinds and dice up the melon for the salad.

headline: Crêpes With Grilled Peaches and Apricots
abstract: Crêpes are great to have on hand for desserts, and easy to make with a nonstick or seasoned crêpe pan.
lead_paragraph: Heat deepens the flavor of both peaches and apricots, and grilling adds one more seared dimension. The trick here is to grill the fruit just until it colors and softens, but not to let it burn or collapse. I find that 3 minutes on one side is sufficient for peaches, and 2 minutes for apricots, with about 1 minute on the other side.

headline: New York Summer Stories: It’s Too Hot
abstract: City Room has dug up articles from The New York Times archives during the past week that tell tales of city summers past. We’ll end the series with articles that are all about the heat.
lead_paragraph: City Room has dug up articles from The New York Times archives during the past week that tell tales of city summers past.

headline: Arugula Salad With Grilled Apricots and Pistachios
abstract: Grilling the apricots makes them contrast beautifully with the pungent arugula in this salad.
lead_paragraph: Pungent arugula contrasts beautifully with fruit of all kinds. Grilling the apricots deepens their flavor and makes them stand out against the arugula even more. You’ll be able to make this beautiful salad only during the summer’s short apricot season, and even then, you should buy the fruits at the farmers’ market so you can sample them to make sure they are juicy and sweet.

headline: The Other Greenhouse Gas, Feeling Lucky in Sports, Animal Madness

headline: Grilled Figs With Pomegranate Molasses
abstract: Serve these figs warm as an appetizer with goat cheese, or as a dessert with ricotta or yogurt.
lead_paragraph: These are wonderful. First you toss them in a mix of balsamic vinegar and olive oil, then you grill them on both sides just until they soften and grill marks appear (at which point they are warm all the way through and just beginning to become jammy), then you remove from the grill and brush with pomegranate molasses. It’s a match made in heaven. Serve while the figs are still warm, as a first course with goat cheese, or as a dessert with ricotta or yogurt.

headline: Tentative Results in Afghan Presidential Runoff Spark Protests
abstract: One candidate, Abdullah Abdullah, rejected the tentative results, and some of his powerful supporters talked of forming a breakaway government.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghanistan’s already tumultuous election grew more perilous on Monday after the announcement of preliminary presidential runoff results that were rejected by the candidate Abdullah Abdullah, leading some of his most powerful supporters to call for protests and even the forming of a breakaway government.

headline: British Phenom Charli XCX on Sudden Success, Singing With Iggy Azalea and What Made Madonna Special

headline: Monday Motorsports: Hamilton Benefits From Rosberg’s Hard Luck
abstract: Lewis Hamilton won at the British Grand Prix; at Daytona, Aric Almirola clinched his first Nascar Sprint Cup victory.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton, who assumed the lead when his teammate, Nico Rosberg, dropped out on the 47th lap, took the victory Sunday in the British Grand Prix at Silverstone. The win, coupled with Rosberg’s no-points nonfinish, helped Hamilton close to within four points of his teammate in the season’s driving championship. Rosberg, whose Mercedes had a gearbox failure, had been leading by 29 points entering the race; he had finished every previous grand prix this season.

lead_paragraph: The Glimmerglass Festival, which presents a summer season of opera at the graceful Alice Busch Opera Theater in Cooperstown, N.Y., will celebrate its 40th anniversary in 2015 with four productions, the company said Monday. As in recent seasons the prospectus includes three operas and a musical – although the musical, Leonard Bernstein’s “Candide,” has a foot in both worlds. It started its life in the theater, while in recent decades it has been presented more regularly in opera houses (it was a staple at the New York City Opera).

headline: Pilot Dies in Plane Crash in Long Island Sound
abstract: Investigators were trying to determine the cause of the crash of the single-engine airplane on Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: The pilot of a single-engine airplane died on Monday after his craft crashed into the waters of the Long Island Sound, Coast Guard officials said. Investigators have yet to determine the cause of the crash or to release the name of the pilot.

lead_paragraph: Nathanael Johnson, Grist’s excellent food and sustainability blogger, offer to mediate a conversation between the ethicist and author Clive Hamilton and me over our differing views of this age of us, known increasingly as the Anthropocene.

lead_paragraph: Can too much studying ruin your eyesight? Maybe. A German study has found that the more education a person has, the greater the likelihood that he will be nearsighted.

headline: The 10 Books That Made Debut Novelist Will Chancellor Want to Write One of His Own
abstract: The author of “A Brave Man Seven Storeys Tall” shares his literary influences, which range from David Foster Wallace to Iris Murdoch.
lead_paragraph: The author Will Chancellor spent a decade working on his debut novel, “A Brave Man Seven Storeys Tall” (out tomorrow from Harper), the tale of a would-be Olympian turned one-eyed wanderer named Owen Burr who goes missing, and his professor father who follows his trail to Athens, Berlin and Iceland. Whenever Chancellor lost his path, he turned to these novels for guidance and inspiration. In each of them, he explains, “I saw more of myself and finally accepted that I had to spend my life writing.”

headline: A Video Debut from Rick Rubin’s New Protégés, Angus and Julia Stone
abstract: The Australian brother-sister folk-blues duo premieres the video for “A Heartbreak” from their self-titled album, due out in August.
lead_paragraph: It goes without saying that if the renowned, elusive music producer and Def Jam Records co-founder Rick Rubin gets excited about someone, they’re probably destined for great things. Now the man who turned the Beastie Boys and the Red Hot Chili Peppers into icons has tapped the Australian folk-blues sibling duo Angus and Julia Stone as his new protégés. “It’s few and far between that I hear something that really excites me,” says Rubin, who’s notorious for rarely speaking to the press. “I heard their music and it really moved me. They make the kind of songs that I can listen to over and over again for a long period of time. They have hypnotic, poetic depth.” What Rubin didn’t know when he contacted the pair — who started making music together in 2006 — was that not only did they have no plans to write any further songs at the time, but they flat-out weren’t getting along at all. “It was only when I reached out to them that they decided to get together to make the album we eventually made, and through that process had a family healing and are better friends today than they, I think, have ever been,” Rubin says. “None of this was intentional. It just happened, and it’s a pretty beautiful part of the story.”

He struggles with bipolar disorder, severe anxiety and depression. Like so many patients, he secretly wondered what his therapist thought of him.

lead_paragraph: Meredith Monk will spend next season celebrating the 50th anniversary of her first New York concert – a work called “Break,” at the now defunct Washington Square Gallery, in September 1964 – with concerts all over Manhattan and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The timing could not be better: as the current occupant of the Richard and Barbara Debs Composer’s Chair at Carnegie Hall, Ms. Monk has a spotlight and resources greater than she has had for most of the 50 years since that first show.

lead_paragraph: Long-simmered tomato sauces are just right in winter, when you’re looking to spend hours next to the stove in the company of a steaming, bubbling pot. But summer demands something brighter and fresher, dishes that feature the season’s ripest produce but do so with minimal cooking time.

headline: The Letters That Warren G. Harding’s Family Didn’t Want You to See
abstract: The strikingly graphic correspondence from Harding, perhaps the worst chief executive in U.S. history, to his longtime mistress.
lead_paragraph: Warren Harding is not the most beloved of American presidents. Two of the earliest polls to assess presidential popularity, conducted in 1948 and 1962, ranked him last and last among chief executives. Harding served only briefly, from 1921 to 1923, before he died in office, but his administration has been widely regarded as visionless, ineffectual and corrupt. He slashed immigration quotas, appointed his cronies — one of whom, his secretary of the interior, accepted bribes from oil companies in what became known as the Teapot Dome scandal — and brought an end to the famously reform-minded eras of Teddy Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson. Perhaps the best that can be said about Harding is that he seems to have been conscious of his defects. “I am not fit for this office and should never have been here,” he once conceded.

lead_paragraph: This past weekend, Yvette Monahan published a book of photographs about a rural area in south-central France between the Mediterranean Sea and the Pyrenees mountains. At the region’s center is a mountain called Bugarach. Monahan spent a year taking pictures of the mountain and its surroundings, which have a rich mythical history. I was enchanted by the photos in her book, ‘‘The Time of Dreaming the World Awake,’’ when I saw them recently, so I reached out to her and got her to tell me what sparked her interest in this French spot:

lead_paragraph: The French Romantic Théodore Géricault will forever be identified with “The Raft of the Medusa,” a wrenching, ripped-from-the-headlines painting of disaster at sea that set off a political controversy in France and has since inspired contemporary artists like Martin Kippenberger and Thomas Hirschhorn. But he was also drawn to quieter subjects, to judge from an intriguing show of drawings, watercolors and small oil paintings.

headline: ‘Supports/Surfaces’ at Canada
abstract: Canada, working with the Paris-based Galerie Bernard Ceysson, is staging the first American survey of some painters of the relatively unknown French Supports/Surfaces art movement.
lead_paragraph: Big, shiny Chelsea galleries are not the only ones that can present missing chunks of recent art history. Canada, working with the Paris-based Galerie Bernard Ceysson, is staging the first American survey of some painters of the relatively unknown French Supports/Surfaces art movement, which was active in the late 1960s, ’70s and early ’80s. With so much of current abstraction in back-to-basics mode, the show is timely, revealing the strengths and pitfalls of its artists’ approach. Some of this stuff looks alive and pertinent; some of it looks ordinary and inert.

headline: Social Anxiety
abstract: For some people, social media offer a respite from shyness. Others say Facebook is just as bad — or worse than — real life.
lead_paragraph: Does social media help shy people open up? Some relish the chance to connect with others without the awkwardness of the face to face. But for others, the Internet is just as bad as the physical world — or even worse. And the question of shyness may open up into bigger questions about how we experience social life online.

headline: Emily Mae Smith: ‘Novelty Court’
abstract: Emily Mae Smith’s Pop-style paintings at Junior Projects comment on sex and gender with satirical ingenuity.
lead_paragraph: Bucking the messy abstraction trend, Emily Mae Smith’s Pop-style paintings comment on sex and gender with satirical ingenuity. Two posterlike works on view in this pint-size gallery mimic the cover of The Studio, a late-Victorian art magazine, with the title lettered at the top and the Art Nouveau-style image of a female artist painting in her studio rendered in thin black lines on white grounds. To each of these genteel images, Ms. Smith has added the realistic, semi-transparent color image of a much-enlarged piece of fruit — a banana and a tomato — highlighting the idea of the woman as a desirable commodity.

headline: Hitting the Ceiling, Then Moving Up
abstract: On “1000 Forms of Fear,” Sia puts pop-production firepower behind lyrics that see romance as a life-or-death battle.
lead_paragraph: Sia goes over the top almost immediately on her new album, “1000 Forms of Fear.” When the chorus of “Chandelier” arrives, a simulated orchestra crashes in, and her voice appears in a strenuous high register, belting, “I’m gonna swing from the chandelier, ” with an I-dare-myself upward leap on the last syllable of “chandelier.” Still aloft, she repeats “from the chandelier” and leaps even higher. It’s showy, impulsive, shrewd, gripping and maybe a little unhinged, and so is the rest of the album.

headline: Youth Tsunami in Arab World
abstract: “The New Arabs” by Juan Cole assesses Arab youth movements.
lead_paragraph: These days, alarming news continues to spill out of the Middle East. Syria’s continuing civil war has claimed tens of thousands of civilian lives. Iraq — where the prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, has stoked sectarian conflict by refusing to form an inclusive government — is hurtling toward civil war, as Sunni militants, led by the Qaeda splinter group ISIS, have moved close to Baghdad. Farther east, the Taliban are resurgent in Afghanistan.

headline: Back to the Beginning of Elemental Emotions
abstract: The Belgian contemporary choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker is presenting four early works at the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: Late one night on Second Avenue, the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker practiced walking and turning in the studios of New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. To the music of Steve Reich and Bach — she couldn’t decide which to use — she played around with permutations of these elemental steps, adding a spiraling torso or swinging arms on top of precisely placed feet.

headline: Would Warren G. Harding Have Fared Better in 1971?
abstract: What The New York Times editorial board of 1971 predicted about how Harding’s lusty letters would go over in 2014.
lead_paragraph: As Gail Collins teased in her column this weekend, the magazine has obtained access to a trove of letters that Harding wrote to his longtime mistress, Carrie Fulton Phillips, between 1910 and 1920. People have known about these letters for half a century — they were front-page news when they were discovered in 1964 — but they’ve mostly been locked up until now. In 1971, the Harding family agreed to donate the letters to the Library of Congress (also front-page news) on the condition that they remain sealed for 50 years.

headline: At Dior, Historical References Translated to Modern Style
abstract: Raf Simons paired an ornately embroidered justacorps jacket and gilet set with a simple black top and trousers for a chic look that didn’t feel the least bit dated.
lead_paragraph: As editors piled in for the Christian Dior fall 2014 couture presentation today, taking in the classic white orchids that lined the walls around the futuristic runway space (shaped a bit like a round U.F.O.), the collection’s theme — a connection between old and new, past and present — began to make itself apparent. The show began, and the house’s artistic director Raf Simons launched his audience into a sort of time travel with his range of references. He embellished archetypal silhouettes like loose, flapperesque dresses; wide-through-the-hips, Marie Antoinette-style gowns; and baggy, one-piece flight suits with anachronistic details like sophisticated embroidery and fresh prints. Among the many knockout looks in the show, it was hard to ignore the ornate justacorps jacket with a matching gilet underneath. Finished off with a simple black top and trousers, it made for a truly modern ensemble that ushered the couture era right into the now.

headline: Earthlike Planets May Be Merely an Illusion

lead_paragraph: In 2010, astronomers were stirred by the discovery of Gliese 581g, a distant Earthlike planet that orbited its star just closely enough to allow for surface water, and possibly life.

headline: Stolen From Cradle, Now Back to Rage
abstract: Kathryn Prescott stars in “Finding Carter,” a new show on MTV that follows a teenager who returns to the family from which she was stolen.
lead_paragraph: Young adult television typically cleaves into two camps — it’s either about the absurd comedy of teenage life, or its unending tragedy. The plotlines aren’t that different, but in the first category, characters respond to pain with charm and wit, while in the other, their shoulders droop, and they stew in bad lighting.

headline: An Undead Tale of the Teenage Years
abstract: “Let the Right One In,” at the Apollo Theater in London, turns your emotions inside out in a way you probably haven’t experienced since you were a teenager.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — And just when you thought you’d had your fill of young vampires in love, along comes a ravishing little romance of the undead that’s guaranteed to warm — and break — your heart, even as it chills your blood. “Let the Right One In,” which is bringing limelight to endless night at the Apollo Theater here, turns your emotions inside out in a way you probably haven’t experienced since you were a teenager.

headline: Acropolis Maidens Glow Anew
abstract: After a painstaking restoration, five of the famed Caryatid statues of ancient Greece are star attractions at the Acropolis Museum in Athens.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — For 2,500 years, the six sisters stood unflinching atop the Acropolis, as the fires of war blazed around them, bullets nicked their robes, and bombs scarred their curvaceous bodies. When one of them was kidnapped in the 19th century, legend had it that the other five could be heard weeping in the night.

headline: An Athlete Who Needs More Than a Ponytail
abstract: The W.N.B.A. player Skylar Diggins’s real splurge is her hair, which she changes often.
lead_paragraph: Skylar Diggins, 23, is a point guard for the Tulsa Shock. She was a basketball star at Notre Dame, where she holds the record as the all-time scoring leader. These days, when not in uniform (the Women’s National Basketball Association regular season runs through mid-August), she might be modeling for Nike or appearing at red carpet events with Jay Z and her Roc Nation management agency. A native of South Bend, Ind., Ms. Diggins now lives in Tulsa, Okla.

headline: Ancient Bird Had Some Feathers Just for Show
abstract: A new fossil of a well-known early bird could help shed light on the evolution of feathers, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: German scientists found a new specimen of Archaeopteryx, the 150-million-year-old winged creature thought to represent the transition from dinosaurs to birds, with well-preserved feather markings. The bird, described in the journal Nature, had feathers on its hind limbs that researchers said were more likely used for display than for flight.

headline: Germany Proposes a Road Tax Aimed Primarily at Foreigners

headline: Giving Tofu the New Look It Deserves
abstract: In an era when many cooks are looking to cut back on meat, it’s an ingredient worth taking seriously. Finally.
lead_paragraph: It’s not likely that tofu will become anyone’s favorite food; this we know. Those who grew up in households where it was well prepared may relish it, but for the rest of us it’s a bit of a requisite, something we think we “should” eat in place of chicken or eggs whenever we can stomach it.

lead_paragraph: Climate scientists long ago settled among themselves the question of whether human emissions of greenhouse gases are a problem, concluding that we are running some grave risks. But the field still features vigorous debate about how bad global warming will get, how quickly, and how to combat it.

abstract: There are three major differences between the way e-commerce works in the United States and in China.
lead_paragraph: There has been much buzz about the initial public offering of Alibaba, China’s e-commerce giant. The company is the top player in an increasingly crowded and diverse Chinese online sales market that features corporations looking to order large quantities of manufactured goods; small business buying items in lots of, say, 25 pieces; and consumers looking for a single product.

headline: A California Oil Field Yields Another Prized Commodity

abstract: Oil producers and farmers have competed for water during the state’s drought, but an oil field in the Central Valley is aiding agricultural irrigation.
lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The 115-year-old Kern River oil field unfolds into the horizon, thousands of bobbing pumpjacks seemingly occupying every corner of a desert landscape here in California’s Central Valley. A contributor to the state’s original oil boom, it is still going strong as the nation’s fifth-largest oil field, yielding 70,000 barrels a day.

abstract: If the World Cup is supposed to be soccer’s ultimate comparison of team skills, why do games keep coming down to “measurement errors,” or luck?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been watching the World Cup with some frustrated American social scientists. When they see an underdog team triumph with a miraculous rebound or an undeserved penalty kick, they don’t jump up and scream “Goooaaalll!” They just shake their heads and mutter, “Measurement error.”
