headline: Venezuela: Stolen Matisse Painting Returned
abstract: Venezuelan authorities on Monday welcomed home a painting by the artist Henri Matisse more than a decade after it had disappeared from a Caracas museum.
lead_paragraph: Venezuelan authorities on Monday welcomed home a painting by the artist Henri Matisse more than a decade after it had disappeared from a Caracas museum. The painting, “Odalisque in Red Pants,” was recovered in 2012 by F.B.I. agents in Miami when they arrested two people and charged them with trying to sell the long-missing artwork. Officials do not know when it was stolen from the Contemporary Art Museum of Caracas, where it was part of the museum’s collection, because the thieves put up a fake version of the painting in its place — a ruse that was discovered in 2002. Photographs showed that the fake, which experts said was crudely executed, was in place at least as early as 2000. News of the painting’s recovery two years ago caused a stir in Venezuela, and officials on Monday made a show of bringing it home, with a live television broadcast from the Caracas airport. When it was recovered, American officials said the painting was worth $3 million.

headline: India: Shariah Courts Rebuffed
abstract: India’s Supreme Court ruled Monday that Shariah courts, which are run by the dictates of Islamic law, had no legal status and were not legally binding.
lead_paragraph: India’s Supreme Court ruled Monday that Shariah courts, which are run by the dictates of Islamic law, had no legal status and were not legally binding. In the court’s judgment, fatwas, or orders declared by Muslim clerics, were deemed to have “no legal status” though they were not found to be illegal, and individuals may follow the Shariah rulings if they wish. The court said, however, that a religious leader “has no authority or powers to impose his opinion and enforce his fatwa on anyone,” adding that legally sanctioned fatwas have “no place in independent India under our constitutional scheme.”

headline: A Victory for Same-Sex Unions
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'International Relations']
abstract: The marriages of gay men and lesbians who work for the United Nations Secretariat will be recognized by the organization if they have been wed in a jurisdiction where same-sex unions are legal.
lead_paragraph: The marriages of gay men and lesbians who work for the United Nations Secretariat will be recognized by the organization if they have been wed in a jurisdiction where same-sex unions are legal, including New York. Previously, the secretariat, the body of employees who work under the secretary general, deferred to the laws of a staff member’s home country in classifying his or her marital status: Same-sex unions were recognized by the United Nations only if the employee’s home country deemed such marriages to be legal. The change, said the organization’s deputy spokesman, Farhan Haq, reflects Secretary General Ban Ki-moon’s support for “greater equality for all staff.” The new rule was announced in an internal staff bulletin, Mr. Haq said Monday. It expands the civil rights of gay and lesbian employees, even as many of the United Nations’ member states, including Uganda, whose foreign minister assumes the presidency of the United Nations General Assembly in September, crack down on their own gay and lesbian citizens.

headline: U.N. Report Calls for Public Sanitation Funding
abstract: Nearly one billion people worldwide defecate in the open, the United Nations said in a report released Monday, which calls for greater effort and funding to redress inadequate sanitation.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one billion people worldwide defecate in the open, and such bad sanitation practices can endanger the health of children who live and play nearby, the United Nations said in a report released Monday. The report, which calls for greater effort and funding to redress inadequate sanitation, measures the world’s progress on the so-called Millennium Development Goals intended to improve the health and well-being of the global poor. The report notes some advances: A greater number of children are living past their fifth birthday. As many girls as boys are enrolled in primary school. Extreme poverty has been halved since 1990. But about one in five people in the developing world still lives on less than $1.25 a day; about 25 percent of the world’s children suffer from stunted growth, reflecting the effects of chronic hunger; and nearly half of all pregnant women did not see a doctor during their pregnancy.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans chose Cleveland on Tuesday for their 2016 national convention, with the hope of appealing to Rust Belt voters who eluded them in the last two presidential elections, and an acknowledgment of the political value of ending the party’s nomination process sooner.

headline: Japan Makes an Asian Pivot
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reinterpreted Japan’s pacifist Constitution, freeing its military to play a more assertive role in Asia, JAKE FLANIGAN writes. Its yet another shakeup in an increasingly tense part of the world.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reinterpreted Japan’s pacifist Constitution, freeing its military for the first time in over 60 years to play a more assertive role in the Asia-Pacific region. The move comes as another shakeup in an increasingly tense part of the world, marked by the growing influence and military might of China, President Obama’s pivot to Asia and the perennial saber-rattling of North Korea.

headline: On Creating a Race Beat

headline: In Dividing Up Extra Tax Spoils, Risks for New Investors
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']

lead_paragraph: Initial public offerings that generate extra tax spoils are in the spotlight. Two private equity firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Silver Lake, are listing the web-hosting company GoDaddy three years after buying it for $2.25 billion. The use of what’s called an Up-C structure means the company will go public with big potential tax deductions on its books. In GoDaddy’s case, investors and sponsors will both benefit. But other I.P.O.s with Up-Cs have more dubious arrangements.

headline: Summer Camp: The Debate
abstract: Should you send your children away to summer camp? Reasonable parents can disagree, and Bruce Feiler and I do.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Bruce Feiler and I are arguing a new question on Room for Debate today: To Camp, or Not to Camp? His 9-year-old daughters left last week for what he hopes will be their first summer of sleep-away camp; they’ll be gone for seven weeks. My children are home and largely (although far from totally) unscheduled. Apart from some assorted day camps, they’re spending the summer wandering around the house, complaining that “there’s nothing to do” until they disappear and discover that there actually is. Bruce and I found that our family differences might have their roots in tradition (I never went to camp, he did), but that we also saw summer freedom very differently. How will your kids spend the summer, and why? Go read and, please, weigh in.

headline: Your Eyes Are Happier Than Your Stomach
abstract: Social media can make food pictures popular, but some chefs seem to be sacrificing the flavor of a meal for the Instagram photo of the dish.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago at a restaurant that regularly tweets photos of dishes as lush as one of Monet’s lily ponds, I found myself poking cautiously at perfect circles of glossy black sauce, discs of potato purée that looked like white roses and cylinders of gnocchi so tiny they seemed to have been pushed out of a drinking straw. Tiny, delicate flowers and tender sprigs of leaves gently rested here and there as if a woodland nymph had casually tossed them from a basket before running off to play hide-and-seek with a den of baby field mice. The dish was definitely ready for its close-up. It was also, by and large, very cold — no surprise given how long it must have taken to squeeze and tweeze everything into position.

headline: As Chanel Proves, It’s Chic to Match Your Bag to Your Dress
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld’s fall 2014 couture collection celebrated the marriage of simple, modern design with ornate 17th- and 18th-century embellishments.
lead_paragraph: The fashion set was eager to see what Karl Lagerfeld would come up with after last season’s suburban supermarket extravaganza of a runway. His fall/winter 2014 couture presentation held today didn’t compete with that infamous show, but instead fell on the other end of the eye-candy spectrum, offering a look that was restrained yet undeniably chic. The collection’s pared-back sensibility was inspired by a now-defunct 1930s Le Corbusier apartment on the Champs Élysées. Like that apartment’s mash-up of design motifs — a gold baroque mirror that sat atop a modern outdoor fireplace, for example — Lagerfeld’s designs married the old and new. Case in point: this modern-silhouetted maxi dress with ornate gold embroidery. Paired with a coordinating messenger bag, it made for a standout look that lent fresh new meaning to the term “matchy-matchy.”

headline: Jake Hoffman (Yes, He’s the Son of Dustin) Makes His Debut as a Director
abstract: The 33-year-old writer-director, who has been acting since childhood, is premiering his first film, “Asthma,” at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival in the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: If Jake Hoffman looks familiar, it’s not just because of his striking resemblance to a certain icon of the silver screen with whom he shares a surname. The 33-year-old — who, yes, happens to be the son of Dustin Hoffman — has been acting since the age of 7, when he appeared in his father’s classic film “Rain Man” (he was an extra eating pancakes in a diner). Since then, he has been cast in “I Heart Huckabees,” “Arrested Development” and “The Wolf of Wall Street” (in which he had a small but memorable role as the shoe designer Steve Madden) and he even played his own father’s grandson in HBO’s ill-fated series “Luck.” Since graduating from NYU’s film school in 2003, Hoffman has tried his hand at writing and directing, and completed a trio of short films. Now, with the release of his debut full-length feature, “Asthma” — which he wrote, produced and directed, and which premiered today at the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival in the Czech Republic — Hoffman is staking out a film career on his own terms.

The verdict, which she learned about in a phone call on Monday, also calls for her to receive 50 lashes.

The first of these cloudlike confections popped up last night during the Giambattista Valli finale, which consisted of a small series of ombré gowns (and evening skirts, which were paired simply with poplin shirts). Then this morning at Chanel, Karl Lagerfeld interrupted his parade of white dresses with a soft, billowing light-blue dress complete with equally full feather sleeves. And finally, at this evening’s Armani Privé show, one of the many red dress options from the designer included a voluminous strapless number topped with an equally dramatic veil.

A man and a woman, on the run from something (the police? a criminal gang?), burst in and demand shelter. Deaf to the writer’s protests, the man leaves the woman — he says she’s his sister — in the other man’s care, promising to come back soon.

The young woman (in the slide show) carried a bag from Nasir Mazhar, a London designer known for his logo-heavy brand of club-kid streetwear. Multiple attendees were spotted with Chanel’s graffiti-printed number . Any of the bags here can be a playful accessory for travel or a day at the beach now, or serve as that all-important conversation starter come back-to-school season.

lead_paragraph: Black and Hispanic defendants are more likely to be held in jail before trial and more likely to be offered plea bargains that include a prison sentence than whites and Asians charged with the same crimes, according to a two-year study of prosecutions handled by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.

headline: More Charges to Come Against Libyan Over Benghazi

abstract: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it intended to file additional charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, the man being held in the 2012 attacks that killed the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, and three others.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said Tuesday that it intended to file additional charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, the man being held in the 2012 attacks that killed the United States ambassador in Benghazi, Libya, and three others. At a hearing in Washington, the government said several factors would determine when it would file the charges, but it did not say what those factors were. Judge Christopher R. Cooper of United States District Court said the case would proceed slowly because of its complexity. He scheduled a status hearing for Sept. 9. A week ago, a magistrate judge ruled that Mr. Abu Khattala should remain in government custody and without bond.

headline: Afghanistan: Taliban Strike in Deadly Bombing
abstract: In one of the deadliest Taliban attacks in recent months, 10 Afghan civilians, two Afghan police officers and four Czech soldiers were killed when a suicide bomber riding a bicycle attacked a village north of Kabul.
lead_paragraph: In one of the deadliest Taliban attacks in recent months, 10 Afghan civilians, two Afghan police officers and four Czech soldiers were killed when a suicide bomber riding a bicycle attacked a village north of Kabul. The attack occurred Tuesday morning, as the soldiers were assessing the security situation in the village of Qalander Khel of Bagram district in Parwan Province. Such attacks have grown increasingly rare as international forces have withdrawn, or stayed within their bases.

In this home makeover show, Carter Oosterhouse, above, oversees three design teams as they each renovate a dilapidated home in a distressed neighborhood in Cincinnati while living together in the house in an effort to raise the area’s property values. Each week the teams will transform a different room on limited time and money, with the designer Kathy Kuo and the Cincinnati-based house flipper Jim Bronzie judging the results. The team that most increases the value of its home will receive $50,000 and a feature on the Dwell magazine website, whose editor in chief, Amanda Dameron, will judge the finale. In “Tiny House Nation,” at 10, John Weisbarth and Zack Giffin tour ingenious small spaces — among them, a micro-apartment in New York City, a transformed caboose car in Montana and a mini-mobile home for taking road trips — while helping families construct their dream dwellings in no more than 300 square feet.

lead_paragraph: “For-profit colleges are lobbying hard to weaken rules proposed by the Obama administration that would deny federal aid to career training programs that burden students with crippling debt and worthless credentials,” writes The New York Times editorial board. Citing the example of Corinthian Colleges, one of the country’s largest operators of for-profit colleges and trade schools, the board argues that such “rules need to be strengthened and that federal oversight generally needs to be broadened.” Corinthian Colleges relies so completely on funding from the government to cover its operating budget that a delay in the delivery of federal aid as part of an investigation threatened to shut down the chain entirely. “If Congress required such operations to get more of their revenue from private sources, then more institutions would be forced to produce higher-quality programs that students would be willing to pay for,” the board writes.

abstract: Three new crafts books suggest ideas for a range of activities to inspire young artists during their summer vacation.
lead_paragraph: Summer vacation offers children unstructured time rich with opportunities for creative projects, and three new crafts books suggest ideas for a range of activities to inspire young artists and their adult assistants. There’s no dearth of crafting books on the market, but as with cookbooks, novelty makes old techniques seem freshly appealing. Parents will recall from their own childhoods the basic skills required: cutting, gluing, taping, tracing, sewing and pom-pom making. But even pom-pom pros can use a refresher course every couple of decades, and the craftiest readers may find a few tricks to be learned from experts who take their projects to new heights.

abstract: When a little bit of religious residue is worse than no religion at all.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, I wrote a column on a crucial sociological distinction between religious affiliation and religious practice in American life — specifically, the way that the strong association between social capital and religious faith only really obtains for people who are active in their faith, and the way that a great deal of social ruin in our nation is concentrated in communities (mostly working class) where religion has half-retreated, leaving a kind of identitarian, Christian-ish residue that either has no real effect on people’s choices or (possibly) shapes them for the worse.

headline: Classical Playlist: ‘West Side Story,’ Schubert, Haydn and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BERNSTEIN: ‘West Side Story’Alexandra Silber, Cheyenne Jackson and others.San Francisco Symphony, Michael Tilson Thomas, conductor(SFSmedia; two CDs)Do we need another recording of “West Side Story” performed by a full symphonic orchestra? Absolutely when it’s this one, taken from live performances in 2013 that Michael Tilson Thomas conducted with the San Francisco Symphony at the orchestra’s home hall. The cast, led by Alexandra Silber as Maria and Cheyenne Jackson as Tony, who bring youthful ardor, beguiling voices and dramatic immediacy to their roles, is ideal. This is a nearly complete version of Bernstein’s score, with lyrics by Stephen Sondheim. The symphonic richness of the playing is an asset. But even better is the stylish naturalness and clarity that Mr. Thomas draws from the players, and the inspired cast. (Anthony Tommasini)

Mr. Harris, who has a pleasantly husky baritone, is offhandedly suave. Cool but winning, he doesn’t go in for seductive wiles or conspicuous emotional display. His pianism, although technically proficient, is relatively impersonal. He swings steadily in phrases that travel long and winding roads to their destination.

headline: 1939: Spinsters Block Tulsa Airport

As soon as the aerials went up, the Civil Aeronautics Authority classified them as a “grave hazard” and forbade the use of the airport. Threats had no effect. For the time being, the sisters are enjoying tranquillity, and the American Airlines, which use the adjacent landing field, admit they are stymied. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 10, 1914

abstract: The Senate voted to confirm Julián Castro as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, catapulting the young mayor of San Antonio to the national stage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Wednesday to confirm Julián Castro as secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, catapulting the young mayor of San Antonio to the national stage and putting him in charge of the agency as it grapples with a sluggish housing recovery and efforts in Congress to overhaul the nation’s housing finance system.

headline: Fed, Confident in Economy, Details End of Bond-Buying Program
keywords: ['Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The decision signals the end of one of the central bank’s most aggressive efforts to stimulate the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it planned to stop adding to its bond holdings in October, in a sign of its confidence that the economy is gaining strength even as the central bank gradually withdraws its support.

headline: Sultry Univision Ads Help Steer Women From Soaps to Soccer
abstract: Univision has benefited from increased female viewership for World Cup games after a series of ads emphasized the soccer players’ manly qualities.
lead_paragraph: In the months before the World Cup, Univision began to unveil its plan to reach female viewers, many of whom are devoted to its daytime talk shows and telenovelas.

headline: Britain to Review I.P.O. Process After Criticism of Royal Mail Offering
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The review will examine the process used to sell public assets, including the method of assessing investors’ interest and share price movement of private and public sector assets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British government began an “informal review” on Wednesday of how it pursues initial public offerings of government assets in the wake of questions about whether the Royal Mail offering last year was properly priced.

headline: Parent on a Smartphone, With Almost No Guilt
abstract: Smartphones can make us more present as parents—or not.
lead_paragraph: Here’s why my colleague Farhad Manjoo spent last week alternating between his smartphone and his 3-year-old, and why he says You Don’t Have to Feel Very Guilty About Using Your Smartphone While Parenting.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Flat-Footed Boots on Couture Runways
abstract: At the fall/winter 2014 couture shows, a crop of modest footwear balanced out decadent, over-the-top looks.
lead_paragraph: Last season’s couture tennis shoe is this season’s modest flat boot. It first appeared in the fall/winter 2014 couture shows at Atelier Versace, an unexpected runway for such tame footwear. (To her credit, Donatella Versace’s suede mid-calf gogo boots were topped with dazzling diamanté buckles.) The trend then began to take shape at Schiaparelli, where perhaps the only toned-down aspect of the designer Marco Zanini’s fanciful and eclectic presentation were the short pointed boots in luxurious monochromatic crocodile and printed leopard. And at Chanel, a single over-the-knee leather boot style, which appeared once in buff and once in black, broke up the onslaught of flat sandals with ribbons that tied around the ankle.

headline: With Eye on LeBron James, Cavaliers Trade Guard to Nets
abstract: The Nets reached a deal on Wednesday to acquire Jarrett Jack and Sergey Karasev from Cleveland in a three-team trade that included sending Marcus Thornton to Boston.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Nets appeared to solve their problem at backup point guard Wednesday by reaching an agreement to acquire Jarrett Jack from Cleveland in a three-team trade that had everything to do with the Cavaliers’ eagerness to create maximum financial flexibility in their pursuit of LeBron James, a free agent.

headline: ‘Short Film’ by Springsteen and Zimny Unveiled
abstract: A film by Bruce Springsteen and Thom Zimny centers on the song “Hunter of Invisible Game.”
lead_paragraph: At the end of June, Bruce Springsteen put a teaser on his website, asking his fans to return for the premiere of “Hunter of Invisible Game,” which he described as “a short film by Thom Zimny and Bruce Springsteen.” That raised a few questions: the title is that of one of the more darkly introspective songs on Mr. Springsteen’s most recent album, “High Hopes,” suggesting that he might be simply unveiling a promotional clip.

headline: Adidas Joins Wearable Stampede With Fitness Tracker
abstract: While the wearables business is getting increasingly crowded, Adidas says it can carve out a niche for itself by placing a personal fitness coach on peoples’ wrists.
lead_paragraph: There are a few things that should give pause to Adidas, the footwear and apparel maker, as it enters the so-called wearables market.

headline: Falcone’s Hedge Fund Files Suit Against Dish Network Over LightSquared
abstract: The legal action is the latest chapter in a bitter fight between two billionaires who have traded lawsuits while the wireless broadband company tries to exit bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: A battle between two billionaires over LightSquared, the wireless broadband company, has played out for months in bankruptcy court. Now one of the billionaires, Philip A. Falcone, has picked a fight with his adversary in a new arena.

headline: Pope Francis Names New Leadership for Vatican Bank
abstract: The pope continued his drive to revamp the Vatican’s murky finances, a source of displeasure for many cardinals and a target of financial regulators.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis continued his efforts to modernize and reorganize the Vatican finances on Wednesday, by appointing a new leadership for the scandal-tainted Vatican Bank, streamlining other operations and signaling future changes to the church’s global media operations.

headline: Suits and Sneakers in the Bronx
abstract: Javier Lopez, who works in politics, considers his personal style formal, but with his own spin on it.
lead_paragraph: Southern Boulevard in the Bronx is a shopping hub for jeans, gold chains and sneakers, with Jordans being elevated to a wardrobe staple. When the Bronx native Javier Lopez is not working in politics, he stays loyal to his sneakerhead roots, matching his outfits with a pair from his collection of nearly 100. This interview has been edited.

headline: Argentina vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
abstract: Argentina beat the Netherlands on penalties, 4-2, after 120 scoreless minutes, and will play Germany in Sunday’s final with the World Cup at stake.
lead_paragraph: Argentina beat the Netherlands on penalties, 4-2, after 120 scoreless minutes, and will play Germany in Sunday’s final with the World Cup at stake.

headline: A Growing Arsenal of Homegrown Rockets Encounters Israel’s Iron Dome
abstract: In some ways, the latest battle is between the increased sophistication of rockets fired by militants in Gaza and Israel’s Iron Dome defense system.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For the moment at least, the hostilities between Israel and Gaza are partly a fight between rockets and interceptors — between the varied and improved arsenal of rockets possessed by Hamas and its allies, like Islamic Jihad, and the antimissile systems of Israel.

headline: Draghi Calls for Closer Economic Integration in Europe
abstract: Europe’s central bank chief said that countries that lag economically put the whole euro zone at risk, and should be compelled to make changes.
lead_paragraph: The president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, said on Wednesday that countries in the euro zone should be compelled to take steps to improve the performance of their economies in the same way that they are already required to observe rules on government spending.

headline: Greece Plans Another Bond Offering
abstract: The country plans a new issue of three-year bonds in an attempt to capitalize on the growing demand for short-term euro-zone debt.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Three months after returning to international bond markets following a long exile, Greece said on Wednesday that it was planning to sell bonds again in an effort to capitalize on the growing demand for short-term euro zone debt.

headline: Argentines Sing of Brazil’s Humiliation, Loudly and in Rio
abstract: Since they arrived in Brazil last month for the World Cup, Argentina’s fans, and even the players, have been singing a song that predicted humiliation for Brazilians.
lead_paragraph: As the Brazil team has come spectacularly undone in the World Cup, the pain for the host country has been compounded by the prospect that its hated rival, Argentina, could still lift the championship trophy on Sunday in Rio de Janeiro’s fabled Estádio do Maracanã, after Argentina won a tense semifinal against the Netherlands in a penalty shootout on Wednesday afternoon.

headline: For Vaporizers, Smoke Means Fire
abstract: Vaporizer companies are altering their marketing game.
lead_paragraph: Hip-hop artists like Wiz Khalifa rap about them regularly. If you pay attention, you’ll see one tucked into the palm of a passer-by’s hand on the street. Whoopi Goldberg wrote fawningly about hers, and shortly after, The New Yorker posted an article titled, “Vaping for Yuppies.”

headline: Handy Liquor Bar in SoHo
abstract: The cozy cocktail den was opened in April by the night-life swami Matt Levine.
lead_paragraph: SoHo’s night life dwindled last year when several well-liked bars, including subMercer, Ñ and Milady’s, abruptly closed, leaving the neighborhood vulnerable to sticky-fingered Cronut pilgrims and fro-yo fiends. Bringing much-needed adult refreshment to this district is Handy Liquor Bar, a cozy cocktail den opened in April by the night-life swami Matt Levine.

headline: Marriage Gone Sour? Go Home to Ma Bell
abstract: In Rainbow Rowell’s “Landline,” a TV writer whose marriage is failing finds a possible way to fix things by dialing a rotary phone and revisiting the past.
lead_paragraph: From the Oz stories to Harry Potter, there have always been books that attracted a crossover following of adults and young readers. Most recently, the runaway popularity of John Green’s “The Fault in Our Stars,” and then anything else John Green has written, more than proved the point. Stephen Colbert defined the phenomenon this way: “As far as I can tell, a young adult novel is a regular novel that people actually read.”

headline: Bieber to Be Charged in Egging of Neighbor’s House
abstract: Justin Bieber is to be charged with misdemeanor vandalism, months after eggs were thrown at a neighbor’s home.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles County district attorney’s office took its time: back in February, a spokesman for the sheriff’s department said it had ample evidence that Justin Bieber egged a neighbor’s house, causing what the department estimated at $20,000 of damage. But it took until now for formal charges to be filed. That is expected to happen on Wednesday at Superior Court in Van Nuys, Calif., where Mr. Bieber is to be charged with a single count of misdemeanor vandalism, The Associated Press reported.

headline: An Ad Campaign for Whistleblowers
abstract: Posters in Washington, D.C., urge federal bureaucrats to blow the whistle on bad stuff happening at the office.
lead_paragraph: Federal bureaucrats commuting to work in the nation’s capital are finding fresh food for thought as they wait for the bus — glossy six-foot posters with an open invitation to blow the whistle on bad stuff happening at the office. Daniel Ellsberg, the patriarch of whistle-blowers who outraged the Nixon White House with his mega-leak of the Pentagon Papers, is depicted on the posters with a plea to “tell the truth with documents that reveal lies or crimes or internal projections of costs and dangers.”

headline: Armadillo to Açaí: Flavors of a World Cup Journey
abstract: The Frugal Traveler’s route to the soccer tournament was adventurous — and so were some of his meals.
lead_paragraph: Language had failed us, so Ruben Dada had resorted to charades to demonstrate which wild animal found in the Surinamese rain forest he was offering to cook up for me.

headline: A Dash of Whimsy, With Leftover Stars
abstract: Jodie Mack will perform with her film, “Dusty Stacks of Mom: The Poster Project,” which features 1990s celebrity imagery set to Pink Floyd music.
lead_paragraph: The experimental filmmaker Jodie Mack grew up around the family business of posters and merch. From a Florida warehouse her parents supplied music retailers and others with the cultural wallpaper that decorated countless bedrooms in the 1990s — from the bands and celebrities du jour to the dorm-room patron saints Belushi, Marley and Guevara.

headline: In a Buenos Aires Barrio, a Quiet Metamorphosis
abstract: Villa Crespo, a working-class area near the hip Palermo Soho neighborhood, is undergoing changes that might even include its name.
lead_paragraph: Just south of the hip Palermo Soho neighborhood, a staunchly working-class Buenos Aires barrio is undergoing a quiet metamorphosis. Long home to the city’s Jewish community, Villa Crespo’s streets are lined with mom-and-pop shops, onetime factories and faded colonial facades that have mostly remained outside the trendsetters’ purview. But given its prime location — enterprising real estate agents are trying to rechristen the enclave Palermo Queens, much to the chagrin of longtime residents — an influx of hip restaurants and boutiques was inevitable. At the moment, the neighborhood still feels removed from the city’s hubbub, but more locals are descending upon its cobbled lanes.

headline: Downtown Las Vegas Jumps Again
abstract: Zappos's move into the neighborhood is part of a revival that has made the area the hippest in town.
lead_paragraph: From its frontier infancy through the mid-20th century, the only Las Vegas was downtown Las Vegas. But the city center known as Glitter Gulch lost the glamour battle post-1960 with the newer Strip, a stretch of Las Vegas Boulevard South with room for massive resorts featuring Egyptian pyramids and dancing water fountains.

headline: The Roar Over the Funds of the Crowd
abstract: The actor Zach Braff, who caught flak for using a crowdfunding site, says his new film could not have been made without it.
lead_paragraph: Eight times a week, Zach Braff stands on a Broadway stage and bellows, in a nebbishy kind of way, “No more compromises!”

headline: Prisons of Gender and a Generation
abstract: Max Ophuls’s “Caught” (1949) is a study of women’s oppression, while Antonioni’s “I Vinti” (1953) presents stories of juvenile delinquency in three countries.
lead_paragraph: Not only actors but also directors can be typecast, particularly strong stylists like Max Ophuls and Michelangelo Antonioni. Ophuls has been dismissed by some as a froufrou formalist, Antonioni as a poet of the privileged. Neither is noted for his social consciousness, but their complexity is evident in new Blu-ray releases of two relatively obscure films, Ophuls’s “Caught” (1949), made under the name Max Opuls, and Antonioni’s “I Vinti” (1953).

headline: Paris Couture Week: Jean Paul Gaultier Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Helga Traxler.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the couture photo diary of Helga Traxler.

headline: Bolshoi Arrives With Drama, Some Onstage
abstract: “The Tsar’s Bride” comes to New York as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: The overture to Rimsky-Korsakov’s “The Tsar’s Bride” begins with unassuming courtliness and swiftly ramps up to seething passion. It is, in a way, a microcosm of the work as a whole: a historical fantasy that quickly reveals itself as a vibrant blood-and-guts drama.

headline: First-Class Fares, on Sale
abstract: GiltCity.com is offering a sale on first-class seats on two routes flown by Delta Air Lines.
lead_paragraph: GiltCity.com, a website that offers local deals on everything from spa services to concerts in 13 major cities, will begin a flash sale Thursday, July 10, encouraging shoppers to get out of town in style, aboard first-class flights on Delta Air Lines.

headline: Trey Songz Is No. 1; Slow Sales for Thicke
abstract: Trey Songz’s “Trigga” sold 105,000 copies, while Robin Thicke’s latest album opened at No. 9.
lead_paragraph: This week on the music charts, the amorous R&B singer Trey Songz scores his second No. 1 album, Iggy Azalea holds her perch with the top single, and Robin Thicke’s latest album flops after a social-media campaign went bad.

headline: Radio Ad on Possible L.I.R.R. Strike
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is alerting Long Island Rail Road commuters about the potential of a walkout by its workers.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is alerting Long Island Rail Road commuters about the potential of a walkout by its workers.

headline: The Birth of a New World Cup Curse
abstract: The curse of Maracana is finally vanquished, but a new beast may have risen: the curse of Mineirao.

headline: External Drives Bring Data Storage Back Home
abstract: Whether desktop or portable, a user’s own device offers an alternative to cloud storage with its monthly fees.
lead_paragraph: BUYING digital copies of movies, music and video games can free up shelf space in your entertainment center, but you still have to store those digital files somewhere.

lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: ‘Big Short’ Case Raises Questions About Finra Arbitration
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Executive Compensation', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The case of Deeb Salem, a former Goldman Sachs trader, highlights an arbitration system that is weighted toward the big Wall Street firms, William D. Cohan writes in the Street Scene column.
lead_paragraph: Deeb Salem, the former Goldman Sachs trader who helped devise the firm’s brilliant and highly profitable proprietary bet against the mortgage market, has never been shy about trumpeting his accomplishments. Mr. Salem no longer works at Goldman — he decamped to GoldenTree Asset Management, a New York hedge fund, in 2012 — but his continuing lawsuit, which contends the firm shortchanged him about $21 million in bonus and deferred compensation during the years after the financial crisis, raises fresh questions about the fairness of Wall Street’s compensation practices, its willingness to make scapegoats out of former employees and the arbitration system — run by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority — that everyone who deals with Wall Street is forced to use to resolve monetary disputes.

headline: Shopping Events in New York City Starting July 10
abstract: A number of cool and unusual sunglasses collaborations in stores; Fendi unveils a very Instagram-friendly pop-up; a Rachel Comey sample sale and more.
lead_paragraph: Sunny Style

headline: Lufthansa to Start Low-Cost, Long-Distance Airline
abstract: The company said the new airline would begin operations in 2015, but provided few details about which destinations it might serve.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Scrambling to find more ways to shave costs and improve profitability, Lufthansa of Germany announced on Wednesday a plan to expand its domestic low-cost operations by creating a new, no-frills airline for long-distance flights, possibly to popular leisure destinations in Southeast Asia.

headline: Viktor & Rolf: Winter 2014 Couture
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Modern Fairy-Tale Dress at Valentino
abstract: The fashion house’s fall/winter 2014 couture runway earlier today had its share of standout moments, including one intricately embroidered minidress.
lead_paragraph: The mood at today’s Valentino fall/winter 2014 couture show was par-for-the-course romantic. The wood-plank runway bedecked with moss and branches suggested a mythical forest to arriving guests, and what followed was a dance of ethereal, fairy-tale-like fashion moments. Subtle ballet references danced throughout the collection: leather belts on many of the looks mimicked the wraparound leotards worn for warm-ups, while delicate, knee-high lace-up sandals evoked the ties of toe shoes. The muted, wearable collection had its share of standout moments, but it was hard to forget this intricately embroidered pleated wrap minidress that felt at once folkloric and resolutely modern.

headline: A Test Run at 19,000 Feet
abstract: Before Jeremy Jones could attempt to climb and ride a massive peak in Nepal, he simply needed to get back on his snowboard after weeks without riding. This task led to a test run—at 19,000 feet.
lead_paragraph: Before Jeremy Jones could attempt to climb and ride a massive peak in Nepal, he simply needed to get back on his snowboard after weeks without riding. This task led to a test run—at 19,000 feet.

headline: Summer Nights, Late and Spooky
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center’s series Freaky Fridays is a delightfully unsettling meeting of horror, kink and 35 millimeter.
lead_paragraph: It’s amazing what joy good air-conditioning and a midnight movie can bring, and the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s series Freaky Fridays — a delightfully unsettling meeting of horror, kink and 35 millimeter running through August (albeit at 11 p.m.) — offers plenty. Among the perverse pleasures are David Cronenberg’s parricidal nightmare “The Brood” (1979), Kathryn Bigelow’s outlaw vampire movie “Near Dark” (1987), Herk Harvey’s fever dream “Carnival of Souls” (1962) and Liliana Cavani’s lurid “The Night Porter” (1974), each for 10 bucks or less.

headline: In Stormy Year, Yanks Lose Anchor as Tanaka Heads to D.L.
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka flew back to New York to undergo an M.R.I. on his right elbow and was later placed on the disabled list with what the team described as elbow inflammation.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Their offense has sputtered and their starting pitching has crumbled, and yet three months into the season, the Yankees have remained competitive. It is easy to recognize why: When their ace, Masahiro Tanaka, pitches, the Yankees tend to win.

headline: Deep in Debt, Sarkozy’s Party Might Have to Sit Out Next Election
abstract: The U.M.P., which backed Nicolas Sarkozy’s failed re-election bid in 2012, is said to be in financial crisis in part over expenses from that effort.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s main conservative opposition party has disclosed that it is more than $100 million in debt, leaving it financially crippled and further impairing its ability to take on President François Hollande’s governing Socialists and head off the growing strength of the far-right National Front.

headline: The New Business Casual Is Still Uptight
abstract: When your office values beer and chitchat over suits and ties, what counts as “professional” behavior? And is its definition even more restrictive than before?
lead_paragraph: Every workplace imposes certain behavioral standards on its workers — dress this way, talk that way, get lunch here and not there. Learning these standards is, we’re told, a big part of being successful. But what do we do if they’re constantly shifting, or if we’re not even sure what they are?

headline: Strategy at the European Team Championships
abstract: A deal from the European Team Championships in Opatija, Croatia, last month.
lead_paragraph: What is the textbook approach to leading against small slams and grand slams? Should you be aggressive or cautious?

headline: Video: Snowboarder Takes a Test Run at 19,000 Feet
abstract: Before Jeremy Jones could attempt to climb and ride a massive peak in Nepal, he simply needed to get back on his snowboard after weeks without riding. This task led to a test run.
lead_paragraph: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: Europe Fines Servier in Pay-for-Delay Crackdown
abstract: Europe’s top antitrust enforcer said several drug makers, including Servier, kept more affordable forms of a popular heart treatment off the market.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Fines totaling 427.7 million euros ($581.8 million) were imposed Wednesday on several European drug makers, including the French company Servier, for keeping more affordable forms of a popular heart treatment off the market.

headline: Kerry Presses China to Abide by Maritime Laws to Ease Tensions
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry, at a high-level gathering of Chinese and American officials, called on China to support the creation of a legally binding code of maritime conduct.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a closed-door session at a high-level gathering of Chinese and American officials here on Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry urged China to follow maritime law in nearby seas to reduce regional tensions, a senior American official said.

headline: The Kids Aren’t All Right, and Neither Is the School
abstract: “Kidnapped for Christ” is a documentary about the major issues at a school meant to help teenagers with problems.
lead_paragraph: Coercive Christianity has been having a rough time on television of late. In May, PBS’s “Independent Lens” broadcast “God Loves Uganda,” a devastating documentary about dubious work being done there by some evangelicals. And now, Showtime offers “Kidnapped for Christ,” an inside look at a school in the Dominican Republic where a certain breed of American parent hoped that God and discipline would straighten out their teenage children.

headline: Tangled Web of Memories Lingers After a Breakup
abstract: Scrubbing painful memories from Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and other sites can be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: The last thing I remember was the tears running in rivulets down my cheek as I confirmed that, yes, I did want to delete the picture on my Facebook page.

headline: Veteran Diplomat Said to Be Picked as Third Envoy in Syrian Conflict
abstract: Staffan de Mistura, an Italian-Swedish diplomat, was chosen by the secretary general as the third envoy assigned to achieve peace, diplomats reported.
lead_paragraph: A veteran Italian-Swedish diplomat, Staffan de Mistura, has been tapped to try to achieve what two seasoned envoys could not: craft a peace deal for Syria.

headline: Obama on Economic Progress

lead_paragraph: The president spoke about the country’s post-recession improvements at a campaign event in Denver, and said Republicans were blocking legislation that would help the middle class.

headline: Zynga Changes Board to Comply With Nasdaq Rules
abstract: The appointment of Regina E. Dugan, a Google executive, to the company’s board removes Zynga from the Nasdaq Stock Market’s penalty box.
lead_paragraph: Companies naming new members to their boards is normally a routine affair. For the game maker Zynga, the appointment of Regina E. Dugan, a Google executive, to its board has special significance because it moves the company out of the Nasdaq Stock Market’s penalty box.

headline: Brooklyn Bureaucracy: A Reporter’s Journey
abstract: Andy Newman, a Metro desk reporter, needed a document from the city. Therein lies a tale.
lead_paragraph: Andy Newman, a Metro desk reporter, needed a document from the city. Therein lies a tale.

headline: Brooklyn Cantor Is Sentenced to 2 Years for Sexual Abuse
abstract: Baruch Lebovits is expected to serve only a few months of that sentence, because he received credit of 13 months for time served on a previous conviction on the same charge.
lead_paragraph: A cantor whose sexual abuse case split the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn was sentenced on Wednesday to two years in prison, as expected under a plea deal struck in May.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: IBM Wants to Invent the Chips of the Future, Not Make Them
abstract: IBM will spend $3 billion over the next five years on computer chip technology, with an eye toward moving beyond the silicon era.
lead_paragraph: IBM plans to spend $3 billion over the next five years on research and development for computer chips, both to stretch the limits of conventional semiconductors and to hasten the commercialization of exotic new designs.

headline: Nagin Sentenced on Corruption Charges
abstract: After former Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans was sentenced on charges including bribery and fraud, Matthew Coman, an assistant United States attorney, spoke about the effects of Mr. Nagin’s actions.
lead_paragraph: After former Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans was sentenced on charges including bribery and fraud, Matthew Coman, an assistant United States attorney, spoke about the effects of Mr. Nagin’s actions.

headline: Democrats Will Vote to Undo the Hobby Lobby Decision
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: It’s a message bill, but at least it’s a clear one.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s ruling last week in the Hobby Lobby case wasn’t based on a fundamental right found in the First Amendment or anywhere else in the Constitution. When the justices said that closely held corporations have religious rights that let them refuse to pay for insurance plans that cover contraceptives, they based their decision on a 1993 law passed by Congress, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

headline: Very Modern Problems Set in a Navajo World
abstract: “Drunktown’s Finest,” by Sydney Freeland, gives a look into the lives of young Native Americans in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: A weakness for drink is only one of the problems encountered by the Native American characters in Sydney Freeland’s debut feature, “Drunktown’s Finest.”

headline: This Time, the Main Attraction
abstract: The play “Between Riverside and Crazy” will give audiences a very good look at an actor they know well from secondary roles, Stephen McKinley Henderson.
lead_paragraph: No one wants to be upstaged by a toilet, especially in his first appearance as a lead actor in a New York production.

headline: The Daily Do | Long Locks Woven with Pearls at Jean-Paul Gaultier
abstract: At the designer’s fall/winter 2014 couture show, extravagant detailing wasn’t limited to the clothes on the runway.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runway.

headline: A Butcher, a Baker, a Luxury-Handbag Maker
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: With its “village feel,” Mount Street in London is luring high-fashion brands.
lead_paragraph: There are no crystal balls in fashion, but there are, at least, weather vanes. Some savvy interpreters point the way the wind is blowing. One is Christopher Kane, the young Scottish designer, whose next-big-thing status was, in effect, confirmed by the Kering investment in his label. So when he announced in September that he would open his first London store, the question was where.

headline: U.S. Will Broaden Sanctions to Deter Violence in Congo
abstract: The measures will be applied to people involved in the recruitment of child soldiers, sexual violence and obstruction of humanitarian assistance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States will expand sanctions on groups in the Democratic Republic of Congo, making it easier to target those who are trying to instigate violence and disrupt peacekeeping efforts in that country, the White House announced on Tuesday.

headline: Scene | ‘Dawn of the Planet of the Apes’
abstract: Matt Reeves narrates a sequence from “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” featuring Jason Clarke.
lead_paragraph: Matt Reeves narrates a sequence from “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” featuring Jason Clarke.

headline: About That Photo of the ‘Reformicons’
abstract: Eric Ogden photographed members of the “reformicons” in Gunston Hall, the historic mansion in Virginia that belonged to George Mason. Ogden recently discussed how the photo came about.
lead_paragraph: To capture the spirit of the “reformicons” for the July 6 cover story about the emerging band of intellectuals in the Republican Party, Eric Ogden photographed members of the group in Gunston Hall, the historic mansion in Virginia that belonged to George Mason. Ogden’s group portrait, which alluded to paintings of the founding fathers, inspired readers to analyze who was included (“This is the Republican idea of diversity?”) and what they were doing (“Who’s going to sweep up that mess on the floor? The rest of the country?”). Ogden recently discussed how the photo came about — and what’s on those pages on the floor.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Bosnia and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Bosnia and China.

headline: Beacons of Creativity, Flung From Rooftops
abstract: An exhibition on Governors Island considers the experimental choreographer Trisha Brown halfway through a farewell tour.
lead_paragraph: The current exhibition about Trisha Brown’s dances on Governors Island occupies just one large room at the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s Arts Center. But (despite its unappetizing subtitle “Embodied Practice and Site-Specificity”) it is a room to linger in for more than an hour. lead_paragraph: “Fase, Four Movements to the Music of Steve Reich,” by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, is a remarkable work, adopting the methods of American Minimalism while swerving away from its ascetic tone. When Ms. De Keersmaeker created it, in the early 1980s, she was barely 20, a student at New York University. And on Tuesday, when “Fase” was performed at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, that amazing precocity was matched by longevity: The choreographer, at 54, dancing her demanding composition with as much electricity as ever.

But this season, the Paris couture shows played out against a background of almost palpable conflict, from the organized and (mostly) entertaining — Federer vs. Djokovic; Brazil vs. Germany — to the unexpected and dismaying: Israel vs. Hamas, the civil war in Ukraine. Escapism was not on the agenda.

headline: Reading Hobby Lobby in Context
abstract: How much further, and in what contexts, will the Supreme Court extend protections beyond what the Constitution requires?
lead_paragraph: To grasp the full implications of the Supreme Court’s Hobby Lobby decision, it helps to read it not in isolation but alongside the court’s other major religion case of the term, Town of Greece v. Galloway. Issued eight weeks before Hobby Lobby and decided by the same 5 to 4 division, Town of Greece rejected a challenge to a town board’s practice of beginning its public sessions with a Christian prayer. A federal appeals court found the practice unconstitutional, concluding that it violated the First Amendment’s Establishment Clause by conveying an official endorsement of one particular religion.

headline: From Bruce LaBruce, a Perfume All About Obscenity
abstract: The transgressive Canadian filmmaker and artist has launched a new project, opening tomorrow at the Hole, that skewers luxury-fragrance campaigns.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian art filmmaker Bruce LaBruce is no stranger to transgression. His work has depicted pornographic bloodbaths, zombie necrophilia and amputee fetishism. By those standards, his latest project, “Obscenity,” the subject of a new show at the New York gallery the Hole, might seem rather tame. Like the artist Francesco Vezzoli’s notorious “Greed,” a mock advertisement that starred Natalie Portman and Michelle Williams having a cat fight over a perfume bottle, it’s a critique of fragrance campaigns, but it bears LaBruce’s unmistakable stamp.

headline: Where the Curtains Were Made of Iron
abstract: “Competing Utopias,” an exhibition of Cold War-era artifacts, opens in Richard Neutra’s former home in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Some 350 Cold War-era artifacts, including teacups, tables and surveillance equipment used by the East German secret police, have replaced most of the furnishings in the Neutra VDL Studio and Residences in Los Angeles for “Competing Utopias: An Experimental Installation of Cold War Modern Design From East and West in One Context,” opening to the public on Sunday. It takes a disorienting look at the parallel universes on either side of the Iron Curtain, a “Twilight Zone”-like scenario where everything is the same — except that it’s different. “The similarity of objects from the East and West are pretty remarkable,” said Bill Ferehawk, who organized the show with Justinian Jampol, founder of the Wende Museum and Archive of the Cold War, and Sarah Lorenzen, the VDL House’s director. They use no labels, so unless visitors consult the iPads in the room, only clues like German phrases on coffee cans will hint at the décor’s origins. As Ms. Lorenzen said: “We want people to wonder: ‘How is history manufactured? How do stories get told? How different are we really?’ ” Through Sept. 13; neutra-vdl.org.

headline: Ode on a Spanish Urn, Filled With a City’s Tap Water
abstract: From Patricia Urquiola, a water pitcher with a charitable purpose.
lead_paragraph: Bilbao, the northern Spanish city, has a new contribution from a design superstar: not a museum or a bridge this time, but a ceramic water pitcher. Patricia Urquiola, the Spanish-born Milanese designer, has created H2O Bilbao, a pitcher based on the kaiku, an ancient Basque wooden milking and cooking vessel. Ms. Urquiola said she borrowed the classic form to pay tribute to Bilbao’s excellent tap water.

headline: Plants With Roots Attached
abstract: Allen Bush is a cultivator of stories and relationships as much as gardens.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — It is through Allen Bush, the seedsman and raconteur, that I lay claim to the 400-year-old legacy of the Dutch engraver and floriculturist Emanuel Sweert. On a cloudless Saturday morning not long ago, Mr. Bush rummaged in his backyard and cut me a clump of a purplish iris. It was an ordinary looking plant, not yet in bloom — hardly noticeable in his oversize city lot.

headline: The Flora and Fauna Chronicles
abstract: “The Living Landscape” gorgeously presents the many-layered life of the garden.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of talk about habitat gardens, but how many gardeners have watched a zebra swallowtail butterfly laying its eggs on a pawpaw leaf and then noticed the fuzzy larvae feeding on the leaves, which contain compounds that make the swallowtails unpalatable to birds? Two giants of the natural gardening world, Rick Darke and Doug Tallamy, have collaborated on their best work yet, “The Living Landscape: Designing for Beauty and Biodiversity in the Home Garden” (Timber Press, $39.95). It documents the layers and creatures of a healthy landscape, like ants carrying seeds of bloodroot and trillium back to their nests, and the blue-gray gnatcatcher nesting in a beech. Mr. Darke, a photographer as well as a plantsman and designer, took most of the gorgeous images, though Mr. Tallamy, an ecologist, offers inspiring close-ups of bugs and birds.

headline: London Theater Journal: Mind Games
abstract: “Handbagged” and “1984” play mind games with their audiences, reminding you that on stage as in life, what you see is not necessarily what you get.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – “Here’s to certainty,” says Queen Elizabeth II, raising a glass of gin and it (just a small one) to Margaret Thatcher. The words produce a hollow echo in “Handbagged,” Moira Buffini’s lively stretched-out sketch at the Vaudeville Theater here, because it is far from certain that the reigning monarch of Britain ever made such a toast to such a drinking partner.

headline: Smiljan Radic: A Rock Star Among Architects
abstract: Fresh from opening his Serpentine Pavilion, the Chilean architect discusses another new project: a boulder-strewn winery south of Santiago.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, a translucent pod of glass-reinforced plastic, poised atop enormous sandstone boulders, appeared on a curve of lawn in Kensington Gardens in London. The folly, which one reviewer called “a collision between an extraterrestrial egg and a Neolithic burial site,” is by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, whom the nearby Serpentine Galleries chose to create a temporary structure in its front yard. It is the 14th year that the museum has commissioned a Serpentine Pavilion, always turning to an architect who has not previously built in Britain, and the unveiling of the park installation has become a closely watched summer ritual.

headline: Office High Jinks
abstract: Artspace’s new headquarters in Lower Manhattan have all the comforts of home (and probably better art).
lead_paragraph: A cozy art-filled living room, a sleek white kitchen, a Yorkshire terrier padding about: Artspace’s new office at 75 Broad Street in the financial district feels more like home than work. The three-year-old company, an online marketplace for contemporary fine art, moved from the Flatiron district last year to a loft that Catherine Levene, a founder and the chief executive, called “a large white box.” She hired the New York designer Maria Gabriela Brito to help personalize the space with art that is sometimes sold off the walls and features like Eurostyle’s Farid chairs, upholstered in a newspaper pattern, for the conference room, below. She nixed a few of Ms. Brito’s wilder ideas, like a bright red pendant lamp in the entry, and insisted on retaining some dull but ergonomic desk chairs. “Catherine is afraid of color,” Ms. Brito said with a smile.

Out the window, I could see people running in the streets of Beit Hanina, my Palestinian neighborhood. Then came a second crash, and a third.

headline: How Coffee Fueled the Civil War
abstract: Union and Confederate soldiers needed one thing, above all, to keep them fighting: caffeine.
lead_paragraph: It was the greatest coffee run in American history. The Ohio boys had been fighting since morning, trapped in the raging battle of Antietam, in September 1862. Suddenly, a 19-year-old William McKinley appeared, under heavy fire, hauling vats of hot coffee. The men held out tin cups, gulped the brew and started firing again. “It was like putting a new regiment in the fight,” their officer recalled. Three decades later, McKinley ran for president in part on this singular act of caffeinated heroism.

headline: Afghanistan’s Dilemma
abstract: One of the candidates is calling the results of the presidential election fraudulent. But stoking outrage among his supporters does not ensure a peaceful outcome.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah Abdullah, one of two candidates for president of Afghanistan, and his supporters are pushing the country toward a dangerous point by calling the election a coup and threatening to establish a parallel government. He is correct in demanding that charges of rampant electoral fraud be thoroughly investigated. But stoking outrage among his supporters with incendiary language does nothing to ensure a credible and peaceful outcome. The better course is to join his opponent, Ashraf Ghani, in ensuring an outcome that Afghans can believe in.

headline: Saving Water in California
abstract: The state needs much stronger conservation measures if it wants to battle its worst drought in decades and not to face severe water shortages.
lead_paragraph: California is in the third year of its worst drought in decades. But you wouldn’t know it by looking at how much water the state’s residents and businesses are using. According to a recent state survey, Californians cut the amount of water they used in the first five months of the year by just 5 percent, far short of the 20 percent reduction Gov. Jerry Brown called for in January. In some parts of the state, like the San Diego area, water use has actually increased from 2013.

Olsen, the director of the National Counterterrorism Center, is resigning after three years, a time during which the threat from Al Qaeda shifted from its headquarters in Pakistan to its affiliates in places like Syria, Iraq and Yemen. “Most Americans may not know Matt Olsen’s name, but every American is safer because of his service,” President Obama said in a statement released by the White House. Mr. Olsen has not set a date to leave the job, but it is expected to be in the next few months, after a successor is selected, a spokesman said. The National Counterterrorism Center is the nation’s terrorism information clearinghouse.

headline: A Summer Clam Feast at the Long Island Home of the Chef Anita Lo
abstract: On the south shore, two extraordinary chefs joined Lo for a day of paddling kayaks through the bay, digging for soft-shell clams and throwing together a summery feast.
lead_paragraph: At around 4:30 in the afternoon, when the tide is low on the south shore of Long Island, April Bloomfield, Elizabeth Falkner and Anita Lo carry kayaks down to the water. There’s no path, so they make their own as they go, clearing tall, wild sea grass with the viciously sharp blade of a scythe that Lo picked up in Hong Kong. Then they climb into their boats and glide away. A school of mirrored shiners moves past. Plovers hop around the frothy shore and small, see-through jellyfish float by, but the chefs are not distracted. They came to dig clams for dinner. “This looks good,” Lo says, when they reach a grassy island in the middle of the cove. “Let’s drop our anchors.”

headline: The Physical Exam as Refuge

The physical exam is one of the unique characteristics of the doctor-patient encounter; a visit to a doctor doesn’t seem the same without one. Yet, increasingly, there’s less and less of it. Visits are shorter and doctors have to spend most of their time at the computer filling out the endless electronic medical records that have come to define the modern medical transaction.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on remittance profits, raising the smoking age, gay marriage in Colorado and a silly lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: “The largest and arguably most effective antipoverty effort in the world is financed by the poor themselves,” writes The New York Times editorial board. “Last year alone, migrants in rich countries sent an estimated $404 billion to their families in developing countries.” Known as remittances, these transfers could see a rise in transfer fees as big banks like Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase are leaving the money-transfer business. Bankers claim “regulation has become too onerous in the wake of recent settlements over money laundering” connected to remittance transfers. But The Times believes “banks want out because they face dwindling profits from cash transfers. Over the last five years, there has been a successful global effort to lower remittance costs through greater transparency, better technology and other innovations.” If banks can’t profitably transmit remittances, “then other secure, low-cost options must be found.”

headline: How the Rise of Cellphones Affects Surveys
abstract: By increasing the number of wireless phones dialed, pollsters get a more representative sample, one that includes all demographic groups.

As of December, 7 percent of Americans did not have a wireless phone. And 4 in 10 adults have eliminated their landline and use a cellphone exclusively, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Health Interview Survey. The rise of cellphones has forced a transformation in the polling field.

abstract: In “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes,” civilized apes and devastated humans debate what to do about each other.
lead_paragraph: A quick montage at the beginning of “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” fills us in on what has happened since “Rise of the Planet of the Apes.” Three years have gone by for us in the audience, and about a decade for the assorted primates on the screen. James Franco and millions of other people are dead, victims of a lethal virus and the usual apocalypse-causing disease of hubris. After a period of violence and chaos, the survivors have cobbled together a reasonably stable society in the ruins of San Francisco, with Gary Oldman in charge.

headline: 1964: New Premier Takes Office
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Moise Tshombe sworn in as Congolese Premier in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LEOPOLDVILLE, Congo — Moise Tshombe was sworn in today [July 10] as the Congo’s Premier and immediately ordered the release of an estimated 600 Congolese political prisoners. He also abolished the seven-week-old midnight curfew in Leopoldville. These were the first official acts of the ten-member cabinet after the 44-year-old Mr. Tshombe presented the ministers formally to President Joseph Kasavubu. Removal of the curfew on Leopoldville, imposed seven weeks ago after a rash of bombings, was expected to spark wild celebrations. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 11, 1964

lead_paragraph: Egypt’s street artists, with their in-your-face approach, aim for an immediate public response. Other Arab artists are more conceptual about their art projects, referring to current events obliquely. “Here and Elsewhere,” on view at the New Museum, at 235 Bowery, Lower East Side, from July 16 through Sept. 28, features 45 artists from Amman, Beirut, Cairo, Dubai, Ramallah and Sharjah, among other cities. “There are artists looking at conflict and wars, but we did not want to restrict this to the Arab Spring,” said Massimiliano Gioni, the museum’s associate director, who worked with a team of curators. “This is not a show in which the artists are forced to illustrate historic changes.”

headline: In Time-Lapse Videos, the Magic Unfolds
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Origami', 'Art', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Movies']
abstract: Online tutorials have opened the art of origami to a new generation of fans weaned on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Robert J. Lang is one of the world’s foremost masters of origami. A former laser physicist at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Mr. Lang ditched his day job at a fiber-optics company 13 years ago to devote his life to folding paper. Dozens of his featherweight creations are on display here at the Art Center College of Design: a peregrine falcon and an emperor scorpion, a stag beetle and a bull moose, all fashioned with such skill and lifelike detail, they appear ready to leap off their pristine white pedestals. The complex pieces require days of work and hundreds to thousands of folds. Viewers spend as much time enjoying their beauty as they do marveling at just how these animal figures were made, without cuts or glue, from a single sheet of paper.

headline: Wheels of Justice Turn Quickly In Bieber Egg Case

lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber’s misdemeanor vandalism case for egging a neighbor’s house has been disposed of swiftly. He will pay $89,000 in restitution and undergo 12 weeks of anger management therapy. He will also be required to do five days of community service, and must stay away from Jeffrey Schwartz and his family (the former neighbor; Mr. Bieber has since moved) for two years.

headline: 1939: Finnish Fascists Lose Election
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Finnish Fascists Lose Election in 1939.
lead_paragraph: HELSINGFORS — Finland’s Fascists suffered the most spectacular defeat in their history in the general election concluded in Finland recently. They lost seven of the fourteen seats they had previously held in the Finnish Parliament. The defeat came on the heels of a ban in 1938 against the patriotic national movement, the Fascists’ organization in Finland, by the Finnish Minister of the Interior, M. Kekkonen. The general election brought new adherence to the democratic government coalition, comprising Socialists, Farmers and Liberals, who will constitute three-fourths of the new Diet. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 11, 1939

headline: We Tell Kids to ‘Go to Sleep!’ We Need to Teach Them Why.
abstract: Sleep does so much more for our bodies than preventing us from being tired tomorrow, but most parents don’t tell our children that. Educating kids about the importance of sleep leads them to sleep more.
lead_paragraph: We tell children why it’s important to eat their vegetables. We tell them why they need to get outside and run around. But how often do we parents tell children why it’s important to sleep? “Time for bed!” is usually the end of it, or maybe “You’ll be tired tomorrow.” No wonder children regard sleep as vaguely punitive, an enforced period of dull isolation in a darkened room. But of course sleep is so much more, and maybe we ought to try telling children that.
