Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, according to three theater executives involved with the production.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Paris Couture Shows
abstract: A peek at what some of the gals in Paris were wearing.
lead_paragraph: A peek at what some of the gals in Paris were wearing.

headline: What to Do About Banco Espirito Santo of Portugal
abstract: Full transparency and a quick restructuring are essential for Portugal’s second-largest bank by value, say George Hay and Neil Unmack of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Lisbon needs to sort out Banco  Espírito Santo – fast. Despite a recent successful rights issue, Portugal’s second-largest bank by value has a troubled major shareholder and a large exposure to shaky Angolan loans. With Portuguese bond yields up 40 basis points since July 7 and domestic bank shares tanking, a speedy restructuring is needed.

headline: Satya Nadella Says Changes Are Coming to Microsoft
abstract: An essay sent to Microsoft employees by the company’s chief executive appears to lay the groundwork for significant changes that will be revealed later this month.
lead_paragraph: Updated, July 17 | Microsoft announced that it would cut up to 18,000 jobs, which accounts for almost 15 percent of its work force.

headline: Crumbs Cupcakes May Live Another Day
abstract: Crumbs shut its doors on Monday. But on Thursday, it was said to be close to securing financing from a group of investors, including Marcus Lemonis, star of the CNBC reality show “The Profit,” about saving small business.
lead_paragraph: It’s not over for the Crumbs cupcake yet.

headline: France Is Not an Anti-Semitic Nation
abstract: The number of hateful acts against Jews has fallen over the last decade. Fighting prejudice remains our moral duty.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — FEW democratic societies are as rich in populations of diverse origins as France’s. This is one of the many traits France shares with the United States. Both are countries of immigrants where citizenship is universal and does not depend on one’s ethnic or religious origins.

headline: FIFA Rejects Suárez’s Appeal of 4-Month Ban
abstract: A FIFA appeals committee on Thursday upheld the decision, which bars Suárez from nine international matches and all soccer-related activity for four months, for biting another player.
lead_paragraph: A FIFA appeals committee on Thursday rejected motions filed by Luis Suárez and Uruguay’s soccer federation that had sought to overturn or reduce his four-month suspension from soccer for biting another player.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Allison Tolman of ‘Fargo’
abstract: Allison Tolman, nominated for her role as Molly Solverson in the FX show, says she and her character both have a strong sense of justice, which is why she decided to call out critics who described her as fat.
lead_paragraph: “That whole sort of fatgate thing” is how Allison Tolman refers to the tempest in an online teapot that erupted on Twitter last month, after she called out weight-shamers for describing her as fat. Happily for her, the spotlight is back on her acting prowess, with an Emmy nomination for her performance as Molly Solverson, the plainspoken deputy in the FX series “Fargo.”

headline: Myanmar Court Sentences Journalists to Prison and Hard Labor
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Censorship']
abstract: Burmese journalists said the jail terms in connection with an article about possible chemical weapons production were a blow to recently won freedoms.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — A provincial court in Myanmar on Thursday sentenced the head of a weekly newspaper and four of its journalists to 10 years in prison and hard labor for publishing a report that said a vast and secretive government factory was designed to produce chemical weapons.

headline: Seven Die, Including 3 Children, in Massachusetts Fire
abstract: The fast-moving fire in Lowell, Mass., also injured nine people and left dozens homeless, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Officials in Lowell, Mass., said Thursday that seven people — three of whom were children — died in an early morning fire that sent nine others to hospitals and left dozens homeless.

headline: TRW Automotive Gets Preliminary Takeover Offer
abstract: The German auto parts maker ZF Friedrichshafen has approached the Michigan company, which has a market value of more than $10 billion. TRW shares surged.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:30 p.m. |

headline: Obscure Rule Restricts Health Law’s Expansion of Care for Addicts
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act says substance abuse treatment is an “essential health benefit,” but an older law is making residential care hard to get.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAZEL CREST, Ill. — On its surface, the Affordable Care Act seems like a boon for addiction treatment centers like the South Suburban Council on Alcoholism and Substance Abuse, housed in a no-frills former hotel outside Chicago.

headline: Rosie O’Donnell to Rejoin ‘The View’ on ABC
abstract: Ms. O’Donnell first joined the show in 2006 and her outspoken and often politically oriented commentary helped spark a surge in its ratings.
lead_paragraph: “The View” will reach back to its higher-rated, but more contentious, past with the addition of its former host Rosie O’Donnell to a reconstructed cast next fall.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Trove of Hebrew Books From Centuries Past
abstract: An exhibition at the Chabad headquarters in Crown Heights features Hebrew book published between 1475 and 1574.
lead_paragraph: The Chabad-Lubavitch movement, a Hasidic group known for its outreach to Jewish communities around the world, has amassed one of the largest collections of rare Jewish manuscripts and books anywhere – on the order of 250,000 items, including some that go back to the 11th century or earlier.

headline: The Secret Life of a Soccer Star
abstract: “Matador,” beginning Tuesday night at 9, arrives in the afterglow of the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Britain has James Bond. Gotham City has Batman. Who would the Hispanic market’s hero be? “We’d have an L.A.-based soccer player who’s a spy by night, that’s who,” Roberto Orci, the Mexican-born writer and executive producer of “The Amazing Spider-Man 2,” said recently.

headline: The Calculus Behind Imagery
abstract: Charles Gaines’s early work is the focus of a show at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: “I use systems in order to provoke the issues around representation,” the Los Angeles artist Charles Gaines has said. His early drawings, the focus of “Charles Gaines: Gridwork 1974-1989” at the Studio Museum in Harlem, resemble math-based artworks by Sol LeWitt and other pioneering conceptualists.

headline: The Bolshoi, Packing Heat
abstract: The Bolshoi brings its big guns to the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: This season’s programming may not be the most progressive, but in the spirit of feverishly passionate ballet, the Bolshoi brings its big guns to the David H. Koch Theater. As part of the Lincoln Center Festival, the company presents “Swan Lake” on Tuesday with David Hallberg — the first American to become a permanent member of the Bolshoi — and the gloriously willowy Svetlana Zakharova. After “Swan Lake,” which runs through next Sunday, are “Don Quixote” (July 22 and 23) and “Spartacus” (July 25 to 27). Since the productions lean toward the musty side — Yuri Grigorovich, the company’s former artistic director, choreographed both “Swan Lake” and “Spartacus” — it might be best to focus on the dancers. Along with Mr. Hallberg and Ms. Zakharova, there is the young Olga Smirnova, who performs “Swan Lake” opposite Semyon Chudin  next Saturday and next Sunday, and the boldly enticing Maria Alexandrova as Kitri in “Don Quixote” on July 22. As for “Spartacus”? It pretty much rains men. Leave your umbrella at home. (Tuesday through July 27; 212-721-6500, lincolncenterfestival.org.

headline: The Greening of Verdi’s Jester
abstract: Will Crutchfield’s Bel Canto at Caramoor series has proved a recurring highlight of the season.
lead_paragraph: Will Crutchfield’s Bel Canto at Caramoor series, held each summer at a genteel Westchester County estate, has proved a recurring highlight of the season. Next Saturday, Mr. Crutchfield, again leading the excellent Orchestra of St. Luke’s, offers Verdi’s “Rigoletto,” starring Steven Powell in the tragic role, the tenor John Osborn as the Duke of Mantua and Georgia Jarman as Gilda. Before each performance, there is a rewarding afternoon lineup of recitals by young artists and lectures by visiting scholars.

headline: Stepping In, Out in Front
abstract: What to do when your favorite band takes to the road, and the recording studio, with a new person out front singing?
lead_paragraph: It used to be called the Sammy Hagar Conundrum and lately has been rebranded as the Arnel Pineda Provocation: What to do when your favorite band takes to the road, and the recording studio, with a new person out front singing? This is an especially perplexing circumstance for fans of Queen, whose frontman, Freddie Mercury, died in 1991, and left a long shadow — in voice and attitude — that few would even try to fill.

headline: Unraveling a Dark Family Secret
abstract: At 21, a writer made a discovery that she feared would betray her beloved grandmother.
lead_paragraph: I was 21 years old and sitting with my grandmother in her parlor as she knitted a heavy winter blanket. It was the middle of the summer in Israel, and that blanket made me sweat just looking at it. I was pretending to read, but really my head was on fire.

headline: 2014 Emmy Nominations: Anna Chlumsky of ‘Veep’
abstract: Ms. Chlumsky on her character’s inability to enjoy success, and whether she’d vote for Selina Meyer.
lead_paragraph: Anna Chlumsky is in Williamstown, Mass., rehearsing for the world premiere of “Living on Love,” a play about an opera diva (Renée Fleming), her maestro husband, and the ghostwriter who comes between them (Ms. Chlumsky), at the Williamstown Theater Festival. “I’m on a 10-minute break,” Ms. Chlumsky said by phone. Plenty of time to discuss her Emmy nod as a supporting actress in the HBO comedy series “Veep,” in which she plays Amy, the sharp but set-upon assistant to the vice president (Julia Louis-Dreyfus, also an Emmy nominee). It’s her second nomination in two years.

headline: Justice Dept. Declines to Investigate C.I.A. Review
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee had accused each other of criminal behavior related to the committee’s investigation of the agency’s interrogations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has declined to pursue dueling claims by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee, which had accused each other of criminal behavior related to the committee’s investigation of the agency’s interrogation practices, the department said on Thursday.

headline: Marching Bands, Kierkegaard and Other Musical Influences
abstract: New releases include those from My Brightest Diamond, Matt Pavolka, Wray, Mndsgn and People.
lead_paragraph: My Brightest Diamond

headline: Dropping the Mask, With Egos in Check
abstract: Even after revealing their identities, the two founders of the music collective Jungle say they see their group as a haven from seeking adulation.
lead_paragraph: The creators of the British electro-soul collective Jungle may have many self-taught skills, but dancing on roller skates is not one of them. When the duo released their celebrated EP “The Heat” last fall in their native Britain, they took an enigmatic route, keeping their faces and names under wraps. The video for the title track featured a pair of synchronized skaters in tracksuits. Confusion ensued.

headline: False Starts Before Cable’s Golden Age
abstract: Cable has discovered the religion of original scripted dramas and comedies. A look back reveals early attempts at the same.
lead_paragraph: In the golden age of the high-class cable drama, it’s easy to forget that no cable channel started its life with such fare. HBO and Showtime? Movies. AMC? Old movies. USA? Sports. ABC Family? Pat Robertson.

headline: In U.S. Data, a Baffling Contradiction
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'United States Economy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The government says that the first quarter of 2014 was the worst for the economy since 2009, but the best in hiring in over six years. How can both reports be right?
lead_paragraph: The first quarter of this year was the worst for the United States economy since the depths of the Great Recession in early 2009.

headline: Guiding and Gliding, the Urban Bush Women
abstract: The Urban Bush Women, whose dances draw on experiences in the African diaspora, will teach a master class and perform at St. Mary’s Park on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: From their debut in a Manhattan loft 30 years ago this month, in a dance performance that Jennifer Dunning called “deeply affecting and stylishly produced” in The New York Times, the Urban Bush Women have gone on to win awards, tour internationally and take part in cultural diplomacy for the State Department.

headline: From Baby Fat to Stubble: Growing Up in Real Time
abstract: Richard Linklater’s tender and profound film, which follows a boy and his family over a dozen years in real time, is a meticulously textured work set to the rhythm of life.
lead_paragraph: The first shot in “Boyhood,” Richard Linklater’s tender, profound film, is of a cloudy sky. The second is of a boy staring up at that sky, one arm bent under his head, the other flung out straight on the ground. He’s a pretty child with calm eyes, a snub nose and a full mouth. It’s a face that you get to know and love because, even as this child is watching the world, you’re watching him grow. From scene to scene, you see the curve of his jaw change, notice his thickening brows and witness his slender arms opening to embrace the world and its clear and darkening skies.

headline: Feet Planted on a Choreographic Riddle
abstract: Tere O’Connor is bringing the four parts of his “Bleed” project to the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., the first time these works will be performed together in one place.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of every project, the choreographer Tere O’Connor asks himself a basic question. As he said recently over coffee near his West Village apartment: “What am I doing? What is dance trying to do?”

headline: Look East, West and Inward
abstract: Turkey’s classical music ensembles face growing challenges, from proposed budget cuts to accusations of a Western-style elitism.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — On a recent evening here, young people tossed Frisbees on the grassy lawns of an American-style college campus, while elegantly clad patrons sipped wine before a concert featuring the soprano Diana Damrau and the harpist Xavier de Maistre.

headline: Homesick Strangers Among Us
abstract: In Cristina Henríquez’s “The Book of Unknown Americans,” an array of characters from Latin America talk directly about their reasons for coming to the United States.
lead_paragraph: “We’re the unknown Americans,” says a character in Cristina Henríquez’s second novel, “the ones no one even wants to know, because they’ve been told they’re supposed to be scared of us and because maybe if they did take the time to get to know us, they might realize that we’re not that bad, maybe even that we’re a lot like them.”

headline: Unlikely Warriors
abstract: A man known as Elephant Bill had an almost mystical understanding of the animals, and trained them to help build bridges and evacuate refugees during World War II.
lead_paragraph: I have to confess — my love of elephants made me apprehensive to review a book about their role in World War II. But as soon as I began to read “Elephant Company,” I realized that not only was my heart safe, but that this book is about far more than just the war, or even elephants. This is the story of friendship, loyalty and breathtaking bravery that transcends species.

headline: The Fault in Our DNA
abstract: Do genes shape behavior and history, or are they malleable? Two authors disagree.
lead_paragraph: In his 2007 book “A Farewell to Alms,” the economic historian Gregory Clark argued that the English came to rule the world largely because their rich outbred their poor, and thus embedded their superior genes and values throughout the nation. In her comprehensive takedown, the historian Deirdre N. McCloskey noted that Clark’s idea was a “bold hypothesis, and was bold when first articulated by social Darwinists such as Charles Davenport and Francis Galton in the century before last.” Indeed, over the past 150 years, various white Western scientists and writers have repeatedly offered biological explanations for Caucasian superiority. They have repeatedly failed because, as Mc­Closkey noted, none ever mounted a credible quantitative argument.

headline: The Settlers
abstract: More than a million Chinese pioneers have built new lives in Africa.
lead_paragraph: On a trip to Lusaka, Zambia, last year, I kept chasing an energetic and jittery Chinese man, the only staff member of a Chinese mining company willing to talk to me after his firm had been involved in several scandals in which both Chinese and Zambian employees were either killed or injured on the job. Zambia, with its abundant copper ore deposits, is one of the most important investment destinations for China. His English was excellent, and he liked to talk — and talk. After telling me about how much he loved the country and its people, he sometimes went into a rant about how Zambian miners liked drinking and money too much, and did not like to work hard. It was that mentality, he continued, that had caused his company all its troubles (not the workplace-safety and low-pay grievances of which it was accused). But even though the Zambian government had repossessed his company’s mines, this man wasn’t leaving. He was now working as an interpreter for the government.

headline: Wedding Q. & A.
abstract: What to do when a couple invited to the wedding has split up, and when the bride has gone fishing — for gifts.
lead_paragraph: Invitation to an Etiquette Disaster

headline: André Greipel Wins a Sprint at the Tour de France
abstract: Greipel, a German, won Thursday’s 120-mile stage, beating, among others, Marcel Kittel, who had won three previous sprint stages. Vincenzo Nibali remained the leader.
lead_paragraph: REIMS, France — Just when it looked as if Marcel Kittel might win all of the sprint finishes at this year’s Tour de France, another German sprinter, André Greipel, was first across the line at the end of the 194-kilometer (120-mile) stage form Arras to Reims on Thursday.

headline: As Gold and Gambling Lose Their Luster, Deadwood Seeks a Spark
abstract: As more states legalize casinos, dissipating the power of that lure, the South Dakota town is trying to restyle its history and offerings into a new tourist-friendly package.
lead_paragraph: DEADWOOD, S.D. — This old Western town of gunfights and gambling is going through an identity crisis.

headline: Direct From the Acme Animation Co.
abstract: The Museum of the Moving Image celebrates a cartoon pioneer with the show “What’s Up, Doc? The Animation Art of Chuck Jones.”
lead_paragraph: He wasn’t famous for chomping on carrots, outsmarting hunters or painting realistic tunnels on the sides of mountains, but Chuck Jones was as important to the history of animation as Bugs Bunny or Wile E. Coyote. Jones spent the 1930s through the 1960s directing many of the most manic and inventive Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies shorts featuring those beloved Warner Bros. characters; he went on to direct and produce more ambitious animation before his death in 2002.

headline: Betting on Diesel Cars, Exxon Is Set to Expand Belgium Refinery
abstract: With refining eroding into a money-losing area for most European players, Exxon Mobil is making a contrarian bet by expanding diesel production.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At Dimitris Poliviou’s car repair shop, customers are increasingly turning up with diesel-powered vehicles.

headline: Google Launches European Venture Fund
abstract: The Internet giant has been investing in start-ups in the United States for years. Now it is extending its venture reach to Europe with a $100 million fund.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a sign that Europe’s tech scene is coming into its own, Google announced that its venture capital unit had started a $100 million fund to invest in the region’s start-ups.

headline: In China, Four Seasons of Design
abstract: Isabelle Pascale, founder of the boutique Wuhao in a preserved corner of Beijing, showcases the work of contemporary Chinese and Western designers.
lead_paragraph: Isabelle Pascale, founder of the boutique Wuhao in a preserved corner of Beijing, showcases the work of contemporary Chinese and Western designers.

headline: Obama’s FunnyorDie.com Video Nominated for Emmy
abstract: The president engaged in a sometimes silly, sometimes awkward interview with Zach Galifianakis.
lead_paragraph: President Obama may have a future in Hollywood. The FunnyorDie.com video starring Mr. Obama and Zach Galifianakis was nominated for an Emmy on Thursday in the category of short-format live-action entertainment programs.

headline: Brazil’s BTG Pactual to Acquire Reinsurer
abstract: The acquisition of Ariel Re is seen as part of a long-term strategy by BTG Pactual to diversify away from its core Brazilian investment banking business.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO —  BTG Pactual of Brazil announced on Thursday that it was buying Ariel Re, a reinsurance company based in Bermuda and London, from the Global Atlantic Financial Group, a privately held insurance company that was spun off from Goldman Sachs in 2013.

headline: Rowin’, Rowin’, Rowin’ on the River
abstract: Harlem River Community Rowing offers eight-session Learn-to-Row courses for beginners throughout the summer.
lead_paragraph: IF you want a workout that’s strenuous, frightening, frustrating, thrilling, exhausting, challenging and serene all at the same time, try rowing in an eight-oared boat on the Harlem River.

headline: A Fugitive Who Stops to Smell the Flowers
abstract: In “Road to Paloma,” Jason Momoa plays a Native American whose act of retribution sets the F.B.I. on his trail.
lead_paragraph: “Road to Paloma,” a leisurely drama about family, brotherhood and Native American rights, plays out on the dusty highways and barren landscapes of an American West that seems frozen in time. Using that quality to powerful effect, the director, Jason Momoa, and his cinematographer, Brian Andrew Mendoza, shore up a simple plot with a richly atmospheric palette of coppery light and caramel sunsets that makes even urgent events seem almost soothing.

headline: Cancer Sidelines Japanese Composer
abstract: The Japanese composer and keyboardist Ryuichi Sakamoto says he is suffered from throat cancer.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese composer and keyboardist (and, occasionally, actor) Ryuichi Sakamoto posted a note on his website on Thursday saying that he has throat cancer, and has decided to cancel his performances at the Sapporo International Art Festival of which he is the guest director.

headline: In Rubble of Gaza Seaside Cafe, Hunt for Victims Who Had Come for Soccer
abstract: At least eight people were killed by a missile, apparently targeting what Israel’s military later described as a single terrorist.
lead_paragraph: KHAN YOUNIS, Gaza Strip — About a dozen local Palestinians gathered Wednesday evening at the Fun Time Beach cafe, a beachside eatery of plastic chairs, umbrellas, walls of cloth and palm leaves, a container for a kitchen and a small bathroom, to watch the World Cup match between Argentina and the Netherlands.

headline: A Spectacle of Pop Idol Proportions
abstract: An inflatable car, a riot of neon Lycra and a flotilla of parade balloons shared the stage with Katy Perry on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment of giddy self-declaration (O.K., one of many) in the splatter canvas of pop pageantry that is Katy Perry’s “Prismatic World Tour.” It comes during “This Is How We Do,” a flippant anthem of consumption featured in one of Ms. Perry’s recent commercials for a major cosmetics brand. On Wednesday night, in her sold-out show at Madison Square Garden, its staging involved an inflatable car, a riot of neon Lycra and a flotilla of parade balloons, including one for the emoji pictograph widely known as “smiling pile of poo.”

headline: Hidden Pleasures Lie Within
abstract: At Khao Kang, the Thai food at the steam table is not labeled, but the layers of flavor make themselves known.
lead_paragraph: If you ask, the patient people at Khao Kang will identify the dozen unlabeled dishes on the steam table for you, but this will not necessarily help. Their one-word descriptions (“shrimp,” “chicken” and, repeatedly, “pork”) tell nothing of the layers of flavor, surprises and comforts to be found here, in one of the sincerest Thai restaurants in New York City.

headline: For One Team, It’s Sink or Swim
abstract: Students from a low-income high school in Arizona win a robotics competition and reflect on their victory in “Underwater Dreams.”
lead_paragraph: Four teenagers winning an academic contest might not seem to merit a documentary. Happens all the time, right? But in “Underwater Dreams,” the teenagers are Latinos — and illegal immigrants, four of the many who could gain citizenship through the Dream Act — from a low-income high school in Arizona. They win against many colleges, including M.I.T., in a robotics challenge. And their unlikely achievement, in 2004, reverberates a decade later, helping the students who followed them at Carl Hayden Community High School to have more confidence and even, in some cases, propelling them to work as engineers and as leaders in Dreamer groups.

headline: Reform Conservatism and the Culture War
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Marijuana', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A response to E.J. Dionne and Andrew Sullivan on conservatives and cultural modernization.
lead_paragraph: After my foray yesterday into the specific case of Paul Ryan, let me return to broader critiques of reform conservatism, picking up threads from E.J. Dionne’s long essay on our little movement and some of Andrew Sullivan’s comments this week. I first read Dionne’s essay some time ago and intended a long point-by-point rejoinder; I’ve read so many (far harsher, less thoughtful) critiques since, however, that upon re-reading the essay seemed marvelously fair-minded, and worth recommending even if I obviously have disagreements with its substance. But here’s a prescriptive passage that’s worth commenting on:

headline: Don’t Bring That Boyfriend Home
abstract: In Shan Khan’s “Honour,” a young British Pakistani woman’s relationship with a Punjabi man incurs her family’s wrath.
lead_paragraph: Folding social realism into a woman-in-peril thriller, “Honour” confronts the problem of so-called honor killings among British Muslims with brash economy and first-feature zeal.

headline: Field of Misfits
abstract: The story of a short-lived baseball team, the Portland Mavericks, is revisited in “The Battered Bastards of Baseball.”
lead_paragraph: The story of the Portland Mavericks could slip easily into the same lineup as “Bull Durham” or “Major League”: A baseball outsider starts an independent team in Oregon, holds open tryouts that draw castoffs and rejects, then watches his wild bunch beat more talented clubs.

headline: The Car That Witnessed the Spark of World War I
abstract: Contrary to many Internet sources, the 1910 Gräf & Stift touring car in which Archduke Franz Ferdinand was assassinated in 1914 is not cursed.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the heir apparent to the Austro-Hungarian throne, and his wife, Sophie, the duchess of Hohenberg, were killed in Sarajevo while riding in a Gräf & Stift open-topped touring car. It was the event that ignited World War I.

headline: Backsliding Into Brutality to Avenge a Daughter
abstract: In “Rage,” Nicolas Cage plays a reformed mobster who forsakes the straight and narrow after his daughter is killed.
lead_paragraph: Those expecting Nicolas Cage theatrics in “Rage” — and why not, with a title that practically cries out for a rhyming tagline — may be disappointed. Mr. Cage underplays in his latest role, as a father out for justice after his daughter’s violent death, and it’s at least an attempt at a change-up. But the hand-me-down showiness and sluggish storytelling by the director, Paco Cabezas, underline the monotony in this ordinary revenge thriller.

headline: A Smitten Boy Senses an Opening and Seizes It
abstract: In “The Empty Hours,” a 17-year-old looking after his uncle’s hotel connects with a woman who is a regular guest.
lead_paragraph: Washed in the colors of surf and sand, and moving to the languid rhythms of swaying palm trees, “The Empty Hours” is like a mental vacation from the noise and bombast of the summer blockbuster. No convoluted plot or high-wattage star distracts from its meandering observations and mellow performances; no crass jokes or car chases disrupt its delicate, yearning mood. In other words, this second feature by the Mexican director Aarón Fernández is a delight.

headline: Sarah Palin’s Impeachment Plan, Rejected
abstract: Republicans don’t seem game to impeach the president. But only because it’s not practical.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin’s argument—if one can call it that—in Breitbart a few days ago that it’s “time to impeach” President Obama isn’t gaining much traction among Republicans with actual power. Andrew Kaczynski of BuzzFeed has pulled together quotes from elected officials with no interest in trying to add Mr. Obama to that exclusive club composed of Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton (Richard Nixon was not actually impeached). What’s notable is that their lack of interest is entirely practical—i.e. they won’t say the president doesn’t deserve impeachment, only that it’s not going to happen.

headline: Guys With Lots of Mileage, on the Road
abstract: “Land Ho!” follows two older men on a journey around Iceland, learning that sometimes self-discovery just needs different vistas.
lead_paragraph: The road movie, that asphalt playground of fast cars, masculine prerogative, gangland sprees and occasional feminist cri de coeur, is such a durable American genre that you can fly the idea halfway around the world, drop it on Iceland, rev up a car the size of a military tank and still make it work. This pretty much describes what happens in “Land Ho!,” a delightful tale of two longtime friends of a certain age, Colin (Paul Eenhoorn) and Mitch (Earl Lynn Nelson), who embark on a classic journey of self-discovery generously embellished with laughter, otherworldly beauty and philosophical inquiries into the nature of existence perfumed by the aroma of cheerfully smoked joints.

headline: Collecting Books That Are Just Covers
abstract: Blooks — antique objects that simulate books for other purposes — are a growing field of interest for collectors.
lead_paragraph: Anything that looks like a book but is not one interests Mindell Dubansky, a preservation librarian at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. For 20 years, she has been buying antiques with simulations of covers, spines and pages.

headline: With the End of Days Near, a Sect Is Torn
abstract: “As It Is in Heaven,” a low-budget debut by Joshua Overbay, was shot in just 17 days.
lead_paragraph: “As It Is in Heaven” opens quietly yet with unmistakable joy as the camera tracks a white-robed young woman through gracious rooms and lush gardens to the banks of a sparkling river. Joining the other members of her small religious sect, she watches their prophet (John Lina) baptize a new recruit (Chris Nelson) and give him the name David.

headline: Britain’s Schindler, a Reluctant Hero
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Despite his natural reticence, a British man responsible for saving 669 children from the Holocaust is getting the recognition he deserves.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, the BBC program “That’s Life!” aired an episode dedicated to Sir Nicholas Winton, a British stockbroker who rescued 669 mostly Jewish children from Nazi-occupied Czechoslovakia in 1939. In the wake of Sir Nicholas’s 105th birthday last May, a segment from that episode went viral.

headline: Candidates Raise Specter of Cheating in Indonesian Presidential Election
abstract: Though quick counts project Joko Widodo as the winner, his opponent, Prabowo Subianto, accused him of trying to hijack the country’s democracy.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Political tensions in Indonesia rose on Thursday, a day after the country’s hotly contested presidential election, as the supporters of the two candidates raised fears about possible cheating during days of vote tallying.

headline: If You Read This, You Might Never Drink a Latte Again
abstract: Maligned as a drink for the out-of-touch privileged classes or as a splurge that’s draining Americans’ bank accounts, the latte says a lot about our attitudes to food, work and money.
lead_paragraph: Lattes have a lot to answer for. To some, drinking one makes you a snob. To others, it makes you a spendthrift. But neither of these perceptions may be particularly accurate — and in fact, the latte can tell us a lot about how America thinks about food, work and money.

headline: Evidence of H.I.V. Found in a Child Said to Be Cured
abstract: The apparent cure had raised the thrilling possibility that aggressive early treatment might be able to reverse infections in newborns — and perhaps even in newly infected adults.
lead_paragraph: A child in Mississippi who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. with aggressive drug treatment immediately after birth is now showing signs of infection with the virus, federal health officials announced Thursday — a serious setback to hopes for a cure for AIDS.

headline: That First Step Is a Doozy
abstract: “A Long Way Down,” a suicide sitcom based on a Nick Hornby novel, stars Pierce Brosnan, Toni Collette, Aaron Paul and Imogen Poots.
lead_paragraph: On New Year’s Eve, four despondent Londoners determined to end it all simultaneously converge at a favorite suicide destination atop a tall building. After jockeying for position (who goes first?), followed by some perky commiseration, they agree not to hurl themselves into oblivion but to postpone their rendezvous with death until Valentine’s Day, at which point they will return and make the leap. In the meantime, they form a cheery mutual support group, meeting here and there around London and even traveling together to Spain.

lead_paragraph: Across Latin America, girls celebrate their 15th birthday as their quinceañera, the beginning of young womanhood. So it was appropriate that intrepid, idealistic women — Ana Tijoux, from Chile, and Danay Suárez, from Cuba — were the standouts at the first concerts of the 15th annual Latin Alternative Music Conference, which continues through Saturday. It presents rock, pop and hip-hop, often bilingual, from across the Americas at free concerts and club events.

abstract: KT Sullivan and Jeff Harnar’s “Our Time” reinterprets Stephen Sondheim’s songs for the era of same-sex marriage and the dissolution of traditional roles.
lead_paragraph: “Our Time,” the opening number of KT Sullivan and Jeff Harnar’s iconoclastic Stephen Sondheim show at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Wednesday evening, is the optimistic dawn-of-a-new-age anthem from “Merrily We Roll Along.” It’s the 1950s, and there are nothing but blue skies and bright futures ahead in the lives of its naïve musical-theater hopefuls gazing forward with starry-eyed confidence.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of uniformed firefighters gathered for the funeral of Lt. Gordon Matthew Ambelas, who died Saturday searching for victims in a burning high-rise apartment building in Brooklyn.

headline: Birth of a Career
abstract: Dealing with an awkward question for a youngster, a returned gift, unwanted matchmaking and rushed dining.
lead_paragraph: I am 11 years old. Practically every adult I meet asks me, “What do you want to be when you grow up?” This would be really cute if I was 4 and could say, “Fireman.” But I’m in the fifth grade and have no idea what I want to do for work 10 years from now. How can I respond that won’t get me in trouble with my parents?

headline: Unlikely Tenants Filling a Neighborhood Vacancy
abstract: The nonprofit art group No Longer Empty organized an exhibition, “If You Build It,” inside an in-progress affordable-housing complex in Washington Heights.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, when a bad economy left commercial spaces vacant across New York City, an itinerant nonprofit art group called No Longer Empty started filling some of them — a storefront on West 23rd Street, the closed-up Tower Records on lower Broadway — with art. This summer, the organization adds a twist to its mission by working on premises that have yet to be occupied, an in-progress 13-story affordable-housing complex called the Sugar Hill Building located on West 155th Street in Washington Heights.

headline: Scant Interest in F.H.A. Program
abstract: A government program aimed at helping “underwater” homeowners refinance captures only a sliver of the borrowers thought to be eligible.
lead_paragraph: A government program aimed at helping “underwater” homeowners refinance into more-affordable, reduced-principal loans has captured only a sliver of the borrowers thought to be eligible in the four years since its introduction.

headline: Devil Swipes a Violin, but the Band Plays On
abstract: The Drunkard’s Wife, an experimental theatrical troupe, loosely adapts “Histoire du Soldat” to create a bleary, madcap musical at the New Ohio Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Feather Gatherers,” part of the Ice Factory festival, a wellspring of singular drama, unfurls in some fantastical Serbia of the mind, a Slivovitz-soaked realm of peasant blouses and folk superstitions. Produced by the Drunkard’s Wife, an experimental theatrical troupe, and loosely adapted from Stravinsky’s dance-theater piece “L’Histoire du Soldat,” this bleary, madcap musical tells the story, more or less, of a naïve soldier (Jess Barbagallo) who falls prey to the wily Devil (Juliana Francis Kelly).

headline: Daniel Heidkamp
abstract: The three main shows at White Columns form a meditation on current painting tactics.
lead_paragraph: The three main shows at White Columns form a meditation on current painting tactics. In one small gallery, Patrick Berran very capably meets the demand for Minimalist paintings made by largely hands-off methods — in his case, layers of photocopy transfers dominated by a pattern that reads as leopard skin or moisture condensation, depending on its size. Nearby, Jennifer Nichols works with thin, bright acrylic, creating abstract tumults of transparent brushwork and, more recently, calmer arrangements of letterlike shapes. Both artists show promise, but so far they are operating within fashionable styles rather than making the work that only they can make.

headline: Long Days, Extra Innings
abstract: New art books include textured dreamscapes by Lee Bontecou and full-size reproductions of Charles M. Schulz’s “Peanuts.”
lead_paragraph: New art books include textured dreamscapes by Lee Bontecou and full-size reproductions of Charles M. Schulz’s “Peanuts.”

headline: Knud Lonberg-Holm: ‘The Invisible Architect’
abstract: The Danish-American architect Knud Lonberg-Holm belonged to that moment in the 1920s when de Stijl principles were translated into three-dimensional space.
lead_paragraph: The Danish-American architect Knud Lonberg-Holm, the first European to teach the Bauhaus curriculum in America, belonged to that white-hot, manifesto-propelled moment in the 1920s when de Stijl principles were being translated into three-dimensional space. A dozen of his limpid gouache renderings of Michigan houses, all masterly compositions of point, line and plane, show buildings broken into constituent walls, roofs, floors and columns. With a palette of photographic black, white and gray, accented in blues and reds, he created weightless abstractions; solids and voids intersect in optical puzzles. He brushed calligraphic proposals for the new streamlined building types of the Machine Age — gas and radio stations — with a fierce graphic energy. His radically angled photographs of America’s traffic jams, skyscrapers, fire escapes and power lines found their way into “Amerika,” the German architect Erich Mendelsohn’s photographic essay of American cityscapes. Letters from Theo van Doesburg, Walter Gropius and Mies van der Rohe authenticate his position as a peer. Buckminster Fuller wanted to write a book about him.

abstract: Ford Models, founded by Mrs. Ford and her husband, Jerry, in 1947, elevated modeling to a serious business and created a market for “supermodels.”
lead_paragraph: Eileen Ford, the grande dame of the modeling industry who influenced standards of beauty for more than four decades while heading one of the most recognizable brands in the trade of gorgeous faces, died on Wednesday in Morristown, N.J. She was 92.

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s new government in India has unveiled its first economic road map aimed at increasing investment, improving infrastructure and reviving manufacturing, even while curbing borrowing. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley said the economy would expand at an annual rate of 7 to 8 percent within three years, but warned that the global slowdown had created a difficult environment for growth. The plan received a mixed reception.

abstract: A new generation of fun zones blending gastronomy, a hip aesthetic and a low-key ambience have sprung up in New York City.
lead_paragraph: REAL New Yorkers don’t do malls. Or amusement parks, unless they’re a little decrepit and dangerous. Or food courts, unless they’re crowded and ethnic. Or street fairs, unless they’re right outside and can’t be avoided.

headline: A River Runs Through It: The Amazon as Inspiration
abstract: In “Waterweavers,” an exhibition at Bard Graduate Center, nature is seen as vulnerable but also in infused with hallucinatory energy.
lead_paragraph: “Waterweavers: The River in Contemporary Colombian Visual Arts and Material Culture” at the Bard Graduate Center is the most unassumingly beautiful show I’ve seen in New York this summer. And with its glades of abstract patterning, eddying pools of woven fiber, and projected images of water sluicing through galleries, it’s visually the coolest.

headline: Harps vs. the Usual Hubbub
abstract: The New York Philharmonic opened its summer series of free parks concerts with a performance in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Members of the New York Philharmonic departing in a bus after a concert Wednesday evening in Prospect Park’s Long Meadow were saluted with cheers and waves, like a triumphant soccer team leaving a stadium. The event, conducted by Alan Gilbert, was the opener in the orchestra’s free parks concerts series, and the police estimated that it drew 15,000 people.

headline: If Gatsby Were Coming of Age Today ...

lead_paragraph: “Affluenza” begins in September 2008, as an investment banker (Roger Rees) blathers to the protagonist, Fisher (Ben Rosenfield), about a “going-out-of-business sale” for the baby boomers. He quotes Rudyard Kipling on the law of the jungle and tells Fisher, an aspiring photographer, that his pictures capture the decline of a generation of overindulged kids.

headline: Ashes to Ashes, Dust to Powder
abstract: “Help!,” Dan Colen’s show at the Brant Foundation in Greenwich, Conn., recalls a friend and muse who died young.
lead_paragraph: At the grassy summit of a low hill outside the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., the metal cargo containers of two 14-foot box trucks rise vertically like twin towers, their cabs buried underground. It’s a sculpture called “At Least They Died Together (After Dash)” (2013-14), by Dan Colen, and it’s a memorial to his friend Dash Snow, who died of a drug overdose in 2009. It appears as an incongruous eyesore against the backdrop of its bucolic surroundings. Visitors may notice that the thin skins of the truck boxes have holes in them. During the exhibition’s opening, Mr. Colen threw rocks and hammers at them, while drummers of the two-person band I.U.D. — one atop each of the truck ends — played thunderously.

headline: Many Sacrifices, but Few Perks for Event’s Volunteers

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The day after Brazil lost to Germany in the host country’s worst World Cup loss ever, thousands of volunteers slipped on their official teal blue shirts, slid on their official dark pants and perhaps pulled the brim of their official hats down low to head to another day of working at this event, which began last month as the nation’s pride but is now its raw humiliation.

headline: Shadowy Rebel Wields Iron Fist in Ukraine Fight
abstract: Once marked as a dead man, Igor Strelkov made his first public appearance in Donetsk in a move to assert authority over fractious separatist militias.
lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — Late one afternoon last month, as separatist militia fighters and Ukrainian forces exchanged fire, a small-time thief by the name of Aleksei B. Pichko left his home on the southern edge of Slovyansk and headed for an abandoned residence at 17 Sadovaya Street. He had been drinking, and wanted to “see what could be stolen from there,” according to documents recovered at the rebel headquarters after their retreat over the weekend.

headline: Form, Function and Beauty Span Eons in Met Acquisitions
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired an ancient Roman urn and a group of 44 20th-century glass works by Carlo Scarpa.
lead_paragraph: Objects have long been considered a poor cousin to paintings, but not at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where two recent acquisitions spanning centuries and civilizations were as functional as they were decorative. One is an early Roman vessel used as a cinerary urn; another, a group of 20th-century Venetian glass designs by the Italian architect Carlo Scarpa, was on view last winter.

headline: The Art of Water Recovery
abstract: The E.P.A. estimates that public water systems lose one-sixth of their water, mainly from leaks in pipes or service connections. Why don’t utilities do more to get it back?
lead_paragraph: Imagine that you run a company that sells bottled water. You spend lots of money, and use lots of energy, pumping the water out of the ground, purifying it and transporting it for sale. Then, one day, you discover that a large number of bottles never make it to the stores. They are falling through holes in the trucks.

headline: Q. and A.: Rana Mitter on the Legacy of World War II in Asia
abstract: The Oxford historian says that, unlike in Europe, where a broad consensus on the war has been achieved, interpretations of the conflict in Asia remain a source of acrimony between the major players, with important ramifications for the future of the region.
lead_paragraph: When Chinese President Xi Jinping spoke at an event in Beijing on Monday commemorating the 77th anniversary of the start of full-scale war with Japan, he warned against efforts to downplay Japan’s brutal occupation of China. It was a stark reminder of how the events of that era continue to shape the geopolitics of Asia today, as China and Japan square off over territorial disputes and Beijing voices concern about Japan’s moves to lift  longstanding restrictions on its military forces.

Mr. Ban said Mr. de Mistura, whose appointment had been expected by other diplomats, would be working to stop “all violence and human rights violations, and promoting a peaceful solution to the Syrian crisis.” Mr. de Mistura’s predecessor, Lakhdar Brahimi, resigned two months ago in frustration. He had replaced Kofi Annan, the former secretary general who called the Syria job “mission impossible.” Mr. Ban also said that he had appointed Ramzy Ezzeldin Ramzy, an Egyptian diplomat, as Mr. de Mistura’s deputy.

headline: These Fruits Were Made for Grilling

lead_paragraph: On the Fourth of July, before the meat and fish hit the grill, I decided to throw on some fruit. I’ve always loved the way roasting summer stone fruit like peaches and apricots deepens their flavors, and I thought a sizzle on the grill might do the same. It did. Just a few minutes on each side – enough to create griddle marks on a peach or an apricot and soften it, but not so long that the fruit collapses, brought out the juices and warmed the fruit through. When I removed the peaches and apricots from the grill I tossed them with a little honey and lemon zest.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Starz) FROZEN (2013) Warm up your vocal cords. This Disney 3-D animated movie musical produced “Let It Go,” the Oscar-winning power anthem, written by Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez, on seemingly every child’s (and quite a few adults’) lips since its release in November. Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee directed this fable about Elsa (the voice of Idina Menzel), an ice princess cursed with a frigid touch, and Anna (Kristen Bell), her younger sister and best friend. When Anna falls for a handsome prince (Santino Fontana), Elsa forbids them to marry, casting their Scandinavian kingdom into eternal winter with a wave of her hand. Horrified, she retreats to an ice palace atop a mountain, but sibling love sends Anna plowing through drifts and up glacial ridges in search of Elsa, confident that she can reverse the spell. “Allegorically, ‘Frozen’ lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like ‘Beauty and the Beast,’ but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this blockbuster, inspired by Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Snow Queen.” “There are moments when you may feel that you are inside a giant crystal chandelier frosted with diamonds.” Josh Gad plays Olaf, the snowman sidekick (above, with Anna and Kristoff, voiced by Jonathan Groff) who would rather be a beach bunny, in this Oscar winner for best animated feature.

headline: The Post-Post-Apocalyptic Detroit
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Black and white, young and old, billionaires and shop owners — a growing chorus of optimists in Detroit is saying that the time is right to invest.
lead_paragraph: In downtown Detroit, at the headquarters of the online-mortgage company Quicken Loans, there stands another downtown Detroit in miniature. The diorama, made of laser-cut acrylic and stretching out over 19 feet in length, is a riot of color and light: Every structure belonging to Quicken’s billionaire owner, Dan Gilbert, is topped in orange and illuminated from within, and Gilbert currently owns 60 of them, a lordly nine million square feet of real estate in all. He began picking up skyscrapers just three and a half years ago, one after another, paying as little as $8 a square foot. He bought five buildings surrounding Capitol Park, the seat of government when Michigan became a state in 1837. He snapped up the site of the old Hudson’s department store, where 12,000 employees catered to 100,000 customers daily in the 1950s. Many of Gilbert’s purchases are 20th-century architectural treasures, built when Detroit served as a hub of world industry. He bought a Daniel Burnham, a few Albert Kahns, a Minoru Yamasaki masterwork with a soaring glass atrium. “They’re like old-school sports cars,” said Dan Mullen, one of the executives who took over Quicken’s newly formed real estate arm. “These were buildings with so much character, so much history. They don’t exist anywhere else. And it was like, ‘Buy this parking garage, and we’ll throw in a skyscraper with it.’ ”

He has ventured to a floating village where children kick improvised soccer balls along narrow docks, to a prison where inmates make balls, to an amateur tournament where teams and beauty queens compete together and to indigenous villages that are an overnight boat ride away from the nearest World Cup match.

headline: 1964: Dance Marathon in Paris
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France celebrates Bastille Day in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The huge doors of firehouses throughout the city swung open this afternoon and thousands of Parisians invaded gaily decorated courtyards to start off the annual dance marathon coinciding with the anniversary of the fall of the Bastille. By tomorrow evening, scores of competing “bals” will have sprung up at most of the major intersections and squares, and seemingly nearly all of Paris will be kicking high in a polka or weaving in a conga line. With a frenzy matching the revolutionary fervor in the streets on July 14, 1789, many will pursue the dancing until dawn on Tuesday. The hardiest then will rest briefly before hustling over to the Champs-Élysées for the annual military parade. Officially, July 14 has been celebrated as a national holiday only since 1880. The parliament then, it has been said, wanted to endow the Third Republic with a fête day comparable to those established under previous regimes. Although nearly a century had passed since the Revolution, strong but futile protests were delivered in parliament against the official glorification of a day associated with the parading of decapitated heads on spikes in the streets. Some of the rites marking that first official commemoration continue to be observed today. Others have been modified or have disappeared. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 13, 1964

One of them, Muhammed Bella, works at Westside Brewhouse, where he waits on tables most days and pitches in as a deliveryman on Mondays. He says the customers are curt and rude much of the time. “They treat you bad,” says Bella, a native of Nigeria who lives in the Bronx. “Not everybody. But when you try to deliver to them, some people are drunk. They act up. I say nothing. I just say, ‘Thank you, have a good day, bye.’ ” ﻿Julie Bosman

headline: 1939: ‘Peace’ Raid Made Over France
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The British Royal Air Force stages a sham air raid in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than 120 of the finest heavy and medium bombers of the British Royal Air Force participated today [July 11] in the most impressive and significant sham air raid yet staged in air-conscious Europe. Taking off in succession this morning from their aerodrome in the English Midlands, the British planes pointed southward and “spread their wings” out over France. Never before had so many military planes of one country carried out an expedition of this character over the territory of another. The only information given the squadron commanders before they left the ground was that their destinations were “somewhere in France.” Sealed orders, when broken in the air, instructed the heavy bombers, totaling about eighty units, to make a round- trip, non-stop flight to Bordeaux, the French port on the Bay of Biscay, a two- way distance of nearly 1,200 miles. Similar orders provided a shorter flight for about forty medium bombers passing above the French cities of Le Treport, Orleans, and Le Mans, near Cherbourg. Their cruising radius is more restricted. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 12, 1939

Anyone who thinks the bond between man and dog or cat is the supreme human-house pet attachment will have to reconsider after reading Martin Windrow’s touching account of the bird who changed his life, a possessive and characterful tawny owl named Mumble who was his domestic companion for 15 action-packed years. In the wild, a tawny owl is lucky to reach the age of 5; Mumble, living with the author in South London and later in rural Sussex, enjoyed three times that life span.

In August 2008, Lindhout — a 27-year-old Canadian traveler and fledgling television reporter — was kidnapped in Somalia along with a photojournalist named Nigel Brennan. This account of Lindhout’s 460 days in captivity is more than a gonzo adventure tale gone awry; it’s a powerful coming-of-age story and a narrative of forgiveness and spiritual triumph.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: FOURTH OF JULY CREEK,  by Smith Henderson. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $26.99.) In Henderson’s deeply impressive novel, an overburdened social worker becomes involved with a near-feral boy and his survivalist father in 1980 Montana.

headline: Teenagers Rule
abstract: Social order breaks down when a mysterious illness spreads worldwide, sparing only adolescents.
lead_paragraph: Chris Weitz’s “The Young World” tells of a Manhattan dominated by tribes of swaggering, self-possessed adolescents, some buzzed on attention-deficit medication, cruising through the city while adults cringe in the shadows, fearing for their lives. Oh, no, that was my teenage daughter’s diary of her life in eighth grade last year. (Sorry for the joke, darling; I would never read your journal, really.) But in Weitz’s novel, those things do happen — save that the adults are all dead. Indeed, Weitz takes that familiar, real-world theme of precocious autonomy and carries it to its logical end: What if Manhattan was not just dominated by adolescents but actually ruled by them in a Hobbesian world of violence and ­savagery?

headline: Health Official on Child’s H.I.V. Return
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director, discussed the case of a child who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. and is now showing signs of infection.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director, discussed the case of a child who was thought to have been cured of H.I.V. and is now showing signs of infection.

headline: On the Move
abstract: Three picture books feature children struggling with displacement and new surroundings.
lead_paragraph: As America’s postwar baby boomers grew up, dipped a toe or more in child psychology studies at college and started families of their own, children’s book publishers took note of a new, pop cultural sensitivity to a wide array of ­developmentally-based childhood trials and tribulations. Picture books about ­potty training, tantrum throwing, the death of a pet and other emotionally charged topics proliferated, and were often shelved together at the library under the catchall heading of “bibliotherapy.” Some authors explored these concerns more artfully than others. Judith Viorst (“Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day”) and the late Charlotte Zolotow (“The Hating Book,” “William’s Doll”) proved to be masters of the genre, their dry-eyed wit, empathic touch and storytelling prowess easily a match for their good intentions.

headline: Avatar
abstract: In this young adult novel, a teenager takes on an identity much like his girlfriend’s for an online role-playing game.
lead_paragraph: Steve Brezenoff’s third young adult novel, “Guy in Real Life,” begins when two teenagers literally collide one night in St. Paul, Minn. Lesh Tungsten, a metal-head with a heart of gold, steps in front of a bicycle ridden by Svetlana Allegheny, an artsy-craftsy dungeon master given to talking to herself in French, and the encounter leaves a deep impression on them both. Svetlana, because she is furious with Lesh for causing her sketchbook to fall into a puddle; Lesh, because Svetlana looks “like an angel. ”

headline: Romeo and Juliet in Crown Heights
abstract: A Hasidic girl and a West Indian boy fall in love and face the consequences in this young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: Even before Devorah Blum meets the lanky West Indian nerd who will derail her plans to remain an “unfailingly obedient” Hasidic girl, there are signs she’s wavering. “Like No Other,” Una LaMarche’s second young adult novel, begins as a hurricane bears down on New York City. Devorah’s 18-year-old big sister, Rose, is about to give birth to her first baby prematurely. In the sweltering hospital waiting room, Devorah, dressed in a long wool skirt and tights for modesty’s sake, envies other girls sitting near by who are wearing shorts and tapping on cellphones, despite a sign forbidding their use. Devorah, 16, isn’t allowed a phone, because her family is part of the strict Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic movement. She used to admire how Rose, who had a “wild side,” read fashion magazines on the sly. Now, she laments how her sister has grown meek in marriage. Devorah’s own imminent future as a doting wife and teenage mother doesn’t look so bright to her anymore.

headline: Into the Deep
abstract: Matthew Gavin Frank’s wide-ranging book explores an amateur naturalist’s compulsion to understand the mystery of the giant squid.
lead_paragraph: In October 1873, 12-year-old Tommy Picco knocked on the door of the Rev. Moses Harvey’s house in Newfoundland, holding something enormous and strange. While out fishing, Picco and his companions had been attacked by a “devil-fish,” or giant squid. He’d finally beaten back the monster by hacking off its tentacles. One of the tentacles was 19 feet long. Picco thought Harvey might like to buy it.

headline: Out of Step
abstract: A New York ballerina helps a Russian dancer defect, but her own desires are thwarted.
lead_paragraph: The ballet world is incestuous — insular and intensely intimate, full of young, beautiful people who work grueling hours and share in one another’s triumphs, setbacks and neuroses. No wonder, then, that dancers’ professional and social lives become inescapably entwined, and that fictional works revolving around ballet so often default to melodrama.

headline: Adaptation
abstract: In this first novel, a girl adopted from China finds it difficult to situate herself in American life.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of Kathryn Ma’s haunting first novel, “The Year She Left Us,” is a young woman who loses her way. Ari is 18 and home from a summer in China, where she worked for a company that takes Western families with adopted Chinese girls on “heritage tours.” They visit the orphanages and, sometimes, the places where the abandoned babies were first found: police stations, department stores and random patches of dirt by the side of the road. For these orphans, their “Finding Day” may be the closest approximation to the simple commonplace most of us take for granted — a birthday.

headline: The Indiscreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie
abstract: A holiday near the Mediterranean leads to disaster for a doctor and his celebrity patient in this novel by the author of “The Dinner.”
lead_paragraph: Published in English last year, “The Dinner,” by the Dutch writer Herman Koch, became an international best seller in part by occupying that slender intersection between literary and commercial fiction. Its prose has the direct, undemanding quality of an airport novel, its story the momentum of a page turner. Yet its more literary devices — an elegant structure, with each section titled by course, “Aperitif,” “Appetizer” and so on, as a single restaurant dinner progresses; a narrator who seems increasingly unreliable — suggest a greater complexity, an ambition to achieve Higher Things.

headline: School for a Scoundrel
abstract: A classicist tries to unravel the enigma of Seneca, the Stoic philosopher who tutored the emperor Nero.
lead_paragraph: The name Seneca brings a particular image to mind: a gaunt, half-naked old man, glaring wildly, his veins open, his lifeblood seeping into the small bath beneath him after he was forced to commit suicide. Painted by Rubens, memorialized by Dante in his first circle of hell, gilded into medieval manuscripts alongside Plato and Aristotle, Seneca has come to represent the perils of proximity to absolute power. The central question of James Romm’s “Dying Every Day” is this: When we confront this tragic Roman wordsmith, tutor to the emperor Nero (and, some argue, the power behind that terrible throne), who stares back at us? Is it a tyrannodidaskalos, a tyrant-teacher? Is he the ultimate exemplar of Stoicism, a would-be philosopher king? Or is Seneca simply an accretion of history, a phantom constructed to fit our ravening for heroes, for antiheroes and for the sensational in the stories of antiquity?

headline: Rage Runs Through It
abstract: A painter with violent impulses tries to start over, but his past catches up with him.
lead_paragraph: Jim Stegner — the narrator of Peter Heller’s second novel, “The Painter” — burns hot. When rage finds him, “everything goes dark at the edges. Kind of tunnels down to the target.” This temper drove him, years ago, to pull a .41 Magnum and shoot a known sex offender point blank.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Joan Rivers’s “Diary of a Mad Diva,” No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list, is filled with the author’s brand of rapid-fire politically incorrect jokes.
lead_paragraph: The Fur Flies: Comedy is like sex, or subatomic particles: The more you try to analyze it, the more elusive it becomes. So it’s probably futile to look too closely at Joan Rivers’s latest book, “Diary of a Mad Diva,” new at No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list. But what the heck. As its title suggests, the book is structured as a conventional diary that happens to be filled with the author’s brand of rapid-fire politically incorrect jokes — in the second entry, Rivers contrasts herself favorably with Anne Frank: “I’ve written six books, and Anne? She didn’t even complete her one.” Rivers is unavoidably outré — racist, sexist, raunchy, crass — which isn’t to everybody’s taste. (Another way comedy resembles sex, and maybe subatomic particles — I’m no scientist — is that different folks like different strokes.) But readers seem divided as to whether Rivers is truly meanspirited or whether it’s all a provocation, a persona she slips into as easily as the fur coat she’s wearing on her book’s cover. When the CNN anchor Fredricka Whitfield suggested as much in a recent interview, noting that Rivers is a well-known animal rights advocate and wondering whether the fur was there just for its shock value, Rivers went ballistic. “Are you wearing leather shoes? Then shut up,” she said, before storming off the set. “I don’t want to hear this nonsense.” She didn’t seem to be joking.

headline: Asian Families Travel a Long Way for Summer Camp
abstract: Camp directors in and around New York City say the children of well-off families now annually descend upon the city to join their American peers in what has become, for those who can afford it, an international rite of passage.
lead_paragraph: After hours spent performing cartwheels, American show tunes and a series of jazzy dance routines in a cramped studio on West 28th Street in Manhattan, 8-year-old Futaba Kawakami left  TADA Youth Theater  camp earlier this week, clammy and slightly hoarse. She pulled off her new camp T-shirt, the one with the slogan Sing! Dance! Act! emblazoned on the back, and marshaled enough energy to ask her mother for ice cream. Then they headed off to 16 Handles in Chelsea.

abstract: It was another hustle play by Pete Rose, but this time even admirers began to suspect there was something off-kilter about him.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, July 14, 1970, 51,838 fans jammed into the spanking-new poured-concrete paradise of Cincinnati’s spare-tire-shaped Riverfront Stadium for Major League Baseball’s 41st All-Star Game. While the spectators waited for the game to start, transistor radios blared out that week’s top hit, a version of “Mama Told Me (Not to Come)” by Three Dog Night.

headline: Saving for Bucket List That’s Likely to Evolve in Years Before Retirement
abstract: Research shows that what people think now that they will want to do in retirement will probably change. The right planning can prepare for that shift.
lead_paragraph: When most of us imagine retirement, our minds wander to what we’ll get to do then that we don’t have enough time for now. If we’re lucky, we can push the uncertainty of our investment performance and future health out of our minds and picture all the fun we’ll have. That’s what will make the decades of saving worthwhile, after all.

headline: Why You Should Tip More Than You Do Now
abstract: Tipping well for good service is not about charity; it’s about compensating people more fairly for the work they do, writes Tony Schwartz in Life@Work.
lead_paragraph: For most of my life, I’m ashamed to admit, I didn’t leave a tip for the housekeeper in the hotels in which I stayed. My wife always did, but I somehow didn’t pay attention. Only recently did I wake up to just how little these folks earn and how exhausting their jobs typically are.

abstract: The Way Out West project from the organization Art City has commissioned twenty talents to reimagine billboards, buses and transit shelters in the gentrifying Mission district.

Then an idea came up and I got fixated on it: What happens when you turn an entire city into a gallery? Is it possible?”

abstract: Conservative thinkers, lawmakers, and commentators have often come forward in support of immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett and Bill Gates don’t seem like such an unlikely pair. Both are extremely wealthy, both have made sizable contributions to the American economic and innovative spheres, and both are staunch progressives who have worked together on many initiative in the past, such as Mr. Gates’s foundation, and Mr. Buffett’s Giving Pledge. But, add the famously conservative casino-magnate Sheldon Adelson into the mix, and you’ve got an unlikely partnership, indeed.

He wasn’t taking drugs that might have caused confusion or dizziness. And he was only 60, which in my world is practically adolescent.

headline: 36 Hours in Graz, Austria
abstract: The country’s second-largest city, built around an ancient hilltop castle, boasts rich design, art and culinary scenes.
lead_paragraph: Ask most travelers about Austrian cities beyond Vienna, and you’ll probably hear suggestions to go to Salzburg or Innsbruck. Austrians, however, might tell you that Graz — their country’s second-largest city, with a population of just over 300,000 — is a better choice for many tourists, thanks to its rich design, art and culinary scenes, and wine and produce from the surrounding south Austrian state of Styria. Built around the Schlossberg, an ancient hilltop castle, Styria’s regional capital is home to scores of boutiques, shops, restaurants and museums, many housed in restored Baroque-era buildings in the city’s well-preserved Old Town. You might not expect to find such a cultivated metropolis two hours down the road from Vienna toward Ljubljana, but Graz has a palpable joie de vivre, thanks in part to the presence of its six universities and over 40,000 students.

headline: Restaurant Report: Peumayen in Santiago, Chile
abstract: Opened early last year, Peumayen celebrates native cuisines and offers an introduction to the vast array of Chilean ingredients.
lead_paragraph: A quick visit to Santiago may leave the impression that typical Chilean food is limited to steak sandwiches and completos, the ever-present hot dogs smeared with avocado. In an effort to change that, the restaurant Peumayen attempts to reawaken the ancestral cuisine of some of the country’s native peoples: the Mapuche, Aymará and Rapa Nui.

headline: Hotel Review: Waldorf Astoria Panama in Panama City
abstract: This 36-story property, the first Waldorf Astoria in Latin America, opened last year in a neighborhood filled with trendy restaurants and nightclubs.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Summer School for Anchovies
abstract: Oceanographers have noted a billion-strong anchovy swarm near Southern California, a remarkably large example of a fish gathering.
lead_paragraph: This week, scientists at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif., noticed an enormous school of anchovies gathering near the coast. Pressed into a huge swarm, an estimated one billion of the tiny fish are taking cues from their neighbors, carefully coordinating their every move.

headline: The German 71 Cocktail
abstract: In honor of Germany 7, Brazil 1.
lead_paragraph: Few people are more worthy of a toast this week than members of the German national soccer team. They defied the modest expectations of their fans and produced one of the most incredible displays in World Cup history by thrashing Brazil — the favorite and host — 7-1. So in honor of the Nationalmannschaft, as they’re known, we bring you this week’s Upshot cocktail: the German 71.

headline: Seeing Johannesburg Through Artists’ Eyes
abstract: Public art is helping to revive urban Johannesburg, Africa's most visited city.
lead_paragraph: In the Ferreirasdorp section of Johannesburg, I passed a group of young men who had set up an informal carwash business with buckets of soapy water arranged by a curb, and as I turned a corner, there was Nelson Mandela.
