abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Blooper Reel: Cleveland Fans Aren’t Used to Such Good News
abstract: A collection of sports lowlights in Cleveland, which has not celebrated a championship team in 50 years but was cheered on Friday by LeBron James’s decision to play for the Cavaliers.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Football. The Republican Convention. Now the second coming of the disgraced hometown hero LeBron James. Could — gasp — things finally be working in Cleveland’s favor?

headline: Teenagers in The Times | June 2014
abstract: Our monthly collection of stories about young people in the news.
lead_paragraph: This slide show taken from “Richard Linklater’s Leading Boy” features images from the new film “Boyhood,” which details the journey from childhood to adolescence of one Mason Jr., played by Ellar Coltrane.

headline: Digital Humanists to Catalog Notes Scrawled in Books
abstract: A new project will analyze handwritten notes scrawled in the margins of centuries-old books.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal recently made a tongue-in-cheek attempt to determine the “most unread” book of the summer using Amazon’s “Popular Highlights” feature, which tracks the passages in any given book that have been most frequently highlighted by Kindle users, taken as an indirect measure of which books were barely read past the introduction. (Here’s looking at you, Thomas Piketty.)

headline: Garth Brooks Planning First New Studio Album Since 2001
abstract: Garth Brooks, the country superstar, says that in November he will release an album of new material.
lead_paragraph: The country music superstar Garth Brooks released his last album of new studio material, “Scarecrow,” in November 2001, roughly a year after he announced that he intended to retire from performing and recording to spend time with his family. Since then he has made occasional appearances on the concert stage and on television, and since 2009 he has been inching toward a full comeback.

headline: A Damaging Distance
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians once worked and socialized together. Increasing separation has made them strangers who distrust and fear each other.
lead_paragraph: DAYS after Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was gunned down in 1995 by an Israeli Jew who opposed compromise with the Palestinians, Shimon Peres, the acting prime minister, held a news conference. He was asked why more had not been done to protect Mr. Rabin from people like his assassin, Yigal Amir. Mr. Peres replied that it had never occurred to the authorities that a Jew could do such a thing.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Keeps the Knicks Waiting on His Decision
abstract: Amid other free-agent moves, the focus now turns to Anthony, who has to choose between remaining with the Knicks or going elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Phil Jackson, clad in a red plaid shirt, watched the Knicks’ summer league team take on the Dallas Mavericks on Friday afternoon from a spot in the bleachers at Cox Pavilion. With General Manager Steve Mills sitting to his right and members of the front office assembled around him, Jackson looked at ease. He hardly fiddled with his phone.

headline: A Dance Battle Begins
abstract: A crew prepares itself for a dance battle at the Salaam Kivu International Film Festival in Goma.
lead_paragraph: A crew prepares itself for a dance battle at the Salaam Kivu International Film Festival in Goma.

headline: Robert Wilson’s Video Portraits of Lady Gaga to Have First American Showing
abstract: “23 Video Portraits of Lady Gaga” will be on display at the Watermill Center in Water Mill, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Although Robert Wilson is best known for his experimental theater works, including several genre-redefining opera collaborations with Philip Glass (most famously, “Einstein on the Beach”), he has created an expansive series of visual art works. Among them is a series of what Mr. Wilson calls “Video Portraits” of artists and performers including Mikhail Baryshnikov, Winona Ryder, Brad Pitt and Isabella Rossellini. He uses high-definition video as the canvas, and costumes, lighting, makeup, gesture and narrative to put his subjects in perspective, usually with references to other art works.

headline: The Directors of “Land Ho!” On Their Icelandic Adventure
abstract: Martha Stephens and Aaron Katz’s rollicking road movie follows a pair of older friends as they carouse their way through the Golden Circle. Here, the filmmakers share their favorite snaps from the set.
lead_paragraph: “Land Ho!,” Martha Stephens and Aaron Katz’s sweet and often hilarious road film about a pair of older men who travel to Iceland to reclaim their youth, began as something far less ambitious. “I wanted to go on a vacation to Iceland,” says Stephens, whose first two films, “Passenger Pigeons” and “Pilgrim Song,” were well-received indie outings. As she researched her trip, however, Stephens saw the opportunity to use the country’s breathtaking landscapes for a more creative purpose. She enlisted Katz, the director of the mumblecore favorites “Dance Party USA” and “Quiet City,” whom she knew from the University of North Carolina School of the Arts, to help write the script and co-direct, and the pair cast Stephens’s second cousin, Earl Lynn Nelson, an oculoplastic surgeon, and the indie actor Paul Eenhoorn (“This Is Martin Bonner”), as the film’s jocular leads, Mitch and Colin.

headline: As Reynolds Looks Ahead, a Familiar Leader, Susan Cameron, Guides the Way
abstract: The chief executive of Reynolds American, who had the job once before, has decades of experience in the tobacco industry and is looking once again to lead a transformation.
lead_paragraph: When the tobacco company Reynolds American confirmed on Friday that it was in discussions with Lorillard about a multibillion-dollar merger, the news hardly came as a surprise.

headline: Best of the World Cup, From The Upshot
abstract: A collection of our interactives and analysis.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup has proved to be a hit not only around the world — as usual — but also in the United States. Television ratings are up, and online discussion has flourished. Here at The Upshot, we too have had a great time watching and analyzing the tournament. Below is a collection of our greatest hits from the last month, many of which can shed light on the final two matches in the tournament.

abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: All About the Terraces
abstract: A penthouse with 5,200 square feet of outdoor space is entering the market.
lead_paragraph: A one-of-a-kind duplex penthouse, one of just four residences carved in 2005 from the 1913 Amory S. Carhart Mansion at 3 East 95th Street and an elegant, newer adjoining limestone structure that replaced a former school at No. 5, is poised to enter the market at $34 million.

headline: The Rings, the Cake, the Rice ... the Insurance?
abstract: It may be a good thing, or just one more part of the big day that can go wrong.
lead_paragraph: Picture a rustic wedding in a verdant California park, the nervous couple about to walk the aisle. Now, picture a firefighter rushing in and telling everyone to immediately evacuate because of a wildfire.

headline: Unity in a Strange Land
abstract: Philip Montgomery, who has photographed New York City’s Islamic communities, visited mosques during the holy month of Ramadan, which this year is June 28 to July 28.
lead_paragraph: Philip Montgomery calls his photographs of New York City’s various Islamic communities an unfinished project, one driven by changing perspectives and questions. He began in 2009 as a new arrival from California and fresh from photographing Sufi Muslims in Kashmir. In an unfamiliar city, Mr. Montgomery, now 26, said he felt a yearning to “work my way back to the kind of connected communities I saw in Kashmir.”

headline: Real Data on Illegal Gun Sales
abstract: Sixty-seven percent of sellers said they had experienced at least one attempted straw purchase in a 12-month period.
lead_paragraph: A recent survey of gun dealers on illegal transactions yields new information on how criminals obtain guns.

headline: Chronicling the Monumental
abstract: A look at the books “Gotham Unbound: The Ecological History of Greater New York,” “Liberty’s Torch: The Great Adventure to Build the Statue of Liberty,” and “Carving a Niche for Himself: The Untold Story of Luigi Del Bianco.”
lead_paragraph: Five years ago in “Mannahatta,” Eric W. Sanderson imaginatively envisioned the natural landscape that Henry Hudson would have witnessed when he sailed into New York Harbor. Now Ted Steinberg, a Brooklyn-born history professor at Case Western Reserve University, engagingly explores what happened to that natural environment in the four centuries since in “Gotham Unbound: The Ecological History of Greater New York” (Simon & Schuster).

headline: Arts Sanctuary in a War-Torn City
abstract: Memories of better days inspire the founders of an arts festival in Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — When Petna Ndaliko was a boy, he would head downtown to watch kung fu movies at the Cine Virunga here. On Saturday and Sunday evenings, his parents would take him to the theater. When he got older, Mr. Ndaliko became an actor himself, performing for the first time in a show at the auditorium next to this city’s Roman Catholic cathedral.

headline: Big Ticket | Rupert Murdoch’s Trophy Pad, Expanded
abstract: Rupert Murdoch closes on the remaining portion of his new home at One Madison for $14.927 million, the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: The glassy 57th-floor getaway that doubles as the bottom level of the media mogul Rupert Murdoch’s four-tier vertical compound at the pinnacle of One Madison, the slender 60-story tower on the southeast side of Madison Square Park, sold for $14.927 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: In Gaza, Airstrikes and Economic Stress Make for an Anxious Ramadan
abstract: The conflict aside, the new military-dominated government of Egypt has largely shut the tunnel system that fed the Gazan economy, making this holy month a difficult one.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — War during Ramadan has a particular tension. It is not just the normal anxiety of airstrikes in a crowded city, no matter how carefully Israel tries to target them. But the holy month of Ramadan falls this year in a particularly hot and humid Gaza July, and observant Muslims are fasting, not even drinking water, until sunset and iftar, the evening meal.

headline: Matt Long: Trading Surf for Turf
abstract: Mr. Long, a professional sand sculptor, spends most of the summer carving castles along the Jersey Shore and Coney Island, but he saves spaghetti omelets, guitar playing and gardening for Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The professional sand sculptor Matt Long spends most of the summer carving castles along the Jersey Shore and Coney Island, but he saves spaghetti omelets, guitar playing and gardening for Sunday. The 59-year-old has been featured on the Travel Channel’s “Sand Masters,” is the founder of the online shop Can You Dig It Sand Tools, competes in international sand sculpturing events, and has been hired by companies to erect elaborate designs, most recently a plane in Wildwood Crest, N.J., to promote the new Disney movie “Planes: Fire and Rescue.” “Unless someone requests the Taj Mahal or something, I just make sand castles up as I go,” he said. Mr. Long lives in West Brighton, Staten Island, with his wife, Nina, 59, and his daughters, Katrina, 34; Madeline, 26; and Emily, 21.

headline: How Good Are Cavaliers Now? And Four Other Questions
abstract: With LeBron James joining a young roster in Cleveland, should the Spurs be worried? And what becomes of the Miami Heat?
lead_paragraph: LeBron James’s decision to return to Cleveland makes the Cavaliers an instant contender and a favorite to win the N.B.A. title, according to manyoddsmakers, even though James himself acknowledged that it will take time to build a winner. The decision also raised many questions, which may not be answered any time soon.

headline: Dead in the Water: A Long Island Ferry
abstract: There is no ferry service from Manhattan to the East End of Long Island, in part because Hamptons communities are against it.
lead_paragraph: It is now clear that before the end of the month, should various labor disputes fail to resolve themselves, workers for the Long Island Rail Road will go on strike, an outcome that would jeopardize the commute of 300,000 working people each weekday. But it is not the fate of this population that ought to concern us, not during the peak of summer, when the genuinely endangered are the 26-year-olds with juice bottles full of vodka who depend on the train to get them to the Jennifer Convertibles sofas at their weekend quarter-shares in Westhampton. Millennials, it would seem, have already endured enough.

headline: As Senate Spotlight Is Given to Vulnerable Democrats, G.O.P. Finds a Dimmer
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Law and Legislation', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: Senate Republicans are blocking legislation that they believe is intended to give a lift to Democrats in tough races.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Very little is happening in the Senate these days, but what passes for action has a lot to do with re-electing Democrats — or blocking their re-election.

headline: A Ride Across America | Campfire Cooking in the Rockies
abstract: Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, is biking across the U.S. talking to people about food. In his fifth dispatch, he meets a 93-year-old Kansan named Effie who whips up a mean burger and makes some open-air meals in the Rockies.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, they’ll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

lead_paragraph: They line up a dozen deep behind the Capitol in Washington, mostly black General Motors S.U.V.s — Chevrolet Tahoes and Suburbans or their GMC equivalents — waiting to shuttle important people to important places. Or to lunch at Chipotle.

headline: A Fig Tree Dies in Brooklyn, and in Other Boroughs
abstract: Cold weather did damage to many of New York City’s fig trees, a legacy of Italian and Greek immigrants who brought cuttings from home.
lead_paragraph: By late spring, Nelson Ryland knew that something was wrong. Normally, the fig trees in his backyard in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, would be plush with verdant leaves and sending up sprays of new branches. This year, though, while the Bronx seedless grape vine, the hydrangea bushes and the black-eyed Susans in his garden flourished, his eight fig trees stood stark and lifeless.

headline: Uber's Travis Kalanick Explains His Pricing Experiment
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Sharp price cuts announced this week by the smartphone-summoned car service are a way of testing demand.
lead_paragraph: Of the several entrepreneurs who are trying to shake up urban transportation, Travis Kalanick of the smartphone-summoned car service Uber has made some of the boldest moves. In my article about the strategic battle between Uber and its rivals, Mr. Kalanick explains that he sees the 20 to 25 percent sharp price cuts announced this week for its UberX service as a way to increase ridership. Here is more from the conversation, lightly edited for length and clarity.

headline: London Theater Journal: The Despot Behind a Desk
abstract: Ben Brantley reports on “Richard III” with Martin Freeman and a revival of Alan Ayckbourn’s “A Small Family Business.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The “hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death,” as Richard III is described by one of his many detractors, has been thoroughly domesticated. As portrayed by Martin Freeman at Trafalgar Studios here, the most fearsome psychopath in Shakespeare seems dangerous only in the manner of a persistent insurance salesman who might sell you a policy you don’t really need.

headline: On Stage and in His Life, the Leading Player
abstract: A Broadway star’s path to marriage sounds like a play script.
lead_paragraph: When Patina Miller performed “Magic to Do” in the opening number of “Pippin,” she wore a top hat and swung from a trapeze, over a stage full of contortionists, tumblers, dancers and acrobats.

headline: Photographers of the Inadvertent
abstract: Hired to document subway construction (and possibly prevent lawsuits), photographers also captured city life.
lead_paragraph: Although the tunneling for the Second Avenue subway is going on far below the street, on the surface whole blocks are in chaos, strewn with barriers, fences, ventilators and huge elevated construction sheds. It was just as much an obstacle course in the early 20th century, when our first subways were built, as we can see from hundreds of thousands of photographs, now divided like a broken Greek vase among various institutions, at least two dealers, several collectors and, on occasion, sale tables at flea markets.

headline: Citroen’s Adjustable Suspension
abstract: Citroën’s suspensions use a hydropneumatic system instead of steel springs. The result is a smooth ride with excellent road-holding. The system also provides adjustable ride height and self-leveling.
lead_paragraph: Citroën’s suspensions use a hydropneumatic system instead of steel springs. The result is a smooth ride with excellent road-holding. The system also provides adjustable ride height and self-leveling.

headline: Shoe Prints, Dripping Blood and Groping
abstract: “The Hunt With John Walsh,” a new eight-episode series on CNN, focuses on criminal cases in which the suspects are still at large.
lead_paragraph: John Walsh can’t seem to stop trying to catch criminals, and who can blame him? But his latest series, “The Hunt With John Walsh,” is a schlocky disappointment.

headline: Doubts on Fasting Before Cholesterol Tests
abstract: It may not be necessary to fast before a blood lipid test, a review finds.
lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health and other groups recommend fasting for nine to 12 hours before taking a blood lipid test, but a large new study provides further evidence that fasting is probably unnecessary.

headline: Measuring Ramadan
keywords: ['Ramadan', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Productivity', 'Fasting', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Long days of fasting may make Muslims poorer, but happier.
lead_paragraph: WE are in the Islamic holy month of Ramadan. During this time, as prescribed by one of the five “pillars,” or obligations, that make up the foundation of Muslim life, hundreds of millions of followers are abstaining from eating and drinking (and a host of other activities, like smoking and sex) between dawn and sunset.

headline: Silver Lake to Pay $29.5 Million to Settle Suit on Collusion
abstract: The private equity firm is the third defendant to settle accusations in the nearly seven-year-old lawsuit, which contends that a group of private equity’s top firms were unofficial partners in an illegal conspiracy to reduce competition.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Silver Lake has agreed to pay $29.5 million to settle accusations that it colluded with its rivals to drive down the prices of corporate takeovers before the financial crisis, according to a court filing on Thursday.

headline: With Merger, Tobacco Takes On Technology
abstract: Reynolds American and Lorillard see joining forces as a way to cope with the disruptive effect of e-cigarettes, writes the Deal Professor, Steven Davidoff Solomon.
lead_paragraph: Disruptive technology can spur takeovers as companies, fearing for their business, race to bulk up and acquire innovators.

headline: Work Out, Then the Wok
abstract: Every workday — he has Friday and Saturday off — Sam Wong, a chef in Midtown Manhattan, exercises on the sidewalk outside his restaurant and has become a fixture of the neighborhood’s morning commute.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you have seen him, the Zen master of Zen Palate, doing his daily exercise routine in the middle of Midtown Manhattan’s morning rush.

headline: Man Charged in Staten Island Crime Spree Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Tyrell Brown, 25, was arraigned on seven charges, including two homicides, in State Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A man accused in a crime spree that included two unrelated murders only 15 minutes apart was ordered held without bail on Friday after he entered a plea of not guilty in State Supreme Court on Staten Island.

headline: Examining a Father’s Role in a Toddler’s Death
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Some people close to Justin Ross Harris are having a hard time believing he killed his son, even as Georgia officials detailed the bizarre actions of Mr. Harris and his wife on the day the boy died.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — On a Friday morning in March 2012, Leanna Harris entered a medical office here and underwent an ultrasound to get a glimpse of the baby she and her husband would name Cooper. The grainy, black-and-white footage was uploaded three days later to the YouTube account belonging to her husband, Justin Ross Harris, with a gleeful caption: “First video known as Cooper!”

headline: Weekend Reading: Have You Even Tried the Potato Salad in Sun Valley?
abstract: Zack “Danger” Brown can raise more than $43,000 on Kickstarter to pay for his potato salad. Surely there is someone at the Sun Valley conference who can make use of his talents.
lead_paragraph: Zack “Danger” Brown can raise more than $43,000 on Kickstarter to pay for his potato salad. Surely there is someone at the Sun Valley conference who can make use of his talents. Or technology and media titans could make use of these delicious potato salad recipes from The New York Times. DealBook recommends Sam Sifton’s grilled fingerling-potato salad with chipotle bacon vinaigrette. Mmm, bacon.

headline: Summer Car Safety: Look Before You Lock, and More
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Parenting', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The terrible accusations against the father alleged to have intentionally left his toddler to die in a hot car in Georgia make it too easy to mentally file the death under the category “things that will never happen to my family.”
lead_paragraph: The terrible accusations against Justin Ross Harris, the father accused of intentionally leaving his 22-month-old son, Cooper, to die in a hot car because he wished to be free of the burdens of parenting, make it easy to mentally file Cooper’s tragic death under the category “things that will never happen to my family.” People in Tuscaloosa, Ala., Mr. Harris’s deeply conservative hometown, are having a hard time believing what happened, as Richard Faussett and Alan Blinder write in The New York Times, even as prosecutors and the Georgia police and prosecutors have provided details of the actions of of Mr. Harris and his wife on June 18, the day the boy died.

headline: The Body of Salem, Its Nerves Frayed
abstract: An earthy production of Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible,” starring Richard Armitage, is playing at the Old Vic in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Puritan torturers who try to break the spirit of John Proctor, the honor-bound hero of Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible,” have nothing on the devastating revival of that play that recently opened at the Old Vic. As directed by Yael Farber, this three-and-a-half-hour production applies unrelieved pressure to your nerves — and, it would seem, muscles that include the heart — until you’re a submissive puddle of pity and terror.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe discusses C.E.O.’s behaving badly.
lead_paragraph: What gives with C.E.O./founders recently? Some have been behaving badly, facing allegations of sexual harassment or making inappropriate comments. It’s even led to a few getting fired. But when they lose their jobs—if we needed another reminder that C.E.O.’s aren’t like the rest of us—they fight to get them back. Case in point: Dov Charney, the founder of American Apparel.

headline: The Children of the Drug Wars
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Drug Cartels', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Gangs', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: They come to our border to escape murder, rape and conscription in the cartels.

abstract: A New York City man fell in love with Citroëns when he was 17 and now owns three of them, including the sporty SM model that’s his daily driver.
lead_paragraph: One Thursday last fall, Brian Brandt got a phone call from “The Americans,” the FX Networks’ period drama about Cold War-era Soviet spies living in a Washington suburb. An anxious member of the production staff explained that the show, filmed in a Brooklyn studio and at locations around Long Island, needed a car repaired — and back on the set the following Tuesday.

headline: An Argentine and a German, but No Sign at the Vatican of a World Cup Rivalry
abstract: A spokesman doubted whether Pope Francis and Pope Emeritus Benedict would watch the World Cup final together — or even separately.
lead_paragraph: ROME — They have prayed together and embraced each other as brothers, but Pope Francis and his predecessor, Benedict XVI, now pope emeritus, find themselves confronting an odd sort of schism: their two countries are competing in the finals of the World Cup on Sunday.

abstract: A racing legend made in New Jersey heads to auction.
lead_paragraph: A racing legend made in New Jersey heads to auction.

headline: In Their Ardor and Sweep, Hints of an Emerging Gold Standard
abstract: New York City Ballet danced works by Balanchine, Jerome Robbins and Justin Peck, its new resident choreographer, on Thursday afternoon at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — To watch New York City Ballet at its open-air summer home at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center on Thursday afternoon was to be made forcefully aware not just how well the company is currently dancing but with what exuberance. Next week, when Moscow’s legendary Bolshoi Ballet opens at the David H. Koch Theater in Manhattan — and two weeks later, when it arrives here — it will be judged by two standards: memories and films of its own past achievements, and the highest standards of today’s foremost American companies.

headline: Jersey-Born, Racetrack-Bred and Headed to the Monterey Auctions
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)", 'Auctions']

headline: Russian Farewells, Quartet by Quartet

It is not enough, for example, merely to scatter the six Bartok quartets (which the group recorded for Deutsche Grammophon, winning a Grammy Award in 1990) among mixed programs; the Emerson has repeatedly performed all six works in a single long evening.

Raúl Castillo, of the HBO young-gays-in-San-Francisco series “Looking,” stars alongside Ms. Oh as her husband, with the veteran Chicago actor John Judd playing the third role of the nefarious (or is he?) doctor.

headline: Undead Plane Passengers in a Medical Whodunit
abstract: In “Strain,” a new series beginning on Sunday on FX, the Centers for Disease Control investigate a virus linked to vampirism.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control don’t always get a good rap. In “The Walking Dead” they were an empty shell that almost got the cast killed before self-destructing in a fireball. So in the new FX series “The Strain,” beginning on Sunday, it’s nice to see the agency getting some respect. You could make a drinking game out of the times it’s mentioned in tones usually reserved for superheroes or counterintelligence outfits. “This crime scene is now under C.D.C. authority!” the hero declares, and no one on screen laughs.

headline: Luna Moth: Green, Glowy and in Vogue
abstract: While moths are often derided as pests, the pistachio-colored luna moths are a true summertime spectacle. They still can be seen on Staten Island, and in Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: At best, moths are often regarded as country-mouse cousins of butterflies. At worst, they are night-flying pests that tangle in our hair and eat holes in our clothing. Their relatives, the butterflies, steal all the glory, flying through the flowery fields of our imaginations, playing in the sunlight and delicately sipping nectar from colorful flowers.

headline: Our Love Affair With Predicting Divorce
abstract: Can psychologists tell if you’re going to break up? Some claim it’s possible, and while they have their critics, the idea that divorce is predictable continues to appeal.
lead_paragraph: One of the great love stories of our era is not a celebrity coupling or an on-screen romance but a series of psychological experiments. These experiments aim to predict which couples will divorce, based on how they act while married. And while some have questioned their findings, the idea that marital discord is predictable (and, perhaps, preventable) retains its hold on our hearts.

lead_paragraph: During its last term, the Supreme Court narrowly decided two cases bearing extensively on the separation of church and state. Both of them broke along familiar 5-4 lines, and both of them implicitly raised a question hardly anyone has asked about a court that is entirely composed, for the first time in American history, of Roman Catholic and Jewish justices.

headline: With Older Parents, Stepping Gingerly Through Life’s Daily Minefield
abstract: My husband and I feel like gold medalists at the end of each day if my father, 83, and my mother, 80, with whom we live, simply go to bed uninjured.
lead_paragraph: One of my friends has come up with a great verb to describe what it is like taking care of her 90-something mother: curling. Just as the players in that enigmatic Olympic sport incessantly brush the ice to help the stone move forward unobstructed, my husband and I feel like gold medalists at the end of each day if my father, 83, and my mother, 80, simply go to bed uninjured. It means we cleared the paths adequately that day.

headline: In St. Andrews, a Heavy Knock on a Neighbor’s Door
abstract: For Louise Richardson, the principal of the University of St. Andrews in Scotland, the exclusion of female members by the Royal and Ancient Golf Club transcends gender politics. It has become a workplace hurdle.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — On the last day of finals before the summer break, Louise Richardson, the principal of the University of St. Andrews, sat in her wood-paneled, book-lined corner office and washed down a vegetarian roll with bottled water. Down the road, a long par-5 from the 15th-century campus, a university donor was dining at the Royal and Ancient Golf Club.

headline: Satirizing Patriotism and Piety
abstract: In “The Devil’s Disciple,” George Bernard Shaw wrote a dark comedy set during the Revolutionary War that exploited Victorian blood-and-thunder melodramas and added his own ironic spin. It’s now being presented by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who thinks that George Bernard Shaw wrote plays that are long on talk and deficient in action will be agreeably surprised by the dramatic goings-on of “The Devil’s Disciple.” In 1896, early in his career as a dramatist, Shaw wrote a dark comedy that exploited the elements of Victorian blood-and-thunder melodramas to his own purposes.

headline: Vietnam’s Overdue Alliance With America

lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — OURS is a small country. We Vietnamese cannot and must not entrust our future to anyone, but we urgently need strategic allies at a moment in history when our priority is to defeat our present-day enemy: China.

headline: New York Musical Theater Festival Report: ‘Searching for Romeo’

lead_paragraph: The night he crashed the Capulets’ little bash, Romeo was smitten with Rosaline, and Paris wanted Juliet for his bride. Then the star-crossed lovers spied each other. “It’s not like people fall in love at first sight. Unless they’re totally shallow,” Paris says in the playful, retropoppy “Searching for Romeo.”

headline: Playing Word Games With Sacred Texts
abstract: “Criss-Crossing the Divine,” the artist Nina Yankowitz’s current exhibition at Guild Hall in East Hampton, combines scriptures, digital games, video art, three-dimensional animation and robotic avatars.
lead_paragraph: The artist Nina Yankowitz is known for projecting words in glass houses, and oh how they can shatter the place. For “Criss-Crossing the Divine,” her current exhibition at Guild Hall in East Hampton, she takes on sacred texts. “I’ve always been disturbed by the way religion is so often used to incite people towards divisive behavior,” she said of the interactive show, which is scheduled to run through July 27. “It prompted me to think of ways to motivate individuals to re-examine their personal value judgments.”

lead_paragraph: To reach Pinch, the “innovative restaurant concept” at the Empire City Casino in Yonkers, patrons arriving at the valet parking station under a bubble-shaped canopy must step through the looking-glass facade, ascend an escalator to the mezzanine — music throbbing, lights pulsing — and then hang a U-turn at the top, walking between chiming slot machines and a clamorous, chandeliered bowling alley. By the time you get to your table, you’re more than ready to sink into one of the padded armchairs and order a drink.

headline: Turkey: Prime Minister Looks Ahead
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan outlined his vision for his presidential campaign, promising to expand rights and liberties, improve welfare programs and build up the country’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Friday outlined his vision for his presidential campaign, promising to expand rights and liberties, improve welfare programs and build up Turkey’s economy. On Aug. 10, for the first time, Turkey’s president will be chosen directly by the voters, rather than by Parliament. The presidency has been largely a ceremonial post, but if Mr. Erdogan wins, as is widely expected, he is likely to try to expand the powers of the office. Mr. Erdogan has been the most powerful figure in Turkish politics for a decade. His opponents fear that if he is elected president, he will face no checks on the autocratic tendencies he has displayed in recent months while confronting challenges from street protests and a corruption inquiry. Speaking to more than two thousand supporters in Istanbul on Friday, Mr. Erdogan offered few details but vowed to expand democracy in Turkey if elected and to expand its role in international affairs.

headline: South Sudan: Refugee Crisis Worsens
abstract: The number of South Sudanese fleeing for neighboring nations has reached 715,000, the United Nations refugee agency said, amid a civil war and the threat of famine.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations refugee agency said Friday that the number of South Sudanese fleeing for neighboring nations is expected to reach as many as 715,000 by year’s end, more than double the number envisioned when the agency began a funding appeal four months ago for refugees from South Sudan, which has been ravaged by a civil war and is on the verge of famine. “The ongoing conflict and worsening humanitarian situation inside the world’s youngest nation is fueling a refugee exodus into Ethiopia, Kenya, Sudan and Uganda at a much higher rate than initially anticipated,” an agency spokeswoman, Melissa Fleming, said in a statement on the crisis in South Sudan. The agency revised its funding appeal to $658 million from the original $371 million and warned that without urgent contributions, “the consequences could be drastic.” In another barometer of the worsening crisis, the charity Save the Children warned that a cholera outbreak that first appeared two months ago had spread, infecting more than 2,600 people and killing more than 60. Pete Walsh, Save the Children’s director in South Sudan, said in a statement that the country’s overstretched health service was plagued by widespread shortages of lifesaving supplies, as “desperate parents are coming to clinics with children who are already considerably weakened by the disease.”

headline: A Man Who Was More Than His Feet
abstract: “Gene Kelly: The Legacy,” a touring presentation by Gene Kelly’s widow, Patricia Ward Kelly, mixes plentiful film clips with a mass of anecdotes and quips.
lead_paragraph: When Patricia Ward Kelly met her future husband, Gene, in 1985, she had never heard of him. Somehow she — a “nerdy Melville scholar” who had been hired as a writer on a television documentary for which he was narrator — had missed all the films. Writer and narrator bonded over poetry and etymology. She fell in love with the man before she had ever seen the on-screen image beloved by millions.

headline: A Pizzeria’s Simple Pursuit of the Sublime
abstract: At Bufalina in Guilford, every pie is made to order, incorporating just three or four ingredients, and every component has been prepared in the wood-burning oven, the restaurant’s only cooking apparatus.

Eye-opening not in the usual manner when it comes to Charney: The magazine didn’t uncover any new allegations of sexual harassment, nor did the reporter watch him engaging in oral sex, as a writer from Jane magazine once famously witnessed.

headline: Governor Cuomo’s Railroad
abstract: The governor should be ready to step in and end the union-M.T.A. fight before riders face a shutdown.
lead_paragraph: Riders on the Long Island Rail Road received alarming notices this week about a possible strike starting July 20. Negotiations between union workers and officials from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the railway, are slow, at best. It will be up to Gov. Andrew Cuomo to prevent disruption for the riders who take 300,000 trips on the line every weekday. Earlier this week, Mr. Cuomo suggested that the labor talks were a federal issue under the Railway Labor Act, and Congress’s problem, not his. But that idea was rejected by New York’s congressional delegation.

headline: Watching Rockets, Feeling Sparks
abstract: The following poems about the romantic aspect of fireworks were recently “found” in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com.
lead_paragraph: Of all the metaphors deployed to describe the experience of love, fireworks are not only among the most explosive but also among the most ephemeral. Like some passions, they erupt in incendiary bursts, only to dissolve once they reach their apogee. The following poems about the romantic aspect of fireworks were recently “found” in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.com. They are reprinted verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

In a similar process in the 10th District, in the Orlando suburb of Winter Garden, an “appendage” was tacked on benefiting the incumbent, Representative Daniel Webster, a Republican.

headline: The Mets, and Boras, Are Looking Ahead With a New Draftee
abstract: The Mets celebrated the signing of Michael Conforto, its first-round draft pick, and also welcomed his agent, Scott Boras. The good feelings continued in a 7-1 win over the Marlins.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets took batting practice, Keith Hernandez and Michael Conforto, the team’s first-round draft pick, approached Scott Boras to chat near the dugout. Soon, Matt Harvey joined them. Of course, neither Harvey nor Conforto played in the Mets’ 7-1 win over the Miami Marlins on Friday at Citi Field, but the scene was symbolic of how Boras, one of the most influential and powerful agents in baseball, could affect the Mets’ future. He had needled the organization in the past for its tight spending, but, as he discussed Conforto and Harvey, he indicated all was well between him and the team.

(HBO) GRAVITY (2013) A medical engineer (Sandra Bullock, above) and an astronaut (George Clooney) become stranded high above Earth when debris from a satellite destroys their space shuttle in this intense spectacle, directed by Alfonso Cuarón. “You have to see it to believe it,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Nothing in the movie — not hand tools or chess pieces, human bodies or cruise-ship-size space stations — rests within a stable vertical or horizontal plane. Neither does the movie itself, which in a little more than 90 minutes rewrites the rules of cinema as we have known them.” The film was nominated for 10 Oscars and won seven, including best director and best cinematography.

Taking his wayward shots in stride, Salmond stopped to sign autographs and pose for photographs, forging connections with his constituents to the far right of the fairway, if not of the political center.

headline: 1914: Brady Climbs The Mönch in Just Ten Hours
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: a perilous ascent in Switzerland in 1914 by Mr. J. H. Brady.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE SCHEIDEGG, Switzerland – The ascent of the Mönch made on Saturday by Mr. J. H. Brady, of Baltimore, was accomplished in face of the most unfavorable conditions, and the route chosen on the northern side of the peak was one of the most difficult. The progress of Mr. Brady and the two Grindelwald guides, Christian and Peter Kaufmann, who accompanied him, could be observed nearly all the time through glasses from the Seiler Hotel, at Little Scheidegg. The party took ten hours to reach the summit. The ascent of the Mönch peak, although its altitude is not quite as great as that of the Jungfrau, is one of the most difficult climbs in the Bernese Oberland. From Little Scheidegg, at the foot of the Eiger — which with the Mönch and the Jungfrau forms the Interlaken group of peaks, of which the Mönch is the central one — the journey requires at least thirteen hours, with a stop for rest and sleep at the Guggi Hut, where climbers for the Mönch and the Jungfrau part company. The Mönch was first scaled by Dr. Porges, of Vienna, in 1857. Its altitude is 13,465 feet, and the climb from the Guggi requires between nine and ten hours. It cannot be undertaken by anyone but a most experienced climber, as the difficulties to be overcome are innumerable. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 14, 1914

headline: 1939: England Bans Revengeful Wills
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: New bill in England bans revengeful wills in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – One of the foundations of English law — that a person of sound mind may will his property to whom he likes — was set aside today [July 13] by the inheritance family provision act which came into operation in the British Isles. The act provides for nullification by court order of revengeful wills in which husbands or wives cut off their widow or widowers and children with a contemptuous shilling or nothing at all, leaving them destitute while the money goes to charity, to persons outside the family or to some freakish cause. Testators are given self-defense, however, in a clause permitting them to append a side statement to their wills setting forth the reason for ignoring the dependants. The courts will take such a statement into consideration when dealing with a contested will. Those who may benefit under the act are limited to a widow or widower, unmarried daughters of any age, sons under twenty-one and sons or daughters who cannot earn their living because of mental or physical incapacity. If any such persons contest a will, a court will decide whether ‘‘reasonable provision’’ has been made. If not, the court may ‘‘tear up’’ the will and redistribute the assets of an estate. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 14, 1939

lead_paragraph: MULHOUSE, France — In time for Bastille Day, Tony Gallopin, a French rider, took the Tour de France lead on Sunday.

headline: Neil Young Cancels a Concert in Israel
abstract: Neil Young and his band Crazy Horse canceled a concert scheduled for Tel Aviv this week, as hostilities continue between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Neil Young has canceled a concert scheduled for Tel Aviv this week because of hostilities between Israel and Hamas. The concert, with Mr. Young’s band Crazy Horse, was scheduled for Thursday at Hayarkon Park in Tel Aviv.

headline: Peak Performances to Offer 14 Premieres
abstract: The series is celebrating its 10th anniversary – and that of the opening of its home, the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, in Montclair, N.J. – with a season that includes 14 music, dance and theater premieres.
lead_paragraph: The Peak Performance series is celebrating its 10th anniversary – and that of the opening of its home, the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, in Montclair, N.J. – with a season that includes 14 music, dance and theater premieres.

headline: A Woman at the Center, Drifting to the Fringe
abstract: “Price of Fame” is the second volume of Sylvia Jukes Morris’s study of Clare Boothe Luce.
lead_paragraph: “Price of Fame” completes Sylvia Jukes Morris’s two-volume character study of Clare Boothe Luce, one of the 20th century’s most ambitious, unstoppable and undeniably ingenious characters. The whole project weighs in at a mere 1,296 pages, so it does not even set the Morris house record. This author is married to Edmund Morris, whose splendid, three-volume Theodore Roosevelt totaled almost twice that page count.

headline: A Life on the Podium
abstract: Lorin Maazel, a former child prodigy who went on to hold the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic and several other ensembles around the world, was 84.
lead_paragraph: Lorin Maazel, a former child prodigy who went on to hold the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic and several other ensembles around the world, was 84.

headline: Mechanical and Sensual, Still Baring Shoulders Decades Later
abstract: Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker returns to one of her early works, “Rosas Danst Rosas,” as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Lincoln Center Festival’s retrospective of four early works by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker offers the opportunity, rare in contemporary dance, to track the development of a major artist piece by piece. And development is not synonymous with improvement.

headline: Mrs. Terrible, Before She Met Her Czar Ivan
abstract: The Bolshoi Opera’s concert version of “The Tsar’s Bride” at the Lincoln Center Festival shows this venerable company in its home repertory.
lead_paragraph: Making a rare appearance in New York, the Bolshoi Opera and Ballet have arrived from Moscow for, in effect, a jam-packed two-week residency courtesy of the Lincoln Center Festival. Opera fans might feel shortchanged: Starting Tuesday, the company is presenting elaborate productions of three ballets: “Swan Lake,” “Don Quixote” and “Spartacus.” But the only operatic offering? A pair of concert performances of Rimsky-Korsakov’s “The Tsar’s Bride.”

headline: Hall of Famers at the Summer North American Championships
abstract: Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., have been voted into the Hall of Fame by their peers.
lead_paragraph: The American Contract Bridge League’s Summer North American Championships begin on Thursday in Las Vegas. The Hall of Fame ceremonies and dinner take place late that afternoon.

headline: Walken as Captain Hook in NBC’s ‘Peter Pan’
abstract: Christopher Walken will grab the hammy role of Captain Hook in NBC’s new live version of “Peter Pan.”
lead_paragraph: Christopher Walken, below, will grab the hammy role of Captain Hook in NBC’s new live version of “Peter Pan,” the network’s follow-up to its hugely successful live musical for this past holiday season, “The Sound of Music.” Robert Greenblatt, NBC’s top entertainment executive, announced the casting of Mr. Walken on Sunday in Los Angeles at an annual gathering of television critics. Mr. Greenblatt cited Mr. Walken’s early experience as a song-and-dance man as well as his numerous well-received appearances as a guest host of “Saturday Night Live.” NBC plans to mount the production, “Peter Pan Live!,” in December. The network still needs to find a Peter. Mr. Greenblatt had no announcement on that front, although he did confirm that the network had pursued Kristen Bell (“Frozen”), but could not work out a schedule for her because of her commitment to the Showtime series “House of Lies.” Mr. Greenblatt did say that NBC would stick to the tradition of hiring a female star for Peter, after originally thinking that a man might be considered for the part.

headline: Germans End Long Wait: 24 Years and a Bit Extra
abstract: Mario Götze broke a scoreless tie in the 113th minute to give Germany its fourth World Cup title, consigning Lionel Messi and Argentina to defeat and setting off celebrations in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — For years, Brazilians had a phrase they would inevitably utter when things went wrong. “Imagina na Copa,” they said after an endless traffic jam or a construction accident or an ugly rash of violence dominated the news — imagine if this happened during the World Cup. It became a foreboding warning, a pre-emptive sigh at the presumed disasters that lay ahead.

headline: A Political Comedy for Off Broadway
abstract: Mario Correa’s political comedy “Tail! Spin!” is to open just as this fall’s midterm elections are heating up.
lead_paragraph: Mario Correa’s political comedy “Tail! Spin!” is to open Off Broadway at the Lynn Redgrave Theater just as this fall’s midterm elections are heating up, the show’s producers announced on Sunday. The play was warmly received at the 2012 New York International Fringe Festival. Dan Knechtges will return as director, and Rachel Dratch (“Saturday Night Live”) will reprise her roles as “Wives, Tails, Beards & Barbara Walters.” Other roles are expected to be cast this month, Billy Zavelson, one of the show’s producers, said by phone. “Tail! Spin!” uses texts, emails, tweets and remarks from four politicians disgraced by sex scandals: Anthony Weiner, Mark Foley, Larry Craig and Mark Sanford. It has been updated to include material from Mr. Weiner’s unsuccessful run for mayor of New York and Mr. Sanford’s election to Congress, Mr. Zavelson said. “And if another scandal of this ilk happens, we’ll add that to the show, too,” he said. “Tail! Spin!” is to begin previews on Sept. 18 and will open on Oct. 1.

headline: The House That Romeo Built
abstract: Romeo Santos, a Bronx-born bachatero, performed two sold-out shows over the weekend at his home borough’s greatest venue, Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: You know the routines by now: Romeo Santos has been doing this for too long. There will be a woman of ample proportions, and Mr. Santos will sing “Un Beso” to her, then kiss her, then encourage her to let her hands roam free on his body. There will be admonishments to the men in the audience about how they aren’t satisfying their women. There will be a microphone stand, parts of the stage and even the air itself that spend long stretches of time on the receiving end of Mr. Santos’s gyrating pelvis.

headline: A Game as Literary Tutorial
abstract: Dungeons & Dragons, the first commercially available role-playing game that is now 40 years old, influenced numerous writers and taught them the art of storytelling.
lead_paragraph: When he was an immigrant boy growing up in New Jersey, the writer Junot Díaz said he felt marginalized. But that feeling was dispelled somewhat in 1981 when he was in sixth grade. He and his buddies, adventuring pals with roots in distant realms — Egypt, Ireland, Cuba and the Dominican Republic — became “totally sucked in,” he said, by a “completely radical concept: role-playing,” in the form of Dungeons & Dragons.

headline: Battle for the 2014 World Cup Trophy
abstract: Germany, just off a stunning victory against Brazil, faced off with Argentina, whose star player Lionel Messi faced the biggest test of his international career. Germany won in extra time.
lead_paragraph: Germany, just off a stunning victory against Brazil, faced off with Argentina, whose star player Lionel Messi faced the biggest test of his international career. Germany won in extra time.

headline: Mets Surge Into the All-Star Break on a Wave of Confidence
abstract: Jacob deGrom pitched seven strong innings, recording eight strikeouts and allowing one run, as the Mets won their eighth game of a 10-game homestand.
lead_paragraph: The Mets celebrated the last win of their best homestand in four years by shaking hands and patting one another on the back. They had just won their eighth of 10 games against Texas, Atlanta and Miami, a 9-1 victory over the Marlins on Sunday at Citi Field.

headline: An Original Tough Career Woman
abstract: The soprano Angela Meade dispatched the dizzying difficulties of Donizetti’s “Lucrezia Borgia” with aplomb at the Caramoor Festival.
lead_paragraph: KATONAH, N.Y. — The most famous aria of Donizetti’s “Lucrezia Borgia” is the title character’s last. In “Era desso il figlio mio,” the power-hungry femme fatale of the title laments the loss of her son, whom she has unwittingly poisoned, in an explosion of vocal fireworks. It’s also an aria that Donizetti cut when he revised the opera in 1840, seven years after its Milan premiere, in an attempt to focus the drama more sharply.

headline: An Incoming Conductor Brings a Sunny Outlook
abstract: The Latvian maestro Andris Nelsons made his first Tanglewood appearances since being named to succeed James Levine as the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s music director.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — The weather here at Tanglewood, the beautiful summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, often seems to reflect the mood of the institution. How frequent were those terrifying thunderstorms and winds during and after the last years of James Levine’s tenure as music director, rife with illnesses and cancellations?

headline: A Bride Finds Her Gown, and a Groom
abstract: A bride-to-be travels to New Delhi to search for a dress and finds herself a new suitor in “Humpty Sharma Ki Dulhania.”
lead_paragraph: The official English title of the Bollywood confection “Humpty Sharma Ki Dulhania” is “Humpty Sharma’s Bride.” Yet, at the start, Kavya (Alia Bhatt), the heroine, is weeks away from an arranged marriage to someone else. Insisting that if she can’t choose her groom, she should at least wear a designer gown, Kavya travels to New Delhi to earn money and buy one.

headline: Using Speech and Instruments, but Mostly Singing Feet
abstract: “Tap and Song,” at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Symphony Space, presented an eclectic program that intertwined tap dancing with musical instruments and spoken word.
lead_paragraph: As the American Tap Dance Foundation wisely realizes, feet get hot in the summer. But at Tap City, its friendly weeklong festival that wrapped up on Saturday, little makes them bleed. (The vibe here is more summer camp.) On Thursday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Symphony Space, the gaiety continued with “Tap and Song,” an eclectic program, directed by Tony Waag, intent on highlighting the breadth of the art form — from vaudeville and comedy to contemporary styles — by showing how tap dance is a form of music.

headline: Q. and A.: Cathy Giangrande on China’s Museum Boom
abstract: Museums are booming in China as people rush to preserve the past and display their growing sophistication after decades of focus on economic growth and cultural depredation. A book, recently given a rare honor by the state, captures that.
lead_paragraph: Whether celebrating fine art or ancient artifacts, salt or signboards, China increasingly has a museum for most tastes — and a few that can be found nowhere else, such as one devoted to whistling kites. As money has piled up in recent decades, Chinese are turning to culture and the country is in a museum-building boom.

headline: Eerie Encounter
abstract: Look! It’s a bird! It’s a plane! No, it’s … the soaring return of MaryEllen Uthlaut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We last saw MaryEllen Uthlaut back in 2010, when she made her debut in The New York Times crossword puzzle and she returns today to remind us that everything is not always as it seems when we look up into the night sky.

headline: Zine Makers Grab Their MetroCards and Go to Work
abstract: Thirteen subway riders on Friday weren’t commuting, but rather were creating zines from one end of the F line to the other.
lead_paragraph: One woman drew cartoons in an artist’s notebook. Another snipped off pieces from a subway map, then pasted them onto a white paper. Yellow fliers that read “Service Changes” along with “Zine Residency!” were taped to subway car walls. And a black banner with the words “Zinesters in Residence” hung from a railing.

headline: Poor Sanitation in India May Afflict Well-Fed Children With Malnutrition
keywords: ['Malnutrition', 'Children and Childhood', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Water Pollution', 'Bacteria', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: Many children in India are exposed to a bacterial brew from human waste that may make it impossible for food alone to cure their malnutrition.
lead_paragraph: SHEOHAR DISTRICT, India — He wore thick black eyeliner to ward off the evil eye, but Vivek, a tiny 1-year-old living in a village of mud huts and diminutive people, had nonetheless fallen victim to India’s great scourge of malnutrition.

headline: The Hudson Project: A Storm Stops the Music
abstract: Rough weather forced organizers of this music festival in Saugerties, N.Y., to shut the event down.
lead_paragraph: With a torrential thunderstorm moving on Sunday afternoon, the Hudson Project music festival in Saugerties, N.Y., was shut down and the site evacuated. Organizers hoped to resume the event if they could fit more music in before another band of storms.

headline: Boeing Optimistic That Export-Import Bank Will Get Funding
abstract: The head of its commercial aircraft division said that failure to keep the bank running would place Boeing at an unbeatable disadvantage to Airbus.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The head of Boeing’s commercial aircraft division said on Sunday that he was optimistic that the United States Congress would ultimately agree to reauthorize funding to the Export-Import Bank, which guarantees billions of dollars in loans to foreign buyers of its airplanes.

headline: Spies Like Us
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: To the Americans, intelligence gathering since 9/11 has been part of a war. Germans would never think that way.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Is it because they know us so little — or because they know us too well — that the Americans can’t stop spying on us Germans?

headline: Editorial Cartoon
abstract: Uncle Sam has a rat problem.
lead_paragraph: Uncle Sam has a rat problem.

headline: Even on Nantucket, a Funeral Home Is a Luxury
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Some people on the island want to establish a nonprofit funeral service, but they are being opposed by powerful organizations representing Massachusetts’ cemeteries and funeral directors.
lead_paragraph: NANTUCKET, Mass. — The hole at the cemetery was dug. The flowers had arrived, family and friends had gathered, food was ready for the reception. All that was missing was the deceased. Doris Davis could not make her own funeral.

headline: Discrimination Is Un-Christian, Too
abstract: Hobby Lobby is now free to deny women access to contraceptives, but it will be violating its own religious principles if it does.
lead_paragraph: Much to the chagrin of women’s rights advocates, Hobby Lobby has won its legal battle — but claims of “victory” for religious freedom must be emended. Make no mistake: This is no victory for the freedom to exercise Christian principles. Though employers like Hobby Lobby are now free to deny women access to contraceptives through their employer-subsidized health plans on the basis of religious objection, they will be violating their own purported Christian principles if they do. While Christians are not compelled by their faith to engage in religious practices that impose upon the freedoms of others, they are compelled — by their belief that all persons, men and women, are created in the image of God — to oppose discrimination.

headline: In a First Since the 1990s, a Large Bulgarian Bank Goes Bankrupt
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The decision to close Corporate Commercial Bank, the country’s fourth-largest lender, came after an audit showed that records relating to most of the bank’s loan portfolio were missing.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous month for the Bulgarian financial sector during which thousands of fearful depositors lined up to pull their savings out of two banks, the country’s central bank has said it will start bankruptcy proceedings against one of the lenders.

headline: ‘No One Is Rooting for Him Harder Out There’
abstract: Phil Mickelson and his longtime caddie, Jim Mackay, work together seamlessly and share a deep emotional bond exemplified by Mackay’s emotional reaction to Mickelson’s victory at the 2013 British Open.
lead_paragraph: ABERDEEN, Scotland — The golfer and the caddie were on a bucket-list course thousands of miles from home, two friends bonding over their shared affinity for the game and for competition.

headline: Samsung Considers Its Counterattack as Rivals Erode Cellphone Profit
abstract: Analysts say the company, which is the world’s top cellphone maker, must cut prices or push innovation as low-cost Chinese handsets threaten its dominance.
lead_paragraph: What goes up must come down. That principle seems to be coming true for Samsung Electronics, the world’s top cellphone maker, whose profit is falling in part because of pressure from its price-cutting rivals in China.

headline: Lindt Nears a Deal to Buy Russell Stover Candies
abstract: Lindt, the Swiss candy company, was among several that bid in recent months for Russell Stover, known for its gift boxes.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss maker of Lindt chocolate is closing in on a deal to acquire Russell Stover Candies, the storied American boxed-chocolate maker, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Caddie Who Mastered the Game
abstract: The British golfer Harry Vardon, the folk hero of professional golf’s formative era, inspired most of the game’s culture as it exists today, notably with his unmatched six British Open titles.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the film “The Greatest Game Ever Played,” the story of the 20-year-old amateur Francis Ouimet’s upset of the celebrated British golfers Harry Vardon and Ted Ray in the 1913 United States Open, Vardon, played by the actor Stephen Dillane, congratulates Ouimet in the locker room.

headline: Rivalry Begins for Sisters With Ambition
abstract: Chiney and Nneka Ogwumike, who were both No. 1 overall picks, played against each other for the first time as professionals Sunday, but they also have plans beyond the basketball court.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — Shortly after she was selected in April as the No. 1 overall pick in the W.N.B.A. draft by the Connecticut Sun, Chiney Ogwumike moved into her own apartment. During her first visit, Ify Ogwumike, Chiney’s mother, presented her second-oldest daughter with a housewarming gift that carried a not-so-subtle message, a study guide for the Graduate Record Examination.

headline: Can a Jury Believe What It Sees?
keywords: ['Confessions', 'Interrogations', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Videotaped confessions have value, but they can also be misleading.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — LAST week the F.B.I., the Drug Enforcement Administration and other federal law enforcement agencies instituted a policy of recording interrogations of criminal suspects held in custody. Only a minority of states and local governments have a similar requirement, but the new rule, which applies to nearly every federal interrogation, will most likely spur more jurisdictions to follow suit. It’s not far-fetched to think that such recordings may soon become standard police practice nationwide.

headline: Whiting Petroleum to Buy Kodiak Oil & Gas
abstract: The deal will join exploration companies that have a strong presence in some of the most oil and gas rich areas of the Dakotas and Montana.
lead_paragraph: Whiting Petroleum Corporation on Sunday said it would buy Kodiak Oil & Gas Corporation for $3.8 billion in stock, and assume $2.2 billion of Kodiak’s debt.

headline: The View From the Handlebars Makes Its Debut
abstract: Once-rigid rules restricting cameras on bikes in professional races are beginning to thaw.
lead_paragraph: NANCY, France — Television production of the Tour de France is a technological and logistical marvel involving fleets of motorcycles, helicopters and airplanes. But it lacks one element that has long been a part of motorsports broadcasting: onboard live cameras.

headline: Marijuana Is at Center of Feud in Capital
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A law to make marijuana possession in the District of Columbia punishable by only a $25 ticket has ignited a feud between Washington’s mayor and a Republican House member.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A law to make marijuana possession in the District of Columbia punishable by only a $25 ticket, one of the laxest drug laws in the nation, has ignited a feud between Washington’s mayor and a Republican House member days before it is to take effect.

headline: The Skeleton Garden of Paris
abstract: For me, the siren call of the city comes from whale jaws, elephant molars and miniature bat skulls under tiny glass domes.
lead_paragraph: I am at the Jardin des Plantes, in the Fifth Arrondissement on the Left Bank of the Seine. Here we find one of the world’s oldest zoos, still officially called a “menagerie,” various greenhouses and rows of brilliant dahlias book-ended by statues of Jean-Baptiste Lamarck and Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon. We also find the various galleries composing the National Museum of Natural History. These include, not least, the Gallery of Paleontology and Comparative Anatomy, a two-floor exhibition hall built in preparation for the 1900 World Fair, where the skeletons and preserved tissues of thousands of animal species are on display: the massive jaws of sperm whales, cross-sections of elephant molars like great petrified mille-feuilles, countless miniature bat skulls under tiny glass domes.

headline: After a Mejia Save, Improvisation Beats Premeditation
abstract: The former Mets starter was still learning the nuances of being a closer, but so far, he prefers to celebrate wins without a trademark routine.
lead_paragraph: Jenrry Mejia of the Mets was one strike away from ending the game, and the fans at Citi Field were on their feet. Mejia composed himself, unleashed a nasty slider and broke into an elaborate celebration. He slapped his glove twice, lifted his arms and his right knee, then slammed them down. It looked like a dance inspired by Ray Lewis.

headline: Tech Scene in Myanmar Hinges on Cellphone Grid
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Limited telephone and Internet infrastructure, and decreasing smartphone costs, mean most of Myanmar’s 60 million people will experience the Internet first through cellphones.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Images of Steven P. Jobs and Mark Zuckerberg adorn the walls of Myo Myint Kyaw’s creative digital agency. He says they inspire him. But he imagines neither man ever worked in an environment where Internet connections were so unreliable that a “file transfer” often involved delivering electronic documents across town by taxi.

headline: Prospects Show Promise in Their Pop
abstract: Kris Bryant and Joey Gallo are two prospects with natural power, something the major leagues seem to have lost.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Chiseled into a limestone wall on the Legends Club level of Target Field is the number 573, several feet high, representing the career home run total of the Hall of Famer Harmon Killebrew.

headline: For a Weekend, Ukraine Rebels Make Love, Not War
abstract: A wedding was billed as the first in the self-declared Donetsk People’s Republic, and on Saturday it was singles night.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — It was a weekend of love in this city of war.

headline: Obamacare Fails to Fail
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act’s huge success is largely slipping under the radar.
lead_paragraph: How many Americans know how health reform is going? For that matter, how many people in the news media are following the positive developments?

headline: ‘The Buck Stops With Me’
abstract: The president has taken responsibility for the country’s problems many times. Have Republicans?
lead_paragraph: In trying to lay the blame for the border crisis on the White House’s doorstep, House Speaker John Boehner exploded at a press conference on Thursday, saying of the president:

headline: With Return of Anthony, Knicks Quietly Edge Ahead
abstract: Retaining Carmelo Anthony represents a down payment on the present, while leaving the door ajar to a brighter future a year from now.
lead_paragraph: Ah, Carmelo, you coquette, it’s good to have you back.

headline: Companies That Offer Help With Student Loans Are Often Predatory, Officials Say
abstract: The debt settlement industry, already accused of questionable tactics related to mortgages, is finding a gold mine of new clients among those with college loans.
lead_paragraph: Student loan debt hovers at more than $1 trillion, a threefold surge from a decade ago, and a record number of college students who graduated as the financial system nearly imploded have an average debt load of more than $20,000.

headline: How to Teach Reading and Writing
abstract: Teachers debate whether “balanced literacy” is the best method.

headline: Vaccines May Be Costly, but They Save Lives
abstract: Pfizer and the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Doctors Run Late
abstract: An internist and public health professor responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Japan’s Security Policy
abstract: Sumio Kusaka, consul general of Japan in New York, takes issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gambling on Casinos in New York
abstract: The state is ramping up its gambling business, but that may not be an easy answer to financial problems.
lead_paragraph: The timing is worthy of note. As trucks in Albany were unloading reams of documents describing 17 proposals for four new casinos in New York, Moody’s Investors Service was issuing its latest report on gambling — downgrading the national gambling business from “stable” to “negative.” In other words, just when New York is proposing to ramp up its gambling business, the financial community is souring on the idea that casinos are an easy answer to state and local financial problems.

headline: Dirty Tricks, Tea Party Suicide and Rising Mississippi Anger
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Senate', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The suicide of a Mississippi Tea Party founder who was charged in a plot to photograph Senator Thad Cochran’s ailing wife has deepened the enmity left by a divisive Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Mark Mayfield, one of the founders of the Mississippi Tea Party, had lost his political appetite.

headline: Poison Shot From Guns
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Environment', 'Lead', 'Editorials', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Fishing, Sport']
abstract: A Senate dispute over gun politics results in the unintended protection of the E.P.A.’s authority over lead ammunition and fishing sinkers.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the gross ineffectiveness of Congress is a boon to the nation by heading off a plainly regressive result. This was the case last week when a partisan Senate dispute over election-year gun politics had the unintended effect of killing off a pernicious proposal to bar environmental controls over lead ammunition and fishing sinkers that increasingly threaten fish and wildlife. The poisonous effects of ingesting lead fragments have been documented in numerous studies — the latest counting more than 120 species of birds in North America suffering from the thousands of tons of lead scattered annually by sportsmen.

headline: Success for Brazil, Just Not on the Field
abstract: Its team suffered a humiliating semifinal defeat, but Brazil is taking comfort in its success as host of the World Cup and in its archrival Argentina’s loss in the final.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When Mario Götze settled a crossing pass with his chest and volleyed a goal that won the World Cup, German fans roared in ecstatic release. Those from Brazil were nearly as delirious, even if it was out of relief as much as celebration.

headline: How Race Skews Prosecutions
abstract: A study of the Manhattan district attorney’s office found a pattern of racial disparities in the criminal justice process.
lead_paragraph: In the legal stratosphere where Supreme Court justices sit, racism may appear to be largely a thing of the past. But down on the ground, where citizens and law enforcement encounter each other daily, race still matters. That is the key finding of an extensive report issued last week on the prosecutorial practices of the Manhattan district attorney’s office, one of the biggest and busiest in the country.

headline: As Strike Threat Looms, Stalled L.I.R.R. Talks Carry Hint of the Past
abstract: The long-running dispute between the railroad and its unions carries echoes of the last time workers walked out, but the gap between the two sides is much smaller this time around.
lead_paragraph: As the Long Island Rail Road lurches toward a possible strike that could shut it down as soon as Sunday, the long-running dispute between the railroad and its unions carries echoes of the last time workers walked out. But in the final week before the strike deadline, the gap between the two sides is actually much smaller this time around.

headline: Kansas’ Ruinous Tax Cuts
abstract: Gov. Sam Brownback’s ill-advised tax policy has contributed to the state’s plummeting revenues.
lead_paragraph: There was a windstorm of hasty excuses in recent weeks after Kansas reported that it took in $338 million less than expected in the 2014 fiscal year and would have to dip heavily into a reserve fund. Spending wasn’t cut enough, said conservatives. Too many rich people sold off stock in the previous year, state officials said. It’s the price of creating jobs, said Gov. Sam Brownback.

headline: In a Latino Enclave, the World Cup Puts Everything on Pause
abstract: As Latin American teams in the tournament dwindled to one, Argentina, residents of Jackson Heights, Queens, chose a side.
lead_paragraph: Something unusual happened on Sunday afternoon on the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens: Quiet.

headline: Brazilians Go Back to Real Life
abstract: Fans and authorities in Brazil breathed a sigh of relief as the World Cup ended without any major off-the-field incidents, and without an Argentine victory.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil suffered mightily with its national team’s 7-1 rout at the hands of Germany in the World Cup semifinals last week, but the authorities here breathed sighs of relief as the tournament came to a close on Sunday with Germany’s victory over Argentina, amid muted street protests and a display of Brazil’s ability to successfully organize sporting megaevents.

headline: Jerusalem’s Damaged Link
abstract: A light rail line connecting Arab and Jewish neighborhoods in Jerusalem was damaged during riots. Some Arab residents would rather not see the line re-opened.
lead_paragraph: A light rail line connecting Arab and Jewish neighborhoods in Jerusalem was damaged during riots. Some Arab residents would rather not see the line re-opened.

headline: After Lapses, C.D.C. Admits a Lax Culture at Labs
keywords: ['Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'ANTHRAX', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Avian Influenza', 'Influenza']
abstract: Recent revelations of safety breaches in the handling of dangerous microbes have created a crisis of faith at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, spent much of Wednesday completing a report that would let the public see, in embarrassing detail, how the sloppy handling of anthrax by scientists at its headquarters here had potentially exposed dozens of employees to the deadly bacteria.
