headline: A Coveted Candle Line Branches Out into Personal Perfumes
abstract: Maison Louis Marie introduces oils for the skin to complement its irresistible home fragrances. Here, the actress Grace Gummer stars in a video that captures their dreamlike effect.
lead_paragraph: The tastefully designed, subtly scented candles of Maison Louis Marie continue to draw distinguished noses to the doorsteps of fashionable outposts like Fred Segal in Los Angeles and Assembly in New York, and all the Steven Alan stores across the country in between. And today, the Belgian behind the brand, Marie du Petit Thouars, introduces her first collection of personal fragrance oils, four of which borrow the delicate bouquet of some of her most coveted candles, and one of which is being introduced for the first time. “Each scent from my collection represents a person, place or memory of my family and childhood that is created through blends of notes that utilize vast arrays of the botanical world,” she says. Another of her dearest childhood memories inspired her to create the oils, four of which are unisex, in the first place. “I remember when I was a child, I went on a fishing trip in the Mauritius Islands with a master perfumer from the Guerlain family,” she says. “He had created a perfume inspired by a woman with whom he had fallen in love with and wanted to reveal her sensuality through a perfume. I was absolutely charmed by this — what a beautiful gift to be able to give someone.”

headline: Le Grand Aioli: a Culinary Ode to Bastille Day
abstract: Francophile chefs agree that this Provençal dish, perfect for sharing, is especially delicious in the summer months.
lead_paragraph: On this, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille, there may not be a more appropriate, or at least delicious, way to celebrate the values of liberté, égalité and fraternité than with the traditional Provençal feast, le grand aioli. The pungent emulsion referred to as “the butter of Provence” is predictably the hero of the meal; however, it is arguably its accompaniments that make it truly grand. Served in bowls or the heavy mortars in which it is made, the aioli becomes a centerpiece flanked by an array of whatever is best from the market that day. Languid, unstructured and designed for sharing, at its best le grand aioli is a celebration of summer’s bounty andesprit.

Sam Brownback.” However, The Times says that the reason was “the spectacularly ill-advised income tax cuts that Mr. Brownback and his fellow Republicans engineered in 2012 and 2013. The cuts, which largely benefited the wealthy, cost the state 8 percent of the revenue it needs for schools and other government services.” Kansas under Mr. Brownback has shown “states cannot cut their way to prosperity. headline: Why Improving Access to Health Care Does Not Save Money
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A favorite argument in favor of the health care law is that improving access to preventive care will lower medical costs over all. It probably won't.
lead_paragraph: One of the oft-repeated arguments in favor of the Affordable Care Act is that it will reduce people’s need for more intensive care by increasing their access to preventive care. For example, people will use the emergency room less often because they will be able to see primary care physicians. Or, they will not develop as many chronic illnesses because they will be properly screened and treated early on. And they will not require significant and invasive care down the line because they will be better managed ahead of time.

headline: A Tale of ‘Too Big to Fail’ in Higher Education

If the problems weren’t fixed in short order, the accreditor said, it would shut down the college. A year later, the accreditor decided that City College’s remedial efforts were too little, too late, and ordered the campus to close its doors this July.

headline: We Are Our Bacteria

lead_paragraph: It was dark. Iraq. The middle of the night. The height of the insurgency. The explosion shook our insides. I ran up to my friend and looked at what was left of his body. His limbs were blown off. His eyes were still open but he stared off into nothingness. He gasped and choked as his body was still trying to breathe. I did everything I could to save him, but he still died in my arms.

headline: Looking Back at Nadine Gordimer’s Life and Work
abstract: Ms. Gordimer, the South African writer who received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1991, died on Sunday at 90.
lead_paragraph: Accepting the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1991, Nadine Gordimer, the South African writer who died on Sunday at 90, said: “I am what I suppose would be called a natural writer. I did not make any decision to become one. I did not, at the beginning, expect to earn a living by being read. I wrote as a child out of the joy of apprehending life through my senses — the look and scent and feel of things; and soon out of the emotions that puzzled me or raged within me and which took form, found some enlightenment, solace and delight, shaped in the written word.”

headline: 1964: Offer of Return to Congo
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Tshombe’s government asks the family of murdered premier Lumumba to return to the Congo in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LEOPOLDVILLE — Premier Moise Tshombe’s government today [July 14] invited the family of murdered premier Patrice Lumumba to return to the Congo from its voluntary exile in the United Arab Republic. Mrs. Lumumba and her four children left for Cairo in 1961 shortly after Mr. Lumumba was murdered in Katanga, where he had been sent for “safekeeping” by the Leopoldville authorities who ousted him from power. Mr. Tshombe, who was president of Katanga at the time, has been accused of complicity in Mr. Lumumba’s death. It was not immediately known whether Mr. Tshombe would attempt personally to persuade Mrs. Lumumba to return. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 15

headline: The Advanced Metrics of Attraction
abstract: We may not realize it, but we’re applying mathematical notions to relationships, and a crush is just a statistically small sample.
lead_paragraph: The essayist Alain de Botton has been writing a great deal lately about crushes, those sudden infatuations aroused by the merest of stimuli — the way she subtly rolls her eyes at a blowhard’s pronouncements, her intentional dropping of a glass to attract a waiter’s attention, the way he casually uses his iPhone as a bookmark. In beautiful prose laden with examples, Mr. de Botton describes how attraction can cascade into exultation but, alas, gradually dissolve into disillusionment and a slow vanishing of the mirage.

lead_paragraph: Created from six of the Dutch city’s most beautiful 17th- and 18th-century brick townhouses, the Waldorf-Astoria Amsterdam, five years in the making, sets an impressively high bar for a new sort of stylish and discreetly luxurious European hotel. It does so by offering a carefully curated contemporary approximation of the genteel lives of the burghers who originally built these mansions during Holland’s Golden Age, the period during the 17th century when the country led the world in everything from trade and maritime supremacy to art and science. So thoughtful and boutique-like is the design, you’d never guess it comes from Hilton (the corporate chain that owns the Waldorf-Astoria name).

lead_paragraph: “Elena’s Aria,” the third of four early pieces that the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker has brought to this year’s Lincoln Center Festival, is commonly characterized as a transitional work. Made in 1984, it was her first dance to use spoken text and film. The program note describes it as a result of self-questioning, a search for a way forward. And on Sunday at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, when it was performed in New York for the first time since 1987, that’s what it looked like: the work of a young artist who has hit an aesthetic wall and hasn’t yet discovered how to get past it.

headline: On the Nature of Our Regime
abstract: Is Mark Lilla right to describe ours as a “libertarian age”?
lead_paragraph: As an interlude between “reform conservatism and …” posts, I want to return to the Mark Lilla essay on our present political situation that I commented on a couple of weeks ago, this time to quibble a little bit with its title. That title is “The Truth About Our Libertarian Age,” and most writers I’ve seen commenting on the essay — from my colleague David Brooks to Andrew Sullivan to Damon Linker — have tended to basically accept Lilla’s formulation, which links the spread of cultural individualism (defined as “an outlook with treats as axiomatic the primacy of individual self-determination over traditional social ties”) to the durable triumph of neoliberalism in political economy, and places both under the umbrella of a libertarianism ascendant.

headline: Arizona Enlists a Beetle in Its Campaign for Water
abstract: Officials have used bulldozers, chain saws and now beetles to get rid of the tamarisk, a tree that consumes a lot of water, but some scientists say it may not help.
lead_paragraph: LEES FERRY, Ariz. — In this corner of America known for its vast landscapes, rugged mountains and deep river canyons, signs of the havoc created by the minuscule tamarisk beetle are everywhere.

headline: The Mysterious Tree of a Newborn’s Life
abstract: Given the placenta’s vital role, and all that can go wrong in pregnancy, relatively little is known about the organ, but that makes it fertile territory for potential medical breakthroughs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Minutes after a baby girl was born on a recent morning at UCSF Medical Center here, her placenta — a pulpy blob of an organ that is usually thrown away — was packed up and carried off like treasure through a maze of corridors to the laboratory of Susan Fisher, a professor of obstetrics, gynecology and reproductive sciences.

headline: Son of Dead Sea Scrolls Scholar Is Sentenced to Two Months in Jail
keywords: ['Dead Sea Scrolls', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'E-Mail', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A Manhattan court upheld Raphael Golb’s convictions on criminal impersonation and forgery counts in a campaign to malign his father’s academic rivals.
lead_paragraph: Five years after he was arrested in a case that tested the limits of free speech on the Internet in New York State, a man convicted of using fake email accounts to impersonate and malign his father’s academic rivals was sentenced on Monday to two months in jail.

headline: On TV by Popular Demand, for Better or Worse
abstract: Fan favorites seem to be coming back to life more frequently than ever, and not everybody is thrilled about it.
lead_paragraph: Two sets of fans received some good news recently: “Community” die-hards could rejoice at the revival of their favorite series by Yahoo, and Neil Gaiman adherents could celebrate the fact that the author’s 2001 novel, “American Gods,” would be adapted to air on Starz. But as more fan favorites get new lives, some are starting to question the wisdom of the reboot.

headline: Helsinki Divided on Plan for a Guggenheim Satellite
abstract: Plans for a proposed Guggenheim museum in Helsinki have proved polarizing, with left-of-center politicians warning that it could squander local resources.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — City boosters in this Nordic capital dream of a Guggenheim museum of Finnish wood rising near the Baltic Sea and one day drawing millions of tourists and cruise passengers. But the huge costs of the proposed development are stirring a backlash here against an institution that is ordinarily accustomed to eager suitors.

headline: Saying Sorry, but for What?
abstract: Amid the emphasis on making quick and heartfelt apologies for medical errors, what about cases when it is more bad luck — a bad rash from a great drug; a joint replacement that leaves lingering pain?
lead_paragraph: The plumber in my apartment was having the kind of bad day I recognize well, although my sympathies were absent for the moment. Summoned to address a cranky toilet, he had set off a chain of events that culminated in a cry of alarm deep within the bedroom closet, followed by the unmistakable sound of gushing water.

headline: Hong Kong to Deliver Report on Electoral Reform to Beijing
abstract: In addition to reflecting Hong Kong people’s views on reform, the report may seek approval from China’s top legislative body for implementing universal suffrage in 2017.
lead_paragraph: In December 2007, Donald Tsang, the chief executive of Hong Kong at the time, told Beijing that a majority of the public hoped to elect the region’s leader by “one person, one vote” in 2012, writing in a report that that expectation “should be taken seriously and given consideration.” A few weeks later, Beijing said “no”: The earliest possible year for such a vote would be a decade from then, in 2017.

headline: New Contraceptive Shot Being Released in Africa
abstract: A new form of the contraceptive Depo-Provera is being introduced in four African countries this year, and its backers hope that its simplicity may eventually allow women to inject themselves.
lead_paragraph: An easy-to-use new form of the injectable contraceptive Depo-Provera was introduced last week in Burkina Faso, the first of four African countries in which it will be rolled out this year.

headline: Carmakers Are Central Voice in U.S.-Europe Trade Talks
abstract: Negotiations for a trans-Atlantic trade pact, which have failed to gain momentum for more than a year, resumed on Monday in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — It’s a task that makes sense only by the logic of international trade strictures — which is why negotiators for the European Union and the United States are eager to change the rule book.

headline: Ticking Viral Bombs, Left in Boxes
abstract: The recent discovery of unguarded vials of the smallpox virus at the National Institutes of Health points to the need for greater safety precautions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the Sept. 11 attacks, fears that terrorists or the regime in Iraq might unleash a secret stash of the smallpox virus led Vice President Dick Cheney to call for a mass vaccination of the American public, an action President George W. Bush rejected.

headline: A Focused Hunt for a Victim to Avenge Israelis’ Deaths
abstract: Officials released new details about the killing of a Palestinian youth, saying that three Israeli Jews looked for hours for a victim to avenge the killings of three Israeli teenagers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — They cruised around the Arab neighborhoods of East Jerusalem for hours in the dark of night, three Israeli Jews: a man of 29, who was driving, and two of his relatives, youths about 17. They were looking for a victim, preferably someone lightweight, who could easily be pushed into the car.

lead_paragraph: The Broadway musical “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” inspired by the music and lyrics of the popular rapper Tupac Shakur, will close on Sunday after failing to attract theatergoers after six weeks of performances.

headline: Weekly Quandary: The Kids Are Ungrateful
abstract: When kids who complain about the things a parent thought they would appreciate, like vacations and even chocolate, how can a parent help them change both tone and attitude?
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family?

headline: Sale of Paper in Venezuela Raises Fears on Freedom

abstract: Secrecy surrounds the new ownership of a leading pro-opposition newspaper, El Universal, leading some to suspect the hand of government supporters in the deal.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — One of Venezuela’s leading pro-opposition newspapers has been sold in a transaction shrouded in mystery, fueling growing concerns here over the independence of the news media.

headline: Back From the Brink, Portugal Still Has a Long Way to Go
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The financial problems of a powerful family have given investors a reminder of the difficulties that Portugal still faces.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Only two months after Portugal proudly exited its international bailout program, the financial problems of the country’s most powerful family have given investors an unwelcome reminder of the potential fragility of the Portuguese recovery.

headline: Israelis Watch Bombs Drop on Gaza From Front-Row Seats
abstract: An image of Israeli spectators gathered on the high ground above Gaza to cheer the destruction below has reverberated online.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday night, as he stood on a hilltop outside the Israeli town of Sderot and watched the bombardment of Gaza on the plain below, a Danish newspaper reporter snapped an iPhone photo of about a dozen locals who cheered on their military from plastic chairs while eating popcorn.

headline: Health Care Hatred
abstract: Good news is unacceptable.
lead_paragraph: The good news about Obamacare so far shouldn’t be considered disputable. Enrollments really are above target; multiple independent surveys show a sharp drop in the uninsured population; health care cost growth really has slowed dramatically, whatever the reason; the newly insured are generally satisfied with their coverage. If you want to insist that big problems lie ahead, fine (but please explain), but the facts so far are pretty good.

headline: Germany 1. World Cup Fever 1,000.
abstract: The 2014 World Cup was a tremendous hit on television, online and in social media like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: THE day after the biggest football game of the year, Madison Avenue was eagerly — and, in some quarters, anxiously — combing through data to learn whether ads were hits or flops with tens of millions of fans.

headline: Ernst & Young to Pay Fine in Lobbying Case
abstract: The audit firm agreed to pay $4 million to settle accusations by the S.E.C. that it broke independence rules with appeals to Congress on behalf of auditing clients.
lead_paragraph: Ernst & Young, the audit firm, agreed on Monday to pay more than $4 million to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it violated independence rules by lobbying on behalf of two of its audit clients.

headline: Echoes of a Strongman in Baghdad Today
abstract: As the Iraqi government comes under relentless pressure from Sunni militants, there are echoes of Saddam Hussein’s rule in how it has responded.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The ghost of Saddam Hussein still hangs over Iraq like a cloud stalking a sunny day; it doesn’t always cover the sun, but it never quite goes away.

headline: Our Bees, Ourselves
abstract: The demise of honeybees should alert us that our own well-being might be similarly threatened.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — AROUND the world, honeybee colonies are dying in huge numbers: About one-third of hives collapse each year, a pattern going back a decade. For bees and the plants they pollinate — as well as for beekeepers, farmers, honey lovers and everyone else who appreciates this marvelous social insect — this is a catastrophe.

headline: The End of the ‘Mormon Moment’
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Women and Girls', 'Excommunication', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: What seems to have touched off the church’s latest hard-line stance is a long-running dispute over the position of women.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, Kate Kelly, a feminist Mormon lawyer who had called on the Mormon Church to open the priesthood to women, was excommunicated on the charge of apostasy. John P. Dehlin, who runs a popular podcast on hot-button church issues and has loudly advocated for the church to welcome gay men and lesbians, also was threatened with expulsion. Other Mormons have faced sanctions for participating in online forums questioning the church’s positions on these and other matters.

headline: Once a British Open Fan From the Neighborhood, Now a Participant
abstract: The fantasy of competing against the best golfers in the world will become a reality at the British Open for John Singleton, a mild-mannered man with a blue-collar job.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — In a break from his routine, John Singleton took his fiancée’s 6-year-old son to school Monday morning. It was his best drive of the day, at least until he arrived at Royal Liverpool Golf Club, a few miles from his home, and split the fairway with his first tee shot as one of his playing competitors, Darren Clarke, looked on.

headline: In a City Mired in Losing, James’s Return Offers a Glimmer of Hope
abstract: A beverage warehouse near Cleveland was a microcosm of what the downtrodden sports town was feeling as the news was being digested.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — He’s back. And suddenly, we are talking about time and home.

headline: A Municipal ID Card That’s Worth the Wait
abstract: A New York City law that creates ID’s for residents is good news for immigrants and marginalized city dwellers, but crucial details still need to be worked out.
lead_paragraph: New York City is creating its own official identification card, which is excellent news for immigrants without papers and other New Yorkers who hope to make their city a more secure and navigable place. Mayor Bill de Blasio signed the bill on Thursday. The cards are supposed to be available early next year, at which point New York will surely leapfrog New Haven and San Francisco in having the largest municipal ID program in the country.

headline: A Defense of Reproductive Rights
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'States (US)']
abstract: An important hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee could move the dynamics of the fight against laws restricting access to abortions in a positive direction.
lead_paragraph: Facing a torrent of state laws restricting access to safe and legal abortions, supporters of a woman’s right to make her own childbearing decisions have been forced to play a defensive game — trying to block enactment of the laws, and, when that doesn’t work, challenging them in court. An important hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday could begin to move the dynamics of the fight in a positive direction.

headline: Cleaning Up After the World Cup
abstract: Soccer is a hugely important force in the world today, so it is time for the sport to clean up its act.
lead_paragraph: Brazil can be proud of the World Cup it held — except, of course, the shocking breakdown of its national team in the 7-1 semifinal loss to Germany. The crowds were colorful, loud and behaved, and the play ranged from entertaining to utterly brilliant, all devoured by record-breaking audiences on television and social media.

headline: Back From the Brink in Afghanistan
abstract: President Obama must be ready to withhold billions of economic and military aid if the deal falls apart.
lead_paragraph: The compromise deal over Afghanistan’s bitterly contested presidential election is a big relief and a credit to all involved, especially Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani, the two candidates, and Secretary of State John Kerry, who brokered the agreement in 12 hours of intense negotiations. It pulled the country back from the risk of civil war and offers a chance for a peaceful political transition after 13 years of Hamid Karzai’s leadership.

headline: Equal Opportunity Employment Officials Take New Aim at Pregnancy Bias
abstract: New guidelines emphasize that employers cannot discriminate against workers because of past, present or future pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission on Monday issued new enforcement guidelines on pregnancy discrimination for the first time since 1983 in an effort to underscore that employers cannot discriminate against workers because of past, present or future pregnancies.

headline: Ukrainian Military Plane Is Shot Down as Russia Adds to Presence at Border
abstract: Although the details have yet to be verified, a spokeswoman for a separatist group said rebels had taken five members of the plane’s crew as hostages.
lead_paragraph: LUHANSK, Ukraine — A military transport plane was shot down over eastern Ukraine on Monday, Ukrainian officials said, while new reports emerged that Russia was building up forces along its border with Ukraine.

headline: Ex-Governor, Suing Over Book, Faces His Own Words
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Lawyers defending the estate of a former member of the Navy SEALs in a defamation case filed by the former Minnesota Gov. Jesse Ventura played audio and video clips of Mr. Ventura and read quotes from his books for jurors.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Jesse Ventura, the flamboyant wrestler-turned-governor, once told reporters that this nation had turned into “the Fascist States of America,” and said he would no longer rise for the national anthem.

headline: All-Stars Tip Caps to a Finale for Jeter
abstract: Derek Jeter, who is making his final appearance as an All-Star, drew one of the largest media crowds as well as praise from other players.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — At 6 feet 8 inches and 260 pounds, Yankees reliever Dellin Betances could easily be mistaken for Derek Jeter’s bodyguard. That is how tightly Betances clung to Jeter on Monday afternoon, the day before his first All-Star Game, and Jeter’s last.

headline: Yahoo Seeks to Bring the Concert to Your Couch
abstract: The company plans to stream 365 live concerts for free, but music executives are skeptical there will be many viewers.
lead_paragraph: The Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena in Jacksonville, Fla., where the Dave Matthews Band is playing Tuesday night, can hold up to 15,000 people. But as Yahoo and Live Nation see it, the potential audience is limitless.

headline: British Foreign Secretary Quits for Lower Position in the Cabinet
abstract: The resignation of William Hague was a surprise in Prime Minister David Cameron’s government shuffle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a surprise announcement, William Hague, Britain’s foreign secretary, said late Monday that he would quit his job to take a lower-profile cabinet position as part of a wider shuffle of the government.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Last week, Standard & Poor’s issued a short report about Boeing. “Boeing Co. Faces Long-Term Credit Risks If The U.S. Export-Import Bank Isn’t Reauthorized,” read the alarming heading.

headline: Abortion Clinic Protections Proposed in Massachusetts
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Law and Legislation', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Massachusetts lawmakers expressed support for a bill filed on Monday that they say would address safety concerns that arose when the United States Supreme Court last month struck down 35-foot buffer zones for demonstrators standing near entrances to abortion clinics.

headline: Toward a New U.S. Defense Model
abstract: What would the American military look like if we could start from scratch?

headline: Reluctantly, Patriot Flees Homeland for Greener Tax Pastures
abstract: Another company is moving its headquarters to Europe, in part to pay lower taxes. This time, it’s led by the daughter of a United States senator.
lead_paragraph: Heather Bresch grew up around politics. Her father is Joe Manchin, the Democratic senator from West Virginia and a former governor. She has heard him say repeatedly, “We live in the greatest country on Earth,” as he did in countless political advertisements. And it appeared to rub off on her: Ms. Bresch was named a “Patriot of the Year” in 2011 by Esquire magazine for helping to push through the F.D.A. Safety Innovation Act.

headline: Gaza Families Near Israeli Border Struggle to Build a Life in the Heart of a Conflict
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Palestinians', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Thousands of Palestinian families have fled, some several times, during years of fighting in the Palestinian coastal territory.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — In 2008, Umm Samer Marouf fled the northern Gaza Strip under Israeli bombardments that destroyed her family’s house and strawberry fields and left her deep in debt. Now, she and her seven children have fled again, from their half-built replacement home, and wonder if it, too, will be demolished.

headline: Baseball All-Stars Take Field, but Fewer People Tune In
abstract: The All-Star Game’s television audience has been cut in half over the last 20 years, and now the game draws a smaller audience than do many episodes of “The Walking Dead” on AMC.
lead_paragraph: The trend is clear and perhaps irreversible: Baseball’s All-Star Game is doomed to be seen by fewer people with each passing July.

headline: A Federal Appeals Court Sidesteps How to Prosecute Detainees
keywords: ['Military Tribunals', 'Detainees', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: The federal appeals court reinstated the 2008 conspiracy conviction of a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, but the long-awaited decision was more confusing than clarifying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a long-awaited decision about military commissions that was more confusing than clarifying, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia on Monday reinstated the 2008 conspiracy conviction of a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Ford Foundation Executive to Lead Consumer Reports

lead_paragraph: Consumer Reports has hired an executive from the Ford Foundation with an interest in social media and advocacy as its new chief executive.

headline: A’s Creative Mining Floods A.L. Roster With Hidden Gems
abstract: A team whose payroll ranks near the bottom of the major leagues sent seven players to the annual celebration of baseball, many of whom have taken unconventional routes to success.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Oakland Athletics traded for Jeff Samardzija after the National League players had voted him to their All-Star team. On Monday at Target Field, Samardzija dressed in the N.L. clubhouse and wore an N.L. warm-up jersey with a generic All-Star cap. Then he watched the Home Run Derby from the American League side.

headline: Anxious Moments for an Afghanistan on the Brink
abstract: The aftermath of the presidential runoff included as tumultuous a six-day stretch for Afghanistan as any since the American invasion in 2001.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was the Germans who uttered the first alarm that a potentially deadly power struggle might be brewing, after weeks of Western officials’ staying on the sidelines as the Afghan election crisis deepened. Just over a week ago, they threatened to withdraw funding and training troops from Afghanistan if a powerful regional governor declared a breakaway government led by the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah.

headline: Here They Come, Big-Boned Beauties All Dolled Up
abstract: In the musical “Pageant,” all the contestants, played by men, vie for the title of Miss Glamouresse.
lead_paragraph: I have fond but vague memories of the original Off Broadway production of “Pageant,” a musical spoof of beauty contests featuring an all-male cast of competitors dolled up in shiny gowns, bathing suits and heels. Having seen the sparkly and serviceable revival of the show that opened at the Davenport Theater on Monday night, I am inclined to wonder if the vagueness might have something to do with the fondness.

headline: Founders’ Day
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel finds some founders.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you know any entrepreneurs, you have probably heard about or seen firsthand how starting a business and making it successful can be all-consuming. In fact, it is sometimes hard, when you are trying to get a business off the ground, to tell where the business ends and you begin. At least, that’s what Zhouqin “C.C.” Burknikel is trying to tell us in today’s puzzle.

headline: Iran Outlines Nuclear Deal; Accepts Limit
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said the country could accept a freeze on its capacity to produce nuclear fuel at current levels for several years, provided it could eventually produce fuel unhindered.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Iran’s chief nuclear negotiator, faced with an imminent deadline for an agreement with the West on the future of the country’s nuclear program, said in an interview on Monday that Iran could accept a deal that essentially freezes its capacity to produce nuclear fuel at current levels for several years, provided it is then treated like any other nation with a peaceful nuclear program.

headline: Group of Law Professors Urges Obama to Deny Religious Exemption in Order
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Religion and Belief', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Government Employees']
abstract: The order would bar federal contractors from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity.
lead_paragraph: More than 50 constitutional law professors urged President Obama on Monday not to include a religious exemption in an expected order barring federal contractors from discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity. Conservative religious leaders want the rule, still being drafted, to exempt religious groups that object to homosexual behavior. But legal experts, organized by Katherine M. Franke of the Columbia University Law School, said in an open letter that church groups are already allowed to favor members of their faith in hiring, and that a new exception would allow employers to discriminate using taxpayer dollars and enshrine a second-class legal status for gay, lesbian and transgender workers.

headline: A Conductor Whose Exuberance Matched New York City’s
abstract: Lorin Maazel, who died on Sunday, made his New York conducting debut as a young boy at the 1939 World’s Fair in New York and was named the New York Philharmonic’s music director at 70.
lead_paragraph: There was so much to see at the 1939 World’s Fair in New York: its icons, the Trylon and Perisphere. The Futurama, with its promise of automated highways. The giant statue of George Washington. The giant cash register atop one building. And little Lorin Maazel, making his New York conducting debut. He was 9 years old.

headline: Indian Rape Victim to Be Enrolled in Boarding School
abstract: An official said the girl, 13, who was raped apparently in retaliation for something her brother did, would also be given a government job at age 18.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The authorities in the northeastern Indian state of Jharkhand said Monday that a 13-year-old girl who was raped in her village last week, apparently in retaliation for something her brother did, would be immediately enrolled in a government boarding school.

headline: Egypt: Opening for the Old Guard
abstract: An Egyptian court on Monday lifted a ban that prevented members of the political party of former President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in 2011, from standing in parliamentary and local elections, state media reported.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian court on Monday lifted a ban that prevented members of the political party of former President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in 2011, from standing in parliamentary and local elections, state media reported. The court’s decision, which said that party members who had not been convicted of crimes should not be excluded from public life, appeared to pave the way for the rehabilitation of members of Egypt’s once-disgraced old guard. Mr. Mubarak’s National Democratic Party, which dominated politics for decades, was dissolved after his ouster. The Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group that won successive elections after Mr. Mubarak’s fall, was swept from power during a military takeover of the government last year and banned as part of a crackdown on political opposition. Experts say a new election law is likely to further constrict Egypt’s political life, producing a legislature subservient to the new president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, while reviving some of the patronage networks that thrived under Mr. Mubarak.

headline: India: Court Stays Executions for 2 Convicted in Gang-Rape Case
abstract: The Supreme Court of India on Monday temporarily stayed the execution of two men convicted of raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman on a bus in New Delhi in 2012, said their lawyer, A. P. Singh, in a case that drew international attention, prompted an outcry in India and led to the strengthening of sexual assault laws in the country.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of India on Monday temporarily stayed the execution of two men convicted of raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman on a bus in New Delhi in 2012, said their lawyer, A. P. Singh, in a case that drew international attention, prompted an outcry in India and led to the strengthening of sexual assault laws. The court on Monday stayed the executions of Vinay Sharma and Akshay Kumar Singh; the executions of two other defendants were also stayed by the Supreme Court in March after appeals were filed. All four were convicted of the crimes and sentenced to death last September. The district court that convicted the men categorized the case, in which the victim was repeatedly assaulted with iron rods on a moving bus, as the “rarest of the rare,” a designation that allowed the application of the death penalty. The four defendants plan to continue their appeals, and a final hearing is scheduled for August, said Manohar Lal Sharma, a lawyer for two of the defendants. Another accused, a juvenile at the time of the crime, was sentenced to three years in prison, and a sixth hanged himself in his prison cell.

headline: Haiti: A U.N. Cholera ‘Pilgrimage’
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations visited Haiti on Monday and sought to assure Haitians that he was committed to ending a cholera epidemic “as quickly as possible,” but he did not acknowledge his organization’s possible complicity in causing it, the subject of at least two lawsuits filed in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations visited Haiti on Monday and sought to assure Haitians that he was committed to ending a cholera epidemic “as quickly as possible,” but he did not acknowledge his organization’s possible complicity in causing it, the subject of at least two lawsuits filed in the United States. In a speech in Los Palmas, a village ravaged by the disease, Mr. Ban called the visit “a necessary pilgrimage” that was aimed at expressing solidarity with the cholera victims. He has been seeking to raise $2.2 billion to eradicate cholera, which has killed more than 8,000 people in Haiti since 2010. It was absent from the country for nearly 100 years until after the January 2010 earthquake. Forensic studies have identified the cholera bacteria as an Asian strain carried by Nepalese members of a United Nations peacekeeping force in Haiti. Stanley N. Alpert, a lawyer representing Haitian victims in a lawsuit, called the secretary general’s speech “devoid of any sense of responsibility for the fact that the U.N. brought the cholera to Haiti and it should have gone into overdrive to shut it down.”

headline: Beyond Looking Out for No. 1, Always Putting the Team First
abstract: There is a clear distinction between LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony in how they have balanced the art of playing a team sport with the equally tricky but more desensitized business of professional basketball.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony declared himself a “Knick at heart” a day after LeBron James said, “I’m coming home.” It was a copycat narrative only in programmed exclamation, not so much in practical execution.

headline: Lobbying Group Adopts de Blasio’s Agenda
abstract: Created by Mayor Bill de Blasio's strategists to promote his plans for universal prekindergarten, Campaign for One New York has moved on to other issues dear to the mayor.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has had his hands full in his first six months in office, with labor contracts, budgets and day-to-day crises to negotiate. But he made time last month to headline a fund-raiser for a new lobbying group: one seeking to promote his political agenda.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 14, 2014

headline: Red Klotz, Beloved Foil for the Harlem Globetrotters, Dies at 93

headline: A Pastry Chef Masters the Veggie Burger
abstract: Brooks Headley, the punk rocker turned haute pastry chef at Del Posto, also makes what just might be the finest veggie burgers on the planet. And this Sunday, he’ll serve them at his first fast food pop up, Superiority Burger, on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Just before the rush of dinner service, the pastry chef Brooks Headley agreed to serve me a veggie burger at Del Posto’s gleaming marble bar in Chelsea. In the mid-’90s, when Headley played drums with the Young Pioneers, he loved veggie burgers so much that he planned the punk band’s tours around stops at Faque Burger in San Diego for the vegetarian diner’s soy-based patty. He’s still obsessed. He has served his own veggie burger to David Chang, who posted a close-up to Instagram (1.8K likes), declaring it the best he’s ever tried. Questlove asked Headley to serve the burger at his food salon. And this Sunday, the guy who turned the most profoundly uncool snack on the planet into something sought after will serve his patties to the public at his first pop-up, Superiority Burger on the Lower East Side.

headline: 1914: President of Mexico Resigns
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The President of Mexico resigned in 1914.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — General Huerta resigned office as President of Mexico this afternoon [July 15]. Congress was immediately convoked to discuss the dictator’s resignation. It is stated that the entire Cabinet and the Military Commission will resign if General Huerta’s resignation is accepted. President Huerta’s family and other relatives and close friends left Vera Cruz on a special train at ten o’clock last night. Rebel troops fired on the train on the outskirts of Orozaba, where the train arrived to-day, but no one was injured. It is believed that the passengers’ destination is Salina Cruz, where a Japanese cruiser is lying at anchor. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 16, 1914

abstract: Jody Williams’s recipes focus on technique, and the results are perfect.
lead_paragraph: Brussels sprouts are not in season. They are available at the supermarket, though, small containers full of green California golf balls shipped great distances to satisfy the tastes of people who want such things year-round. We know we should shun them in favor of what the farmers’ market has now: young cabbages from the field across from the sheep; rhubarb from along the stone fence; “real” strawberries; “local” radishes. It is smart to shop and cook and eat seasonally. It tastes better. It is better.

headline: What Happened When Martha Stewart Got a Drone
abstract: The lifestyle mogul’s enthusiasm for unmanned aircraft is not shared by everyone.
lead_paragraph: If you have lingering questions about drones — particularly about whether they can take nice pictures of a farm — allow Martha Stewart to reassure you. She recently posted the following on her blog:

headline: MoMA Names New Architecture and Design Curator
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art has picked a Swiss art history professor to be its new curator for architecture.
lead_paragraph: Martino Stierli, a Swiss art history professor, has been appointed chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, Glenn D. Lowry, the museum’s director announced Tuesday.

headline: Cardinal Reliever’s Tumultuous Road Leads to an All-Star Ending
abstract: Almost two years after losing his firstborn to an illness, pitcher Pat Neshek, 33, won a roster spot with St. Louis, became a father again and, finally, a first-time All-Star.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Those who know Pat Neshek understood the significance of it all. A St. Louis Cardinals relief pitcher, he entered a Hyatt Regency ballroom a few minutes late for the National League All-Stars’ media session Monday afternoon. Something else had required his attention.

headline: Casualties in Moscow Subway Derailment
abstract: Witnesses described the morning rush hour crash that killed 20 people on Tuesday, as officials opened an investigation into the cause.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses described the morning rush hour crash that killed 20 people on Tuesday, as officials opened an investigation into the cause.

headline: Border Tensions Rise Between Ukraine and Russia
abstract: Ukraine accused Russia of downing a military transport plane, and each side accused the other of attacking the town of Snizhne.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine and Russia traded increasingly bitter accusations of cross-border hostilities on Tuesday, deepening a shadowy war of real attacks or orchestrated sabotage that increasingly threatens to draw the two countries into direct conflict.

headline: A Spoonful of Medicine May Put Children at Risk
abstract: Many professional associations have begun recommending that a uniform unit be adopted for medicines: the milliliter.
lead_paragraph: Each year, about 10,000 people contact poison centers in the United States, afraid that they gave too strong a dose of medicine or were confused by measurement directions, according to the American Association of Poison Control Centers. About three-quarters of the callers are parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12, often baffled by such options for measuring as milliliters, milligrams, teaspoons, tablespoons and droppers.

headline: For Proof Wall Street Is Changing, Look at Citigroup's Numbers
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The bank is still huge, but smaller than it used to be. Its earnings are smaller, too, and less subject to volatility.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to be cynical about Wall Street reform. Nothing ever changes. The big banks get bigger and more powerful than ever. Too Big to Fail is worse than ever.

headline: Kerry on Nuclear Negotiations
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry announced that intense nuclear negotiations with Iran have yielded “tangible progress,” but that significant gaps remain.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry announced that intense nuclear negotiations with Iran have yielded “tangible progress,” but that significant gaps remain.

headline: 1964: Brezhnev As Successor?
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Leonid I. Brezhnev emerged as the man most likely to succeed Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Leonid I. Brezhnev emerged today [July 15] as the man most likely to succeed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. Mr. Brezhnev, Soviet president since May, 1960, gave up the largely ceremonial post to devote himself fully to Communist party affairs. His place as president was taken by First Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan, 68. Western diplomats said the change in party assignments, unquestionably made with Mr. Khrushchev’s  personal approval, represent a marked promotion for 58-year-old Mr. Brezhnev. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 16, 1964

headline: The Shadow Universe Revealed
abstract: Recently astronomers have used a cosmic web imager to visualize simulations of dark matter, showing how the large scale structure of the universe grows and the nests in which galaxies are hatched.
lead_paragraph: Recently astronomers have used a cosmic web imager to visualize simulations of dark matter, showing how the large scale structure of the universe grows and the nests in which galaxies are hatched.

headline: Yellen Testifies on U.S. Recovery
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress that an ailing job market and stagnant wages justify keeping interest rates low.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress that an ailing job market and stagnant wages justify keeping interest rates low.

headline: Mulford Farm Prepares for the East Hampton Antiques Show
abstract: The event, to benefit the East Hampton Historical Society, is to be held on July 19 and 20.
lead_paragraph: Once again, Mulford Farm in East Hampton, N.Y., a 3.5-acre property with a restored 17th-century farmhouse, is the backdrop for the annual East Hampton Antiques Show, Saturday and Sunday. The show, a benefit for the East Hampton Historical Society, offers furnishings from more than 55 antiques dealers from around the United States.

headline: A Feminist in the Forest
abstract: “White Beech: The Rainforest Years” is Germaine Greer’s personal account of restoring a plot of land in Queensland, Australia.
lead_paragraph: Germaine Greer, the Australian author of “The Female Eunuch” (1970), that garrulous classic of second-wave feminism, has been a lifelong agitation artist. In her heyday she tangled with William F. Buckley and Norman Mailer, her skeptical blue-gray eyes boring holes through to the backs of their heads. Her sound bites, lanky good looks and proclivity for posing nude prompted Life magazine to call her, on its cover, the “saucy feminist that even men like.”

headline: The Gay Mormon Known Sperm Donor From Utah
keywords: ['ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Sperm']
abstract: My friends used to offer up my status as a gay former Mormon as an icebreaker. Now, they’re helpfully tossing my role as “known sperm donor” out at dinner parties.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I find myself in a social situation that could use the aid of an icebreaker, some of my friends are a bit quicker than I would like to offer me up as conversational fodder.

headline: Walking Through History in Ireland
abstract: New walking trips in Ireland take visitors to archaeological sites like medieval burial grounds and a former fortress.
lead_paragraph: Travelers can explore the archaeological riches of Ireland’s northwest coast through new walking trips from the Toronto-based active adventure company Butterfield & Robinson.

headline: ‘Hedwig’ Recoups on Broadway
abstract: “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” has recouped its capitalization, with another month to go before Neil Patrick Harris departs.
lead_paragraph: The critically acclaimed Broadway musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” has turned a quick profit in just 15 weeks, with robust tickets sales driven in large part by the popularity of its star, Neil Patrick Harris.

headline: Investors See Pricing Power in Tobacco Deal
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: Reynolds and Lorillard have gained more than $10 billion in market value since talk of a merger surfaced. Investors apparently like the idea of a duopoly in cigarettes, writes Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews. But will regulators?
lead_paragraph: American trustbusters deciding whether to approve Reynolds American’s deal with Lorillard will want to heed the market’s message. The combined market value of the No. 2 and No. 3 cigarette makers in the United States has jumped more than $10 billion since merger talk surfaced. Those gains can’t be justified by the cost savings on offer. Expectations of an increase in pricing power, through the creation of an effective tobacco duopoly, may best explain investors’ enthusiasm.

headline: Janet Yellen on the Everything Bubble
abstract: In policy testimony, the leader of the Federal Reserve made it clear that while she sees signs of some overvalued assets, she is not alarmed over all.
lead_paragraph: Last week we wrote here about how virtually all major asset classes on earth are relatively expensive compared with their historical values. We called it the Everything Boom, with a worrying asterisk that it could be, or become, the Everything Bubble.

headline: Filings Aimed at Challengers to Corcoran Takeover
abstract: The lawsuit filed in Washington is a response to another suit aimed at blocking the takeover of the Corcoran by the National Gallery of Art.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Corcoran Gallery of Art and its art school filed papers in Washington on Monday challenging an attempt by a group to block a takeover of the Corcoran by the National Gallery of Art and George Washington University.

headline: After Reynolds Buys Lorillard, Few Big Tobacco Deals Remain
abstract: Once the deal is completed and several brands are divested to Imperial Tobacco, there will be few cigarette brands popular in the United States not owned by either company or the market leader, Altria.
lead_paragraph: Reynolds American’s acquisition of its smaller rival, Lorillard, is sure to face antitrust scrutiny in Washington. In the United States market, the deal will create a virtual duopoly, with Altria remaining the largest cigarette seller.

headline: No Comment Necessary: ‘Down to a Woman’s Level’
abstract: “Men do tend to talk about things on a much higher level,” Representative Ellmers said.
lead_paragraph: At a Friday meeting of conservative women, Representative Renee Ellmers of North Carolina said her male colleagues could improve their messaging by bringing policy discussions “down to a woman’s level.”

headline: Obama Presses Congress for Long-Term Transportation Bill
abstract: President Obama argued that Republicans were more interested in trying to “score points on cable TV” than in fixing the country’s roads and bridges.
lead_paragraph: McLEAN, Va. — President Obama on Tuesday pressed Congress to break a deadlock over a long-term transportation spending bill, arguing that Republicans were more interested in trying to “score points on cable TV” than in fixing the country’s roads and bridges.

keywords: ['Money Market Accounts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Financial Stability Oversight Council must soon decide whether to accept proposed S.E.C. rules on money market funds or to press for tougher measures.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the financial crisis, Congress created an elite group to hunt down risks that might cause another global collapse.

headline: Though Scorned by Colleagues, a Climate-Change Skeptic Is Unbowed
abstract: John Christy, a highly credentialed professor in Alabama, says warming predictions have been greatly overstated. His critics are many.
lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — John Christy, a professor of atmospheric science at the University of Alabama in Huntsville, says he remembers the morning he spotted a well-known colleague at a gathering of climate experts.

headline: Still Walking on Air, Germans Touch Down for World Cup Party
abstract: Germany’s national soccer team returned to Berlin on Tuesday on a customized 747 and received a heroes’ welcome in a celebration at Brandenburg Gate.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany paraded its pride and its festive side on Tuesday when hundreds of thousands of fans gathered on a joyous, sun-kissed day to welcome home their victorious World Cup soccer squad.

headline: Garth Brooks Sets a Single Tour Date After Canceling Irish Shows
abstract: Mr. Brooks is set to emerge from retirement with a new album, and he announced a single date of a planned tour.
lead_paragraph: When Garth Brooks announced the decisive end of his retirement, last week, he left his fans with news of a new recording contract, a forthcoming album and the availability of music in downloadable form, and promised that the details of a world tour would be forthcoming. On Monday evening, he announced the first stop, a concert at the Allstate Arena in Rosemont, Ill., on Sept. 4. And so far, that’s it: it was unclear on Tuesday whether Mr. Brooks planned to announce the tour one date at a time – a tip of the hat, perhaps, to the British author David Mitchell, who is spending this week publishing a short story on Twitter, 140 characters at a time – or would announce the full tour shortly.

headline: A ‘Stampede’ for Freedom
abstract: How the rush of black Kentuckians to enlist in 1864 changed the meaning of the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: In early 1864, the Union Army began enlisting black soldiers in Kentucky, but Capt. J. Bates Dickson, an enlistment officer in the state, didn’t expect much – they might come “singly and in squads,” but not waves. Indeed, despite tens of thousands of fighting-age black men in the state, turnout was paltry – after all, Kentucky was still a slave state, and enlistment was restricted to free blacks and to slaves whose owners permitted them to go. Most slaveholders and their allies resisted black enlistment by any means possible, often with cruelty and violence.

headline: The Latest News That Isn’t
abstract: “Last Week Tonight With John Oliver” offers focus and depth, while Clickhole takes a full satirical swing at sites like BuzzFeed and Upworthy.
lead_paragraph: At this point, we all have heard that print media is dying and that online journalism rests upon shaky business models. But at least fake news is thriving, right? Not so fast.

headline: Immigration Activist Detained in Texas
abstract: Jose Antonio Vargas, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and an activist for immigrants, like him, who do not have legal status, was detained at McAllen-Miller International Airport on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: The Norwegian trumpeter performs “I ensomme Stunde” composed by Ole Bull.

headline: Okwiri Oduor Wins Caine Prize for African Writing
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Ms. Oduor, 25, a Kenyan writer, won the prize for her short story “My Father’s Head.”
lead_paragraph: Okwiri Oduor, a 25-year-old Kenyan who studied law but switched to writing, has won the 2014 Caine Prize for African Writing. The award was announced Monday at the Bodleian Library in Oxford, England. This annual prize, for a short story by an African writer published in English, was first awarded in 2000 to highlight literary talent from the continent.

headline: Beware John Cornyn’s ‘Humane’ Immigration Act
abstract: Children at the border need lawyers and victim advocates, not a swift trip back home.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Cornyn, the Texas Republican, has offered a bill that he says will solve the crisis of unaccompanied migrant children at the southern border.

headline: Pebble Beach Concours to Feature Grand Prix Centennial Cars

abstract: The organizers of the concours announced this week that cars from the 1914 Grand Prix of the Automobile Club of France would be displayed.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition celebrating the centennial of the 1914 Grand Prix of the Automobile Club of France, which will include the winning Mercedes, the race trophy and five other cars of the era, will be on display at the Aug. 17 Pebble Beach Concours d'Élégance in California, it was announced by Sandra Button, head of the concours.

headline: It’s Woods and It’s Royal Liverpool, but It’s Not 2006
abstract: Tiger Woods, who has not won a major tournament for six years and is coming off back surgery, said that an acceptable finish at this week’s British Open would be first place.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — On his way to the British Open, Tiger Woods stopped in Geneva and spent the day touring a Rolex factory. He has reason to be preoccupied with time.

lead_paragraph: MIRPURKHAS, Pakistan — In a country roiled by violent strife, the southern province of Sindh, celebrated as the “land of Sufis,” has long prized its reputation as a Pakistani bastion of tolerance and diversity.

abstract: This week our top winner is Madeline, but we’ve also chosen five runners-up and 10 honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another wonderful set of student entries in our Summer Reading Contest.

lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Race of Attrition Continues, Even on a Rest Day
abstract: The Swiss rider Fabian Cancellara voluntarily pulled out of the Tour de France on Tuesday, a rest day, and Vincenzo Nibali of Italy played down his status as the overall leader.
lead_paragraph: BESANÇON, France — Short of its halfway point, this year’s unusually cruel Tour de France has raised several questions. Did the organizers go too far in their attempt to liven up the first week of the race with difficult routes? Are riders taking excessive risks? And, above all, with Chris Froome and Alberto Contador removed by crashes, can anyone beat Vincenzo Nibali?

headline: When Climate Change Floods Your Heart
abstract: As politicians argue over the science of climate change, others are starting to talk about its emotional impact.
lead_paragraph: In 2100, I will live in Florida.

headline: A Brooklynized Take on the Populist Musical, Courtesy of Yeasayer’s Front Man
abstract: Anand Wilder and Maxwell Kardon, two veterans of the local scene, have enlisted a cast of indie-rock luminaries for their new album (and possible future stage production), “Break Line,” a track from which appears here.
lead_paragraph: What happens when two Brooklyn guys dream up a musical about the ravages of industry on a small town in contemporary gilded-age America and cast it full of indie-rock intelligentsia? Something like what would have happened if the Byrds’ Gene Clark restaged “Jesus Christ Superstar” as a series of Dorothea Lange tableaux. “Break Line: the Musical” (Secretly Canadian), a new project written by the Yeasayer front man Anand Wilder and his longtime friend, the pianist Maxwell Kardon, features a cast of musicians from Vampire Weekend, Man Man, Dirty Projectors, MGMT, Suckers, Kishi Bashi and Sinkane, among others, in telling the tale of a coal-mining Pennsylvania town called Greenbelt. The result mixes earnest politics, open-throated Broadway belting and sly psychedelic instrumentation.

headline: In Illinois, a Challenge to Services Like Uber
keywords: ['Chauffeurs and Drivers', 'Law and Legislation', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Illinois General Assembly recently approved legislation that would make it difficult for ridesharing services like Uber to operate in the state.
lead_paragraph: The ride-sharing services UberX, Sidecar and Lyft may soon find it almost impossible to operate in Illinois.

headline: Away From Home but Not the Kitchen
abstract: The three brothers and owners of El Celler de Can Roca in Girona, Spain, are taking a summer vacation but still cooking.
lead_paragraph: GIRONA, Spain — El Celler de Can Roca has climbed to the summit of world gastronomy without ruffling the simple routines of the family that runs it. The restaurant, in this city about an hour’s drive northeast of Barcelona, is owned and operated by three brothers who still lunch on their mom’s food every day in the nearby restaurant where they grew up, learning about cooking while playing soccer among the tables and chairs.

headline: In London, You Can Join the Show
abstract: From an immersive staging of Macbeth to a participatory "Back to the Future," these productions weave the audience into the story.
lead_paragraph: Almost 30 years after “Back to the Future” first hit theaters, time travel is about as realistic as Doc Brown’s flux capacitor. But as of July 24, you can visit  California’s Hill Valley between 1955 and 1985 — as in the movie, but in the flesh — via London.

headline: Eating Across Texas, Puffy Tacos to Frito Pie
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Lisa Fain, of the blog “Homesick Texan,” talks about some of the dishes she sampled on a book tour between Houston and Marfa.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Fain’s blog, “Homesick Texan,” is predicated on food nostalgia. From her New York kitchen, she conjures recipes of the kind of comfort food and Tex-Mex dishes she knew growing up in the Lone Star State, often updated with fresh ingredients.

headline: Restaurant Report: Hog Island Oyster Bar in San Francisco
abstract: After closing this past January to remodel and expand, this popular seafood spot is back.
lead_paragraph: In 1983, when two young marine biologists planted oyster seed on a Tomales Bay intertidal tract about 50 miles north of San Francisco, little did they know their Hog Island Oyster Co. would grow into a bay-to-bar juggernaut with nearly $12 million in annual sales and a trio of retail locations.

headline: Arbitration Clauses Let American Apparel Hide Misconduct
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The scandal over the ouster of Dov Charney from American Apparel shows the consequences of confidentiality agreements, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor.
lead_paragraph: The real lesson from the ouster of Dov Charney at American Apparel is the danger of arbitration clauses.

headline: Stroke Rates Are Declining
abstract: The incidence of stroke in the United States has declined significantly over the past two decades, a new analysis has found.
lead_paragraph: The incidence of stroke in the United States has declined significantly over the past two decades, a new analysis has found.

headline: Harper Lee Says New Book Not Authorized
abstract: Ms. Lee, 88, says that she did not cooperate with Marja Mills, the author of “The Mockingbird Next Door: Life With Harper Lee,” but instead left “town whenever she headed this way.”
lead_paragraph: For an author who is as famous for her reclusiveness as for her work – a single but extraordinarily influential novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird” – Harper Lee has been awfully public lately. An on-again, off-again lawsuit against the Monroe County Heritage Museum, in Monroeville, Ala., Ms. Lee’s hometown, over what she said was the unauthorized use of her book brought her into the spotlight several times from October 2012 to this May.

headline: Philharmonic Cancels Tuesday’s Park Concert
abstract: Rain caused the New York Philharmonic to cancel a concert planned for Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic’s second attempt to pay tribute to Lorin Maazel, its former music director, who died on Sunday, has come to grief. The orchestra was to have performed a concert at Central Park on Monday evening, part of its annual series of free outdoor concerts, and had announced that in memory of Mr. Maazel, Alan Gilbert would conduct Samuel Barber’s “Adagio for Strings.” But when dire weather predictions led to the orchestra to cancel the concert on Monday afternoon, the tribute was moved to the Tuesday evening concert in Van Cortlandt Park, in the Bronx.

headline: Big City Book Club Discusses ‘Lush Life’
abstract: The Big City Book Club’s discussed Richard Price’s best-selling 2008 novel, “Lush Life,” on The Times’s City Room blog.
lead_paragraph: This concludes our live discussion of “Lush Life.” Thanks to all who participated. Anyone who missed the conversation should feel free to post comments here throughout the week. We will soon announce the next selection of the Big City Book Club.

headline: Chilled Corn Soup
abstract: Melissa Clark shows how to make a delicious cool corn soup with garlic, buttermilk and basil.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows how to make a delicious cool corn soup with garlic, buttermilk and basil.

headline: Suit Seeks to Establish Right to Record New York Police Officers
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: A federal lawsuit, which cites arrests of people who recorded police confrontations or activity, was filed on Tuesday asking a judge to declare that people have a right under the First Amendment to film or record officers working in public places.

headline: Motivating Corporations to Do Good
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Executive Compensation', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Businesses once addressed the needs of workers and society, partly out of self-interest. Now the shareholder is king.
lead_paragraph: Is it naïve to expect corporations to assist in addressing the social, economic and environmental challenges of the day?

headline: Corporate Medicis to the Rescue
abstract: As Italy struggles with a stagnant economy and crushing public debt, politicians are now looking to private companies to help preserve its cultural heritage.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Since early July, workers have been carefully unscrewing the steel scaffolding that for months has obscured much of the ancient facade of the Colosseum. Slowly, this monolithic symbol of Rome is coming into view again after the first portion of a 25 million euro ($34 million) refurbishment that underscores how Italy is coming to rely on private aid to preserve national treasures.

headline: Germany’s Defense Against the N.S.A.: Typewriters
abstract: A German politician said he and his colleagues were thinking of ditching email for sensitive communications.
lead_paragraph: In the television series “Battlestar Galactica,” by which I mean the most recent version, the human race is essentially saved from extinction because there are no fancy computer networks or other interconnected devices aboard the Galactica, an old spacecraft designed to resist infiltration by angry robots.

headline: London Theater Journal:  A ‘Carousel’ That Really Moves
abstract: Ben Brantley on energetic productions of “Carousel” and “The Pajama Game.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – When June starts bustin’ out all over in the exuberant production of “Carousel” at the Arcola Theater here, you might wish you had been equipped with riot gear. Flying arms, legs and torsos look as if they’re in imminent danger of colliding with one another and with the audience, too. Hormones, with which the rowdy young things onstage are abundantly equipped, suddenly seem like dangerous weapons.

headline: Hauser & Wirth’s Newest Outpost in English Farm Country Is Now Open
abstract: The new gallery and arts center in Somerset, England, is finally ready for the public to explore its sprawling grounds, landscaped by Piet Oudolf and filled with site-specific sculptures by Phyllida Barlow.
lead_paragraph: In Somerset, an English county marked by rolling farmland, the new and much-anticipated Hauser & Wirth outpost finally opened its doors today. T first profiled the project in April, in the Spring Design 2014 issue, with a first look at the arts center being carved out of a working farm there. The story focused on the farmhouse at Durslade Farm, a property that had been abandoned for 10 years and then left untouched for 50 before being restored and renovated by the Paris-based architect Luis Laplace. Its six guest bedrooms were then filled with pieces by Hauser & Wirth’s impressive lineup of artists, including Pipilotti Rist and Paul McCarthy, and the grounds were landscaped by none other than Piet Oudolf, the Dutch garden designer behind home-like public gardens such as the High Line in Manhattan.

headline: Controlling the Home, Google Style
abstract: Google’s Nest thermostat company is at the forefront of an effort to make home devices talk with each other as well as the Internet.
lead_paragraph: When Google goes after the home, it goes big. And maybe it goes after control, too.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Building the Front Page
abstract: Laying out the front page of The New York Times is an exercise of assembly, Tom Bodkin explained.
lead_paragraph: Tom Bodkin is design director, chief creative officer and a deputy managing editor. Each day, after the best stories and photos are selected by top editors, he sketches the layout of the front page, which will determine the rest of the news sections’ design. We asked him about the process.

headline: The Risks of Hillary Clinton’s Quasi-Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In the absence of policy statements, voters gravitate toward personal traits and characteristics to fill in the blanks.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is not running for president — at least not by her own admission. But it’s been a month since the start of her “Hard Choices” book tour, and nearly all the elements of a presidential campaign have emerged. There are boisterous crowds, speeches, interviews, an appearance tonight on “The Daily Show,” lists with names and email addresses, attacks from the opposition, and gaffes.

headline: Today in Small Business: Pregnancy Discrimination
abstract: Understanding the economics of lobsters. The value of the right domain name. And how to get customers to write online reviews.

abstract: An alternative to the Whitney Biennial in Arkansas focuses on contemporary artists and “the evolving narratives that make up our cultural fabric.”
lead_paragraph: After a restless cross-country search in which two curators logged more than 100,000 miles in airplanes and rental cars, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art – founded by the Walmart heiress Alice Walton – announced Tuesday that it had finalized its artist list for an ambitious fall show that will present a snapshot of unheralded 21st century American art.

headline: Life Without Cars
abstract: Can America be Uberized?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been following some of the discussion about Uber, Lyft, and all that, and I have a few unoriginal thoughts. Well, strictly speaking they are original, in the sense that I haven’t read them anywhere else — but surely they’re out there. So this post is partly a bleg for references.

headline: Would-Be Rescuers of Wayward Spacecraft Previously Solved a NASA Mystery
abstract: A project by Dennis Wingo and Keith Cowing involved the rescuing of magnetic tapes from five robotic craft photographing the moon’s surface.
lead_paragraph: Before reviving a zombie spacecraft, Dennis Wingo and Keith Cowing traveled to the past to rescue a trove of early moon photographs that otherwise would have been destined for oblivion.

headline: Introducing a Poet Who Works in 3-D
abstract: Alex Butler’s new verse volume, “Circling the Same” — which she’ll read from tonight at Creatures of Comfort — is a multimedia experience.
lead_paragraph: The writer Alex Butler may live in brownstone Brooklyn, but that’s about the extent of her similarities to the young literary set. A licensed social worker, she has also worked for the designer Jane Mayle, served as a production assistant on the set of “Sex and the City” and recorded a series of humorous performance videos. It was the loss, in quick succession, of both her parents — and Butler’s experience as her mother’s caretaker during a harrowing illness — that spurred her to turn what had been a secret hobby into a career. But rather than sit down at a laptop and type about the experience, she began speaking words and dialogue into a Dictaphone — and later her computer’s camera — which led to not one, but two books: her debut memoir, “Walking the Night Road,” due out next year from Columbia University Press, and “Circling the Same,” a 41-poem meditation on loss. The latter — newly available online through its publisher, the Los Angeles–based gallery and art-book press Ohwow — is as much art object as literature: Butler’s words are printed alongside photographs from the artists Mirabelle Marden and Andrea Longacre-White. “Both of these artists’ work, and what I imagined were their intentions, reminded me of a world altered by grief,” she explains.

headline: Philippines: A Deadly Typhoon
abstract: A powerful storm cut through the Philippines on Wednesday morning, killing at least one person and sending more than 150,000 people into shelters, disaster response officials said.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm cut through the Philippines on Wednesday morning, killing at least one person and sending more than 150,000 people into shelters, disaster response officials said. Typhoon Rammasun caused landslides and flooding along its path from the central Philippines to the northern peninsula of Bataan, passing just south of the capital city, Manila. Government rescue teams were trying to reach remote areas south of Manila affected by the storm, which packed winds of 90 miles per hour and gusts to 115 miles an hour. The one confirmed fatality as of Wednesday morning involved a woman being hit by a falling electric pole, officials said. Last November, Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms on record, devastated the islands of Leyte and Samar on the east coast and killed more than 6,300 people.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Dutch court ruled on Wednesday that the government was liable for the deaths of about 300 victims of the 1995 Srebrenica massacre in Bosnia, Europe’s worst ethnically motivated mass murder since World War II, saying that a United Nations team of Dutch peacekeepers had failed to prevent those deaths.

headline: Gtech of Italy to Acquire Slot Machine Maker for $4.7 Billion
