lead_paragraph: Gtech, the operator of the Italian lottery, has agreed to acquire the slot machine maker International Game Technology of Las Vegas for $4.7 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Stalking the Shadow Universe
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Dark Matter (Astronomy)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: It has long been theorized that it is dark matter that provides the scaffolding for stars and galaxies. Now, scientists are using computer simulations to show us the universe we can’t see.
lead_paragraph: For centuries people have found meaning — or thought they did — in what they could see in the sky, the shapes of the constellations echoing old myths, the sudden feathery intrusion of comets, the regular dances of the planets, the chains of galaxies, spanning unfathomable distances of time and space.

headline: A Master of Illusion Endures
abstract: “Magic in the Moonlight,” about a 1920s stage magician, is Woody Allen’s first directorial release since he was confronted again with past personal accusations.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The cafe here on Westminster Street that was the location for a future Woody Allen movie looked like an elaborate stage illusion, surrounded by large screens that focused light into the restaurant, while also concealing any action within from onlookers outside.

headline: Kimpton Now Rewards How You Act, Not Just How Long You Stay
abstract: In the new Kimpton Karma Rewards program, guests receive points for stays–and just maybe for attending a hotel wine hour.
lead_paragraph: Hotel loyalty programs generally measure guests’ commitment by the frequency of their stays. But Kimpton Hotels aims to discern – and reward — true passion with its new Kimpton Karma Rewards program, beginning Wednesday.

headline: A Tiny Wire, and a Big Train Wreck
abstract: Investigators said that the crash, which killed 22 people in Moscow, was caused by the snapping of an improperly placed wire in a subway, three millimeters wide.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The snapping of one small, improperly installed wire caused a Moscow subway crash this week that killed 22 people, investigators said on Wednesday. The police arrested a senior track foreman and his assistant.

headline: Note to Cadres: Hands Off the Black Audi and Chauffeur
abstract: As part of its drive against corruption and waste, the Chinese Communist Party said it would stop allowing dedicated official vehicles for all but the highest-ranking government staff.
lead_paragraph: You can take away a Chinese official’s dignity, as frolicsome videos on the Internet show. You can take away, at least for a while, gluttony on the public purse, chandeliered offices and vacations abroad in the guise of inspection tours. But can you take away that ultimate perk of the respectable cadre — the black car with intimidatingly tinted windows, an equally intimidating medley of official insignia, passes and a faithful driver?

headline: Greek Fugitive Is Arrested in Athens Shootout
abstract: Nikos Maziotis, the self-professed leader of Revolutionary Struggle, resisted an inspection by the police, leading to an exchange of fire in a busy shopping district.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece’s most wanted terrorist, Nikos Maziotis, the self-professed leader of the leftist guerrilla group Revolutionary Struggle, was arrested on Wednesday after a shootout with the police in the middle of a busy shopping district and popular tourist spot in Athens.

headline: BlackRock Results Show a Shift Away From Stocks
abstract: With higher revenue from managing more money, BlackRock said its quarterly profit rose 11 percent, to $808 million.
lead_paragraph: With stock market indexes near record highs, investors committed more money to BlackRock in the second quarter, helping increase profit for the giant asset management firm.

headline: Morning Agenda: Murdoch Pursues Time Warner
abstract: 21st Century Fox is said to have offered $80 billion for Time Warner. | The danger of arbitration clauses. | Yahoo to retain more of its Alibaba stake after I.P.O. | Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase second-quarter earnings exceeded analyst expectations.
lead_paragraph: The media giant 21st Century Fox, the empire run by Rupert Murdoch, made an $80 billion takeover bid in recent weeks for Time Warner but was rebuffed, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced write in DealBook. The bold approach could put Time Warner in play and might again ignite a reshaping of the media industry, prompting a new spate of mega-mergers among the nation’s largest entertainment companies.

headline: Portugal Telecom and Brazil Phone Giant Revise Merger Terms
abstract: Portugal Telecom and Oi of Brazil have renegotiated the terms of their planned merger to salvage a deal threatened by the financing problems of the Espírito Santo group.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Portugal Telecom and Oi of Brazil said on Wednesday that they had renegotiated the terms of their planned merger to salvage a deal threatened by the financing problems of the Espírito Santo group, which is controlled by Portugal’s most powerful family.

headline: Tomas Maier Seeks an Entirely New Fashion Niche

We got onto the subject of “What happens next?” with his own brand. The topic isn’t so surprising, but part of the answer was.

headline: A Robot With a Little Humanity

lead_paragraph: As a graduate student at M.I.T. in the 1990s, Cynthia Breazeal studied with the roboticist Rodney Brooks and explored the idea of “social” robots that were designed to interact and collaborate with humans.

headline: Assad Begins a Third Term in Syria, Vowing to Look After Its People
abstract: During a closely scripted ceremony, President Bashar al-Assad swore on the Quran to respect the Constitution as he embarked on his third seven-year term as president of a country mired in a war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Feted by supporters, whom he hailed as the victors of his country’s brutal civil war, a triumphant President Bashar al-Assad was sworn in on Wednesday for a third seven-year term after an election that was widely seen as a gesture of calculated defiance toward the United States and others in the West and in the Arab world seeking his ouster.

headline: Pakistani Airstrikes Target Haven for Qaeda and Taliban Fighters
abstract: At least 35 people were killed, the military said, hours after locals reported that an American drone strike in the same area killed 20 others.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Pakistani fighter jets killed at least 35 people in attacks on militant bases in a remote part of the North Waziristan tribal district, the military said Wednesday, hours after local residents reported that an American drone strike in the same area had killed 20 people.

lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. GEORGE WASHINGTON — Fighter jets roared off an American aircraft carrier into a gray sky on Wednesday as the United States kicked off a joint naval exercise off the west coast of the Korean Peninsula, with the South Korean president, Park Geun-hye, calling for strong punishment if North Korea initiated a military provocation.

headline: What’s News in Washington: Boehner Moves Ahead With Plan to Sue Obama

lead_paragraph: A report out on Tuesday from the Violence Policy Center confirms yet again the lunacy of America’s loose gun policies.

lead_paragraph: I’ve differed with Time Magazine’s fine correspondent Michael Grunwald on the importance of the Keystone pipeline (Grunwald, me), but cheered him on earlier this week on Twitter after climate campaigners attacked him (Grunwald a “denier” and “polyanna”?) for challenging an overheated Guardian account of the impacts of rising sea levels on Miami (Grunwald’s home turf). (The Guardian story was an echo of a May feature in The Times.)

headline: Briarwood, Queens: A Quiet Refuge Bounded by Traffic
abstract: A neighborhood in central Queens with good subway service, relatively reasonably priced real estate and a strong sense of community.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood of Briarwood in central Queens borders the Kew Gardens interchange, one of the city’s most congested traffic hubs, but is home to residents who value a quiet, low-key way of life. With its single- and multifamily homes and large co-op and rental complexes, it is an affordable refuge for a diverse mix of middle-class New Yorkers.

headline: Roche Reports Mixed Results in Trial of an Alzheimer’s Drug
abstract: While the drug, crenezumab, did not slow progression of the disease over all, at the highest doses it seemed to delay a decline in mental ability in patients with mild Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: Roche, the pharmaceutical company, on Wednesday reported mixed results in its latest trial of an Alzheimer’s drug. It said that while the drug did not slow progression of the disease over all, at the highest doses it did seem to delay a decline in mental ability in patients with mild cases of Alzheimer’s.

You pick a bustling neighborhood thick with people, put your space near other businesses likely to attract the sort of people you think will appreciate your wares, fling open your doors and — voilà — retail Valhalla. You’ll be fighting them off at the door.

headline: Fauna, Flora and Freighters in the Danube Delta

headline: The Rise of Cafe Culture in New York
abstract: In 1964, there were only about 30 sidewalk cafes in the city, about half in Greenwich Village. Today there are over 1,000.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “Need for a Sidewalk Cafe Society” appeared on July 5 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Simplifying Measuring Medication for Children
abstract: Parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12 are often baffled by measuring options and confusing labels.
lead_paragraph: Parents trying to administer medicine to children younger than 12 are often baffled by such options for measuring as milliliters, milligrams, teaspoons, tablespoons and droppers. In A Spoonful of Medicine May Put Children at Risk Jan Hoffman describes new efforts by professional associations to persuade manufacturers and pharmacists to adopt a uniform unit for liquid medicines: the milliliter. She describes the mistakes in dosing made by parents grabbing kitchen spoons, confusing teaspoons and tablespoons, and misreading instructions. Of 287 parents interviewed shortly after they had finished giving medication to their children that had been prescribed at the emergency departments at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan and Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn, more than 40 percent of the parents had not measured correctly.

headline: 1964: Hostility Shown to Goldwater
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: the world press condemned Senator Goldwater’s presidential nomination in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The world reacted emphatically to Barry Goldwater today and most of the reaction was hostile. From London to Paris to Bonn to Moscow, commentators denounced the Arizona senator as a reactionary and a cold-warmonger. Only in Madrid and Johannesburg and a few other cities were voices of approval raised as the news flashed around the world of the senator’s nomination as the Republican presidential candidate. In London, the pro-Labor mass-circulation “Daily Mirror” said: “The corpse of much that is decent and wise and tolerant in American society is in the coffin, although the lid has not yet finally been screwed down.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 17, 1964

headline: Brazilian Private Equity Firm Near Closing on $1 Billion Fund

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The investment firm Gávea Investments, founded by the former Brazilian Central Bank president Arminio Fraga and Luiz Henrique Fraga in 2003, is near final closing on a new private equity fund that could exceed $1 billion, two people familiar with its plans said.

headline: Small Businesses Are Finding Bank Loans Easier to Come By
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Small Business', 'Credit and Debt', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Some small-business owners don’t think they can qualify for a loan. But they would be surprised by how eager some banks are to lend.
lead_paragraph: Jake Fitzsimmons opened his first Stuft Burger Bar in Fort Collins, Colo., in 2010, after the worst recession in decades. It turned out to be an excellent time to open a burger joint — Coloradans were downsizing their dinners out — but a terrible time to apply for a loan.

lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — Bernard Darwin, Charles Darwin’s grandson and a Hall of Fame golf correspondent, wrote long ago, “Hoylake, blown upon by mighty winds, breeder of mighty champions.”

headline: Stir-fried Rice With Amaranth or Red Chard and Thai Basil
abstract: This is another Thai-influenced dish, spiced with sriracha and featuring the beautiful green vegetable amaranth.
lead_paragraph: Amaranth is a beautiful green with small red and green leaves that grow, bush-like, off medium-thick stems. I get it from Asian vendors at the farmers’ market, where I can also find Thai basil. I cut away the very tough ends but use the more tender parts of the stalks. A good substitute here would be red chard, whose stems can be diced and included in the stir-fry. You could also use beet greens, but I’d omit the stringy stems. I spiced this Thai-influenced stir-fry with sriracha, but that spicy chili sauce is optional.

headline: Stir-Fried Turkey Breast With Snap or Snow Peas and Chard
abstract: Turkey cutlets are easy to prep and cook quickly, and young snap peas can be almost as tender as the more traditional snow peas for stir-fries
lead_paragraph: Shopping for ingredients for this week’s recipes in my farmers’ market, I found young, tender snap peas that were almost as delicate as snow peas. I had part of a bunch of Swiss chard and used both vegetables. I like using turkey breast cutlets in stir-fries; they’ve already been cut to a uniform thickness, so all you need to do is slice them across the grain to get even pieces that cook in minutes.

headline: Paul Gibson Jr., New York City’s First Black Deputy Mayor, Is Dead at 86
abstract: Mr. Gibson, a lawyer and vice president of American Airlines, was the deputy mayor for planning under Mayor Abraham D. Beame.
lead_paragraph: Paul Gibson Jr., a lawyer and an airline executive who in 1974 became New York City’s first black deputy mayor, died on July 11 at his home in Jamaica, Queens. He was 86.

headline: Money Alone Won’t Secure Time Warner for Murdoch
abstract: To win the battle for Time Warner, Rupert Murdoch will need to consider converting 21st Century Fox into a one-vote, one-share company, Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch has one last big takeover left in him. Time Warner makes the perfect swan song for the 83-year-old media mogul. The HBO-to-Looney Tunes conglomerate sits at the top of a pyramid where content is king, has no controlling shareholder and poses few insurmountable antitrust hurdles for 21st Century Fox. But winning will not just be a matter of price.

headline: Changyuraptor, Large Species of Flying Dinosaur, Is Discovered
abstract: The microraptor was four feet long and weighed about nine pounds — by far the largest such dinosaur that lived about 125 million years ago.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered a large species of flying “four-winged” dinosaur that may have relied on a long, feathery tail to prevent crash landings.

headline: Randall Stout, Architect Tied to Nature, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Stout explored the relationship between architecture and energy in holistic designs that were no less sculptural and humane for being ecologically responsible.

headline: Analyzing Next Steps, Airbus Chief Is Closely Watching Google and Facebook
abstract: Thomas Enders admires the speed and innovation achieved by American high-tech giants — and may even see them as future partners.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thomas Enders, the chief executive of the Airbus Group, has not been shy in his public admiration for the speed and scale of innovation that has been achieved by American high-technology giants like Google, Facebook and SpaceX. But it is only recently that he has begun to consider such companies potential future aerospace partners.

headline: Marvel Will Introduce a Female Thor This Fall
abstract: A female hero will take up the hammer Mjolnir, along with its powers, in a series called “Thor, God of Thunder.”
lead_paragraph: Marvel Comics revealed on Tuesday that Thor, the God of Thunder and the son of the Norse god Odin, will be replaced by a woman. The character, who Marvel has revealed few details about, will star in “Thor, God of Thunder,” a new series that begins in October, written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Russell Dauterman.

headline: An Apartment as Co-Star
abstract: Of course, “Between Riverside and Crazy” is by Stephen Adly Guirgis, a playwright whose distinctive style extends to his titles.
lead_paragraph: Of course, “Between Riverside and Crazy” is by Stephen Adly Guirgis, a playwright whose distinctive style extends to his titles. Longtime admirers of this wistfully poetic writer know that he favors references to places in New York or New Jersey (“Our Lady of 121st Street,” “The Little Flower of East Orange”), hard consonant sounds (“The _______ With the Hat”) and a sense of careening movement (“Jesus Hopped the ‘A’ Train”).

All six have been approved for transfer for more than four years.

headline: Whisky, Summer Style
abstract: Shaken up with sweet, complementary summertime flavors and served on the rocks, sultry Scotch becomes warm-weather appropriate.
lead_paragraph: Scotch whisky might not seem like a natural fit for lighter summer cocktails. The adjectives you hear applied to these whiskies — peaty, earthy, even mediciney — may not immediately suggest beach-ready drinks. But in fact the smokiness or salinity of Scotch whiskies is the very reason they can do so well in citrus-infused drinks with a bit of sugar: they stand up to the sweetness. And just as the complex layers of flavors and aromas of straight whisky open up when you add water, they also sing when combined with the ingredients in these three warm-weather Scotch drinks, created by bartenders from Glasgow, New York City and Los Angeles.

headline: A Westerner’s Inside View of Alibaba Successes and Failures

lead_paragraph: After studying Chinese in the early 1990s and hosting a travel show on state-run television in China, Porter Erisman went to work for a public relations firm. Then, during the dot-com boom in 2000, he joined a tiny, Chinese Internet start-up called Alibaba.

headline: Should Janet Yellen Be Giving Us Stock Picks?
abstract: The Federal Reserve chairwoman has raised questions by using her bully pulpit to send a message on market prices.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen years ago, when Alan Greenspan wanted to send a message that he worried the stock market was getting a little bubbly, he did it with a typically inscrutable phrasing buried in an otherwise unremarkable speech.

headline: Classical Playlist: Schumann, Mozart, Brahms and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: WORKS BY SCHUMANN AND JANACEKMarc-André Hamelin, pianist(Hyperion)The pianist Marc-André Hamelin brings commanding technique, elegant musicianship and imagination to a program of suites about, variously, rural life, nature and children. Janacek’s “On the Overgrown Path,” Book I is a 30-minute compilation of mood pieces, character pieces and short works inspired by folk music. Mr. Hamelin searches out the strangeness in the music while conveying the character. He gives a beguiling, lively account of Schumann’s overlooked “Waldszenen” (“Forest Scenes”) and brings freshness and distinction to his familiar “Kinderszenen” (“Scenes of Childhood”). (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Today in Small Business: Same-Day Delivery
abstract: A customer-service call goes viral. Do you know the true cost of a cheeseburger? Do corporations have any social responsibility beyond making profits?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Is Truvada, the Pill to Prevent H.I.V., 99 Percent Effective? Don’t Be So Sure
abstract: Experts disagree about using such a high and specific estimate for the level of protection, even as they celebrate the drug’s promise.
lead_paragraph: Truvada, the once-a-day pill to help keep people from contracting H.I.V., is on the cover of this week’s New York magazine, and Tim Murphy’s cover story focuses on how the pill is changing sex by drastically reducing gay men’s fear of infection.

headline: The Moderate Revolution in Kansas
abstract: The center is fighting back against Gov. Sam Brownback’s extremism.
lead_paragraph: A surprising political revolt is now brewing in Kansas, one that could provide a model for breaking the stranglehold of the hard right on the Republican Party — if enough people join in.

headline: Are Banks Fighting Over Your Business?
abstract: At banks across the country, small-business lending is up, if not exactly back to where it was seven or eight years ago.
lead_paragraph: In an article we just published, Jake Fitzsimmons describes how last fall he and his partner induced four banks to compete for the opportunity to loan them money. Mr. Fitzsimmons co-owns Stuft Burger Bar, which was making plans to open its third restaurant in northern Colorado. “We went into it at the front and said we’re going to take the best initial opportunity,” Mr. Fitzsimmons said. “Our hope with that was that they would give us their best offer originally, knowing that we were looking at other banks.” In the end, three of the four banks came back with bids.

headline: Weather May Not Affect Back Pain
abstract: Many people think the weather affects their back pain, but a new study shows they are probably wrong.
lead_paragraph: Many people think the weather affects their back pain, but a new study shows they are probably wrong.

headline: Yellen Says Restraining the Fed’s Oversight Would Be a ‘Grave Mistake’
abstract: Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, testified that a Republican proposal would undermine the central bank’s independence in monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, said on Wednesday that it would be a “grave mistake” for Congress to adopt legislation proposed by House Republicans constraining the Fed’s management of monetary policy.

headline: Witness Accounts of Gaza Attack That Killed 4 Boys
abstract: Foreign correspondents reporting from the Gaza Strip provided detailed accounts of a deadly attack that killed four children on a beach.
lead_paragraph: Foreign correspondents reporting from Gaza on Wednesday offered visceral accounts of a deadly attack that killed four children on the beach outside a hotel in which the journalists were staying. Tyler Hicks, a New York Times photographer, was among those who rushed from the hotel to the beach as a desperate scramble unfolded to save the lives of other children wounded in the shelling.

headline: Easy Ways to Get More Vegetables on the Table, More Often
abstract: Lots of different types of vegetables and beans can fill a taco, be the excuse for a soup, or top a big bowl.
lead_paragraph: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. Last week, Renee did her first stir-fry, based on last week’s advice and a recipe like those found here.Hello Martha,

headline: Sweet and Sour Stir-Fried Radishes With Their Greens
abstract: The bitterness of radish greens pairs wells with a sweet-and-sour sauce in this stir-fry.
lead_paragraph: We always toss out radish greens, but we shouldn’t. They are as nutritious as any green, and they have a pleasantly bitter flavor that is very much like that of turnip greens, which are a close relative. The bitterness works very well against a sweet and sour stir-fry sauce. The radishes should be barely cooked. This is a great dish for large, colorful breakfast radishes. The big bunches I get at my farmers’ market weigh a pound, sometimes a little more. Use 2 bunches if yours are smaller.

headline: Some Top Money Managers Push for Fed to Start Raising Interest Rates

lead_paragraph: The Fed is out of step with Wall Street, say some of the country’s wealthiest investors.

lead_paragraph: I WOULD bet that more than once over the last several weeks you have forgotten to put sunscreen on before you went outside, even though we all know the dangers of getting too much sun. As in so many situations, your smartphone can come to the rescue, with sunshine prediction and advice apps.

headline: Gene Therapy Is Used to Adjust Pigs’ Heartbeat
abstract: The technique, in which a gene is injected into the heart to reprogram cells, may one day be an alternative to electronic pacemakers, researchers say.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Loses 4 Performers

lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:44 p.m. | Not many comedians will know what it is like to be a cast member of “Saturday Night Live”; at least Brooks Wheelan, John Milhiser and Noël Wells can say they were part of that NBC late-night comedy franchise for one year. But all three of those featured performers who joined “SNL” in last fall – a season that began with Tina Fey poking fun at the dispensability of the show’s rookie players – are now gone.

headline: Boys Drawn to Gaza Beach, and Into Center of Mideast Strife
abstract: Two explosions struck an area that had been considered relatively safe from the intense Israeli bombing campaign.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — The four Bakr boys were young cousins, the children of Gaza fishermen who had ordered them to stay indoors — and especially away from the beach. But cooped up for nine days during Israeli bombardments, the children defied their parents and went out Wednesday afternoon, the eldest shooing away his little brother, telling him it was too dangerous.

headline: Reform Conservatism and Foreign Policy

abstract: Does it have one? Does it need one?
lead_paragraph: The recent dust-up between Rand Paul and Rick Perry (among other Paul critics) makes for a good occasion to add another entry to my series on critiques of reform conservatism — this time, responding to the suggestion that our movement either doesn’t offer any foreign policy ideas, or else is shackled to the carcass of Bush-era neoconservatism. The former critique is, in a way, complimentary, a testament to our tendency’s newfound influence (“first they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then they demand that you supply a foreign policy agenda as well …”); the latter strikes me as mostly ill-founded but somewhat understandable. Here’s Andrew Sullivan making both at once:

headline: Did a Headline on Germany’s ‘Global Might’ Go Too Far?
abstract: Some German readers protest a World Cup headline.
lead_paragraph: When Germany won the World Cup earlier this week, not just the sports pages of The Times took note. The news pages featured a story on the joyful mood in Germany, but the headline bothered some German readers, who said it played into offensive stereotypes. It read: “Germans See World Cup Win as Symbol of Global Might.”

headline: Mystery Solved on Names and Money Behind Thad Cochran Ads

headline: Lena Dunham’s Book Tour Is a Hot Ticket

headline: The Trials of Graham Spanier, Penn State’s Ousted President
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Football (College)', 'Football', 'College Athletics']
abstract: For 16 years, Spanier oversaw the school’s growth from remote outpost of American higher education to top-tier public university. Now he is facing felony charges. How much should anyone pay for a sin of omission?
lead_paragraph: On the day the police arrived at the home of Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State assistant football coach, to arrest him on multiple counts of child sexual abuse, Graham Spanier was beginning his 17th year as Penn State’s president. It was an extraordinary tenure, and one that had seemed most likely to continue for many more years. A man of ceaseless energy and considerable ego, Spanier led the university as it grew from a remote outpost of American higher education into a top-tier public university.

headline: Euro Comes Back Into Investor Favor
abstract: The European Central Bank said there were signs the currency was becoming more popular for issuing debt and conducting international transactions.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The euro appears to be regaining favor with international investors.

headline: Apple Could Pay $400 Million in E-Books Price-Fixing Case

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has decided to reopen an electronic eavesdropping post in Cuba that it closed more than a decade ago, reaching out for a onetime symbol of its global superpower status, Russian officials and newspaper reports said on Wednesday.

headline: The Big Electoral Consequences of Splitting California Six Ways

headline: Bank of America Still Struggles to Churn Out Solid Earnings
abstract: Bank of America will have to find a lot more in earnings or do even more cost-cutting to increase its return on equity, Antony Curries writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is stuck in a low-profitability trap. Several businesses at the bank actually put in a good showing for the second quarter. The trouble is, Bank of America as a whole is still struggling to churn out solid earnings – even after aggressive cost-cutting.

headline: South Africa Cycling, With Cultural Side Trips
abstract: The new tour Cycling South Africa: Cape Town and the Garden Route takes riders to Table Mountain and also includes a visit with a traditional healer.
lead_paragraph: VBT Bicycling and Walking Vacations’ new tour, Cycling South Africa: Cape Town and the Garden Route, includes more than sightseeing.

headline: Dusting Off the 2-Iron and Bracing for the Links
abstract: To keep shots below the wind and out of pothole bunkers, golfers often prefer 2-irons instead of drivers off the tee at a links course like Royal Liverpool, home of this year’s British Open.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — Players take great care setting the table for the British Open, a formal — and for many, foreign — event. For this one week, many will take out and polish off a club that, like a salad fork, is reserved for special occasions. It is the 2-iron, the nearest thing the golfers have in their bag to a repellent for the British links courses’ biggest pest, the pothole bunker.

headline: Game of Thorns
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Women and Girls', 'Hair']
abstract: How to wear blooms in your hair without looking like a bridesmaid or a flower child.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, when Jasmin Larian was 21 and a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology, she started making silk floral crowns in her spare time for herself and her friends to wear out on the town. Her designs were modest — white and pink roses on a simple wire frame — but they sparked immediate reactions from strangers.

headline: Republicans and Democrats Agree, the C.D.C. Was Incredibly Sloppy
abstract: Researchers mishandled dangerous pathogens.
lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats in the strife-ridden House of Representatives miraculously found common ground at a hearing today. The subject: the sloppiness of researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in mishandling dangerous pathogens and sending them out to other laboratories without completely inactivating them. The universal response: dismay and incredulity.

headline: Refugee From Sitcom Land, Guzzling a Bile Cocktail
abstract: A sitcom is central to the plot of “Enter at Forest Lawn,” by a former executive producer for “Two and a Half Men.”
lead_paragraph: For seven seasons, the writer Mark Roberts served as an executive producer on “Two and a Half Men.” Apparently, this has made him angry. Dangerously angry. Batten-down-the-hatches, threat-level-red, oh-God-I-think-he-might-actually-stroke-out angry.

headline: Raising Stakes on Russia, U.S. Adds Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama imposed a new round of sanctions against Russia on Wednesday, targeting some of the crown jewels of the country’s financial, energy and defense industries in what officials described as the most punishing measures taken to date by the United States in retaliation for Moscow’s intervention in Ukraine.

headline: Sia Scores Her First No. 1 Album

lead_paragraph: Sia Furler, the Australian-born musician who writes monster hits for Rihanna and Beyoncé yet has had an uneasy relationship with fame in her solo career, has scored her first No. 1 album.

headline: And You Thought Your Teenage Years Were Tough
abstract: In “Those Who Wish Me Dead,” a new Michael Koryta thriller with a fiery backdrop, a boy is on the run after witnessing a murder.
lead_paragraph: What a difference four years make. The summer of 2010 brought Michael Koryta’s “So Cold the River,” a long, spooky, overplotted book that featured haunted mineral water and a hotel that brought “The Shining” to mind. The summer of 2014 brings “Those Who Wish Me Dead,” a lean, propulsive action-adventure thriller with a raging forest fire as its backdrop and with much more finesse than that description might suggest. The ingenious tricks and conversational wit of “Those Who Wish Me Dead” don’t usually come with this territory.

headline: S.U.V.s and Crossovers Eclipse Sedans in Popularity
abstract: A new report from IHS Automotive says that, for the first time, sedans are no long No. 1 in new car registrations.
lead_paragraph: Americans don’t seem to like station wagons much, but their slightly trucklike counterparts — sport utility vehicles and crossovers — have swelled in popularity over the last few years.

headline: E.U. Meets to Consider More Sanctions on Russia
abstract: European Union leaders are under pressure to strengthen their response to Russia over Ukraine and choose the bloc’s next foreign policy chief.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders met here on Wednesday under pressure to strengthen their response to Russia after the latest spasm of violence in Ukraine and to overcome divisions about who should become the bloc’s next foreign policy chief.

headline: California Death Penalty System Is Unconstitutional, Federal Judge Rules
abstract: The sense of uncertainty and delay within the system, the judge wrote, “violates the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.”
lead_paragraph: LA QUINTA, Calif. — A federal judge ruled Wednesday that California’s death penalty system is so arbitrary and plagued with delay that it is unconstitutional, a decision that is expected to inspire similar arguments in death penalty appeals around the country.

headline: Refusing to Quit, American Is Surrounded by Cheers After a Lonely Finish
abstract: Andrew Talansky crossed the finish line of Wednesday's Tour de France stage more than 32 minutes after the stage winner, Tony Gallopin, to cheers from fans who, like Talansky, decided to stick it out.
lead_paragraph: OYONNAX, France — The American rider Andrew Talansky’s hopes of winning the Tour de France effectively vanished after two crashes last week. But he became another kind of cycling hero Wednesday: the rider who would not quit when he probably should have.

headline: Emergency Routine in Israel: 30 Seconds to Run for Cover
abstract: The day-to-day life of residents of a seaside town is punctuated by sirens and rocket fire from Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: ASHKELON, Israel — The usual crowd had gathered behind the police cordons after a rocket struck the yard of a house in this seaside town in southern Israel on Wednesday: police officers, a bomb disposal squad, neighbors, municipal social workers, reporters and television crews.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Piece of My Heart’
abstract: A scene from the number “I Want Candy” from the musical “Piece of My Heart,” about the songwriter Bert Berns.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the number “I Want Candy” from the musical “Piece of My Heart,” about the songwriter Bert Berns.

headline: Many-Hit Wonder, Out of Obscurity
abstract: Bert Berns, a top songwriter and producer who died young and largely unknown, is the focus of a biography, a musical and a planned documentary.
lead_paragraph: Even in his mid-1960s heyday, Bert Berns was barely known beyond the obsessives who studied songwriters’ and producers’ credits on 45 r.p.m. records and LP album jackets. And then, after his death in 1967 at the age of 38, something truly odd happened: Though the songs he wrote and produced, like “Twist and Shout” and “Hang On Sloopy,” proved to have durability, growing in stature and popularity as the years passed, Berns’s own reputation receded even further into obscurity.

headline: The Lake Is Frozen in Time
abstract: Returning to New York after nine years, the Bolshoi Ballet is presenting three works at the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: Returning to New York after nine years, the Bolshoi Ballet — the most heroically warm-blooded of ballet companies — seems keen to prove that it has reverted to the ghastly artistic torpor it enjoyed in the last two decades of the Soviet era. For a short time this century (thanks principally to the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, who was for a few years its artistic director), this flagship company became an important center of new choreography and home to major revivals that changed Russia’s and the world’s view of dance history. But the three productions that it’s showing as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, all deriving from an earlier era, have been seen here before — a lot — and none of them are good.

headline: My Gigolo Is Waiting (He’s Much More Fun)
abstract: Domestic doldrums are front and center in the shows “Satisfaction” and “Married,” and an odd couple takes shape on “You’re the Worst.”
lead_paragraph: Looking at someone else’s marriage is a bit like hearing about someone else’s dream — unless something truly awful happened, it’s kind of a bore.

headline: Making Discreet House Calls for the Rich and Mortified
abstract: In the USA series “Rush,” a doctor makes cash-only visits to clients who beat their girlfriends, sustain embarrassing sex injuries or suffer health crises that require discretion.
lead_paragraph: College students eager to study something that could actually secure them a job after graduation might consider majoring in fixing. Fixers — people who make the mistakes of rich and famous idiots go away — are popping up regularly on scripted television these days, which presumably means they’re in demand in real life as well.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: 3 Things to Know About Niacin and Heart Health
abstract: New studies are adding to concerns about the safety and effectiveness of niacin, a popular drug for the prevention of cardiovascular disease.
lead_paragraph: Recent studies published in The New England Journal of Medicine are adding to concerns about the safety and effectiveness of niacin, a popular drug for the prevention of cardiovascular disease. The studies reveal that although this B vitamin can reduce triglyceride levels, raise “good” cholesterol levels (HDL) and reduce “bad” cholesterol levels (LDL), it does not produce the benefits that patients and their doctors might expect. And the studies are revealing serious harms. Here are three things you need to know about niacin.

headline: Clad in Shorter Skirts, the Better to Let Loose

headline: On the Trail of ‘True Grit’: A Tale Comes to Life
abstract: Finding new admiration for the novel and its author on a journey across Arkansas and Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: On a January night in Fort Smith, Ark., on a desolate block off the main drag of Garrison Avenue, I was having a nightcap of Knob Creek on the rocks at Doe’s Eat Place, after consuming two tamales with chili, a three-inch-thick eight-ounce filet and a couple of glasses of cabernet sauvignon. The motley collection of sports and historical memorabilia hanging on the walls cultivated a divey atmosphere consistent across Doe’s eight Southern locations.

headline: Easily Encrypt Your Email

lead_paragraph: Molly Wood explains how you can use several tools to encrypt your email and lock down your communications.

headline: Despite Security Breach, eBay Posts Profit and Sees Steady Growth

headline: This Is the Best Anti-Superhero Movie of the Summer
abstract: For many, the horrific inequality in the world of “Snowpiercer” carries a lesson about our own.
lead_paragraph: Bong Joon-ho’s “Snowpiercer” takes place on a train carrying the survivors of a human-engineered disaster that has frozen the earth. While the poor are forced to cram into tight quarters and eat disgusting “protein blocks,” the rich eat sushi or sit knitting in an orange orchard. The setup has inspired comparisons to our pre-apocalyptic world — but just what “Snowpiercer” says about that world is a matter of some debate. (Be warned: Spoilers follow.)

headline: A Smartphone for Consumers Who Want Privacy

headline: Hounded by Reality, Staging a Fairy Tale

headline: Debt Shall Have No Dominion
abstract: The death of the debt spiral.
lead_paragraph: Update: Douglas Elmendorf, director of the CBO, emails me to point out that there is (and it says so in the report) a tilt to nominal growth and interest rates, so that growth exceeds interest for the first decade but falls below it thereafter. This means that there is a bit of a debt spiral post 2025 or so. But it’s still nothing like the rhetoric.

headline: Old Friend, New Collections
abstract: Buddy Warren, a psychologist-turned-decorator, has a new design shop on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: No question, Buddy Warren’s first Manhattan antiques store, Cranberry Hole Road, was an original. It had a coffee bar downstairs and a place for Mr. Warren to conduct family therapy sessions upstairs. That boutique closed in 2004, but the psychologist-turned-interior-decorator-and-licensed-contractor is back with another retail adventure. His new self-named shop (left photo) sits in a 19th-century building on the Lower East Side that began life as a barn. About a third of the items are Mr. Warren’s own concoctions, like an iron cage table with a base sliced from an 18th-century marble column and a glass top ($950, seen in right photo). The rest ranges from cleansing bars made by a New Hampshire beekeeper ($6) to authentic Windsor chairs ($14,000 for a set of eight). Coffee is still served, but upstairs is now for workshops on themes like organization. 171 Chrystie Street (Rivington Street). Information: 212-727-8400 or buddywarren.com.

It’s also a time to think about a system that doesn’t do all it can to protect those pilots and passengers. Flying in small private planes is far riskier than flying in commercial aircraft.

lead_paragraph: Lining both sides of the Avenida Álvaro Obregón, a main artery in the Roma Norte neighborhood of Mexico City, are the remnants of a strong European influence — so strong that many of the old buildings survived the 1985 earthquake, while more-modern structures crumbled. Today, converted pastel-colored houses dating from the early 1900s contain restaurants, boutiques and popular mezcal bars. Camila Sarasola Montiel often wanders through the sculpture garden that divides the main avenue, drawing style inspiration from the mix of old and new. This interview has been edited. FRITZIE ANDRADE

The actress, Shannon Guess Richardson, 35, pleaded guilty to possession of a toxin for use as a weapon. Prosecutors said Ms. Richardson placed ricin onto letters sent to Mr. Obama, Mr. Bloomberg and Mark Glaze, at the time the director of Mayors Against Illegal Guns. Ms. Richardson, who played a zombie on “The Walking Dead,” among other small roles, had falsely accused her husband of mailing the letters.

headline: The Weird, Scary and Ingenious Brain of Maria Bamford
abstract: America’s most vulnerable comedian jokes about O.C.D., psych wards, even suicide. Somehow it’s all very funny.
lead_paragraph: Maria Bamford has a mantra of sorts, and here it is: Do the work. Three words, three syllables. An easy, orderly thing. She tells it to herself when she wakes up in the morning, whether it’s at her bungalow in a middle-class neighborhood on the outskirts of Los Angeles or at a Holiday Inn in Boston or a Marriott in Bloomington, or any of the other highway-side hotels she hits for one night before moving on. Do the work. It’s a stay against paralysis, against the descent of dread. It’s less dramatic than “seize the day!” more affirming than “stop overthinking everything!” It is functional, and that’s what she’s trying to be. Do the work. She repeats it on airplanes, in taxis, on the long walks she takes to calm her nerves before a show. Sometimes she amends it to: Just do the work, the “just” a reminder that she’s not, after all, performing surgery on babies. There’s another, more refined version, too. Do your bits, she’ll tell herself, resigned to the idea that this may always be a struggle. Just do your bits.

abstract: Videre Licet, a new collection from Stefan Lawrence and Daniele Albright, is launching in conjunction with a sweeping new space for Lawrence’s contemporary showroom, Twentieth.
lead_paragraph: President Obama sits behind a custom walnut desk of their design in his private study, and François-Henri Pinault and Salma Hayek’s Paris apartment is illuminated by their light boxes, but until now, the design partnership of Daniele Albright and Stefan Lawrence fell under the auspices of Twentieth, Lawrence’s contemporary furniture showroom in Los Angeles. Now, the longtime collaborators have launched Videre Licet (Latin for “to be able to see”), a new line of furniture and lighting, in conjunction with Twentieth’s sweeping new space on Beverly Boulevard. Designed using contemporary technologies but crafted entirely by hand — and priced accordingly, in the $20,000 range — the collection is daring, glamorous and a touch tongue-in-cheek, with sly references to Hollywood, modernism and the ’70s.

headline: Understanding the Crank Epidemic
abstract: Addicted to fake inflation stories.
lead_paragraph: James Pethokoukis and Ramesh Ponnuru are frustrated. They’ve been trying to convert Republicans to market monetarism, but the right’s favorite intellectuals keep turning to cranks peddling conspiracy theories about inflation. Three years ago it was Niall Ferguson, citing a bogus source. Ferguson was widely ridiculed, by moderate conservatives as well as liberals — but here comes Amity Shlaes, making the same argument and citing the same source. The “reform conservatives” have made no headway at all.

abstract: AXS Folk Technology and Objects Without Meaning offer inventive new takes on the laid-back California look.
lead_paragraph: Left coasters may have long since ceased to worry about being underdressed, but from a factory nestled under the 10 freeway in Los Angeles, two labels are reinventing what it can look like to be comfortable in your own clothes. “California is about the idea of adventure and freedom,” says the designer Kyle Ng, who grew up near Berkeley with a rock-climbing father who planted flags all over Yosemite. Ng’s men’s wear line AXS Folk Technology, which debuted two seasons ago, draws on the state’s pioneer spirit as well as the practical demands of communing with nature: “For me, the idea of quality comes from the sense that you can do anything in it,” Ng says, “that your clothes won’t break.”

headline: 1939: Actor Dies, but His Voice Lives On

But the voice of Georges Dorival will be heard by many hundreds of Parisians each day for many years. For he dictated phonograph records, which automatically announce the time of the day to the subscriber on dialing the Observatory. His voice also replies to the caller when there is change of number, announcing in measured tones, ‘‘Le numéro de votre correspondant est changée.’’— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 18, 1939

headline: Goodbye to Cloth Diapers, and Ideal Motherhood
abstract: Those washable diapers were part and parcel of the vision I had of myself as a woman and a mother. And when I gave them up, I didn’t know who I was any more.
lead_paragraph: I cloth diapered my daughter until she was 2, and she began using the toilet. And when I had my son, I was determined to continue. After all, I loved cloth diapering. headline: The Challenges of Empire
keywords: ['International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: On foreign policy blueprints and the questions they can’t always answer.
lead_paragraph: As a supplement to my last post, which ended by discussing some of the difficulties inherent in devising a point-by-point foreign policy agenda – difficulties that the horrific news from Ukraine throw into sharp relief – let me quote from a new essay from The American Conservative’s editor, Daniel McCarthy, on the subject of “liberalism and empire” and (he argues) the dependence of the former on the latter. The essay as a whole is an extended discussion of our current end-of-history era, engaged with some of the same questions as Mark Lilla, Steven Pinker, and other writers frequently discussed in this space. But its conclusion speaks directly to the moment’s foreign policy debates, offering critiques of both the anti-imperial left and the interventionist right, qualified sympathy for what McCarthy calls “anti-liberal anti-imperialists” (like his magazine’s founder, Pat Buchanan, and the late George Kennan, who are “among our greatest critics” but “preach what a liberal nation will not hear”), before coming around to a qualified endorsement of a “conservative realism” in the service of a liberal empire:

headline: Young’uns With a Yen for Wisdom
abstract: “Pump Boys and Dinettes,” a jubilant yet plaintive musical revue at City Center, is set in a filling station and coffee shop in the rural South.
lead_paragraph: A little strip of lonesome highway has plopped down at City Center, where a flavorsome revival of the chicken-fried musical revue “Pump Boys and Dinettes” plays through Saturday as part of the Encores! Off-Center series. Should you pull off the road for a fill-up, a Coke and a piece of pie, you’ll find amiable company in the show’s beaming cast members, who make like a big old human jukebox as they sing of the daily grind in a gas station (the pump boys) and the roadside coffee shop nearby (the dinettes).

headline: For-Profit Colleges Under Investigation
abstract: Well-paid lobbyists are telling Washington that the for-profit educational sector is fine as is. But that’s far from true.
lead_paragraph: It seemed until recently that regulators and law enforcement agencies would never rein in the predatory for-profit colleges that enrich themselves and their shareholders by misrepresenting their programs, saddling students with high-cost loans and then shoving them out the door with useless degrees or no degrees at all. The situation began to change in 2011, when a group of state attorneys general led by Jack Conway of Kentucky joined forces to investigate a growing number of complaints from students who had been exploited. With so much happening at the state level — 36 attorneys general are now involved — federal agencies had no choice but to take notice.

headline: Flaws in How Mississippi Reports Elections Add to Its Problems

lead_paragraph: Amid the allegations of fraud and the legal wranglings over the Mississippi Republican primary and runoff elections last month, one thing is clear: The lack of timely, useful election results has not helped assure citizens the election was fair.

headline: With Surge in Child Migrants, New York Forms Task Force on Aiding Them
abstract: Opposition to sheltering a wave of young migrants has mounted in many communities across the country, but in New York City, the reaction has been different.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials have formed a task force in response to the surging population of unaccompanied migrant children from Central America who have arrived in the city in recent months and swamped community-based groups in search of help for their deportation cases, health issues, school enrollment and other urgent needs.

lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — The women’s gymnastics coach at Alabama, Sarah Patterson, used to run into Pat Summitt, the storied former women’s basketball coach at Tennessee, at Southeastern Conference events.

lead_paragraph: Finland has staked much of its national pride on the worldwide growth of Nokia, based on the outskirts of Helsinki. And many Finns still hold a lot of affection for the company’s handsets.

headline: Should Republicans Do Anything About the Border Crisis?
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A response to the conservative case for immigration inaction.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t commented on the border situation since my column a few weeks ago, mostly because it’s the kind of situation (there are so many these days) where it’s easier to say what should have been done in the past than to figure out what the correct policy course is right now. But as House Republicans debate what kind of legislative response they intend to support, I want to say something briefly about the argument that they shouldn’t back any response at all, on the theory that since the president has already claimed sweeping, dubiously-legal powers over spending flows and immigration enforcement, fixing the mess should be his responsibility alone.

headline: The String of ‘Safest Airline Years’ Is Over
abstract: The years 2012 and 2013 were the the safest for worldwide flights since World War II. This year will not be, but is still likely to be among the safest.
lead_paragraph: The year 2012 was the safest since World War II for air travel, and 2013 was even better. Because of the two Malaysian Airlines crashes — including the airline that went down Thursday over Ukraine — this year will not be the safest on record. But it is less of an outlier than many might expect.

headline: James Franco, Poet
abstract: For all his inclination to wander among callings, James Franco’s interest in poetry is genuine.
lead_paragraph: If you were alive in 1985 and happened to buy Eddie Murphy’s album “How Could It Be” (featuring the hit single “Party All the Time”), then you may have asked yourself — in addition to wondering what shape of Band-Aid is best suited to the human ear — why it is that artists who are vastly successful in one genre feel the need to dabble in another. Because they do, a lot. Sometimes it’s just the case that they happen to be very good at more than one thing (by all accounts, Steve Martin is a genuinely excellent banjo player). But often there seems to be something else going on.

headline: Scientists Name a Newly Discovered Water Mite After Jennifer Lopez
abstract: The researches said they chose the name, Litarachna lopezae, because Ms. Lopez’s music kept the team in a good mood.
lead_paragraph: Scientists who discover new things – from microorganisms to galaxies – get to name them, and often they name them after public figures, usually ones they admire. Arnold Schwarzenegger has a muscular-looking beetle named after him; there are trilobites (an extinct, prehistoric arthropod) named for Mick Jagger and each of the Sex Pistols; and Frank Zappa has at least five animals named for him, including a jellyfish and a spider.

headline: Malaysia Airlines Flight: History's Lessons in Crisis Management
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'International Relations']
abstract: In 1962, President Kennedy offered a primer in how to prevent an episode involving an airplane from escalating into conflagration.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 27, 1962, at the zenith of the Cuban missile crisis, President Kennedy learned that an American U-2 spy plane had unintentionally penetrated Soviet air space near Alaska, drawing a complaint from the Soviets. He was concerned that the Soviet leader, Nikita Khrushchev, or those around him, might view the incursion as the deliberate forerunner of a full-scale United States invasion of his territory, which could lead quickly to nuclear war. He persuaded them that it was an accident. Of the American pilot, Kennedy bitterly said, “There is always some son of a bitch who doesn’t get the word.”

headline: AbbVie-Shire Deal Is Expected, in a Flight to a Lower-Tax Locale
abstract: The biggest wedding of the year comes as the Treasury and Congress prepare legislation to prevent tax inversions, possibly retroactively. What provision AbbVie has made for that is unclear.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:41 p.m. | The biggest deal of the year is set to be announced on Friday morning, as the pharmaceutical giant AbbVie plans to announce a $53 billion acquisition of Shire, according to people briefed on the matter.

lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Martha Rhodes, the director of Four Way Books.

headline: By the Bees on My Chinny Chin Chin
abstract: Clovermead Apiaries is hosting its 10th annual Worldwide Bee Beard Competition in Ontario, Canada, on July 25.
lead_paragraph: Beauty is in the eye of the bee-holder. At least, that’s the case in Aylmer, Ontario, on July 25, when Clovermead Apiaries hosts its 10th annual Worldwide Bee Beard Competition. The event brings together teams of insect aficionados who strut their stuff on a catwalk — while covered in thousands of confused bees — in a contest for charity to crown the queen (or king) of bee beards.

headline: At Berl’s Brooklyn Poetry Shop, Balm for the Borrower
abstract: Poets will gather at Berl’s Brooklyn Poetry Shop on Friday to share verses aimed at dispelling the shame attached to debt.
lead_paragraph: Poetry may be a noble vocation, but poets are generally an impecunious lot. Resigned to significantly less than blockbuster sales and often saddled with student loans, they’re on intimate terms with arrears. A handful of them will gather Friday night at Berl’s Brooklyn Poetry Shop for “Write Off Debt,” a reading that revolves around the concept. Organized by Ashleigh Lambert and featuring her fellow poets Max Cohen, Dustin Luke Nelson, Allyson Paty, Niina Pollari, Christopher Salerno and Emily Toder, the evening aims to imagine fresh approaches to debt.

abstract: The 20th Fire Island Dance Festival is bringing in dancers from top companies, including American Ballet Theater’s Marcelo Gomes, who has also choreographed a new work for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Like all performers at the Fire Island Dance Festival, Marcelo Gomes was awed by his surroundings when he participated for the first time in 2010. The sun, looking like a burning tangerine, descended behind him as he danced, before extinguishing itself in the bay.

headline: For a Smooth Ride, Look Someplace Else
abstract: In a class at the Brooklyn Bike Park, cyclists get a workout as they negotiate bumpy terrain.
lead_paragraph: WAITING in line to see the Kara Walker exhibition in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, not long ago, I noticed an off-road cycling course across the street, where numerous children in helmets were zipping around. It looked like fun, so I returned on a recent sunny afternoon for what I thought would be a light two-wheeled frolic.

headline: A Duke’s Gilded Haven, Recreated in Paris
abstract: The lavish art and architectural fittings of a razed 18th-century townhouse built in Paris for Philippe II, the duke of Orléans, will be installed in a new home.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Sections of 18th-century gilded walls and paintings of deities are sprawled across the floor of a warehouse on this city’s outskirts. After nine decades in limbo, this architectural salvage is being reorganized  into period rooms that will rival Versailles’s for inventiveness and visual impact.

headline: A New Book Explores the Art of Plants
abstract: “Strange Plants” depicts the relationship between artists and flora through in-depth interviews and original artwork.
lead_paragraph: From Monet’s “Water Lilies” to Andy Warhol’s “Flowers,” plants have been a perennial subject of interest for artists. “Strange Plants,” the first title from the new L.A.-based art book publisher Zioxla, is a celebration of this ongoing relationship. A mix of in-depth interviews with photography, paintings and sculpture from established and emerging artists, the tome ($30, available online today) explores the roles that plants play both in the creative process and in artists’ personal lives.

headline: Fallen Bodies, Jet Parts and a Child’s Pink Book
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Local residents and rescue workers saw smoldering debris litter miles of sparsely populated Ukrainian farmland after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crashed.
lead_paragraph: GRABOVO, Ukraine — Incongruously, given that the plane fell from more than 30,000 feet, many of the bodies strewn about in the smoldering wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 were largely intact. A woman in a black sweater lay on her back, blood streaming from her face, her left arm raised as if signaling someone. Another victim, naked except for a black bra, lay on the field, her gray hair mixing with the green grass, one leg broken and her body torn.

headline: Using a Camera to Make More Than Memories
abstract: “The Photographic Object, 1970,” at Hauser & Wirth, revisits MoMA’s 1970 show “Photography Into Sculpture,” reliving heated late-1960s debates about photography’s role in society.
lead_paragraph: When an art show reaches the end of its run, it usually goes gently into the archives. Lately, however, a number of exhibitions from the 1960s and ’70s have been coming back to haunt us.

headline: A Call to Fight Malaria One Mosquito at a Time by Altering DNA
abstract: Two papers published Thursday say the procedure, known as Crispr, can have wide benefits. But other experts worry about unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: Every year, malaria-carrying mosquitoes kill more than 600,000 people, most of them children. Over the centuries, people have battled those mosquitoes in numerous ways, like draining swamps, spraying insecticides and distributing millions of bed nets. And yet malaria remains a menace across much of the world.

abstract: Ms. Steyerl’s show confirms that she is among the most rigorous yet playful artist-filmmakers today.
lead_paragraph: Beginning with an unprintable adjective, the subtitle of Hito Steyerl’s latest New York show identifies it as a “Didactic Educational Installation.” But don’t be misled. The show confirms that Ms. Steyerl (pronounced STYE-rill) is among the most rigorous yet playful artist-filmmakers today, and unusually skilled at working her mediums and messages into an experience of form that is anything but didactic.

lead_paragraph: For IBM, the challenge is to convert the future of technology into an opportunity rather than a threat.

headline: The Morgan Gets a Gift: A Lichtenstein Trove
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum has been given sketchbooks and drawings by Roy Lichtenstein’s estate, including early drawings like “Mickey Mouse I” and “Donald Duck.”
lead_paragraph: Scholars tend to seek out the Morgan Library & Museum’s archives as a place to research old masters and 19th-century drawings, or to peek at the letters that modern masters like Chagall and Dubuffet wrote to the art dealer Pierre Matisse. But a recent gift from the Roy Lichtenstein estate will now make the Morgan a destination for classic contemporary artists, too.

headline: The Two Faces of Soave
abstract: This Italian white wine has evolved into two styles: one crisp and fruity, the other rich and complex.
lead_paragraph: It’s no longer news that Italy makes great white wines. In the bad old days, the Italian whites available in the United States tended to be insipid mass-marketed brands or campy contrived bottles. But since then, a revival has introduced the world to wonderful selections from the Valle d’Aoste at the farthest reaches of Italy’s northwest, from Alto Adige and Friuli-Venezia Giulia in the extreme northeast, from Sicily at the southernmost end, and from just about everywhere in between.

headline: What to Eat With Italian Soave
abstract: The fruitiness of the wine calls for food that’s got a salty component: like melon with ricotta salata.
lead_paragraph: When I was quite small, I remember my mother telling me that if you put salt on your watermelon, it would taste sweeter. I never quite bought that theory — the salt made it weird to me. I still do not salt my watermelon. But I do like something that comes close: a savory, salty component that I have found does complement melon quite nicely. This was brought home to me on many occasions, traveling in Greece, Jordan, Israel and elsewhere in the Middle East, where watermelon and feta or a similar salty white cheese is often on the breakfast buffet.

headline: Pay Your Taxes, Kill the Neighbors
abstract: In “The Purge: Anarchy,” Americans are again asked to spend a night running amok and killing.
lead_paragraph: Kill or be killed isn’t the official tag line of “The Purge: Anarchy,” but it fits. It would also make a more suitable title for this satisfyingly creepy, blunt, down-and-dirty thriller, one of those follow-ups that improves on the original. Once again, it’s a new morning in future America, and crime is still down, as is unemployment. The only thing that appears to be keeping the peace and assuring prosperity is the government-sanctioned annual bloodletting, that one night a year in which the citizenry can run amok without punishment. The word anarchy is purely superfluous.

headline: Back to the Future: Another High-Tech Twist on Tap-Dancing
abstract: “ETM: The Initial Approach” melds tap-dancing with electronic dance music at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — In the 1989 film “Tap,” the old-timer character played by Sammy Davis Jr. has an idea for how to save tap-dancing, how to make it contemporary and popular again. The idea is to hook up tap-dancers to synthesizers. As realized in the film, the great dancer Gregory Hines taps, and in place of the nuanced music of his feet come 1980s video game noises. It’s ridiculous, especially since the real future of tap was present in the film, in the form of the teenage Savion Glover.

headline: Palestinian Youth Who Was Abducted and Killed Struggled to Stay Alive, Indictment Says
abstract: Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, who was kidnapped this month in Jerusalem, fought his three attackers before being kicked in the head and bludgeoned with a wrench, charging documents said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the moments before he was kidnapped at dawn on July 2, Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16, suddenly sensed that there was something suspicious about the two casually dressed Jewish teenagers who were asking him directions. He tried to move away and call a friend, then shouted and struggled as the two youths forced him into a waiting car driven by an adult relative, according to court documents released on Thursday.

headline: This Procedure May Improve Your Brain — and Uncover the Real You
abstract: Transcranial direct-current stimulation delivers a small jolt of electricity to the brain but may have a significant impact on how we learn, recover from illness and combat mental illness. Will it also change our personalities?
lead_paragraph: People are fascinated by the idea of enhancing themselves — by, say, 10,000 hours of practice or drugs to improve cognitive performance. Now a noninvasive, 20-minute procedure called transcranial direct-current stimulation, or tDCS, may be able to help us learn a language faster, increase our alertness and curb food cravings. It has been shown to help hasten stroke rehabilitation, ameliorate chronic pain and treat even major depressive disorders.

headline: Q. and A.: Bill Porter on Journeys, Poets and Best-Sellerdom in China
abstract: Bill Porter has been one of the most prolific translators of Chinese texts, while also developing into a travel writer with a cult following. In an interview, he discusses his works and his plans.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, Bill Porter has been one of the most prolific translators of Chinese texts, while also developing into a travel writer with a cult following. Under the pen name Red Pine, the 70-year-old resident of Port Townsend, Wash., has translated over a dozen books of poetry and religious texts, including collections of poems by Hanshan and Song Boren, the Daoist classic Dao De Jing and numerous Buddhist sutras. Under his own name, he has also published travel works like “Zen Baggage: A Pilgrimage to China” and “Road to Heaven: Encounters With Chinese Hermits.”

lead_paragraph: Let’s assume you’re already a savvy user of travel apps that save you money on the road. You know Gas Buddy can tell you whether the gas station just up the road is cheaper than the one you’re currently passing, and you would never exchange currency without checking the current market exchange rate on Oanda’s Currency app. You don’t pay for text messages to new friends abroad or family back home in the States, thanks to WhatsApp, Heywire and their kin. (For more guidance to travel apps, read past New York Times coverage here, here, here and here.)

lead_paragraph: It’s one of the greatest stories ever told, the Bible’s tale of God, Adam, Eve and the Serpent in the Garden of Eden, as related in Genesis 2:4 to 3:24. Derived from Babylonian mythology, it circulated in Jewish oral tradition before being written down in the 10th century B.C. It’s not long: In English translation, it amounts to fewer than 1,300 words. Despite its brevity and antiquity, it remains as resonant today as ever.

headline: Recitals That Linger, a Festival That May Not
abstract: The pianists Alexander Schimpf and Alon Goldstein performed Wednesday, part of an annual Mannes College event whose future is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: On most days of the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, a popular annual venture sponsored by Mannes College the New School for Music, there are two piano recitals each evening. So it was on Wednesday, the third full day of the festival. For the early-evening Prestige series, which mostly presents exceptional younger artists, the award-winning 32-year-old German pianist Alexander Schimpf played a varied program culminating with Beethoven’s mighty “Hammerklavier” Sonata. Later that evening, the Israeli pianist Alon Goldstein, admired for the refinement and imaginativeness of his performances, played a formidable program on the Masters series. The recitals were presented at the intimate concert hall of the Mannes College building on the Upper West Side, which seats just 275.

headline: Staring at the Flame
abstract: John le Carré recalls Philip Seymour Hoffman’s intensity in performing the role of a self-destructive German intelligence officer in the film adaptation of his novel “A Most Wanted Man.”
lead_paragraph: I reckon I spent five hours at most in Philip Seymour Hoffman’s close company, six at a pinch. Otherwise it was standing around with other people on the set of “A Most Wanted Man,” watching him on the monitor and afterward telling him he was great, or deciding better to keep your thoughts to yourself. I didn’t even do a lot of that: a couple of visits to the set, one silly walk-on part that required me to grow a disgusting beard, took all day and delivered a smudgy picture of somebody I was grateful not to recognize. There’s probably nobody more redundant in the film world than a writer of origin hanging around the set of his movie, as I’ve learned to my cost. Alec Guinness actually did me the favor of having me shown off the set of the BBC’s TV adaptation of “Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy.” All I was wanting to do was radiate my admiration, but Alec said my glare was too intense.

That certainly seems likely, given the ingenious contraptions, live-action and animated, that motor and hum through his latest, “Mood Indigo.” Nominally a romance about a boy and a girl, the movie is more rightly a feature-length expression of Mr. Gondry’s love of whirring, purring creations, including the doorbell that scuttles like a large ring-a-ding insect and the upright piano that whips up cocktails and the mouse that makes mischief and the mechanical cloud that sails over Paris and, and, and. ...

headline: Making the Spiritually Skeptical Believe, and the Blind Worms See
abstract: Mike Cahill’s “I Origins” is a sci-fi romance about two genetic researchers and a mysterious woman who sees things more spiritually than scientifically.
lead_paragraph: The eyes are windows to the soul. That fuzzy bit of wisdom is repeated several times, with both reverence and skepticism, in “I Origins,” Mike Cahill’s new film. Whatever that may mean, there’s no doubt that eyes are also the portals through which movies, good and bad, enter our consciousness. Considered strictly as a visual experience, this one, which might be described as a faith-based emo-science romance-thriller, is often quite beguiling.

headline: Replaying the Past, to a New Soundtrack
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Elderly', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: I’m not sure the doctor recognizes me, and he doesn’t know my name. I feel he’s fishing around in his imperfect memory, trying to place me.
lead_paragraph: One of the things old people do is visit other old people in hospitals. It sounds dreary, and it is dreary, but it has its benefits. If you can learn to read the gauges and dials, you will, next time you are a patient, be able to find out how close to death you are (nobody else will tell you) by keeping an eye on your vitals: blood pressure, ejection fraction. And you can secretly rejoice that it’s not you in the bed. Not yet.

abstract: The right is obsessed with the claim that runaway inflation is either happening or about to happen.
lead_paragraph: The first step toward recovery is admitting that you have a problem. That goes for political movements as well as individuals. So I have some advice for so-called reform conservatives trying to rebuild the intellectual vitality of the right: You need to start by facing up to the fact that your movement is in the grip of some uncontrollable urges. In particular, it’s addicted to inflation — not the thing itself, but the claim that runaway inflation is either happening or about to happen.

lead_paragraph: Sarah Johnson is the director of Weill Music Institute, Carnegie Hall’s education and community engagement enterprise, which has a staff of 25, a budget of $10 million and a reach of 450,000 people in New York and around the world. Among other duties, she oversees the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America, for musicians ages 16 to 19 who come to Purchase, N.Y., from all over the country for a two-week training residency. The ensemble’s eight-city 2014 tour opens at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College on July 20 and at Carnegie Hall on July 22. (Showtime) LEE DANIELS’ THE BUTLER (2013) Inspired by the real story of Eugene Allen, Mr. Daniels follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (Forest Whitaker, above), and his wife, Gloria (Oprah Winfrey), as history — particularly the civil rights movement — unfolds over seven presidential administrations in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called “a brilliantly truthful movie on a subject that is usually shrouded in wishful thinking, mythmongering and outright denial.” Robin Williams portrays Dwight D. Eisenhower; Liev Schreiber is Lyndon B. Johnson; and Alan Rickman is Ronald Reagan, with Jane Fonda as his wife, Nancy; Cuba Gooding Jr. and Lenny Kravitz are the fellow butlers who become Cecil’s close friends; and David Oyelowo is the older son whose politics Cecil eschews. “In part, their story is a chronicle of the generational misunderstanding that has occurred in upwardly mobile families of every background, especially in the baby boom era, when educated and restless young people turned against the parents who had sacrificed so much on their behalf,” Mr. Scott wrote. “ ‘The Butler’ has the historical insight and the generosity of spirit to honor the father and the son equally, and to look with skepticism at each’s point of view.” He added: “We remember those who marched and who stood up for themselves in the face of injustice. It is good to remember that, to paraphrase Milton, they also stand who only wait and serve.”

headline: 1939: London and Warsaw Skeptical
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Poland and Britain expressed doubt in Hitler’s willingness to keep the peace in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There were ample indications today [July 18] that both British and Polish official quarters continue to be highly skeptical of Berlin reports that Adolf Hitler is now prepared to seek a peaceful solution of the Danzig issue on the basis of terms which could be considered by Warsaw. Almost as if these reports had not been broadcast Poland issued today a new warning to the Fuehrer. A semiofficial communiqué issued in Warsaw read: ‘‘Quite apart from the manner in which Germany may desire to incorporate Danzig in the Reich, Polish political quarters declare that the very fact of such an incorporation would constitute an inadmissible violation of the present political and juridical state of affairs and would evoke the appropriate response.’’ This response, if previous Polish declarations are to be trusted, would be in the form of the use of force by Warsaw to restore the status quo ante in the Free City. In a declaration in the House of Commons at the beginning of last week Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain made it clear that should Warsaw determine to resist an attempted change from within or without in the status of Danzig, Britain, backed by France, would come to its aid. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1939

Varese, in the foothills of the Alps, was a magnet for these estates, several of which are clustered on the parklike hill of Biumo Superiore. At its crest sits the Villa Menafoglio Litta Panza, the most storied, thanks to its longtime owner, Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, the Milanese businessman whose adventurous tastes and ardent appetites made him one of the most important art collectors of the last century.

headline: A Japanese Artist Launches Plants Into Space
