His latest installation piece, if you could call it that, takes this statement to the extreme. Two botanical objects — “Shiki 1,” a Japanese white pine bonsai suspended from a metal frame, and an untitled arrangement of orchids, hydrangeas, lilies and irises, among other blossoms — were launched into the stratosphere on Tuesday in Black Rock Desert outside Gerlach, Nevada, a site made famous for its hosting of the annual Burning Man festival. “I wanted to see the movement and beauty of plants and flowers suspended in space,” Azuma explained that morning.

headline: Who Made That Scotch Tape?
abstract: From slur to solution for cheap and easy repairs.
lead_paragraph: The particulars are hard to pin down, but everyone seems to agree that Scotch tape, the now-famous brand, originated as a slur. Back in the ’20s, Scotch was a synonym for “cheap.” Richard Drew, a 23-year-old research assistant at Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, was trying to create a sticky-but-not-too-sticky adhesive tape for auto painters to use on two-tone paint jobs. When he erred on the not-too-sticky side, one of the car-painters asked, “Why so Scotch with the adhesive?” and a brand name was born.

headline: 1964: Anti-Negro White Is Shot
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Shooting at an integrated restaurant in Atlanta in 1964.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Restaurant owner Redell Crosby last night shot and critically wounded a 22-year-old white man who entered his integrated restaurant with other whites shouting that Negroes should leave. The shooting coincided with racial outbursts in other Southern cities, including St. Augustine, Fla., and Philadelphia, Miss. Police said five white men who entered Mr. Crosby’s drive-in restaurant were arrested and charged with assault in a scuffle that preceded the shooting. The victim of the shooting was identified as Maurice Lawson of Atlanta. Mr. Crosby was arrested and charged with wounding Mr. Lawson. He was released on $1,500 bond. Detective Tony Quave said Mr. Lawson and the five told the Negroes in the restaurant, “You just have to go.” Mr. Quave said the white men attacked two of the Negroes, punching one in the nose, before Mr. Crosby pulled his pistol. Mr. Crosby held his fire and ordered the white men to leave. All left except Mr. Lawson, who advanced on the restaurant owner with a beer bottle. Mr. Crosby then began shooting. A few blocks from Mr. Crosby’s restaurant, a white man and his son were wounded by blasts from a shotgun fired by Negroes from a passing car. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 19, 1964

lead_paragraph: West Africa’s hub for nongovernmental organizations and international agencies, Dakar draws a cosmopolitan mix of travelers to its dusty downtown streets and surf-pounded coastline. It’s a city of hustlers and traders, bargainers and touts, eager to show you something or sell you something and not always dissuaded by a polite “non, merci.” Keep saying it. Daytime streets are crowded with men in sharp suits and women rustling in the hand-dyed polished cottons called bazins. At night, intimate restaurants offer Lebanese and French-influenced dishes or simple but fresh grilled fish with Creole sauce. Much later, the dance clubs in Plateau and Almadies, along with the calls to prayer, resound into the early morning.

headline: The Immodest Scope of Reform Conservatism
abstract: On a small movement’s genuinely big ideas.
lead_paragraph: This will hopefully be the last post for a while with the word “reform conservatism” in the title (sex, pop culture and religion all deserve more attention), and by the standards of the series it will be relatively brief. Since so many of the criticisms of the reformist tendency have focused on issues where there either isn’t a definite “reform” position or where our ideas are more modest and incremental than the received wisdom about what American conservatism “must” do, I’m concerned that my responses — whether on immigration, foreign policy, the culture war, or climate change — have contributed to the sense that reform conservatism somehow has an ambition problem … that it’s a plausible first step toward a new right-of-center agenda, but lacks (or hasn’t yet been gutsy enough to advance) the Big Ideas that conservatism really needs to matter in American policy debates again. (See David Frum, Kevin Drum, Bill Galston and others for variations on this theme.)

headline: But I Didn’t Know Filming Fights Was Wrong!
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Laundry and Laundromats', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Forbidden footage; washer wars.
lead_paragraph: At my high school, two students were expelled for getting into a fight wherein a teacher was injured. In addition, two students who filmed the fight — and later circulated the video among students — were also threatened with expulsion. Expelling students for filming fights is unheard-of in my district. The school said it had grounds to expel the two who took the video, as outlined by the handbook given to all students: “Students may be disciplined for any other misconduct which is deemed by school authorities to be disruptive or to interfere with the educational process.” There seems to be no rule, however, explicitly banning filming and circulating a fight. How much does students’ ignorance of a rule matter when determining a punishment? Is it ethical for a school to expel students for something they reasonably don’t know to be wrong? NAME WITHHELD, CLEVELAND

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “The Girls of August,” No. 13 on the hardcover fiction list, is the novelist Anne Rivers Siddons’s 13th best seller.
lead_paragraph: Enemy Territory: The Southern novelist Anne Rivers Siddons is a fixture on the best-seller list — “The Girls of August,” new this week at No. 13, is her 13th book to land on the hardcover fiction list. So is 13 a lucky number for Siddons? Maybe not, judging from the largely disappointed comments readers are posting online about “The Girls of August.” But Siddons has overcome negative reviews before. As a student at Auburn University in the late 1950s, she was fired from the campus newspaper for defying the administration with a scorching column in support of integration (an incident that later found its way into her novel “Heartbreak Hotel”). “Never write a column when you’re mad or sick or disgusted, or all three,” she proclaimed early in the offending essay. “These are the things that make bad little columnists get reprimanding letters from the intelligentsia. Only the greenest, foolhardiest, most naïve amateur would broach a forbidden subject in Enemy Territory. . . . Meet an amateur par excellence.” Later in the same column she mulled the word “tolerance” — “It’s a grown-up word. Children and mobs do much better with four-letter ones” — and criticized people who were content to let their “moral petticoats” drag in the “good old Southern mud.” Auburn finally did integrate in 1964, seven years after that column, and the school eventually forgave Siddons for her justified dudgeon. It awarded her an honorary doctorate of humane letters in 1997, and organized a tribute to her last fall on the anniversary of the column’s publication date.

headline: Stop the Clocks
abstract: David Grossman’s book in verse is an intimate study of grief and mourning.
lead_paragraph: The emblematic Man, any man, every man — dazed, heartsick, utterly bewildered — suddenly pushes away his dinner and gets up from the kitchen table. He can’t take it any longer — the overwhelming, claustrophobic grief, which has hollowed him out — and so he decides to go “there.” But where is there? That’s what the emblematic Woman, any woman, every woman, can’t figure out. That’s what she wants to know. She understands, this woman who is also a mother, a wife, that there is no place to go when you’ve lost a child. You are already wounded by disaster, forever bereft. “In an instant we were cast out / to a land of exile,” she remembers. But this man can’t sit still any longer. The trouble has taken him over again. And so he sets out to go “there” anyway. It has been five years, and he is determined to see his dead son one more time, though no one has ever made the journey and come back alive. Like a figure in a myth, he is going to walk across a divide, leaving the living behind, the innocent ones, who still exist inside of ordinary time.

headline: Picture Everyone Naked
abstract: Patricia Lockwood’s second poetry collection continues her interrogation of gender, nature and sexuality.
lead_paragraph: It’s always wrong to judge a poem by its retweets, but when a literary work, by a poet not world famous for something else, gets hundreds of thousands of “shares,” “likes” and other such notices online, within weeks of publication, it’s time to ask why. That is what happened, in 2013, to Patricia Lockwood’s “Rape Joke.” Like rape itself, “Rape Joke” was no joke: “The rape joke is that you were 19 years old,” it began. “The rape joke is that he was your boyfriend. . . . The rape joke is that you had been drinking wine coolers. Wine coolers! Who drinks wine coolers? People who get raped, according to the rape joke.” To readers who had suffered similar outrages, Lockwood offered wit and a fed-up solidarity; to others, the poem brought news.

headline: Sing to Me, O Muse (But Keep It Brief)
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Thoughts on the state of poetry in the age of Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Maybe I dreamed it. Don Draper sips Canadian Club from a coffee mug on Craig Ferguson’s late-night talk show. “Are you on Twitter?” the host asks. “No,” Draper says. “I don’t” — he pauses before pronouncing the distasteful verb — “tweet.” Next question. “Do you read a lot of poetry?” Though the hero of “Mad Men” is seen reading Dante’s “Inferno” in one season of the show and heard reciting Frank O’Hara in another, the question seems to come from left field. “Poetry isn’t really celebrated anymore in our culture,” Draper says, to which Ferguson retorts, “It can be — if you can write in units of 140 keystrokes.” Commercial break.

headline: In Real Life
abstract: Young women grapple with jobs, men and each other in the blogger Emily Gould’s first novel.
lead_paragraph: “Friendship,” the first novel by Emily Gould, is about, well, friendship: It chronicles the several-years-long platonic love between two just-barely-30 New York City strivers, Bev and Amy. Bev is a classic ne’er-do-well, an inelegant Midwestern transplant who can’t seem to earn any real money or avoid getting trampled by various cads, one of whom she disastrously follows to Madison, Wis., and another of whom gets her pregnant on their first date. (She accepted the invitation only for the free meal, poor thing.) She exists in sharp contrast to the charming, affable Amy, the more stable, interesting and well dressed of the pair, who was once — remember this next part — a blogger on a prominent gossip site, but who now works at another blog, if the term “work” can be stretched to encompass countless hours of “online window-shopping and Wikipedia rabbit holes and . . . Gchatting with Bev.”

headline: Harm’s Ways
abstract: Gabriel Chevallier’s autobiographical novel about serving on the front lines of World War I.
lead_paragraph: In the era before cheap air travel, those in the English-speaking world who wanted to taste authentic French village life read Gabriel Chevallier’s gently satirical novels, published between the mid-1930s and the early 1960s. “Clochemerle” and “Clochemerle-Babylon” were deft, wise and celebratory in what people thought of as the French style. On the town of Cloche­merle, in the Beaujolais region, the issues of French politics, class difference and coming or past collaboration with fascism lay more lightly than did eccentricity, pride in local wine, cooking and love.

headline: I’ve Ruined My Boys
abstract: My sons—and my husband—expect me to wait on them. I can’t really blame them. I made my bed. And everyone else’s.
lead_paragraph: “Anyone want pasta for lunch?” I asked, and my 6-, 9- and 11-year-­old boys stared at their little screens in front of the big screen and ignored me. Incredulous, I glared at them. And then I repeated the question, the pitch of my voice notably higher.

lead_paragraph: Reaction from world leaders to Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash.

headline: Content and Its Discontents
abstract: The Internet was hailed as a digital democracy, but has resulted in inequities and concentrations of power.
lead_paragraph: Astra Taylor is a documentary filmmaker who has described her work as the “steamed broccoli” in our cultural diet. Her last film, “Examined Life,” depicted philosophers walking around and talking about their ideas. She’s the kind of creative person who was supposed to benefit when the Internet revolution collapsed old media hierarchies. But two decades since that revolution began, she’s not impressed: “We are at risk of starving in the midst of plenty,” Taylor writes. “Free culture, like cheap food, incurs hidden costs.” Instead of serving as the great equalizer, the web has created an abhorrent cultural feudalism. The creative masses connect, create and labor, while Google, Facebook and Amazon collect the cash.

headline: Viva la República
abstract: The hero of Alan Furst’s new espionage novel risks his life for the loyalists in the Spanish Civil War.
lead_paragraph: There’s a certain sense of fatedness that emerges in the 13 espionage novels Alan Furst has written about Europe before and during World War II, even if it’s never quite enunciated in their wry, reticent storytelling. It has to do with the nature of the genre. Furst’s makeshift spies act with courage, but their choices are shaded with a brutal irony, darkened by what we readers, a few paces further along in history, know will be coming for them and the people they care about: the battlefields, the camps. The consolation Furst offers for this knowledge is present in a careful hedonism, which insists on the heightened beauty of the evanescent during wartime — the unexpected pleasure of a meal or a glass of wine, a night in bed with a stranger as it snows outside, anything human.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe discusses Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: Big changes could be coming to the media world after Rupert Murdoch made an $80 billion bid to buy Time Warner. The offer was rejected, but that doesn’t mean it’s the end of the story. If Murdoch succeeds, he would wind up with movie and TV studios like Warner Brothers and HBO. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar consider what would happen if Rupert Murdoch succeeds in purchasing Time Warner.

headline: A ’70s Childhood
abstract: Dan Chiasson’s new collection evokes the father he never knew.
lead_paragraph: In his fourth book of poems, “Bicentennial,” Dan Chiasson is after beauty of a kind, so his poems are often beautiful, odd and quite moving. He seldom resorts to lilting cadences or glow-in-the-dark imagery to achieve this, and complicates any move toward traditional lyric warmth; his poetry is genially brainy, jokey, casually formal, sometimes essayistic and humorously oracular. Yet “Bicentennial” is no mere intellectual pleasure. It’s also a journey into a 1970s New England childhood haunted by a father Chiasson never knew.

headline: Why Myers-Briggs Is Totally Useless — but Wildly Popular

lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever filled out a Myers-Briggs personality test only to feel the results didn’t describe you at all, take heart. According to Vox’s Joseph Stromberg, “The test is completely meaningless.”

headline: A Rose by Other Names
abstract: From urban pigeons to the Adirondacks, Maureen N. McLane celebrates the intricacies of the natural world.
lead_paragraph: I know a songwriter who hates nature poetry. Just about every other style of verse speaks to this guy, whether it’s traditional or avant-garde, unabashedly romantic or abstractedly cerebral, but as soon as my friend hears about silvery, moonlit branches swooshing in some mountain breeze, or raindrops mystically anointing a spray of spring wildflowers, he wants to gag.

headline: Grave Business
abstract: In Ace Atkins’s “The Forsaken,”
lead_paragraph: A tornado tore through the town of Jericho, Miss., in the most recent of Ace Atkins’s deeply rooted regional novels set in a gritty pocket of the rural South. In THE FORSAKEN (Putnam, $26.95), a resident who survived that last book reflects on “the ugliness of what we’ve done to this place, all the logging, busted-up trailers, and stripping of anything that can make a buck” and decides that “we didn’t need a tornado to rip this town apart, we just needed a few more good years.”

headline: Less Boyish at the Bolshoi
abstract: David Hallberg is developing as a dancer, showing off his bigger, broader, Bolshoi-influenced style in that company’s “Swan Lake,” now at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Ballet fans love a campy, insidery way of referring to dancers by their first names, regardless of whether they’ve ever met them or would presume thus to address them. Margot, Rudi, Natasha, Lynn, Anthony, Suzanne, Misha, Gelsey were among the darlings of my youth, and today, it’s Wendy, Marcelo, Alina, Herman, Gillian, Sara, Robbie. Most of these are not remotely household names around the world, in the way that Oprah and Brad are. But that’s the point. They’re names in the cliquey household of ballet. To employ first names shows you belong.

headline: James Tobin and Aggregate Supply (Implicitly Wonkish)
abstract: He’s looking good these days.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Palley argues that mainstream macroeconomists have been looking in all the wrong places for an explanation of the stickiness of inflation in the face of high unemployment; what they should do is consider the old Tobin approach that combines multiple sectors (so that some workers have rising wages even in an economy that’s depressed on average) with downward nominal wage rigidity.

headline: Lincoln Agonistes
abstract: In the summer of 1864, the president was sure he would lose his reelection bid.
lead_paragraph: The summer of 1864 found Abraham Lincoln, and the Union war effort, in a conundrum: The Northern public desperately wanted an end to the war, and yet the two possibilities – a negotiated peace or a military victory – seemed increasingly remote. But if he wanted to win reelection in the fall, he had to show movement on one front or the other.

headline: A Buzzy Hotel Oasis in West Hollywood
abstract: A boutique hotelier has turned this former gay landmark the San Vicente Inn into a chic, affordable hotel — and he’s not done yet. For now, summer looks good on the 29-room property with its cleaned-up grounds.
lead_paragraph: In West Hollywood, the San Vicente Inn is gradually being transformed by the boutique hotelier Jeff Klein, who is garnering lots of attention for turning the historically gay, seedy hotel into a clean and chic place for the young and beautiful to shack up on a budget (rooms range from $99 to $209 per night). Now known as the San Vicente Bungalows, the 29-room property has undergone basic renovations — like spiffed-up bathrooms, now stocked with Malin & Goetz products — that are attracting the 20- to 30-something international jet set. In addition to bright and cozy digs, guests enjoy free breakfast and can rent beach cruisers ($15 for 4 hours) to ride out to places like Venice Beach and Santa Monica, each just about 45 minutes away by bike. Even the locals are popping in for a swim — access to the pool and newly landscaped grounds is $35/day. Eventually, the now-charming place will get a complete makeover. So T checked into the buzzy little oasis to memorialize things as they stand now, while summer is in full swing.

headline: When Contemporary Poetry Is Your Muse

We had strong reviews of recent work by a couple of major American poets, Dan Chiasson and Maureen N. McLane. Our On Poetry columnist, David Orr, wrote a review of a collection of poems by the actor James Franco (“James Franco, Poet”). And this year’s editor of “The Best American Poetry,” David Lehman, proposed adapting his introduction to that volume, which comes out in September and broadly asks what role poetry plays in a technologized world.Moreover, recently, and to some people, amazingly, contemporary poetry has been making headlines. headline: There Is So Much That Must Live On
abstract: Merce Cunningham’s legacy is in danger among American dance troupes.
lead_paragraph: This month, in a fifth-floor studio at City Center, I spent part of an afternoon watching 30 minutes of Merce Cunningham’s 1997 “Scenario.” When new, this had been a work both glamorous and difficult. The most famous feature was its radical couture, outfits by Rei Kawakubo (of Comme des Garçons), wonderfully colored and patterned, but with padded bulges that changed the dancers’ outlines and sometimes limited their movements. And its choreography was also one of Cunningham’s more advanced creations in his late, “computer,” phase. (He was 78 at the time of its premiere.)

headline: A ‘Cold Supper’ That Goes Beyond Leftovers
abstract: When company is coming, avoid the stove with cold raw sea scallops, a pork loin roast, a salad of green beans and fennel, and frozen raspberry spuma.
lead_paragraph: The weather is oppressive, sizzling, stifling. At the end of the day, a cook doesn’t feel much like cooking, and the cook’s brood is flushed and cranky. A cold beer and a mediocre takeout pizza won’t improve things much, but they are an option. If company’s coming, however, that may be perceived as less than hospitable.

headline: Everyone’s Here, Now Let’s Innovate
abstract: The Aix-en-Provence Festival has a reputation as an incubator of innovative opera, and this year’s version is no exception.
lead_paragraph: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Officially, the small square in front of the former residence of the archbishop, in the historic center of this elegant Provençal town, is named after the martyrs of the French Resistance. But every summer, the musicians, administrators and theater professionals who flock here for the Aix-en-Provence Festival give it a nickname drawn from the opening scene of Bizet’s “Carmen”: “La Place Chacun Passe” — the square where everybody comes and goes.

lead_paragraph: Jon Voight was ribbing his new co-star, the media-shy Ann-Margret.

abstract: Commissioning or customizing a ceremony’s music can make it even more meaningful.
lead_paragraph: Last year, when Daniel Knobler decided to propose to Carrie Crowell, a granddaughter of Johnny Cash, he said he “knew from the get-go” that he wanted the music to be something special.

headline: Adieu to That Dapper Detective
abstract: The British actor David Suchet seems ready to put some distance between himself and Hercule Poirot, Agatha Christie’s detective.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As David Suchet walks into the green room backstage at the Ahmanson Theater, a half-finished jigsaw puzzle on a table catches his eye. “Someone in the cast must be working on that,” mused Mr. Suchet, who is appearing in a production here of “The Last Confession.” “Personally, I’m not one who particularly enjoys putting together puzzles.”

abstract: As Bitcoin has become more mainstream, merchants may now be embracing digital money to reduce payment processing fees and make purchases easier for already-loyal customers.
lead_paragraph: Another well-known company is embracing digital money.

headline: Drinking What's Available
abstract: A toast to old-style newsrooms, and the misfits who inhabit them.
lead_paragraph: It’s another primary night. It’s after 11. You are still at your desk because they’re counting absentee ballots in Waukesha County and The Associated Press hasn’t called the race. Finally, the closest challenger concedes, and you’ve filed your story; you and the copy editor would really like a cocktail right about now. But you don’t want it to make you too tired. The last time you fell asleep on the subway home, you wound up in Coney Island.

headline: Judge Rules in Tale of a Soured Love Affair as Told on Anonymous Blogs
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A judge dismissed much of a defamation suit earlier this month brought by an architect who said that anonymous and salacious postings about him online were written by a former lover.
lead_paragraph: For all the inquiries they have facilitated into humanity’s highest intellectual realms, blogs have also proven themselves good incubators for petty squabbling, savage back-stabbing and ad hominem warfare of all varieties. The same, of course, is true of academia. So if, as a recent lawsuit alleges, an editorial associate at Cornell University’s Sage School of Philosophy took to the Internet in 2012 to savage a former lover, it may not be surprising that things got out of control.

headline: Every Single Place Has Its Own Sound
abstract: A strong sense of place informs the music of the composer John Luther Adams.
lead_paragraph: A strong sense of place informs the music of the composer John Luther Adams, who won a Pulitzer Prize this year, be it the Pacific Ocean, the Sonoran Desert, or the plains of his adopted Alaska. With “Sila: The Breath of the World,” which receives its premiere on Friday in a free joint production of the Mostly Mozart Festival and Lincoln Center Out of Doors, Mr. Adams invites audiences to open their ears to the sounds of their city.

headline: Like What You See? It May be for Sale
abstract: The American conceptual artist Christopher Williams, whose first retrospective opens July 27 at the Museum of Modern Art, treats photography with very tough love.
lead_paragraph: The American conceptual artist Christopher Williams, whose first retrospective opens July 27 at the Museum of Modern Art, treats photography with very tough love. During a 35-year career, it has been both his medium of choice and the target of his critical thinking. He takes as a basic premise the assumption that in a consumer society, the main purpose of photographs is to sell something — one of those things being art.

headline: Several Styles, All Together Now
abstract: Just as there are fusion cuisines — and you never know what they’re like until you try them — so, too, there’s fusion dance.
lead_paragraph: Just as there are fusion cuisines — and you never know what they’re like until you try them — so, too, there’s fusion dance, in which various styles unite into a new, surprising and, let’s hope, choreographically tasty concoction. Dancegoers can sample the fare of a new fusion troupe when FJK Dance offers its first full New York engagement. Founded by Fadi J. Khoury, the Baghdad-born son of an Iraqi ballet director, the company gave preview performances in April. Mr. Khoury seeks to mix ballet with ballroom, Middle Eastern and jazz dance, stripping away unnecessary glitter from these forms to emphasize the beauty of movement itself.

headline: Big Ticket | Upper East Side Townhouse for $27.25 Million
abstract: A 16-room, 6,700-square-foot neo-Georgian townhouse on the Upper East Side is the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A meticulously renovated neo-Georgian townhouse on the Upper East Side, defined by its multiple outdoor entertainment spaces and an interior-décor ode to blue, sold for $27.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Festival Starts With the Sensual
abstract: Karim Aïnouz’s “Futuro Beach” is the pungently sensual opening-night film of this year’s NewFest: The New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Karim Aïnouz’s “Futuro Beach” is the pungently sensual opening-night film of this year’s NewFest: The New York Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Film Festival, whose 26th edition takes place Thursday through July 29 at the Walter Reade Theater. The movie is the fifth fictional feature by this Brazilian director, whose sensational 2002 debut, “Madame Satã,” was a fictionalized biography of a notorious nightclub performer and criminal in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: A Salsa Opera Returns Outdoors
abstract: Larry Harlow’s “Hommy,” a landmark of New York music, was an Afro-Latin answer to the Who’s “Tommy.”
lead_paragraph: Larry Harlow’s “Hommy,” a landmark of New York music, was an Afro-Latin answer to the Who’s “Tommy”: a 1973 salsa opera, with lyrics by Heny Álvarez, telling the story of a deaf and blind boy gifted at playing the conga drum.

headline: How Tests Make Us Smarter
abstract: Low-stakes quizzing helps people retain more of what they learn.
lead_paragraph: TESTS have a bad reputation in education circles these days: They take time, the critics say, put students under pressure and, in the case of standardized testing, crowd out other educational priorities. But the truth is that, used properly, testing as part of an educational routine provides an important tool not just to measure learning, but to promote it.

headline: The Trial Ends, the Doubts Linger
abstract: The entrapment defense did not convince the jury that convicted four men on terrorism charges in New York in 2010, but it is very persuasive in “The Newburgh Sting.”
lead_paragraph: The entrapment defense did not convince the jury that convicted four men on terrorism charges in New York in 2010, but it is very persuasive in “The Newburgh Sting,” a documentary about the case, Monday night on HBO. Partly that’s because prosecutors and investigators declined to be interviewed for the film, which thus presents only one side. But, mostly, it’s because surveillance video of the men and the informant who egged them on, which makes up a significant part of the film, shows four buffoons who do not remotely fit the portrait of terror masterminds painted by the authorities when they announced their arrests in 2009.

headline: McIlroy Pulls Away as Woods Hangs On

lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — Rory McIlroy made his way around Royal Liverpool on Friday as if the course were a bouncy house, his springy step signaling his sky-high confidence.

headline: Marry to Make a Match (Not to Beat the Market)
abstract: New research suggests we seek partners who share our levels of attractiveness and status — and this could have bigger implications for how we talk about marriage.
lead_paragraph: In the search for love, are straight men always looking for women who are better looking than they are, and straight women holding out for men who are richer? Or do they tend to pair up with partners who are more on their level? Recent research suggests the latter — and this may have larger implications for how we talk about love and marriage.

When dancers of the caliber and charm of Robert Fairchild, Tiler Peck and Teresa Reichlen come to town, it’s a special event — even if, as is the case here, the town is regularly visited by premier dancers.

headline: Examining the Growth of the ‘Spiritual but Not Religious’
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Books and Literature', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Four recent books offer perspectives on Americans who want some connection to the divine but not traditional religions.
lead_paragraph: “Spiritual but not religious.” So many Americans describe their belief system this way that pollsters now give the phrase its own category on questionnaires. In the 2012 survey by the Pew Religion and Public Life Project, nearly a fifth of those polled said that they were not religiously affiliated — and nearly 37 percent of that group said they were “spiritual” but not “religious.” It was 7 percent of all Americans, a bigger group than atheists, and way bigger than Jews, Muslims or Episcopalians.

headline: Now Verified, a Veteran Is Honored
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Military Vehicles']
abstract: A 1918 Cadillac Type 57 was one of 20,000 passenger vehicles to go overseas for the United States in World War I and one of the few to actually return.
lead_paragraph: The United States had few military vehicles in its arsenal when in April 1917 it declared war and joined Britain, France and Russia in the horrific struggle that was the Great War. But if America’s supply of tanks and troop carriers was meager, its civilian auto fleet was substantial: More than 1.8 million cars were manufactured in the country in 1917.

But the directive will not exempt religious groups, as many of them had sought.

headline: Dislocation, Italian Style
abstract: I realized that my assumptions about medicine were in keeping with my American outlook on life, which, like it or not, revolves around money.
lead_paragraph: “SCUSI,” I said, calling a nurse in the same tone of casual deference used to summon a waiter, trying to ignore the pain that was blaring like a siren in my mind. It was a glorious day in Milan, and I had planned to spend it having lunch with a colleague, visiting a favorite museum, shopping for shoes. Instead, I found myself staring at the emergency room ceiling in the Ospedale Gaetano Pini, which the ambulance driver assured me was the best orthopedic hospital in the north of Italy. “People come from all over to have surgery here,” he said.

headline: Charles Aznavour’s September Concert May Be His Last in New York — Or Not
abstract: Mr. Aznavour, 90, seems inclined to dismiss the promotion for his concert, which promoters are describing as a farewell.
lead_paragraph: The French singer, songwriter and actor Charles Aznavour will give what may or may not be his farewell performance in New York at the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 20. The Garden is promoting the show as Mr. Aznavour’s final New York concert, and a spokeswoman for the complex said, after checking with the singer’s agent, that “this is the singer’s last performance in New York, and is being billed as his farewell performance,” adding that “there are no plans for Charles Aznavour to tour in the U.S. or perform in New York City again.”

On Sunday even the normally soft and weepy Lifetime channel joins in with “The Lottery,” a new series that postulates a world in which human beings can no longer reproduce the old-fashioned way.

abstract: The trumpeter Sean Jones, whose album “imp.ro.vise = never before seen” comes out Tuesday, plays with his quartet at Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: Good leadership in jazz is hard to quantify, but you know it when you see it — you can usually sense, in a musician’s judgment and yield and carriage, that some higher instinct has been activated. Sean Jones, whose glowing stature as a trumpeter has accrued over the last dozen years or so, didn’t always embody that quality on the bandstand. He does now, as he showed decisively at the Jazz Standard on Thursday in the opening set of a four-night run.

headline: An Indian Girl Who Just Wanted to Be Puerto Rican
abstract: In Qurrat Ann Kadwani’s solo show, “They Call Me Q,” a girl from India moves with her family to the Bronx and wants desperately to fit in.
lead_paragraph: By the end of “They Call Me Q,” you’re apt to like Qurrat Ann Kadwani so much that you’ll be doubly disappointed that she hasn’t written herself a better show. Her easy smile and lively eyes can brighten up a moment, but they can’t overcome a shortage of laughs and a wandering story line.

headline: Pedaling a Party Back to Life
abstract: Pilobolus performs “The Inconsistent Pedaler,” which is having its New York premiere, as part of its Program B at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: As if to assure us that they are real people, not superheroes or machines, the members of Pilobolus begin each show by warming up onstage. On Thursday at the Joyce Theater, before the program began, Shawn Fitzgerald Ahern fired off a few push-ups, Eriko Jimbo floated into a wide-legged handstand and Jordan Kriston whipped through a series of spiraling falls. The whole group circled up along with someone who appeared to be their stage manager (the technical crew is equally part of this clan), for a chummy preshow ritual that ended with a collective roar.

headline: Hundreds in Detroit Protest Over Move to Shut Off Water
abstract: About 300 demonstrators rallied downtown Friday, calling the city’s plan to end service to customers behind in their bills a human rights violation.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — At least 300 demonstrators marched through downtown streets on Friday, protesting a move by the city’s Water Department to force tens of thousands of delinquent customers to pay up or face a cutoff in service. From the Cobo Center to Hart Plaza on the banks of the Detroit River, protesters chanted, “Fight, fight; water is a human right.” Others carried placards that read “Thirsty for Justice.”

headline: After a Run of 19 Years, Passing the Baton
abstract: David Zinman, the American music director of the orchestra in Zurich, is leaving the post after 19 years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The American conductor David Zinman is a small man, physically — conductors often seem to be — but with a giant profile in the Swiss city of Zurich. People recognize him on the sidewalk. Waiters hover. Strangers wave. And so they might. He’s been the music director of the city’s venerable orchestra, the Tonhalle, for 19 years: a long time, given the speed with which most leading figures in his line of work swap partners.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up »

headline: Clashing Holds on Renaissance Art History
abstract: The discovery of a meaningful work of art in the Balkans sets off the drama in “Pentecost,” at Atlantic Stage 2.
lead_paragraph: What if the Renaissance began earlier and elsewhere? That audacious question kindles David Edgar’s “Pentecost,” a 1994 play revived by PTP/NYC. No less resonant now than when it had its premiere, the drama is a testament to Mr. Edgar’s literary skill and a rebuke to the political climate in Eastern Europe and elsewhere.

headline: If They’d Overthrown the Labour Party
abstract: A new production of “Richard III” at Trafalgar Studios in London offers a bureaucratic functionary of a leader, portrayed by Martin Freeman.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The “hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death,” as Richard III is described by one of his many detractors, has been thoroughly domesticated. As portrayed by Martin Freeman at Trafalgar Studios here, the most terrifying psychopath in Shakespeare seems dangerous only in the manner of a persistent insurance salesman who might sell you a policy you don’t really need.

headline: In Santa Fe, An Art Space Reinvents the Biennial
abstract: One of the early pioneers of the style of art exhibition that’s swept the world, SITE Santa Fe is trying to do things differently with a show focused on the Americas.
lead_paragraph: Beginning tonight, the adobe walls of the art space SITE Santa Fe will house a re-creation of an illegal 19th-century New Mexico gambling den, complete with dealers staging rounds of the Spanish card game known as monte. Inspired by the casinos that cropped up during the 1830s New Mexican gold rush, it’s part of a multipronged piece by the artist Pablo Helguera, one of 45 artists in “Unsettled Landscapes,” the latest edition of SITE Santa Fe’s contemporary art biennial, opening this Sunday.

headline: City Politics Abhors a Vacation
abstract: Officeholders, like Mayor Bill de Blasio, are in the difficult position of having to showcase family devotion, only to face scrutiny when they honor the obligations of parenthood.
lead_paragraph: From 1926 to 1932, James J. Walker — Beau James as he was known — presided over the city as mayor, succumbing to Jazz Age seductions more easily than he did to the demands of municipal governance. Speakeasies, boxing matches, Broadway, mistresses, expensive clothes — these were his pastimes when he found himself in town, but often he found himself elsewhere. During his first two years in office he is said to have taken seven vacations totaling 143 days.

headline: Sass and Slow-Motion Bullets
abstract: “Gunslingers,” opening Sunday on the American Heroes Channel, combines re-enactments of events in the Old West with expert narration and amusing camera tricks.
lead_paragraph: You can always learn something by watching television. On Sunday night, it’s this:

headline: Shakespeare’s Shipwrecked Twins Settle on the Asphalt and Astroturf
abstract: An outdoor “Twelfth Night” is underway as part of the Drilling Company’s Shakespeare in the Parking Lot.
lead_paragraph: The Delacorte it ain’t.

headline: Negotiators Agree to Extend Iran Nuclear Talks Four More Months, Diplomats Say
abstract: Iran, the United States and five other countries agreed to a four-month extension as they try to bridge a divide over whether Iran must dismantle parts of its nuclear program, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Iran, the United States and the five other countries negotiating the future of the Iranian nuclear program have agreed to a four-month extension of the talks, giving them more time to try to bridge major differences over whether Tehran will be forced to dismantle parts of its nuclear infrastructure, according to a statement released early Saturday in Vienna by all seven nations.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Spingold Knockout Teams
abstract: The Spingold Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Summer North American Championships taking place in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Spingold Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Summer North American Championships taking place here.

headline: Under Cover: Silent Picture
abstract: The magazine’s editors used a close-up image of Graham Spanier, Penn State’s former president, to illustrate Michael Sokolove’s cover story about his downfall.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sokolove’s cover story in this week’s magazine describes the downfall of Penn State’s former president, Graham Spanier. Gail Bichler, the magazine’s art director, said that because the article was about Spanier’s silence, she cropped Bryan Schutmaat’s portrait of him. ‘‘We thought focusing attention on his mouth was a powerful way to illustrate this,’’ she said. And Bichler said that showing him in casual dress (he also sat for photographs in a suit and tie) was a way to reflect the personal nature of Spanier’s discussions with Sokolove. The image was shot in color, but it was converted to black and white to give the cover a somber feel and make it more graphic.

headline: Bill Cunningham | In Black and White
abstract: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer.
lead_paragraph: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer.

headline: A Broadway Tale: A Little Web Series and How It Grew
abstract: The comedy “It Could Be Worse,” created by two Broadway actors, has moved to the streaming service Hulu for its second season.
lead_paragraph: Although, as Wesley Taylor says, “show business is the best platform for humiliation,” he and his fellow Broadway performer Mitchell Jarvis have turned their personal and professional setbacks into victories. Their DIY web series, “It Could Be Worse,” about a struggling and somewhat hapless actor played by Mr. Taylor, seems to be doing better in its career than the fictional character at its center.

headline: Bill Cunningham | In Black and White
abstract: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer.
lead_paragraph: Black and white pack a particular punch midsummer. New this year are skirts and dresses of Marimekko dotted fabric. There are stripes, too, in flattering diagonals. A whimsical backless jacket is held together with a ribbon at the neck. And then there are the leopards, zebras, pandas and long-earred furry friends who wear the color combo so well.

headline: They’re on a Boat!
abstract: New York’s new floating restaurants have had to navigate bureaucracy, bad weather and boat plumbing in an effort to redefine the once-stodgy dinner cruise.
lead_paragraph: As the early-evening sun blazed, the old Navy boat gently pushed into the East River and the 32 passengers were mindfully served cocktails, wine in tumblers and beer in cans. Life aboard the Revolution eased to two knots.

headline: Evening Hours | Toasts All Around
abstract: A week for dancing in the streets and celebrating athletes and artists.
lead_paragraph: A week for dancing in the streets and celebrating athletes and artists.

headline: Eileen Ford: Through the Years
abstract: Eileen Ford is remembered for her legacy of scouting models and building her business into an empire.
lead_paragraph: Eileen Ford is remembered for her legacy of scouting models and building her business into an empire.

headline: The Pickpocket’s Tale
abstract: As younger thieves turn to high-tech crimes, one of New York’s old-fashioned wallet snatchers recalls his decades-long career, from behind bars.
lead_paragraph: Wilfred Rose, 58, spent a career studying the pants pockets of New Yorkers, always on the lookout for “a nice stiff wallet” full of cash, or better yet, the fainter outline of a dozen folded bills.

headline: Does Poetry Matter?
abstract: Sunday's New York Times Book Review featured several new collections of poems. But does poetry matter? Is it relevant?

headline: Eileen Ford’s Legacy
abstract: For a time, there was no more powerful person in fashion than Eileen Ford, particularly for the young women she discovered and made into stars.
lead_paragraph: When Lauren Hutton first arrived in New York in the early 1960s, there was little to suggest she would soon become one of fashion’s highest-paid models and, later, an alluring actress paired with leading men like James Caan and Richard Gere.

headline: Waterfront Developments
abstract: Peter’s Clam Bar, a local institution since 1939, was ravaged by by Hurricane Sandy but has reopened under new ownership.
lead_paragraph: When Peter’s Clam Bar first opened in Island Park, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was in the White House, Hitler was menacing Europe, “The Wizard of Oz” was in movie theaters and Island Park’s homegrown politician, former Senator Alphonse M. D’Amato, was a toddler. It managed to stick around for 73 years, until it was ravaged by Hurricane Sandy in 2012. In June, Peter’s reopened, under new ownership.

headline: Lost and Found in Space
abstract: A crowd-funded project to rescue a derelict spaceship shows that exploration doesn’t belong just to governments and billionaires.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — WHEN we think about space missions, what generally comes to mind are large rooms filled with rocket scientists at consoles that control expensive new spacecraft doing unintelligible things. That’s still the norm but, in fact, there doesn’t need to be an entrance exam for people who want to explore space, and we’ve proved it.

headline: Don’t Blame Malaysia Airlines
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Pilots', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Flight 17 didn’t shoot itself down.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — ALMOST as soon as the news broke about the shooting down of a Malaysia Airlines flight over Ukraine on Thursday, in which all 298 passengers and crew members were killed, people began to ask: What was a commercial aircraft doing over a conflict zone in the first place? Was this disaster somehow the airline’s fault?

headline: Tibetan Leader, a Red Sox Fan, Knows the Value of Taking the Long View
abstract: Lobsang Sangay, Tibet’s prime minister in exile, has learned to draw strength from unfulfilled aspirations as he faces criticism and meager prospects for autonomy.
lead_paragraph: DHARAMSALA, India — From his office in the hill station of Dharamsala, where Tibetan exiles have spent the past half-century waiting for the seismic changes that could restore Tibet’s independence, Prime Minister Lobsang Sangay was reminiscing, a bit wistfully, about a world he had left behind.

headline: A Neighborhood Place in the Right Spot
abstract: The chef Paul Vuli returns to a familiar spot, which he ran as Fortuna a decade ago, offering fresh takes on classic Italian dishes.
lead_paragraph: Italian food is not hard to come by in Westchester County. Just about every town has at least one pizzeria, and many have several. More ambitious Italian restaurants, those where the wine list includes a Barolo or two and the menu goes beyond calzones, garlic knots and Neapolitan pies, are less common. And good ambitious Italian restaurants are rarer still.

headline: Putin’s Deadly Doctrine
abstract: The right to protect one’s “people” — where does it end? In blood.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — SOMETIMES, just sometimes, you should pay attention to annoying things said by tiresome people at worthy conferences.

headline: White House Opens Door to Exploring Atlantic for Oil
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Environment', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: The Obama administration’s approval of guidelines for seismic searches for oil and gas in the Atlantic Ocean handed the petroleum industry a significant victory over environmental groups.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration approved guidelines on Friday for seismic searches for oil and gas deposits in the Atlantic Ocean, handing the petroleum industry a significant victory in a bitter dispute with environmental groups over the searches’ impact on marine life.

headline: A Loss (Sabathia, for the Season) Before a Win for the Yankees
abstract: After Brian Cashman said C. C. Sabathia would have an arthroscopic debridement procedure next week, David Phelps helped the Yankees beat the Reds in their return from the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: The news that C. C. Sabathia would have knee surgery and miss the rest of the season was hardly stunning: He experienced pain and swelling the day after pitching for Class AA Trenton on July 2 and was shut down, making surgery the most likely course of action.

headline: Needing Skilled Workers, a Booming Germany Woos Immigrants
abstract: The country is competing more aggressively with the United States, Britain and other nations to attract and keep educated people from abroad.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — After just a few months in Germany, Cristina Torres knows she would like to stay here in Berlin, where her husband is studying global production engineering and their 21-month-old daughter can grow up in safety.

headline: A Sumptuous Supper and Setting
abstract: The new restaurant in the Mayflower Grace hotel, formerly the Mayflower Inn, serves the healthful and the rich.
lead_paragraph: Luxury at the Mayflower Grace hotel, in the Litchfield County town of Washington, is embodied in its parklike setting, by its two-story antique-laden entrance foyer, and by its spa services that go well beyond massages, facials and miscellaneous scrubs and wraps. Luxury is also evident in its restaurant, Muse by Jonathan Cartwright, where candles and sterling silver salt and pepper shakers adorn linen-draped tables, and veranda seating overlooks an exquisitely manicured garden.

headline: Tom Tierney, Who Made Paper Dolls an Art Form, Dies at 85
abstract: A spate of diminutive two-dimensional figures sprang to life on Mr. Tierney’s drawing board, including American presidents, monarchs and silver-screen stars.
lead_paragraph: Tom Tierney, who quite by accident found fame and fortune dressing — and undressing — notables from George Washington to Greta Garbo to Pope John Paul II, died on July 12 at his home in Smithville, Tex. Mr. Tierney, who almost single-handedly revived the lost art of paper-doll making, was 85.

headline: Dust Still Settling in Aftermath of Move by LeBron James
abstract: James’s decision to return to Cleveland set in motion a series of free-agency-related developments that has left few teams unaffected.
lead_paragraph: Nobody expected N.B.A. free agency to be dull or predictable, and even the leaguewide holding pattern as the game’s top player evaluated his options this month was fraught with intrigue. LeBron James was in control of the process, his decision to return to the Cleveland Cavaliers instantly setting in motion dozens of interconnected moves.

headline: Two Ex-Players Say Players Union Withheld Information
abstract: Christian Ballard and Gregory Westbrooks assert that the players association knew but did not disclose the dangers of hits to the head.
lead_paragraph: Two retired professional football players sued the N.F.L. Players Association for concealing from them information about the dangers of repeated head hits. The lawsuit filed on Thursday in United States District Court in Missouri echoes hundreds of similar cases against the N.F.L. and may represent a new front in the legal battle over concussions in sports.

headline: Ethiopia: Bloggers and Journalists Are Charged as Terrorists
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Three Ethiopian journalists and six bloggers were charged with planning terrorist attacks during a court hearing in Addis Ababa on Friday morning, nearly three months after they were arrested.
lead_paragraph: Three Ethiopian journalists and six bloggers were charged with planning terrorist attacks during a court hearing in Addis Ababa on Friday morning, nearly three months after they were arrested. The charges, under a sweeping antiterrorism law passed in 2009, were dismissed by the defendants’ lawyer, Ameha Mekonnen, as lacking specificity. “If you read the text between the lines, it doesn’t make any sense,” he said. “It’s nonsense.” Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn of Ethiopia said late Friday, however, that the case had nothing to do with the defendants’ profession. “I don’t think becoming a blogger makes somebody immune, if someone involves into this terrorist network that destabilizes my country,” he said.

headline: Embrace the Fuzz of New Jersey’s Peaches
abstract: New Jersey is the fourth-largest peach producing state. Midsummer is the ideal time to visit one of the state’s pick-your-own farms or to attend one of its peach-related festivals.
lead_paragraph: At Demarest Farms in Hillsdale, midsummer brings peach season, when Jason DeGise and James Spollen, the owners, are constantly reminded that the public can be out of touch with peaches in their natural state.

headline: NBC Correspondent Ayman Mohyeldin Is Returned to Gaza
abstract: Ayman Mohyeldin was reinstated by the network after he was removed following postings on Twitter that stirred controversy, although NBC did not make any public comment.
lead_paragraph: Only days after NBC removed him from its coverage of the fighting in Gaza, the correspondent Ayman Mohyeldin will be reinstated and sent back into the region, the network said Friday evening.

headline: Central American Leaders to Meet Obama on Migrants
abstract: The presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras will discuss efforts to stop the flow of children through Mexico and into the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has summoned the presidents of Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras to the White House next week in an effort to demonstrate high-level cooperation to stanch the flow of migrant children from Central America through Mexico and into the United States.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lake Street Dive, What I’m Doing Here
abstract: I ain’t got a clue.
lead_paragraph: When I heard this I assumed it was an old standard — but no, Rachael Price wrote it, and the performance … well, just listen.

headline: Questions on Funding for Lawyer in Terror Case
abstract: Months before a Libyan terrorism defendant is scheduled for trial in Manhattan, a dispute has arisen over who is paying his legal fees.
lead_paragraph: Just months before a Libyan terrorism defendant is scheduled for trial in Manhattan, a dispute has arisen over who is paying his legal fees and whether his poor health would interfere with resolving that issue.

headline: Israel Ready to Expand Ground Forces
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that the Israeli military was ready for a “significant expansion” of ground forces in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that the Israeli military was ready for a “significant expansion” of ground forces in Gaza.

headline: Part-Time Schedules, Full-Time Headaches
abstract: New York Times readers responded to an article published Wednesday about part-time and on-call work with their own experiences.
lead_paragraph: A worker at an apparel store at Woodbury Common, an outlet mall north of New York City, said that even though some part-time employees clamored for more hours, the store had hired more part-timers and cut many workers’ hours to 10 a week from 20.

headline: ISIS Forces Last Iraqi Christians to Flee Mosul
abstract: An era of tolerance for different religions appeared to have come to an abrupt end as minority sects sought sanctuary from militants in Christian enclaves.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — By 1 p.m. on Friday almost every Christian in Mosul had heard the Sunni militants’ message — they had until noon Saturday to leave the city.

headline: When Settlement Buys Time
abstract: Ex-players who oppose the N.F.L.’s concussion settlement struggle with the knowledge that they are keeping payments from others with life-threatening conditions like A.L.S.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Kevin Turner and Sean Morey played a combined 17 years in the N.F.L. They were never teammates, but they became friends in 2010 when they worked with the Mackey-White Traumatic Brain Injury Committee for disabled retirees. They consulted with doctors studying the effects of concussions on football players. Morey raised money for Turner’s foundation after Turner received a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., four years ago.

headline: From a Local Artist, the Great Outdoors
abstract: “Don Resnick: Essence of Place,” which includes paintings, water colors and drawings by the artist, is on display at the Emily Lowe Gallery.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, Beth E. Levinthal, the executive director of the Hofstra University Museum, received an intriguing call from a member of the family of Don Resnick, a Long Island landscape painter who had died the year before at age 80: Would the museum, the caller wondered, like to be given a few of the artist’s paintings?

headline: A Classroom Leaves the Syllabus to the Students
abstract: Lehigh University, in an attempt to foster innovation, is offering a program with no course credit, no set curriculum and no penalty for failure.
lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — The scene in a cavernous building atop a forested hill here resembles a brainy, free-form summer camp, or a loft where twentysomethings meet to pursue esoteric dreams. It does not look like the usual notion of college.

headline: Astros Fail to Sign Top Pick; Holliday Paces Cards to Win
abstract: The California pitcher Brady Aiken became only the third player in the history of the draft not to sign after being selected as the top choice.
lead_paragraph: On June 5, the night of the baseball draft, Reid Ryan, the Houston Astros’ president of business operations, tweeted a photo of a Brady Aiken jersey in a team gift shop.

headline: Pakistan’s Struggle Against Polio
abstract: The international community must pay more attention if the uncontrolled outbreak is to be contained.
lead_paragraph: The campaign in Pakistan to contain an uncontrolled outbreak of polio hit an alarming point this week when the nation’s tally of new cases exceeded last year’s total of 93, with months to go in the emergency effort to vaccinate children over fierce opposition from the Taliban.

headline: New Art at Parrish: Theater
abstract: Two sons of the Hamptons will present the world premiere of an adaptation of the 1985 Kurt Vonnegut novel “Galápagos” in Water Mill.
lead_paragraph: Since opening its sleek, barnlike headquarters on the East End two years ago, the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill has expanded its cultural agenda to include circus arts, jazz and yoga. Now the museum can add live theater to the mix. This month it will present the world premiere of an adaptation of the 1985 Kurt Vonnegut novel “Galápagos.”

headline: At Long Last, Justice for Ronnie White
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: The Senate confirmation of a judge for a Federal District Court seat in Missouri is 15 years overdue.
lead_paragraph: In Congress, as in life, circumstances seldom collide to allow correction of a glaring injustice. Yet that is what happened in the Senate on Wednesday, when the chamber confirmed Ronnie White for a seat on the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri.

headline: General Motors Resists Expanding Victims’ Fund
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles', 'Consumer Protection', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: The company maintains that a distinct difference exists between its recall of 2.6 million older Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars, and has refused to expand a compensation fund, infuriating safety advocates.
lead_paragraph: The cars are different, but the circumstances surrounding their recall are strikingly similar.

headline: Arizona: Mom of Boys Left in Car May Be Spared Charge
abstract: A prosecutor has agreed to drop felony child abuse charges against Shanesha Taylor, 35, a homeless mother who left her two sons in a hot car while she went to a job interview.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor has agreed to drop felony child abuse charges against Shanesha Taylor, 35, a homeless mother who left her two sons in a hot car while she went to a job interview, if she completes parenting and substance abuse treatment programs and sets up trust funds for her children. The money is to come from the $115,000 donated to Ms. Taylor after her case drew national attention.  Bill Montgomery, the Maricopa County attorney, said the deal would hold Ms. Taylor accountable “while also recognizing the best interests of her family.” She is seeking to regain custody of her children, who were placed in foster care after her arrest.

headline: G.M. Rebuked in the Senate
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Consumer Protection', 'Editorials', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: At a hearing of a subcommittee on consumer protection, a corporate culture “of lawyering up” is chastised.
lead_paragraph: A consistent theme in the emerging revelations about General Motors’ deadly ignition switch has been the central role the company’s legal department played in concealing the problem from the public, government safety regulators and purchasers for more than a decade.

headline: Israel’s War in Gaza
abstract: The tragedy of the military action is that innocent civilians on both sides of the border are paying the price, once again.
lead_paragraph: After 10 days of aerial bombardment, Israel sent tanks and ground troops into Gaza to keep Hamas from pummeling Israeli cities with rockets and carrying out terrorist attacks via underground tunnels. The tragedy is that innocent civilians on both sides of the border are paying the price, once again, and that military action will not guarantee long-term stability or peace.

headline: Padres’ Offense May Go Down as Worst Ever
abstract: If the San Diego Padres’ offensive output remains the same through the end of the season, it could tie the 1968 Yankees for the lowest mark in the last 100 years.
lead_paragraph: Because of baseball’s long history, there is usually comfort in knowing that as bad as it gets for your team, there is almost always some other club that was worse. But the 2014 San Diego Padres might not have that consolation. At this point, their awful offense is about as bad as any in history, and there are still more than 60 games to be played.

headline: Downing of Jet Exposes Defects of Flight Precautions Over Ukraine
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL']
abstract: Flight restrictions underestimated the risks to a startling degree, leaving Flight 17 exposed at 33,000 feet to missiles known to fly to more than twice that height.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — As this Southeast Asian nation mourns the loss of scores of passengers aboard another lost Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200, the precautions instituted by the aviation authorities and flight planners to protect commercial aviation along the Russian-Ukrainian border have been shown to be catastrophically insufficient.

headline: Stop. Hey, What’s That Sound?
abstract: An exhibition of sound art offers works that address global issues, but also grow out of their creators’ affinity for specific spots amid Caramoor’s formidable flora and fountains.
lead_paragraph: If, as the sound artist Stephan Moore likes to say, the laptop has become the 21st-century folk instrument, then the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah has propelled itself to the forefront of that development, commissioning and bringing to its 90-acre campus an exhibition of sound art featuring 10 works by 11 laptop-wielding artists.

headline: The $300,000 Drug
abstract: Miracle cystic fibrosis treatment carries a heavy price.
lead_paragraph: Kalydeco is truly a wonder drug.

headline: For High School Senior, It’s Clarinet First, Then Homework
abstract: Phillip H. Solomon, a senior at Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose, was chosen to play in the tour of the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America.
lead_paragraph: Phillip H. Solomon, a senior at Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose, did not expect to win a position as a clarinetist in the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America.  “Every young musician I know had applied,” Mr. Solomon, 16, said.

headline: UConn to Pay $1.3 Million to End Suit on Rape Cases
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'College Athletics']
abstract: Five students charged that the University of Connecticut treated their claims of sexual assault and harassment with indifference.
lead_paragraph: The University of Connecticut will pay $1.28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by five students who charged that the university had treated their claims of sexual assault and harassment with indifference, the two sides announced on Friday in a joint statement.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 18, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Netherlands, a Nation in Mourning but Mindful of Ties to Russia
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: For the Dutch, the prospect that Russian-backed separatists might be responsible for the loss of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 poses a dilemma.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Flags flew at half-staff Friday in this small but extremely international country, one that is accustomed to standing on the forefront of global cultural debates over such things as gay rights, euthanasia and marijuana policies. But on Thursday, after the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the Netherlands found itself thrust squarely into an unaccustomed role at the center of the realpolitik of the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: Next Gold Rush: Legal Marijuana Feeds Entrepreneurs’ Dreams
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Many investors and job-seekers are flocking to Washington and Colorado to take advantage of the legal marijuana industry, but the risks can be high and the rewards nonexistent.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Like the glint of gold or rumors of oil in ages past, the advent of legal, recreational marijuana is beginning to reshape economies in Colorado and Washington State.

headline: Presidents Find Occasions, Far More than Occasionally, for Proclamations
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The practice of scoring political points with official documents has flourished since the Truman administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on May 30 issued a proclamation formally declaring June as Great Outdoors Month. President Obama reaffirmed his commitment to preserving the nation’s lands and waters, and urged all Americans to “explore the great outdoors.”

headline: Relaxed Thief Is Videotaped as He Browses
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Education (K-12)', 'Charter Schools', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A burglar entered the Red Rabbit, a business that sells healthy meals for schoolchildren, and made off with two laptops and maybe something from the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: There is a white board marked “Food for Thought” inside the office door at Red Rabbit, a business that sells healthy meals for schoolchildren, and every morning an employee jots an inspirational or funny quotation with a marker. The board served a less whimsical purpose on July 4.

headline: With Grief on Top of Grief, Malaysians Are Tested on Flight 370’s Lessons
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Anger over Malaysia Airline’s decision to fly the Ukraine route could prove a new challenge for the government four months after another plane operated by the carrier disappeared.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Still raw from the loss of one airliner four months ago, Malaysians on Friday confronted the improbable loss of another passenger jet, this time the victim of a conflict far from home.

headline: A Young Mother, Damaged by the War
abstract: In Tammy Ryan’s play at the Zella Fry Theater, nightmares fester for a Marine and single mother as flashbacks trace what happened during her deployment to Iraq.
lead_paragraph: The problem of sexual abuse in the American military system is the subject of “Soldier’s Heart,” a new drama by Tammy Ryan. This sometimes compelling play is currently presented in Union by Premiere Stages, which produced her “Lost Boy Found in Whole Foods” in 2010.

headline: A Mother Asks Obama: ‘Please Remember My Amir’
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Iranian-Americans', 'United States International Relations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The letter from Behnaz Hekmati, the mother of Amir Hekmati, appeared timed to convey the family’s wish that the United States use its leverage in the talks to win his release.
lead_paragraph: The mother of Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent imprisoned in Tehran for nearly three years, has written to President Obama, asking him to “please remember my Amir” in the negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program.

headline: For the G.O.P., Fine Line Seen on Migration

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:30 P.M. (History) THE UNKNOWN KNOWN (2013) The director Errol Morris and the former defense secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld square off in a battle of wits and words on topics including truth, power, torture and the Iraq war as Mr. Rumsfeld, above, reads aloud from a dozen or so of the most memorable memos — or “snowflakes,” as they were known at the Pentagon — he composed during his six-year tenure in the administration of George W. Bush. “Yes, it is a probing and unsettling inquiry into the recent political and military history of the United States, but it is also a bracing and invigorating philosophical skirmish,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The tension between those two registers — between hard facts about state violence and devilish abstractions about causes and consequences — is what gives the film some of its energy and suspense.” The film, he added, “is a cat-and-mouse game in which each player thinks he’s the cat, making it both thrilling and disconcerting to watch. It is also a nature documentary about behavior at the very top of the imperial food chain and a detective story about the search for a mystery that is hidden in plain sight.”

headline: What Writers Can Learn From ‘Goodnight Moon’
abstract: The children’s book sets up a world and then subverts its own rules even as it follows them.
lead_paragraph: I gave birth to twins a little more than a year ago, and at the baby showers we received many books: colorful board books, big illustrated books, collections of Sandra Boynton and nursery rhymes and Dr. Seuss, but none multiple times except this one: a board book “Goodnight Moon,” a flimsy “Goodnight Moon,” a large lap book “Goodnight Moon,” and an anthology by the book’s author, Margaret Wise Brown. Of course, I thought. It’s that one that says good night a lot. I figured I’d read it before, just a story of going around the room saying good night to stuff, and I thought it was popular as a gift because it’s so appropriate for bedtime and everybody wants babies to sleep.

headline: Frack Quietly, Please: Sage Grouse Is Nesting
keywords: ['Grouse (Bird)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Land Use Policies', 'Environment', 'Biodiversity']
abstract: The greater sage grouse might be declared an endangered species, restricting development of its habitat, leading the energy industry and the government to try to save the bird.
lead_paragraph: CASPER, Wyo. — In a new oil field among the rolling hills near here, Chesapeake Energy limits truck traffic to avoid disturbing the breeding and nesting of a finicky bird called the greater sage grouse. To the west, on a gas field near Yellowstone National Park, Shell Oil is sowing its own special seed mix to grow plants that nourish the birds and hide their chicks from predators.

headline: A Golf Hazard on the Way to a Tournament
keywords: ['Golf', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'AIRPORTS', 'Luggage', 'British Open (Golf)']
abstract: For golfers, whose success is predicated on acting only after a careful consideration of the odds, there is no greater leap of faith than entrusting their golf bags to a network of strangers.
lead_paragraph: HOYLAKE, England — On the first leg of Gary Woodland’s British Open odyssey, he glanced out the airplane porthole in time to see a baggage handler at Kansas City International Airport haul his golf bag out of a cart, drop it on the tarmac and fling another suitcase on top of it. The sight of the tools of his trade being treated with such little care made Woodland so agitated that his fiancée told him to turn away from the window.

headline: Usher Signals
abstract: Many ushers communicate during church services using a sequence of hand signals called the “National Silent Uniform System.” Here are some of the central elements of these signals.
lead_paragraph: Many ushers communicate during church services using a sequence of hand signals called the “National Silent Uniform System.” Here are some of the central elements of these signals.

headline: Influx of South Americans Drives Miami’s Reinvention
abstract: As South Americans flock to Miami, their influence has transformed the city’s once recession-dampened downtown, enriched its culture and magnified its allure for businesses.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As the World Cup played out over the past month, yellow-clad Colombians packed the Kukaramakara nightclub downtown, Aguila beers in hand, shouting, “Colombia, Colombia!” Outside, Brazilians in car caravans blasted samba music. Argentines, some in blue-and-white striped jerseys, jammed into nearby steakhouses and empanada joints. Around town, children filed into Sunday Mass, their jerseys ablaze with their futbol heroes from across Latin America.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 20

lead_paragraph: With two foreign crises — the Malaysia Airlines plane downed in Ukraine and the Israeli ground invasion in the Gaza Strip — erupting, Secretary of State John Kerry will appear on five Sunday talk shows, on ABC, CBS, CNN, NBC, and Fox News.

headline: On Southern Border, Mexico Faces Crisis of Its Own
abstract: Mexico has announced plans for tightened deportation and border control policies as its migrant numbers surge in response to worsening gang violence in Central America.
lead_paragraph: TENOSIQUE, Mexico — For years, Mexico’s most closely watched border was its northern one, which generations of Mexican migrants have crossed seeking employment and refuge in the United States.

headline: In Remote Corners of India, Immunity for Soldiers Who Kill and Rape Civilians
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Immunity from Prosecution']
abstract: In remote areas like Kashmir, and Manipur State, a colonial-era immunity law continues to embolden soldiers and police officers there to commit crimes without bothering to cover them up.
lead_paragraph: MAYAI LEIKAI, India — A dozen soldiers burst through the front and back doors of a small home here in the middle of a July night, dragged Thangjam Manorama into a room and began to torture her. Her older brother tried to stop them and was badly beaten. Her mother rose to defend her and was knocked unconscious.

headline: Pathogen Mishaps Rise as Regulators Stay Clear
abstract: The recent number of mistakes documented at federal laboratories involving anthrax, flu and smallpox viruses have contributed to a debate over lax government oversight at high-level containment labs.
lead_paragraph: The recently documented mistakes at federal laboratories involving anthrax, flu and smallpox have incited public outrage at the government’s handling of dangerous pathogens. But the episodes were just a tiny fraction of the hundreds that have occurred in recent years across a sprawling web of academic, commercial and government labs that operate without clear national standards or oversight, federal reports show.

headline: Second Day’s Effort Pays for a Climber From Poland
abstract: Rafal Majka, a Polish climbing specialist, won Stage 14 of the Tour de France, and Vincenzo Nibali finished in second to extend his overall lead.
lead_paragraph: RISOUL, France — For Rafal Majka, persistence paid off on Saturday. The day before, Majka, a Polish climbing specialist, found himself off the front of the final Alpine climb of a Tour de France stage with Leopold Konig, a Czech rider. But the two fell victim to a show of force from the Tour leader, Vincenzo Nibali, who passed them for the win.
