headline: New Dimension in Scoreboard Watching
keywords: ['Football', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Television Sets and Media Devices']
abstract: Daktronics, in Brookings, S.D., has become one of the largest makers of sports video displays as teams try to recreate the living room experience in their parks.
lead_paragraph: BROOKINGS, S.D. — The seemingly endless prairie that blankets this part of the United States would seem to be an unlikely place for one of the largest makers of sports video displays, Daktronics. After all, the nearest big-league ballpark is a four-hour drive from this town, which has barely enough residents to fill any of the arenas and stadiums where the high-tech screens are fixtures.

headline: Arsenal Refilled, a New Yankee Throws a Gem

lead_paragraph: During his time with the Arizona Diamondbacks, Brandon McCarthy was told by the team to stop throwing his cut fastball, a pitch that had been essential to his success over the years.

headline: Readers Comment on my Middle East Column
abstract: My Sunday column criticizes the Israeli invasion of Gaza. Here readers have their chance to weigh in.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about the Middle East crisis and the Israeli incursion into Gaza—but, more fundamentally, about the way hardliners on each side have dominated the narrative and created conditions in which hardliners on the other side are empowered. And the reasonable folks, such as Mahmoud Abbas on the Palestinian side and the Labor Party and liberal civil society on the Israeli side, become somewhat marginalized.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A jury in northwestern Florida awarded a staggering $23 billion judgment late Friday against the country’s second-largest tobacco company for causing the death of a chain smoker who died of lung cancer at the age of 36.

headline: Before Leaving Tour de France, a Rider Displays a Champion’s Endurance

lead_paragraph: Andrew Talansky, one of the United States’ top road cyclists, never expected to spend the second half of the Tour de France on a lounge chair at his pool in Girona, Spain, with an ice pack chilling his ailing back and gauze covering several spots on his body now missing layers of skin.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least 21 Egyptian soldiers were killed on Saturday when heavily armed gunmen attacked a border guard post near a remote desert oasis, according to an army spokesman.

headline: Always Inflation Somewhere
abstract: So you can always be hysterical.
lead_paragraph: Whenever you point out that the hyperinflation the usual suspects have been predicting for the past 6 years hasn’t materialized, you get a rash of comments declaring that yes it has, the government is just lying about the statistics. One answer — aside from come on, how do you think that works? — is that independent measures, like the Billion Price Index, aren’t very different from the official index. Still, people will point to the price of something that has gone up as evidence that we have lots of inflation.

headline: A Three-Sibling Rivalry Extends to the Pro Ranks

headline: Shake-Up on Opium Island
abstract: Tasmania, with its huge poppy crop, is the top producer of a crucial raw material in prescription drugs. But companies fear that they depend too much on that harvest.
lead_paragraph: Now is the sowing season for opium poppies in the Australian state of Tasmania. Tractors chug up and down paddocks, pulling elaborate machinery that drills pairs of adjacent, miniature holes in the dirt, and then drops a dozen tiny kernels of fertilizer in one of the holes and a tiny poppy seed in the other.

headline: Moving Parts

These letters will move to a pair of circles elsewhere in the puzzle. (In all cases, new words will be formed.) The nine letter pairs, when properly arranged, will spell an appropriate answer at 72-Across.”

The bunt appeared to be poorly executed, hit too sharply to first. The fielder, Gaby Sanchez, fielded it cleanly and intercepted Hamilton’s path to the bag. But Hamilton was gone.

headline: Yehuda Nir, a Psychiatrist and Holocaust Survivor, Dies at 84
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: As a child, Dr. Nir had to masquerade as a Roman Catholic in German-occupied Poland, an ordeal that he turned into a well-received memoir and that guided him in treating victims of trauma.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Yehuda Nir, a psychiatrist whose childhood was shaped by having to masquerade as a Roman Catholic in German-occupied Poland to escape Nazi persecution, an ordeal that he turned into a well-received memoir and that guided him in treating victims of trauma, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Complaints About Chokeholds Are Focus of Study
abstract: Two days after a Staten Island man died following a police encounter in which a chokehold appeared to be used, the city is looking into the more than 1,000 complaints it has received in recent years about police officers using the hold.
lead_paragraph: The city agency that investigates allegations of police misconduct is studying the more than 1,000 complaints it has received in recent years about police officers using chokeholds, the agency said on Saturday, two days after a man died following a police encounter in which the hold appeared to be used.

headline: In Hospitals Across Gaza, Scenes of Chaos and Grief
abstract: Hospitals that were poorly equipped and staffed even before the Israeli military operation are struggling to cope with a surge of casualties from a war that continues to intensify.
lead_paragraph: JABALIYA CAMP, Gaza Strip — The ambulance at Kamal Adwan, the main hospital in the northern Gaza Strip, already had turned on its sirens to move a critically injured man to a better-equipped hospital. Several women blocked its way, one of them clinging to the vehicle and trying to open the side door. Only when she fainted from emotion could the ambulance leave.

abstract: While traditional cigarettes are banned from most jails, vendors of e-cigarettes, which vaporize a liquid solution for inhalation, see a big market in Texas.

headline: Neighborhood Ravaged on Deadliest Day So Far for Both Sides in Gaza
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The withering assault on the neighborhood of Shejaiya, and the death of 87 Palestinians and 13 Israeli soldiers and officers, appeared to shake the international community.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — The mayhem began in the early hours of Sunday morning in Shejaiya, an eastern neighborhood of Gaza City, where Israeli forces battled with Hamas militants. Terrified civilians fled, sometimes past the bodies of those struck down in earlier artillery barrages. By dusk it was clear that Sunday was the deadliest single day for the Palestinians in the latest conflict and the deadliest for the Israeli military in years.

headline: As Anger Rises Over Crash, Malaysian Government Is Reluctant to Assign Blame
abstract: Officials have so far avoided joining the United States and many other countries in openly attributing the disaster to the Russian government.

headline: With Poncho, Custom Weather Alerts That Say When to Pack an Umbrella

headline: Bodies From Malaysia Airlines Flight Are Stuck in Ukraine, Held Hostage Over Distrust
abstract: World leaders expressed a growing outrage over pro-Russian rebels’ refusal to cede authority over the site where the downed jet’s debris is scattered.
lead_paragraph: TOREZ, Ukraine — Three wrenching days after the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, the bodies of most of those aboard have ended up here, in a fly-infested railway station in a rough coal-mining town in eastern Ukraine.

headline: James Garner, Witty, Handsome Leading Man, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Garner was best known as the amiable gambler Bret Maverick in the 1950s western “Maverick” and the cranky sleuth Jim Rockford in the 1970s series “The Rockford Files.”
lead_paragraph: James Garner, the wry and handsome leading man who slid seamlessly between television and the movies but was best known as the amiable gambler Bret Maverick in the 1950s western “Maverick” and the cranky sleuth Jim Rockford in the 1970s series “The Rockford Files,” died on Saturday night at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Immaculate Incarceration: A Baby in Solitary Confinement
abstract: According to my mother’s prison records, she served around 17 weeks in “The Hole”—solitary confinement. Only for her it wasn’t so solitary. She had me.
lead_paragraph: At a time when most infants rock in cradles, take naps on grandma’s shoulder or play bouncy-bounce on a knee, I crawled around in a 4-by-6-foot concrete box the size of a small closet. Instead of the background lullaby from a pull toy in a crib, I would have heard “Chow time!” yelled through the slot in the steel door and then a slam — the food port in our prison cell in solitary confinement. I was born in prison; I spent part of the first year of my life in “the hole.”

headline: 1889: Jack The Ripper Said to Have Connection With Police
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Jack the Ripper strikes again in London in 1889.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the most interesting and, perhaps, significant points in connection with the murder of Alice Mackenzie is one to which much attention has not yet been called. At the time of the August, September and November murders last year the number of constables on patrol duty in what is known as the ‘‘murder district,’’ covered by Commercial street and Leman street stations, was strengthened by 100 extra men from other divisions. There were at that time 300 men in uniform and plain clothes on night duty in this comparatively small area. As the excitement died away this extra force was gradually diminished.

headline: De Blasio and Family Land in Rome, and the Cameras Start Snapping
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio began his Italian vacation by mixing business with pleasure — and impressed the paparazzi by loading his own baggage into the van carrying his family.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Mayor Bill de Blasio was having a paparazzi moment.

headline: What Millennials Want Is Cookies Shaped Like Pizza
abstract: Some say young people are “confused” about politics. They may be less confused about dessert.
lead_paragraph: A new survey of young Americans’ political views has some saying millennials are “incoherent” or “confused.” One company, however, knows exactly what they want and is committed to giving it to them.

headline: Kerry Says Russia Trained Separatists to Use Antiaircraft Missiles
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry stopped short of saying Russia provided the missile unit that downed Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In presenting the most detailed case yet alleging Russia’s involvement in the Ukraine crisis, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday that Russia had funneled large quantities of heavy weapons to Ukrainian separatists and trained them how to operate SA-11 antiaircraft missiles, the type of system that is believed to have been used to shoot down the Malaysian airliner over eastern Ukraine.

headline: A Parent Answering a Call for Pre-K Teachers Goes Back to Work (and School)
abstract: Lisa Martino is one of 95 fellows poised to become New York City’s newest teachers, as part of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s universal prekindergarten program.
lead_paragraph: Long before her campers tumble out of bed for breakfast, Lisa Martino is huddled over her kitchen table, poring over her graduate school textbooks and clack-clack-clacking on her laptop as she absorbs lessons on literacy and curriculum development.

headline: A Slow Weekend at Movie Theaters
abstract: Box-office sales at North American theaters were down 25 percent compared with the same three days last summer.
lead_paragraph: “Sex Tape” failed to perform. “Planes: Fire & Rescue” flew a bit low. And the third major newcomer at North American movie theaters, “The Purge: Anarchy,” had a smaller body count than its grisly franchise predecessor. That left the weekend box office down 25 percent compared with the same three days last summer, as the No. 1 movie in the United States and Canada was a hold-over: “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” (20th Century Fox), which took in an estimated $36 million, for a two-week domestic total of about $140 million.

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. Kerry strongly criticized Palestinian leaders on Sunday for rejecting a cease-fire plan, but he also appeared — in comments captured by a live microphone — to express exasperation with the high cost in civilian lives as Israel pressed its ground attack on Gaza.

headline: Bill Mulliken, Who Swam to Olympic Gold in 1960, Dies at 74
abstract: Mulliken was a little-known college swimmer when he outpaced the world-record holder in the 200-meter breaststroke in the 1960 Summer Games.
lead_paragraph: Bill Mulliken, a little-known college swimmer who outpaced national champions and the world-record holder in the 200-meter breaststroke to win gold in the 1960 Olympic Games, died on Thursday in Chicago. He was 74.

headline: 1964: Harlem Riots Flare Anew; 2 Negroes Shot
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Two people were shot in clashes between roving gangs and police in Harlem in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — For the third consecutive night police broke up an unruly, bottle-throwing crowd in the Negro community of Harlem tonight [July 20]. The steel-helmeted, nightstick-waving police scattered the two separate crowds without firing a pistol shot. Neither police nor members of the crowds were injured. Two Negroes were shot and wounded early today in clashes between roving gangs and scores of police. Bottles, rocks and Molotov cocktails rained down from tenement rooftops and smashed in the littered streets. In the weekend of riots, police said that one Negro was killed and 116 civilians and 18 policemen were injured. At least 45 stores were broken into and looted or damaged. The violence, and demands from civil-rights leaders that the city act to protect the Negroes, prompted the mayor’s office today to order a study of complaints of police brutality. Regular meetings between Harlem leaders and city officials were also arranged. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 21, 1964

headline: Today’s Students Don’t Have to Suffer if They Hate Their Roommates
abstract: Technology is providing some solutions to problems that college students have with their roommates.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, many colleges and universities have adopted online roommate matching programs that help incoming students look for and select their own first-year roommates. Like dating sites, the roommate analytics systems can match people based on preferences like music volume, sociability and even tolerance for snoring.

headline: Hoofing It From Hollywood
abstract: Marguerite Derricks, a Hollywood choreographer known for “Austin Powers” and “Showgirls,” among many other movies and TV shows, brings her skills to the Off Broadway “Heathers.”
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen a movie in the last 20 years, chances are you know the choreographer Marguerite Derricks’s work, if not her name. Austin Powers’s epic go-go dance through the streets? Ms. Derricks’s idea. Abigail Breslin’s climactic strip routine in “Little Miss Sunshine”? Ms. Derricks was just off camera, encouraging Ms. Breslin to claw like a tiger. Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt’s tango in “Mr. and Mrs. Smith”? Well, Ms. Derricks was Ms. Jolie’s first partner.

headline: A Man, a Van, a Plan
abstract: The Mana Contemporary arts complex in Jersey City remains one of the metropolitan area’s biggest cultural secrets and its namesake remains low profile.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — A year after its opening, the Mana Contemporary arts complex, on 35 acres here, remains largely unknown to the artgoing public. So does the man for whom it’s named.

headline: This Constant Reinvention Called Life
abstract: In “Lucky Us,” the novelist Amy Bloom describes the improvised passage through the 1940s by two half sisters, their father and loves.
lead_paragraph: These two things about Amy Bloom’s surprise-filled “Lucky Us” are indisputable: It opens with a terrific hook and closes with an image of exquisite resolution. But that opening sets off a string of serial adventures, and it’s not until the book ends that all the pieces fall into place. Ms. Bloom does not write deep-dish, straightforward yarns for readers who enjoy conventional drama. She writes sharp, sparsely beautiful scenes that excitingly defy expectation, and part of the pleasure of reading her is simply keeping up with her. You won’t know where “Lucky Us” is headed until, suddenly, it’s there.

headline: Out of Tune, and Seeking New Muses
abstract: The soprano Renée Fleming stars in her first role in a play in “Living on Love,” a new comedy about a theatrical couple handling hard times.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — When Renée Fleming tweets, she doesn’t confine herself to 140 characters. In the second act of “Living on Love,” a fun and flimsy entertainment at the Williamstown Theater Festival here, she glides into the room warbling sweetly. “Did I just hear the birds singing?” she asks. Then she looses several more soaring notes. “Oh no,” she says, as if surprised, “that was me.”

headline: A Reflection of the Heat, on a Pair of Pianos
abstract: This summer’s Jazz in July season will explore the music of Hoagy Carmichael, Leonard Bernstein and Miles Davis, among others.
lead_paragraph: The emblematic image of Jazz in July, the tried-and-true concert series at the 92nd Street Y, would probably be a pair of grand pianos facing each other across the stage. A New York City summer institution about to begin its 30th season, the festival has always found good use for that setup, drafting an impressive roster of jazz pianists into the service of musical dialogue. Among them are Dick Hyman, who founded Jazz in July and programmed its first two decades, and Bill Charlap, his handpicked successor.

lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Speaking, once again, of Ian Livengood, we have a debut today by a young man named Matt Fuchs, who met Mr. Livengood at a career day at their high school in Bethesda, Maryland. Mr. Livengood is an alumnus; Mr. Fuchs is still a student there.

headline: U.S. Naval Ties With China Advance, Symbolically
abstract: While the United States chief of naval operations was spending time aboard China’s aircraft carrier, the Chinese Navy was participating for the first time in the United States-led multinational exercises off Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: The United States chief of naval operations, Adm. Jonathan W. Greenert, visited China’s aircraft carrier last week, a symbolic step in the campaign the Pentagon is waging with Beijing for greater transparency even as the two navies become greater rivals.

headline: Man of Two Faces, One Broken Heart
abstract: Caramoor’s “Rigoletto” features some unusual tempos and Stephen Powell in the title role.
lead_paragraph: KATONAH, N.Y. — The title role of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” is one of the great Jekyll and Hyde operatic characters: a man of manipulative sneer in public and tender paternal love in private. His dual personalities were aptly illuminated at Caramoor on Saturday evening in a powerful performance by the baritone Stephen Powell.

headline: Unleashing Her Voice, With Ferocity and Finesse
abstract: The jazz singer Gabrielle Stravelli wielded her powerful instrument to entrance an appreciative audience during her opening show on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the jazz singer Gabrielle Stravelli is like imbibing a potent cocktail whose flavor changes as you drain the glass. In the first couple of sips, the predominant taste is the sparkling wine that has drifted to the top, for Ms. Stravelli’s bright, rippling voice exudes a natural effervescence. Before long, it darkens, and the heady liquor underneath kicks in.

headline: Revisiting the Facts, After the Convictions
abstract: “The Newburgh Sting,” an HBO documentary, makes extensive use of F.B.I. surveillance to offer a case that the four New York men convicted in a bomb plot were framed.
lead_paragraph: The case made — convincingly — by the documentary “The Newburgh Sting” is that the four upstate New York men convicted of plotting to bomb synagogues in the Bronx and destroy airplanes in 2009 were the fall guys in an elaborate, cinematic performance orchestrated by the F.B.I. The film, showing Monday on HBO, offers a competing narrative to the one presented at trial and in the news media by the government. So far, the government’s story is winning: The men are all serving 25-year sentences in federal prisons.

headline: ‘Deliverance’ to Open 59E59’s New Season
abstract: A stage adaptation of James Dickey’s “Deliverance” will open the fall and winter season at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: A stage adaptation of James Dickey’s “Deliverance” will open the fall and winter season at 59E59 Theaters, that Off Broadway organization announced on Sunday. Based on the 1970 novel, which also inspired the 1972 movie of the same name starring Burt Reynolds, Jon Voight, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox about an ill-fated canoe trip through the backwoods of Georgia, “Deliverance” is slated to have its world premiere on Oct. 10 as part of the Godlight Theater Company’s 20th anniversary celebration. Because of the more graphic scenes of the story, approving the theatrical version a “was quite a decision to make,” Peter Tear, 59E59’s executive producer, said by phone. He said that the playwright Sean Tyler, who adapted the story, had done “a tremendous job.” Other season highlights include “On a Stool at the End of the Bar ”(Nov. 14 through Dec. 14), Robert Callely’s work about a family’s reaction to a loved one’s long-held secret. Alex Webb’s “Cafe Society Swing: A True Story,” a musical revue based on the 1940s jazz venue that became New York City’s first racially integrated nightclub, will follow from Dec. 16 through Jan. 4. That will also represent the return of Evan Pappas (“Chorus Line,” “My Favorite Year,”) to New York stages for the first time since 2007, when he was badly injured in a car accident while touring with “On Golden Pond.” “Evan was one of those adored New York performers,” Mr. Tear said. “So people were terribly excited to hear he’s coming back.” Also slated for the season is the Crossroads Theater Company’s production of Walter Mosley’s “Lift” (Oct. 21 through Nov. 30); Little Opera Theater of New York’s performance of Carlisle Floyd’s “Slow Dusk” and “Markheim” (Dec. 5 through 14); and “Beware of Young Girls: Kate Dimbleby Sings the Dory Previn Story” (Dec. 16 through Jan. 4). More information is at 59e59.org.

headline: Regular Gig for Patti LuPone
abstract: Patti LuPone has signed on to appear at the supper club 54 Below regularly through 2016.
lead_paragraph: Two years after starring in the first performances at the supper club 54 Below, Patti LuPone has signed on to appear there regularly through 2016. Ms. LuPone, a two-time Tony winner for best actress (“Gypsy,” 2008; “Evita,” 1980), will begin the first of her twice yearly, two-week engagements on Monday night with Scott Wittman’s “The Lady With the Torch,” a collection of torch songs Ms. LuPone originally performed at Carnegie Hall in 2005. The deal makes her the first artist to sign a long-term agreement with the 54 Below, the publicist Keith Sherman said by phone by Sunday.

headline: A New Project for Jolie and Pitt
abstract: An on-screen reunion is in the works for Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt.
lead_paragraph: An on-screen reunion is in the works for Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt. Donna Langley, the chairwoman of Universal Pictures, recently announced that the studio had acquired worldwide rights to Ms. Jolie’s next film project, “By the Sea,” which she will co-star in and co-produce with Mr. Pitt. Written and directed by Ms. Jolie, the film was described in a news release as an “intimate, character-driven drama.” It’s been nine years since the couple’s first and last on-screen appearance, in the 2005 action comedy “Mr. and Mrs. Smith,” which grossed nearly $500 million worldwide. Mr. Pitt and Ms. Jolie (above) are each currently involved in World War II-focused films scheduled to reach theaters this year: Mr. Pitt will star as the leader of a tank crew in “Fury,” slated for release on Nov. 14 from Columbia Pictures, and Ms. Jolie’s sophomore directing project, “Unbroken,” based on the true story of the Olympian and war prisoner Louis Zamperini, is set for a Christmas Day release from Universal.

headline: A Fight for the Right to Read Heidegger
abstract: The philosopher’s anti-Semitism can’t be ignored. But the push to entirely discredit his work is dangerous and wrong.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the Students’ Union at the University College London banned meetings of a group called the Nietzsche Club, which was formed to discuss the ideas of philosophers who inspired, among others, far-right politicians and leaders of the past, like Benito Mussolini, an admirer of Nietzsche’s work. The Union Council decided that the discussion of such thinkers and ideas would foster a dangerous wave of fascism among its students, and prevented them from holding a public meeting.

headline: A Bloop Leads to a Blooper, Lifting the Yankees to a Sweep
abstract: The Yankees escaped with a victory in the bottom of the ninth when Brian McCann’s single off Aroldis Chapman dropped into short right field after miscommunication by three Reds fielders.
lead_paragraph: When a batter is facing a pitcher who throws 102 miles per hour, there is not really time for directional hitting. It is the kind of heat that sends murmurs through the crowd during warm-ups. The pop of the baseball when it hits the catcher’s mitt echoes an extra beat, and even major league hitters take notice of the radar-gun readings. At the plate, hitters just hope for the best.

headline: In Gaza, Epithets Are Fired and Euphemisms Give Shelter
abstract: In a clash of narratives, officials from both Israel and Gaza advise supporters on the language and images that should be used on social media platforms.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Gaza-based interior ministry advises its supporters in a YouTube video that whenever talking about the dead, “always add ‘an innocent citizen.’ ” In Israel, the message is quite different: Those same victims are described as “human shields” sacrificed by the “heartless” Hamas “terrorists” that rule Gaza.

headline: Give Us a Bishop in High Heels
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'ANGLICAN CHURCHES', 'Priests', 'Religion and Belief', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Nuns']

lead_paragraph: SANDWICH, England — LAST Tuesday, on the front page of The Daily Telegraph of London, which I buy like thousands of other dementia-fearers because of the kindly crossword, I saw the face of a young woman at the General Synod at York with a bright teardrop sliding down her cheek. I thought, Oh dear! More misery. Newspapers now are only frigates of misery.

headline: Busy Doctors, Wasteful Spending
keywords: ['Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Why cutting payments to physicians ends up costing money.
lead_paragraph: OF all the ways to limit health care costs, perhaps none is as popular as cutting payments to doctors. In recent years payment cuts have resulted in a sharp downturn in revenue for many hospitals and private practices. What this has meant for most physicians is that in order to maintain their income, they’ve had to see more patients. When you reduce the volume of air per breath, the only way to maintain ventilation is to breathe faster.

By the time the piano player had finished the Iraqi national anthem, and before the prayers, Manhal Younis was crying.

headline: Eataly-Style Food Halls Are Taking Over America
abstract: The New York trend that gave rise to Mario Batali's culinary emporium and others like Gotham West Market has now led to upscale food marketplaces in San Francisco, Denver, Seattle, Washington, D.C. and Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Todd English opened his upscale food court and market at the Plaza Hotel in the summer of 2010, the notion of combining communal dining space and artisan grocery shopping has caught fire in New York. English’s endeavor was soon followed by Mario Batali’s Italian food emporium Eataly, where patrons can snack on charcuterie, drink wine and purchase artisanal produce. At the end of 2013 Gotham West Market opened in Hell’s Kitchen with stalls serving ramen, tapas and microbrews, in addition to gourmet foodstuffs and sundries. Downtown, Battery Park residents can now patronize Hudson Eats, yet another swanky, upscale food court. And now, other cities around the country are getting in the game. Here are five new (or upgraded) food halls in Denver, Seattle, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C., and Atlanta.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on the U.S. border crisis, warning labels on cigarette packages, Vladimir Putin and Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, payday loans, and more.
lead_paragraph: “The crisis of young migrants at the Texas border is a test of American values,” writes The New York Times editorial board, “One of those surprise exams that history now and then throws our way: Here are 57,000 helpless children. We are a nation of 300 million. Do we spit on them, or give them blankets and beds?” It’s a test the country may be flunking, according to the editorial. In neighboring Arizona, “Hearing that migrant children were being sent to the town of Oracle, a county sheriff instigated a protest that ensnared a busload of bewildered YMCA campers. A disbarred former county attorney running for governor has an ad showing a Mexican flag swallowing up a map of Arizona and the slogan ‘Before It’s Too Late.'” The crisis “emboldens demagogues in Washington” as well, the board writes. “Mr. Obama has the obligation to act the grown-up” when dealing with an obstructionist Congress, “but he can be a tepid ally where unauthorized immigrants are concerned, since he sees the issue through a calculating lens that overlooks the moral urgency to act.” And urgent the situation is.

headline: 1964: Doctors Call for End to Free Treatment
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Family doctors in Britain pressed for the introduction of a fee on consultations in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s family doctors have decided to press for an end to free treatment for patients under the socialized health service. The decision, announced by the British Medical Association, is intended to reduce overcrowding in consulting rooms and ease the burden of the country’s doctors. The BMA council’s chairman, J.R. Nicholson-Lailey, said that the BMA did not want these payments collected by the doctor. Mr. Nicholson-Lailey’s statement indicated that the payments might be used to keep persons with frivolous complaints from monopolizing the doctor’s time. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1964

headline: Campaign Tries Tapping Into Hong Kong’s ‘Silent Majority’

headline: Karl Albrecht, a Founder of Aldi Stores, Dies at 94
abstract: The German billionaire and his brother built their mother’s World War II-era corner shop into a global grocery empire known for bare-bones ambience enlivened by cut-rate prices.
lead_paragraph: Karl Albrecht, who with his brother Theo returned from Allied prisoner-of-war camps after World War II to find their mother’s corner shop still standing in bombed-out Essen, Germany, then proceeded to build it into the international grocery empire Aldi, died on Wednesday in Essen. He was 94.

lead_paragraph: The label on my bottle of Nature’s Bounty Advanced Probiotic 10 says it contains 10 probiotic strains and 20 billion live cultures in each two-capsule dose. The supplement provides “advanced support for digestive and intestinal health” and “healthy immune function.”

headline: A Homeowner’s Refusal to Cash Out in a Gambling Town Proves Costly
abstract: Vera Coking’s Atlantic City home — once coveted by Donald Trump, who had offered her seven figures — will be up for auction with a reserve price of $199,000.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — A stand of blossoming lilac trees and a fresh coat of white paint hardly hide the decrepitude of the three-story boardinghouse half a block from the boardwalk. Ripped screens cover the windows that have not been smashed or boarded up. In the kitchen, refrigerators stand open and empty in a row; dirty plates fill the sink. Some guest rooms look untouched, beds made, while bags of trash and piles of suitcases litter others. What appears to be a crack pipe sits on a dresser.

lead_paragraph: This is not exactly the way people usually recall John F. Kennedy. Wearing spectacular headgear, Kennedy, then a Massachusetts senator, was speaking in October 1959 in Crowley, La., alongside a then-obscure city councilman named Edwin Edwards, who later became the state’s longest-serving governor.

headline: Taking Pledges for a Brooklyn Movie Marathon
abstract: Participants must raise donations in order to attend a 24-hour film marathon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will present a 24-hour film marathon as a way of raising money for its BAM Education program of classroom and after-school arts education, which reaches about 30,000 students, teachers and parents every year. The event is modeled after the marathon walks and bicycle rides for various health causes. Participants must raise a minimum of $250 to join in, and there are prizes for those who raise greater amounts. The marathon takes place on Sept. 5 at 8 p.m. at the Steinberg Screening Room of the BAM Harvey Theater.

headline: Uncooked Tomato and Mint Sauce with Poached Eggs
abstract: This dish turns summer tomatoes into a salsa cruda that can also work well with most any kind of fish.
lead_paragraph: My friend and colleague Clifford A. Wright serves this delicious salsa cruda with grilled salmon. It’s also wonderful with most other fish, grilled, oven-roasted or pan-cooked, and it makes a terrific sauce for foods like cooked grains, the vegetarian burgers I published a few weeks ago or simply cooked green vegetables. One of my favorite uses is in a Mediterranean huevos rancheros: poach an egg, set it on a lightly charred corn tortilla, sprinkle the egg with a little salt and pepper if desired and spoon on the sauce.

headline: Whole Wheat Focaccia With Tomatoes and Fontina
abstract: Focaccia, a little crisp on the bottom but soft on the top and inside, can take on many toppings besides tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: Focaccia is a dimpled flatbread that can take a number of toppings, like a pizza but breadier. I used Community Grains whole wheat flour for this half-whole-wheat version, and I’m loving the results so much that I’m ready to start on a week’s worth of focaccia recipes with different toppings very soon. The bread is fragrant with olive oil, a little crisp on the bottom but soft on the top and the inside. It’s a great vehicle for summer tomatoes.

headline: A J.Crew Grows in Brooklyn
abstract: The store, which remarkably is the brand’s first outpost in Williamsburg, features a playful mural on its exterior wall.
lead_paragraph: “I used to have a studio in Williamsburg, until about 1999,” the typography and graffiti artist Greg Lamarche said. “And then it went residential.” Lamarche, whose graffiti appeared on walls throughout northern Brooklyn in the 1990s, is making a return of sorts. His newest (legal) piece is a colorful jumble of found letter forms spelling out J.Crew, which cascade along a wooden barricade outside the brand’s coming store on Wythe Avenue in Williamsburg. Set to open in mid-September, it will be the company’s first outpost in the neighborhood.

headline: Spiced Tomato Ketchup
abstract: This sauce is a tomato jam that tastes more like a richly spiced ketchup. A long simmer is important.
lead_paragraph: This is inspired by a recipe for a delicious tomato jam in the chef Matthew Kenney’s cookbook, “Matthew Kenney’s Mediterranean Cooking.” My version is not as sweet as his; I decided to call it ketchup rather than jam because to me, it tastes like a richly spiced ketchup, with sweet and sour flavors and a little kick from the cayenne. A long simmer is important for cooking the sauce to the right consistency and for concentrating the flavors. After that, I put the ketchup through a food mill to achieve smoother texture, but that step is optional. I salt toward the end of cooking because the mix will reduce quite a lot and it’s too easy to oversalt if you salt before that happens. However, be sure to use enough salt to balance out the sweetness and bring out the spice.

headline: Heirloom Tomato Concassé with Wilted Swiss Chard
abstract: Sweet, juicy heirloom tomatoes can be made into a concassé that works as well with vegetables as it does with pasta or grains.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, I can’t bear to cook sweet heirloom tomatoes. I love this concassé with pasta or grains, but this time, I decided to use it as a sauce for Swiss chard. I steamed the chard to wilt it, heated it in a little bit of olive oil, then piled it on my plate and spooned the tomato sauce on top. It’s a great combo, and now I think I’ll use it as the vegetable and sauce element of a big bowl. A little feta sprinkled over the top would not be lost on this.

headline: Ex-Executive of Autonomy Seeks to Block HP Settlement Over Disastrous Deal

headline: Risotto with Tomatoes and Corn
abstract: This colorful risotto serves as a luxurious showcase for summer’s bounty of tomatoes and corn.
lead_paragraph: This is about as colorful and summery a risotto as you can get. The tomatoes and broth team up as a rich medium for the rice. Don’t add the corn too soon, or it will develop a starchy texture like the rice. But cook it long enough to bring out its sweet flavor. Simmer the corn cobs for about 20 minutes in your broth to get a great sweet corn flavor.

headline: Why Writers Are Opening Up About Money (or the Lack Thereof)

One man, a passenger in a blue car that was stopped at a red light, said two people in his building were killed in the day’s fighting. He said he ran out of his house in nothing but his slippers.

I turn to veggie burgers when I crave the hamburger experience (soft bun, chewy protein, lots of spicy condiments) but would, at that moment, rather consume vegetables than meat.

headline: 1939: Sign of Life on Mars Reported
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: An American astronomer spotted signs of life on Mars in 1939.
lead_paragraph: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa — Dr. V. M. Slipher, director of the Lowell Observatory at Flagstaff, Ariz., who is here to take color photographs of Mars from the Lamont-Hussey Observatory, today reported that camera studies definitely indicate the presence of life on the planet — which in six days’ time will be nearer the earth than it has been for fifteen years. Dr. Slipher’s photographs show a gradual change in the appearance of the planet, he said, which prove the growth or decay of vegetable matter. Scientists have long believed that Mars is a planet where all conditions needed for life are to be found. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 22, 1939

headline: 92nd Street Y’s Lineup: Jimmy Page, Amy Poehler and More
abstract: The new season at the Y will include a tribute to Dylan Thomas, an evening with Jimmy Page, a conversation with Amy Poehler and a reading by Kazuo Ishiguro, among many other events.
lead_paragraph: A centenary tribute to the Welsh poet Dylan Thomas, and an exhibition that includes letters, photographs and memorabilia from Thomas’s visits to the United States, presented by the Unterberg Poetry Center, will be among the highlights of the 92nd Street Y’s wide-ranging 2014-15 season of readings, lectures and discussions.  The Y has a particular affinity for Thomas, who made his American debut there in 1950, and returned to give the world premiere of “Under Milk Wood” in 1953. He will be commemorated in a program on Oct. 26. The exhibition opens the same day.

headline: The Gene That Turns Worms Into Pavlov’s Dogs

headline: Beyond Energy, Matter, Time and Space
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Science and Technology', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Mathematics', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Philosophy']
abstract: Humans might think we can figure out the ultimate mysteries, but there is no reason to believe that we have all the pieces necessary for a theory of everything.
lead_paragraph: Though he probably didn’t intend anything so jarring, Nicolaus Copernicus, in a 16th-century treatise, gave rise to the idea that human beings do not occupy a special place in the heavens. Nearly 500 years after replacing the Earth with the sun as the center of the cosmic swirl, we’ve come to see ourselves as just another species on a planet orbiting a star in the boondocks of a galaxy in the universe we call home. And this may be just one of many universes — what cosmologists, some more skeptically than others, have named the multiverse.

headline: For Alibaba Investors, the Benefits and Risks of Trusting Jack Ma
abstract: Alibaba’s founder will continue to exert near-total control of the Chinese e-commerce giant even after its I.P.O. Can shareholders trust him to act in their interest? Up to a point, says John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Buy a share in Alibaba and you place your trust in Jack Ma. The Chinese e-commerce giant’s founder, executive chairman and spiritual sultan will remain a controlling force even after the company completes its huge initial public offering later this year. The $100 billion-plus question for prospective shareholders is whether they can depend on him to always act in their best interests.

headline: Coming Off Neck Surgery, Wilson Is Set For Contact
abstract: Giants running back David Wilson, sidelined since October, announced he had been cleared to resume full contact workouts, with the team’s first full practice of training camp Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Giants running back David Wilson, who has been sidelined since October because of a neck injury that required surgery, announced Monday morning that he had been given a go-ahead to resume full-contact workouts with the team. The Giants’ first full practice of training camp is Tuesday.

headline: An Eye to the Past Can Help Guide the Future
abstract: A survey finds financial health is higher among those who dwell on the past, compared with those who live in the moment or even plan for the future.
lead_paragraph: Over time, we’ve come to accept the concept that knowledge is power. In theory, when we have more knowledge, we can make better decisions. But for many of us, there can be a disconnect between knowing something and acting wisely on that knowledge. As you probably know from experience, it happens often with money.

headline: Helping Parents Cope, Leaving Kids Alone
keywords: ['Child Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Parenting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Welfare (US)', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: On public policy, working families, and the policing of parenthood.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column, on the (literal) policing of parents who don’t live up to a helicoptering standard of supervision over their offspring’s every waking move, concluded with a particular emphasis on the obligations of conservatives, who tend to support measures that encourage single parents to take jobs, to fiercely oppose policies and practices that then punish such parents when they leave their kids unsupervised. (Parents, for instance, like Debra Harrell, a working mother who recently fell victim to this cruel Catch-22.)

headline: Research Suggests Students Adjusting to New School Lunches
abstract: School administrators agree that students complained about new lunch standards when they were first implemented in the fall of 2012—but tell researchers that by spring, the complaints had largely subsided.
lead_paragraph: While many schools have been gradually improving the quality and nutrition of their lunches in the last few years, the updated standards released by the United States Department of Agriculture (as directed by the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010), which most schools put in effect over the 2012-13 school year, meant larger, faster changes to lunches nearly across the board. Higher-fat milk is gone; schools are required to serve a vegetable and a fruit daily; there can be no trans fat; and half of the grains offered must be whole grains (in the 2014-15 school year, all grains must be whole grains).

headline: Monday Motorsports: Drought Ends for Bourdais, Todd and Stewart
abstract: Sébastien Bourdais won his first IndyCar race in six years; J.R. Todd won his first Top Fuel victory since 2008; Tony Stewart took first in a sprint car race.
lead_paragraph: Sébastien Bourdais and Mike Conway each won a race Sunday in an IndyCar twin bill in Toronto over the weekend. The victory  in the rain-delayed first event ended a drought of more than six years for Bourdais, a four-time series champion. He finished just over three seconds ahead of Helio Castroneves, the series points leader. Tony Kanaan took third.

She asked me what agency I was with. I had no clue what she was talking about. I’m from Vermilion, Ohio, and growing up there was great, but there aren’t a lot of modeling agencies in northern Ohio.

headline: Beyond Salty and Sweet: A Budding Club of Tastes
abstract: The days when only four — sweet, salty, sour and bitter — were recognized are passing. Savory is widely recognized as the fifth, and others, like soapiness and metallic, are jockeying for acceptance.
lead_paragraph: Sweet, salty, sour and bitter — every schoolchild knows these are the building blocks of taste. Our delight in every scrumptious bonbon, every sizzling hot dog, derives in part from the tongue’s ability to recognize and signal just four types of taste.

lead_paragraph: From 2009 to 2013, an oversight board substantiated nine complaints by people who said New York City police officers restrained them with a chokehold, a banned tactic that may have played a role in the death of a Staten Island man last week.

And astronomers have been busy working the proverbial smoke-filled rooms (or whatever passes for them today) where the destiny of big science is often shaped and crisscrossing one another in airports on fund-raising trips. headline: The Scene | Kendrick Lamar, Grimes, St. Vincent and More at the Pitchfork Music Festival
abstract: Legendary indie acts like Slowdive and Neutral Milk Hotel played alongside today’s big names in the music website’s annual bash. T captured the fun.
lead_paragraph: The ninth edition of the Pitchfork Music Festival, held in Chicago’s Union Park this past weekend, featured a lineup as diverse and influential as the offerings on the music-arbiter site. A young and enthusiastic crowd turned out to see legendary indie acts reunited — like Neutral Milk Hotel and Slowdive, which played its first show in more than 20 years — and catch a who’s-who of indie superstars (Kendrick Lamar, Grimes, St. Vincent) and emerging names (Danny Brown, FKA Twigs, Empress Of). The mild-for-Chicago-in-July weather made for a laid-back vibe — and allowed several headliners to comfortably sport that perennial rock-and-roll staple, the leather motorcycle jacket. The photographer Andres Gonzalez was on the ground to capture the action for T.

abstract: Mr. Berger was known as the author of “Little Big Man” and books that explored the American West, but his body of work was broader than that.

headline: Coveting Vintage Discs in a Digital Universe
abstract: “Do Not Sell at Any Price,” by Amanda Petrusich, and “Dust & Grooves,” by Eilon Paz, look at people who are obsessive about collecting old records.
lead_paragraph: Something unexpected happened to Amanda Petrusich when she set out to explore the “oddball fraternity” of fanatical collectors of 78 r.p.m. records, the increasingly hard-to-find shellac discs that circulated before World War II. At first she was almost repulsed by the avidity of their passion. But when she heard the music of Skip James, Charley Patton, Blind Uncle Gaspard and Geeshie Wiley played in its original format, she fell under its spell, just as the collectors had.

headline: Should You Track Your Child?

What does a standard of constant surveillance mean for kids, many are asking, and for their families?

headline: As the City Birds Nod Off, a Crooning Gull Steps In
abstract: The New Juilliard Ensemble presented a contemporary program, including premieres of works by Roberto Sierra and Errollyn Wallen, at a MoMA Summergarden concert.
lead_paragraph: It’s always good to keep the competition in mind when planning a concert. It made sense, then, for the members of the New Juilliard Ensemble, who assembled Sunday’s program of new music for string quartet with flute for the Museum of Modern Art’s Summergarden series, to keep the flute music for last. By then it had grown dark and the birds, which had earlier filled the museum’s Sculpture Garden with their end-of-day chatter, had gone to bed. The birds also slept through the performance of Peter Sculthorpe’s String Quartet No. 14 and could not comment on the verisimilitude of the gull croons written into the third movement.

headline: A Newly Found Mite Is Jenny From the Reef
abstract: A research team that liked listening to the music of Jennifer Lopez called an aquatic mite it discovered Litarachna Lopezae.

Lo’s songs and videos kept the team in a continuous good mood,” said Vladimir Pesic, a biologist at the University of Montenegro and lead author of the study.

headline: Light Show That Fizzled

abstract: Eagerly anticipating a gas cloud’s collision with the Milky Way’s black hole, astronomers instead saw nothing. An intriguing explanation has emerged.
lead_paragraph: Like eager paparazzi, astronomers trained an arsenal of telescopes this spring on the Milky Way’s crowded center, hoping for a once-in-a-lifetime chance to watch an immense gas cloud collide with the galaxy’s supermassive black hole. The shock generated when the cloud smashed into gas surrounding the black hole, 26,000 light-years from Earth, could have produced radio waves, X-rays and a possible brightening of infrared light. But researchers saw nothing.

It aims to mobilize efforts to end female genital mutilation and child, early and forced marriages. The study said child marriage remains widespread in parts of South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. South Asia is home to almost half of all child brides worldwide, the study found. While an adolescent girl today is about a third less likely to be subjected to genital mutilation compared with 30 years ago because of activism, legislation and changing attitudes, Unicef said that in countries where it is still practiced, parents “continue to compel their daughters to undergo the procedure because of strong social pressure.”

(ESPN) SLAYING THE BADGER This “30 for 30” documentary, directed and written by John Dower, looks back at the 1986 Tour de France and the rivalry between Greg LeMond, above left, the first American to win the race, and Bernard Hinault, a.k.a. the Badger, right, his friend, mentor and teammate on La Vie Claire. The film is based on Richard Moore’s book, which describes how Mr. Hinault, then the reigning champion, had seemingly promised to help Mr. LeMond to his first victory in return for his support of Mr. Hinault as he struggled in the 1985 tour. But Mr. Hinault repeatedly attacked Mr. LeMond in the race, “because I felt like it,” he said. “If he doesn’t buckle, that means he’s a champion and deserves to win the race. I did it for his own good.”

headline: What the Hobby Lobby Ruling Means for America
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Corporations, it turns out, really are people. And that could be very bad news for the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: Last month, as you’ve probably heard, a closely divided Supreme Court  ruled that corporations with religious owners cannot be required to pay for insurance coverage of contraception. The so-called Hobby Lobby decision, named for the chain of craft stores that brought the case, has been both praised and condemned for expanding religious rights and constraining Obamacare. But beneath the political implications, the ruling has significant economic undertones. It expands the right of corporations to be treated like people, part of a trend that may be contributing to the rise of economic inequality.

headline: A Love of Land in Egypt’s Farms
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Grandparents', 'Land Use Policies', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Photography']

lead_paragraph: Laura El-Tantawy was in her sixth year photographing Egypt when she decided she needed a drastic change. What had started as a project to reconnect with her home country took a decided shift at the spark of the 2011 revolution. Echoing the tumult in Tahrir Square in Cairo, her images had grown menacing and haunting.

headline: The Tragic Price of Flight 17
abstract: Who in the airline industry is accountable for the demise of the Malaysia Airlines jet?
lead_paragraph: The downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 is a terrible tragedy, but then we were already well aware of President Vladimir Putin’s dangerous meddling in eastern Ukraine. What we didn’t know about is how the airline industry assesses security risks. I would be interested in reading a thorough piece on how the various civil aviation authorities and airline companies decide which routes are safe to fly. How is it possible that some airlines avoided Ukrainian airspace altogether while others did not? Who in the airline industry is accountable for the demise of Flight 17?

headline: When Hiring Employees in Poorer Countries, Difficult Moral Questions Arise
abstract: What responsibilities do we have to those employees? And how do we balance those responsibilities with our obligations to keep costs down and productivity up, a serious concern for start-ups like ours with limited cash and time.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, I wrote about the issues I’d encountered while building an outsourced office in another country. We’ve now expanded to a team of 14 in Manila, and we recruited everyone there using processes similar to those we use at home. I’ve worked out of the office there and have come to know each employee. We hold regular team lunches at our Manila office, and the whole company meets once a week by video conference. As a result, I had the impression that we were building a strong company culture across both offices.

They eluded all but the first 100 autograph- seekers and escaped to the near-by surf.  The couple since disembarking ten days ago at Naples had been on a leisurely automobile tour through Italy. The couple will leave tomorrow for Le Pyla to visit Annabella’s mother. Later they will see Paris, then sail in August for America to commence work again in Hollywood in September. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1939

lead_paragraph: The CIT Group, the lender to small and midsize businesses run by John A. Thain, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the parent company of OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in cash and stock, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes. The deal will bolster CIT’s lending abilities by more than doubling its deposit base. OneWest currently manages $15 billion in deposits, as well as $23 billion in assets, including commercial and home mortgages. It will merge with CIT’s own bank, creating a subsidiary with $28 billion in deposits and $67 billion in assets.

headline: A Power Broker’s World Comes Tumbling Down
abstract: Wallace Shawn turns the title character of Ibsen’s imperious “Master Builder” into a megalomaniacal little creep facing his death and his past.
lead_paragraph: As both an actor and a playwright, Wallace Shawn, at his most audacious, goes for the jugular, but in sneaky roundabout ways. In “A Master Builder,” a filmed version of Henrik Ibsen’s play “The Master Builder,” which he also freely adapted, Mr. Shawn stars as the despicable title character, Halvard Solness. As is his wont, Mr. Shawn employs insidious sleight of hand to score moral points. Halvard may not be a murderer, but he relishes crushing the hopes and dreams of everyone around him.

This weekend, ModelFIT, the Karlie Kloss-approved workout located on the Bowery in Manhattan, is coming to the Surf Lodge, where trainers will host two mornings of complimentary classes out on the deck as part of the hotel’s summer wellness program. Available to anyone, even non-hotel guests on a first-come, first-serve basis (there’s a limit of 30 people), the one-hour classes will mix cardio with isometric training for long, lean muscles and a strong core.

headline: A Child of the Slum Rises as President of Indonesia

headline: The Dark Side of Sharing

headline: Researchers Question Expansion of Antarctica’s Fringe of Sea Ice

lead_paragraph: Updated, July 23, 1:40 p.m. | A new study of methods used to track Antarctic sea ice trends has raised important questions about whether recent increases in ice there are, to a significant extent, an illusion created by flawed analysis of data collected by a series of satellites. headline: Abandoning All Stability to Test Fate
abstract: In Catherine Lacey’s novel “Nobody Is Ever Missing,” a woman abruptly flees her life in New York and flies to New Zealand, where she has one surreal encounter after another.
lead_paragraph: Renata Adler’s cult novel “Speedboat” (1976) was reissued last year and has caught on among a new generation of readers. It’s having a long, largely deserved moment.

headline: Technology, Aided by Recession, Is Polarizing the Work World
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Routine tasks that follow well-defined procedures are especially likely to be taken over by computers, and the recession has sped this process up.
lead_paragraph: The American work force has been growing polarized for decades. On one end, there are highly skilled jobs like writing software or performing surgery, and on the other are service jobs like child care and cutting hair. The jobs in the middle, meanwhile, such as factory work, sales and bookkeeping, are shrinking — one of the reasons for the economy’s slow climb out of the recession.

headline: Obama Sends Aide to Soothe German Allies
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: With Berlin angry over a series of spying incidents, President Obama sent his chief of staff, Denis R. McDonough, for talks on the state of bilateral relations and improving cooperation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a sign of just how much German-American relations have frayed, President Obama sent his chief of staff to Berlin to try to smooth over the rupture caused by recent revelations of American spying on its ally, the White House said Tuesday.

headline: In Dublin, Tweaking a High Tea
abstract: The tea served at the Four Seasons Hotel Dublin was inspired by a sculpture by the Irish artist Michael Warren.
lead_paragraph: Luxury hotels in Dublin have a reputation for their formal afternoon teas, but the Four Seasons Hotel Dublin recently introduced Tempo Tea, a more fun and less fancy rendition of the ritual.

headline: New Victory Theater to Host 10 New Works for Children
abstract: Among the shows are works from Taylor Mac and the Civilians company.
lead_paragraph: The New Victory Theater, a house known for its presentation of works for children and families, also runs an artists’ residency program, New Victory LabWorks, now in its second year. It gives playwrights, performers and artists in other disciplines rehearsal space and support while they assemble new works for children. During the 2014-15 season, LabWorks will host 10 projects and companies, the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Who Said It: Beauty-Pageant Contestant, Philosopher or Politician?
abstract: Pageant queens are not the only ones who face the challenge of answering rapid-fire questions about current events.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Chu’s article in this past weekend’s magazine about Bill Alverson, a practicing lawyer in Alabama and beauty-pageant coach, noted that one of the biggest challenges for pageant contestants is the interview. Alverson ‘‘often suggests Khaled Hosseini’s novel ‘A Thousand Splendid Suns,’ to improve their understanding of women’s rights globally,’’ Chu writes. ‘‘He also insists that they read The Week and USA Today online.’’

headline: Now You Taste It, Now You Don’t
abstract: When beloved dishes fall off menus, some diners fight back.
lead_paragraph: I can’t recall the exact date a few years ago when I ate my first ciabatta egg sandwich at Seersucker, in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But I remember precisely how great it tasted and made me feel, which is why I ate it again and again at every possible opportunity.

headline: Wheelies: The Farewell, Mr. Scheele Edition
abstract: Nick Scheele, a former Ford president, dies at 70; Cadillac may offer a high-performance Vsport version of its Escalade S.U.V.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Andy Spade on Learning From David Lynch, Amish Clothing and Rene Ricard
abstract: The curator and entrepreneur, who will soon open the Boerum House & Home store in Brooklyn, also shares his thoughts on Glenn O’Brien, conceptual art and the BMW 2002.
lead_paragraph: Andy Spade does many things, all with an intimidating degree of success. He has helped transform the role of “curator” into that of “business strategist,” lending his canny eye to major brands like J. Crew and Target. He is also an entrepreneur, helping to launch the Kate Spade handbag empire, Jack Spade menswear, Sleepy Jones (a line of pajamas and intimates) and, soon, the Boerum House & Home store in Brooklyn. The new shop, a collaboration with Flank Architects, will feature objects from 130 designers. He also produces movies, shoots photographs and makes books. Here, a few of the inspirations that drive this very driven man.

headline: Candidate Rejects Indonesia’s Election
abstract: Prabowo Subianto, a retired Indonesian Army general, denounced the result of the country’s presidential election and withdrew his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Prabowo Subianto, a retired Indonesian Army general, denounced the result of the country’s presidential election and withdrew his candidacy.

headline: Obama Goes to West Coast for 3 Days With Donors
abstract: President Obama will help the Democratic Party’s campaign committees and two “super PACs” that were created for the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will spend the next three days helping to fill the coffers of his party’s campaign committees and working to lift the fortunes of two “super PACs” created to help House and Senate candidates in the midterm elections.

headline: Getting From Gaza to Israel, by Underground Tunnels
abstract: Israel says its invasion of the Gaza Strip is intended to destroy the underground tunnels Hamas militants use to infiltrate Israel. Where are these tunnels and how are they used?
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said the focus of its ground operations in Gaza is to destroy the labyrinth of tunnels from the strip into Israel that can be used for launching attacks.

headline: Airlines Suspend Flights to Israel After Hamas Rocket Falls Near Main Airport
abstract: After a rocket fell near Ben-Gurion airport outside Tel Aviv, the Federal Aviation Administration told American carriers to halt service for 24 hours, and some other airlines followed suit.
lead_paragraph: Airlines in the United States and Europe suspended flights to and from Israel on Tuesday after a rocket fell about a mile from Ben-Gurion International Airport outside Tel Aviv.

headline: In Shake-Up at Sony Pictures, Jeff Blake to Leave
abstract: The 22-year veteran was the vice chairman of the company and ran its worldwide marketing and distribution operation. He is stepping down Aug. 1.
lead_paragraph: In another jolt to its rapidly changing management structure, Sony Pictures Entertainment said that Jeff Blake, the company’s vice chairman and the chairman of its worldwide marketing and distribution operation, will leave on Aug. 1.

headline: Time Warner Deal Clad in the Emperor’s Old Clothes
abstract: Time Warner stockholders should remain cautious about trading their shares for those in 21st Century Fox, where power would still be consolidated in the hands of Rupert Murdoch, Rob Cox writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner shareholders who are pondering whether to surrender to Rupert Murdoch would be well advised to listen to the media mogul’s muzzled minorities. Most 21st Century Fox believers are relegated to owning nonvoting stock in the conglomerate, the same second-tier paper on offer as part of the $80 billion takeover bid for the owner of HBO, CNN and Warner Bros. studios. Despite broad investor overlap in the two companies, the record shows a clear distaste for Mr. Murdoch’s imperialism.

headline: Giving Another Debut Author the Colbert Bump
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Stephen Colbert, whose endorsement of the Hachette author Edan Lepucki, helped sales of her book “California,” has now singled out “Sweetness #9,” by Stephan Eirik Clark.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert has rescued another Hachette debut novelist from possible obscurity.

headline: Not Everyone Is Addicted to Inflation
abstract: Even if the goal of looser money and higher inflation has failed to attract much conservative support, market monetarists have achieved most of their policy goals.
lead_paragraph: Paul Krugman made a little fun of me in a column last week. He wrote that “market monetarism,” a set of ideas about monetary policy that I once called “the shining success of the conservative reform movement,” had not caught on with any actual conservatives. Over the last few years, market monetarists have wanted looser money and higher inflation. Yet many conservatives still fear inflation and want tight money; in 2012, the Republican Party even added a plank to its platform calling for re-examination of the gold standard.

headline: Fortune Names Alan Murray Top Editor
abstract: Mr. Murray, the president of the Pew Research Center, is expected to begin his new position in August.
lead_paragraph: Fortune magazine appointed Alan Murray, the president of the Pew Research Center and a former deputy managing editor at The Wall Street Journal, as its new top editor on Tuesday.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Startup Guy’ Fashion
abstract: A business owner and former illegal immigrant speaks up. An Uber customer takes an odd ride to the Denver airport. And an appeals court deals a blow to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': We Really Are Putting on a Play
abstract: John Lithgow gets a visit by an old friend.
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: No-Stick, No-Fuss, No-Fail Rice
abstract: Kim Severson offers up a recipe for can’t-miss rice, which surprisingly involves the oven.
lead_paragraph: Kim Severson offers up a recipe for can’t-miss rice, which surprisingly involves the oven.

headline: Rulings on Health Law Are Far From Last Word
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The administration will not reconsider its Affordable Care Act regulations until the conflicting cases are resolved.
lead_paragraph: An appellate court ruling issued Tuesday would be very bad news for the Affordable Care Act if it became the law of the land. But it’s still a long way from a settled issue, as a second appellate decision, issued a few hours later, highlighted.

headline: A Singapore Startup Sells Contemporary Art from Southeast Asia, Without the Intimidation Factor
abstract: Art Loft, an online gallery founded by three young women, works directly with talent throughout the region and aims to demystify the buying process.
lead_paragraph: Groceries, books, clothing — we buy everything, it seems, from our laptops and phones these days, so why not original art too? That’s the question posed by the founders of Art Loft, a Singapore-based e-commerce art platform with a focus on connecting emerging contemporary artists, largely from Southeast Asia, with collectors around the world.

headline: 1964: De Gaulle Refuses to Pay U.N.
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: De Gaulle refuses to pay his country’s debt to the U.N. in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — During his talks with U Thant yesterday [July 21], President Charles de Gaulle flatly turned down the United Nations secretary-general’s request for payment of French debts to the world organization. U Thant left Paris ‘‘without illusions and without hope,’’ said an official French spokesman today. Thus, despite the warm praise, which Gen. de Gaulle and U Thant exchanged, all hope disappeared that France would pay the $16 million it owes the UN for the Congo operation, an action France opposed from the start. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 23, 1964

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Would Address Hamas Demands After Cease-Fire
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Egypt had provided the framework for a cease-fire, but there was no indication that a deal was imminent.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday said that the United States was prepared to address the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip and the political demands of the Palestinians living there, but that a cease-fire first needed to be carried out.

headline: London Theater Journal: On Artifice and Oxygen, Earnest and Jeeves
abstract: Productions of the comedies “Jeeves and Wooster in Perfect Nonsense” and “The Importance of Being Earnest” operate on the “it’s only a play” premise, calling attention to the artifice with which these stories are told.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — People often speak of poetic license, but why not theatrical license? Think of the wanton liberties that have been taken with respectable plays over the years in the name of showbiz, box office, star power and intellectual theorizing.

headline: Spitzer Returns, Taking Aim Again at Financial Analysts
abstract: Eliot Spitzer is now backing a website called TipRanks, an Israeli start-up that aims to hold financial experts accountable for their stock recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer has re-emerged in the public eye.

headline: In Praise of the Trusty Rice Cooker
abstract: For someone raised in southern Louisiana, rice cookers are preferred because they work every time. No timers, no worries, no excuses.
lead_paragraph: Every cook has her trusted tools. Those implements that help you through just about any prep process and make the kitchen feel like home. For many it’s a special chef’s knife that sits just right in the hand, a cutting board with the perfect amount of countertop acreage, or maybe a sauté pan that responds to the slightest change in flame.

headline: Fluffy. Tasty. Tricky.
abstract: Embarking on a simple culinary quest: learning how to cook a good pot of basic rice.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Of the many ways I can be humbled in the kitchen, rice is at the top of the list. I’m not a bad cook but, oh, the pots of rice I have driven to a gummy, scorched grave.

headline: The Whiskey Bar Is Taking a Step Up
abstract: New whiskey “libraries” offer hundreds of choices.
lead_paragraph: Multnomah Whiskey Library in Portland, Ore., has a lot of the things you’d expect to find in a whiskey bar — leather chairs, dark wood, a certain amber glow. It also has something you don’t see every day: a ladder.

headline: Senate Panel Takes On Tax Inversions
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Lawmakers spoke out against American companies reincorporating abroad, but there was no consensus on how to address the issue.
lead_paragraph: The chorus of voices on Capitol Hill calling for an end to corporate inversions grew louder on Tuesday as the Senate Finance Committee held a hearing on the issue of American companies reincorporating abroad, and legislators proposed new punitive measures against inverted companies.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 4 | A Millennial on Patriotism
abstract: Congratulations to this week’s winner, someone who goes by the handle MSDHAP2014, and to this week’s guest judge, the author Ally Condie.
lead_paragraph: For five years now, every week during the summer we’ve invited teenagers all over the world to come to our blog and answer the question, “What interested you most in The Times this week?”

headline: Yankees’ Newest Upgrade Drives in the Game Winner
abstract: Chase Headley, acquired from the Padres in exchange for Yangervis Solarte and the minor league pitcher Rafael De Paula, singled in the winning run with one out in the 14th.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a hectic day in which Chase Headley left the only organization he ever played for to join the most famous club in baseball, the situation called for a moment of calm reflection.

headline: Melodrama in Full Flower (and With a Wink)
abstract: Marieann Meringolo delivers ballads and melodrama with grand style (and a trio) at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: “Meadowlark,” the Stephen Schwartz ballad from the musical “The Baker’s Wife,” is a classic example of a song from a flop musical that endures and takes on a life of its own as a semioperatic showpiece. It needs a substantial voice to do it justice, and on a recent night at the Metropolitan Room, Marieann Meringolo, a singer who bears some physical and vocal resemblance to Barbra Streisand, delivered one of the two or three strongest renditions I can remember.

headline: Hedge Fund Chief Testifies at Senate Tax-Avoidance Hearing
abstract: Peter Brown argued that Renaissance Technologies’ tactics in trading were important and helped “produce modest returns with very low volatility.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:30 p.m. | Complex financial instruments that the government has said helped the hedge fund Renaissance Technologies claim billions of dollars in tax savings were “extremely important,” its co-chief executive said at a Senate hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Putin Pledges to Help but Sees Limits on Role
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he would attempt to rein in pro-Russian separatists, but that Ukraine also needed to act to reduce tensions.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin delivered a short but wide-ranging foreign policy speech on Tuesday, pledging to use Russia’s influence on the separatists in eastern Ukraine while also seeking to reassure his domestic audience that any fallout from the downing of a passenger jet over Ukraine could be contained.

headline: What the Internet Can See From Your Cat Pictures
abstract: Calling attention to “the wave of decreased privacy for all,” a professor has used cat pictures to build a site showing the locations of the cats and their owners.

lead_paragraph: BATS Global Markets, the exchange operator, said on Tuesday that its president, William O’Brien, had left the company.

headline: Toronto Film Festival to Include Films by Chris Rock and Noah Baumbach
abstract: The festival, which opens Sept. 4, will include 37 world premieres among its 59 films. Mr. Rock’s film “Top Five” is about a comedian-turned-movie star.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bill Pohlad, the film financier, directs a biopic, “Love & Mercy,” about Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys, who is played by both Paul Dano and John Cusack. Noah Baumbach writes and directs a story of aging and ambition, called “While We’re Young.” Chris Rock goes one better: He writes, directs and stars in “Top Five,” about a New York City comedian-turned-movie star.

headline: Facts & Figures: Higher ‘Obamacare’ Bills Under Halbig
abstract: Millions of Americans could be deprived of the support they need to purchase health insurance.
lead_paragraph: A panel of the D.C. federal appellate court ruled today that the federal government does not have the authority to administer insurance subsidies in states that refused to set up their own exchanges. If the ruling stands—a big if—it could deprive millions of enrollees of the support they need to purchase health insurance.

headline: 10 Tours and 205 Tries Later, Australian Wins a Stage

lead_paragraph: BAGNÈRES-DE-LUCHON, France — Michael Rogers has many cycling titles to his name, including three world time trial championships. But it took until his 10th Tour de France for him to win a stage of the sport’s most prominent event.
