abstract: Use this guide to match the type of photographer you are with storage and organization tools for your vacation pictures.
lead_paragraph: Laptop littered with vacation photos? And dare I mention your smartphone? There are dozens of solutions for storing and organizing your snapshots. But how to choose?

headline: After Health Law Rulings, Here Are Possible Next Steps
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Supreme Court may ultimately resolve the conflicting decisions of two federal appeals courts, but that’s just one option among many.
lead_paragraph: We now have two federal appeals courts that have issued conflicting rulings on a major provision of the Affordable Care Act. Those decisions are not the final word on whether residents of some states will be able to continue receiving financial assistance to buy health insurance. Here are some possible next steps:

headline: Jane Alexander's Bird-Watching Tips
abstract: The actress, who has traveled widely to see and hear birds, talks about some top birding spots and offers guidance on finding tours.
lead_paragraph: Bird-watching, it turns out, is a hobby well suited to film actors, who go to far-flung locations and can have time to kill between shooting.

headline: Exxon Mobil Moves Ahead With Russian Oil Drilling Project
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A rig set sail two days after the downing of a Malaysia Airlines jet in Ukraine led to mounting pressure for new sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Exxon Mobil, which is assisting a Russian state energy company in exploring the Arctic Ocean for oil and natural gas, took a pivotal step to further this project over the weekend.

headline: A World Teaches and Tugs
abstract: “A Letter to Momo” covers a range of emotions as it tells the story of a young girl whose father was lost at sea.
lead_paragraph: Enveloped in a sweetness that buffers the depths of its emotions, Hiroyuki Okiura’s “A Letter to Momo” explores the stains of loss and regret on a personality too young to articulate them. Yet the film’s tiniest viewers are more likely to be entranced than distressed by this magical animated tale — Mr. Okiura’s second, after “Jin-Roh: The Wolf Brigade” (2001) — even if their parents find themselves surreptitiously sniffling.

headline: The High/Low | Tough Sandals at a Gentle Price
abstract: A sturdy-soled, open-toed shoe style seen on the runways is now available in these three affordable versions, perfect for wearing around the city for what’s left of summer.
lead_paragraph: July in New York means sweaty bangs, sticky skin and seemingly unsolvable fashion challenges — like finding a stylish sandal that’s sturdy enough for watching outdoor live shows, trekking to surf spots at the Rockaways and dancing on Brooklyn rooftops. Thankfully, 2014 has been the year of the comfort shoe in fashion, and the heavy-soled sandal trend that walked the spring 2014 Givenchy runway and carried over into such fall 2014 shows as Céline has now trickled down to two go-to sites for all things cool: Asos and Nasty Gal. Dr. Martens, too, is offering a reasonably priced rendition of the tough sandal. These versions are affordable even for 20-somethings, so take your pick and wear them out for what’s left of summer.

headline: Pizza to Go, and on the Go
abstract: Michele Iuliano has devised a wood-burning pizza cart that is stationed in different locations around the city.
lead_paragraph: To Enjoy: A Wood-Fired Pizza Cart That Roams the City

headline: BorderMania Jumps the Shark
abstract: Rick Perry’s National Guard scheme is silly.

headline: War and Media in the Gaza Strip
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'News and News Media', 'Palestinians', 'Social Media', 'War and Revolution']
abstract: The conflict in Gaza is playing out on two fronts: on the ground, and in the media. And when it comes to the latter, some say Israel is losing ground.
lead_paragraph: Alleged gunfire at an Al Jazeera bureau in Gaza on Tuesday was hardly a boon to the Israeli Defense Forces’ public image – and this was only the latest installment in a string of P.R. debacles facing the Jewish state.

headline: A Spinster at the Center of a Madcap Swirl. Cue the Double Entendres.
abstract: In the plot-filled comedy “Drop Dead Perfect,” Everett Quinton plays a spinster in the Florida Keys.
lead_paragraph: In a sweet 1950s peach crocheted dress and matching bolero, Everett Quinton has never looked lovelier. As Idris Seabright, a lonely and overwrought spinster growing old in the Florida Keys, he laments a storm having wreaked “havoc on my African hibiscus — and my poor bougainvillea,” hitting each syllable with that posh Eastern accent that 1930s actresses favored. When a chord of ominous movie music plays, Idris strikes a terrified pose, and we could easily be downtown at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, where Mr. Quinton and Charles Ludlam starred in the original “The Mystery of Irma Vep” 30 years ago.

lead_paragraph: The president discussed the bipartisan bill that helps expand opportunity for more workers by ensuring they will have access to the training and skills they need to compete in the work force.

headline: Iraqi Police Use Detentions to Blunt Militants
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Askariya Shrine (Samarra)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The detention of a woman said to be related to a leader of ISIS is part of a campaign to find a lever against the group.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Iraqi security forces on Tuesday said they had briefly detained a woman near the city of Samarra who was said to be a relative of the leader of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, in part of intensifying campaign to find a lever against the advancing militant group.

headline: Palestinian Family Finds Missing Son in YouTube Video of His Shooting
abstract: Searching the web for news, a family was horrified to discover video of a missing son apparently shot to death in Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: After two days of searching for a son they lost contact with during a rushed evacuation from their home in Gaza City, one Palestinian family was surprised to hear the young man’s voice, calling out for a missing cousin, in video posted on YouTube on Monday by human rights activists.

lead_paragraph: As the death toll rises in the latest round of Israeli-Palestinian fighting, a look at the Obama administration’s strategy for reaching a cease-fire.

headline: Made in House? Prove It
abstract: A law intended to help restaurant diners know what was made in house is off to a rocky start.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The black-and-white symbol looks like a saucepan with a roof for a lid. And if it sits next to an entry on a restaurant menu, it signals that the dish is “fait maison” — house-made.

headline: Debt Disaster Dead-Enders
abstract: They want their crisis, and they won’t let go.
lead_paragraph: I got some correspondence from people telling me to read Rob Portman’s op-ed in the WSJ, intended to refute the growing evidence that the budget deficit has been grossly overrated as an issue. And it is an interesting piece — it’s a very good illustration both of the desperate desire to see a debt crisis, and what happens when someone (Portman, or more likely the staffer who wrote it) tries to be a Very Serious Person without actually understanding the numbers or having followed any of the analysis.

headline: A Youthful Vigor, Flowing Through to His Fingertips
abstract: Conor Hanick played, in his own words, an “unorthodox” program at the International Keyboard Institute and Festival on Monday.
lead_paragraph: There is always a downside in describing a young artist like the brilliant New York-based pianist Conor Hanick as a champion of contemporary music. At 31, Mr. Hanick, who holds a doctorate from the Juilliard School, has won acclaim for his exciting performances of new and recent music with orchestras and ensembles around the world. On Monday night he brought his enthusiasm for contemporary music to the two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, at Mannes College the New School for Music, playing an engrossing and, in his own words, “unorthodox” program.

headline: Chaotic Yet Pensive, Pounding the Keys
abstract: The pianist Marc-André Hamelin performed at the International Keyboard Institute and Festival on Sunday, offering both works of obscure composers and repertory standards.
lead_paragraph: Villa-Lobos wrote his “Rudepoêma” — a 20-minute solo work sometimes described as “ ‘The Rite of Spring’ meets the Brazilian jungle” — as a portrait of the pianist Arthur Rubinstein, a friend who had championed his music. Villa-Lobos said he wanted to portray Rubinstein’s “true temperament” in the work.

headline: Yearning for Performers Who Transcend Victim and Vamp
abstract: Olga Smirnova finds complexity in her portrayals of Odette and Odile in the Bolshoi Ballet’s “Swan Lake,” at the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: Much about the current Bolshoi Ballet season at the Lincoln Center Festival is unexplained. Since other Western cities have seen this Moscow company’s productions of “Coppélia,” “Lost Illusions,” “Jewels,” why isn’t New York seeing them? All of them would expand our idea of the troupe. And why has the company not brought Evgenia Obraztsova, Ruslan Skvortsov or Vyacheslav Lopatin? Each has made a striking impression in one or more leading roles in recent live broadcasts by the company; Ms. Obraztsova, in particular, is one of the world’s most exquisite classical stylists. You’d think that a troupe that lost Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev in 2011 would be working harder to prove that it has an abundance of remaining stars.

headline: Turkey: Officers Arrested in Spy Case

abstract: Dozens of Turkish police officers were detained on Tuesday and accused of spying on Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his top aides.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Turkish police officers were detained on Tuesday and accused of spying on Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his top aides, news agencies reported. The Istanbul chief prosecutor’s office, in a statement carried by the semiofficial Anadolu News Agency, said the officers had fabricated an investigation into a supposed terrorist group as a pretense to spy on top officials. More than 500 prominent figures have been illegally wiretapped since 2010, CNN Turk television reported, citing the prosecutors’ office. More than 100 officers have been charged with falsifying evidence, illegal wiretapping and espionage, and 67 were taken into custody in a 22-city security operation. Some of those who were detained were involved in a corruption inquiry that ensnared Mr. Erdogan’s close circle and forced four ministers to resign in December, news reports said. Mr. Erdogan has said the graft investigation was driven by people loyal to Fetullah Gulen, a cleric who lives in Pennsylvania and is a former ally who still has influence in various state institutions. Sinan Ulgen, a visiting scholar at Carnegie Europe in Brussels, called the arrests “the latest episode in the war waged against the Gulen community.”

headline: U.N. Warns of Polio Risk in War Zones
abstract: The United Nations expressed concern about the possible spread of polio in the war-ravaged countries of Syria and Iraq and beyond on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations expressed concern about the possible spread of polio in the war-ravaged countries of Syria and Iraq and beyond on Tuesday despite the biggest vaccination campaign undertaken in the history of the Middle East. A report by the World Health Organization and Unicef said that 36 children had been paralyzed by the polio virus in Syria since the disease first reappeared there last October after a 14-year absence. Polio also has been detected in two Iraqi children in Baghdad, and it paralyzed one of them in April, the report said. Although 25 million children under the age of 5 have been vaccinated multiple times in seven Middle East countries under an emergency campaign, the report said many Syrian children missed out because of fighting and restrictions on distributing medical aid. The report said 765,000 Syrian children under 5 live in hard-to-reach areas. Polio, which is spread by feces, was thought to be nearly eradicated a few years ago, but it has spread in some fragile countries this year. In May, the W.H.O. declared a global health emergency because of the resurgence, imposing travel restrictions on Pakistan, Syria and Cameroon because the virus had spread from those countries to neighbors.

The ruling, which The Board calls “mindless and harmful,” seized on “poorly drafted” language in the Affordable Care Act to end subsidies in the states that opted not to set up a state health exchange and instead relied on the federal exchange. “It defies common sense to think that Congress really intended that there be no subsidies at all in 36 states,” The Board writes. For now, the outcome is unclear: A second federal appeals court panel ruled the opposite way just a few hours later and the Obama administration is expected to appeal the first decision. “Consumers are expected to retain their coverage and tax credits while this and similar suits in other jurisdictions wend their way through the court system.” In future decisions, The Board calls for “common sense in interpreting the law, not ideological opposition to Obamacare.”

I’m really that person.” This month, on the tail end of a summer European trip that included stops in Paris and Capri, Fernandez traveled for the first time to the mountainous Mediterranean island of Corsica. What was originally planned as a weeklong jaunt stretched out to nearly twice that amount when Fernandez found out that her friend Laure Heriard Dubrueil, the owner of Miami’s the Webster boutique whose family has a house on the island, was heading over. “It’s really incredible that you can go to a place so close to France that’s so wild and refined and understated and not polluted with too much of anything,” Fernandez says. headline: His Own Godfather
abstract: The new biopic “Get On Up” covers the life of James Brown, an artist who despite personal challenges exerted a lasting influence in pop music.
lead_paragraph: It’s just the kind of movie clip YouTube was made for. In the 1965 Frankie Avalon vehicle, “Ski Party,” James Brown and his backing vocal group, the Famous Flames, enter a ski lodge after rescuing a frozen reveler. Resplendent in a white-and-red sweater, tight black slacks, black pointy-toed shoes and a regal pompadour, Brown performs “I Got You (I Feel Good),” giving the lily-white crowd of clapping skiers a taste of the showmanship that had made him a star on the so-called “chitlin circuit” among blacks. Even in a movie as disposable as “Ski Party,” Brown turned a corny scene into genuine entertainment.

headline: Ghost Towns, Puffins and Unspoiled Views
abstract: Exploring the Bonavista Peninsula, one of Newfoundland's most dramatic appendages, two decades after a fishing moratorium was declared.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Miller throttled back the engines of his 27-foot boat and entered the pinched harbor at Ireland’s Eye, an uninhabited, rock-rimmed island that lies eight miles off another, much larger island: Newfoundland. Scattered piles of weathered, gray boards dotted the steep, grassy banks like forgotten kindling. The captain held up a black-and-white 8-by-10 photo that echoed the view circa 1940. Back then, the timber stacks were clearly houses, schooners rested at anchor, and on the farthest hill stood a white church. Now, in the church’s place, a steeple lay in the tall grass. Worshipers last attended a service here in 1965, before a government resettlement policy forcibly moved the 157 residents of the remote fishing village, or “outport,” to larger communities in order to centralize the population.

headline: An Elegant New Boutique Hotel in French-Colonial Pondicherry, India
abstract: La Villa, an intimate six-room getaway opening August 1, offers an eclectic take on luxury.
lead_paragraph: India’s sliver of the Francophonie, the region where French is still the official language, occupies a grid of tree-lined boulevards just south of city of Chennai along the Coromandel Coast, facing east toward the Bay of Bengal. Streets bear names like Rue de la Campaigne and Rue Labourdonnais. Buildings in the White Town (also called the French Quarter) are still graced with long verandahs and elegant compound walls, a genteel French-colonial vision straight out of Indochina, inflected with the pastel calm of India’s palm-fringed south. Since 2006 the town has officially been known as Puducherry, but most people here and across India still call it by its original name, Pondicherry, or its loving diminutive, Pondy.

headline: A Chinese Caesar Salad With Umami

lead_paragraph: Mission Chinese Food is a restaurant in San Francisco with an outlet that pops up occasionally in an old stable behind an Italian-restaurant compound in Brooklyn, where it offers a set dinner menu cooked in a catering kitchen that’s shared with the German steakhouse on the corner. One of Mission Chinese’s owners is a chef named Danny Bowien, a skateboardy young man who was born in Korea and raised in Oklahoma City. Bowien cooks punk-rock food to a hip-hop soundtrack. That makes him, functionally, a hippie.

headline: Do Personhood Laws Protect Or Harm?
abstract: A debate is unfolding over a new Tennessee law that allows pregnant women who take opiates to be charged with assault.
lead_paragraph: Jessica DeSamito, a Navy vet who had been arrested in 2011 for drug possession, started using heroin again this February after her release from prison. Soon after, she became pregnant. In May, the San Antonio thirty-year-old failed a random urine test administered by her parole officer, and in July, as punishment, she was sent back to jail before being released to house arrest. The same week that Ms. DeSamito was reincarcerated, Mallory Loyola, a twenty-six-year-old with a history of using methamphetamine, gave birth to a child in Tennessee. Two days later, she was arrested and charged with assault – the first woman to be charged under a new law, effective July 1, that criminalizes the use of opiates while pregnant. Ms. Loyola later admitted that she had smoked meth three or four days before the baby was born, and was released on bail.

headline: How’s California Doing?
abstract: Jobs and insurance and surpluses, oh my.
lead_paragraph: The states, said Louis Brandeis, are the laboratories of democracy — although that may not work as well as it used to now that the “I’m not a scientist” wing has taken complete control of the GOP. Still, state experiences can tell the rest of us something. There’s been a lot of talk lately about how the great Kansas tax-cut experiment is doing, namely very badly. But what about the anti-Kansas — California? It’s a state with a Democratic supermajority. Its policies aren’t left-wing in the way Kansas’s are right-wing, but it’s enough of a liberal agenda to have the right frothing at the mouth. So how is it going?

lead_paragraph: Is the pencil over? It’s no secret we’ve turned to keyboards and touch screens to convey our thoughts, complete our work in the office and design everything from bespoke stationery to custom footwear. For most, it’s hard to recall the last time an octagonal wooden shaft rested between our fingers. But for a select set of highly creative individuals, writing instruments are still in high demand. headline: A Dietitian Who Won’t Oversell Nutrition to Her Kids
abstract: I learned long ago that nutrition information alone doesn’t motivate people to eat healthy, and I know telling my children that “broccoli will make them big and strong” could backfire.
lead_paragraph: We sit down to eat and the bowls of food are passed around. I help my 5-year-old get his food, while my 7-year-old can fend for herself. If they refuse an item, like broccoli, I don’t get into how good it is for them or how it will make them big and strong. Instead, it goes on a separate plate in case they change their mind or want to learn more about the food, which is often new or unfamiliar.

headline: 1964: East Germany Seeks Germans in Poland
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: East Germany tries to persuade Germans living in Poland to move to East Germany in 1964.
lead_paragraph: BONN — East Germany, one of the few countries of the world to suffer a loss of population following the war, is seeking to add Germans now living in Poland to its undermanned labor force. The West German Red Cross said today that East German consulates were carrying on an active campaign in Poland to persuade persons of German extraction to move to East Germany. The campaign has thus far been unsuccessful. However, reports circulated in West Germany that Poland and East Germany were about to sign an agreement for the mass resettlement of 150,000 such persons. Those involved presumably would have no choice over their fate, according to these reports. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 24, 1964

headline: Classical Playlist: Herbert von Karajan, Brahms, Tchaikovsky and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: HERBERT VON KARAJAN: Choral Music 1947-1958Works by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms(Warner Classics; five discs)Warner Classics has issued a series of 13 box sets of the recordings Herbert von Karajan made for EMI between 1946 and 1984, all newly remastered. This five-CD album of choral works offers Beethoven’s “Missa Solemnis” from the mid-1950s with the Philharmonia Orchestra and a 1947 Brahms “German Requiem” with the Vienna Philharmonic. Of special interest for me is the 1952 account of Bach’s Mass in B minor, with the Philharmonia Orchestra, the Singers of the Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde and quite a quartet of vocal soloists: Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Marga Höffgen, Nicolai Gedda and Heinz Rehfuss. This recording, the one I grew up with, harkens to an earlier time of weighty, thick-textured Bach performances. Contrast Karajan’s opening “Kyrie,” which lasts 12:17 minutes, with Philippe Herreweghe’s 1996 account on period instruments, an undulant 9:29! Still, Karajan draws solemnity, depth and character from the score. A fascinating recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: 5 Ways To Help Your Kid Not Stink At Math
abstract: The “new math” curriculum is great — and nearly guaranteed to drive children and their parents understandably insane, because teachers don’t know how to teach it yet. Here’s what to do to help your child while they learn.
lead_paragraph: In “Why Do Americans Stink at Math” for this week’s edition of the magazine, I wrote about the latest wave of math reforms, which are both the best chance we have of curing our national “innumeracy” (the mathematical equivalent of not being able to read), and a near guarantee at driving children and their parents understandably insane. As I write in the story, the problem is not the new approach itself. The problem is our widespread failure to help teachers figure out how to teach in the new way.

headline: Dole, Slumped but Sharp, Returns to Senate to Push Disabilities Treaty
abstract: Former Senator Bob Dole implored the Senate to act swiftly to ratify a treaty that would provide greater protections for disabled people all over the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Senator Bob Dole returned on Wednesday to the institution he once led, his posture more slumped, his legs less sturdy, but his wits still sharp.

headline: Why the ‘Sucker List’ of Jordan Belfort, the Wolf of Wall Street, Won’t Be Released to ‘Inside Edition’
abstract: Financial criminals go to great lengths to hunt down and size up their prey, but to the con man, nothing can top the “sucker list” of people who have already fallen for a scam.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing the criminal case against Jordan Belfort, the felon depicted in the movie “The Wolf of Wall Street,” had bad news last month for the syndicated newsmagazine “Inside Edition.” He denied its request for a list of Mr. Belfort’s 1,300 victims.

headline: How Senator John Walsh Plagiarized a Final Paper
abstract: A line-by-line analysis of Mr. Walsh’s 2007 final paper shows that he took much of it from other sources without giving them credit.
lead_paragraph: A line-by-line analysis of Mr. Walsh’s 2007 final paper shows that he took much of it from other sources without giving them credit.

headline: Senator’s Thesis Turns Out to Be Remix of Others’ Works, Uncited
abstract: An examination of the final paper required for Senator John Walsh of Montana’s master’s degree from the Army War College indicates that at least a quarter of it was appropriated without attribution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats were thrilled when John Walsh of Montana was appointed to the United States Senate in February. A decorated veteran of the Iraq war and former adjutant general of his state’s National Guard, Mr. Walsh offered the Democratic Party something it frequently lacks: a seasoned military man.

headline: Nibali Still Leads the Pack as Fast Food Fails to Help the Vuelta Winner
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Vuelta a Espana (Bicycle Race)', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Chris Horner, who beat the Tour de France leader, Vincenzo Nibali, to win the 2013 Vuelta a España at age 41, finished 29th in Wednesday’s stage. Rafal Majka won it.
lead_paragraph: PLA D’ADET SKI STATION, France — Vincenzo Nibali, the leader of the Tour de France, may seem invincible at the moment, but Chris Horner knows how to beat him. Last year, Horner crushed Nibali in the mountains to become the first American to win the Vuelta a España.

headline: Deutsche Bank Shares Waver on Reports of Regulator’s Letter
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: News reports of the criticism by regulators is a setback for Deutsche Bank in its efforts to convince investors and the public that it is remaking itself to be more ethical and less risky.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:34 p.m. | FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank shares slipped slightly Wednesday, and its efforts to rebuild its reputation suffered another blow, after reports that a regulator in the United States had found serious problems with the bank’s financial reporting procedures and oversight.

headline: Met Opera Prepares to Lock Out Workers
abstract: A letter warned members of the orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers to prepare for a lockout if no contract deal is reached by next week.
lead_paragraph: The labor strife at the Metropolitan Opera took on a new urgency Wednesday when its general manager, Peter Gelb, sent the company’s orchestra, chorus, stagehands and other workers letters warning them to prepare for a lockout if no contract deal is reached by next week.

headline: Nelson Peltz’s Efforts to Shake Up Pepsi Get Backing of Calstrs
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The California State Teachers’ Retirement System, known as Calstrs, has sent a letter to a senior PepsiCo director, urging the food and beverage company to put Nelson Peltz on its board.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:11 p.m. | The activist investor Nelson Peltz has won the support of one of the largest pension funds in the United States in his campaign against PepsiCo.

headline: Pressure Grows on E.U. Regulator to Rethink Google Settlement
abstract: An antitrust inquiry into Google’s search engine and advertising business could last for many years.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — During the past five years, Google has taken a gingerly approach to fighting its antitrust battles in the European Union, nurturing a working relationship with Joaquín Almunia, the bloc’s competition commissioner, and patiently presenting him with three sets of proposals to settle antitrust complaints that it favored its own business over that of rivals in search results.

headline: Stealing a Page From the Boomers’ Playbook
abstract: A member of the “aging industrial complex” starts a campaign against ageism.
lead_paragraph: When we last checked in with Alice Fisher, Hurricane Sandy had forced her ailing 90-year-old parents out of their ruined co-op apartment in Long Beach, N.Y., where they had expected — with the enthusiastic approval of their two daughters — to live out their days.

headline: Learning ‘Lear': Perform, Rehearse, Stagger Home
abstract: John Lithgow recounts how it feels to perform in the first preview of “Lear.”
lead_paragraph: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses “King Lear” for Shakespeare in the Park.

headline: John Walsh: From the Military to Politics
abstract: Mr. Walsh served for more than three decades in the National Guard before being elected Montana lieutenant governor in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Walsh, Democrat of Montana, was appointed by Gov. Steve Bullock in February to fill the seat vacated by Max Baucus, a six-term senator who stepped down to become the United States ambassador to China.

headline: Stephen Colbert Will Keep CBS’s ‘Late Show’ in New York
abstract: The successor to David Letterman will tape the show from the same location — the Ed Sullivan Theater on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: New York’s status as the center of late-night television was reinforced on Wednesday after CBS announced that its “Late Show," which under David Letterman has been based in New York since 1993, will remain in the city when Stephen Colbert steps in as host next year.

headline: Workman Names Dan Reynolds Chief Executive
abstract: Mr. Reynolds will take over the role of Peter Workman, the publisher’s founder, who died last spring.
lead_paragraph: Workman Publishing, one of the country’s largest independent publishers of nonfiction trade books, has appointed a new chief executive, its first since the death of its founder, Peter Workman, last spring.

headline: Prosecutors Sidestep Race as Trial Begins in Shooting of Black Michigan Youth
abstract: Theodore P. Wafer is facing second-degree murder charges in the shooting death of Renisha McBride.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The trial of a suburban homeowner accused of the shotgun shooting of a young black woman last fall opened on Wednesday with jarring images projected on a large screen before jurors. Renisha McBride, 19, grinning for the camera. And then, Ms. McBride, bloodied and lifeless on a porch.

headline: After Split Vote, S.E.C. Approves Rules on Money Market Funds
keywords: ['Money Market Accounts', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Nearly six years since the panic after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the S.E.C.’s new rules are intended to prevent investors from dumping their shares in funds during times of stress.
lead_paragraph: Regulators on Wednesday imposed new restrictions on a vast market that played a significant role in the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: The Location May Stay the Same, but Everything Else Will Change
abstract: The World’s Fair Play Festival at the Queens Theater features short works inspired by the 1964 and 1939 World’s Fairs.
lead_paragraph: It’s not quite site-specific theater, but the World’s Fair Play Festival, a collection of short works by well-regarded playwrights, benefits beautifully from its location: the Queens Theater on the grounds of the 1964 and 1939 World’s Fairs. The writers have delivered nuggets that catch the wistful ambience of the place deliciously.

headline: Ángel Corella Is Named Artistic Director of Pennsylvania Ballet
abstract: The former American Ballet Theater principal Ángel Corella will become the artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet in September, the company announced on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The former American Ballet Theater principal Ángel Corella will become the artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet in September, the company announced on Tuesday.  Mr. Corella, who left Ballet Theater in 2012 to devote himself to the company he had founded in 2008 in his native Spain, closed that troupe, the Barcelona Ballet, last year. (The company toured in New York in 2010 and 2012, receiving mixed reviews.)

headline: Remembering a Man Whose Death Made Him a Symbol of a Divide
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation']
abstract: Mourners of Eric Garner, who died on Staten Island after an officer apparently put him in a chokehold, said there were systemic problems in the relationship between residents and the police.
lead_paragraph: As the sun set over Brooklyn on Wednesday, hundreds of people gathered to mourn a man who died after begging for air.

headline: UBS Being Investigated in France Over Tax Evasion
abstract: In a case similar to one brought by American prosecutors, UBS faces charges of money laundering and tax fraud for helping French clients to hide money from the French tax authorities.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – UBS, the largest Swiss bank, was placed under formal investigation by the French authorities on Wednesday and ordered to post bail of more than $1 billion in the kind of tax-evasion case that ensnared it in the United States several years ago.

headline: Travels in a Maze in Mexico
abstract: Francisco Goldman’s new book, “The Interior Circuit,” recounts the troubles that he and his adopted home, Mexico City, have seen, and his attempts to rebound from his.
lead_paragraph: On the back cover of Francisco Goldman’s new book about Mexico City, two blurbs describe it as funny. Now Mexicans can be very funny, but there is nothing funny about “The Interior Circuit: A Mexico City Chronicle.” How could there be? Dwelling as it does on booze, drugs, corruption, violence and murder, it offers a decidedly bleak picture of one of the world’s largest metropolises.

headline: On Capri, a Chic New Shop Takes a Stand Against Sameness
abstract: Helen White, a former assistant to Anna Wintour and fashion writer for Harper’s Bazaar, opened Cabana last month. It’s full of custom-made items for the home and the closet.
lead_paragraph: “This whole business was against mass prestige,” explains Helen White in the intimate space of Cabana, her newly opened shop on Capri. In a world in which luxury is becoming ubiquitous and traveling to Asia lands you in the same shops you’d find on Madison Avenue, she is indeed taking a position. Cabana is unique: almost everything in its edited collection of objects and clothes for resort life is not available anywhere else. Many items, from cutlery (bamboo-handled knives emblazoned with the store’s name) to beach bags, are sourced and designed by White and custom-made for the store.

headline: Breaking Cabaret’s Rules, and Just Shrugging It Off
abstract: The Broadway star Patti LuPone makes a declaration of independence with her disregard for the niceties of torch singing in a show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: What does the torch refer to in Patti LuPone’s scorching cabaret show, “The Lady With the Torch”?

headline: Twist and Plunge on Outlaw Run
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Roller Coasters', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Take a virtual ride on the Outlaw Run roller coaster at Silver Dollar City in Branson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: Take a virtual ride on the Outlaw Run roller coaster at Silver Dollar City in Branson, Mo.

headline: New Twists for Wooden Roller Coasters
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Roller Coasters']
abstract: In the past few years, three wooden coasters that take their riders upside down have been built. See what these next-generation woodies can do, taking one for a virtual ride.
lead_paragraph: Wait, a wooden coaster that goes upside down? For many of us who have spent a lot of our childhoods (and adulthoods) at theme parks, the idea of a wooden coaster with a loop or a spiral seems counterintuitive. After all, woodies, as they’re called, are known for their sprawling beauty, not the heart-pounding features that have made modern steel coasters so exciting.

headline: Gilead’s Hepatitis C Drug, Sovaldi, Is on Pace to Become a Blockbuster
abstract: Sales of Sovaldi reached $3.5 billion in the second quarter, testifying to the effectiveness of the drug, which can essentially cure over 80 percent of patients with few side effects.
lead_paragraph: Sales of the new hepatitis C drug Sovaldi reached $3.5 billion in the second quarter, a huge figure that puts it on track to become one of the world’s best-selling medicines but could intensify concerns about society’s ability to pay for it.

headline: Commission for Dead Composer, and Other Pieces
abstract: The eclectic program played by the Knights on Tuesday at the Naumburg Bandshell featured works by Stravinsky, Ligeti and Sufjan Stevens.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Tuesday evening’s concert by the Knights at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park, the WQXR radio host Annie Bergen asked the violinist Colin Jacobsen a question about the last item on the program. Why did he think Stravinsky’s “Dumbarton Oaks” concerto was a good fit for them?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: A Trumpeter and Mentor Goes With What He Knows Best
abstract: The trumpeter Marcus Belgrave and his band kept a sense of proportion during a set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: At the center of the trumpeter Marcus Belgrave’s band on Tuesday night was a nucleus of familiarity, and not the kind that leads to autopilot thinking, but the kind that stays engaged and present, the rare and underrated kind.

headline: The Thrill of a Lifetime, Tinged by Teary Respect
abstract: The National Youth Orchestra, whose members range in age from 16 to 19, projected both eagerness and depth in its concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the concluding work in the inspiring concert by the National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, the conductor David Robertson spoke to the audience about the “irrepressible enthusiasm and energy” of the young players, ages 16 to 19, in this select ensemble. Even after a concert lasting two and a half hours, a program that opened with a fresh, urgent account of Bernstein’s Symphonic Dances from “West Side Story” and ended with a weighty, richly characterized performance of Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition,” these eager players looked ready for more.

headline: Facebook’s Profit Propelled by Mobile
abstract: Mobile devices accounted for nearly two-thirds of the social networking company’s revenue, which rose 61 percent over the same quarter last year.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Once again demonstrating its mastery of the mobile computing wave, Facebook dazzled Wall Street on Wednesday by posting significant growth in revenue and profits for the second quarter, driven largely by ads shown in the news feeds of a billion Facebook users checking the service on their mobile phones.

headline: Officials on Taiwan Plane Crash
abstract: Taiwan’s transport minister discussed the search efforts after a TransAsia Airways plane crashed in bad weather during an emergency landing, and the airline’s president apologized.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s transport minister discussed the search efforts after a TransAsia Airways plane crashed in bad weather during an emergency landing, and the airline’s president apologized.

headline: Shake, Shake, Shake: Let the Best Man Win
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Movies', 'Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Passinho is a preening, athletic dance craze, with mostly male performers, that spread via YouTube, and can now be seen in New York.
lead_paragraph: It’s a story we’ve heard before. In a ghetto best known to the outside world for drugs and crime, young people come up with a new dance style.

headline: Registering History
abstract: The National Register of Historic Places listed 803 sites when it was created. Now it’s over 90,000.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “96 Historic Sites Approved by U.S.” appeared on July 19 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Gabby Women, Silent Men? Maybe Not
abstract: Recent research has found that who talks more depends on context. So why does the stereotype that women always out-talk men persist?
lead_paragraph: The idea that women talk more than men remains popular enough that it’s accepted in some circles as fact. But over the past few years, some have called it into question — and now new research shows that who talks more may depend on the situation.

headline: A Double-Digit Swing at Grand National Teams
abstract: Three big events were decided in Las Vegas on Sunday evening.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Three big events were decided here on Sunday evening.

headline: Tilting at Sunshine
abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet, known for the physical vigor of its performances, adds bravado and spontaneity to its “Don Quixote.”
lead_paragraph: It does the heart good to see the Bolshoi Ballet be jolly. On Tuesday night, as this Moscow company danced the first of three performances of “Don Quixote,” you could feel the whole air in the theater change. The opening week of “Swan Lake” at the Lincoln Center Festival had been so dispiritingly overcast, but now here was the sun.

headline: Enter Will, With Tongue Still in Cheek
abstract: The Oscar-winning film that pondered the sexual and writing habits of William Shakespeare is adapted for the stage in “Shakespeare in Love: The Play.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Many people, it must be said, prefer the idea of Shakespeare’s plays to the reality of them. Whether they admit it or not, such souls feel that Shakespeare is great for seasoning but indigestible as a main course. They’re often the ones you hear promiscuously peppering their conversation with the canon’s best-known lines or speaking of failed politicians as “truly Shakespearean.”

headline: Speaking Her Language
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Dresses', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants']
abstract: Long-sleeve minidresses take hold; Charlotte Gainsbourg inspires a Current/Elliott collection; and new shops from International Playground and Whisper Editions.
lead_paragraph: The actress, singer and Nicolas Ghesquière muse Charlotte Gainsbourg, celebrated for her undone Parisian style, has joined forces with the Current/Elliott creative director Serge Azria on a capsule collection that’s out this week. The garments reflect the prevailing perception about the strenuously edited French wardrobe, with its combination of unfussy staples and just-loud-enough statement pieces. There are sharp blazers and raw denim jeans, which, worn together, is very much Ms. Gainsbourg’s look, and layering knits and cotton shirting to mix in. A red leather jacket is one of the standouts, and there’s a pair of mini (read: supershort) shorts that are covetable but may require Gainsbourg genes to pull off. At currentelliott.com.

headline: Photos of the Day: Netherlands and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Netherlands, Gaza City, Israel and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Netherlands, Gaza City, Israel and India.

headline: New General Motors Recall Covers 800,000 More Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The auto company announced six more recalls on Wednesday for various flaws, and its worldwide recall total for 2014 is 29 million.
lead_paragraph: General Motors announced six recalls on Wednesday, expanding beyond the ignition switch defects that have plagued the company, and bringing its total for the year to 60 recalls involving about 29 million vehicles worldwide.

headline: In Chelsea, a Pedestrian-Friendly Night of Art
abstract: The city’s gallery district stays open late tomorrow evening with a series of shows and events for the fifth annual Chelsea Art Walk.
lead_paragraph: On one evening each summer since 2010, the Chelsea Art Walk has transformed the gallery-rich blocks of New York between West 16th and 30th Streets into a welcoming arena for visitors, connoisseurs and people getting off work to discover contemporary art. It returns this Thursday, July 24, for its fifth iteration, with nearly 100 participating galleries, nine open studios, artists’ talks and, naturally, cocktail ceremonials from 5 to 8 p.m. The event uses the High Line as its central vein, giving visitors the ability to experience a Manhattan sunset from above the busy streets between gallery pop-ins.

headline: At a Spanish Border, a Coordinated Scramble
abstract: African migrants said they camped out for months to study the border guards' patterns as they prepared to scale the fences and enter Europe.
lead_paragraph: MELILLA, Spain — More than 1,000 African migrants rushed toward the high fences topped with razor wire. They were met by the Moroccan police, who, with the support of the Spanish military police and a Spanish helicopter, thwarted their plan to scale the fences and enter Europe through this tiny Spanish enclave that clings to northern Morocco.

headline: AT&T Gains Customers, but Its Profit Is Slightly Lower
abstract: The communications giant, in reporting its second-quarter results, said its contract-free plans helped attract many new subscribers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — AT&T has made major changes to its phone plans in the past year, and those moves are paying off.

abstract: Molly Wood reviews LG’s new G watch, which is powered by Android Wear, Google’s new operating system for wearable devices.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood reviews LG’s new G watch, which is powered by Android Wear, Google’s new operating system for wearable devices.

headline: No Joke! He’s Topping the Charts
abstract: Weird Al Yankovic’s “Mandatory Fun” is the first comedy album to top Billboard’s album chart since 1963.
lead_paragraph: At some point last week, Weird Al Yankovic’s Twitter account became unmanageable.

headline: You Don’t Need Glasses to See the Message
abstract: Image issues affect both male and female leaders, the latest debate set off by President François Hollande of France’s glasses.
lead_paragraph: Once again the question of sex discrimination when it comes to politics and fashion has reared its pundit-baiting head.

abstract: Google's operating system for wearable devices has some promising features, but they’re not ready yet.
lead_paragraph: GOOGLE has a new operating system for wearable devices like smartwatches. It’s called Android Wear and it works like a miniature version of an Android phone on your wrist.

lead_paragraph: The image of two Indian girls – victims of gang rape – hanged from a tree has inspired discussion on the use and impact of such a graphic image.

headline: Six Indicted on Hacking Charges Related to StubHub Tickets
abstract: What do tickets to Jay-Z, the Yankees and “The Book of Mormon” have in common? Authorities say a criminal ring used stolen credit-card information to buy those hard-to-get tickets and pocketed the money when they resold them.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in New York indicted six people on charges that they were part of an international crime ring that defrauded the online ticketing service StubHub of some $1.6 million.

headline: Famous Eyebrows
abstract: Eyebrow trends, like hairstyles, tend to be cyclical and led by women with memorable eyes.
lead_paragraph: Eyebrow trends, like hairstyles, tend to be cyclical and led by women with memorable eyes.

headline: Brow of the Decade
abstract: The bushy brow has returned to fashion. Bringing it back to your face is more difficult.
lead_paragraph: When Joni Mitchell warbled that you “don’t know what you’ve got till it’s gone,” she was referring to trees and flowers, but her lament could just as easily apply to the bushy forest of a woman’s eyebrows: Once plucked, the terrain is never the same.

headline: With All Due Deference
keywords: ['AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Minorities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a ruling on the University of Texas affirmative action case, the Fifth Circuit supplies what the Supreme Court’s decision lacked: understanding.
lead_paragraph: Given the avalanche of world-shaking news since last week, the shrug greeting the latest chapter in the long-running affirmative action saga at the University of Texas is understandable. Even the usually lively constitutional law blogosphere has had little to say about the July 15 ruling  by which the federal appeals court in New Orleans once again upheld the flagship Austin school’s admissions plan.

headline: The Number That Many French Businesses Fear
abstract: Taking on a 50th person unleashes nearly three dozen labor regulations that are a serious burden for companies.
lead_paragraph: ÉGUILLES, France — Philippe Plantier, a seasoned French mountaineer, was rappelling down a cliff more than a decade ago when the inspiration struck: He could turn his passion for climbing into a business.

headline: Acetaminophen No Better Than Placebo for Back Pain
abstract: In a large trial, researchers discovered that pills like Tylenol worked no better than a placebo, but could help with other pains.
lead_paragraph: About two-thirds of adults have lower back pain at some point in their lives, and most are told to take acetaminophen, sold under brand names like Tylenol and Panadol. Medical guidelines around the world recommend acetaminophen as a first-line treatment.

headline: Style in Nashville’s 12South Neighborhood
abstract: A touch of the West, in the form of boots, and a hat in the style of Jakob Dylan will remind this young resident of home when he moves east.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the 12South neighborhood of Nashville has undergone drastic changes. The city improved the sidewalks and increased street lighting. More residents and popular businesses, like Jeni’s Splendid Ice Creams and the denim purveyors Imogene & Willie, have moved in. On a balmy day typical of Nashville summers, Logan Yandell was relaxing at a local coffee shop, the Frothy Monkey. Mr. Yandell will be moving to Boston soon to further his music studies, and sees his signature Goorin Brothers hat, ostrich-skin boots and tattoos as a way to stay connected to home. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Martha Stewart and Dom Pérignon Are a Match Made in the Hamptons
abstract: The deity of domesticity hosted a party to celebrate the Champagne maker’s 1998 vintage.
lead_paragraph: In some places, a neighbor may ring your doorbell with a basket of scones or muffins. In East Hampton, N.Y., how about a bottle of vintage 2004 Champagne?

headline: Mister Sunday Parties at Industry City in Brooklyn
abstract: The weekly Mister Sunday parties have found a happy home at Industry City, a warehouse complex in Sunset Park.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, in a dappled grove on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, the weekly Mister Sunday parties built an ardent following as a laid-back disco day camp. This year, forced out of its bucolic birthplace by a real estate development, the party relocated to Industry City, a warehouse complex in Sunset Park. Could it recreate that same mellow magic in its new locale?

headline: S.E.C. Scrutinizes McGraw Hill Over Commercial Mortgage Securities
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: McGraw Hill said the S.E.C. had sent the company a Wells notice over commercial mortgage-backed securities that were rated by its S.&P.’s Ratings Services subsidiary.
lead_paragraph: McGraw Hill Financial, the parent company of the Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services, could face an enforcement action related to six commercial mortgage-backed securities issued in 2011.

headline: Fare Thee Well, My Pen
keywords: ['Computer Monitors', 'Pens and Pencils', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The pen has finally met its demise, losing out to finger and the touch screens it controls.
lead_paragraph: The pen is dead. It was murdered by the finger.

headline: Foreign Correspondents in Israel Complain of Intimidation
abstract: Some Israelis, incensed by reporting on Gaza they call overly sympathetic to Palestinians, have started to take their frustration out on correspondents.
lead_paragraph: As the death toll mounts and passions spike, the Foreign Press Association in Israel condemned on Wednesday what it called “deliberate official and unofficial incitement against journalists” who are reporting on the fighting in Gaza. That includes “forcible attempts to prevent journalists and TV crews from carrying out their news assignments,” the association said.

headline: New York City Asks Cultural Groups to Help Enhance Municipal IDs
abstract: Cultural institutions have been invited to offer benefits to New York municipal ID cardholders, part of an effort to expand use of the new cards beyond undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: The much-heralded municipal identification card announced this month by the de Blasio administration will make it easier for undocumented immigrants in New York City to check out library books and sign a lease.

headline: Fake IDs, Still Coveted, Are Harder to Get
keywords: ['Identification Devices', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Drivers Licenses', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: For under-age drinkers, a phony card is now high tech, and it comes at a high price.
lead_paragraph: What is the true cost of a fake ID these days? Samantha K., a 19-year old college student, is still finding out.

headline: Art, and Handbags, for the People
keywords: ['Art', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'T-Shirts (Apparel)', 'Frieze Art Fair']
abstract: Jeff Koons and H&M come up with an affordable collaboration.
lead_paragraph: AMONG THE IMAGES inscribed on Jeff Koons’s consciousness is a black-and-white photograph of the legendary art dealer Leo Castelli presenting a bronze Jasper Johns flag to President John F. Kennedy. For Mr. Koons, the moment was a watershed. “People from film, music and other areas of the arts have always participated in the popular culture,” he said. “But before that time, the fine arts had been neglected.”

headline: Pop-Up Shops, Sales and Special Offers in New York City
abstract: Show your support at temporary shops, find bargains and snag some pricey handmade sunglasses.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Poking the Fourth Wall
abstract: Bars and nightclubs have started hosting theatrical shows as a way of drumming up foot traffic during off-hours.
lead_paragraph: “There are eight million people in New York City, and three million of them are drunk,” said Ben Maters, 24, an actor and bartender at Fat Baby, a multilevel bar on Rivington Street on the Lower East Side.

headline: Candleholders: Waxing Poetic
abstract: They’re jewelry for the home, even when bereft of candles — or covered in their residue.
lead_paragraph: Last year, as part of his work at Heath Ceramics, Tung Chiang designed about 120 candlesticks. They weren’t all intended to be manufactured; it was more of an exploratory exercise.

headline: A Two-Ring Circus
abstract: As in two circus tents. Also in this Catskills retreat, a ballroom, psychedelic school buses and a secret compartment. A washer and dryer? Maybe later.
lead_paragraph: COTTEKILL, N.Y. — Five years ago, on a very long train ride from Ulan Bator in Mongolia to Beijing, Kat O’Sullivan and Mason Brown took out a notebook and made a list of all the things their dream house should have. On a recent afternoon here, Ms. O’Sullivan, an artist who makes colorful patchwork sweaters out of other sweaters she finds at thrift stores and then sells them through Etsy, and Mr. Brown, who works part-time for a publisher and plays in a band, dug out the list and read it to a curious visitor.

headline: New Gleanings from a Jewish Farm
abstract: A rural Connecticut program teaches perennials, permaculture and pickling. But no work on the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: FALLS VILLAGE, Conn. — Come seek enlightenment in the chicken yard, young Jewish farmer! Come at daybreak — 6 o’clock sharp — to tramp through the dew and pray and sing in the misty fields. Let the fellowship program called Adamah feed your soul while you feed the soil. (In Hebrew, “Adamah” means soil, or earth.) Come be the vanguard of Jewish regeneration and ecological righteousness!

headline: From Beets to the Borscht Belt
abstract: Even in the 19th century, Jews had roots in agricultural colonies.
lead_paragraph: The annals of Jewish agriculture in the United States are a little like the story of great Jewish baseball players. After you’ve name-checked Sandy Koufax and Hank Greenberg, the conversation becomes terminal.

headline: Twitter, Like Other Big Tech Companies, Comes Up Short on Diversity
abstract: The social media company’s report on employees’ gender and ethnic backgrounds is the latest in a string of reports indicating that when it comes to diversity, the tech industry has “a lot of work to do.”
lead_paragraph: The technology industry continues to provide evidence that it is not terribly diverse.

headline: A Mad Dash to Points South
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Restaurants', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: As Condé Nast prepares to anchor 1 World Trade Center, the businesses that cater to its staff have been angling for space within walking distance (in stiletto heels, of course).
lead_paragraph: Over the last four years, the Lamb’s Club has evolved into the Condé Nast canteen. On any given afternoon, you might spot Anna Wintour holding court at her corner table, dining with the CBS chief executive Les Moonves, Tory Burch or Tommy Hilfiger. Nearby, you might find the W editor Stefano Tonchi exchanging a quick handshake with Jason Wu or Michael Kors on his way out. Condé Nast publishers, editors and executives work the dining room every day and bring in as much as “20 percent of our daily breakfast and lunch business,” said David Rabin, an owner of the restaurant on 44th Street.

headline: Polishing the Imperfection
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Design', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: A modernist house was rough around the edges, but the price and provenance were right.
lead_paragraph: By now, it is an almost universally acknowledged truth that affordable apartments near San Francisco are difficult, if not impossible, to find. And overlooked architectural gems? At this point, surely nothing in the Bay Area has been overlooked.

headline: New Ingredients in Classic Cookware
abstract: Thomas Keller refines a collection for All-Clad.
lead_paragraph: All-Clad TK, a partnership with the celebrity chef Thomas Keller, is not a reinvention of All-Clad’s cookware, but a touch-up. Many of the pots and pans in the new line, which is divided into the TK Foundation Set (about $800), the TK Integrity Set (about $1,000) and the TK Inspiration Set (about $1,600), are modified versions of existing products.

headline: The Maya Decorators Had It Tough
abstract: Grain’s latest textiles — and the pillows sewn from them — show off the weaving traditions of their Guatemalan makers.
lead_paragraph: Grain’s new line of decorative pillows was produced with Maya artisans in Guatemala — the country, as it happens, where the company’s now-married founders met eight years ago while students at Rhode Island School of Design. At that time, James and Chelsea Minola were introduced to the region’s fabric-making techniques, including the use of foot looms and indigenous-plant dyes, and they have been working with the makers ever since. “Colors can vary depending on the season and how much rain they’ve had,” Ms. Minola said, adding: “It’s a little nerve-racking from a designer’s point of view: You can’t match a Pantone chip and you can’t always get it exactly perfect.” This mildly erratic quality, however, is part of the charm of the five textiles in the new collection. The pillows come in two sizes: 16-inch square and 20-inch square, and range in price from $118 to $285. Information: 206-965-9302 or graindesign.com.

headline: A Virtual Collective of New York Designers
abstract: WorkOf.com features the goods of some 60 furniture makers, many from Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Last year while attending BKLYN Designs, a trade fair presenting the work of Brooklyn furniture makers, Charlie Miner and John Neamonitis, colleagues at a financial research firm on Wall Street, found a conundrum in the collections they saw. If visitors were attracted to, say, a Shaker-inspired table or hammered-brass pendant light, and decided six months later that they wanted to buy it, how would they find that particular item? “We decided to make the process easy,” Mr. Miner said. In January they introduced WorkOf.com, a website that sells goods by some 60 makers in the New York area, such as Stefan Rurak, a Brooklynite whose Hephaestus chair, pictured ($1,500), is solid ash that has been torched then sealed with oil and trimmed in black leather. Designers who wish to be considered for inclusion can apply on the site. Information: WorkOf.com.

headline: So Down-to-Earth, You Could Spend Time Haggling
abstract: Sean Naftel of the artist duo Attenborough-Naftel on their latest work: a yard sale in a Chelsea gallery.
lead_paragraph: Chris Attenborough, 36, and Sean Naftel, 31, artists who collaborate as Attenborough-Naftel, have a guiding principle when creating the installations they specialize in. “In our minds, if we’re not having fun, we don’t want to make the art,” Mr. Naftel said.

headline: Horns of Plenty
abstract: From Unitfive Design in Toronto, a trophy stag that you don’t have to bag.
lead_paragraph: First came the buck, then came the bling.

headline: Discounts at Desiron, Frederick P. Victoria & Son and Aero
abstract: Sales on furniture and lighting.
lead_paragraph: All new furniture orders are up to 35 percent off at Desiron, through July 31 (the Hudson sofa, shown, is regularly $6,600, is $4,662); 200 Lexington Avenue (32nd Street), Suite 702, 212-353-2600, desiron.com.

headline: With Trade Deadline Looming, Mets’ Colon Is Untouchable Into the Seventh
abstract: Bartolo Colon allowed his first base runner with two outs in the seventh, and the Mets hung on to defeat the Mariners.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Bartolo Colon politely clapped his glove, his back turned, as Robinson Cano trotted to first base. Cano had just slapped a single to left with Colon seven outs from a perfect game. Colon adjusted his cap and kicked the dirt. Appreciating the moment, the Safeco Field crowd stood and applauded.

headline: Afghanistan’s Election Result Hinges on a Squabble-Prone Audit
keywords: ['Elections', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Hundreds of observers in Afghanistan are working to separate fraud from fact in last month’s presidential runoff. But the process has only yielded new disputes and confusion.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Seemingly endless squabbles are interrupted by full-scale shouting matches. Campaign aides mutter suspiciously about what foreign visitors might be up to. And ballot boxes are piling up, waiting to be cracked open and examined for signs of fraud.

headline: An Idiot’s Guide to Inequality
abstract: If you don’t have time for Thomas Piketty’s comprehensive best seller, here’s a quick five-point take on the gap between the rich and poor.
lead_paragraph: We may now have a new “most unread best seller of all time.”

headline: Paul Ryan and His Poverty Prophet
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Poverty', 'Welfare (US)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Will a new conservative anti-poverty plan, however well-intended, just lead directly to the soup kitchen?
lead_paragraph: After being chastised early this year for proclaiming that there was a “tailspin of culture,” particularly among inner city men, of “not working and just generations of men not even thinking about working or learning the value and the culture of work,” Paul Ryan is going to take another swipe at an anti-poverty proposal.

headline: For Obama, Protectiveness About Daughters Gives Way to Pride
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When he became president, President Obama vowed to shield his daughters from the public and press. Now, he can’t stop talking about them.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — President Obama moved his family into 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue five and a half years ago vowing to shield his young daughters from the prying eyes of the public and the press.

headline: Let Our Oil and Gas Go

lead_paragraph: AS a young reporter covering energy for The New York Times, I saw firsthand the distortions and inefficiencies caused by the web of regulations that followed the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74, and the resulting surge in gasoline prices.
