keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreign Investments', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The resignation of the Bulgarian prime minister and his cabinet extends the wrangling over a rescue plan for the troubled bank, Corporate Commercial Bank.
lead_paragraph: The fate of one of the biggest banks in the European Union’s poorest country, Bulgaria, remains hostage to a political crisis, which caused the prime minister’s government to resign on Wednesday.

headline: What I Saw on Rikers Island
abstract: Ritual humiliation of inmates leads to death of the soul.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY served 58 days of a three-month sentence on Rikers Island. I was convicted in May of assaulting a New York City police officer as the police cleared Zuccotti Park of Occupy Wall Street protesters in 2012. (I am appealing my conviction.) I got a firsthand experience that I did not seek of what it is like to live behind bars.

headline: 42 Are Killed in Bombings Aimed at Nigerian Figures
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Officials said the terrorist bombs in the northern city of Kaduna were intended for Muhammadu Buhari, a leading politician, and Sheik Dahiru Bauchi, a cleric.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Bombs targeting two prominent Nigerians, a cleric and a leading politician, exploded in the northern city of Kaduna on Wednesday, killing at least 42 people but missing the intended victims, officials said.

headline: Turning Wind Into Electricity
abstract: With a sprawling network of new high-voltage power lines, Texas is conducting an experiment that might hold lessons for the rest of the United States.
lead_paragraph: With a sprawling network of new high-voltage power lines, Texas is conducting an experiment that might hold lessons for the rest of the United States.

headline: Texas Is Wired for Wind Power, and More Farms Plug In
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Supporters say the wind farm experiment is essential if states want to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and meet new federal rules on carbon emissions.
lead_paragraph: PANHANDLE, Tex. — The wind is so relentless that a week can go by before it is calm enough for a crane operator to install the 30-ton blades atop the 260-foot towers at the Panhandle 2 wind farm here. It’s worth the wait; a single turbine at the farm can produce 40 percent more energy than an average one.

headline: Food Safety in China Still Faces Big Hurdles
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Food', 'Meat', 'Chickens']
abstract: From factory inspections to product recalls, laboratory testing to prosecutions, China’s emergent food-quality apparatus has turned into reform on the fly, with ever-changing threats and setbacks.
lead_paragraph: China has been scrambling to right its gargantuan processed-food ship ever since six infants died and thousands more were hospitalized with kidney damage in 2008 from milk adulterated with an industrial chemical.

headline: American Apparel Names a New Board, Minus Dov Charney
abstract: After a riveting corporate shake-up that began last month after the firing of its controversial founder and chief executive, Dov Charney, American Apparel named four new members to its board.
lead_paragraph: American Apparel announced four new members of the company’s reconstituted board on Wednesday, the most recent step in a riveting corporate shake-up that began with last month’s firing of the company’s controversial founder and chief executive, Dov Charney.

headline: Robert Newhouse, 64, Rusher Whose Pass Secured a Title, Dies
abstract: Mr. Newhouse, who played 12 seasons in the N.F.L., mostly as a fullback, threw a touchdown pass on a trick play in the Super Bowl in 1978.
lead_paragraph: Robert Newhouse, a hard-working running back for the Dallas Cowboys who played in three Super Bowls and helped win one of them not just with his legs but also with his arm — throwing a game-clinching touchdown pass against the Denver Broncos in 1978 — died on Tuesday in Rochester, Minn. He was 64.

headline: Boeing Earnings Take Hit Over Problems in Air Force Tankers
abstract: Boeing stock took a 2.3 percent dip after the company announced $425 million in charges over a problem with Air Force refueling tankers.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Wednesday that it took $425 million in pretax charges against its second-quarter earnings over problems with the wiring in the refueling tankers it is developing for the Air Force.

headline: Ryder Uses New Campaign to Highlight Array of Services for Businesses
abstract: The company wants executives to know that it is a business-to-business solutions provider that helps companies manage their fleet and supply chain functions better than they can themselves.
lead_paragraph: RYDER SYSTEM, the truck leasing, maintenance and logistics management company, is introducing its first advertising campaign in almost 20 years to update business leaders on the breadth of its services.

headline: Prosecutors Snooping on Legal Mail
abstract: Federal prosecutors are abusing the most important privilege in the American legal system by accessing emails between inmates and their attorneys.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever consulted a lawyer knows that private communications seeking legal advice are confidential. The attorney-client privilege is the oldest, broadest and most important of all privileges in the American legal system.

headline: Philadelphia Man Accused in Nazi Case Dies
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Extradition']
abstract: After ordering the extradition to Germany of Johann Breyer, 89, who served as an armed guard at Auschwitz, a judge learned that the man had died hours earlier.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In what will most likely be one of the last Nazi cases on American soil, an 89-year-old Philadelphia man who served as an armed guard at Auschwitz during World War II died Wednesday, just hours before a judge ordered him extradited to Germany in the murders of 216,000 prisoners at the notorious concentration camp.

headline: Iraq’s Imperiled Minorities
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Editorials', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Minorities', 'Chaldean Catholic Church']
abstract: The brutal crackdown by Sunni extremists deserves the strongest possible international condemnation.
lead_paragraph: The Sunni extremists who control large swaths of Iraq recently presented Christians in Mosul with an ultimatum: Convert to Islam, pay a religious tax or die by the sword. The militants gave them until July 19 to comply, and by the deadline hundreds of the city’s remaining Christian families had fled from this cruel choice. The exodus goes far beyond the harm suffered by individual families forced to leave their homes.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Broken Promises
abstract: The governor of New York created an independent commission to root out corruption in Albany, but he blocked investigations of his own office behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo ran for office four years ago promising first and foremost to clean up Albany. Not only has he not done that, but now he is looking as bad as the forces he likes to attack.

headline: Quick Action in Chokehold Case Has Shielded de Blasio From Ire, for Now
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio quickly ordered aides to reach out to community leaders and the family of Eric Garner, who died in police custody, limiting the mayor’s exposure to direct criticism.
lead_paragraph: After Mayor Bill de Blasio watched a video of Eric Garner slipping into unconsciousness as the police subdued him last Thursday, he issued an order.

headline: I Was the Sick Passenger
abstract: A glimpse of New York City’s softer side.
lead_paragraph: I was the sick passenger on the No. 2 train, the one responsible for the line’s delay. It was I who kept New Yorkers from their destinations, and prompted the notice that thanked them for a quality they’re not known to have.

headline: New Rules for Part-Time Work
abstract: Should there be a law limiting unpredictable schedules for hourly and part-time workers?

headline: Track Team Is Peerless and, Seemingly, Ageless
abstract: Five men set world records in three relay events last weekend because, according to USA Track & Field, they were the first team of nonagenarians to compete in a relay at an official meet.
lead_paragraph: LAKE RIDGE, Va. — There’s no exact blueprint explaining how to build a dream team, but it usually starts with a star, like LeBron James, and backbreaking and sometimes heartbreaking attempts to woo others to create an untouchable superpower that can win championships.

headline: At Hall, a Blank Look Is in Style
abstract: When the bronze plaques of Greg Maddux and Tony La Russa are unveiled at the annual induction ceremonies at the Baseball Hall of Fame on Sunday in Cooperstown, their caps will have no logos.
lead_paragraph: A baseball cap can be doffed, waved and turned around. It can fly off the head of an outfielder pursuing a fly ball or be pulled down over the forehead to frame a pitcher’s glare at a batter.

headline: G.O.P. Plan on Migrants Calls for Less Cash Than Democrats and Obama Seek
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Human Trafficking', 'Law and Legislation', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: With days left until Congress begins its recess, House Republicans and Senate Democrats are struggling to reach a compromise on the amount of funds to allot to the migrant crisis at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans unveiled a $1.5 billion plan on Wednesday to address the crisis of thousands of young migrants along the southern border, proposing significantly less than President Obama and Senate Democrats say is necessary and setting up a standoff over pushing through the emergency funds before Congress begins its five-week break at the end of the month.

headline: Arizona Takes Nearly 2 Hours to Execute Inmate
abstract: In an eerie parallel to a botched execution in Oklahoma in April, Joseph R. Wood III repeatedly gasped for one hour and 40 minutes on Wednesday before dying, according to witnesses.
lead_paragraph: In another unexpectedly prolonged execution using disputed lethal injection drugs, a condemned Arizona prisoner on Wednesday repeatedly gasped for one hour and 40 minutes, according to witnesses, before dying at an Arizona state prison.

headline: As Much of the World Frowns on Israel, Americans Hold Out Support
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Civilian Casualties', 'International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The failures of the Arab Spring to spread democracy in the Middle East have left many in America more inclined to side with Israel, which has lost backing elsewhere, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Israel’s incursion into Gaza enters its third week and Palestinian civilian deaths mount, reaction in the United States has been muted, with polls through last weekend showing most Americans still supportive — in part, analysts say, because of the failures of the Arab Spring to spread democracy in the Middle East. But in a situation long familiar, Israel is losing the public relations war outside the United States.

headline: Wheelies: The Keystone Velocity Edition
abstract: Pennsylvania announces a higher speed limit along part of the Pennsylvania Turnpike; Porsche and Hyundai score well in a J.D. Power owner survey.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: N.C.A.A. Players’ Winning Streak, Off the Field
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Basketball (College)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Several changes, including the N.C.A.A.'s decision not to ask student-athletes to sign statements allowing promotional use of their likenesses, come amid growing unrest over the amateur model of college sports.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the multibillion-dollar college sports industry, under increasing legal scrutiny over the rights of student-athletes, have begun rolling back some of the most contentious policies regarding amateurism.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for July 23, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Swindlers Target Kin of Migrants
abstract: The F.B.I. is investigating how con artists received detailed information about migrant children being housed at military bases to lure relatives into paying hefty sums to reunite their families.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The federal government is investigating how detailed information about migrant children being held at two American military bases wound up in the hands of con artists who are using it to lure unsuspecting relatives into paying hefty sums to reunite their families, preying on people who have been separated for years, according to the F.B.I.

headline: Violent Attacks on Homeless in Albuquerque Expose City’s Ills
abstract: Three teenagers have been arrested in killings that the police said were staggering in their brutality.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Jerome Eskeets’s last sight before he fell asleep on a soiled mattress late on Friday, on an empty lot speckled by shards of liquor bottles and discarded syringes, was the stars that glistened up above — “a beautiful thing,” he recalled this week, drunk, already, at 9:30 a.m. A cousin lay next to him that night, their bodies warmed by the cheap vodka they had shared. It had been “a good night,” Mr. Eskeets said, until he felt a dull pain on the bridge of his nose, a punch by one of the masked assailants that surrounded them.

headline: A Celebrity’s Welcome in Italy for de Blasio
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio was treated to a rock star’s reception in Sant’Agata de’ Goti, the birthplace of his maternal grandfather, where he was awarded honorary citizenship.
lead_paragraph: SANT’AGATA DE’ GOTI, Italy — Mayor Bill de Blasio was leaving the cemetery in this picturesque hillside town, where his grandfather was born and his ancestors are buried, when an elderly Italian woman standing nearby made the sign of the cross.

headline: General Manager’s Recipe for Giants: Youth and Speed
abstract: Jerry Reese, the Giants’ general manager, said age may have played a role in the team’s woeful performance last season, but he expressed confidence in quarterback Eli Manning.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — General Manager Jerry Reese said little last year as the Giants decayed. The team was aging and lacked imagination offensively. When the Giants’ record dropped to 0-6, they became the butt of jokes nationwide.

headline: Ryan Feels ‘Incredible’ About Jets, Who Show Lots of Confidence Themselves
abstract: As training camp began, Coach Rex Ryan said, “I don’t know if we’ve had a better quarterback situation,” and the backup Michael Vick talked of becoming “even better.”
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — On the eve of training camp, the Jets checked into their dormitories at SUNY Cortland with the things that would sustain them for the next three weeks: laptop computers and flat-screen televisions, video-game systems and beloved pillows, and, to a man, an unshakable confidence in their prospects for this season.

headline: Control of Senate May Hinge on Georgia Race
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: After David Perdue’s victory in the Republican primary, he will face off against the Democrat Michelle Nunn in what many in both parties see as a race crucial to gaining a majority in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Now that David Perdue has emerged as Georgia’s Republican Senate nominee with his runoff victory, the race is shaping up as a battle of two candidates pitching themselves as Washington outsiders: Mr. Perdue, a businessman caricatured by Democrats as a heartless fat cat, and Michelle Nunn, painted by Republicans as a liberal masquerading as a moderate.

headline: Bolstered by Ruling, Republicans Attack Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Republicans pointed to a ruling by an appeals court panel, which said premium subsidies paid to millions of Americans were illegal, as evidence of problems in the law that could not be solved easily.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress resumed their campaign against the Affordable Care Act on Wednesday with new zeal, fired up by a ruling of a federal appeals court panel that said premium subsidies paid to millions of Americans in 36 states were illegal.

headline: A Rolling Stone Gathers No Moss
abstract: A debut by David Phillips, who gathers no moss.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — The song on which today’s puzzle theme is based gets stuck in my head a lot for reasons I don’t quite understand, and now that I have solved David Phillips’s New York Times puzzle debut, I will never get rid of it. Thanks a lot, Mr. Phillips.

headline: Israel Says That Hamas Uses Civilian Shields, Reviving Debate
abstract: Israel said it takes precautions to avoid killing civilians but because its adversaries embed forces throughout Gaza, it strikes at targets where large numbers of civilian casualties are likely.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Militant rockets can be seen launching from crowded neighborhoods, near apartment buildings, schools and hotels. Hamas fighters have set traps for Israeli soldiers in civilian homes and stored weapons in mosques and schools. Tunnels have been dug beneath private property.

headline: Ruling on Health Care Subsidies Puts Coverage at Risk
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A federal court ruling barring some subsidies under the health care law raised the possibility that many of the 4.5 million people who were found eligible for them would drop their coverage.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Even with a federal subsidy to help cover the cost, Gloria Spottswood has had to squeeze her household budget to afford the health insurance she bought this year through the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Port Authority Approves $90 Million in Upgrades at Bus Terminal
abstract: Travelers at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's Midtown Manhattan bus terminal will see improvements, but a significant overhaul will have to wait.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Wednesday approved $90 million in upgrades to its moldering Midtown Manhattan bus terminal, calling it “functionally obsolete” in its current form.

headline: 8 Are Removed as Queens Library Trustees
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The dismissed members voted in April not to fire the director of the library system, who is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Eight members of the Queens Library board of trustees were dismissed on Wednesday by Mayor Bill de Blasio and the borough president, Melinda Katz, according to the mayor’s office.

headline: After Tough Competition, Rival Baby E-Commerce Sites in Brazil to Merge
abstract: Baby, an e-commerce site that was once the darling of Silicon Valley’s ambitions in Brazil, is being acquired by its rival BebeStore.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The online baby and maternal products company BebeStore completed an agreement to acquire its former rival Baby, and was expected to announce the deal this week.

headline: In Downpour, Delay by the Grounds Crew Helps the Yankees
abstract: As rain lashed Yankee Stadium, the grounds crew struggled to get the tarp over the infield, and the game was called with one out in the bottom of the fifth.
lead_paragraph: As the rain lashed Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night and the grounds crew struggled to get the tarp over the infield, it grew increasingly clear that this normally routine procedure had gone sideways and would affect the outcome of the game.

headline: For Muslims in New York, Observing Ramadan Is a Blend of Rituals Far and Near
abstract: New York City’s estimated 600,000 to one million Muslims mark the holiday with traces of the religious rituals of their home countries.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering afternoon, Mohab A. Sewilam worked at his 40th Street lunch cart, serving hot dogs and gyros in the thick of the Times Square crowds. Finished cooking, he handed a hot dog to a waiting customer. But he had not eaten lunch himself this day, or for the previous two weeks.

headline: Crash Victims to Undergo Routine Tests, Experts Say
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Forensic Science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Some of the testing may help illuminate exactly what happened to the jetliner after it was hit by a surface-to-air missile.
lead_paragraph: While the circumstances surrounding the Malaysia Airlines disaster in Ukraine are far from ordinary, forensic experts said that the examination of victims’ bodies, now just beginning at a Dutch military base, should be relatively routine.

headline: Over Government Objections, Rules on No-Fly List Are Made Public

headline: Photography as a Balm for Mental Illness

headline: Rain Cuts Short Once-in-a-Generation Performance of ‘Hommy’
abstract: The first performance in 40 years of “Hommy: A Latin Opera,” a 1973 album by Larry Harlow’s Orchestra Harlow that was meant as a salsa rejoinder to the Who’s “Tommy,” was stopped halfway through.
lead_paragraph: One theme of “Hommy: A Latin Opera” — a concept album released in 1973 by Larry Harlow’s group Orchestra Harlow as a salsa rejoinder to the Who’s rock opera “Tommy” — is that what looks like a calamity can be a blessing in disguise. Alas, not so for what was to have been the first performance of “Hommy” in 40 years, produced by Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Wednesday at Damrosch Park. It was a full-scale concert production, complete with orchestral string and horn sections, a core salsa band, a chorus and a procession of vigorous singers. But less than halfway through its one scheduled performance, a deluge and lightning storm shut down the concert.

headline: Morning Views

headline: The Jenny Lewis Experience
abstract: The indie darling and former child star is back after six years of anguished silence — and she wants to blow your mind.
lead_paragraph: “They’d put the ‘Do Not Disturb’ sign on,” Jenny Lewis said. We were sitting in a restaurant in Laurel Canyon, not far from her home, and she was describing her early childhood with parents who made their living performing as an itinerant Sonny-and-Cher-style lounge act called Love’s Way. “We lived in hotels,” she said. “My sister and I, they would just keep us in the hotel room, and they’d go down and play.” When Lewis was born in 1976, her parents were doing a stand at the Sands. They split up when she was 3, and her mother — herself the daughter of a dancer and a vaudeville performer — took Jenny and her sister to Van Nuys, in the San Fernando Valley, where she worked as a waitress and struggled to keep her family afloat. “We were on welfare,” Lewis said, before describing the day their fortunes changed, when an agent picked young Jenny out of a crowd at her preschool. “I think mostly because I was a redhead,” she said. “And I was a weird little kid, a weird little tomboy.”

headline: In Ukraine, Spent Cartridges Offer Clues to Violence Fueled by Soviet Surplus
abstract: Samples of cartridge cases gathered by two reporters for The New York Times in eastern Ukraine showed that ammunition for assault rifles used in the clashes originated in plants that once were mainstays of Soviet arms production.
lead_paragraph: With its independence in 1991, Ukraine inherited a huge and unneeded stockpile of arms and ordnance from its former Soviet masters. In the years since, the country’s businessmen, security services and cargo carriers, operating in an environment plagued by corruption, have repeatedly been accused of trafficking the surplus in black-market arms deals to Africa and the Middle East. So it was little surprise that this year, after fighting broke out, that Ukraine felt the sting of what had been its own shadowy trade. Exactly the sort of weapons it has long exported found bloody use on Ukrainian soil.

lead_paragraph: I have a bias against convenience stores that started when I was seven years old, and my father and I stopped at a Suwannee Swifty to get an Icee. Afterward we drove a couple extra miles to a Piggly Wiggly grocery store to get milk. When we got home, I asked my dad why we hadn’t just bought the milk at the Suwanee Swifty. He said it would have cost us double because the store charged extra for the convenience of being closer to our home.

Yatsenyuk resigned abruptly on Thursday after the governing coalition of Parliament collapsed, creating uncertainty about the makeup of the government in Kiev as it continues its fight against pro-Russian separatists in the country’s restive east.

headline: Walmart U.S. Chief Leaving; Successor Headed Asian Unit
abstract: The executive will be replaced as of Aug. 9 by Greg Foran, who is head of the company’s Asian unit.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Walmart’s United States division is leaving the company and will be replaced by the head of its Asian division, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Bloomberg Hires a Founder of The Verge to Lead Online Initiatives
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Josh Topolsky, who also worked at Engadget, will oversee a series of new online journalism ventures.
lead_paragraph: Josh Topolsky, the co-founder of the technology website The Verge, will join Bloomberg as the editor of a series of online ventures it is introducing as part of a revamped journalism strategy.

headline: G.O.P. Congressman’s Plan to Fight Poverty Shifts Efforts to States
abstract: A proposal by Paul Ryan to consolidate programs into one, shifting efforts from the federal government to the states, is part of a broader strategy to increase the party’s appeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin, outlined a plan to combat poverty on Thursday that would consolidate a dozen programs into a single “Opportunity Grant” that largely shifts antipoverty efforts from the federal government to the states.

headline: Spectators to War, West Bank Residents Hail the Hamas Fight Against Israel
abstract: Two protesters were reported killed in the West Bank, bringing the total number of protesters killed there in the last week to five.
lead_paragraph: AL AMARI REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Maher al-Naden, a street cleaner, said he had stopped buying Tapuzina, a popular Israeli orange-flavored drink, and Israeli dairy products.

headline: Barclays Asks Court to Dismiss New York Suit Over Its ‘Dark Pool’
abstract: The bank argued that its customers were sophisticated enough to understand that “glossy marketing brochures” about its private market did not reflect its actual composition.
lead_paragraph: Barclays filed a motion on Thursday to dismiss a lawsuit brought by New York State’s attorney general that accused the bank of lying to customers of its private stock market.

headline: Metaphysical Sleight of Heart
abstract: In Woody Allen’s “Magic in the Moonlight,” a magician is summoned to the French Riviera to expose a young clairvoyant who has won over a rich family.
lead_paragraph: “Magic in the Moonlight,” Woody Allen’s new film, stages a debate that will be familiar to anyone who has seen more than a couple of the previous 43. There are various ways to characterize the argument: between reason and superstition; between doubt and faith; between realism and magic. On one side is the belief in some kind of unseen, metaphysical force governing the universe; on the other is the certainty, shared by the director, that no such thing exists. Not incidentally — and not for the first time in Mr. Allen’s oeuvre — the opposed positions are advanced by a dyspeptic middle-aged intellectual and a much younger, relatively untutored woman. Among the big jokes this time around: She misattributes a literary quotation and seems never to have heard of Nietzsche.

headline: Sculptures Found in Disputed Art Trove
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Experts investigating hundreds of works hidden by a Munich art collector and believed to have been looted by Nazis identified the pieces.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Experts say they have found what they believe to be a sculpture by Edgar Degas, a small marble figure by Auguste Rodin as well as a painting and other sculptures, in the Munich home of Cornelius Gurlitt, the reclusive German art collector who kept hundreds of European masterworks, many of them possibly looted by the Nazis, stashed in his apartment for decades. Mr. Gurlitt died in May.

headline: Paul Ryan and the Party of Ideas
abstract: Notes on the House Budget Chairman’s latest proposals.
lead_paragraph: I will probably have more to say about Congressman Paul Ryan’s latest policy proposals on poverty and mobility — both their substance and their possible implications — very soon; either tomorrow or in Sunday’s column, mostly likely. You can read a good summary of the highlights here; for now, I’ll just make two quick and one slightly longer points:

headline: Lively Surroundings for Man and Beasts
abstract: Julius Towers found an apartment to buy in South Central Harlem.
lead_paragraph: When Julius Towers arrived in New York in 2003, he rented a place on the Upper East Side. Two years ago, wanting a change, he moved to a one-bedroom in a contemporary high-rise in Long Island City with a postcard view of Manhattan. His rent was around $2,900 a month.

headline: One Room for Many Guests
abstract: Each of the 36 rooms in NYAH (Not Your Average Hotel) in Key West, Fla., can be customized according to the number of guests, thanks to modular furniture that can be rearranged.
lead_paragraph: For those who like traveling in groups but want an alternative to the cookie-cutter hotel room with rollaway beds, NYAH (Not Your Average Hotel) in Key West, Fla., has a solution: Each of its 36 rooms can be customized according to the number of guests, thanks to modular furniture that can be rearranged. Gustaf and Jesper Arnoldsson, brothers who own NYAH, came up with the concept for the hotel, opened in February. “We saw that sharing a room was not so much a move to save money as it was about having a unique experience,” Jesper Arnoldsson said in a phone interview.

headline: Britain Brings Corruption Charges Against Unit of Alstom
abstract: The Serious Fraud Office said it had charged Alstom Network UK with six corruption-related offenses linked to contracts in India, Tunisia and Poland.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — British authorities said on Thursday that they had brought criminal charges against a unit of Alstom, the French industrial conglomerate that is selling its energy business to General Electric. A five-year investigation, authorities said, found evidence of corruption in large transport contracts in India, Tunisia and Poland.

headline: Venice Film Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The festival, which runs from Aug. 27 through Sept. 6, features 55 films, 20 of which are in competition.
lead_paragraph: ROME — “Birdman or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance,” Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s black comedy about a former action hero, will open the 71st Venice Film Festival, its organizers announced on Thursday. It will compete with new films from Abel Ferrara, David Gordon Green, Andrew Niccol and others for the Golden Lion award.

headline: In Portugal, Ex-Chief of Bank Is Arrested
abstract: The former official was brought to court for a hearing in a major money laundering and tax evasion case aimed at a Swiss asset management company.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The problems of Portugal’s most powerful family deepened Thursday when Ricardo Espírito Santo Silva Salgado, the patriarch and the former head of its bank, was arrested and ordered to post bail of 3 million euros by a judge leading a major money laundering and tax evasion case.

headline: With Lead Extended, It’s All Downhill to Paris
abstract: Only illness, accident or profound bad luck are likely to prevent Vincenzo Nibali from winning the Tour de France on Sunday after his stage victory on Thursday in the mountains.
lead_paragraph: ARGELÈS-GAZOST, France — Alexander Vinokourov, the manager of Vincenzo Nibali’s Astana team, said Nibali used Thursday’s final mountain stage of the Tour de France to show that he was the “padrone,” or boss, of the cycling world.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Tour of Hospice
abstract: I welcomed the idea of touring a new hospice facility to confront my fears of pain while dying, writes Susan Gubar in her continuing “Living With Cancer” series.
lead_paragraph: Before the visit, I had been split in two not by fear of death but by dread of dying — in anxiety, dementia, but mostly in pain from recurrent ovarian cancer.

headline: Conservatives Hone Script to Light a Fire Over Abortion
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Social conservatives are moving to put abortion at the center of the midterm elections, despite warnings from other Republicans to tread lightly on social issues.
lead_paragraph: It was not on the public schedule for the Republican National Committee’s spring meeting at the stately Peabody Hotel in downtown Memphis. But inside a conference room, a group of conservative women held a boot camp to strengthen an unlikely set of skills: how to talk about abortion.

headline: A Craig Grant Show and a New Lucy Thurber Play Coming From Labyrinth Theater
abstract: The Labyrinth Theater Company’s 2014-15 season will open with a one-man show by Craig muMs Grant.
lead_paragraph: The Labyrinth Theater Company, an enterprising Greenwich Village group that specializes in new work, will open its 2014-15 season with “A Sucker Emcee,” a one-man show written and performed by Craig Grant. The work is built on a blend of hip-hop, slam poetry and Mr. Grant’s personal recollections, and will be directed by Jenny Koons. It is scheduled for September, a spokeswoman for the company said, but the specific dates will be announced later. The company’s performances are at the Bank Street Theater.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Proposal Hints at Change in Tone on Poverty
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Poverty', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: His new plan would expand the Earned Income Tax Credit to a larger group of people, essentially making a low-wage job more attractive.
lead_paragraph: Something about the new anti-poverty plan from Representative Paul Ryan feels different from his previous efforts to overhaul the system of support for the poor.

headline: Do You Work Too Much?
abstract: Researchers and workers themselves are paying increasing attention to the problem of overwork, and some say the culture of certain professions makes burnout inevitable.
lead_paragraph: The American economy generally operates on the assumption that the more hours you work, the better an employee you are. But increasingly, researchers and workers themselves are saying that working to the point of burnout can be unhealthy, unproductive, and even dangerous — and some are advocating for large-scale solutions that tackle the problem at its source.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Television Is Muscling Out Movies
abstract: Ads for television shows seemed to take over San Diego as the convention began.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO – As the Comic-Con International fan convention got underway here on Wednesday night, it became clear that 2014 is the year of the castle.

headline: Botox Maker’s Bosses Put Money Where Their Mouths Are
abstract: Allergan, the target of a $52 billion hostile bid, is linking stock and option grants to lofty profit goals. It is a bold tactic that should become a norm in M.&A., contends Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Allergan‘s bosses have put money where their mouths are.

headline: Today in Small Business: Chief Happiness Officer
abstract: The owner of the Denver Broncos offers a sad reminder on the importance of succession planning.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: A Search and Destroy Thyself Mission
abstract: In “A Most Wanted Man,” a grim German intelligence agent played by Philip Seymour Hoffman zeros in on a Chechen whom he believes he can link to terrorist cells.
lead_paragraph: An inescapable melancholy pervades the espionage film “A Most Wanted Man,” a smart, bluntly effective adaptation of John le Carré’s post-9/11 political passion play about good, evil and the sins committed in the name of national security. It’s no surprise that the weight of that day and its aftermath hangs over the story, which finds expression in the atmospheric gloom of Hamburg, the port city in which most of the story unfolds, and in the movie’s assembly of crushed and deflated souls. Most of all, there’s the presence of Philip Seymour Hoffman as Günther Bachmann, a German intelligence officer and man of sorrows driven by his uncompromising belief in himself.

headline: Ex-Chelsea Midfielder Joins New York Expansion Club
abstract: Frank Lampard, 36, and New York City F.C. confirmed the signing on Thursday, bringing the expansion soccer team’s roster to four players.
lead_paragraph: The former Chelsea midfielder Frank Lampard joined New York City F.C. on Thursday, becoming the second European Champions League winner signed by the expansion Major League Soccer club.

headline: A Trophy Wife With a Cheesy Heritage
abstract: Marta Milans, whose family owns an organic goat farm in Spain, takes on a complicated role in Tanya Saracho’s “Mala Hierba,” now in previews at Second Stage Uptown.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish actress Marta Milans does not seem like the sort of woman who knows her way around a goat. In “Mala Hierba,” the fiery Tanya Saracho drama now in previews at Second Stage Uptown, Ms. Milans plays Liliana, a Texas trophy wife with “the kind of charm that can’t be taught.” On a recent afternoon, she flounced around the rehearsal room in a see-through shirt and snakeskin sandals. Silver bracelets dangled from her wrist; black polish gleamed from her fingernails.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Pay $275 Million in Mortgage Case
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The Wall Street firm and securities regulators have finalized a $275 million settlement stemming from the 2007 sale of securities backed by subprime mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley and securities regulators finalized a $275 million settlement on Thursday stemming from the Wall Street bank’s role in the sale of securities backed by subprime mortgages.

headline: Court Censures Poland Over C.I.A. Renditions
keywords: ['Extraordinary Rendition', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Interrogations']
abstract: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that by allowing the transfer of two terrorism suspects to a secret C.I.A. site in Poland, the country violated the men’s rights.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The European Court of Human Rights ruled Thursday that Poland had violated the rights of two terrorism suspects by allowing their transfer to a secret detention center run by the C.I.A. in Poland, where the two men were tortured.

headline: Study Gives Hope of Adaptation to Climate Change
abstract: Research on flies in drier conditions indicates that some have the genes to survive longer over generations.
lead_paragraph: As we pour heat-trapping gases into the air, we’re running an experiment. We’re going to see what a rapidly changing climate does to the world’s biodiversity — how many species shift to new ranges, how many adapt to their new environment and how many become extinct.

headline: Seeing the Child, Not the Disability
abstract: “People in health care, they don’t stare at my son like he’s some kind of freak, you know? They see him for who he is,” a patient’s mother said at a recent appointment.
lead_paragraph: It had been several months since I had last seen my patient, and even longer since I’d seen his mother. He was 3 and unable to walk or talk, and when I caught his eye, his face broke open into a huge smile, accompanied by the grunting and rhythmic thrusting of his torso and arms that he uses to express himself.

headline: Hermès Names New Designer for Women’s Fashion
abstract: Nadège Vanhee-Cybulski is the first artistic director at the French luxury house in years who isn’t also designing for another brand.
lead_paragraph: New chief executive, new designer.

headline: Deadly Tornado Hits Campground in Virginia Two Times
abstract: A severe storm left two people dead, injured 36 others and sent massive trees flying at a Chesapeake Bay campground filled with vacationing families.
lead_paragraph: A tornado sent towering pines trees crashing into tents, cabins and cars at a popular Virginia campground on Thursday before apparently turning and passing over the site a second time on its way out to sea, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Putting Liberty Island on the Map
abstract: A team from Google set out to create an immersive 360-degree map of Liberty and Ellis Islands on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A team from Google set out to create an immersive 360-degree map of Liberty and Ellis Islands on Wednesday.

headline: Google to Offer Close-Up View of Liberty Island
abstract: On Wednesday, Google began the work of putting Liberty and Ellis Islands on Google Maps with Street View.
lead_paragraph: Alberto Elias polished the 15 camera lenses on his four-foot-tall backpack. As he prepared for his trek around the Statue of Liberty, he took a deep lunge and strapped the green, 40-pound Google Trekker onto his back.

headline: Extended Week for MOMA Boosts Attendance
abstract: Seven-day week has little impact on Metropolitan Museum
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s seven-day-a-week schedule, which it began in May 2013, has pumped up its already strong annual attendance, according to figures compiled by the museum.

headline: Rising Airline Crash Fatalities Making 2014 Even More of an Aberration
abstract: With two more crashed airliners this week, the number of fatalities now stands at 757.
lead_paragraph: Last week, after Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was shot down over Ukraine, The Upshot published a chart of air fatalities and noted that:

headline: Deep in Her Gut, She Knows She’s Not Ordinary
abstract: Luc Besson’s new film, “Lucy,” turns Scarlett Johansson from a frowzy, cheerful young woman into a killing machine.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness (or the goddess) for male directors who dig strong female characters. Whatever their reasons, these directors often expand the range of roles women play, whether it’s one of Howard Hawks’s dames calling the shots or one of James Cameron’s. That the French director Luc Besson, an industrious multi-hyphenate, has a thing for femmes fortes has been evident since 1990, when he unleashed a pouty toothpick in “La Femme Nikita,” a delirious, violent fantasy that turned an outlaw into a gun-toting gamine and an exploitable commodity that, in turn, spawned both an American big-screen remake (“Point of No Return”) and a television series.

headline: Even Utopian Citizens Like to Leave the House
abstract: “Beyond the Supersquare,” at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, looks back at 20th-century modernism in South America and toward new ways to view architecture.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-20th century, certain Latin American cities looked like the most modern on earth. Not only was their architecture imaginative, but so was the thinking behind it: ideas, amounting to faith, that design could positively shape civic life across lines of money and class; that art and architecture were inseparable; that while Europe and the United States were the cultural powers of the day, South America had a shot at tomorrow.

headline: Emma Stone and Colin Firth on Working With Woody Allen
abstract: The co-stars of “Magic in the Moonlight” share memories from the set in Cote d’Azur and insights about the legendary writer-director’s creative process.
lead_paragraph: As Woody Allen maintains his astounding one-movie-per-year pace, the list of actors who’ve appeared in one of his films continues to grow. The newest members of the club are Emma Stone and Colin Firth, who star in the the 78-year-old director’s sumptuous period comedy “Magic in the Moonlight.” In the Cote d’Azur-set story, Firth plays a cynical illusionist with a dry wit and drier worldview who sets out to debunk a woman (Stone) who’s attached herself to a wealthy family by claiming to be a psychic. The two leads spend the film trading barbs among the villas and cliffs of Southern France until eventually — well, you know. The co-stars sat down with T to discuss Allen’s notorious shyness, their terrifying first day and what it’s like to work with a legend.

headline: Ravens’ Rice Draws 2-Game Suspension From Goodell
abstract: After an off-season arrest on a charge of felony assault against a woman, Baltimore running back Ray Rice, received a two-game ban from the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: With training camps opening across the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell has begun handing out suspensions to players for various instances of unacceptable behavior in the off-season. Running back Ray Rice of the Baltimore Ravens drew the first punishment, receiving a two-game ban Thursday in connection with an incident in which he was accused of assaulting a woman who was then his fiancée and is now his wife.

headline: In Argentina, Cycles and Cameras
abstract: The 25-year-old bike touring company Ciclismo Classico has created a series of photography tours in northwest Argentina.
lead_paragraph: The 25-year-old bike touring company Ciclismo Classico has created a spinoff that focuses on seeing as much as doing. The charter destination for a series of photography tours — called TravelVision Journeys — is northwest Argentina. The four scheduled Vision & Vine treks will explore mountain landscape, indigenous communities and high-altitude vineyards. They were developed by Ciclismo founder and enthusiastic photographer Lauren Hefferon, who will co-lead the nine-day trips with the Argentine photographer and documentary filmmaker Ossian Lindholm. Destinations include the  Las Salinas Grandes salt desert, the small cities of Humahuaca and Cachi, and Los Cardones National Park. The first scheduled trip is on Aug. 20.

headline: Spared Sudanese Christian Woman Meets Pope in Rome
abstract: The pope spent half an hour speaking with Meriam Ibrahim, whose death sentence in Sudan for refusing to renounce her faith set off an international protest.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Mariam Ibraheem Ishag, a Christian woman whose death sentence in Sudan for refusing to renounce her faith set off an international protest, arrived in Rome on Thursday morning to a hero’s welcome and a private audience with Pope Francis.

headline: Obama Seeks to Close Loophole That Firms Use to Shield Profits Abroad
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The president asked Congress to remove the tax advantages of inversion, in which corporations designate a foreign country as their official address.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Obama on Thursday called for Congress to strip away tax advantages that have encouraged a rush of mergers and acquisitions that give companies an overseas base while they maintain their presence in the United States.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Hardware: Smart Garbage
keywords: ['Electronics', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Smartphones', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: The old gadgets are piling up. Is there a way to deal with the formerly shiny new things being dumped in the back of closets?
lead_paragraph: There’s a box on a shelf in my closet stuffed with smart smoke detectors, old smartphones, chargers, battery cases, fitness trackers, a Kindle that I sat on and broke and various sensors that have long ceased to detect anything.

headline: Check This Out: Elvis’s Library Card Up for Auction
abstract: A library card with Elvis Presley’s earliest known signature is among the items to be auctioned at Graceland next month.
lead_paragraph: Elvis Presley’s earliest known signature – on a library card he signed as a 13-year-old student in Tupelo, Miss. – is one of the main draws in an auction of Elvis memorabilia to be held at Graceland, the singer’s palatial headquarters, in Memphis on Aug. 14. (The library card was sold at auction for $7,500 – a bargain, you would think – in 2012.)

headline: To Help Mount Giant Time Warner Bid, Murdoch Calls On European Outposts
abstract: A sale of pay-TV arms could help sweeten an $80 billion offer. How Rupert Murdoch treats many non-Murdoch owners involved is the linchpin, says Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch is calling on European outposts to help in his pursuit of Time Warner. The media mogul’s 21st Century Fox is poised to sell its Sky pay-TV arms in Italy and Germany to Fox’s British affiliate, British Sky Broadcasting. There’s strategic logic to the asset shuffle and the proceeds could help sweeten his $80 billion bid for the owner of CNN and Warner Bros. How Mr. Murdoch treats non-Murdoch owners is the linchpin.

headline: Rules for Money Market Funds Arrive, Finally
keywords: ['Money Market Mutual Funds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The slowness of the effort to reduce risk in this important sector is a depressing indication of the overall state of affairs in the financial system.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, a huge chunk of the financial system nearly imploded, and it took an enormous federal bailout to prevent it from bringing down the whole system. That would be money market mutual funds, which millions of American individuals and businesses use to park $2.6 trillion in savings.

headline: Brooklyn Factory, Japanese Food
abstract: Comfort food from Japan, coffee and tea can be relished from an unassuming warehouse in the New York City borough.
lead_paragraph: The wine is in plastic cups, the view of flaking paint, vinyl siding, a tin tub of flowers and graffiti 10 feet tall. It is so quiet on the roof, for a moment we wonder if the people working the cash register downstairs have forgotten we’re up here and have gone home. None of us are in a hurry to find out.

headline: From Kenzo, an Interactive 3-D Virtual Gallery and Fashionable Art Heist
abstract: The brand has created an immersive web experience to showcase its pre-fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Breaking news: an art gallery has been raided and the culprits are fashion models. That, in any case, is the fictional narrative of Kenzo’s new multimedia project, designed to showcase Carol Lim and Humberto Leon’s pre-fall 2014 collection. In an interactive online video exhibition titled “Grace to the Nth Power,” the film director Partel Oliva and the web designers Kim Boutin and David Broner have created a gallery space and “art show” dedicated to the Sudanese-American model Grace Bol. As visitors to the site enter and move around the darkened 3-D gallery, it becomes clear that the artwork inside has been ransacked and replaced by videos showing the thieves in action. One bandit turns out to be the exhibition’s subject, Bol; her accomplice is the male model Sang Woo Kim.

headline: U.S. Considering Refugee Status for Hondurans
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The plan aims to stem the surge at the border, allowing hundreds of minors and young adults to enter the United States without making a dangerous trek through Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to stem the recent surge of migrants at the Southwest border, the Obama administration is considering whether to allow hundreds of minors and young adults from Honduras into the United States without making the dangerous trek through Mexico, according to a draft of the proposal.

headline: Give to Get
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Gifts', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Families and Family Life', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: Addressing fund-raising as a wedding plan, seat-saving at a bar, children’s comments about weight and the scope of a bridal shower.
lead_paragraph: Being one of a dozen cousins, I have been to many family weddings. They have been ostentatious, wasteful affairs, in my opinion, with thousands of dollars thrown away on useless revelry and gifts. I am the last cousin to marry, and my relatives expect the same from me. But my fiancée and I don’t need toasters or linens. We need a down payment on an apartment. We think putting our money toward that is more prudent than buying a fancy wedding dress or floral arrangements. Is there a nice way to tell our families this and still reap the rewards of a wedding (in cash)?

headline: Thanks for the Taunts, Classmates
abstract: Desiree Akhavan is relishing a moment: Her first feature film played at Sundance this year, and now she is getting a role in HBO’s “Girls.”
lead_paragraph: The tall, attractive, very funny woman across the table was a hit at Sundance this year with her first feature film, the comedy “Appropriate Behavior,” and then was summoned by Lena Dunham to join the cast of “Girls” next season. At 29, she’s having, or is about to have, or maybe can look forward to, a moment. But Desiree Akhavan wants you to know there were some rough spots on the way.

headline: Reviewing Those Uncharted Restaurants: The Romance and the Reality
abstract: Ligaya Mishan on exploring New York’s five boroughs in search of interesting bites.
lead_paragraph: Ligaya Mishan writes the Hungry City column for the Dining section (her most recent column, on Brooklyn Ball Factory, appears here). We asked her about her process and about exploring New York’s five boroughs in search of interesting bites.

headline: Ford Ekes Out a Profit in Europe
abstract: The European unit of the automaker posted its first profit in three years in the second quarter, even as it warned that it would probably slip back into the red later.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European unit of Ford Motor eked out its first profit in three years in the second quarter, the company said Thursday, even as it warned that it would probably slip back into the red later this year in part because of slumping sales in Russia.

headline: From Republicans, a New Approach to ‘Accountability’
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Welfare (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: Paul Ryan’s plan for the poor seeks to improve incentives for work. It also reflects a big change: no spending cuts for them.
lead_paragraph: For Republicans, the top concerns about anti-poverty programs have long been: Are they affordable, and do they discourage people from working their way out of poverty? A new plan out Thursday from Representative Paul Ryan’s House Budget Committee reflects a significant change in the way Republicans talk about both concerns.

headline: The Wisdom of the Moving Man
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Unlike my boyfriend, Derek promised he would treat me, and my stuff, with respect.
lead_paragraph: No one goes into a move expecting to fall for her mover. I was no exception. This was back in October 2001, when people advertised their services by taping fliers to lampposts among signs for the 9/11 missing.

headline: Yellen Settles for a Slingshot Instead of a Shotgun
abstract: The Federal Reserve should be using higher interest rates to curb the mispricing of risk in the market for financial assets, says William D. Cohan, the Street Scene columnist.
lead_paragraph: Has Janet Yellen jumped the shark already?

headline: Why Are We Ignoring a New Ebola Outbreak?
abstract: The deadly ebola outbreak in West Africa deserves the full attention of the international community. There is no time to wait.
lead_paragraph: Three small, impoverished nations in West Africa—Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone—now demand the world’s attention as the deadly Ebola epidemic spins out of control, killing hundreds and threatening millions. Caused by a highly contagious virus, the disease starts with typical flu-like symptoms, yet most often leads to a horrific death in just a matter of days.

headline: UBS Lashes Out at French Prosecutors
abstract: The Swiss bank says that the government’s demands for bail in the tax evasion case were excessive.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — UBS sounded a combative note on Thursday, criticizing the decision of French prosecutors to place it under formal investigation over allegedly helping French clients evade taxes.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Glossy New Poverty Plan
abstract: It’s better than previous efforts, but it’s not serious.
lead_paragraph: Every year or so Paul Ryan comes up with a glossy new plan to deal with poverty or spending on social programs. The plans never go anywhere, but they’re not really intended to: They’re designed to make the Republican Party (and Mr. Ryan himself) appear more thoughtful than it actually is on these subjects.

headline: 36 Hours in Provincetown, Mass.
abstract: From seaside strolls to dance parties, street performances to gallery exhibits, you can find it all during a weekend on the tip of Cape Cod.
lead_paragraph: Perched at the tip of Cape Cod — or at the end of the world, as locals like to say — Provincetown is a quirky beach community favored by artists, drag queens, L.G.B.T. people, heterosexual families from the suburbs and oddballs on the run. Provincetown combines small-town charm with big-city spunk, and it’s nestled among miles of peaceful dunes and seashore. If you want solitude, come in the winter when hardly anyone is here — or anything is open. But if you’re after warm weather and high-season theatrics, arrive in July, August or early September. Be careful about what summer week you choose. Many have a theme, and your Provincetown experience will differ whether you’re here for “Family Week,” “Girl Splash” or “Bear Week.”

headline: An Abstract World That Looks Like Silence
abstract: Mana Contemporary in Jersey City is offering an exhibition of the works of the artist Milton Resnick.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — “What can be said at all can be said clearly, and what we cannot talk about, we must pass over in silence.” Thus the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein summarized his first, notoriously difficult book, ’Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.” Wittgenstein’s declaration is usually taken to mean that talk about anything metaphysical — God or gods, supernatural phenomena, mystical experience — collapses into nonsense under scrutiny. What’s less often noted is that silence itself can be powerfully expressive.

headline: Bright Passages Along the Northeast Corridor
abstract: A five-mile stretch of railroad track is home to seven enormous works of art by the Berlin-based visual artist Katharina Grosse.
lead_paragraph: The five-mile stretch of railroad track that slices through some of Philadelphia’s most impoverished areas along the Northeast Corridor is dispiriting. It encompasses a wasteland of abandoned warehouses and buildings missing walls and roofs, neglected neighborhoods and graffiti-strewn passageways. Since mid-May, though, the area has been home to (and a scene on view for train commuters) a Christo-esque installation of seven enormous works of art by the Berlin-based visual artist Katharina Grosse, titled “psychylustro.”

headline: So, Winning Isn’t the Only Thing?
abstract: Warren Leight’s “Sec. 310, Row D, Seats 5 and 6,” about three friends who are long-suffering Knicks fans, is the highlight of the three one-act plays of “Summer Shorts: Series A.”
lead_paragraph: Marriages are celebrated. Divorces are granted. Children are born. Parents die. And through all the joy and tumult and change, the Knicks continue to lose.

headline: The Workout Doctor
abstract: Dr. Jordan Metzl is a sports medicine physician who developed an extreme total-body workout routine called Ironstrength. He now teaches free exercise classes all around New York City.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jordan Metzl is a sports medicine physician who developed an extreme total-body workout routine called Ironstrength. He now teaches free exercise classes all around New York City.

headline: An Art Project That Lets Regular Citizens Become the Stars of Times Square
abstract: Conceived by the Spanish artist Daniel Canogar and filming over the next few days, “Storming Times Square” is the latest in a series of public art installations to transform the crossroads of the world.
lead_paragraph: Ordinarily, only models and celebrities get to have their faces splashed across a giant screen in Times Square, but now everyone has a shot. “I don’t like working with professionals or models, people who are used to being in front of the camera,” says Daniel Canogar, the Madrid-based new-media artist who is masterminding the latest installment of the Times Square Alliance series known as “Midnight Moment.”

headline: The 2015 Sonata Shows That Hyundai Can Play With the Big Boys
abstract: Driving a subpar vehicle through Greenwich, Conn., is a no-no, but Hyundai’s well-designed new Sonata can fit in without joining the upper crust.
lead_paragraph: Driving a ratty car through Greenwich, Conn., a wealthy suburb just outside of New York, just isn’t to be done. But when Hyundai gave a group of journalists a chance to drive the all-new 2015 Sonata there on Wednesday, the automaker proved three things: The car drives very well, it looks good to journalists and rich people won’t be offended by it.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘A Most Wanted Man’
abstract: Anton Corbijn narrates a sequence from his film featuring Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams and Grigoriy Dobrygin.
lead_paragraph: Anton Corbijn narrates a sequence from his film featuring Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams and Grigoriy Dobrygin.

headline: Ukraine Crisis Is Testing E.U.’s Resolve
abstract: As it considers sanctions against Russia, the European Union faces a question: Can it reconcile competing interests, confront a conflict on its borders and play a meaningful role in foreign policy?
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As it pushed efforts to coalesce around tougher sanctions against Russia, the European Union on Thursday was preparing to draw up lists of oligarchs close to President Vladimir V. Putin, working out how it could limit Russian access to European financial markets and studying the risk that Russia would respond by limiting Europe’s energy supplies.

headline: The Workout: Practicing His Own Medicine
abstract: Dr. Metzl’s favorite medicine is exercise. It is one he takes often and prescribes to all of his patients.
lead_paragraph: Many doctors encourage their patients to exercise. But one who follows his own advice – and then some – is Dr. Jordan Metzl, a sports medicine physician at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York.

headline: Soviet Valor, Revised for the ’50s
abstract: A 1943 account of a Soviet village’s resistance to invading Nazis was re-edited 14 years later for a different era in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Context is everything, comrade — to use a word carefully expunged from the soundtrack of Lewis Milestone’s 1943 “The North Star” when this wartime extravaganza was rereleased 14 years later, recut and retitled “Armored Attack!”

headline: Hey, Mister, I’ve Got a Park I Can Sell You
abstract: About two-thirds of Brooklyn Bridge Park is now open, following the East River for more than a mile, from Dumbo, along a tidal shoreline with six reclaimed piers, down to Atlantic Avenue.
lead_paragraph: MAYBE it’s in our bones. That urge to seek water. To go down to the river.

headline: Sketching When the Pencil Requires Ignition
abstract: “Lee Bontecou: Drawn Worlds” focuses on the unconventional sketches made from the 1950s on by an artist known for her formidable sculptures.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — “Lee Bontecou: Drawn Worlds,” at the Princeton University Art Museum, is as stimulating an exhibition of works on paper as you might expect from an artist known for “drawing” with a blowtorch.

headline: When Reality Comes With a Score
abstract: A spate of new productions, and at least one business, consider what it might feel like to live within a musical.
lead_paragraph: For a certain kind of theater fan, to live life as a musical would be a gift from the show-tune gods. Wake up to an overture. Catch a performance by Chita Rivera and cheerful chorus boys in kick-line formation at the water cooler. End the day with an 11 o’clock number and applause for a job well done.

headline: Subway Inn to Make Its Last Stop
abstract: The endearing dump of a saloon, which has endured for nearly eight decades, is expected to close “on or about the 15th of August.”
lead_paragraph: New York’s dive bars are living up to their name lately. Because several of them are going down.

headline: 10 Questions for Hillary Rodham Clinton
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke Thursday with The Times’s John Harwood about America’s current foreign policy crises, potential presidential rivals and her relationship with the press.
lead_paragraph: As she ponders a second bid for the presidency in 2016, former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton continues a string of media appearance promoting her foreign policy memoir, “Hard Choices.” She spoke Thursday with The Times’s John Harwood on the National Public Radio program “On Point with Tom Ashbrook” about America’s current foreign policy crises, potential presidential rivals and her relationship with the press.

headline: India House Artwork Inspires a New Book
abstract: The artwork shown at India House, a private club in Lower Manhattan, will be examined in a forthcoming book that also looks at two founders.
lead_paragraph: India House, a private club in Lower Manhattan founded 100 years ago, has removed much of the art it has displayed over the years, but related documents survive to entice researchers. The art historian Margaret Stocker, a trustee of the India House Foundation and a former curator at the club, is writing a book about Asian and maritime art that has been on view there, while the pieces themselves have been going on the market.

headline: How Was School? Deadly
abstract: “Big Little Lies” by Liane Moriarty is full of women with ethical and emotional issues, men with possibly criminal ones, and high drama at a school, including a murder.
lead_paragraph: The book-buying public isn’t taking many chances this summer. Established hits like “Gone Girl,” “Unbroken” and “The Glass Castle” remain lodged on best-seller lists. Readers are still struggling to get through “The Goldfinch.” One of the few new authors to gain a toehold is Robert Galbraith, who has the advantage of having been J. K. Rowling in a previous life. And “The Husband’s Secret” by Liane Moriarty continues to sell briskly in hardcover, even though next week will be the first anniversary of its publication.

headline: Feeble Rangers Give Fuel to Yankees’ Sudden Surge
abstract: Brandon McCarthy, acquired in a trade on July 6, allowed one run and four hits in six innings, and the Yankees finished a four-game series with the Rangers with three wins.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have not looked like anything close to a dominant team, struggling to hit and at times bumbling defensively. Their injury-depleted starting rotation has exceeded expectations, turning in excellent outings, but it could fall back to earth.

headline: Anton Corbijn Narrates a Scene From ‘A Most Wanted Man’
abstract: The director discusses a scene from his film featuring Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams and Grigoriy Dobrygin.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Anton Corbijn discusses a chase sequence from his spy thriller “A Most Wanted Man,” based on a book by John le Carré and featuring Philip Seymour Hoffman, Rachel McAdams and Grigoriy Dobrygin. The director discusses shooting this sequence in a film that hey says “is very much NOT a Jason Bourne kind of movie.”

headline: The Muddled Case of Argentine Bonds
abstract: Because of rulings meant to force Argentina to pay its creditors, Citibank may either have to violate a court order or risk prosecution in Argentina.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Poole Griesa has been a federal judge for 42 years. He has been grappling with Argentina’s debt default for a decade.

headline: Passing of a Video Store and a Downtown Aesthetic
abstract: Kim’s Video, once a chain of four stores in the East and West Village, has closed. Its creative habitués and former employees remember it fondly.
lead_paragraph: When Kim’s Video & Music announced that this summer it would be closing its last store, on First Avenue in the East Village, written tributes ranged from the resigned to the exultant. “Kim’s was this portal into New York City I never came back from,” Eddie Huang, the restaurateur, author and television personality, wrote in a blog post. “Everything in my life, I can somehow attribute to finding Kim’s.”

headline: Your Teenager on Vacation — and on Social Media
abstract: Some parents want their teenagers to put their phones down on vacation and connect with their families. But their teenagers might have a different, and valid, sense of what it means to be connected.
lead_paragraph: What I Did on My Summer Vacation on My Smartphone:

headline: The Roar of the Crowd
abstract: In the 1920s, Manhattan was transformed into America’s entertainment and communications epicenter.
lead_paragraph: Between 1922 and 1930, a new building went up in New York City every 51 minutes, according to Donald L. Miller. Most of the truly spectacular structures — like the Chrysler Building, with its aspirational steel spire — emerged in Midtown, previously a region of open rail yards and shabby industry. Beginning with the reconstruction of Park Avenue in the early 1920s, Midtown became a destination neighborhood for the city’s ultrarich, eager to abandon their stand-alone Fifth Avenue palaces in favor of contemporary “mansions in the sky.” Alongside the real estate boom came a decadent new night life and a host of more serious cultural diversions, all of them fueled, in Miller’s telling, by a steady supply of ambition, energy and illicit booze.

headline: Amazon’s Ambitious Bets Pile Up, and Its Losses Swell
abstract: The company continues to reinvest aggressively in its business, to the chagrin of investors hoping to see signs of profit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Writers are peeved at Amazon. On Thursday, investors became disgruntled too.

headline: Clash of the Items, at a Gallery Near You
abstract: The mingling of like with extremely unlike is an increasingly popular curatorial approach among the summer’s group shows.
lead_paragraph: Heterogeneity and lots of it is trending among the summer’s group shows. The mingling of like with extremely unlike is an increasingly popular curatorial approach, as is arranging them in dense installations. In numerous galleries, works of all mediums, artifacts, and objects of design and craft keep company, often at the behest of outside curators. Different time periods are spanned, disparate cultures contrasted, with all kinds of surprises.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Meditation on President Obama’s Portrait
abstract: A portrait of Barack Obama before he became president reveals an unguarded moment in the life of a very private man.
lead_paragraph: A portrait of Barack Obama before he became president reveals an unguarded moment in the life of a very private man.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Toyota announces details and pricing for its all-new 2015 Yaris; G.M. may invest $800 million into facilities in Michigan.

headline: Undercover Portraits
abstract: Kai Bird tells the story of Robert Ames, an American operative in the Middle East, while Jack Devine’s memoir recounts his time helping rebel fighters battle Soviet troops in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Before the dead ends and the false dawns, before the latest revenge killings and Secretary of State John Kerry’s quixotic shuttle diplomacy, there were people who believed that a lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians was possible. One of them was a quiet American named Robert Ames, the subject of Kai Bird’s textured and absorbing book “The Good Spy.”

headline: In From the Cold
abstract: Ben Macintyre’s latest nonfiction thriller, “A Spy Among Friends,” is about Kim Philby, the high-level British spymaster who turned out to be a Russian mole.
lead_paragraph: When devouring this thriller about Kim Philby, the high-level British spymaster who turned out to be a Russian mole, I had to keep reminding myself that it was not a novel. It reads like a story by Graham Greene, Ian Fleming or John le Carré, all of whom make appearances, leavened by a dollop of P. G. Wodehouse. But, in fact, “A Spy Among Friends” is a solidly researched true story. The London journalist Ben Mac­intyre, who has written nine previous histories chronicling intrigue and skulduggery, takes a fresh look at the grandest espionage drama of our era. And like one of his raffish characters relaxing around the bar at White’s, that venerable clubhouse of England’s old boys’ network, he is able to play the role of an amusing raconteur who can cloak psychological and sociological insights with dry humor.

headline: Why the Death Penalty Is Doomed
abstract: Judge Alex Kozinski launched into a meditation on why we kill people the way we do.
lead_paragraph: Alex Kozinski, a federal judge on the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, has gone on the record saying he is “generally not opposed to the death penalty.” But his opinion in a recent case may nevertheless find itself in the history books one day — in the section explaining why the death penalty in America finally ended.

headline: Ringing the Cowbell for Two Suppers
abstract: Shakespeare & Company puts on the repertory staple “The Servant of Two Masters,” adapted and directed by Jenna Ware, in an Elizabethan-style tented playhouse.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Good help is so hard to find. Particularly in the alleyways and waterways of 18th-century Venice.

headline: What’s Behind Canada’s Troubled Relationship With Its Aboriginal Peoples
abstract: Canada is often lauded as a model of successful multiculturalism – but some say the country’s integrationist policies have largely neglected its native communities.
lead_paragraph: They call it “Murderpeg.” With 6,222 instances of violent crime reported in 2012, the city of Winnipeg, Manitoba consistently ranks among the most violent cities in Canada.

headline: Profits Tell of a Turnaround by Major Airlines, and Point to the Start of a New Era
abstract: American, United and Delta all posted record quarterly profits after a turbulent period of bankruptcies and mergers.
lead_paragraph: Signaling a major turnaround in the airline industry’s fortunes, the nation’s three major legacy carriers — American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines — all posted record profits in the past quarter.

headline: Rushing to the End of Adolescence
abstract: The directorial debut of the Oscar-nominated screenwriter Naomi Foner, “Very Good Girls,” stars Elizabeth Olsen and Dakota Fanning.
lead_paragraph: There is so much talent in “Very Good Girls,” Naomi Foner’s examination of a close friendship threatened by sexual rivalry, secrecy and guilt, that you wish this fraught coming-of-age vignette had ignored the screenwriting formulas that bring the story to a too-tidy conclusion.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Taiwan and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, Taiwan and India.

headline: 5 Soldiers, 3 Afghans and Grisly Atrocities
abstract: “The Kill Team” is a documentary about one of five American soldiers accused of murdering three Afghan civilians for what has often been described in news accounts as sport.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, five American soldiers were accused of murdering three Afghan civilians for what has often been described in news accounts as sport. The Americans hunted the Afghans, posed in photographs with the corpses (pictures they shared with others) and even took body parts as souvenirs. The soldiers were members of the Fifth Stryker Brigade, Second Infantry Division, which had been deployed in a region near Kandahar. The crimes were ghastly, and seemingly unfathomable. In a 2010 article in Stars and Stripes, a lawyer, Eric Montalvo, representing one of the accused, Specialist Adam C. Winfield, said the entire leadership needed to be looked at, asking, “How was this allowed to happen?”

lead_paragraph: A United Nations school that had sheltered Palestinians who fled their homes for safety from Israeli military assaults was struck on Thursday.

headline: Improving Default Rates on F.H.A. Loans
abstract: New research from the Urban Institute suggests reasons that V.A. mortgages are less likely to go into default than F.H.A. loans.
lead_paragraph: Default rates for loans backed by the Federal Housing Administration have consistently been higher than those on loans guaranteed by the Department of Veterans Affairs. New research from the Urban Institute suggests that a key difference in how the programs measure a borrower’s ability to pay could account for much of this performance gap.
