headline: Oliver Payne and Nick Relph: ‘Ash’s Stash’
abstract: A British duo restage a 2007 installation they found oddly predictive of the current trend for sharing carefully chosen photographs of our bookshelves and closets on social media.
lead_paragraph: “Today everything is always ‘on’ at once, simultaneously forever — we’ve simply run out of past,” the British duo of Oliver Payne and Nick Relph write in a statement for their latest show at Gavin Brown. There, boutique-style shelves hold small, colorful assemblages of formerly trendy gadgets and accessories, among them, Reebok pump sneakers, Sony Walkman cassette players and one forlorn-looking Macintosh Classic computer with a protruding floppy disk.

headline: Exploring Motown Music at the Schomburg Center
abstract: “The Truth Is a Hit,” an exhibition at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, examines the legacy and significance of Motown Records.
lead_paragraph: The Miser’s mom and dad, growing up in the South in the 1960s, tuned in to the soul sounds coming from Memphis and Muscle Shoals and danced the shag to Carolina beach music. Those songs, in turn, underscored the Miser’s childhood, so it was Sam Cooke, Aretha Franklin and Al Green who molded his imagination before he ever encountered Bob Dylan, the Beatles, Bach or bebop.

abstract: The channel’s new shows are decidedly not earthbound.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO – Forget “Sharknado 2.” What the Syfy network really wants Comic-Con attendees to notice is a sharp turn back into space.

headline: Patricia Esquivias: ‘111-119 Generalísimo/Castellana’
abstract: A Venezuelan artist’s work that focuses on five apartment buildings in Madrid, erected in the late 1950s, is as much art history or urban archaeology as it is art.
lead_paragraph: As seen in her third solo at Murray Guy, the work of the Venezuelan artist Patricia Esquivias is as much art history or urban archaeology as it is art, and consequently very dependent upon having a visually interesting, historically resonant subject. That is the case here, in a meandering installation that focuses on five apartment buildings in Madrid erected in the late 1950s at 111-119 Avenida del Generalísimo (named for Franco and later renamed Paseo de la Castellana), and Ms. Esquivias’s gradual excavation of their history.

headline: Spare Times Listings for July 25-31
abstract: A guide to street fairs, film festivals, literary events, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Outdoor Readings (Saturday through Wednesday) Summertime, and the listening is easy at the many free literary events in the city’s parks and green spaces. On any given day, bookworms of all ages can find their favorite activity in Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas, at 40th Street. Tuesdays mean poetry readings and book club gatherings. On Wednesdays? There are author talks and workshops. Next Wednesday at 12:30 p.m.,  Jason Mewes and Kevin Smith will discuss their illustrated book, “Jay & Silent Bob’s Blueprints for Destroying Everything.” There is also an area for teenagers, children and those interested in community and social issues. A schedule is at bryantpark.org.

headline: Social Emergencies Get Their Own Warning System
abstract: The risk is high in the summer, particularly if you live in New York or have a summer house. If only we had a way out.
lead_paragraph: My iPhone emitted a frightening, high-pitched alert last week just as I was settling into a nice afternoon nap. My first terrified thought, as it is July, was: summer house guests!

headline: ‘This is what sculpture looks like,’ at the Postmasters Gallery
abstract: An exclusively female show of sculptures by 16 artists has a freewheeling spirit and sprawling diversity of approaches, materials and subjects.
lead_paragraph: The best things about this overflowing group show of sculptures by 16 artists are its freewheeling spirit and sprawling diversity of approaches, materials and subjects, as well as its exclusively female roster. To a degree, these factors balance the weaker, more conventional inclusions.

headline: TicketNetwork Settles Deceptive Marketing Complaint
abstract: The online company and two of its affiliates have agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a complaint from federal and state authorities in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: An online ticketing company and two of its affiliates have agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a complaint from federal and state authorities in Connecticut that they used deceptive marketing tactics to resell tickets for entertainment events around the country.

headline: ‘Displayed’ at the Anton Kern Gallery
abstract: Organized by the artist and curator Matthew Higgs, this excellent show presents works by 18 artists exemplifying a trend he calls “displayism.”
lead_paragraph: When you exhibit a work of art, there are two things going on. There’s the object and there’s the presentational apparatus, which might be a frame, a pedestal, a shelf or a vitrine. Also involved are the gallery architecture, the structure of the exhibiting institution and, in the broadest terms, the art world social system. Usually, viewers are supposed to focus on the object and take for granted the apparatus.

headline: 20 Minutes and 100 Years Away
abstract: Reasons to visit Murray Hill, Queens, include the Voelker Orth Museum, Bird Sanctuary and Victorian Garden, as well as Mapo Korean BBQ.
lead_paragraph: “A Stop at Willoughby,” an enduring “Twilight Zone” episode about an advertising executive who abandons modern life at a phantom commuter rail station, shares a kinship with an idyllic corner of Murray Hill, Queens, a Korean-dominated neighborhood east of Flushing. A pink, shingled gingerbread house built in 1891 is garlanded by Catawba grapevines, sunflowers and holly trees, so locked in time you half-expect a gentleman in a bowler hat to glide by on a penny farthing.

lead_paragraph: A Moscow court on Thursday convicted two prominent activists and sentenced them to four and a half years in a prison colony for their roles in organizing a protest a day before President Vladimir V. Putin’s inauguration in May 2012. The protest against Mr. Putin ended in violence between the police and demonstrators. A three-judge panel concluded that Sergei Udaltsov, the leader of the Left Front, had tried to organize “mass riots” in regions across Russia using money provided by a lawmaker from Georgia, with which Russia fought a war in 2008. The prosecutors’ case was partly based on information from a television special called “The Anatomy of a Revolution” that was broadcast on a state-funded television station. Mr. Udaltsov, the most prominent of 11 opposition activists sentenced to prison since the May 2012 protest, said the case was politically motivated. Mr. Udaltsov’s co-defendant, Leonid Razvozzhayev, accused Russian agents of kidnapping him while he was seeking asylum in Ukraine.

lead_paragraph: Two gallerists, a design retailer and a creative director walk into a bookstore. The punch line? One might imagine a battle of egos, but that’s not the case for Kyle DeWoody, the community-minded owner and creative director of Grey Area, a Brooklyn-based gallery and design consultancy responsible for a series of exhibitions this summer at Glenn Horowitz Bookseller in East Hampton. After Horowitz asked her to take over the street-level and second-floor spaces within his bookstore, DeWoody opted to bring together people like herself — curators of art and tastemakers of design — to expose the talents they were most excited about. Called Grey East, the project has netted a series of splashy collaborations in an otherwise staid beach town.

headline: What’s On TV Friday

lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) WADJDA (2013) A rambunctious 10-year-old Saudi girl (Waad Mohammed, above) enters a Quran-reciting contest with a cash prize in the hope of buying the bicycle of her dreams — a mode of transportation discouraged for women, with which she intends to race a boy — and in the process overcome her reputation as a troublemaker. Heartbreak hovers over “Haifaa al-Mansour’s sharply observed, deceptively gentle film, reportedly the first feature ever directed by a Saudi woman,” with its “decorous, deliberate scenes” hinting at the difficulties facing her gender, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But “with impressive agility, ‘Wadjda’ finds room to maneuver between harsh realism and a more hopeful kind of storytelling. There is warmth as well as austerity in Wadjda’s world, kindness as well as cruelty, and the possibility, modestly sketched and ardently desired, of change.” (In Arabic, with English subtitles.)

headline: 1914: Servian Nation to Resist Austria
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A correspondent appraised Serbia’s chances in a war with Austria-Hungary in 1914.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — Servia will not shrink from the power of the great Austro-Hungarian Empire, and will reply to force by force. It is a possible case of David and Goliath. Such is the opinion I have gathered here on every side. It may sound at first suicidal on the part of this small country to seek to measure itself against the might of the Dual Monarchy. But the Servians don’t seem to have an atom of fear. Undoubtedly — and the opinion of all military experts who have seen them is the same — the officers and men of the Servian army constitute the best fighting material in Europe. I saw them, at the time of the first Balkan war — three divisions, or 60,000 men, march through Mustapha  Pasha, to the aid of the Bulgarians. Every man had already been in one, two or more actions. Everything one hears and sees leaves the impression that the Servians know what they are about, and that their lack of fear concerning their traditional enemies, the Austrians and Hungarians, is not without good reason. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 26, 1914

headline: Sketched Out on the Subway
abstract: You lookin’ to draw me?
lead_paragraph: I was sitting next to someone on the subway who was surreptitiously sketching portraits of fellow commuters. I once spotted someone opposite me doing this, and actually changed cars when I suspected he was eyeing me as a subject. Being present in a public space does not seem akin to offering permission to record your likeness without consent, despite the intended (lack of) audience or purpose of the final piece. Unlike being captured in a tourist’s random photograph, this act seems to involve a level of scrutiny, focus and invasiveness that makes me uncomfortable. Is it ethical to draw someone without his or her permission or knowledge? CHRISTIANA MAVROMATIS, BROOKLYN

headline: Who Made That Ziploc Bag?
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Plastics', 'Zippers', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: The brilliant marriage of plastic sleeve to zipper.
lead_paragraph: “It seems hard to believe it now, but people did not know how to open the bag,” Steven Ausnit, developer of the original Ziploc, recently told an audience at Marquette University. He recalled that sometime around the early 1960s, his company persuaded Columbia Records to try a plastic sleeve with the zipper on top for albums. “At the final meeting, we were all set to go. The guy called in his assistant, handed her the sealed bag and said, ‘Open it.’ I thought to myself, Lady, please do the right thing! The more she looked at it, the more my heart sank. And then she tore the zipper right off the bag.”

headline: Marlon’s Method
abstract: A biographer of Marlon Brando delves into the archives and tries to demystify her complex subject.
lead_paragraph: The title of Susan L. Mizruchi’s Marlon Brando book is a hassle. You don’t want to be seen with anything called “Brando’s Smile.” You just don’t. I read the book the old-fashioned way — on paper. I read it in restaurants, on the subway and in the park. I read it with the front cover obscured. To dislike the title of the book is to reject its putative premise — that Brando wasn’t just a sexy slob with no technique but an extremely skilled, deeply intelligent, fiercely perceptive “public citizen” who “carefully controlled his smiles.” Mizruchi seems to be making a case that the modus operandi of one of the movies’ greatest performers can be reduced to the strategic concealment of dental work.

headline: Devilish Audacity
abstract: A biography of the “strangely hidden” man who, since boyhood, wanted to be “the greatest actor in the world.”
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, giants bestrode the British boards. In that theatrically golden 20th century, the stage could boast those wonderful knights, Sirs John Gielgud, Laurence Olivier, Michael Redgrave and Ralph Richardson. Close on their heels were Alec Guinness, John Mills, Paul Scofield, Trevor Howard and Peter O’Toole, among others. And all along there was that chameleon of genius, Noël Coward.

headline: Reports From the Exterior
abstract: Amy Rowland’s solitary heroine is unhinged by a harrowing stream of disembodied words.
lead_paragraph: The same week I began reading Amy Rowland’s debut novel, “The Transcriptionist,” a Malaysian jetliner vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. It’s a testament to the eerie power of Rowland’s fictional world that while I watched and read the news about the search for the plane, hands to my mouth, I wondered: “Who will call this story in to Lena? And can Lena bear it?”

headline: Captivating and Repellent
abstract: Ben Macintyre says Kim Philby’s writings are “completely unreliable, which makes sifting fact from fiction a real challenge, but a hugely enjoyable one.”
lead_paragraph: Ben Macintyre’s “A Spy Among Friends,” about Kim Philby, the British spy who served as a double agent for the Soviet Union, is reviewed this week by Walter Isaacson.

headline: Short Stories
abstract: New books by Lee Upton, Alexai Galaviz-Budziszewski, David James Poissant and Adam Wilson.
lead_paragraph: THE TAO OF HUMILIATION  Stories  By Lee Upton  BOA Editions, paper, $16.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Marja Mills, whose “Mockingbird Next Door” is No. 4 on the hardcover nonfiction list, spent ample time observing Harper Lee going about her ordinary daily life.
lead_paragraph: Private Lives: America’s most famous literary recluses are back in the spotlight. J. D. Salinger, who died in 2010, is the subject of Thomas Beller’s gentle New York-centric biography, “J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist,” while Harper Lee turns up at the center of “The Mockingbird Next Door,” by the former Chicago Tribune reporter Marja Mills, new at No. 4 on the hardcover nonfiction list. There are a lot of superficial similarities between Salinger and Lee: Born seven years apart, both wrote beloved novels that have endured for decades as staples of high school reading lists — “The Catcher in the Rye” and “To Kill a Mockingbird,” as if you didn’t know — and both quit writing in the early 1960s to retreat into strictly enforced silences. But they probably never met for drinks, to judge from the portrait of Lee that emerges in “The Mockingbird Next Door.” Mills first met Lee and her sister on assignment for The Tribune, and eventually rented the house neighboring theirs in Monroeville, Ala., for a year and a half, during which she had ample time to observe Lee going about her ordinary daily life: eating at McDonald’s, feeding the town ducks, fishing with hot dogs as bait. Contrast those humble details with what we’ve learned over the years about the deeply eccentric Salinger, whose daughter claimed he sat in an orgone box and drank his own urine, and it becomes clear they don’t have much in common after all.

headline: Most Migrant Children Entering U.S. Are Now With Relatives, Data Show
abstract: Officials said more than half of all children initially placed in shelters have gone on to be reunited with at least one parent already living in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The vast majority of unaccompanied migrant children arriving in the United States from Central America this year have been released to relatives in states with large established Central American populations, according to federal data released Thursday night.

headline: Much Ado About Everything
abstract: Why do paper clips bend? What makes elastic stretchy? A scientist examines the ubiquitous substances we take for granted.
lead_paragraph: I once met a man with magic in his pocket. He was a former hairdresser named Maurice Ward, and the magic was a material he invented called Starlite. He said it was one of the most astonishing thermal barriers in the world and had been tested in high-profile labs, including a British atomic weapons facility, where it withstood several simulated nuclear flashes. Despite its dizzying potential — fireproof airplanes, laser-resistant tanks — Starlite never ventured far out of Ward’s pocket, because he refused to sell or reveal its recipe before his death a couple of years ago. I mention this because it still intrigues me, as a good mystery should, and because it was my first encounter with the head-­scratching, captivating possibilities of man-made materials.

headline: Sneaking Suspicions
abstract: A boy in a remote Scottish town tries to understand the terrible thing that has happened to his mother.
lead_paragraph: Lisa O’Donnell’s dazzling new novel transports us to small-town Scotland and into the increasingly volatile mind of an 11-year-old boy. Michael Murray, who narrates the book, lives with his parents and grandmother in Rothesay on the Isle of Bute. As in most small towns, everybody seems to know everybody else’s business. Here gossip is something more than a spectator sport.

headline: An Architect Gets Busy
abstract: Four major creations from the British designer Norman Foster, who favors lots of stainless steel and glass, are under construction or close to breaking ground in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: His buildings might not be the tallest, priciest or zaniest. But in New York, the British architect Norman Foster seems to be having a moment all the same.

headline: Those Who Stay
abstract: These stories portray women’s lives in Magadan, Russia, a town known as an entryway to gulag labor camps.
lead_paragraph: Kseniya Melnik’s accomplished debut collection, “Snow in May,” takes us deep into the complex fabric of Magadan, an isolated fishing and mining town in the northern reaches of Russia that once served as a transit center for prisoners dispatched to Stalin’s labor camps.

headline: Radical Inquiry
abstract: Ellen Willis, who emerged in the 1960s, asked serious questions about culture and politics.
lead_paragraph: “I love Ellen Willis,” a friend told me upon hearing there would be an anthology collecting the work of the cultural critic, who was also The New Yorker’s first pop music writer. “She makes me feel less embarrassed to enjoy the Who.”

headline: The Wealth of Ideas
abstract: A history of liberalism, told through the lives and ideas of a dynamic group of European and American thinkers.
lead_paragraph: Before it became a political philosophy, liberalism was not that difficult to define: A person was liberal if generous, catholic in taste or even excessively rotund. Liberal people may not have been universally admired, but few took to castigating them as dangerous to the health of the state. The opposite of “liberal” was not “conservative” but “strict.” When Bassanio tells Portia in “The Merchant of Venice” that he will give her “the dearest ring in Venice,” she replies, “I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.” No one in Shakespeare’s audience would have concluded that the dissolute nobleman with whom she banters stood on the left side of the political spectrum.

headline: Against Closure
abstract: This novel’s protagonist cannot surmount his grief over his wife’s murder.
lead_paragraph: A while ago, on the planet of the novelists, two warring factions argued over whether or not characters had to be likable. Absolutely not, the frowny-face contingent claimed, arguing that one of literature’s goals is to illuminate the state of being human, in all its flawed glory. The smiley-face tribe took umbrage: What’s the matter with creating characters readers would like to have as friends? But maybe the question of liking or not liking is the easy one. The harder one, maybe, is what should we make of characters who never really allow us to know them? Characters who are in pain for reasons we understand and behave badly for reasons we can comprehend, but who inspire nothing as strong as liking or loathing. What happens when we close a book with neither a shudder nor a smile, but only a shrug?

headline: Off the Reservation
abstract: Brando Skyhorse’s turbulent childhood was built on myth.
lead_paragraph: As I began Brando Skyhorse’s “Take This Man,” I thought, Ah, another New Agonist! New Agonists serve the kettle corn of memoir, candy you can’t put down. But often, at book’s end, there’s little to do except swap horrors: “Can you believe the part where Brando’s mama tries to drown him in the toilet?” “What about when she tries to put him up for adoption by placing an ad in a magazine?” And so on.

headline: Love Is Strange
abstract: Cruelty and lust predominate in A. L. Kennedy’s stories.
lead_paragraph: My inappropriate nickname for A. L. Kennedy is “Dr. Strangelove.” Not because she’s a devious former Nazi played by Peter Sellers in a movie of the same name, but because her work is obsessed with love and strangeness and, in this particular case, with the strangeness of love. There’s also a strangeness in her writing — both her premises and her sentences — that makes it tricky to situate this prolific Scottish author in any particular literary context. She does things her fellow widely prized and widely translated peers do not: compose whole novels in the second person, write BBC dramas, perform stand-up comedy and ponder in prose the existence of such items as a chocolate-flavored condom, as she does in her new collection of stories, “All the Rage.”

headline: World of Our Great-Grandfathers
abstract: A history of Jewish life in the villages of Eastern Europe before the period familiar to American Jews.
lead_paragraph: Back in the days when Jews could travel without having to go anywhere — one minute a house was in Poland, the next in Russia — they lived in places called shtetls, defined neither by physical size nor population, possessing mysterious features both urban and rural. Though Christians lived there too, the shtetl tilted spiritually toward Jerusalem, while performing economic services for the Slavic society to which it also belonged, giving it an Eastern European character all its own. Its amorphous nature has made it the subject of easy mythologizing, so that it often pops up in the American imagination as a kind of Jewish Brigadoon where all the villagers are singing, unless they are running from a pogrom.

headline: Insatiable Gaze
abstract: A biography of the painter who crossed paths with everyone from Kate Moss to the Kray brothers.
lead_paragraph: Was Lucian Freud really a great painter? I’m not convinced. But he looms large in the social history of postwar London, an inimitable figure who crossed paths with everyone from Kate Moss to the Kray brothers. Born in Berlin in 1922, Freud was 10 when his family moved to London (well before his famous grandfather, who escaped Austria only in 1938). He showed precocious talent as a draftsman — and as a troublemaker. Quick with his fists, he was a chronic expellee. Eventually he ended up at a private art school in Essex run by Cedric Morris; when the school burned down one night, Freud took the credit. But he remained a protégé of Morris, one of a series of gay elders with whom the young Freud knew how to ingratiate himself — though he was conspicuously, not to say voraciously, heterosexual. His looks were as striking as his talent, despite Stephen Spender’s observation at the time that he resembled Harpo Marx.

headline: Was Warren Harding, In Fact, a Terrible President?
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Impeachment', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There is a reason Warren Harding ends up, generally, on the lowest rung of some of the more notable presidential rankings conducted by historians and political scientists, finishing dead last in at least half of them.
lead_paragraph: The many scandalous letters that Warren Harding wrote to his mistress, Carrie Phillips, which the Library of Congress is releasing on July 29, are deliciously fun to read. Written from 1910 to 1920, before Harding was elected president, the correspondence has helped inspire reassessments of his time in office. Harding is usually relegated to the bottom of presidential rankings. But he shouldn’t be, according to Vox’s Dylan Matthews and Slate’s Ronald and Allis Radosh. “Harding was hardly a great president,” Matthews writes, “but he doesn’t deserve the overwhelmingly negative reputation he’s developed.”

headline: Decline and Falling
abstract: Tim Winton’s hero, a disgraced and despairing activist in Western Australia, is called to help a childhood friend.
lead_paragraph: Ten floors up in a seedy apartment building on the edge of a city on the edge of a dry continent and a vast ocean, Tim Winton’s antihero teeters on the brink of destitution and despair. In the wake of several storms that have engulfed his life, he’s been left stranded, a fish flapping uselessly on the sand. Set, as so many of Winton’s books are, in Western Australia — “which was, you could say, like Texas. Only it was big” — his new novel, ­“Eyrie,” is a dark but dazzling study of people and places on the edge. These marginal zones are where Winton enjoys spending time, scavenging for driftwood, floats, rope, old sea boots — and characters like Tom Keely, a washed-up environmentalist who’s been unceremoniously ejected from the world of idealism and activism.

headline: A Contender
abstract: Elia Kazan’s letters underscore his central importance in the maturing of American film and theater at midcentury.
lead_paragraph: “So much precious time goes by and it seems to me I get so little out of it,” Elia Kazan wrote to John Steinbeck in 1955. “I ask myself is this it? Is this why? Is this what I wanted to do? Is this why I accumulated what dough I have. I feel like a highly publicized meal ticket, some of the time, doing what the hell my wife and family and society expects of me and not at all — since I dont think originally enough — what I’d like to do. I can imagine great excitement to life again. But something prevents my going after it.”

headline: The Special Challenges of Retiring From a Business You Own
abstract: To prevent organizational or financial hardships in retirement, owners must take time to prepare children or other relatives to take over, experts say.
lead_paragraph: RETIRING is challenging for almost everyone. But if you’re a small-business owner, preparing to hand your company to your children can create an even bigger knot of anxiety — worries about financial security, the legacy of your life’s work and the prospects for your offspring. The process can touch everything from spreadsheet-driven company valuations to awkward talks about your children’s limitations. It can demand the technical knowledge of a C.P.A. and the soft skills of a psychologist.

headline: New Find Hints at More Feathered Dinosaurs
abstract: A species with feathers was discovered in Russia. It is the first find of a feathered dinosaur not of the theropod suborder.
lead_paragraph: A new dinosaur species, one with feathers, has been discovered in Russia. The finding could mean that feathers were more widespread among dinosaurs than previously thought, the researchers say.

headline: Are Trophies Really So Bad?
abstract: Trophies have gotten a reputation as vehicles for millennial narcissism, but one writer says they’re unfairly maligned. Do our ideas about achievement and special-ness need updating?
lead_paragraph: Those who see the 21st century as a time of unprecedented narcissism frequently focus on trophies: Too many kids get them nowadays, the argument goes, and it’s leading to rampant entitlement and jerkitude. But anyone who’s felt the sting of not getting a gold star (especially in our allegedly gold-star-happy times) may relate to Molly Knefel’s recent examination of the trophy and its discontents.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: India Threatens to Block Global Trade Deal
abstract: New Delhi is making its support for an agreement at the World Trade Organization conditional on addressing a dispute over its food security program.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India could put a landmark World Trade Organization deal in jeopardy at hectic negotiations in Geneva after saying that it would withhold support for the agreement unless there was simultaneous progress on resolving a dispute over its food security program.

headline: Addressing Caregivers’ Loss of Retirement Income
abstract: A congresswomen has proposed Social Security credits for family caregivers who must cut back on work.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of New York, introduced what she’s calling the Social Security Caregiver Credit Act, intended to increase retirement income for middle-class citizens who must reduce their work hours or leave the work force because of caregiving duties.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: July 25
abstract: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from the funeral of a Staten Island man and white flags on the Brooklyn Bridge.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes images from the funeral of Eric Garner, who died after a confrontation with the police on Staten Island, and white flags on the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: Today in Small Business: What It’s Really Like to Own a McDonald’s
abstract: Why are fewer small businesses buying cyber liability insurance?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Alan C. Greenberg, 86, Dies; Led Bear Stearns in Good Times and Bad
abstract: A risk-taking trader at heart, Mr. Greenberg began at the brokerage as a $32.50-a-week clerk and emerged unscathed after its collapse.
lead_paragraph: Alan C. Greenberg, a risk-chasing Wall Street titan who built Bear Stearns into a global investment banking powerhouse and shared responsibility, many analysts said, for its collapse as America slid toward a calamitous recession in 2008, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MOTHERLAND FATHERLAND HOMELANDSEXUALS,  by Patricia Lockwood. (Penguin Poets, paper, $20.) Lockwood offers a collection at once angrier, and more fun, more attuned to our time and more bizarre, than most poetry can ever get.

headline: A Case of Murder, Streamlined
abstract: A chamber version inspired by the tale of a famous ax murder travels to Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The story of Lizzie Borden — tried and acquitted, yet still often assumed guilty in the 1892 ax murder of her father and stepmother — was a tantalizing spur to artists, inspiring Agnes de Mille’s 1948 ballet, “Fall River Legend,” and Jack Beeson’s 1965 opera, “Lizzie Borden.” While Beeson, who died in 2010, and his librettist, Kenward Elmslie, created a memorably anxious, creepy work, its three acts all but ensured it would remain a rarity.

headline: When Making Sense Was Optional
abstract: Jonathan Demme’s Talking Heads concert film “Stop Making Sense” will be featured on Friday as part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s second Sound + Vision festival.
lead_paragraph: When Jonathan Demme’s Talking Heads concert film “Stop Making Sense” came out 30 years ago, practically everyone agreed that the genre had taken a stupendous leap forward.

headline: Original, and Built to Stay That Way
abstract: The avant-garde jazz musician Henry Threadgill and his band Zooid debuts at the Village Vanguard Tuesday through Aug. 3.
lead_paragraph: Time has often smiled on the art of Henry Threadgill, a composer, saxophonist and flutist who has followed his own labyrinthine path through the realm of avant-garde jazz. The oldest of his albums, made 35 years ago, retains the spark of an unfolding event: It sounds at times as if it could be made by musicians working today, which probably tells you what you need to know about Mr. Threadgill’s influence.

headline: Bite-Size Flights of Fancy
abstract: The New Victory Theater introduces top contemporary dance artists to young audiences in family-friendly, roughly hourlong performances.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary dance has a reputation for being adult entertainment. Not so much because of heavy themes or graphic images — which are rare — but because we don’t trust children to get abstraction (which may just be our own internalized bafflement). “The Nutcracker” feels safer.

headline: Defining Visions, on the Road
abstract: A show, organized by the curators from the National Gallery of Art in Washington, displays works from its postwar and contemporary art collection in Williamstown, Mass.
lead_paragraph: With the East Building of the National Gallery of Art in Washington closed for a three-year renovation and expansion, curators there have organized a series of exhibitions with works from its postwar and contemporary art collection. One show, “Make It New: Abstract Paintings From the National Gallery of Art, 1950-1975,” opens Saturday at the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., in its new Clark Center designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando.

headline: Investigators and Their Secrets
abstract: The series’s final installment, Season 4 of “The Killing” will be available for streaming on Netflix on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Blood is everywhere in Season 4 of “The Killing”: flowing off the body of Sarah Linden (Mireille Enos), spackled on the jacket of Stephen Holder (Joel Kinnaman), splattered at the scene of their latest case like a Pollock in red and white. “We just got to keep our stories straight, Linden,” Holder tells his perpetually glowering partner, now in full-on rattled mode. “No one’s going to find out. No one’s got to know what we did.”

headline: To Pop Legends, He Was a Guitar Hero
abstract: “The Breeze: An Appreciation of JJ Cale,” a tribute album by Eric Clapton being released on Tuesday, features Tom Petty, Mark Knopfler, John Mayer and Willie Nelson.
lead_paragraph: Rock ’n’ roll cult heroes burn brightly and briefly. Such romantic figures as Nick Drake, Syd Barrett, Gram Parsons and Jeff Buckley recorded just a few tracks before they were gone — literally or figuratively — left to be discovered by later generations of cool kids, forever frozen as young, beautiful and alluringly obscure.

headline: Of Green Day, Green Hair and Still Green Rock Stars
abstract: In individual interviews, the boys of 5 Seconds of Summer talk about their early influences, their latest grooming habits and the transition to celebrity life.
lead_paragraph: The guys of 5 Seconds of Summer — four lanky Australian youths with a taste for pop-punk, notable hair and a following of millions across social media — would rather not be thought of as a boy band.

headline: A Boss Who’s Open to Suggestions
abstract: If Courtney Kemp Agboh, the show runner for “Power,” has questions about the world of drugs and money, she can ask an executive producer, 50 Cent.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the first few episodes of “Power,” a new series from Starz, one man is shot in the forehead; another is beaten to a bloody pulp; a third is doused with rubber cement and set ablaze. At the center of the mayhem is James St. Patrick (Omari Hardwick), better known as Ghost, a husband and father who manages a swanky nightclub when he’s not stepping out on his beautiful wife, Tasha (Naturi Naughton), or running one of New York City’s most powerful drug empires.

headline: Today’s Hot I.P.O.: El Pollo Loco
abstract: Tasty chicken? The stock of El Pollo Loco is up more than 50 percent from its I.P.O. price.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:39 p.m. | Investors seem to like the taste of chicken.

headline: Rand Paul Stands Out in Courting Black Voters
abstract: The Kentucky senator, taking heed of lessons for the Republican Party in 2012, made his pitch at a National Urban League Conference.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — After Mitt Romney received just 6 percent of the black vote in 2012, the Republican Party said that it could no longer afford to ignore African-Americans. “We are never going to win over voters who are not asked for their support,” its leaders wrote in a candid election post-mortem.

headline: Against Walter Kasper (II)
keywords: ['ADULTERY', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Polygamy']
abstract: Catholicism, divorce and remarriage, revisited.
lead_paragraph: Back in May, I offered some general comments on the question of communion for divorced and remarried Catholics — which looms over the Synod on the Family scheduled for this autumn in Rome, and may represent one of the defining controversies of Pope Francis’s pontificate — and then wrote what was intended to be the first of two posts addressing Cardinal Walter Kasper’s high-profile case for admitting the remarried to the sacrament. That post offered theological and sociological reasons to be skeptical of Kasper’s broad suggestion, offered in an interview with the editors of Commonweal, that Catholic marriage generally is in a crisis more severe even than divorce statistics would suggest, in which (he argued) possibly as many as half of all Catholic marriages are actually invalid. The second post, which I promised and then didn’t deliver, was supposed to be a detailed response to his specific proposal on communion, which he first presented in remarks to his fellow cardinals in the winter and then elaborated again in the Commonweal interview this spring.

headline: Weekend Auto Calendar: Old Parts at an Old Show
abstract: The Long Beach Model T Club will hold the 60th annual Vintage & Classic Parts Exchange; Sportscar Championship and Nascar to race at Indianapolis.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

headline: Graffiti and the Civil War
abstract: With burnt sticks or knives, soldiers left behind their names and regiments, crude pictures and jokes, political statements, taunts and prayer requests.
lead_paragraph: In September 1864, Cpl. Robert I. Hogue was stationed with his regiment, the 8th Ohio Volunteer Cavalry, at an unassuming church known as Morgan’s Chapel in Bunker Hill, W.V. Mustered into service earlier that year, the unit had seen hard fighting throughout the Shenandoah Valley that summer. A month later, it would participate in the decisive Union victory at Cedar Creek. But in this interstitial moment, the soldiers had some down time.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: CATASTROPHE 1914: Europe Goes to War,  by Max Hastings. (Vintage, $17.95.) This is an excellent chronicle of World War I’s first months, from the initial diplomatic crisis to the fighting in Belgium and France on the Western Front, and Serbia and Galicia to the east. Hastings, the author of “Inferno: The World at War, 1939-1945,” finds the argument that Germany bore principal blame “overwhelmingly strong.” Sean McMeekin’s JULY 1914: Countdown to War (Basic Books, $17.99) opens with a vivid reconstruction of Archduke Franz Ferdinand’s assassination in Sarajevo on June 28, then focuses on the actions of a small group of statesmen — Austrian, German, Russian, French — as they sought to capitalize on the fallout.

headline: Movie Review: ‘A Most Wanted Man’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Most Wanted Man.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “A Most Wanted Man.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Lucy’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Lucy.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Lucy.”

headline: Russia Steps Up Help for Rebels in Ukraine War
abstract: Russia has accelerated its intervention, moving more of its own troops to its border with Ukraine, American and Ukrainian officials said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Rather than backing down after last week’s downing of a civilian passenger jet, Russia appears to be intervening more aggressively in the war in eastern Ukraine in what American and Ukrainian officials call a dangerous escalation that will almost certainly force more robust retaliation from the United States and Europe.

headline: In Investing, 'When' Matters Just as Much as 'What'
abstract: More examples, this time from real life, of how the timing of stock market peaks and troughs can drastically affect retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: Today I brought you the story of four hypothetical savers to show how timing can be unlucky for some investors who are saving for retirement via the stock market. If you’re building retirement savings little by little over decades, it matters a great deal not just what the stock market or other investments return, but when those returns materialize.

headline: Text and Ride in India
abstract: In a country with heavy traffic congestion and poor public transportation, companies are finding new ways to better connect drivers and passengers.
lead_paragraph: PUNE, India — When Praveen Narayan Dusane first started driving an auto-rickshaw in this crowded college town, he had to hustle for every rupee. He could wait hours at a rickshaw stand for passengers. He fought with other drivers and haggled with passengers over the fares. Typically, he earned just 300 rupees, or roughly $5, during a 12-hour shift.

headline: A Mac That Keeps Working, Even in Sleep Mode
abstract: Plus, how to multitask with Windows 8.1.
lead_paragraph: Q. I thought I wasn’t getting new mail on my phone when I was out running around, but it turns out my new iMac at home was downloading mail even though I put it to sleep. How is this possible?

headline: Taking Stock of Four Years of Dodd-Frank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Banks are still too big to fail and the regulatory framework is incomplete, writes Jennifer Taub, a professor at Vermont Law School.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Taub is professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” was published in May by Yale University Press.

headline: In Context or Out of Step?
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: On West 79th Street, from Amsterdam Avenue to Broadway, is a remarkable example of two facing rows of late 19th-century townhouses on a wide street.
lead_paragraph: On West 79th Street from Amsterdam Avenue to Broadway is a remarkable holdover from the late 19th century, two facing rows of townhouses on a wide street. In the Upper West Side/Central Park West Historic District, the buildings are almost intact, although four were replaced in the 1970s with a homely apartment house of the same height, 203-209 West 79th.

headline: Tomatoes All Summer Long
abstract: Summer tomatoes are flourishing, and they go well with a wide variety of foods. Some can be used to make marinara sauce to get you through the winter, and the rest can be enjoyed raw and cooked in salads, sauces for everything from fish to vegetables to eggs, and breads.
lead_paragraph: Once summer tomatoes are flourishing in my garden and at farmers’ markets, capturing their bounty for the rest of the year becomes a weekly ritual. This mostly involves the making of marinara sauce; I try to have enough of it in the freezer to last me through a winter’s worth of impromptu pasta dinners.

headline: On the Upper West Side, a House Divided by Income
abstract: A development received approval from the city for separate entrances — one for wealthy residents and one for those earning far less who would occupy the project’s affordable units.
lead_paragraph: Even as so many crises roiled the world recently, the news that a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan would proceed with a brand of distasteful social engineering still managed to command international attention. The building, in what is known as Riverside South, a stretch of land reaching below 72nd Street that seems largely like a pop-up location for people who have never heard of Katz’s deli or the G train, had received approval from the city for separate entrances — one for wealthy residents and one for those earning far less who would occupy the project’s affordable units, in a separate wing.

headline: Best Time of Day for a Testosterone Test
abstract: Testosterone levels may fluctuate throughout the day, but variations are most important only in men younger than 45.
lead_paragraph: Doctors often recommend that men with erectile dysfunction have their testosterone measured from 8 a.m. to 11 a.m., because levels are usually highest then and vary over a 24-hour period. But a new study has found that this variation occurs only in younger men.

headline: Letting a Child Make the Small Sacrifice
abstract: It’s always my instinct to sacrifice for my kids. To step back; to say, you take it, you go, it’s ok, I don’t mind. My daughter’s gift of a horseback ride reminded me that being the giver isn’t always the right thing to do.
lead_paragraph: It so happened, recently, that my 10-year-old daughter and I wanted the same thing. It could have been anything — the last brownie, the window seat — but what matters is that there was only one. If our happiness depended on this one thing, there was no way we would both end up happy.

headline: British Prosecutor to Pay $5.1 Million in Case Related to Kaupthing Inquiry
abstract: Britain’s Serious Fraud Office apologized to Vincent Tchenguiz, a property magnate, over how it handled his case as part of an inquiry into the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:02 p.m. | LONDON – Britain’s Serious Fraud Office said on Friday that it would pay 3 million pounds, or about $5.1 million, to settle civil claims brought by a property developer following a flawed investigation into the collapse of the Icelandic bank Kaupthing during the financial crisis.

headline: Big Ticket | Park and River Vistas for $30 Million
abstract: A three-bedroom at 15 Central Park West, owned by the daughter of the fashion designer Perry Ellis, was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath apartment with Central Park and Hudson River vistas from the 33rd floor of the tower at 15 Central Park West sold for $30,003,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: At the Wheel, the Balloonatic
abstract: Nick Rotondo is a city bus driver — as a hobby, he says — but his true calling is as a balloon twister.
lead_paragraph: To many regular passengers on the weekday morning M-8 crosstown bus, Nick Rotondo, 53, is the consummate city bus driver: a seasoned, cheery fellow with a New Yorker’s savvy.

headline: Once an Ornamental Hermit, Now a German Media Darling
abstract: An artist who has no phone or computer, Friedrich Liechtenstein has drawn millions of hits on YouTube with his commercial for Edeka, one of Germany’s largest supermarket chains.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — On a hot summer night here, under the twinkling lights of a spinning disco ball, Friedrich Liechtenstein took the stage in a paisley-print silk bathrobe. “My dear people,” the newly minted German media star said, in a sonorous voice, “If things don’t work out tonight, don’t think of this as an awful show. Rather, I recommend you look at it as if it were a film — one that replicates, very precisely, an awful show.”

headline: French President on Air Algerie Crash
abstract: President François Hollande of France said there were no survivors in the crash of an Air Algérie jetliner, as the first images of the wreckage site in Mali were released.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France said there were no survivors in the crash of an Air Algérie jetliner, as the first images of the wreckage site in Mali were released.

headline: John Walsh’s Campaign Sinking Under Plagiarism
abstract: It’s a bad sign when the establishment declares its “100 percent” support.
lead_paragraph: It’s virtually an axiom in Washington politics that when the establishment declares its undying support for a person at the center of a scandal, that person is about to be thrown under the bus. The latest potential traffic victim is Senator John Walsh of Montana, the retired Army colonel who seems to have plagiarized his master’s thesis for the United States Army War College.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Kim Philby Case
abstract: This week, Ben Macintyre discusses “A Spy Among Friends”; Alexandra Alter and Parul Sehgal talk about the week’s literary news; Donald L. Miller discusses “Supreme City”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ben Macintyre discusses “A Spy Among Friends”; Alexandra Alter and Parul Sehgal talk about the week’s literary news; Donald L. Miller discusses “Supreme City”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Transforming the Investment Case for BSkyB
abstract: Sky Europe promises scale, growth, and cost savings — but leverage will soar and cash returns will shrivel, writes Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: “British” Sky Broadcasting is no more. The company is buying sister Sky units in Germany and Italy for at least 4.9 billion pounds ($8.3 billion) in cash from Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox. That transforms the investment case for Britain’s top pay-television company.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Kim Philby Case
abstract: This week, Ben Macintyre and Donald L. Miller.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ben Macintyre and Donald L. Miller.

headline: Mark Fisher: A Day Away From the Ninjas
abstract: Mr. Fisher, who opened Mark Fisher Fitness two years ago, spends time on Sunday thinking about fitness, but also finds room for dessert.
lead_paragraph: While acting in regional theater in his 20s, Mark Fisher often shared workout techniques with fellow cast members, and his advice became so popular that he turned it into a regimen, called “Snatched in Six Weeks.” Two years ago, with residuals from an Allstate commercial, he and his business partner opened Mark Fisher Fitness on West 39th Street in Hell’s Kitchen — and moved into an apartment upstairs. The gym (known as the clubhouse) draws scores of Broadway performers, including Shina Ann Morris, an actress in “Rodgers & Hammerstein’s Cinderella” who became Mr. Fisher’s girlfriend. Mr. Fisher, 34, and Ms. Morris, 28, live together in the apartment with Mr. Fisher’s business partner and his boyfriend.

headline: The New Oil Patch: Rail Lines in Albany and Elsewhere
abstract: The oil boom in the West is creating traffic jams of oil trains in New York’s Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: In a thorough piece, “Albany Nears Oil-Hub Status as 100-Car Trains Jam Port,” Bloomberg News does a great job of illustrating why New York State has to work swiftly to get a handle on issues related to the oil-by-rail boom.

headline: Taking New Music From Los Angeles to Reykjavik
abstract: A concert in August will unite composers and performers from Los Angeles with a women’s choir in Iceland.
lead_paragraph: Here is a glimpse of how an enterprising classical new-music ensemble gets projects underway in 2014.

headline: An Exclusive New Club in Paris With a No-Social-Media Rule
abstract: Isolation is the theme at L’isolé, a bar in the red-light district of Pigalle that will open before Paris fashion week.
lead_paragraph: L’isolé, a bar in the red light district of Pigalle that will open in time for Paris fashion week, translates to “the isolated.” It’s not exactly antisocial, but it does have a strict “No Facebook, No Twitter” policy. Co-founders Guillaume Le Donche and Antoine Galabert want it to be a place with a human touch. “We manage all our communication with prints and real-life networking,” says Le Donche, 27, who honed his skills at Parisian hot spots La Clique, Showcase and L’Inconnu. “With only digital promotion, you’re just lost in the maze of the Internet.”

headline: Is Moore’s Law Less Important to the Tech Industry?
abstract: Moore’s Law wasn’t just about building better transistors; it was a way of organizing the tech business. What happens when that computing strength matters less to a company, thanks to cloud computing?
lead_paragraph: The central organizing principle of much of the tech industry is Moore’s Law. In one very important sense, it may be of less value than it once was.

headline: Before Kubrick Was an Auteur
abstract: Before making movies like “Dr. Strangelove,” Stanley Kubrick worked at Look magazine, holding his own with the New York photojournalists of the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Kubrick, who would have turned 86 on Saturday, was once known professionally as just “Stan Kubrick” — an almost comically breezy abbreviation for the man we know as a titanically exacting director. Then again, Kubrick was only 16 at the time, a precocious boy from the Grand Concourse with a Graflex camera, who had somehow blustered his way into the picture department at Look magazine. For the next five years there, before his movie career began, he held his own with the New York photojournalists of the 1940s, covering street life, prizefights, jazz concerts, stars and starlets, and forging a recognizable style of his own.

headline: Smooth Dogfish Shark: A Threat, if You’re a Clam
abstract: The smooth dogfish (Mustelus canis) never grows much larger than three feet long and can be surprisingly abundant off the beaches along New York City’s Rockaway Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic shoreline has not been the same since June 1975, when “Jaws” opened. For many, the movie’s deep, pulsating theme music remains an ominous reminder that there could be something looking up at us from under our kicking feet. Sightings of great white sharks off our coastlines sell newspapers for weeks each summer — and this year has been no exception.

headline: Stepping Into the Frame in the South of France
abstract: L’Estaque once drew artists from Cézanne to Braque to its shores near Marseille. Now the author takes her own trip to see the landscape for herself.
lead_paragraph: It was Paul Cézanne who went to L’Estaque first, in 1864. He escaped the gray dreariness of Paris and later avoided army conscription in the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 in this sunny shorefront village outside Marseille. From the windows of a rented house next to the little church on the hill, he could look out on the tile rooftops leading down to the harbor, with its fishing boats, and across the wide bay to Marseille, the low, rocky mountains at its back.

headline: 1939: World’s End Because of Mars?
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A French astronomer denies news of the end of the world in 1939.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican ‘‘astronomer’’ who has seized on the planet Mars’s approach to the earth to predict the end of the world tomorrow is ignorant of the elements of astronomy, according to Ernest Esclangon, director of the Paris Observatory, who, in a mock-serious vein, yesterday ‘‘authorized a denial’’ of the publicity-seeking prediction. ‘‘Why, in the firmament’s name, should the approach of Mars be a danger to this planet of ours?’’ M. Esclangon told anxious reporters. ‘‘It is a simple matter of planetary motions which brings Mars in line with the earth and the sun every sixteen years, and if this geometrical phenomenon were to be the end of the world every time it occurred, there would have been no world long before this.’’ Mere proximity of Mars to the earth is no menace, M. Esclangon explained, since both planets continue to move in their respective orbits, like ships that pass by each other on the high seas, each on its own course. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 26, 1939

headline: A Turkish Town Where Baklava Beckons
abstract: Gaziantep, a city of about a million people, claims some 100 baklava shops, which supply 90 percent of the baklava consumed in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you notice among passengers departing from Oguzeli Airport in Gaziantep, Turkey, is the profusion of shopping bags containing baklava, the intensely sweet Middle Eastern phyllo pastry and nut confection that is a staple of every Turkish celebration. This city of about a million people, in the province of the same name and situated on the Silk Road about 530 miles southeast of Istanbul, claims some 100 baklava shops, which supply 90 percent of the baklava consumed in Turkey. Last December, Gaziantep baklava, which is made with locally grown pistachio nuts, was awarded “protected status” by the European Union, a designation that recognizes a specific local food, protects it from imitators and potentially helps boost tourism to the area.

headline: Hotel Review: Pestana South Beach Art Deco Hotel in Miami Beach
abstract: This property, which opened in April 2013, aims for a retro beach vibe in a quiet nook of South Beach.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: A Secluded Modern
abstract: A 22-acre estate with 2,000 feet of waterfront in Eastport is poised to enter the market for the first time in 35 years.
lead_paragraph: Seatuck Cove Farms, a secluded 22-acre estate with 2,000 feet of waterfront on Seatuck Creek and Little Seatuck Creek in Eastport, and panoramic views across Moriches Bay to Dune Road in Westhampton, is entering the market for the first time in 35 years. The asking price is $12 million.

headline: Lots of Paul Ryan’s New Report Is About State and Local Policy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Intellectual Property', 'States (US)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: At the federal level, Republicans should look to untapped areas for reform, like intellectual property and infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most innovative ideas for conservative reforms are in policy areas controlled by state and local governments. That’s why, beyond its proposals to change how the federal government fights poverty, the new “discussion draft” from Representative Paul Ryan has recommendations in areas you might not associate with him: education, sentencing, parole and occupational licensing, to name a few.

headline: Passions Running to Art, or Infanticide
abstract: Three plays with particularly passionate women are running in London: “Medea,” “Bakersfield Mist” (with Kathleen Turner) and Noël Coward’s “This Was a Man.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — You have heard this story before, many times, and it’s never been pretty. A wife devotes her existence to furthering her husband’s career, making countless self-denying sacrifices. And then the bum trades her in for a younger model. The discarded wife gets angrier and angrier and angrier, until there’s truly hell to pay.

headline: Peach Crumble Slab Pie
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a delicious deep-dish dessert with fresh peaches that is equal parts crumble and pie.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a delicious deep-dish dessert with fresh peaches that is equal parts crumble and pie.

headline: A Stripped-Down Domestic Drama
abstract: A production at the Westport Country Playhouse of “Nora,” the 1981 adaptation by Ingmar Bergman of “A Doll’s House” by Henrik Ibsen, has a modern look and an inspired ending.
lead_paragraph: Just why “A Doll’s House” needs stripping down to its essentials, I don’t know, but people keep trying. The new production of “Nora” at the Westport Country Playhouse has a minimalist set and a naked man in the spotlight at the end. “Nora” is the 1981 adaptation by Sweden’s genius film auteur Ingmar Bergman of “A Doll’s House,” Henrik Ibsen’s landmark 1879 feminist domestic drama; Bergman had already eliminated six of the original play’s characters (the children and the servants).

headline: Studs Terkel Audio Archive to Go Online
abstract: A digital archive of Terkel’s oral histories is one of 177 projects funded by new grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities.
lead_paragraph: The creation of a publicly accessible digital archive with nearly 5,000 oral history interviews, conducted by the Chicago journalist Studs Terkel, is one of 177 projects awarded a grant this week by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

headline: The Future Looks Peachy
abstract: A good peach pie will often disappear in a flash. A slab pie, on the other hand, will feed a crowd and still provide leftovers.
lead_paragraph: The sad truth about homemade peach pie is that there’s never enough.

headline: Indian Air Force Helicopter Crashes, Killing 7
abstract: The helicopter possibly hit a high-tension wire, and witnesses said they saw it explode before it crashed.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian Air Force helicopter exploded and crashed in northern India on Friday, possibly after hitting a high-voltage electrical cable, killing all seven people aboard, the authorities announced.

headline: Setting Sights on Long Island and Wars Past
abstract: An exhibition at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages focuses on Long Island’s role in American wars from the Revolutionary War through the conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Ruff, the chief curator of the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, has chosen objects of all shapes and sizes for the exhibitions there — including, recently, a large gun sight from a World War II B-32 bomber that Mr. Ruff estimates weighs “about 400 pounds.”

headline: In Queens, Immigrants Clash With Residents of New Homeless Shelter
abstract: A defunct hotel in Elmhurst that the city turned into temporary housing has been the focus of racially tinged protests — and resentment that the city did not alert the community in advance.
lead_paragraph: The crowd of 500 included grandmothers and small children, Chinese immigrants and the president of a local Republican club, all shouting that the mayor had trampled their rights.

headline: Long Beach Film Festival Finds a Home
abstract: After Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, the Long Beach International Film Festival, which had just finished its inaugural year, threatened to collapse before ever fully taking off. But it is back for its first full season, with a movie by Daniel Baldwin.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, the fledgling Long Beach International Film Festival, which had just finished its inaugural year, threatened to collapse before ever fully taking off. A prospective screening site had been destroyed, and without a proper venue the festival could not attract filmmakers and sponsors.

headline: Popcast: Arto Lindsay’s Ecstatic Procession
abstract: Arto Lindsay discusses his work and career, including a new album, “Encyclopedia of Arto.”
lead_paragraph: Arto Lindsay, the singer and guitarist who was born in Virginia and raised partly in Recife, Brazil, has been an important if inconstant figure in New York music over the last 35 years.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Kim Philby Case
abstract: Ben Macintyre discusses “A Spy Among Friends,” and Donald L. Miller talks about “Supreme City.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Walter Isaacson reviews Ben Macintyre’s “A Spy Among Friends: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal.” Mr. Isaacson writes:

headline: 1875: The Airplane, Still a Flight of Fancy
abstract: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: A Hamptons Bistro Gets an Update
abstract: In Sag Harbor, Page at 63 Main, an American bistro that opened four years ago, is recently recharged, having undergone significant renovations and changes, including the hiring of a new chef this year.
lead_paragraph: If there is such a thing as a restaurant mecca in the Hamptons these days, it would mostly likely be Sag Harbor, the quaint former whaling town located north of Bridgehampton.

headline: Top Sprinter’s Crash Ruins Bid for First Stage Win
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Cycling, Road', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Peter Sagan’s fall ended his chances of catching Ramunas Navardauskas, who won Stage 19 in heavy rain. Vincenzo Nibali, the Tour de France’s overall leader, stayed out of trouble ahead of Sunday’s finish.
lead_paragraph: BERGERAC, France — It was another rainy day at the Tour de France with a rider from the American Garmin-Sharp team at the front as the finish neared. But unlike Jack Bauer, who was caught only yards before the finish line in Nîmes on Sunday, Ramunas Navardauskas managed to win alone Friday after a 129.5-mile trek through downpours, thunder and lightning.

headline: Employees Who Leave Increasingly Return to the Fold
abstract: LeBron James is just one example of a boomerang employee — one who leaves a job only to return. The practice is on the rise, and it is more welcome than it used to be.
lead_paragraph: LeBRON JAMES has been called a king, a superathlete, a traitor. And now that the basketball megastar has decided to return to Cleveland and the team he once abandoned, he’s earned a new moniker he may not even know about: boomerang.

headline: Putting the A in STEAM
abstract: “Steam,” a new exhibition in White Plains, takes its name from an educational movement, STEAM, which is STEM (another curriculum that is an acronym for science, technology, engineering and mathematics) with the addition of the “A” for art.
lead_paragraph: An arrangement of test tubes containing color-coded genetic material; a wearable garden that purifies the air; an installation inspired by the periodic table — these artworks all incorporate components of STEM, an educational curriculum that is an acronym for science, technology, engineering and mathematics. They are currently among more than 40 pieces on view in “Steam,” a new exhibition at ArtsWestchester’s Arts Exchange.

headline: S.E.C. Says Citigroup Unit Failed to Protect Customer Trading Data
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Citigroup will pay $5 million to settle charges that LavaFlow, a unit that operates an alternative stock trading venue, allowed another bank subsidiary to access customer trading data.
lead_paragraph: LavaFlow, a unit of Citigroup that operates an alternative stock trading venue, agreed to pay $5 million to settle charges that it failed to protect the confidential trading data of its customers, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday. The payment includes a $2.85 million penalty that the S.E.C. said was the largest it had levied against an alternative trading system.

headline: A Drop in the Long-Term Unemployed
abstract: After lagging for years, the rate of those considered long-term unemployed — out of work for at least 27 weeks — is declining rapidly.
lead_paragraph: THE long-term unemployment rate, which soared in 2009 to heights not seen since the Great Depression, is finally declining rapidly. The proportion of the work force that has been unemployed for at least 27 weeks has fallen to 1.98 percent, less than half the record high of 4.4 percent reached in 2010.

headline: At Goldman Sachs, the Right Candidate for a Half-Right Job
abstract: The Wall Street firm has named Adebayo Ogunlesi to be the board’s new lead director. If only Goldman saw fit to call him chairman, writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has found the right man for a half-right job.

headline: A Greek Summer Treasure
abstract: In a classic salad or a dish with shrimp, sweet, meaty, sun-ripened tomatoes are served virtually unadorned.
lead_paragraph: In Greece, the summer produce of choice is the sweet, meaty, sun-ripened red tomato. Tomatoes are eaten daily, usually with not much more adornment than a sprinkling of sea salt and a drizzle of fruity olive oil. They can be raw or cooked; either way, they are wonderful.

headline: A Landlord Rents Office Space, and Maybe a Picture or Two
abstract: The Durst Organization, a New York office landlord, and Asher Edelman, an art financier, plan to acquire fine art and allow businesses to lease it for their office walls.
lead_paragraph: Many business owners want their offices to reflect good taste, with fine art on the walls. But they must weigh the cost against the vagaries of the marketplace. A few good years, and the millions come rolling in. A few setbacks, and the banks send a crew to pack up the furniture.

headline: Vick Teaches Smith Virtually and in Reality
abstract: The Jets’ major story line of the summer will be Geno Smith’s performance at quarterback and his relationship with Michael Vick, who first made an impression on him in a video game.
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — After a recent morning practice, Geno Smith, the young quarterback who many presume will be the Jets’ starter, recalled the first time he was introduced to Michael Vick, the veteran who could well be his backup.

headline: How to Charge Your Phone in 15 Minutes
abstract: The Unu Ultrapak is the fastest-charging battery pack on the market, effectively letting you charge up your phone in 15 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Say you’ve got 15 minutes in an airport between flights and your phone is nearly dead. What do you do?

headline: Brooklyn Bridge White Flag Culprits Avoiding Capture, So Far
keywords: ['Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: The police have no strong leads as to the identities of the people who put two ghostly white flags on the bridge towers in place of two American flags.
lead_paragraph: The daredevils who scaled the towers of the Brooklyn Bridge and put white flags in place of the American flags there have eluded capture for three days, and authorities said Friday that they were not much closer to finding them.

headline: Documenting Missteps in Death of Peace Corps Volunteer
abstract: Documents, including emails, letters and investigative reports about the death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old Peace Corps volunteer in China.
lead_paragraph: Documents, including emails, letters and investigative reports about the death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old Peace Corps volunteer in China.

headline: The 19th-Century Home of Jell-O’s Forefather
abstract: After two years of renovations, Ringwood Manor, bought in 1853 by Peter Cooper, who is credited with inventing a gelatin that would become Jell-O, is again open for tours.
lead_paragraph: As the historian of Ringwood Manor, a sprawling country home on the grounds of Ringwood State Park, Sue Shutte often deals with the constant quirks and mysteries of this 19th-century estate.

headline: Peace Corps Volunteers in Their Own Words
abstract: To reflect the diversity of experiences in the Peace Corps, The Times asked recent volunteers to share stories about their service.
lead_paragraph: To reflect the diversity of experiences in the Peace Corps, The Times asked recent volunteers to share stories about their service.

headline: Trail of Medical Missteps in a Peace Corps Death
abstract: The death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old volunteer in China, raises serious questions about Peace Corps medical care.
lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, Calif. — Nick Castle had just graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, when he loaded up his backpack with Mandarin-language books and set off for rural China to teach in the Peace Corps. Seven months later, in January 2013, a 2 a.m. telephone call jolted his parents awake.

headline: Ezra Klein Asks the Wrong Question
abstract: Paul Ryan, same as he ever was.
lead_paragraph: He asks, Why should anyone trust Paul Ryan’s poverty plan? That’s easy: nobody should. This has been another edition of simple answers to simple questions.

lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.
