abstract: Find out how well you communicate using emojis in this 10 question quiz.
lead_paragraph: Find out how well you communicate using emojis in this 10 question quiz.

headline: The Emoji Have Won the Battle of Words
keywords: ['Emojis and Emoticons', 'Symbols', 'Social Media', 'Text Messaging', 'E-Mail', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: Emoji begin to dominate the conversation.
lead_paragraph: It started about six months ago, with a smiley face here and there, a sequence of pictograph red hearts when friends would send baby pictures or a string of blown kisses to say good night. I especially liked the face with a toothy, uncomfortable-looking grimace: “Yikes,” it seemed to say. Perfect for “I’m sorry I’m late!” or “Eek, it’s 1 p.m. and I just woke up.”

headline: Opaque System Obscures Support for Health Care Ad
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Political Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'Small Business', 'Insurance', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: An Arkansas business owner was the face of a television ad critical of the Obama administration’s health care plan, but insurance companies were backers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The television ad sponsored by the advocacy arm of the National Federation of Independent Business featured a small-business owner in Arkansas, frustrated at what he said were the higher bills he had seen since the Obama administration’s health care plan went into effect — and pointing blame at Senator Mark Pryor, a Democrat considered one of the most vulnerable incumbents facing re-election this fall.

headline: No Time to Think
abstract: Nowadays, people can keep negative thoughts at bay with a frenzy of activity.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the biggest complaints in modern society is being overscheduled, overcommitted and overextended. Ask people at a social gathering how they are and the stock answer is “super busy,” “crazy busy” or “insanely busy.” Nobody is just “fine” anymore.

headline: Failure Is Our Muse
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: The entrepreneurs at FailCon have nothing on us. Writers are the professional losers.
lead_paragraph: JULY 8, in case you happened to miss it, was Fitz-Greene Halleck Day, a chance to remember the most intensely forgotten writer in American history. “No name in the American poetical world is more firmly established than that of Fitz-Greene Halleck,” Edgar Allan Poe wrote in 1843. And yet, despite a Central Park statue that still stands in his honor, Fitz-Greene Halleck may now be the most famous man ever to achieve total obscurity.

headline: In Wake of Disasters, an Air Travel F.A.Q.
abstract: The downing of the Malaysia Airlines plane and the rocket strike near Ben Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv may leave you with questions about your travel plans. We have answers.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the shooting of Malaysia Airlines flight 17 last week and the rocket strike near Ben-Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv this week, people planning to fly to the Middle East or on a route crossing Eastern Europe have been left wondering whether or not they could — or should — continue with their travel plans.

headline: We’re Missing the Story
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: News media are cutting back on the immersive reporting that matters most.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — THE Western news media are in crisis and are turning their back on the world. We hardly ever notice. Where correspondents were once assigned to a place for years or months, reporters now handle 20 countries each. Bureaus are in hub cities, far from many of the countries they cover. And journalists are often lodged in expensive bungalows or five-star hotels. As the news has receded, so have our minds.

headline: Bel Kaufman, Who Told What School Was Really Like, Dies at 103
abstract: Ms. Kaufman’s first novel, “Up the Down Staircase,” portrayed the topsy-turvy world of a New York City public school and was based on her experience as a teacher.
lead_paragraph: Bel Kaufman, a former New York City schoolteacher whose classic first novel, “Up the Down Staircase” — shot through with despair and hopefulness, violence and levity, bureaucratic inanity and a blizzard of official memorandums so mind-bendingly illogical as to seem almost Kafkaesque — was hailed as a stunningly accurate portrait of life in an urban school when it was published in 1965, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103.

headline: The End of the Cringe
abstract: The Democrats, they are a-changing.
lead_paragraph: Doug Sosnik has an interesting piece in Politico on how “the left” is taking over the Democratic Party. Of course, what he calls “left” would be centrist, maybe even right of center, in most other Western democracies; and I think it’s still true that today’s progressive icons — say, Elizabeth Warren — are to the right of where old-line liberals like Teddy Kennedy were.

headline: Audubon Seeks a More Bird-Friendly Design for the Vikings’ New Stadium
abstract: The Audubon Society said thousands of birds might die if the design of the stadium did not include bird-safe glass, but the building authority said it did not have the money.
lead_paragraph: As if they did not already have their hands full trying to beat the Eagles, the Falcons and the Ravens, the Minnesota Vikings now have to grapple with ruby-throated hummingbirds, song sparrows and hermit thrushes.

headline: Finally, a Cocktail Congress Can Agree On
abstract: In honor of Congress, where getting even the minimum done is hard work, a drink that does the job, and not much more.
lead_paragraph: Next week, the Senate is expected to pass a bill that will keep the Federal Highway Trust Fund from running out of money for almost a year. Nobody’s really happy with the bill, attacked by lawmakers from both parties for including fiscal gimmicks. But at least it means states won’t have to start shutting down existing highway projects on Aug. 1 for lack of funds.

headline: Following a Very Different Path to Marital Bliss
abstract: Moving in with my parents seemed akin to setting up camp in a wedlock war zone. But instead, our marriage has improved, as we witness my parents’ union up close.
lead_paragraph: Last month, in anticipation of our 25th anniversary, my husband, Daniel, and I pulled out our wedding video, thinking it would be fun for our now-teenage children to see their parents’ partying pre-kids and for my parents to remember what a great party they had given that day. But the viewing party soon resembled a game of “Duck, Duck, Goose,” as my father, now 83, gave the status of their friends in the church as the camera panned over their smiling faces.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Weekend Reading: Waiting on Rupert
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The announcement today that 21st Century Fox was selling some of its European assets has renewed talk that Rupert Murdoch is reloading for a new Time Warner bid.
lead_paragraph: The only way Rupert Murdoch’s highly anticipated Time Warner bid could grab any more attention is if 21st Century Fox moved its headquarters from New York to tax-friendly Australia.

headline: Broadway’s Musical Chairs
abstract: Substituting for regular musicians on Broadway pays pretty well if you can deal with the high stakes.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the stage of Broadway’s Al Hirschfeld Theater lies a dark space with a low ceiling — a cross between a suburban rec room and a submarine. Shortly before each performance of “Kinky Boots,” 13 black-clad musicians file to their battle stations, each illuminated by a small light attached to a music stand. The expectant buzz of the audience filters down from a narrow opening at the edge of the stage.

headline: Quick, Sloppy and Expensive Background Checks
abstract: A security contractor reviewed 15,152 clearances cases in a single month last year.
lead_paragraph: Running security background checks on government job applicants has become a booming private industry in Washington’s war on terror. It’s such a busy sector that one of the many workers vetting citizens managed to review 15,152 clearance cases in a single month last year. That’s about one and a half cases per minute handled by the employee, not allowing for bathroom breaks.

headline: Remembering Ace Greenberg, Through Good Times and Bad
abstract: DealBook looks back at the career of Alan C. Greenberg, who led Bear Stearns through its rise and fall, in his words and others’.
lead_paragraph: Alan C. Greenberg, who led Bear Stearns through its rise and fall, died on Friday at the age of 86. During his long career on Wall Street, he was known as a colorful character with a penchant for magic tricks and a generous heart.

headline: Front-Wheel-Drive Ingenuity
abstract: Early front-drive cars would often stall on steep grades, but the makers of the Ruxton solved that problem by moving the engine forward, increasing traction and improving handling.
lead_paragraph: Early front-drive passenger cars had an alarming tendency to slip or stall on steep grades. A crucial challenge in the development of the Ruxton was to accommodate both a lengthy reverse-mounted straight-8 engine and conventional transmission so that as much weight as possible would end up over the front wheels.

headline: Even After Ruxton, the Drama Continued
abstract: William J. Muller and Archie M. Andrews, the men behind the Ruxton, briefly reunited in a subsequent automotive venture.
lead_paragraph: The years after the death of the Ruxton automobile proved eerily circular for the two men most entwined in its checkered history, William J. Muller and Archie M. Andrews. Briefly reunited in a subsequent automotive venture, a final twist pitted them against each other.

headline: Remembering the Ruxton
keywords: ["Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)", 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The Ruxton seemed destined for greatness in 1929, but the company that made the car fell apart. In August, the Pebble Beach concours is expected to display at least 15 of the cars.
lead_paragraph: With its pioneering front-wheel drive, low-slung silhouette and cat’s eye headlamps, the multicolored Ruxton automobile seemed destined for greatness in 1929.

headline: Good While It Lasted
abstract: Ruxtons were beautiful, innovative automobiles, but a little over a year after the first model was produced for 1929, the company was gone.
lead_paragraph: Ruxtons were beautiful, innovative automobiles, but a little over a year after the first model was produced for 1929, the company was gone.

headline: Not Quite an M Car, but Stirring in Spirit
abstract: The handsome 2 Series, which replaces the 1 Series in the BMW lineup, has more interior luxury than the previous model and is a blast to drive, especially the M235i version.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a tire-kicking experiment: Pay a visit to your BMW dealer. Weave through the sleek wares on display — but tiptoe around that strange blobby thing called a 5 Series GT. Now, stop when you see a window sticker that’s less than $40,000.

headline: Under the Hood, More Than Just Horsepower
abstract: Automakers have long given their engines striking names, like Hemi and Rocket. The best engine naming is a form of marketing that mixes the mechanical and biological in old-style American braggadocio.
lead_paragraph: Detroit’s newest muscle car is best known by the name of the 707-horsepower supercharged Hemi V8 under its hood. The brawniest 2015 Dodge Challenger SRT may as well dispense with the rest of its official nomenclature: As long as its power comes from the Hellcat, that’s what people will call this car.

headline: 2014 BMW M235i
abstract: The M235i may not be a full-blown M car, but in many ways it performs like one.
lead_paragraph: The M235i may not be a full-blown M car, but in many ways it performs like one.

headline: The Many Names of Power
abstract: In automotive marketing, an engine is more than a power plant. It’s a Super-Hurricane, a Fire Dome, a Hemi.
lead_paragraph: In automotive marketing, an engine is more than a power plant. It’s a Super-Hurricane, a Fire Dome, a Hemi.

headline: Panama-Crossed Paths, Far From Brooklyn
abstract: He’s the yin to her yang, as an Ivy-educated lawyer meets her match when he was in Peace Corps as an environmental health worker.
lead_paragraph: When Erik King was 26, he outfitted an old school bus with bunk beds and surfboards, transforming it into a roving surf hostel, which he drove along the coast of Mexico and Central America for two years.

headline: A Low-Cost Head-Up Option
abstract: The Garmin HUD+ projects information drivers can see while looking through the windshield. The technology lets drivers get vital information without taking their eyes off the road.
lead_paragraph: For drivers who have grown dependent on head-up displays to monitor their speed and read navigation instructions, the Garmin HUD+ may be a boon, a disappointment or a bit of each.

headline: Top 15 Fantasy Football Quarterbacks
abstract: The position is deep heading into the 2014 fantasy football season.
lead_paragraph: The position is deep heading into the 2014 fantasy football season.

headline: Fantasy Football: Quarterback Primer
abstract: A look at some of the different approaches when drafting a fantasy football quarterback, along with sleeper, bust and breakout picks.
lead_paragraph: Strike early, or wait? That is always the great debate when it comes to drafting a quarterback for your fantasy team. The 2013 season gave us 14 passers who averaged 20 or more standard fantasy points per week. Astonishingly enough, that group excluded flashy names like Colin Kaepernick (19 pts), Matt Ryan (18.8), Tom Brady (18.6) and Robert Griffin III (18.5).

headline: Sophisticated, With a Side of Service
abstract: Chic ambience and friendly service aside, the draw at Mémoire in Ridgewood is decidedly the food.
lead_paragraph: Many restaurants in downtown Ridgewood, a charming scene full of homegrown boutiques and cafes, open with great fanfare and then suddenly are shuttered. But judging by the robust, enthusiastic crowds, Mémoire, a new, sleek establishment that makes the most of local seasonal produce and an extremely accommodating staff, could have some staying power.

headline: Police Stop-and-Frisk in Newark
abstract: Philip Montgomery found few cinema-worthy stop-and-frisk moments in Newark. Instead, he found distrust and misunderstanding clouding these encounters.
lead_paragraph: Philip Montgomery found few cinema-worthy stop-and-frisk moments in Newark. Instead, he found distrust and misunderstanding clouding these encounters.

headline: Friday Night Music: Hotel California
abstract: You can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.
lead_paragraph: For obvious reasons. Also, still pretty great:

headline: Carrie Hessler-Radelet
abstract: In an interview recorded before The Times learned the details surrounding Nick Castle’s death, the director of the Peace Corps reflected on her volunteer experience and the agency’s future.
lead_paragraph: In an interview recorded before The Times learned the details surrounding Nick Castle’s death, the director of the Peace Corps reflected on her volunteer experience and the agency’s future.

headline: A Toast? How About a Toke?
abstract: In Colorado and Washington State, wedding planners for pot enthusiasts are incorporating weed in everything from bouquets to decorations to gifts.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, when Ellen Epstein arrived at the Devil’s Thumb Ranch in Tabernash, Colo., for the wedding of her friends Lauren Meisels and Bradley Melshenker, she, like the other guests, found a gift bag waiting for her in her hotel room. But rather than a guide to activities in the area or a jar of locally made honey, the canvas bag contained a rolled joint, a lighter and lip balm infused with mango butter and cannabis, along with this note: “We wanted to show you some of the things we love the best.”

headline: Video: The 2015 Hyundai Genesis Delivers Value, but Not Much Flash
abstract: At $38,950, the second-generation Genesis offers solid standard features in a large, rear-wheel-drive touring sedan package. But it’s no Audi.
lead_paragraph: The best way to find a car’s strengths and weaknesses is to take it on an extended road trip. I recently did just that with the second-generation Hyundai Genesis, traveling from Seattle to Corvallis, Ore., with my 17-year-old son and two of his friends. Boys are great to travel with. They talk sports, point out cool cars, eat junk food and then retreat to their headphones to listen to music their mothers don’t approve of.

headline: By the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, a Treasure Island
abstract: In a borough where curating is a way of life, shoppers at New York Old Iron are offered the rare opportunity to rummage through the unedited castoff past.
lead_paragraph: Visitors entering the Lowe’s parking lot from Ninth Street inevitably slow to a crawl as they pass by New York Old Iron. Even along the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, you don’t expect to see this.

headline: Powerful and Coldhearted
abstract: It’s hard for powerful people to feel empathy.
lead_paragraph: I FEEL your pain.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, France and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Gaza City, Israel, France and Germany.

headline: Why We're Likely to See More 'Worst' Presidents
abstract: A reflection of the nation's polarized political climate shows up in changing answers to a poll question.
lead_paragraph: How much do members of the opposite party dislike whoever happens to be president? A lot, and the feeling seems to be getting stronger.

headline: Kerry Vows to Continue Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry planned to fly to Paris on Friday night to continue his diplomatic push for a cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that an intensive effort to arrange a seven-day humanitarian cease-fire in the conflict in Gaza had fallen short, but he promised to keep trying.

headline: A Fan’s Essential Jenny Lewis Primer
abstract: Earlier in my career, I worked as a music reviewer, which meant listening to a lot of really bad music. But the first time I heard Jenny Lewis, I became an instant fan.
lead_paragraph: Earlier in my career, I worked as a music reviewer, which, as you can imagine, meant listening to a lot of really bad music. But the first time I heard Jenny Lewis, I became an instant fan. She is an ‘‘indie goddess,’’ as Jeff Himmelman writes in this week’s magazine, ‘‘a stylish performer who defies genre and salts her songs with a sly and off-kilter intelligence.’’ I love that her lyrics transcend the simplistic tropes of pop music. Instead, each song draws you in and tells a story. I’m not ashamed to admit that I cried when I saw Lewis perform with the Watson Twins in 2006.

headline: The Brando, Both a Resort and a Lab
abstract: The 35-villa luxury resort and scientific research lab opened on the atoll Marlon Brandon had bought north of Tahiti.
lead_paragraph: Marlon Brando first visited Tetiaroa, a 12-island atoll 30 miles north of Tahiti, while filming “Mutiny on the Bounty.” He bought it five years later, and briefly ran an inn, where he invited conservationists and researchers interested in the South Pacific ecosystem. This month, Tetiaroa continues this legacy with the opening of the Brando, a 35-villa luxury resort and scientific research lab.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Challenges for Amazon’s Cloud Computing Hopes
abstract: Amazon Web Services reported a surprising decline in quarterly revenue on Thursday. Amazon blamed Google’s price cuts, but its web services could be hitting some harder business sales.
lead_paragraph: How worried should Amazon be about its biggest hope for the future?

headline: Sing a Song, End a War: All in a Supernatural Camp Routine
abstract: The musical “The Lightning Thief,” based on Rick Riordan’s young-adult novel, centers on a sixth grader who learns he’s the son of a Greek god.
lead_paragraph: I plan to change the subject when my 11-year-old daughter asks about “The Lightning Thief,” a new musical at the Lucille Lortel Theater. She was excited to attend, but a last-minute appointment prevented it. To tell her how much fun she missed might be a little cruel.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Animated ‘Star Wars’ Series Aims to Be True to Original Film
abstract: “Star Wars Rebels,” which debuts in October on Disney Channel and Disney XD, marks the start of the Walt Disney Company’s stewardship of the space franchise.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — “Star Wars Rebels,” an animated series that marks the start of the Walt Disney Company’s stewardship of the space franchise, will not be anything like the last three “p” movies — you know, the prequel trilogy that took in more than $3.3 billion worldwide but left many hard-core fans fuming.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Summer Prints
abstract: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns.
lead_paragraph: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns.

headline: Remembered as Victims, Recast as Heroines
abstract: An upbeat new musical pushes a girl-power message, casting two historical characters as strong-willed, smart, selfless heroines who choose their own destinies.
lead_paragraph: One woman’s life is spent mostly in slavery. The other woman’s death comes at the guillotine. The stories of Sally Hemings and Marie Antoinette are a little short on cheer.

headline: Why We Live In Unhappy Places
abstract: A recent paper ranks America’s happiest cities — and explains why you don’t live in them.
lead_paragraph: The happiest city in America, at least according to a recent study, is Charlottesville, Va. But that information may not do you much good — the study also found that when we choose where to live, happiness may not matter all that much.

headline: A Squeeze From the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs
abstract: The 64-board final of the Wagar Women’s Knockout Teams was played in Las Vegas on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The 64-board final of the Wagar Women’s Knockout Teams was played here on Thursday. The winners were China Red: Lu Yan, Wang Hongli, Ran Jingrong, Wang Wenfei, Wu Shao Hong and Zhang Yu. They defeated Lynn Baker, Karen McCallum, Kerri Sanborn, Irina Levitina and JoAnna Stansby by fewer than 2 international match points after an appeal was heard after the end of the match. The full story will be in Monday’s column.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Summer Prints
abstract: Summer prints took different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns.
lead_paragraph: Summer prints took two different directions: contemporary blocks of color mimicking unusual buildings and romantic flower patterns suggesting the charm of a picket fence in a cottage garden. A surprising wash of color appeared on a sanitation truck. But the most striking prints echo protruding oriel-like windows or a building’s narrow red-to-yellow column or the Mondrian pattern on a building in Columbus Circle.

headline: Evening Hours | Everyone Outdoors!
abstract: Summer traditions to support the arts and those living with AIDS.
lead_paragraph: Summer traditions to support the arts and those living with AIDS.

headline: No Secret to Creating an Intriguing Cover
abstract: To convey the drama implicit in the spy genre, The Times chose a graphic novelist to illustrate this week’s cover.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover features three books about spying. After Walter Isaacson agreed to review “A Spy Among Friends: Kim Philby and the Great Betrayal” by Ben Macintyre, we decided to hold a slightly earlier review by Mark Mazzetti, of two books on spying, in order to run them together on a spy-themed cover.

headline: Where Snarl Meets Roar
abstract: Neighbors of the East Hampton Airport are complaining about noise, which they say has worsened as private flights increase.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday this summer, or at least when the weather cooperates, a ritual specific to the very wealthy takes place at the East Hampton Airport.

headline: Keeping Secrets in Hollywood
abstract: Whisper and Secret, apps that let you dish dirt while staying anonymous, are rather tame in a city of insiders.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A ripple of dread rolled through Hollywood’s power publicist ranks in February. For the first time since its 2012 debut, the anonymous secret-sharing app Whisper had ensnared an A-list star.

headline: Russia Sues McDonald’s, Questioning Quality of the Food
abstract: Russia’s consumer protection agency alleged that nutritional information had been misrepresented and that contaminated food had been found.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The McDonald’s cheeseburger will have its day in court.

headline: New Approach to Being There: ‘Fan-bots’ Will Cheer Korean Baseball Team
abstract: Cheer on your baseball team through a “fan-bot” set in the stands as you watch and tweet on your phone.
lead_paragraph: Starting with childhood visits to dusk summer softball games in East Greenwich, R.I., and then a couple of memorable trips to Fenway Park, baseball always had a visceral feel for me that was never matched on a television screen.

headline: All Tribalism and Treachery, Dude
abstract: Dwayne Johnson plays the title role in “Hercules,” a piece of tongue-in-cheek revisionist mythology directed by Brett Ratner.
lead_paragraph: No knowledge of antiquity is required to appreciate “Hercules,” which assumes a low base line from the start. “His father was Zeus, the Zeus,” the voice-over explains, in case you were expecting Dr. Zaius.

headline: Voices and Vulnerability
abstract: “The Fluffy Movie” stars Gabriel Iglesias, a comedian who talks about his spoiled son, his estranged father and risqué parenthood techniques.
lead_paragraph: In the origin-myth prologue to “The Fluffy Movie,” a child-size version of the comic Gabriel Iglesias chuckles at “Eddie Murphy Raw,” viewed on a sneaked VHS copy. That may suggest that showboating and shock are in store, but Mr. Iglesias’s style in his first theatrical concert film is grounded in a down-to-earth warmth and a nimble mimicry that bolsters even routine subject matter.

headline: Under Cover: Math Problems
abstract: Andrew B. Myers used simple visuals to illustrate this week’s complicated cover story about the difficulties of teaching math to American students.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Green’s cover story this week about the difficulties of teaching math in American schools was illustrated by Andrew B. Myers, a Brooklyn-based photographer. We went to him, according to Clinton Cargill, a photo editor at the magazine, because he’s ‘‘a strong conceptual thinker, and his pictures have a colorful, playful palette.’’ Recently we put a few questions to Myers about his work.

headline: In Rescue Deal, K.K.R. Provides Financing to Troubled Sand Maker
abstract: The private equity giant will provide $680 million of financing to Preferred Sands, a company that had been on the verge of bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Friday that it would provide $680 million of financing to Preferred Sands, a company that had been on the verge of bankruptcy.

headline: A Vortex of Samba, Funk, Hip-Hop and Vivid Hues
abstract: Rennie Harris Puremovement and street dancers from Brazil brought funk and a dance battle to Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Watching dance at Lincoln Center’s Damrosch Park Bandshell is tricky. While performers look like ants from faraway, if you sit too close, feet have a way of disappearing. Obviously, this is a real hitch. Go for the ants.

headline: Youngsters Who Excel at Robotics and Drollery
abstract: Amazon has posted seven episodes of its new show, “Annedroids,” which targets a preteen audience with its science-based story line.
lead_paragraph: Amazon broke into original children’s programming in May with “Tumble Leaf,” an animated show for preschoolers that was interesting visually but mind-numbing if you weren’t a preschooler. On Friday, the online service posted seven episodes of its first live-action children’s show, “Annedroids,” aimed at slightly older viewers (4 to 9) and explicitly tied to the so-called Steam curriculum (science, technology, engineering, arts, math). And surprise: despite the educational associations and the preteenage target audience, “Annedroids” is entertaining and amusing, a show that won’t drive an adult crazy. It’s almost worth watching without a 4-to-9-year-old for company.

headline: Insurance Coverage for Fertility Treatments Varies Widely
keywords: ['Infertility', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Personal Finances', 'In Vitro Fertilization']
abstract: From 2006 to 2010, 7.4 million women used infertility services, like an evaluation by a specialist, drug therapy or in vitro fertilization.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Patterson, a 27-year-old nurse, suffered four miscarriages over the last four years because of several medical problems, including a condition that causes cysts to form on the ovaries. After her second loss, she said, her husband asked for a divorce because he could not handle the stress.

headline: Fastidious Belgian Detective Bows Out
abstract: “Agatha Christie’s Poirot” is coming to an end, on PBS and online, leaving behind David Suchet’s decades-long portrait of a detective with style.
lead_paragraph: You could almost set your clock by it, if you still had to set a clock. In the final five 90-minute episodes of “Agatha Christie’s Poirot,” the denouement — the long scene in which the dapper Belgian detective Hercule Poirot explains it all to his puzzled audience, including us — arrives reliably somewhere between 22 and 17 minutes from the end. We have reached our destination, intact and on time.

headline: Choosing to Shiver or Not to Shiver
abstract: Two reality series — “Ice Lake Rebels” and “Escaping Alaska” — introduce people with different attitudes toward life near the Arctic.
lead_paragraph: The big brains at Discovery Communications apparently enjoy messing with our heads as we search for vicarious relief from the summer heat. One of their channels, Animal Planet, begins a reality show on Sunday that extols the rugged virtues of life in the remote frozen north. Meanwhile another channel, TLC, serves up a series about young people who want nothing more than to get out of there.

headline: Chevrolet Impala’s Air Bags the Subject of New Safety Inquiry
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Federal safety regulators are looking into complaints that passenger-side air bags did not deploy in crashes involving the 2008 Impala sedan.
lead_paragraph: Federal auto safety regulators, continuing their scrutiny of air bags, have opened an inquiry into the failure of passenger air bags in General Motors’ 2008 Chevrolet Impala sedan.

lead_paragraph: Clapper tells Congress that intelligence agencies hunting for officials who make unauthorized disclosures of classified information will not monitor legislative computer systems.

headline: Fresh Focus on Siberian Permafrost as Hole Count Rises
abstract: A report of a second odd hole in the Siberian permafrost draws fresh attention to the warming Russian tundra.
lead_paragraph: I had a Skype chat Wednesday about Siberian permafrost in the context of climate change with Marina Leibman, a top Russian permafrost expert who had just returned from examining the unusual crater spotted on the Yamal Peninsula in Siberia late last week.

headline: Classic Italian, With Atmosphere
abstract: Barolo Trattoria and Wine Bar, which opened in February in New Canaan with Giuseppe Castellano, who is from Naples, as chef, has an inviting dining space with secluded alcoves.
lead_paragraph: There has been no shortage of Italian restaurants in New Canaan, but Barolo Trattoria and Wine Bar, which opened in February, is a worthy addition.

headline: Under the Tracks, a Kiosk With a Bronx Beat
abstract: An open-air sound booth beneath the elevated Freeman Street station, the Boogie Down Booth, is part of an initiative to reclaim underused public areas.
lead_paragraph: Jazz and mambo flowed along a stretch of the Bronx in the 1940s and for years after. Lined with nightclubs, theaters and catering halls, Southern Boulevard was a musician’s playground.

headline: Watching the River Flow
abstract: Aside from waterfront views, Harvest on Hudson, in Hastings-on-Hudson, offers diners an opportunity to build up their appetites with a pre-dinner stroll through the restaurant’s vegetable and herb gardens.
lead_paragraph: Like the other restaurants operated by the Fort Pond Bay Company — Harvest on Fort Pond and East by Northeast in Montauk, and Half Moon in Dobbs Ferry — Harvest on Hudson, in Hastings-on-Hudson, sits on a waterfront with million-dollar views.

headline: A Syrian Rebel’s Improvised Battery
abstract: A rebel in Syria, Maj. Abu Al-Baraa, seems to have made significant steps toward developing an improved battery that could put many more shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles into use.
lead_paragraph: A rebel in Syria, Maj. Abu Al-Baraa, seems to have made significant steps toward developing an improved battery that could put many more shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles into use.

headline: Bill to Legalize Unlocking Cellphones Passes Congress

abstract: You will no longer be breaking the law if you unlock your cellphone. On Friday, the House of Representatives passed a bill that will make it legal for consumers to open the digital locks on their cellphones so that they can more easily switch wireless carriers. The Senate has already passed the bill.
lead_paragraph: Soon, you will no longer be breaking the law if you unlock your cellphone.

headline: Political Divisions Threaten Kerry-Brokered Agreement in Afghanistan
abstract: The deal that Secretary of State John Kerry reached in Afghanistan two weeks ago appeared in trouble as rival presidential candidates revealed serious differences.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The political agreement between Afghanistan’s two rival presidential candidates brokered by Secretary of State John Kerry two weeks ago appeared in trouble on Friday as serious differences emerged between the camps.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — After an extraordinary outpouring by angry employees, the board of directors of the Market Basket supermarket chain said Friday that it would consider offers to buy the chain, including one from the ousted president, Arthur T. Demoulas.

She wore reading glasses and no makeup, a departure from her nocturnal elegance as a jazz singer. Even from a six-time Grammy nominee, this particular spotlight called for humility.

headline: Solar Industry Is Rebalanced by U.S. Pressure on China
abstract: The Commerce Department on Friday found that Chinese companies had dumped their products on the American market at below cost, and imposed duties of 10.74 percent to 55.49 percent.
lead_paragraph: Even as regulators continue to wrestle with the protracted trade conflict with China over solar panels, the case has already started to reshape the industry, lifting manufacturers based outside China while also raising prices of panels for developers.

headline: Hotel in Manhattan Ordered to Halt Sale of Time Shares After Buyers Complain
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Attorneys General', 'Time-Sharing', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The state attorney general obtained a court order in response to complaints from buyers who say they were misled by the hotel, the Manhattan Club.
lead_paragraph: The state attorney general moved on Friday to stop the sale of time shares in a Midtown Manhattan hotel after buyers complained of being misled and of having trouble reserving rooms they thought they had paid for.

headline: Why the Border Crisis Is a Myth
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Cities are dealing with immigration, even if politicians can’t.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — TO hear the national news media tell the story, you would think my city, El Paso, and others along the Texas-Mexico border were being overrun by children — tens of thousands of them, some with their mothers, arriving from Central America in recent months, exploiting an immigration loophole to avoid deportation and putting a fatal strain on border state resources.

headline: Shootings Redefine Beat of School Police Officers
abstract: Radical shifts in tactics have swept the field — even calling on officers to rush toward shooters without backup.
lead_paragraph: LA QUINTA, Calif. — Once, perhaps unfairly, they fit a Mayberry image. headline: To Save Gaza, Destroy Hamas

The victims were brothers ages 7 and 10 and their 15-year-old sister, who were selling fruit for a church fund-raiser. According to the police, the vehicle struck the siblings as they stood at Allegheny and Germantown Avenues with their 43-year-old mother and a 65-year-old woman, who were in critical condition on Friday. The vehicle’s owner, a 45-year-old woman, was also in critical condition. The suspects had forced her into the back seat of her vehicle at gunpoint before the crash, the police said. The suspects, whom the police described as two armed men in their 20s, fled and remained at large on Friday.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Epix) THE HUNGER GAMES: CATCHING FIRE (2013) A camera-ready Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence, above) and Peeta Mellark (Josh Hutcherson) embark on their victory tour of the Panem districts as the Capitol prepares for the 75th games in this franchise’s second installment, directed by Francis Lawrence from the books by Suzanne Collins. But the champions aren’t safe yet: this new round of games pits past winners against one another in an ultimate death match. Donald Sutherland returns as President Snow, the target in Katniss’s sights; Liam Hemsworth is one of her love interests, Gale Hawthorne; Woody Harrelson is Haymitch Abernathy, the only living Hunger Games victor from District 12; and Elizabeth Banks is Effie Trinket, the tributes’ escort. “ ‘Catching Fire’ isn’t a great work of art but it’s a competent, at times exciting movie and it does something that better, more artistically notable movies often fail to do: It speaks to its moment in time,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Boys (and men) are still boys, of course, including in movies, but the very existence of Katniss — who fights her own battles, and kisses and leaves the boys, only sometimes to save them — suggests cultural consumers are ready for change, even if most cultural producers remain foolishly stuck in the past. It’s unlikely Katniss will lead the real revolution the movies need, but a woman can dream.” The original “Hunger Games” (2012) leads in at 6:30.

abstract: Candidates for the Cooperstown shrine now have 10 years to be voted in by the Baseball Writers’ Association of America.
lead_paragraph: Since 1962, candidates for election to the Baseball Hall of Fame have had 15 years of eligibility, as long as they received at least 5 percent of the vote totals by the Baseball Writers’ Association of America each year. But on Saturday, the Hall changed the process, reducing the period of eligibility to 10 years.

headline: Effort to Secure Malaysia Airline Crash Site Falters in Eastern Ukraine
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Fighting in eastern Ukraine on Saturday prevented Dutch military police officers from securing the site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, while Russian news media stoked conspiracy theories of a secret Dutch military mission.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — An international push to secure the crash site of a Malaysian passenger jet shot down by a missile over eastern Ukraine stalled on Saturday, with the leader of a Dutch forensic mission announcing that scores of foreign police officers and experts gathered at a luxury hotel here would not start moving toward the site for at least five days.

headline: 1964: Hong Kong, A Tourist Paradise
abstract: The New York Herald Tribune explores tourist spots in Hong Kong in 1964.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The wealthy British Crown colony of Hong Kong, checkered with emerald hills, sky-blue bays, and modern architecture, is a tropical tourists’ paradise of sunning, swimming, and spending.

headline: Amid Outcry Abroad, a Wealth of Backing in Israel for Netanyahu
abstract: Facing growing international outcry over the ground assault in Gaza, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has found support from Israel’s politicians and people.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is stuck between mounting international outcry over civilian casualties from his assault on the Gaza Strip and intensifying calls at home to finish the job he started.

headline: Women as Athletes, Not Accessories, at Least for a Day
keywords: ['Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Women and Girls', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: La Course by le Tour de France, a women’s race around Paris set for Sunday, is a triumph for those who would like women to be more than hostesses at cycling’s premier event.
lead_paragraph: Female cyclists will race at the Tour de France on Sunday for the first time in 25 years, but anyone who thinks women haven’t been key participants in the sport’s top race obviously hasn’t been watching.

headline: Budding Author and Inventor Emerges Quickly in Giants’ Backfield
abstract: Running back Andre Williams, whose career goals extend beyond football, has assumed a prominent role in the opening week of training camp.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The rookie running back Andre Williams arrived at the Giants’ training camp with a reputation for a bruising rushing style and a workhorse mentality.

headline: Royals Approach Their Destiny in Fits and Starts
abstract: The Kansas City Royals have gone longer without making the playoffs than any team in Major League Baseball, the N.F.L., the N.B.A. or the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Royals had one winning record in a stretch of 18 seasons, from 1995 to 2012. It came in 2003, when they were 83-79, and Raul Ibanez was their regular left fielder. Now, after his release from the Los Angeles Angels, he is back as a reserve.

headline: Revered Essays on the Game Lead to a Hall of Fame Honor
abstract: Roger Angell, a longtime writer for The New Yorker, received the J. G. Taylor Spink Award, the Baseball Hall of Fame’s writing honor.
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — In 1980, Roger Angell wrote a revealing portrait of Bob Gibson that is one of his most admired baseball articles for The New Yorker. Gibson was in his fifth season of retirement, and Angell thought that people might have begun to forget what a fierce and marvelous pitcher, and competitor, he was. Angell believes Gibson opened up to him to help his chances at being elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame, which happened in his first year of eligibility.

headline: Bound by Bridge, 2 Baghdad Enclaves Drift Far Apart
abstract: Sunni Adhamiya and the Shiite Kadhimiya, linked by the Al Imams Bridge and once inextricably joined in the imagination of Baghdad residents, are drifting further and further apart.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Al Imams Bridge spans the Tigris River between two of the oldest communities in Baghdad — one Sunni, the other Shiite — and on Ramadan evenings it can seem as if the mosques near either bank are calling to each other as their muezzins sing prayers.

headline: Moore of the Same
abstract: Doesn’t anyone at Heritage know how to play this game? Actually, no.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago the buzz was that the Heritage Foundation was getting serious after a series of blatant errors and ludicrously biased “research”. The supposed evidence for this turn was the hiring of Stephen Moore from the Wall Street Journal to become chief economist. I was, shall we say, unimpressed.

headline: As Technology Makes Bicycles Lighter and Faster, It’s the Cyclists Falling Harder
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Sports Injuries', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Cycling, Road']
abstract: The strength, lightness and design flexibility offered by carbon fiber have ensured its dominance at the Tour de France.
lead_paragraph: PÉRIGUEUX, France — In terms of technology, Greg LeMond, the three-time Tour de France winner, was a pioneer. In an age when steel still dominated, LeMond rode bikes made of carbon-fiber composites, then an exotic material mostly used by the military.

headline: Why the Beach Is a Bummer
abstract: Sand? Sunbathing? Swimsuits? Overrated.
lead_paragraph: IT is summer, and so, we are repeatedly reminded, it is time for the beach — beach bodies, beach reads, fruity beach drinks in tall glasses festooned with tiny paper umbrellas and fruits skewered on tiny plastic swords. This is an ideal beach of hot sun, warm sand, crystal-clear water that leaves your skin salted. But it is all too often a mirage.

headline: In Labor, in Chains
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Many states forbid the shackling of pregnant inmates. But the laws are often disregarded.
lead_paragraph: EARLY one morning in November 2011, Tina Tinen, a pregnant prisoner at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Westchester County, N.Y., woke with painful contractions. Guards called an ambulance to take her to the hospital and, according to her account, shackled her wrist to the bar of a gurney — despite a 2009 state law against shackling pregnant inmates during and after labor.

headline: Up From Greenwich
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2008']
abstract: Can the G.O.P. stop being the party of the rich?
lead_paragraph: WHEN Barack Obama won the White House in 2008, he did so in an unusual way for a Democrat: As the candidate of the rich. He raised more in large-dollar donations than any of his rivals and raked in more cash from Wall Street than John McCain. In November, he won the upper class’s votes: By 52 percent to 46 percent, according to exit polls, Americans making more than $200,000 cast their ballots for Obama.

headline: The Wrong Approach to Breast Cancer
abstract: A double mastectomy will not significantly extend life.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — ONE of the nastier aspects of breast cancer is that it doesn’t have the five-year sell-by date of some other malignancies: you’re not considered “cured” until you die of something else. Although it becomes less likely, the disease can come back eight, 10, even 20 years after treatment. I fell on the wrong side of those odds.

headline: When Thrill Rides Are Real Risks
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Roller Coasters', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: No one knows for certain whether amusement park rides are getting safer or more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, nearly two dozen people were stranded midair for hours after a fallen tree branch partly derailed a roller-coaster ride at the Six Flags Magic Mountain amusement park in Valencia, Calif. Last summer, a woman was killed at Six Flags Over Texas in Arlington after she fell out of the Texas Giant roller coaster. That same day, a boat on Cedar Point’s Shoot the Rapids water ride in Sandusky, Ohio rolled backward and flipped over injuring at least six people.

headline: Angell in the Outfield
abstract: From Babe to Jeter, Roger Angell has taken his readers out to the old ballgame.
lead_paragraph: ROGER ANGELL takes off his brown J. Press sports coat and blue cap, yanks out his hearing aids, stashes his cane, and sits down for a shave and haircut at Delta barbershop at 72nd and Lex., the same spot he’s patronized for 40 years. “I don’t see Henry Kissinger doing any interviews in a barbershop,” he says dryly.

headline: Andres Amador
abstract: A sand artist who lives in a straw bale yurt and uses a drone to photograph his artwork.
lead_paragraph: Andres Amador is an artist who uses the beach as his canvas and a rake as his brush. His sand designs have been commissioned for corporate advertisements as well as countless marriage proposals.

headline: The New Instability
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Income Inequality', 'Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Marriages', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Men and Boys', 'Income', 'Minimum Wage', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The rules of marriage have changed, for rich and poor.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past 40 years, the geography of family life has been destabilized by two powerful forces pulling in opposite directions and occasionally scraping against each other, much like tectonic plates. One is the striking progress toward equality between men and women. The other is the equally striking growth of socioeconomic inequality and insecurity.

headline: Where Reason Ends and Faith Begins
abstract: In the face of uncertainty, being precise about what you don’t believe in can shore up your confidence in what you do.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — NOT long ago, I was at an event in which many people, most of them professors, were arguing for the existence of things that many of their colleagues did not believe in. Someone gave a talk in which he explained that he knew that U.F.O.s existed even though all the best evidence for them turned out to be false. Others spoke sympathetically about shamanic healing, reincarnation and near-death visions. But then a woman described her research on what it was like to be dead, which she had based on reports from mediums who claimed to have had the dead speak through them. She cited, as evidence of the benevolence in the afterlife, an Anglican priest, Msgr. Robert Hugh Benson, who wrote a book attacking spiritualism while alive but who, she said, recanted the book after his death in 1914. The group stared at her in disbelief. This, they felt, was flabby-minded.

headline: The World’s Coolest Places
abstract: Looking for a summer escape? Here are some suggestions for adventure way beyond a scintillating beach read.
lead_paragraph: TRAVEL season is here, when so many Americans decamp to Cape Cod or the Jersey Shore. All of which is wonderful, and some day I plan to do a 10-part series on the world’s best beaches.

headline: Jets Add Tight End With Insights
abstract: The Jets are hoping that Jace Amaro, a big tight end drafted No. 49 over all, will blossom into a pass catcher able to cause matchup problems like Jimmy Graham or Rob Gronkowski.
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — Jace Amaro has received a text message from his father, Bob, every morning for the last several years. The Good Words of the Day, Bob calls it. Sometimes it contains a Bible verse, sometimes an inspirational quotation from someone like Winston Churchill or Muhammad Ali.

headline: A Carter for Governor, Again
abstract: President Jimmy Carter’s grandson, State Senator Jason Carter, is following in his grandfather’s footsteps by running for governor of Georgia. But his family name is a blessing and curse there.
lead_paragraph: President Jimmy Carter’s grandson, State Senator Jason Carter, is following in his grandfather’s footsteps by running for governor of Georgia. But his family name is a blessing and curse there.

headline: Grandson Proudly Squirms in Carter’s Footsteps
abstract: As Georgia's Democratic nominee for governor, Jason Carter has distanced himself from many beliefs of his grandfather, former President Jimmy Carter.
lead_paragraph: PLAINS, Ga. — Like many candidates, Jason Carter, the Democratic nominee for governor in Georgia, is courting the Jewish vote. But when Mr. Carter, a state senator, declared his “powerful connection” to Israel, it was more than a campaign sound bite.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 27
abstract: A brief cease-fire in Gaza and a stalled investigation of the downed Malaysian flight will dominate the Sunday shows conversation.
lead_paragraph: A cease-fire on Saturday between Israel and Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza, allowed families to take stock of the damage of intense violence in the Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will discuss the pause in fighting on “Fox News Sunday” and NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Sought in Vegas, a Swindler Is Dealt a Losing Hand Far From Home
abstract: Jubreal Chahine was no stranger to Las Vegas casino floor managers, who had busted him several times for his old-fashioned cheating moves. But then he went underground and resurfaced in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, PA. — He could have browsed the volumes at the Moravian Book Shop, or dined al fresco at the historic Hotel Bethlehem. But the out-of-towner was looking to take a chance, so he headed instead to the Sands Casino, a glittery, jittery place rising from the old Bethlehem Steel stacks along the Lehigh River.

headline: Nibali Goes Into Finale With Time on His Side
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Cycling, Road', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Tony Martin won Saturday’s time trial as Vincenzo Nibali virtually clinched the overall victory in the Tour de France.
lead_paragraph: PÉRIGUEUX, France — Vincenzo Nibali, who had won four stages of this year’s Tour de France, did not add its first and last time trial to his list on Saturday. The win went to Tony Martin, a German who is the current world champion in racing against the clock.

headline: Echoes of Past Battles on Immigration Ring Through Current Debate
abstract: More than 30 years after the Mariel boatlift, the current fight over how to handle the tens of thousands of migrants from Central America has resurfaced political fault lines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Up in arms about being forced to provide emergency housing for a flood of immigrants entering the country illegally, voters turned to the ballot box to punish elected officials they faulted for failing to resolve the crisis. The backlash was swift, costing Bill Clinton his 1980 bid for a second term as Arkansas governor in the aftermath of the boatlift from Mariel, Cuba.

headline: Martin R. Hoffmann, Army Secretary in 1970s, Dies at 82

lead_paragraph: Martin R. Hoffmann, a former secretary of the Army who in the 1970s presided during a cheating scandal at West Point and helped usher in the all-volunteer Army, died on July 14 at a hospital in Warrenton, Va. He was 82.

headline: Augie Rodriguez, 86, Half of a Mambo Team, Dies
abstract: Mr. Rodriguez and his wife, Margo, were often accompanied by renowned bandleaders like Xavier Cugat.
lead_paragraph: Augie Rodriguez, half of Augie and Margo, the husband-and-wife team who at midcentury helped turn mambo from a sultry social dance into a dazzling public entertainment, died on July 18 in Deerfield Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Carlo Bergonzi, 90, an Operatic Tenor of Subtlety and Emotional Acuity, Dies
abstract: Mr. Bergonzi, small and admittedly without leading-man looks or acting skills, was considered to have a vocal elegance that more than compensated for perceived shortcomings.
lead_paragraph: Carlo Bergonzi, one of the 20th century’s most distinguished operatic tenors, renowned for the refined interpretive taste and keen musical intelligence he brought to his art, died on Friday in Milan. He was 90.

headline: Yankees’ Defensive Lapses Help Blue Jays End 17-Game Bronx Skid
abstract: The Blue Jays scored the go-ahead run in the seventh inning after shaky plays by Brian McCann, substituting for the injured Mark Teixeira at first, and second baseman Brian Roberts.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have been able to survive a glut of injuries largely by shifting players around the field, often to unfamiliar positions. When Mark Teixeira strained a back muscle early last week, Manager Joe Girardi put catcher Brian McCann at first base even though he had never played the position in his professional career before this season. Entering the year, McCann had not played first in a game since a travel team tournament in high school.

headline: Comic-Con 2014: Disney’s ‘Phineas and Ferb’ to Broadcast Tribute to ABC’s ‘Lost’
abstract: “Lost in Danville,” as the special is titled, will air in the fall and revolve around a mysterious locked capsule that suddenly appears in Phineas and Ferb’s backyard.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO – Calling all “Lost” fans: Damon Lindelof, one of the creative forces behind that late, great ABC castaways drama, has written a special “Lost”-themed episode of the Disney Channel’s animated “Phineas and Ferb.”

headline: Let States Decide on Marijuana
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'States (US)', 'Editorials', 'Series', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s time for the federal government to step aside.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, at the height of his white-hot war on crime, President Richard Nixon demanded that Congress pass the Controlled Substances Act to crack down on drug abuse. During the debate, Senator Thomas Dodd of Connecticut held up a package wrapped in light-green paper that he said contained $3,000 worth of marijuana. This substance, he said, caused such “dreadful hallucinations” in an Army sergeant in Vietnam that he called down a mortar strike on his own troops. A few minutes later, the Senate unanimously passed the bill.

headline: The Public Lightens Up About Weed
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Editorials', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Americans have moved to a decidedly libertarian stance on marijuana, and younger people are left wondering why anyone ever made such a fuss about it.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Clinton ran for president in 1992, he admitted that he had “experimented with marijuana,” but said he “didn’t like it,” “didn’t inhale it” and “never tried it again.” Whatever the accuracy of that statement, he was accused of pandering to the marijuana-wary voting public.

lead_paragraph: “Boyhood,” the film shot over 12 years with the same actors, which opened recently in Texas, begins in what the director, Richard Linklater, describes as a “mythical little childhood home that you dream about the rest of your life.”

lead_paragraph: ROME — The body of Yara Gambirasio, a 13-year-old student, was found on a chilly day in a quiet northern city in Lombardy in February 2011, three months after she was reported missing following a gymnastics practice. abstract: The Yankees have lost two aces this season, but additions like Chris Capuano and Brandon McCarthy have preserved their chances of making the postseason.

Chris Capuano became their 28th pitcher this season when he started against Toronto in the Bronx. The Yankees have never sent more pitchers to the mound in one season, but they have landed on 28 three other times: in 2005, 2007 and 2011.

headline: Blinkers Help a Colt Surge at Saratoga After Earlier Flops
abstract: Wicked Strong, who faded in the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes, charged to a win in the Jim Dandy Stakes.

headline: Sticks and Stones, and a Diagnosis in Words That Can’t Hurt Us
abstract: A diagnosis, of autism or anything else, won’t make me mourn my daughter, who is different, not dying.
lead_paragraph: To reach my eldest daughter at her elementary school, we have to walk down our street, turn on what Google Maps refers to as “Unknown Road,” cross a bridge over a shallow stream and follow an asphalt path around to the bright red doors of the school. All in all, it’s a seven-minute walk, but with my 3-year-old in tow it can take twice the time.

headline: 1914: German Emperor Backed Austria
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany is backing her ally in 1914.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — All Austrian reservists living in Germany have been summoned to join the colors from today [July 27], and all leave of German officers and soldiers has been stopped. According to a despatch from Vienna, one of the highest personages in Germany — whom, I learn, is none other than the Emperor — is said to have written personally to Herr von Tschirschky und Bogendorff, the German Ambassador in Vienna, telling him to stiffen the back of Count Berchtold, who at that time was all for conciliation with Servia. The result was that the Austro-Hungarian Foreign Minister entirely changed his attitude and prepared the drastic ultimatum to Belgrade.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (WGN America) MANH(A)TTAN John Benjamin Hickey and Ashley Zukerman portray the scientists at the center of the race to create an atomic bomb, and Olivia Williams (above, with Mr. Hickey) and Rachel Brosnahan are their smarty-pants wives, in this fictionalized but fact-based accounting set in Los Alamos, N.M., “766 days before Hiroshima,” as the show puts it. “The atom bomb didn’t just end the war, it forever changed the peace,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “Richard Rhodes, the author of ‘The Making of the Atom Bomb,’ quotes Herbert S. Marks, general counsel of the Atomic Energy Commission, who said the Manhattan Project was a state unto itself that had ‘a peculiar sovereignty, one that could bring about the end, peacefully or violently, of all other sovereignties.’ ‘Manh(a)ttan’ provides a cleverly imagined portrait of the men and women who were at the epicenter of that peculiar sovereignty.”

headline: What ‘The Leftovers’ Says About Climate Change
abstract: The way the characters respond to the disappearance of 2 percent of humanity has some parallels with the way some see global warming.
lead_paragraph: The new HBO series “The Leftovers” is about what happens after 2 percent of humanity simply vanishes from the earth (this is not really a spoiler; however, some follow). This event has obvious religious connotations, which the show explores. But the story may have secular implications, too: The way the characters reckon with their new, bizarre circumstances has something in common with how some are responding to the threat of climate change.

headline: In Coney Island, Weaving a Confection That Tastes Like Long-Ago Summers
abstract: Jenny Villon, a 30-year-old mother of three who emigrated from Mexico as a teenager, has been making cotton candy for nearly a decade in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Every New Yorker has a favorite summertime treat. As a girl, mine was cotton candy, that wondrous melt-in-your-mouth confection that vanishes when it touches your tongue. For me, it still brings to mind bumper cars and roller coaster rides, street festivals and jelly-sandaled strolls.

headline: Your Own Choices for Coolest Places on Earth

I’m sure some of you disagree with my choices, so post your thoughts below—and include your own recommendations for off-the-beaten path choices for others to take up.

lead_paragraph: Scarlett Johansson punched out “Hercules” at the weekend box office. Her new science-fiction thriller, “Lucy,” was No. 1 at North American movie theaters, taking in an estimated $44 million and proving that her name on the marquee (and pouty picture on the poster) could anchor a wide-release movie. “Lucy,” which Universal Pictures marketed squarely on Ms. Johansson’s shoulders, cost about $40 million to make and was directed by Luc Besson. The film performed particularly well in theaters with screens marketed as Premium Large Format, which charge higher prices.

headline: 1939: Britain Set to Deport all Suspects in I.R.A. Blasts
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain plans mass deportations of I.R.A suspects in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the sequel to yesterday’s fatal bomb explosions staged by Irish terrorists at two London railroad stations, the British government was reported tonight [July 27] to be planning mass deportations during the week end of hundreds of suspected members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. It was understood that a warship would be sent on Saturday to Fishguard or Holyhead, the two principal Welsh ports on the Irish Sea, to await batches of Irish men, and women, who will be rounded up for expulsion as soon as the government obtains its unprecedented police powers of search and arrest under the prevention of violence bill, drafted specifically to smash the I.R.A. The measure, rushed through the House of Commons in record time last night, was given a hasty first reading by the House of Lords today. Earl Stanhope, First Lord of the Admiralty and leader of the Upper House, said the government wanted the bill passed by the Peers tomorrow, rather than wait until Monday. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 28, 1939

headline: At Front Lines, Bearing Witness in Real Time
abstract: We used to witness war in the rearview mirror. But journalists often now deliver what they see via Twitter, before consulting with headquarters, and it has made for more visceral reporting.
lead_paragraph: My social media feed has taken a bloody turn in the last few weeks, and I’m hardly alone. Along with the usual Twitter wisecracking and comments on incremental news, I have seen bodies scattered across fields and hospitals in Ukraine and Gaza. I have read posts from reporters who felt threatened, horrified and revolted.

headline: After Losing Province in 2010, Afghan Taliban Strike Back
abstract: Heavy fighting has returned to Kandahar Province, on the Pakistani border, which was a militant stronghold until the 2010 American troop surge.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A sudden Taliban offensive in the southern province of Kandahar in recent days has led to some of the heaviest protracted fighting there in years, officials said on Sunday. The militants overran a district center on the border with Pakistan, battled government forces near the provincial capital and staged a suicide-bomber attack on a home of the province’s powerful security chief.

headline: Rough Ride for the F-35
keywords: ['F-35 Airplane', 'Editorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense Contracts', 'Military Aircraft', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A $400 billion next-generation fighter plane has multiple problems. Congress isn’t listening.
lead_paragraph: The F-35 fighter jet was expected to be exhibited at an international air show a few weeks ago — a chance for America to showcase its state-of-the-art war plane, the world’s most expensive weapons project. But, in an embarrassing turn of events, the star-crossed, single-engine F-35 was a no-show.

headline: Legacy Tarnished by His Own Words
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Watergate Affair', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “The Nixon Defense,” by John W. Dean, Richard M. Nixon’s counsel during the Watergate scandal, is a day-by-day account of the president’s cover-up.
lead_paragraph: A Gallup poll in 2010 assessing the nine presidents from John F. Kennedy to George W. Bush put Richard M. Nixon last with a 29 percent approval rating. In a Quinnipiac University survey at the beginning of July, however, Barack Obama had replaced Nixon as the worst president since World War II: 33 percent assigned that unwanted distinction to President Obama; only 13 percent thought Nixon was that bad.

headline: Chasing a Chivalrous Bandit
abstract: In “Kick,” a cop follows a thief to Warsaw where comedy, romance and action intersect.
lead_paragraph: The Hindi movie “Kick” takes pains to assure us that Devi Lal Singh, its antihero hero, is “amazing” and has “impeccable charisma.” Good to know. Otherwise you might think that Devi (Salman Khan), who shakes things up for the fun of it — to feel a “kick” — was another bad-boy narcissist who can’t grow up or keep a job.

headline: Winning Ways at the Spingold Knockout Teams

headline: Amid the Destruction, Aftershocks of an Emotional Magnitude
abstract: “Fallen City,” on POV,” is a documentary that follows three Chinese families as they deal with the emotional and logistical aftershocks of the 2008 Sichuan earthquake.
lead_paragraph: During the three years Qi Zhao spent filming “Fallen City,” he captured his subject — the town of Beichuan, wiped out in the 2008 Sichuan earthquake, two-thirds of its people killed and 80 percent of its buildings destroyed — as it slowly disappeared. In time-lapse images, fields of rubble become fields of grass. Part of the old city is turned into an earthquake museum, with railings installed in front of piles of shattered concrete.

headline: Steal by Bautista Helps Blue Jays Overcome Three Yankees Rallies
abstract: The Yankees came back to tie the score at 2-2, 3-3 and 4-4, but in the ninth, they allowed Jose Bautista to steal second, and he soon scored the decisive run.
lead_paragraph: In the race for the playoffs, even a seemingly inconsequential mistake can be the difference between a postseason appearance and a lost season. Should the Yankees narrowly miss a berth this season, closer David Robertson might regret ignoring Jose Bautista at first base in the ninth inning of Sunday’s 5-4 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

headline: An Intricate Combination of Music and Movement
abstract: Pam Tanowitz’s witty choreography enhances complex duets, complemented by an energetic score, and ranks with the most vivifying work of recent years.
lead_paragraph: Catching the entire performance of Pam Tanowitz Dance at Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Friday took more than the usual effort. After listening to a smart, vibrant set of contemporary music by the sextet Eighth Blackbird in the Damrosch Park Bandshell, I hurried to the opposite end of the plaza to watch the unannounced beginning of Ms. Tanowitz’s contribution. There, engrossed by the dancer Lindsey Jones’s rendering of Ms. Tanowitz’s witty steps, I nearly failed to rush back to my seat in time for the main portion of the show.

headline: Sloshing in Symphonic Waters
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival', 'Mostly Mozart Festival', 'Music']

lead_paragraph: The 81 musicians and singers who were about to give the premiere of “Sila: The Breath of the World,” an alluring, mystical new work by the American composer John Luther Adams conceived for performance outdoors in Lincoln Center’s Hearst Plaza, began to take their assigned places early on Friday evening. It was quite a procession.

headline: Melodrama, as in Mellow
abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet, wrapping up its Lincoln Center Festival season, presented Yuri Grigorovich’s signature 1968 production of “Spartacus.”
lead_paragraph: How much good and evil can you take in a night? Watching “Spartacus,” Yuri Grigorovich’s ponderous three-act ballet, is a like being trapped inside a pinball machine and bounced among four protagonists. One team features the noble, valiant Spartacus and the innocently virtuous Phrygia. On the other are the sadistic Crassus and the conniving Aegina.

headline: In Every Note, Passion That Needs No Translation
abstract: Mahmoud Ahmed, the 73-year-old singer who helped introduce Ethiopian pop to a wider world in the 1970s, performed in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: It’s the quaver that makes the Ethiopian singer Mahmoud Ahmed’s voice so arresting. He seizes on a note, brief or sustained, and makes its pitch tremble as if its urgency could barely be contained. It’s a show of controlled intensity, and in the course of a song, it happens again and again, making each phrase leap out anew: with sorrow, with anticipation, with a plea. That quaver is coupled with emphatic rhythm and grainy determination in a voice that Ethiopians in and out of the country have prized since the 1970s. Mr. Ahmed’s 1975 album, “Ere Mela Mela,” helped introduce Ethiopian pop to a wider world, and in the 1990s, reissues of his recordings as part of Buda Musique’s “Ethiopiques” series brought him further international attention.

headline: Chocolate Factory Announces Season
abstract: The theater in Queens will feature nine commissioned United States premieres and two first-time collaborations with other New York City arts institutions in its new season.
lead_paragraph: The Chocolate Factory Theater in Long Island City, Queens, will feature nine commissioned United States premieres and two first-time collaborations with other New York City arts institutions in its 2014-15 season, the theater’s organizers have announced. The performances are to begin with Marissa Perel’s return to the Chocolate Factory for the first time since the theater’s debut season in 2005. She will present “More Than Just a Piece of Sky,” a work based on the 1983 movie “Yentl” starring Barbra Streisand. The performances, Sept. 17 through 20, also represents the theater’s first partnership with the annual Queer New York International Arts Festival. Other season highlights include “Rude World,” a duet choreographed and performed by Molly Lieber and Eleanor Smith, in January as part of the Coil festival. And in April, the Chocolate Factory will team up with Abrons Arts Center to present the Bessie award winner David Neumann’s “I Understand Everything Better,” a multidisciplinary work exploring the need to report on calamity and the results of a person’s proximity to death and trauma. Brian Rogers, the artistic director of the Chocolate Factory, said he hoped that a smaller schedule would better allow the theater to serve its artists. “This is our small attempt to value the work of the performers in a different way,” Mr. Rogers said recently by phone. More information is at chocolatefactory.org.

headline: New Cast Members for ‘Game of Thrones’

lead_paragraph: With the population of Westeros dwindling, HBO has announced that a crop of new characters will enter the fold in Season 5 of its hit drama “Game of Thrones.” The stage and screen veteran Jonathan Pryce and Keisha Castle-Hughes, a best actress Oscar nominee for the 2003 film “Whale Rider,” are among nine new cast members set to join “Thrones” in 2015. While Season 4 brought the demise of several main characters, the coming season will try to fill the void with the Martells of Dorne. Most of the new characters are relatives or associates of Oberyn Martell (Pedro Pascal), the playboy prince who met a particularly gruesome death while fighting on behalf of Tyrion Lannister (Peter Dinklage). Ms. Castle-Hughes is to portray Oberyn’s eldest bastard daughter, Obara Sand. She is to be joined by Alexander Siddig (“Star Trek: Deep Space Nine,” “Da Vinci’s Demons”) as Doran Martell, the ruler of Dorne and older brother of Oberyn, and Toby Sebastian as Doran’s son Trystane. New additions not of the Martell bloodline are to include Mr. Pryce as High Sparrow, a prominent figure in a religious order; Nell Tiger Free, who replaces Aimee Richardson as Myrcella Baratheon; and DeObia Oparei as Areo Hotah, captain of Doran’s guards. The series is expected to return in the spring.

headline: Privacy and the Pool of Information
abstract: If nothing bad that we know about has happened as a result of the N.S.A.’s “incidental collection” of data of ordinary Americans, what’s the problem?
lead_paragraph: It’s been a while since we all became aware of what the National Security Administration has been up to. But as revelations of government breaches recede and the concerns of daily life resume, the public occasionally needs a reminder. A recent story in The Washington Post was exactly that. It laid out in detail what many had long suspected: that the N.S.A., in targeting foreign nationals, is collecting and storing extremely large amounts of information on many American citizens. This information is not restricted to metadata; it is content — photos, web chats, emails and the like. While United States law prevents targeting American citizens without a warrant (even if it is just a warrant from the secret FISA court) nothing currently prevents the N.S.A. from engaging in this “incidental collection” and no law prevents the agency — and other United States intelligence and law enforcement agencies — from accessing such content without a warrant into perpetuity.

Established in Shanghai in 2002, Spin carries a range of bespoke ceramic tableware designs (from $11 ebony chopsticks to a one-of-a-kind $3,200 vase) using traditional, handmade techniques from Jingdezhen, the capital of Chinese porcelain since the Ming Dynasty.

lead_paragraph: 8:15 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE QUIET AMERICAN (2002) Michael Caine in an Oscar-nominated role, stars as Thomas Fowler, a British journalist who flees a loveless marriage in England to live in Southeast Asia and report on the Vietnamese fight for independence from French colonial rule. There, he becomes infatuated with Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen, above, with Mr. Caine) in a relationship that can last only as long as he keeps his job. Then Alden Pyle (Brendan Fraser), an American intelligence officer, comes along. And he wants Phuong, too. “Fowler may be the richest character of Mr. Caine’s screen career,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about Phillip Noyce’s adaptation of the Graham Greene novel. “This great English actor gives a performance of astonishing understatement whose tone wavers delicately between irony and sadness.”

headline: Daily Report: Reddit Looks to Grow Up Without Selling Out
abstract: Efforts by the freewheeling online community to monetize without driving away its 114 million monthly users will require appealing to advertisers without sacrificing values like personal data privacy.
lead_paragraph: Since it was founded nine years ago, Reddit — a freewheeling online community with an antiquated design where users find, share and talk about web links and photos — has stuck to its own weird guns. You don’t need to hand over any personal data, not even an email address, to sign up and post or view an item. And unlike many other Internet start-ups, Mike Isaac reports, Reddit has never fully embraced the dominant business model of selling advertising to support its free service.
