headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on a surveillance bill, university affirmative action in Texas, a buffer-zone revision and threatened honeybees.
lead_paragraph: “The Senate is about to begin debate on a bill that could, at long last, put an end to the indiscriminate bulk collection of Americans’ telephone records,” according to an editorial in The New York Times. The bill will “bring needed transparency to the abusive spying programs that have tarnished the nation’s reputation.” Introduced by Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, the measure would require the government “to disclose how many people’s data was collected by intelligence agencies, and how many of those people were American.” Perhaps most important, the bill will “create a panel of advocates to argue before the court in support of privacy rights and civil liberties, and would require the court to issue public summaries of its decisions that specifically detail the impact on those rights.” It “represents a breakthrough in the struggle against the growth of government surveillance power.”

headline: The Problem With 'Pay for Performance' in Medicine
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The idea is intuitively appealing: Reward doctors for positive outcomes, not per procedure. But it doesn't seem to work as well as hoped.
lead_paragraph: “Pay for performance” is one of those slogans that seem to upset no one. To most people it’s a no-brainer that we should pay for quality and not quantity. We all know that paying doctors based on the amount of care they provide, as we do with a traditional fee-for-service setup, creates incentives for them to give more care. It leads to increased health care spending. Changing the payment structure to pay them for achieving goals instead should reduce wasteful spending.

headline: The Lessons Thus Far From the Transition to Digital Patient Records
abstract: The use of digital patient records has not led to overbilling, as feared, according to a new report — but it has not yet delivered efficiency gains or improved care, either.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the financial crisis hit, the Obama administration decided to toss into the economic stimulus package a carrot to accelerate the computerization of health care. Within the roughly $800 billion pump-priming project, the health technology initiative could be seen as a modest down payment on the future: about $20 billion in incentives spread over several years to encourage doctors and hospitals to move from paper records into the computer age. The Bush administration had championed the cause, and, seizing a crisis-created opportunity, the Obama administration put up the money.

headline: Roasted Corn and Tomato Salsa
abstract: Grilling tomatoes, jalapeños and corn makes for a nice mix of flavors. The sweetness of the corn contrasts well with the charred and picante flavors of the salsa.
lead_paragraph: I’ve added corn to salsa fresca before, but this time, eyeing generous ears of corn on the cob in the market, I imagined it grilled or roasted in a roasted tomato salsa. I used as a starting point the renowned chef Rick Bayless’s terrific roasted jalapeño tomato salsa with fresh cilantro, from a book he published in 1998 called “Salsas That Cook.” After I had grilled the tomatoes and jalapeño under a broiler (you could also cook them on a grill), I grilled an ear of corn, also under a broiler. The kernels take on a beautiful color, and their sweetness contrasts nicely with the charred and picante flavors that run through this salsa. The corn also contributes crunch. The salsa is great with tacos, chips, and grains, and is particularly good with chicken.

headline: For Kangaroos, Tail Becomes a Fifth Leg

lead_paragraph: The signature gait of kangaroos is a marvel. As they hop, they seem to float along almost effortlessly on their large, springy hind feet, tail stretched out behind for balance.

headline: Salsa Fresca with Kohlrabi
abstract: Kohlrabi, with its crisp texture, is a pleasant surprise diced into this tomato salsa. It goes well with chips, nachos, tacos and quesadillas, or with fish and chicken.
lead_paragraph: For the past month, I’ve been a guest on the New York Times’s Motherlode Blog, helping out Renee Ruder and her family in Bend, Ore., put more vegetarian meals on the table using produce they receive in their community-supported agriculture basket each week. She received kohlrabi one week and was at a loss as to what to do with it. I had some suggestions for ways to use the vegetable in main dishes, and now I’ve come up with a way to use it in a side. The kohlrabi has a crisp texture much like that of jicama, with a nice cruciferous flavor. This salsa fresca would be welcome with just about any tostada, nacho or taco, with chips, or as a condiment with fish or chicken.

headline: Grilled Mango Salsa
abstract: A mango’s rich flavor is deepened through grilling in this salsa full of contrasts. It also works if you do not want to grill the mango.
lead_paragraph: I love mango salsa whether or not the mango is grilled, so if you don’t feel like grilling, you can still get a great salsa with these ingredients. Grilling, whether on an outdoor grill, a griddle or a grill pan, deepens the flavor of an already-rich-tasting fruit. I love the contrasts in this salsa: the crisp jicama with the soft, juicy mango; the sweet fruit; the spicy chile; and the grassy cilantro. Serve with fish or chicken.

headline: Pineapple Avocado Salsa

lead_paragraph: This is a sweet, fruity salsa, with a wonderful array of textures: juicy, sweet-acidic pineapple; soft, creamy and subtle avocado; and crisp and refreshing jicama, with everything set off by the heat of the chiles. The avocado gives a pale green cast to the mix. It looks beautiful with salmon and goes with just about any other fish, as well as with chicken or even fajitas.

headline: Jonathan Chait and Cherry-Picking

headline: Masterworks vs. the Masses

headline: Just as Dangerous as We Think
abstract: “The Norm Chronicles: Stories and Numbers About Danger and Death” is a kinetic trip through the percentages of risk and the primacy of perceptions.
lead_paragraph: If the British comedy troupe Monty Python had been commissioned to produce a self-help book, they might have come up with something along the lines of “The Norm Chronicles,” a cheerfully subversive variation on the genre. The authors contemplate not inner peace but outer woe with an encyclopedic guide to life’s risks, among them health care catastrophes, sexually transmitted diseases, auto accidents, plane crashes, mountaineering fatalities, sudden unemployment and the chances that an asteroid will fall from the sky and squash you.

headline: 4 Years Later, Still No Answers in Killing of a Long Island Laborer
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hate Crimes']

Beer flowed. So did tequila. By the following afternoon, one of the men was dead, his body lying in the woods. headline: The ‘Battle Rhythm’ of Helping to Build a Democracy

Blackhawks, flying out of the Kabul night, the gunner hanging out the side, scanning the city from behind the sights of an M-240B automatic rifle. The blades thunder their rhythm throughout the compound, too loud to talk over. They land quickly, spill out their passengers and a few bags, and leave. This isn’t the place to linger.

headline: Introducing Sway Clarke II, R&B Hitmaker With a Canadian Sense of Humor
abstract: The Berlin-based Canadian songwriter, who has taken the Internet by storm, plays his first American show tonight.
lead_paragraph: Who on earth would blend a “Bennie and the Jets” groove, trilling harpsichords evoking the Beatles’ “In My Life” and a dance-floor-quaking bass into an exuberant paean to infidelity? Answer: Sway Clarke II. The song, “Secret Garden,” is one of several by the Berlin-by-way-of-Toronto singer-songwriter that have taken off on the Internet (another is a moody cover of Kendrick Lamar’s “Swimming Pools”) and propelled the singer (who plays his first American show this evening at Bardot’s School Night in Los Angeles) to next-big-thing status. His combination of storytelling and hooks has earned comparisons to the hitmaking likes of Lorde and Frank Ocean, but a streak of naughty humor, often at the singer’s own expense, is uniquely his own. “That comes out of being Canadian,” he laughs. “There’s a reason why great comedians like Jim Carrey and Mike Myers came from Canada. It’s in our DNA to be self-deprecating and funny.”

headline: Sweet Rides and Good Vibes at an Underground Biker Rally in the Motor City
abstract: These photos document the surreal scene at a weekly gathering in East Detroit that has been steadily growing through word of mouth over the last decade.
lead_paragraph: Every Sunday for the past decade, people have been gathering in a sparse corner of East Detroit for an ad hoc bike rally and block party that has grown solely through word of mouth. The event grew out of jam sessions held in a small shed called John’s Carpet Shack that featured local blues and jazz musicians including Otis Williams, the last surviving member of the Temptations. After the organizer, John Estes, passed away and the property burned down in 2008, the event moved to a vacant lot across the street. Since then it has grown into its current form, drawing people from all over Michigan to eat, drink, listen to bands and show off their cars and motorcycles, while organizers, including neighborhood resident Pete Barrow (a.k.a. Big Time Pete), who nominally runs things now, wend their way through the crowd with collection plates. On July 22, police shut down the event for the first time, citing a lack of permits. These pictures were taken a few weeks earlier.

headline: The Injustice of Marijuana Arrests
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Series', 'Editorials', 'Police', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The costs of criminalization: billions of dollars spent on law enforcement and lives destroyed by harsh penalties.
lead_paragraph: America’s four-decade war on drugs is responsible for many casualties, but the criminalization of marijuana has been perhaps the most destructive part of that war. The toll can be measured in dollars — billions of which are thrown away each year in the aggressive enforcement of pointless laws. It can be measured in years — whether wasted behind bars or stolen from a child who grows up fatherless. And it can be measured in lives — those damaged if not destroyed by the shockingly harsh consequences that can follow even the most minor offenses.

The store, once thriving, was closing its doors. The stacks had been picked over, and all that remained were some used cookbooks and a smattering of other genres. I have had moments in used bookstores when I feel destiny pushing me toward an obscure title, but that day I felt nothing, no sign or vibration coming from any of the odd, unwanted books. But because Cornelia was a new friend and had driven me into the city to show me this store that she hadn’t known was going out of business, I grabbed a beat-up biography of Margaret Mead and took it to the counter.

headline: Iran: Muslims Seek American’s Release
abstract: Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent incarcerated in Tehran for nearly three years, spent his 31st birthday in prison on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Amir Hekmati, an American of Iranian descent incarcerated in Tehran for nearly three years, spent his 31st birthday in prison on Monday, despite new pleas to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei for his compassionate release sent from prominent Muslim American figures in his home state, Michigan. Letters from the Michigan chapter of the Council on American Islamic Relations and from the Imams’ Council of the Michigan Muslim Community Council, released by Mr. Hekmati’s family, beseeched the ayatollah to grant Mr. Hekmati a pardon, invoking the tradition of mercy associated with the end of the Ramadan holiday. It is unclear whether Ayatollah Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, has seen the letters. Mr. Hekmati, a former Marine from Flint, was arrested in 2011 while visiting relatives in Iran for the first time. He was tried and sentenced to death for espionage, but the verdict was overturned and he was later convicted of cooperation with a hostile government — the United States — and given a 10-year sentence. Iranian prosecutors have never explained the substance of their case, and Mr. Hekmati and his family have said he is innocent of any wrongdoing.

headline: What Is Chris Christie Doing in Iowa?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The same thing as Rick Perry, Scott Walker and Bobby Jindal: Talking about how much he loves Iowa!
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Chris Christie was standing in the parking lot of MJ’s Restaurant, in Marion, Iowa, holding a news conference. Earlier that day, a Malaysia Airlines jet had been shot down in Ukraine; Israel was launching its ground invasion into Gaza. And here was Christie — a tell-it-like-it-is, straight-talking, no-nonsense Jersey guy — telling about 60 members of the media what he really thought. “Governor Branstad is a role model for me,” Christie gushed, referring to his 67-year-old counterpart from Iowa. Terry Branstad, who is seeking his sixth term in November, is hoping to become the longest-serving governor in the nation’s history. And Christie — who referred to Branstad as a “dear friend,” a “legend” and someone who embodies “what public service is all about” — hoped to perpetuate his dynasty. In fact, he even offered to return to Iowa, over and over, “as often as Governor Branstad wants me to.”

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on the costs of criminalizing pot, signing a disability treaty, changing the Redskins name and domestic violence in Israel.
lead_paragraph: “America’s four-decade war on drugs is responsible for many casualties,” writes Jesse Wegman for The New York Times, “but the criminalization of marijuana has been perhaps the most destructive part of that war.” The measure of that destruction can be estimated in billions of dollars, “thrown away each year in the aggressive enforcement of pointless laws,” and in years, “whether wasted behind bars or stolen from a child who grows up fatherless.” Decriminalizing marijuana use at the federal level will, first, eliminate “costly, futile” policing programs and enforcement laws that, each year, cost American taxpayers “more than $3.6 billion.” Second, it is an important step forward in resolving racial disparity in arrests and mass incarceration: “The war on drugs aims its firepower overwhelmingly at African-Americans on the street, while white users smoke safely behind closed doors.” And third, it offers an opportunity for state lawmakers to roll back the psychological and social damage already inflicted on drug offenders, such as sealing records of drug convictions in order to “make it easier for defendants to get jobs and housing after a conviction.”

headline: The Cuckoo Bird and the Baby

lead_paragraph: Typically when I experience a bout of insomnia, which fortunately isn’t that often, I’ll switch on my laptop and start trolling the Internet for animal videos — cats jumping in boxes, goats screaming like humans, sheep jumping over fences — whatever I can find to distract myself until I fall back to sleep.

headline: A Health Trade-Off That’s Here to Stay: Lower Cost, Limited Choice
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Regulators are addressing consumer complaints about too few doctors on their plans, but economic logic suggests narrow networks will endure.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally, there were a few ways that health insurers could keep premiums low for individual health plans. They could select people with no prior health problems, to limit the chances of getting stuck with big hospital bills. They could pare back the services and products they offered to avoid ones that could be expensive, like maternity care or prescription drugs. They could increase premiums or deductibles so their customers would pay a larger share of any eventual bills.

headline: 1964: 65 Sentenced Over Revolt
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Participants of a failed revolt are sent to prison in Portugal in 1964.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — The biggest political trial of Premier Antonio Salazar’s regime ended today with the sentencing of 65 people to prison terms ranging from 17 months to ten years for involvement in an abortive revolt on Jan. 1, 1962. Seventeen people were acquitted. The state charged that the rebellion was planned by former Gen. Humberto Delgado — defeated candidate in the 1958 presidential election and now regarded as the leader abroad of opposition to the regime. The state said Manuel Serra, a former merchant-navy officer who drew a ten-year term, helped organize the plot. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 30, 1964

abstract: It’s understandable if MetLife objects to being labeled a systemically important financial institution, an action that’s likely later this week. But public disputes with regulators are never advisable, Rob Cox writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Quick, who’s the chief executive of MetLife? That the name Steve Kandarian doesn’t roll off the tongue for almost anyone who isn’t deeply steeped in the insurance business is probably a good thing for MetLife’s shareholders. How he handles his company’s inevitable designation later this week as a systemic threat to the financial industry could change that. A Jamie Dimon-style public spat with regulators would be foolish. Better to speak softly, and keep his relative anonymity intact.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking

This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar discuss how these and other events happening abroad could affect U.S. economic growth. Plus, more U.S. corporations are rushing to “invert,” or incorporate in another country with lower tax rates. Could this spate of inversions inspire Congress to change the tax code?

lead_paragraph: From her 1200-acre farm in the Champlain Valley of Vermont, Tata Harper has built a beauty empire. The Colombian-born entrepreneur’s cult organic skincare and aromatherapy products, many made with herbs grown on site, are stocked everywhere from J.Crew to the world’s best boutiques. In August, she’ll launch her first color cosmetics product, Volumizing Lip and Cheek Tint, in three shades. Whether Harper’s radiant glow can be chalked up to her all-natural products or the benefits of rural living, the woman may be her own best advertisement. Just in time for the lazy days of late summer, when urbanites crowd the region’s verdant hills and valleys, Harper shares with T her most inspiring destinations for shopping, dining and relaxing around the Green Mountain State.

headline: In Paris, a Playful Path Along the Seine
abstract: A 1.4-mile pedestrian promenade, opened in June 2013, is packed with recreational activities, restaurants and bars and patches of flowers, plants and trees.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Voies sur Berges along the Seine on Paris’s Left Bank was one of the busiest two-lane thoroughfares in the city, with up to 2,200 vehicles passing through an hour. But on a warm afternoon in June, a different scene unfolded on the roadway. Along the water’s edge, a group of children could be heard singing “Joyeux Anniversaire” out of a large white tepee, while a glimpse into the canvas structure revealed a woman holding a candlelit birthday cake.

headline: In a Singapore Neighborhood, Gritty Mixes With Trendy
abstract: Jalan Besar, known for its divey karaoke bars and cheap hotels, has recently lured design stores and hip coffee shops.
lead_paragraph: At first, it was the smell that kept people away. In the mid-19th century, farmers in Singapore’s Jalan Besar neighborhood used night soil (human waste) to fertilize their vegetable plots, prompting residents to give the main road the tongue-in-cheek name Lavender — still the name today. Jalan Besar has been on the gritty side of gleaming Singapore ever since, known primarily for its divey karaoke bars, cheap hotels and hardware shops. Lately, however, its low rents have lured design stores, trendy coffee shops and the beautifully restored Kam Leng Hotel. With a new metro line set to open in 2017, residents are bracing for the coming real estate boom.

headline: Elephants, My Brother and Me
abstract: Remembering an adventurous trip to an elephant festival in Thailand, one of the last vacations the author took with her brother.
lead_paragraph: The elephant didn’t seem particularly confused. It was merely curious. That was the only way to make sense of why, as it meandered down a street in a remote village in Thailand, it had chosen to stick its sizable head into the lobby of the no-frills hotel that I was grudgingly using as my base. My brother Michael and I exchanged glances and smiled.

headline: To Fully Appreciate Frozen Dumplings, I Learned to Make Them by Hand

lead_paragraph: While exploring the rise of refrigeration in China for last weekend’s magazine, I spent an entire day chatting with Chen Zemin, the former surgeon who invented the frozen dumpling in China. During my visit with Zemin, I tasted exotic dumpling flavors of the future and admired a roomful of high-tech machines that fill, pinch and fold dumplings in automated, origami-like fashion.

headline: The Right, the Rich and Reciprocity
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Poverty', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Welfare (US)']
abstract: The conservative vision for the welfare state wouldn’t only impose contractual burdens on the poor.
lead_paragraph: From the pundit’s perspective, the best thing about Paul Ryan’s new proposals on poverty is the way they’ve surfaced some very interesting debates about the welfare state, debates that tend to go underground when anti-poverty spending is just being discussed in the context of the overall fiscal picture and the quest (or not) for a balanced budget. In particular, it’s been interesting to watch Ryan’s liberal critics train so much fire at his blueprint’s support (not as a universal requirement, as I understand it, but as a potential model for states to follow) for a contractual approach to anti-poverty spending, in which beneficiaries draw up customized life plans, set goals and targets, and have rewards and penalties pegged to their follow-through on those responsibilities. The liberal critiques of this idea, from writers like Annie Lowrey and Jamelle Bouie among many others, have been genuinely informative: I feel (sincerely!) like I have a better handle on the left-of-center view of poverty and anti-poverty policy than I did a week ago, and hopefully my future posts on the subject will profit from that advance in understanding.

lead_paragraph: If, as the disco act Indeep once sang, D.J.’s can save lives, then Harvey Bassett might be classified as sort of an elite ER surgeon of the profession. A music connoisseur’s music connoisseur, the British-born turntablist known as DJ Harvey has spent four decades collecting records and is frequently flown around the world to play them. A teenage punk rocker turned fixture of the U.K. dance-party scene in the ’80s and ’90s, Bassett has in recent years returned to making his own music (the house-centric album Locussolus, the genre-blending collaboration Map of Africa). His latest project, Wildest Dreams, releases its self-titled debut on Smalltown Supersound today. Its lo-fi psychedelic rock songs were inspired by the mood of Los Angeles and Bassett’s nostalgia for his garage-band youth. “It sounds like the music I was making 40 years ago when I was 11 years old and we wanted to be like Cream or the Jimi Hendrix Experience,” he says. A track from the album, “Rollerskates,” appears here.

headline: Massachusetts: Lawmakers Finalize Bill Aimed at Protesters Outside Abortion Clinics
abstract: The bill would allow the police to disperse an assembly of one or more that “substantially impedes” passage to a clinic entrance.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on Tuesday finalized legislation intended to prevent demonstrators from hindering patients and employees who are entering abortion clinics. The bill, proposed after the United States Supreme Court struck down a state law that barred demonstrators from standing less than 35 feet from a clinic entrance, would allow the police to disperse an assembly of one or more that “substantially impedes” passage to a clinic entrance. It would also require those individuals to stay 25 feet away from the entrance for, at most, eight hours after a dispersal order. The bill would also expand the suite of civil actions the state could take if the law was violated. The bill was sent to Gov. Deval Patrick, a Democrat, who was expected to sign it.

headline: Suit Filed Against N.H.L.

Jon Rohloff, a defenseman for the Boston Bruins from 1994 to 1997, is the lone named plaintiff in the suit, which was filed in United States District Court in Minnesota. The suit says that the league concealed the dangers of concussion and did not pass rules designed to reduce the risk of brain injury until recent seasons. N.H.L. representatives did not respond to a request for comment late Tuesday afternoon. After a similar suit was filed in April, Bill Daly, the deputy commissioner, said, “We are completely satisfied with our record on player safety, including as it relates to head injuries and brain trauma.”

It said the improvements at the site, the Sohae Satellite Launching Station, near the border with China, suggested that North Korea intended to launch “larger rockets with greater ranges and payloads.” The report, published on the institute’s website, 38north, was the latest indication that North Korea was moving toward another launching at Sohae, where it successfully fired a long-range missile in December 2012 that reached as far as the Philippines.

headline: Stealth Single Payer
abstract: Obamacare: not just the exchanges.
lead_paragraph: The Kaiser Family Foundation has a new survey (pdf) on Obamacare in California, and it’s full of remarkably good news. It was also a place that really needed reform: the uninsured were a high percentage of the population, and an individual market without community rating meant that the mere hint of a preexisting condition was enough to prevent coverage.

headline: A Taste of Barcelona’s Evolving Dining Scene
abstract: While restaurants take a more casual, accessible approach, creativity still sparkles on the plate.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that dining out in Barcelona means bouncing from one Michelin-starred restaurant to the next, with chefs like Ferran and Albert Adrià and Albert Raurich leading the way. But as the Spanish economy has suffered in recent years, the fine-dining scene has hit its share of road bumps. Tourism, in large part, has been able to sustain many of the great temples of Spanish cuisine, though not all have survived. Can Fabes, a restaurant outside of Barcelona that earned three Michelin stars every year from 1994 to 2011, closed in August, while Madrid’s two-star restaurant Sergi Arola Gastro closed months before, after owing back taxes (though it has since reopened). Albert Adrià has even gone as far as to say that “the high gastronomy formula doesn’t work now.”

abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson bars vice presidency to Kennedy in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson’s swift and final dumping of Robert F. Kennedy tonight [July 30] was a bitter blow to the attorney general that brought to an end a gay and glittering era that became known as ‘‘the New Frontier.’’ It really ended with an assassin’s bullet in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963. But it had been kept alive in the person of Robert Kennedy, the brother of the slain President. Tonight, just an hour after Mr. Johnson had abruptly ruled him out of the vice-presidential nomination, the attorney general issued a terse statement saying ‘‘it is the President’s responsibility to make known his choice.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 31, 1964

headline: Libertarians and Reformers
abstract: Two ideological tendencies and their respective perils.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column divided American conservatism’s would-be populist reformers into two camps, “reform conservatives” and “libertarian populists,” and tried to briefly describe the overlap and distinctions between the two. I’ve made this distinction before, and like any binary it’s in some sense artificial: You could easily fold both groups into a broad reformist tendency, or disaggregate them further into smaller camps. But I do think the typology is pretty useful, for various reasons — one of which is that it helps clarify two of the gravitational pulls (from very different directions) that today’s conservative reformers need to at least partially escape.

headline: Finding Art That Speaks to You
abstract: If you have blank walls and no idea how to fill them, there’s a service to put you in touch with your inner art connoisseur.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know much about contemporary art, but I know what I like. Actually, I don’t really know what I like. ArtKapsule, a London service co-founded by Elaine Ronson that recently extended to New York, is for people like me, with blank walls and exhaustingly endless possibilities. For a $250 consultation fee, I first received a questionnaire designed to reveal my taste. Then, Ms. Ronson, a delightful Glaswegian, and one of her consultants, Wayne Northcross, came to my home, looked around and chatted with me about my needs and $5,000 budget. They showed me about 45 images of contemporary artworks. “We want you to look at the art and imagine that it’s a shape-shifting alien who’s desperately trying to communicate with you, but it’s using means that are beyond any language that you’ve ever encountered before,” Ms. Ronson said. Her point was that if you know a piece is trying to tell you something, you’ll strain every sense to understand it. Instantly, I went from feeling that contemporary art thinks it’s better than I am to feeling it was trying to embrace me.

headline: Weave to the Beat
keywords: ['Textiles', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Music', 'Knitting and Knit Goods', 'Art']
abstract: A tapestry based on a Rachmaninoff concerto inspires new pillows and scarves.
lead_paragraph: It was while she was earning a degree in textile design that Nadia-Anne Ricketts discovered a connection between music and weaving. “When I used to weave, it felt like I was playing a piano,” said Ms. Ricketts, the founder of BeatWoven, a London textile company. “I realized that it was very similar in terms of counting, and the mathematics.” Working with the help of a software designer, Ms. Ricketts developed a computer program to translate audio patterns into woven ones. The result, she said, “looks like a sound wave, but it’s been granulated.”

Soft contours, metallic glimmers and lush velvet are features of his seven chair and five banquette styles. The collection also includes mirrors, mosaics and a copper statue of a Georgian aristocrat.

headline: Everyone Into the Kitchen
abstract: Johnny Grey, a celebrated kitchen designer, on strategies for making food preparation more sociable.

headline: The Looks of Summer
abstract: Girls in their summer dresses stride on. Even if those dresses these days can be a bit of a mishmash.
lead_paragraph: Many people regard the Irwin Shaw 1939 short story, “Girls in Their Summer Dresses,” through the haze of affectionate nostalgia, but its plot is really quite devastating. A young married couple, Frances and Michael, take a post-breakfast walk down lower Fifth Avenue that soon goes south metaphorically as well when she observes him checking out other women. They repair to a bar and knock back three glasses of brandy apiece while the husband, prodded by his wife, expounds on his greed for the bountiful “picnic” of female pulchritude on display in New York and she cries hopelessly. Seventy-five years after that story was first published in The New Yorker, a descendant of the Brevoort, where the couple lived, still stands. But their argument would probably play out not over Courvoisier but coffee with hearts etched into the foam on top, or complicated green juices. If Michael’s leers turned into actual overtures, he might be excoriated on Twitter for street harassment (#HollaBack); safer to examine his quarry on Tinder instead. Frances might be too engrossed in her own iPhone to even notice.

It said that problems stemming from the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty were “not new” and that Russia also had concerns about American weapons tests, including of missile defense systems slated for deployment in Poland and Romania, as well as armed drones. headline: Libya: Benghazi March Protests Militias

abstract: Residents of the eastern city of Benghazi marched Wednesday in protest against Islamist militias, the city’s dominant force for years.
lead_paragraph: Residents of the eastern city of Benghazi marched Wednesday in protest against Islamist militias, the city’s dominant force for years, in a burst of public fury a day after the Islamist fighters seized a local special forces base. Residents marched to a hospital, temporarily routing fighters from the extremist militia Ansar al-Shariah, who had been providing security for the hospital. But the militiamen fired on the civilians when they tried to approach the special forces base, scattering the demonstrations. Protesters said they were especially angered after the leader of Ansar al-Shariah declared Wednesday on the radio that Benghazi was an “Islamic emirate.” Violence in Libya has sharply escalated in recent weeks, in Benghazi and in the capital, Tripoli, where rival militias have been fighting for control of the international airport. Several countries have closed their diplomatic missions, and thousands of Libyans have fled to neighboring Tunisia in recent days.

headline: With Time Dwindling to Make Trade, Yankees Show They Need Help

headline: Décor at Gracie Mansion Now Fits de Blasio’s Style

headline: ‘Pension Smoothing’: The Gimmick Both Parties in Congress Love
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Both Republicans and Democrats will vote for a policy that pretends to raise revenue; they only disagree on how to spend the proceeds.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Highway Trust Fund is set to run out of money. If Congress does not put more money in the fund by Friday, the federal government will start reducing its payments to states for highway projects, and some construction might stop. So the House and Senate are fighting over how to get money in the fund, and the fight has boiled down to “pension smoothing,” a budgetary gimmick worthy of Rube Goldberg.

headline: The Kids Who Beat Autism
abstract: New research suggests that one in 10 autistic children sheds symptoms before adulthood. But no one knows why they do — or why others do not.
lead_paragraph: At first, everything about L.'s baby boy seemed normal. He met every developmental milestone and delighted in every discovery. But at around 12 months, B. seemed to regress, and by age 2, he had fully retreated into his own world. He no longer made eye contact, no longer seemed to hear, no longer seemed to understand the random words he sometimes spoke. His easygoing manner gave way to tantrums and head-banging. “He had been this happy, happy little guy,” L. said. “All of a sudden, he was just fading away, falling apart. I can’t even describe my sadness. It was unbearable.” More than anything in the world, L. wanted her warm and exuberant boy back.

headline: Digital Photography: A Look Back
abstract: Twenty-five years ago – before people were texting and taking pictures with their cellphones – the future of photography was explored at a workshop where photographers encountered early digital tools.
lead_paragraph: I was there when the first shots were fired in the Photographic Digital Revolution. There were no rifles 25 years ago on Martha’s Vineyard, but there were strange-looking prototype cameras that captured images with small sensors and saved them on floppy disks.

But separate figures showing a drop in unemployment provided some reassurance that the region was not yet on the brink of a destructive downward price spiral.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on pot science, Putin in a corner, real reform in Iran, brown lawns in California and unrest in Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Federal law enforcement policies on marijuana use are out of step with scientific consensus, writes Philip M. Boffey for The New York Times. “Marijuana is far less harmful to human health than most banned drugs and is less dangerous than the highly addictive but perfectly legal substances known as alcohol and tobacco.” Mr. Boffey concedes that marijuana isn’t an entirely harmless substance: “The potency of current strains may shock those who haven’t tried it for decades, particularly when ingested as food. It can produce a serious dependency, and constant use would interfere with job and school performance. It needs to be kept out of the hands of minors.” But on balance, “its downsides are not reasons to impose criminal penalties on its possession, particularly not in a society that permits nicotine use and celebrates drinking.”

headline: Recalling the Horror of the Flight 17 Crash Site
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'News and News Media', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: Sabrina Tavernise discusses the experience of reporting on the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash.

She was one of the first journalists to arrive at the scene of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 crash. This week, she is back at home in Washington, D.C. We asked her about the challenges of reporting on the crash.

headline: Yee-Ha! Space Cowboy Rides to the Rescue
abstract: “Guardians of the Galaxy,” starring Chris Pratt, is one of those interstellar westerns about a motley group of appealing baddies who rise to the occasion.
lead_paragraph: Talking about directing in blockbusters is sometimes nothing more than wishful thinking. Most are such impersonally operated machines — dedicated to the business of brand storytelling — that they tend to obliterate any whisper of individuality. That there’s a palpable directorial sensibility in “Guardians of the Galaxy,” along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons. Here, a pulse, wit, beauty and a real sensibility have been slipped into the fray, alongside the clockwork guffaws, kabooms and splats.

headline: An E-Commerce Emporium for Locally Made Goods

The problem was that people just didn’t know about them.”

headline: Making Work Fun Is Not About Table Tennis and Paintball
abstract: “How do you make shredding metal fun?” a chief executive asked. “For goodness’ sake, we are an industrial recycling plant.”
lead_paragraph: You know something that is often overlooked in business? Having fun at work. No, I am not talking about the make-believe fun of team-building exercises and paintball scrimmages and company picnics. Most of that is a waste of time. I’m talking about making the actual work fun so people take pleasure in doing it.

headline: Taking Your Teenagers to Kyoto

headline: 36 Hours in Green Bay, Wis.
abstract: There’s more to this town of 100,000 than just the Packers. Green Bay boasts everything from craft beer to a postcard-perfect amusement park to the National Railroad Museum.
lead_paragraph: Few cities evoke a single notion in the minds of locals and visitors alike as does Green Bay. This is Titletown, home for nearly a century to the Green Bay Packers, a place where streets are named Lombardi Avenue and Holmgren Way, after former Packers coaches. On Sundays during the fall, the streets empty out, as residents (the lucky ones) fill up Lambeau Field. The remaining six days of the week are spent discussing the game just played and sizing up the next. It’s hard to begrudge the city its love of its home team. Green Bay, with a population of 100,000, is by far the smallest metropolis to boast a professional football team, and the only one with a publicly owned franchise. The Packers are, indeed, Green Bay’s, and no one else’s.

headline: He Feels Good, Sometimes
abstract: “Get On Up,” directed by Tate Taylor (“The Help”), tells the story of the R&B and funk singer James Brown.
lead_paragraph: If musical genius is a gift randomly bestowed, it requires intense monomaniacal cultivation to reach fruition. Witness James Brown, a.k.a. “the hardest-working man in show business,” as portrayed indelibly by Chadwick Boseman in the viscerally explosive biopic “Get On Up.” A monumental egotist, perfectionist and harsh taskmaster with a streak of paranoia, Brown reigned as the absolute monarch of his personal kingdom, answering to no one but himself.

headline: Amy Bloom: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “Lucky Us” would like to invite Sappho, George Bernard Shaw and James Baldwin over for a literary dinner. “It’s not clear to me that everyone will get along.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “Lucky Us” would like to invite Sappho, George Bernard Shaw and James Baldwin over for a literary dinner. “It’s not clear to me that everyone will get along.”

abstract: Global Volunteers, a non-profit organization providing aid to communities around the world with the assistance of short-term vacationers, has launched International LGBT Volunteer Vacations, the first program of its kind in the volunteer-vacation field.
lead_paragraph: Global Volunteers, a non-profit organization providing aid to communities around the world with the assistance of short-term vacationers, has launched International LGBT Volunteer Vacations, the first volunteer vacation program directed specifically at L.G.B.T. travelers.

headline: Israel on Destruction of Gaza Tunnels
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, and Moshe Yaalon, the Israeli defense minister, discussed their efforts to complete the destruction of Gaza tunnels used by militants.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, and Moshe Yaalon, the Israeli defense minister, discussed their efforts to complete the destruction of Gaza tunnels used by militants.

headline: Feeling as if I Failed the Patient
abstract: I thought about the patient I had been treating for three years for leukemia. I would be seeing her in clinic in a few hours, and I had a bad feeling about her disease.
lead_paragraph: On bad nights, I jolt awake at 2 a.m. and settle in for what will be two hours of tossing and turning as I ponder the mundane (did I remember to pack a belt for the meeting I’m flying to in the morning?), the profound (will my children grow to be happy and contributing adults?), and the prophetic. On this night, I thought about the patient I had been treating for three years for leukemia. I would be seeing her in clinic in a few hours, and I had a bad feeling about her disease.

headline: Synchrony Shares Open Flat After Largest I.P.O. for Year
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Shares in Synchrony Financial, the retail finance unit being spun off by G.E., opened largely unchanged on Thursday after the firm raised about $2.9 billion in an initial offering.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Synchrony Financial, the North American retail finance unit being spun off by General Electric, opened largely unchanged on Thursday after it raised about $2.9 billion in its initial public offering.

headline: In Portugal, Central Bank Moves to Clean Up Banco Espírito Santo
abstract: The central bank moved to limit family control of the bank, after a staggering first-half loss, and ordered it to raise more funds.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Portugal’s central bank stepped up efforts to clean up the troubled lender Banco Espírito Santo and end its family control after the bank reported a stunning first-half loss of $4.8 billion that will force it to raise more capital.

headline: From Townhouse to TriBeCa, the Hard Way
abstract: Benjamin Berkman and Boji Wong overcame a few hurdles on the way to a new home.
lead_paragraph: As their family grew, Benjamin Berkman and Boji Wong knew they would need more space than they had in their two-bedroom Battery Park City condominium.

headline: On Eventful Day, the Action Begins With One Ace and Ends With Another
abstract: In a dizzying spree of moves before the nonwaiver trade deadline on Thursday, the A’s got Lester from Boston, while Detroit obtained David Price from Tampa Bay.
lead_paragraph: In one of the more dizzying days in recent baseball history, 12 deals involving 37 players were completed Thursday before the 4 p.m. deadline for trades without waivers. All-Stars and prospects and many players in between were on the move in a flurry of activity that could change the landscape of the pennant races.

headline: And the Moral of the Story Is: Keep It Positive
abstract: Do morality tales change children’s behavior? Research suggests that emphasizing the positive effects of honesty may, while tales of dire consequences fall on deaf ears.
lead_paragraph: The slower pace of summer means more time to tell stories to our kids, whether it’s around a campfire or in a car on the long, long trip to our vacation spot. We tell these stories for many reasons: to entertain, to pass the time, to share adventures from our own past. And sometimes we tell stories in order to make a point.

headline: Alda, Burnett, Dennehy and Farrow Among Roster of Stars for ‘Love Letters’
abstract: A Broadway revival of A.R. Gurney’s “Love Letters” is scheduled to open Sept. 13.
lead_paragraph: Alan Alda, Carol Burnett, Brian Dennehy, Mia Farrow, Diana Rigg, and Martin Sheen will be among the rotating actors this fall and winter in a Broadway revival of A.R. Gurney’s play “Love Letters,” which will begin performances Sept. 13 at the Nederlander Theater, the producers announced Thursday.

headline: Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert Take Aim at Tax Inversions
abstract: Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “The Colbert Report” mocked the growing trend of companies seeking to elude taxes through overseas mergers.
lead_paragraph: Comedy Central’s “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “The Colbert Report” mocked the growing trend of companies seeking to elude taxes through overseas mergers.

headline: Argentina Official on Failed Debt Talks
abstract: After debt talks collapsed, the economy minister of Argentina, Axel Kicillof, characterized the negotiations with an American hedge fund as extortion.
lead_paragraph: After debt talks collapsed, the economy minister of Argentina, Axel Kicillof, characterized the negotiations with an American hedge fund as extortion.

headline: A Panorama of After-Hours New York, From the Brooklyn Band Bear in Heaven
abstract: The art-rock ensemble’s video for “Time Between,” premiering exclusively at T, is the result of a month of filming late-night characters around Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: An error message on a friend’s broken TV set inspired the title of the band Bear in Heaven’s fourth album, “Time Is Over One Day Old” (out Aug. 5 on Dead Oceans). “The sentiment, and how it randomly came into our world, seemed connected to our state of mind at the time,” says Jon Philpot, the frontman. The album alternates between revving synths and drifting melodies, and between two lyrical ideas: outer space and inner travel. It’s an accessible brand of art rock that often gets the band compared to fellow Brooklynites like the National, Grizzly Bear and the Antlers. “We’re too weird for the straights and too straight for the weirds,” jokes the guitarist and bassist Adam Wills.

headline: Posthumous Album by Robin Gibb to Be Released
abstract: An album of unreleased songs by Robin Gibb will be released in September, compiled by his widow and his son.
lead_paragraph: An album of unreleased, and in some cases, unfinished songs by Robin Gibb – including his final song, written and recorded shortly before his death in 2012 – will be released in September. The album, called “50 St. Catherine’s Drive” (the address of the home on the Isle of Man where the singer was born in 1949) was compiled by Gibb’s widow, Dwina Murphy Gibb and his son R.J. (who co-wrote several of the songs),  the BBC reported.

headline: On the Border, Who Gets to Be a Refugee?
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Are the minors on the United States-Mexico border undocumented immigrants or refugees? It depends on what they’re running from.
lead_paragraph: A poll by the Public Religion Research Institute asked Americans whether they thought children illegally crossing the United States border from Mexico “should be treated as refugees and be allowed to stay.” Sixty-nine percent of respondents said “yes,” according to The New York Times’s Julia Preston, and “about a quarter of Americans in the survey, 27 percent, said the minors should be ‘treated as illegal immigrants’ and deported to their home countries.”

headline: Fortress Investment’s Results Are Buoyed by Private Equity Gains
abstract: The Fortress Investment Group, which manages a range of hedge funds and other strategies, said its distributable earnings rose 16 percent, to $172 million.
lead_paragraph: The Fortress Investment Group, a publicly traded alternative asset manager, said on Thursday that its second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, aided by sales of its private equity investments.

headline: Falling Glass From Midtown Office Tower Injures 3
abstract: Three people were hurt Thursday morning when a window shattered and fell from the 18th floor of an office building on West 57th Street at Avenue of the Americas.

headline: In Real Estate Listings Deal With Zillow, Trulia Bears Most of the Risk
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Trulia is at a significant competitive disadvantage while it waits to see whether its deal with Zillow will clear regulatory scrutiny, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The success of Zillow’s $3.5 billion acquisition of Trulia may depend not on an “and” but an “or” that the parties put in their acquisition agreement to deal with antitrust issues. Not only that, but the deal leaves Trulia the loser if the merger fails on antitrust grounds.

headline: Inquiry by C.I.A. Affirms It Spied on Senate Panel
abstract: A report by the agency’s inspector general also found that C.I.A. officers read the emails of the Senate investigators and sent a criminal referral to the Justice Department based on false information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An internal investigation by the C.I.A. has found that its officers penetrated a computer network used by the Senate Intelligence Committee in preparing its damning report on the C.I.A.’s detention and interrogation program.

headline: 1964: Rusk Bars Threat to Soviet Ties
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Secretary of State Dean Rusk vetoed a suggestion that the United States tried to extract ‘‘concessions’’ from the Soviet Union in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Dean Rusk vetoed firmly today a suggestion by Sen. Barry Goldwater that the United States try to extract ‘‘concessions’’ from the Soviet Union by threatening a break in diplomatic relations with Moscow. The United States does not and will not yield to ‘‘pressure or threats’’ when its vital interests are involved, Mr. Rusk said, and it would be ‘‘unrealistic’’ to think the Soviet Union might do so. Without mentioning the Arizona Republican presidential nominee by name, Mr. Rusk, who usually avoids partisan political issues, said he does not foresee any shifts in the near future in U.S. policies abroad. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 1, 1964

headline: Tell Me About Your Next Job
abstract: Jon Bischke, the chief of Entelo, a recruiting software platform, says that employees who think ahead do well at their current jobs.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Jon Bischke, the chief executive of Entelo, a recruiting software platform, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Requests for User Data Rise in Twitter’s Latest Transparency Report
abstract: Requests from governments around the world increased 46 percent since Twitter made its last bi-annual report.
lead_paragraph: Twitter on Thursday released its bi-annual transparency report, detailing the number of requests for information the company receives from government agencies around the world.

headline: Interpreting ‘The Maids’ Through a Shifting Societal Lens
abstract: Productions of Genet’s play “The Maids” have variously zeroed in on class, gender, race and, now, an obsession with celebrity.
lead_paragraph: Jean Genet’s creepy, sexy play “The Maids,” which had its premiere in 1947, has never gone out of fashion. But in the last several years, it has been riding a new wave of interest, with revivals in Europe and Canada and mash-ups like the Off Off Broadway ensemble Sister Sylvester’s forthcoming “The Maids’ The Maids,” whose cast, according to the company, will include two professional housekeepers.

headline: Sadistic Fantasy in a Fun House Mirror
abstract: Cate Blanchett and Isabelle Huppert reflect on their taxing roles as homicidal sisters in Genet’s 1947 play “The Maids,” opening at the Lincoln Center Festival.
lead_paragraph: It was a particularly brutal murder. In 1933, the French domestics Christine and Léa Papin killed the wife and daughter of their employer, gouging out their eyes while the women were still alive and knifing their thighs and buttocks.

headline: With Eyes on Seats in Maryland and West Virginia, Politicians Cross Borders
abstract: As congressional candidates take a chance on changing districts, and even states, to try to get elected, they raise the question of whether local ties even matter anymore.
lead_paragraph: CHARLES TOWN, W.Va. — Only 30 miles and the Potomac River separate this bedroom community in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains from Frederick, Maryland’s second-largest city.

headline: Protests Thwart Israeli Troupe at Edinburgh Festival
abstract: An Israeli theater company is seeking a new venue at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe after protests disrupted other shows.
lead_paragraph: A run of “The City,” a hip-hop musical being presented at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe by the Incubator Theater, a company based in Jerusalem, has been halted after one performance after protests on Wednesday. A demonstration organized by the Scottish Palestine Solidarity Campaign, reacting to the violence in Gaza, forced organizers at Underbelly, the presenting site, to call off the rest of the run there, saying the demonstration was disturbing other productions at nearby performance spaces.

headline: In Final Hours, Metropolitan Opera Extends Contract Deadlines for Unions
abstract: Hours after a mediator began work Thursday evening, the Metropolitan Opera granted a temporary deadline extension.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera postponed a threatened lockout late on Thursday night, saying that it had done so at the request of a federal mediator who was brought in at the 11th hour to try to salvage its contract negotiations with the unions representing its orchestra and chorus.

headline: 50 Shades of Blue, Green, Everything
abstract: “Kate Ericson & Mel Ziegler,” at Galerie Perrotin, surveys the work of a couple who shared a passion for color, taxonomy and the revelation of unseen patterns.
lead_paragraph: Art and adversity are old friends. When Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler, currently the subject of a poignant exhibition at Galerie Perrotin  on Madison Avenue, were starting out as artists, straitened circumstances meant they had to take house-painting jobs to pay the rent. They found themselves fascinated by houses, colors, even the names of colors: subjects that became the focus of a joint career that continued until Ms. Ericson’s death from brain cancer in 1995 at the age of 39.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Lawyers
abstract: Are legal apprenticeships a good way to avoid excessive law school debt and create different perspectives on the law?

headline: Li Out of U.S. Open With Knee Injury
abstract: A knee injury has sent Li Na’s season into a tailspin, including knocking her out of the final Grand Slam of the season.
lead_paragraph: Li Na started this year well, winning titles in Shenzhen, China, and at the Australian Open by the end of January. Shortly before her 32nd birthday in late February, Li reached a career-high No. 2 ranking.

headline: A Jaguar F-Type, Modified for Tour de France Duty
abstract: Jaguar sponsored the British Sky team in the Tour de France and modified one of its 550-horsepower F-Type coupes to serve as an unusual support car.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The team cars following the riders this month at the Tour de France were, for the most part, large and sensible station wagons. But there was one notable exception. During last Saturday’s time trial, as riders raced against the clock, the British Sky team appeared with a modified Jaguar F-Type coupe to carry its riders’ spare bikes and wheels.

headline: Tesla and Panasonic Agree to Build Factory in U.S.
abstract: The planned factory will produce batteries for Tesla’s all-electric vehicles, as well as modules designed for the stationary storage market, according to a news release from Tesla.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors announced on Thursday that it had an agreement with Panasonic to build a large-scale battery plant in the United States.

headline: Today in Small Business: Time to Give Raises?
abstract: Why entrepreneurs are heading to Canada. Big Brewers try to “hijack” craft beer. And a water-balloon device raises $645,000 on Kickstarter.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: F.D.A. Acts on Lab Tests Developed In-House
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said it felt the need to act to ensure the safety of home-brew test systems that are being developed and marketed widely.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Thursday that it would start regulating medical laboratory testing, saying that tests used to make important treatment decisions must be vetted and validated before they go into use.

headline: Keep the Met Open
abstract: Don’t shorten the season or rattle the opera lovers or scare away donors who spend a great deal of money and time sustaining the excellence of New York’s great opera house.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens in the bitter negotiations between unions and management at the Metropolitan Opera this week, here’s the bottom line: don’t shut the doors, even briefly.

headline: When the Fourth Wall Is Nature
abstract: Theater under the stars attracts all manner of unbidden, and unforgettable, human, creaturely and meteorological participation.
lead_paragraph: IN the final scene of the Public Theater’s production of “King Lear,” now in previews and opening on Tuesday at Shakespeare in the Park, the bereft Lear enters, bearing his dead daughter in his arms.

headline: Google Details Problems With Handling Right to Be Forgotten Requests
abstract: Google said that the company often had to rely only on information provided by the submitters, and that it struggled to decide whether the requests complied with Europe’s recent ruling.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Google says complying with Europe’s so-called right to be forgotten ruling is getting complicated.

headline: San Diego Symphony Names Chief Executive
abstract: Martha S. Gilmer, a mainstay in the administration of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will take over in San Diego in September.
lead_paragraph: The San Diego Symphony has appointed Martha S. Gilmer, for many years a mainstay in the administration of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, to be its chief executive, starting in September.

headline: What to See and Do in Montreal, From the Local Designer Arielle de Pinto
abstract: The Canadian designer with the global following shares her suggestions for shopping, dining and more in the Quebecois city.
lead_paragraph: The Montreal-based designer Arielle de Pinto has perhaps single-handedly made crochet cool again through her signature knitted metal jewelry and footwear, sold at such stores as Dover Street Market. And though she is not Québécois, the Toronto native moved to the poutine capital of the world in 2003 and by now is probably as close as any transplant can get to the real thing. With the Osheaga Festival happening this weekend and the Francophone capital’s fleeting summer in full swing, now is, she says, the perfect time to visit. “Montrealers save it all up in the winter and let it all out in the summer,” she says. “It’s two months of perpetual rejoicing.”

headline: More Polls in Arkansas, but No More Clarity on Senate Contest
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Almost all the polling in the state this year has been sponsored by partisan organizations, making it hard to know what’s really going on.
lead_paragraph: Arkansas is one of the states where we could really use more rigorous, nonpartisan polling. Three new polls came out this week, and they’ve done little to help clear things up.

headline: Wheelies: The Payload Policy Edition
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: G.M. says that it removes parts when calculating pickup truck payload capacity; Chrysler recalls 30,000 Fiat 500Ls.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Why Crucial Vaccines Are Sometimes Unavailable
abstract: An outbreak of a rare meningitis strain at Princeton drew attention to the fact that a vaccine for it existed — one not sold in America.
lead_paragraph: When cases of a potentially fatal strain of meningitis began cropping up at Princeton last year, university officials trying to stop its spread could recommend little beyond precautions like frequent handwashing and not sharing beverage containers.

headline: Inversions May Be the Least of U.S. Corporate Tax Issues
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Real Estate Investment Trusts', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Politicians are indignant over firms that move overseas — even when home-grown tax loopholes, like real estate investment trusts and master limited partnerships, are costlier, Christopher Swann of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: A couple of home-grown tax breaks in the United States are making inversions look like a diversion. The American authorities are letting Windstream designate its telecommunications cables as real estate, qualifying them for tax breaks. And a partnership will shield assets of the energy firm Hess from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Upstart French Telecom Iliad Bids $15 Billion for a Majority Stake in T-Mobile US
abstract: The move by Iliad, the fourth-largest cellphone operator in France, would be a huge test of its financial capabilities and comes as T-Mobile and Sprint continue discussions on a potential merger.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:14 p.m. | Sprint and T-Mobile US have been slowly dancing toward a $32 billion merger of the third- and fourth-largest cellphone operators in the United States. Now a French upstart wants to break in on the cozy couple.

headline: Grab a Seat, Prepare for the Sizzle
abstract: The Filipino menu at Lumpia Shack Snackbar in the West Village takes a step up from the food market.
lead_paragraph: Ears, jowls, belly. They come brined, blanched, shattered and fried, each tip blackened and alchemized, each pocket of fat approaching liquefaction. A raw yolk idles on top. Stab it and churn. This is sisig, the greatest pork hash — arguably greatest pork dish — on earth. Say the name with two flicks of the tongue, somewhere between a whisper and a hiss.

headline: Having More Than One Set of DNA Carries Legacy of Risk
abstract: Mosaicism is more common than once thought and can lead to diseases in the children of those with more than one genome, a study says.
lead_paragraph: The family seemed to defy the rules of genetics.

headline: Rebellion Inside G.O.P. Scuttles Vote on Border Bill
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A $659 million emergency spending measure to address the surge of young migrants was withdrawn, but leaders are expected to hold another meeting Friday morning to decide how to proceed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Conservatives in the House rebelled against their leadership on Thursday to scuttle an emergency spending measure that addressed the migrant crisis at the southern border, pushing the issue to a showdown on Friday as lawmakers prepared to leave for a five-week recess. The unexpected turmoil offered a coda to the dysfunction that has gripped the Capitol for much of the year.

headline: For Wings and a Prayer, and Maybe a Pint
abstract: There is a subset of restaurants in New York that cater specifically to people celebrating birth, mourning death and negotiating illness, all because of where they are.
lead_paragraph: IT was one of those crazy moments, my brother told me, when he wasn’t sure if he was hallucinating or receiving a sign from God. You have to know Greg to appreciate that the words “Jake’s Saloon” could be considered a divine message, but in this instance, it wasn’t the saloon invoking reverence. It was “Jake’s.” Because on July 2, Greg’s wife, Monica, gave birth to their son, Jacob Benjamin, whom they were thinking of calling Jake.

headline: Summer Treats in the Met’s European Galleries
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum has made a few changes that may beguile summer visitors, like hanging all 17 of its van Goghs together for the first time in over a decade.
lead_paragraph: Before 10 a.m. on a recent steamy morning, lines started forming up the front steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with visitors clutching New York City street maps waiting patiently for the doors to open.

headline: London Has Plans for Rowdy Drunks
abstract: People who repeatedly commit alcohol-related crimes will be forced to wear ankle tags that monitor their drinking, the mayor of London said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Londoners are getting a warning about engaging in alcohol-fueled escapades, which can be disorderly at best or cause serious injuries and criminal behavior at worst.

headline: Chief Says Discovery Communications Is Open to Deals
abstract: Discovery has been the target of much merger and acquisition speculation as a series of proposed megadeals threatens to reshape the television business.
lead_paragraph: With talk of deal-making gripping the media industry, the chief executive of Discovery Communications signaled on Thursday that his company was open to striking deals, particularly outside the United States, while also contending that the television group would be fine on its own.

headline: Summer Streets Program Begins in Manhattan
abstract: The annual Summer Streets celebration will stretch more than six miles across Manhattan, featuring a nine-hole miniature golf course, among other activities.
lead_paragraph: While the Miser enjoys a short vacation, let those of us left behind create our own staycation on the cheap, right here in our boiling but beloved asphalt jungle. This weekend, in fact, you can pretty much have an entire getaway right down the middle of Manhattan at the annual Summer Streets celebration.

headline: Inquiry Reveals Flaws in Training of Con Ed Workers
abstract: Scrutiny into a blast in East Harlem led the utility to say that most of the people it had trained to connect sections of plastic gas mains had failed to comply with safety regulations.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators have not yet announced the cause of a powerful explosion that leveled two buildings and killed eight people in East Harlem in March. But a follow-up inquiry by state regulators has exposed flaws in how Consolidated Edison trained workers who install the vast network of plastic pipes that carry natural gas under New York City’s streets.

headline: A Father-Son Fishing Trip on the Chesapeake Bay
abstract: Returning to the area where he grew up, the author joins his dad on a hunt for the treasured speckled trout.
lead_paragraph: The breeze came slow and easy out of the west, and the creek was glassy and calm as if it were just waking up, too. From the wharf in Onancock, a hamlet on Virginia’s Eastern Shore, the Onancock Creek courses for about five miles past stately homes and black water coves to empty in the Chesapeake Bay. Out there the waves would be less than a foot high, perfect conditions for our prey. “Those specks really like clear water,” said Bob Walter, a 58-year-old fishing guide everyone calls Captain Walt. My father, Bill Neville, stood next to him near the skiff’s center console as we motored downstream, the wake fracturing the sunlight into golden tesserae. The captain had been doing this for 43 years, and my father, who is in his 70s, has pretty much spent his entire life within whiffing distance of the bay. For as long as I can remember he has been chasing speckled trout.

headline: Zeroing In on the Female Traveler
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Women and Girls', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Single Persons']
abstract: A hotel package focuses on women without children. Could a trend be in the making?
lead_paragraph: Melissa Braverman, the marketing manager for the Westin New York Grand Central hotel, wanted to create a novel vacation package — a departure from the engagement and babymoon promotions that she helped dream up throughout her career, including a getaway for would-be parents known as the “procreation vacation.”

headline: The Richest Man, and His Mansion
abstract: An oil magnate’s fortune wouldn’t spark nearly as much excitement today as it did 50 years ago. His English estate, however, still fascinates.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “'Richest Man’ Label Irks Getty” appeared on July 30 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: The Reader as Artist, Intuitively Plumbing a Psychic Well
abstract: “What We See When We Read,” by the graphic artist Peter Mendelsund, explores the way we graft our own images onto the people and places we encounter in fiction.
lead_paragraph: Like a TED talk or a lesser Alain de Botton book, Peter Mendelsund’s “What We See When We Read” is friendly and shyly philosophical, filled with news you can almost use.

headline: A Tale in Pictures of Pictures
abstract: “Anne Collier,” a midcareer retrospective at Bard College, reveals sexist biases that have plagued the history of photography.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — In one of Anne Collier’s signature works, the photographic diptych “Woman With a Camera,” we see two stills of Faye Dunaway in the 1978 thriller “Eyes of Laura Mars.” Ms. Dunaway, playing a fashion photographer who has visions of murder scenes every time she tries to take a picture, is seen staring through her viewfinder and then lowering her camera with a look of horror.

headline: Reed Krakoff’s East Hampton Essentials
abstract: The fashion designer has a home there, and will open a three-day summer pop-up shop at Glenn Horowitz Bookseller on August 7.
lead_paragraph: For three days next week, Reed Krakoff will fill Glenn Horowitz Bookseller with items from his pre-fall 2014 and fall/winter 2014 collections. It comes as little surprise that the designer chose East Hampton for a summer pop-up; he and his wife Delphine have a home there, once owned by the Bouvier family, which they escape to this time of year. While in town, they often stop into the bookshop, which doubles as a gallery, “to view the latest exhibition, which I always find inspiring,” he says.

headline: A Toxic Menagerie
abstract: A conversation with Mark Siddall, the author of a new book about the ways in which animals use poisons — sometimes against humans.
lead_paragraph: Mark Siddall, the curator of the division of invertebrate biology at the American Museum of Natural History, has spent most of his career studying leeches and the chemicals they use to block the coagulation of blood from their prey. It is, he discovered, a deftly targeted toxicity.

headline: Writing His Own Tune
abstract: The pianist Jeremy Denk is at work on a book, a mix of memoir and thoughts about music tentatively titled “Every Good Boy Does Fine.”
lead_paragraph: This week, the pianist Jeremy Denk reviews Jan Swafford’s new biography of Beethoven. Denk, who has written for The New Yorker and blogs at Think Denk, is working on a book of his own for Random House, a mix of memoir and thoughts about music tentatively titled “Every Good Boy Does Fine.”

headline: Immortal Beloved
abstract: This biography of Beethoven is also a personal journey through his music and the Enlightenment-era ferment that shaped it.
lead_paragraph: In the show “30 Rock,” there was a running joke about tragedy. A character appears, reveals her tearful past, then brightly adds, “They made a Lifetime movie about me” — the credential of an absurdly pathetic story with a redemptive payoff. Of all the great composers’ lives, Ludwig van Beethoven’s seems the most made for Lifetime. The curtain opens on a difficult childhood: an abusive alcoholic father, a boy genius mocked for his dark skin. He survives, makes his way to Vienna for fame and fortune — only to be stricken by (gasp) deafness. In addition, we have impossible passions for mysterious beloveds, side themes of class struggle, freedom, individuality, the backdrop of Napoleonic conquest and a score (what a score!) surging with alternating storminess and tenderness. Beethoven’s story is almost too good to be true, and almost too bad to be television.

headline: Mr. Salinger’s Neighborhood
abstract: Thomas Beller views J. D. Salinger as a New York writer.
lead_paragraph: “J. D. Salinger: The Escape Artist,” by Thomas Beller, is a story of echoes. In this short, sensitive and irresistible biography, echoes ricochet from Salinger to Beller and back, bouncing off a word, a phrase, an accent, a memory, a chat with an acquaintance. Beller grew up in Salinger’s far-reaching shadow, that cool, shady place so many kids have discovered in “The Catcher in the Rye”: the overwhelming relief of shared anxiety. He also grew up in New York. The sidewalks, the gravel paths of Central Park, the elevators and white-tiled bathrooms that figure so prominently in Salinger’s work are part of Beller’s vocabulary, too. He writes about New York in both his fiction and nonfiction with intimacy and patience and wonder. New York City is a unifying theme in “J. D. Salinger,” almost as much as Salinger’s life itself, almost as much as Salinger’s work. It is in New York, the fictional, literary city and the actual city, where the two writers truly meet.

headline: A Distant Mirror
abstract: “The Invisible Bridge,” Rick Perlstein’s panoramic third volume about the rise of the modern conservative movement in America, covers the span of 1973 to 1976.
lead_paragraph: Next to the more apocalyptic spells of American history, the dismal span of 1973 to 1976 would seem a relative blip of national dyspepsia. A period that yielded the blandest of modern presidents, Gerald Ford — “a Ford, not a Lincoln,” as he circumspectly described himself — is not to be confused with cataclysmic eras like the Civil War, the Great Depression and the Vietnam ‘60s. The major mid-70s disruptions — the Watergate hearings and Richard Nixon’s abdication, Roe v. Wade, the frantic American evacuation of Saigon, stagflation, the dawn of the “energy crisis” (then a newly minted term) — were adulterated with a steady stream of manufactured crises and cheesy cultural phenomena. Americans suffered through the threat of killer bees, “Deep Throat,” the Symbionese Liberation Army, a national meat boycott, “The Exorcist,” Moonies and the punishing self-help racket est, to which a hustler named Werner Erhard (né Jack Rosenberg) attracted followers as diverse as the Yippie Jerry Rubin and the Apollo astronaut Buzz Aldrin. Even the hapless would-be presidential assassins of the Ford years, Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme and Sara Jane Moore, were B-list villains by our national standards of infamy.

lead_paragraph: “The Killing” returns on Friday for one last somber season, a six-episode coda on Netflix. The snakebit show was canceled twice by its original channel, AMC, the second time after a cliffhanger third-season finale in which the Seattle police detective Sarah Linden killed her lover — a fellow cop — when she figured out that he was a pedophilic serial killer. Thanks to Netflix, we get to find out what happens to Linden and her partner, Stephen Holder, in the aftermath.

He’d seen my memoir about our family and autism in the library and he wanted to know if I’d heard about a treatment that was getting remarkable results. headline: Turning Tables on Market Forces
abstract: The work of four 1960s artists from a divided Germany is recognized in “Living With Pop: A Reproduction of Capitalist Realism,” at two locations of Artists Space.
lead_paragraph: Circa 1960, Germany was newly rich, geographically split, mum about its recent past and churning out young artists by the score. Two of them, Gerhard Richter and Sigmar Polke, would go on to international celebrity. How they began that climb is the subject of a fascinatingly odd exhibition from Artists Space called “Living With Pop: A Reproduction of Capitalist Realism,” which has the distinction of being an art history survey with no art, or not the sort most museums would acknowledge.

lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, George Steinmetz, a photographer based in New Jersey, boarded a small helicopter with cameras in tow and spent several hours peering down on the rooftops of some privileged New Yorkers. (See the resulting photo essay here.) Steinmetz, who is more accustomed to taking pictures of the sandy vistas of the Sahara or the dunescapes of Brazil, recently discussed what it was like to pierce the privacy of Manhattan’s rooftop sunbathers and gardeners.
