headline: Agreeing to Accept and Move On
abstract: Releasing expectations and assumptions as a mother and daughter move on.
lead_paragraph: After my mother was told she had incurable cancer, she became obsessed with finding me a husband. One afternoon from her office, between negotiations for a client’s book contract, she called three times to tell me about a man my father had met who worked in a SoHo lamp store. My mother, a powerful publisher and literary agent who had championed Stephen King, now wanted to set me up with someone who sold lamps.

headline: Words With Friends
abstract: Addressing a husband’s gibes about romance, and other questions about roommate issues, well-meaning acquaintances and the parents of the happy couple.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have a good marriage; we’ve been true partners and best friends for nearly 15 years. But I can’t help noticing that when we’re at dinner parties, for instance, or out with friends, he often jokes about our sex life, implying that it’s boring or nonexistent. When I question him later, he insists that he was only joking. It’s true that many friends join him in this line of humor. But these jokes hurt my feelings. Should I make an issue of it or let it go?

headline: Fragments of History That Fit in a Pocket
abstract: For true shard collectors, the more interesting finds are in the weedier parts of the Northeast, where slag heaps and demolition debris survive from the long vanished factories that once thrived.
lead_paragraph: I HAVE been digging in the kinds of desolate spots where corpses turn up on crime shows. What I have turned up instead, fortunately, are fragments of the plentiful colored glass and molded ceramics that decorated the American skyline a century ago.

lead_paragraph: The advice from most mortgage professionals to first-time home buyers is to begin sprucing up their credit at least six months before applying for a loan. lead_paragraph: An Atlantic City homeowner who became known for fending off eminent domain, Donald J. Trump and his multimillion-dollar offers finally sold the property at auction on Thursday. The price was $530,000.

headline: Get Your Tootsy Frootsy TV Clips!
abstract: Shout! Factory’s “The Marx Brothers TV Collection” assembles separate appearances (for the most part), in series, commercials, skits and home movies.
lead_paragraph: Rich, strange and intermittently fascinating, Shout! Factory’s three-DVD set “The Marx Brothers TV Collection” follows Groucho, Chico and Harpo, or rather their well-known personae, through the decades that postscripted the brothers’ 1949 Hollywood swan song, “Love Happy.”

headline: Tom Friedman: ‘Paint and Styrofoam’
abstract: The artist Tom Friedman tends to blow our minds and then move on, rarely repeating himself.
lead_paragraph: The artist Tom Friedman tends to blow our minds and then move on, rarely repeating himself. (A starburst made of toothpicks or a realistic fly, having seemingly alighted on the corner of a pedestal, come to mind.) Nearly each artwork is some one-off feat of concept, technique and common materials. So it’s unexpected to see Mr. Friedman staying in one place as he does here and to realize that the effect is even more intense.

headline: Nancy Rubins: ‘Our Friend Fluid Metal’
abstract: For this show, Ms. Rubins has turned cast-aluminum playground animals into precarious-looking feats of artistic engineering.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Rubins’s sculpture comes out of the collage and assemblage tradition of artists like Kurt Schwitters, Robert Rauschenberg and John Chamberlain. In the 1980s she used salvaged appliances to make scruffy punk sculptures that occasionally raised the ire of viewers; later she worked with airplane parts and dozens of small boats to create pieces that are more streamlined and elegant.

headline: ‘The Intuitionists’ and ‘Small’
abstract: “The Intuitionists” presents a bewildering array of works; but a more engaging show, “Small,” awaits in a nearby gallery.
lead_paragraph: In 1977 the Drawing Center began a program in which aspiring artists could submit works to be seen by the center’s curators. Supplicants might be included in the center’s artist registry, and the luckiest would be featured in Selections, an often interesting series of new-talent shows.

headline: ‘New Hells’
abstract: In a world laid bare to technological scrutiny, a retreat to the psychological dark side seems like a smart idea, and that’s where “New Hells” goes.
lead_paragraph: In a world laid bare to technological scrutiny, a retreat to the psychological dark side seems like a smart idea, and that’s where “New Hells”, organized by Isaac Lyles, associate director of Derek Eller Gallery, goes. Declaredly pro-weird, the show is a maze of inscrutable references but has nicely sticky visual texture that keeps us looking even when we’re not sure what’s going on.

headline: To Russia With Love
abstract: On Love and Radio, the German amateur aviator Mathias Rust told the story of his unauthorized flight to Moscow in 1987 to build an “imaginary bridge” for peace between West and East.
lead_paragraph: The rocket attack on Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 killed 298 people and changed the geopolitical landscape. The United States and the European Union have responded with sanctions, while Russia continues to amass troops on its border with Ukraine.

headline: A World Without Pity Spawns a Fallen Son
abstract: James Franco is the director and co-writer of a screen adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s novel “Child of God.”
lead_paragraph: Make no mistake: There is nothing pleasant about “Child of God,” James Franco’s very fine adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s short, pitiless novel. But then, Mr. McCarthy is a bard of the apocalyptic who, in his unsparing period novel “Blood Meridian” writes that “war is the truest form of divination.” His is no country for old men, to borrow the title of one of his few books that have been turned into a successful film; neither is it a place for bromides about the triumph of the human spirit, one reason most of the screen adaptations have failed. There isn’t a war per se in “Child of God,” just good and (mostly) evil in a Christ story in reverse about a mystery who becomes a man.

headline: Kodak Moments, Deconstructed
abstract: “Christopher Williams: The Production Line of Happiness,” at the Museum of Modern Art, goes deep into the mechanics of creating the exhibition itself.
lead_paragraph: One of the most telling images in the Museum of Modern Art’s beautiful but demanding survey of the Conceptual photographer Christopher Williams represents an act of elegant iconoclasm. It lays bare something most of us rarely see: the guts of a camera’s lens. It is an amazing sight.

headline: Systematized Postmodernism
abstract: Abstract works using shapes and numbers are featured in “Charles Gaines: Gridwork 1974-1989,” at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The art of Charles Gaines is the opposite of hedonistic. Austere, cerebral, coldly formal and elliptically self-reflexive, it won’t play to viewers who look for sensual pleasure, emotional expression, imaginative fantasy and traditional craft in art. But if the history of postmodern theory is your thing, you should see “Charles Gaines: Gridwork 1974-1989,” at the Studio Museum in Harlem.

headline: Defending Their Worldly Possessions
abstract: As anyone who has ever tried to clean out a parent’s home knows, the process requires not just a firm hand, but extreme patience — and for some, an estate appraiser.
lead_paragraph: “This was your grandmother’s,” my mother said to me holding up a china teacup and delicate saucer, admiring its flowery Wedgwood pattern. “It’s very special.”

headline: The Steamy ‘Fifty Shades of Grey’ Trailer Deserves Some Answers
abstract: Nobody really cares about how realistic a portrayal of journalism or the business world “Fifty Shades of Grey” is going to be. What they want is relationship advice. Here it is.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the release of the “Fifty Shades of Grey” trailer, which opens with the gorgeous heroine interviewing a cool, controlling titan of industry who will ultimately initiate her into S&M, people have been asking me, “Is journalism really like that?” and I say, “Absolutely.”

headline: Holiday Visitor Who’s a Tough Sort of Gift
abstract: Joe Swanberg’s modest “Happy Christmas” is a serious comedy about marriage, parenthood and creative life.
lead_paragraph: What a pleasure it is to watch a film showing life as it is, not warped into a fantasy of superhuman power. You can feast on such realism in Richard Linklater’s seven-course masterpiece, “Boyhood,” or sample it in Joe Swanberg’s modest but savory amuse-bouche, “Happy Christmas.” Both films are portraits of white middle-class American families, the first set in Texas and stretching over 12 years, the second during a single Christmas holiday in Chicago.

headline: Forgive Me, Father, for I Must Sin
abstract: “Calvary,” John Michael McDonagh’s mordantly funny murder mystery, revolves around an Irish Roman Catholic priest.
lead_paragraph: The Anglo-Irish writer and director John Michael McDonagh opens his cold, mordantly funny murder mystery, “Calvary,” with a misleadingly pacific image: a close-up of the Irish actor Brendan Gleeson. An imposingly big man who’s often called on to suggest authority, Mr. Gleeson has played cops, criminals and Winston Churchill, and had the recurring role of Mad-Eye Moody in the Harry Potter series. In “Calvary,” he plays a world- and time-tested expert of another sort: Father James, a conscientious priest and widower whose faith isn’t shared by his flock, which includes a serial sinner, a hostile Buddhist, a dog hater and other furious souls, including one self-professed future executioner.

headline: Mrs. Obama Details Progress in Effort to End Homelessness Among Veterans
abstract: More than 180 mayors, governors and other leaders have joined the Obama administration’s effort to end homelessness among military veterans by the end of 2015, Ms. Obama said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: More than 180 mayors, governors and other leaders have joined the Obama administration’s effort to end homelessness among military veterans by the end of 2015, Michelle Obama said Thursday. Mrs. Obama, addressing the National Alliance to End Homelessness, said the military could set an example for American policy, as it did when it desegregated the armed forces. Mrs. Obama also wrote an op-ed on Thursday in which she said that nearly 100 of the local and state officials involved had pledged their support for the Mayors Challenge to End Veteran Homelessness in the last two months. Phoenix and Salt Lake City have already eliminated chronic homelessness among their veterans, and New Orleans is expected to do the same within six months, she said.

headline: The War on New York’s Waterfront
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Couldn’t some public money be found to save the South Street Seaport, arguably Manhattan’s last grand public space?
lead_paragraph: THE New York City waterfront has, as everyone and his uncle from New Jersey who’s visiting for the weekend knows, come back to life. Governors Island has sloughed off its dreary Coast Guard skin and now hosts everything from harbor swims to art exhibitions. Cyclists and boaters throng Hudson River Park, which, as of this summer, has its own floating oyster bar. Even actual living oysters, once driven from our waters by billions of gallons of raw sewage, are making a comeback thanks to the Clean Water Act.

abstract: A guide to street fairs, film festivals, literary events, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The City by Water  A boat ride is sometimes the best way to appreciate the full landscape of a city. On any given day, excursions are available on all kinds of boats to see a variety of sights, sample food and beverages, hear music or take in a burlesque show. Yes, a burlesque sail — for those 21 and older — on a tall ship is among the fare offered by Manhattan by Sail, with the next one scheduled for Aug. 14 at 9:45 p.m. (the cost is $28), leaving from Slip 2 in Battery Park, Lower Manhattan. Details: 212-619-6900, manhattanbysail.com.

headline: America’s Hidden Credit Card Bill
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Social Security (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: The federal government should have to report all its liabilities, like Social Security — not just the official debts.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — HOUSEHOLDS can’t spend, on a continuing basis, more than they earn. Countries can’t either, at least not over the long run. But countries can certainly leave the bill for their current spending to the young and to future generations. Official borrowing is the old-fashioned way to do this: Sell Treasury bonds, and other securities, and spend the proceeds. But borrowing in broad daylight has a drawback: The more you do it, the more lenders worry about repayment, and the more interest they charge for their loans.

headline: When Wheelchairs Are Cool
abstract: In an age of equal rights, is it ever O.K. to play the disability card?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — LAST week, the celebrity gossip site TMZ posted pictures of Justin Bieber in a wheelchair. He was not at a hospital. He was at Disneyland. As everyone knows, Disney patrons in wheelchairs get to cut to the front of the lines. But as a dispute flared over whether this was Mr. Bieber’s intent, becoming a trending topic on Twitter, one fact remained unassailable: I was there first.
